HEADLINE: Human Rights Treaty Deserves Criticism

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's allegation of a conspiracy by the financier George Soros to attack Malaysia's currency would indeed appear to be misplaced (news article, July 29), Dr. Mahathir's call for a retooling of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights is reasonable.
With some articles vague to the point of meaninglessness and others "entitling" people to more rights than those enjoyed in the most progressive nations, the declaration was flawed from the beginning. More important, the United States has itself never been in compliance with the treaty. 
 For example, its unemployed and underemployed citizens may want to consider pushing for enforcement of Article 23, which guarantees work, protection from unemployment and "equal pay for equal work."
Overworked Americans may be interested in reviewing Article 24, guaranteeing "rest and leisure." Millions of homeless Americans ought to press for fulfillment of Article 25, which not only requires governments to provide food, clothing, housing and medical care to their citizens but also calls for these items to be bundled into a guaranteed "standard of living."
 
DAVID J. DALY
Chicago, July 29, 1997

HEADLINE: As Bonn Fails at Tax Reform, German Businesses Study U.S.

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: NEUSTADT-WIED, Germany, July 31

 BODY:
The timing was a coincidence, but no less telling for that: just as United States lawmakers were preening over legislation to balance the budget and cut taxes, German politicians acknowledged failure early today in negotiations to streamline their land's burdensome system of taxation.
For people like Ralf Riba, who runs a small design company here that has taken an American cue -- not only by marketing 6 foot tall, 100 pound steel representations of the Empire State Building, but also by downsizing its staff and outsourcing work -- the implications were obvious. 
 "Medium-sized companies are still the motor of the German economy," he said. "And this has put the brakes on."
Indeed, across a spectrum from industry representatives to Government ministers, the assessment was gloomy. "The chance to make Germany more attractive in the international race for investment was frittered away," said the Economics Minister, Gunther Rexrodt.
Neither was the comparison with Washington lost on commentators.
"Two worlds," said the Frankfurter Allgemeine, a conservative daily. "With pragmatic common sense, the Americans presented themselves with a reduction of capital taxes to keep their economy on the upswing; in Germany, a tax reform that would have offered a realistic chance to the unemployed has collapsed on ideological divisions."
The German tax reform, which Chancellor Helmut Kohl labeled "the reform of the century," centered on a Government proposal to cut $16 billion worth of taxes, in part by lowering the top-end income tax rate from 53 percent to 39 percent and the starting rate from 25.9 percent to 15 percent. The Government proposal also foresaw a reduction of an income tax surcharge for the staggering costs of German reunification from 7.5 to 5.5 percent.
The aim was to encourage investment and thus stimulate jobs in an economy where unemployment exceeds one million people, or 11 percent of the work force.
The opposition Social Democrats, with a majority both in the upper house of Parliament and on the mediation committee that met for 15 hours on Wednesday, blocked the package, saying its terms favored the rich. Not only that, the opposition's own counterproposal to lower Germany's prohibitive labor costs in return for increases in the value-added tax and the fuel tax now seems certain to be voted down by the Government majority in the lower house.
The result: political paralysis and, according to Arnold Willemsen, a spokesman for the Federal Association of Germany Industry, "catastrophic implications" for Germany's record-level unemployment and "a signal to German investors to take their money abroad and to foreign investors to avoid Germany even more."
For Mr. Riba, 29, in his design office in this leafy backwater 25 miles south of Bonn, the tribulations seemed ominously familiar: It was a combination of high costs and global pressures that turned his family's business from a substantial manufacturer of clothing-industry machinery employing 70 workers to a modest studio with just two full-time employees -- a parable of German costs and complacency at a time of global economic change.
When its American marketing partner pulled out under disputed circumstances two and a half years ago, Mr. Riba said the company, founded in 1947, was left to fend for itself in a world that had changed radically.
The company's patented machinery designs, it turned out, had been copied in Poland and Greece, Mr. Riba said in an interview. The clothing industry had moved away from Germany because of high labor costs to places where it was cheaper -- Romania, Turkey, the former Yugoslavia and parts of southeast Asia.
"As Germans, we had been so arrogant," Mr. Riba said. "We ranked No. 2 in the world as exporters. But we lost sight of the world market and realized too late that our competitors had not been sitting still."
When the banks demanded repayment of loans worth some $800,000, the company -- Dipl. Ing. Riba G.m.b.H. -- was left with 26 full-time employees it could not afford to dismiss because of the high severance pay mandated by German law.
It declared bankruptcy last September, sold off manufacturing plants and office buildings and was reborn this year as Ralf Riba Design, with one small workshop, one rented design studio and two full-time employees -- Mr. Riba and an assistant. Start-up cost: $30,000.
Although Mr. Riba has never visited the United States, his formula seems a microcosm of American economic restructuring. In a land where social contributions devour 40 percent of gross salaries, he employs a designer and technical staff as freelancers so that he does not have to pay those outlays. Rather than maintain costly work space, Mr. Riba subcontracts labor to four independent shops.
"We don't want mass markets," he said. "We want niche markets for new ideas." Apart from the Empire State Building look-alikes, about 100 of which have been sold as decorative objects or CD racks for around $1,200 each, his company also produces a device to measure the conductivity of building materials, costing roughly $80,000 each. The future, he said, is in high-tech innovation.
Such thinking might be profitable in the United States. But in Germany, steep taxes and the world's highest labor costs inhibit companies like Mr. Riba's that simply are not big enough to transfer production plants abroad, as many bigger German companies have.
"It's worse for small companies than big ones," said Mr. Willemsen of the Federal Association of German Industry. "The big firms have made their investments abroad and even the bigger medium-sized firms have begun to move abroad. The smaller firms find this difficult. They stay here and remain under the tax-yoke. For them, there's no relief."

HEADLINE: Unexpected Fall In Jobless Claims

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
The number of workers applying for state unemployment benefits unexpectedly fell last week to the lowest level in more than 23 years, in a sign the United States job market continues to power ahead, Labor Department figures showed today.
First-time jobless claims fell 22,000, to a seasonally adjusted 277,000, in the week that ended last Saturday. In the previous week, claims declined 42,000, to 299,000. The latest figure was the lowest since Jan. 5, 1974, when claims stood at 269,000. Analysts had expected jobless claims to rise by 1,000 last week, to 300,000. 
 The four-week average for new jobless claims, a less volatile gauge of employment conditions than weekly numbers, fell to 325,750 from 340,750 the previous week.
Last week's decline could reflect quirks in adjusting claims for seasonal variations in the job market, a Labor Department spokesman said.

HEADLINE: Rescuing the District of Columbia

 BODY:
The District of Columbia's faltering aspirations to govern itself took a severe blow this week when Congress and the White House agreed to bail out the nation's capital from its financial crisis but at a stiff political price. The agreement would strip Washington D.C.'s Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr., and its City Council of many powers and turn them over to a financial control board that was created by Congress two years ago to handle an earlier fiscal debacle. Stripping elected officials of duties is always regrettable. But Congress could not turn over hundreds of millions of dollars to a city administration that is as incompetent as Marion Barry's.
The District's own (non-voting) representative in Congress, Eleanor Holmes Norton, was an author of the agreement and embraces many of its provisions. Those who wish the District well can only hope that the control board succeeds in putting the District on firm financial footing quickly, so that political control can be returned to the elected officials who should rightly wield it. 
 The District's huge financial shortfall is largely due to reasons beyond its control. Over 40 percent of its land is occupied by the Federal Government, which pays no taxes and makes only limited contributions instead. Congress also forbids the District to tax commuters, with the result that most of the income earned in the District goes untaxed and the whole tax burden falls on a relatively poor population. Unlike other cities, the District has no state government to pitch in and help out. Its population of transient politicians and suburban commuters provides skimpy community leadership.
But it is also true that the Barry administration and its predecessor were glaringly inept. A recent series in The Washington Post showed a city that suffers high rates of tuberculosis and other diseases, yet cannot figure out how to spend $90 million of available Federal grants to ameliorate the problems. The poor live in dilapidated housing, yet city agencies sit on tens of millions of dollars in unspent Federal housing grants. The city wastes hundreds of millions of dollars each year because it fails to collect taxes due or require competitive bids on city contracts. Over all, the city hires more workers and spends more money per resident than does any other city, yet potholes go unfilled and the fire department has limped along with just one of its 16 ladder trucks in working condition.
The new agreement would have the Federal Government take over a $5 billion pension shortfall and pay for the courts, a prison and some other parts of the criminal justice system. It would pump about $170 million more each year into the city's Medicaid program and grant residents and businesses large tax cuts. Next year alone the agreement would provide over $200 million in relief for the city. Over five years, the city will get almost $1 billion in additional aid. In return, Congress exacted stern measures of accountability. It gave more control to an already powerful financial control board, which will now control hiring for most city agencies. The board will also send in experts to overhaul the management of city agencies.
It is not possible to discuss the accord without tackling the problem of race. For decades the residents of the District, a majority of whom are black, were governed by Congressional committees run by Southern whites. Resentment remains, and Mayor Barry is tapping into it with charges that the agreement amounts to "recolonization." But the victims of the city's pathetic performance are its black as well as white residents.
Congress voted limited home rule for the District in 1973, and the District elected its first Mayor two years later. The new agreement does not so much trash the principle of home rule as bend it. The Mayor is kept in office and not in effect replaced with a city manager, as many in Congress proposed. But if control is returned to elected officials at the first possible moment, the agreement can be welcomed because it gives hope that the District will be a better place to live tomorrow than it is today.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Seven-Building Apartment Project Would End Rental Drought in Fort Lee

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A 351-unit apartment complex that will begin rising this fall a mile from the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee, N.J, will be the first new rental project in the community in 25 years. It is also the latest in a string of upscale rental projects its developer has built in the New York metropolitan area in the last eight years.
The developer, Avalon Properties of Wilton, Conn., with offices in Princeton, N.J., has 4,572 apartments in 13 properties in the region and 5,800 more apartments in 19 developments under way or planned. 
 Jeffrey B. Albert, an Avalon vice president, said his company concentrates solely on rentals. "While the overall housing market in the metropolitan area is tight," he said, "rentals do well on both sides of the economic picture because, whether by choice or necessity, people will rent."
The apartments at the Fort Lee project, Avalon Crest, will be in seven four-story buildings on 13 acres along Executive Drive, just off Route 4. They will have one to three bedrooms and 725 to 1,300 square feet of space, and some will have lofts. Rents will range from $1,300 to $2,200 a month.
Avalon was drawn to the site for several reasons. "It is one of the last large fallow pieces of land in the borough and is blessed with access to major highways and employment centers," Mr. Albert said. "It is also in a solid market where there is a dearth of rentals."
Avalon Crest will rise over the next two years on land originally planned for a 30-story office tower, part of a 600,000-square-foot, two-building office park. Avalon is under contract to buy the site for $9.5 million from the park's owner and expects to close on the purchase in November when construction is to start, Mr. Albert said.
Avalon, which became a real estate investment trust four years ago, enabling it to raise money through stock offerings, is financing the $54 million project. Prior to 1993, the company's executives were partners with Trammell Crow Residential, a development firm in Atlanta.
Fort Lee has many high-rise residential towers atop the cliffs of the Palisades. It was a focus of the conversion frenzy of the late 1970's and early 1980's when many of its rental units were converted into condominiums and cooperatives. Of the 11,000 housing units in the borough, there are just 1,000 rental apartments.
Large-scale rental construction is limited in most of New Jersey. Among the reasons are zoning constraints, the scarcity and high cost of land, and public resistance. Another factor is that rent control ordinances are in place in 115 of the state's 566 municipalities.
An exception to that pattern in the 18-mile Hudson River shoreline, where some 2,682 residences, most of them rentals, are under way or about to begin. Among them are a 276-unit project in West New York and two rental building totaling 786 units at Newport, the huge mixed-use center in Jersey City.
Getting the Avalon Crest site rezoned from commercial to residential use took a year and a half of negotiation with the borough and with the owners of Linwood Park, a 1,170-unit cooperative complex next to the new project.
Avalon initially proposed its new rental to include 525 apartments in three 10- to 14-story buildings. That design "would have boxed us in," said Michael W. Sanitmauro, president of the board of directors at Linwood Park, adding that the taller buildings would have blocked views and hurt property values.
Scaling back the project to its current size and moving the buildings farther away from their border with Linwood Park addresses those issues and "satisfies the needs of both parties," Mr. Sanitmauro said.
The rental vacancy rate is under 5 percent in Fort Lee, where the inventory also includes condominium and some cooperative apartments rented out by their owners, said Charles Oppler, a partner at Oppler-Ketive Realtors, a brokerage in Fort Lee. Even with new rental construction in the nearby waterfront town of Edgewater, the demand for rentals exceeds the supply, he said.
Consistent with its other developments, Avalon is designing the Fort Lee project with open apartment layouts and a high degree of amenities, from on-site management to recreation, Mr. Albert said.
All the apartments at Avalon Crest will have washers and dryers, and some will have fireplaces. Among the planned amenities are a club house, swimming pool and children's play area. There will also be garage and surface parking. Leasing will begin next summer, Mr. Albert said.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: A rendering of the Avalon Crest apartments, which will be just off Route 4 in Fort Lee. The four-story buildings will have a total of 351 units. (Avalon Properties)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
A Warning Light Largely Ignored in Thai Currency Crisis

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
The plunge in the Thai baht, followed by a wave of currency depreciations through South and Southeast Asia, illustrates the shortcomings of the international early-warning system set up after the Mexican peso crisis of 1994-95 to head off currency upheavals in emerging economies.
Over the last year, officials say, Thailand steadfastly resisted pressure from the International Monetary Fund and Western governments to take new steps to curb its current-account deficit, raise productivity, reduce short-term foreign borrowing and strengthen a creaky banking industry weighed down by speculative property loans. 
 In the meantime, foreign bankers and investors continued to pour money into the country, even though they knew that Thailand had an estimated $60 billion of foreign debt falling due but only $40 billion in foreign-exchange reserves.
Even after speculative pressure started building against the baht around February, Thailand refused to apply new economic measures or to seek I.M.F. assistance, saying that it could weather the storm with help from Asian neighbors.
And even after it was forced to effectively devalue the baht on July 2 -- by allowing it to float to market levels -- Bangkok waited until this past Monday before reluctantly accepting that the only way to restore confidence in its currency was to ask for an I.M.F. loan and accept whatever economic disciplines were imposed.
"Frankly, the early-warning system failed," said C. Fred Bergsten, a former Under Secretary of the Treasury, who heads the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "The Thais did not listen to the fund and the markets were very slow to send Bangkok warning signals, even though they knew there was trouble coming. The I.M.F. and the Group of Seven countries should have really put the heat on the Thais."
While pleased that Thailand has finally agreed to put its economy under their supervision, senior officials of the monetary fund remain angry that their warnings went unheeded so long and that officials in Bangkok refused to cooperate with the elaborate procedures put in place after the Mexican debacle.
In a speech in Jakarta in November, the I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus, warned that despite high growth rates, Southeast Asian countries faced "new challenges and risks" to their economic and financial stability.
"It had no effect beyond making the Asians angry," said a senior I.M.F. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "They thought they could manage on their own.
Then in June, after a highly critical review of its economic policies by the I.M.F. executive board, Thailand refused to allow publication of an account of the discussion under a procedure instituted the previous month intended to let financial markets know more quickly where the fund sees trouble brewing.
"That should tell you something: the Thais thumbed their nose at us all along," the I.M.F. official added, noting that the Thai delegation sent to Tokyo right after the devaluation returned empty-handed because Japan refused to help unless the Thais called in the monetary fund.
Under the early-warning system, emerging economies were urged to provide markets with much more information than in the past about their economic performance. At the first hint of trouble, the reasoning went, well-informed bankers would press them to take new measures or seek I.M.F. help.
At the same time, the fund vowed to increase its surveillance, keeping a hawk-like lookout for signs of weakness that could undermine their creditworthiness and cause a Mexican-style outflow of capital.
The I.M.F. also set up a World Wide Web site where countries can post their latest financial statistics. It arranged a big new pool of lendable funds to finance future bailouts, and streamlined its lending procedures so borrowers could get credit more quickly.
It began publishing background papers on economies it is monitoring to keep markets better informed. And in May it agreed to release the results of these economic checkups, as long as the country agreed.
Such precautions reflected a perception that the Mexican crash represented a new type of financial crisis, one closely linked to the globalization of markets. In this new world, flood tides of speculative capital could flow in and out of emerging economies, playing havoc with their development and sending shock waves out to foreign lenders and investors.
Thailand, along with some other Southeast Asian countries, was vulnerable to devaluation because it had linked its currency to the dollar as a way of limiting inflation. But as the dollar rose, these export-dependent economies lost their competitiveness.
Once the baht fell, other regional currencies became candidates for devaluation, as well. Speculative pressures quickly forced down the Philippine peso, the Malaysian ringgit, the Indonesian rupiah and even the mighty Singapore dollar.
"The rest of the region had to re-establish its competitiveness against Thailand," said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, the Salomon Brothers chief economist based in London.
While Thailand delayed approaching the I.M.F. after it devalued, the Philippines, whose economy was already under I.M.F. surveillance, moved quickly to negotiate a new $650 million loan with the fund and to take additional economic measures.
Last week, the I.M.F. sought to assure investors that the wave of devaluations did not spell the end of the Asian economic miracle. The strong growth record of these countries, it said, leaves these countries able to ride out a currency crisis.
"We don't see the underlying adjustment that has to be made in any of these economies as anywhere like what had to be done in Mexico," Stanley Fischer, the fund's deputy managing director, said in the first official comment on the Asian currency losses.
Mr. Schoenholtz agrees, saying: "These countries retain impressive fundamentals -- including high savings rates, flexible labor forces, natural resources and now a more competitive exchange rate. Growth will return."
I.M.F. officials warn that they are likely to recommend a much greater dose of austerity for Thailand than they imposed on the Philippines, though they still hope that the Thai economy will record some growth this year and avoid the 6.2 percent contraction Mexico underwent the year after it devalued.

Dollar Is Mostly Higher
(By The Associated Press) -- The dollar recovered from an early selloff to end mostly higher yesterday.
It gained in European trading after the Dutch central bank left a key interest rate unchanged. The move reinforced a view that interest rates in Europe were likely to remain low because of sluggish economies and high unemployment. That view was bolstered by a French Government report that the June jobless rate had risen to 12.6 percent from 12.5 percent in May.
The dollar increased further in New York trading when the Commerce Department reported that the economy grew in the second quarter at an annual rate of 2.2 percent, stronger than expected.
The dollar rose to 118.59 Japanese yen, from 118.57 yen on Wednesday, and to 1.8384 German marks from 1.8370 marks. The British pound rallied broadly, indirectly helping the dollar against the yen and the mark. The pound rose to $1.6420 from $1.6287.
The gains came as the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported that United States monetary authorities did not intervene in foreign-exchange markets in the three-month period ending on June 30. It was the seventh consecutive quarter that the Government had not bought or sold currencies on the market.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET DEAL: DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA;
Local Governing in Capital to Be Transformed

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
The budget bill passed by Congress today will profoundly change the governing of the nation's capital, taking away much of the mayor's powers in exchange for nearly $1 billion in new Federal aid over the next five years.
With those provisions of the bill, Federal lawmakers have stepped into the debate over one of the most contentious issues facing the city: the degree to which local residents should have direct control over their fortunes. For now, it will not be much. 
 In reclaiming control of city operations and giving it to the financial control board created by Congress two years ago to oversee the District's budget, the lawmakers have demonstrated that for the time being, they have little confidence in the ability of local elected officials to stanch years of fiscal bleeding and population decline that have badly eroded the tax base.
That shift of authority has reopened an emotional debate among many residents over whether they enjoy the same democracy as other Americans. In the process, it has put some distance between the two Democrats who are the city's leading political figures: Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District's nonvoting delegate to Congress, who helped shape the final deal with White House negotiators and Republican leaders, and Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., who harshly criticized it as a "recolonization" of the city in diminishing limited home rule granted by Congress 23 years ago.
Under the new legislation, the Federal Government will create tax breaks for the District's residents and businesses, will assume the city's $4.9 billion pension liability and will take over typical state functions like running courts and prisons. The Government will also increase its share of Medicaid costs, to 70 percent from the current 50 percent.
Over five years, according to the White House Office of Management and Budget, the deal is worth $928 million beyond what the District would have received from the Government under the current relationship.
But in exchange for the package of benefits, the city is being required to yield more managerial power to the control board.
The bill will allow the board to send private consultants into the city's nine major agencies to identify problems and impose solutions; the consultants will be accountable only to the board, not to the mayor or the city council. In addition, the mayor's nominations for department heads will require the board's approval.
The changes are temporary, remaining in effect only as long as the board itself operates. But by law, the board can disband only after the city has balanced its budget for four consecutive years.
Ms. Norton said the transfer of these powers to the board had been the only way to prevent an even more radical change: the creation of a city-manager-type government that would have all but eliminated any mayoral power. That change was favored by Senator Lauch Faircloth, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee for the District of Columbia.
For now, the mayor will still have authority over some city agencies, including the economic development office, the taxi commission and the office of tourism and promotion.
"It is a major victory for home rule that I was able to avoid the imposition of a Congressionally imposed city manager," Ms. Norton said in a statement. "However, during the process, provisions were forced into the bill requiring the mayor to share some of his authority with the control board."
Mr. Barry, who is regarded by some Federal lawmakers as the prime source of the District's problems, was outraged by the deal. He lashed out at "mean-spirited, conservative and anti-self-determination Republicans" who had insisted on tight managerial restraints on local officials in return for the tax breaks, sought by Ms. Norton, and the Federal assistance for municipal operations, proposed by President Clinton.
In language that was particularly charged in a city with a majority black population, Mr. Barry said:
"Recolonization is being promoted by several key members of the Republican Party. To take power from local elected officials is taking away the rights of 600,000 citizens of the District of Columbia and denying them their God-given and constitutional rights to help decide their fate and their freedom."
He singled out Mr. Faircloth, saying the Senator "led the effort to recolonize the citizens of the District" and "raped democracy and freedom."
For his part, the Senator referred to his appointment as chairman of the District subcommittee seven months ago, recalling that he recognized then that "the largest problem was mismanagement."
"Everything I've seen as chairman," he added, "has only confirmed that belief."

HEADLINE: Growth Eased To 2.2% Rate In 2d Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
The economy slowed during the spring as consumers cut back on their spending, Government figures showed today.
The economy grew at an annual rate of 2.2 percent in the April-June period, less than half that of the preceding quarter. The Clinton Administration and private analysts cheered the news because it portrayed an economy no longer running faster than its presumed speed limit, above which inflation would revive. 
 "It's about as good as it can get for a fully employed economy," said Robert G. Dederick, economic consultant to Chicago's Northern Trust Company. "I'm running out of adjectives to describe how well it's doing."
The related Commerce Department price index covering everything Americans buy posted its slimmest quarterly increase since 1961, benefiting from a hefty decline in the price of oil. This inflation gauge rose at a modest 1.9 percent pace in the first quarter even though energy prices advanced.
At the White House, Janet L. Yellen, the President's chief economic adviser, said at a briefing: "Today's G.D.P. numbers suggest that the economy continues to hum. Growth is robust, unemployment remains low at 5 percent, inflation is in check, household wealth is rising and consumer confidence surveys register record optimism."
She added that as one of Mr. Clinton's "paid worriers" she was finding it hard to identify things that could jeopardize the good times.
The report also heartened bond investors, who extended a rally in Treasury securities. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for consumer and corporate interest rates -- fell to 6.29 percent today, its lowest level in nearly a year and a half. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions.
The 2.2 percent annual growth rate this spring in gross domestic product -- the value of all goods and services produced within the nation's boundaries -- is what most analysts regard as the economy's limit before setting off an upswing in inflation based on how fast the labor force is growing and the amount by which these workers and their machines become more efficient.
The G.D.P. growth rate decelerated from the first quarter, when the growth pace was 4.9 percent, a figure that the department today revised downward from 5.9 percent. Although spring growth matched the consensus expectation, some economists had worried that the pace of expansion would be 3 percent or higher and rekindle speculation that the Federal Reserve could be driven by subsequent evidence of strong momentum to raise interest rates in coming months.
On Friday, the Labor Department is to report on the July job market, which shows few signs of easing.
The Commerce Department also issued today its annual revision of previous G.D.P. numbers. The revision slightly increased the average annual economic growth for the four years from the fourth quarter of 1992 through this year's first quarter. Instead of 2.7 percent a year, the revision put the growth at 2.8 percent.
For the quarter that just ended, Commerce reported that Americans sharply scaled back their spending for motor vehicles and other long-lived and consumable products while cutting back only slightly on services, today's report disclosed.
Personal consumption outlays rose just eight-tenths of 1 percent at an annual rate after surging 5.3 percent during the winter. Durable goods fell at a 5.7 percent pace following a 14.1 percent leap while spending on nondurables fell 2.1 percent after rising 4.7 percent. Services grew at a 3.7 percent clip, nearly matching the January-March gain of 3.9 percent.
The nation's businesses, meanwhile, added to inventories at a very rapid rate for the second consecutive quarter but this accounted for only two-tenths of a point to G.D.P. because there was very little acceleration. By contrast, inventories swelled first-quarter G.D.P. by 1.8 points, or more than one-third of the total increase.
Goods are counted in G.D.P. whether they reach consumers or wind up on store shelves or in warehouses. They are important indicators of future production but hard to analyze because it is never clear what proportion of a buildup results from a consumer pullback and what represents the orders of supremely confident merchants.
But Lee Price, Acting Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, pointed today to inventory-to-sales ratios near historic lows, "suggesting little, if any, accumulation of unwanted" stocks.
Real final sales of domestic product rose at a 1.9 percent pace in the second quarter compared with 3 percent in the first quarter, today's report also showed.
Reflecting more cautious consumer spending, the savings rate, as a percentage of disposable personal income, climbed to 4.2 percent in the latest quarter from 3.7 percent for the January-March period.
In current dollars, G.D.P. rose at a 3.6 percent rate in the spring compared with a 7.4 percent pace last winter.
The downward revision in first-quarter G.D.P., to a 4.9 percent pace from 5.9, involved nearly all major sectors, with less fixed investment by business most pronounced.
In a footnote to history, the department wiped away by revision the only quarter of economic contraction, albeit slight, during an expansion that is now in its seventh year. The first quarter of 1993, which had shown a one-tenth of 1 percent rate of decline, is now positive by that amount.
Data included in the gross domestic product for the second quarter of 1997 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Best Month For Treasuries Since May '95

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, rounding out their best month since May 1995, after the Government reported that economic growth slowed in the second quarter while inflation remained subdued.
"It's more of the same story -- growth is fine and inflation is excellent," said Barry Evans, who manages about $2 billion of bonds at John Hancock Funds in Boston. Mr. Evans added that he did not expect today's report on employment for July to disrupt the rally, which drove yields on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond yesterday to the lowest level in almost a year and a half. 
 The 30-year bond's price rose 12/32 , to 104 13/32 , pushing its yield down three-hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.29 percent, the lowest since February 1996. Traders bought bonds after the Government said the economy grew at a 2.2 percent annual pace in the April-June period, compared with 4.9 percent -- which was revised downward from 5.9 percent -- in the first quarter. The price deflator, a measure of inflation, rose at just a 1.4 percent annual rate, the smallest increase since 1964.
Treasuries were also helped when a Colorado highway authority sold municipal bonds and bought more than $700 million of Treasury securities with the proceeds.
Government securities got an additional lift as investors in mortgage bonds switched some of their holdings into Treasuries, amid concern that falling yields might spur a wave of homeowner refinancing, which could hurt returns on mortgage bonds.
Yields on 10-year Treasury notes -- the benchmark for setting most mortgage loans -- dropped to 6 percent, which "will spur a lot of activity in the mortgage market," said Mark Mahoney, chief government bond strategist at UBS Securities.
While investors were cheered by the report on gross domestic product, bonds briefly retreated after the Chicago Purchasing Management Association's index of manufacturing for July fell less than expected, and its index of prices paid rose.
A separate report, showing a bigger-than-expected drop in initial claims for unemployment benefits last week, also kept alive concern that a strong labor market might increase wages and inflation.
Now traders are turning to today's report on July employment. The monthly jobs report is seen as one of the best measures of the economy's strength and prospects for inflation, and can cause large swings in bond prices.
Separately, the Treasury sold $18.1 billion in 48-day cash-management bills yesterday, at an average discount rate of 5.35 percent. The following are the results of yesterday's auction:

HEADLINE: Lula Journal;
When a Casino Loses Its Lifeline to Customers

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: LULA, Miss., July 29

 BODY:
The few blackjack dealers still employed at the Lady Luck Casino stand grimly behind their empty tables, nervously tapping the felt with stacks of $5 chips. The one-armed bandits are resting, their slumber broken only occasionally by the whir and clang of a distant machine. The roulette wheel is spinning, but there are no bettors, not for red or black, even or odd, or anything.
"It's going around and around," said Robert Lawrence, the roulette dealer, "but nobody's playing." 
 Nobody has played much of anything at the Lady Luck since July 15, when a barge crippled the U.S. 49 bridge spanning the Mississippi River between Helena, Ark., and Lula, Miss., the most heavily traveled route to the casino.
Luck was not a lady that night. A tall crane being ferried north on a barge scraped the bottom of the 105-foot-high bridge, twisting several steel beams and forcing highway officials to close the span for repairs. It is scheduled to reopen on Monday.
Since the closing, the number of customers to the Lady Luck has dropped 80 percent, said Neal Miller, the casino's general manager. Mr. Miller has spared no expense in trying to keep his regular customers from straying to competing casinos, even offering free helicopter rides from a weedy airstrip in West Helena to the Lady Luck's parking lot. But with the helicopter carrying only three gamblers each trip, it can help only so much.
"It's all been pretty devastating," Mr. Miller said.
The Lady Luck, whose facade features giant guitars soaring from the roof, opened at the foot of the bridge in 1994, four years after casino gambling was legalized in Mississippi. The sole rationale for placing a casino in Lula, a Mississippi Delta hamlet with a population of 225, was to lure gamblers across the bridge from Arkansas, Oklahoma and other states where casinos are banned. The nearest river crossings are in Memphis, 90 miles to the north, and near Greenville, Miss., 90 miles to the south.
The bridge closing has only reinforced the isolation of this desolate, impoverished corner of the South, where the casinos have become islands of population and prosperity in a sea of cotton fields.
Mr. Miller said he could not discuss the financial impact of the bridge closing on the casino, which had a revenue of $88.9 million in 1996. Last year, the casino produced 55 percent of the revenue generated by the Lady Luck Gaming Corporation of Las Vegas, Nev., which owns all or part of six casinos.
Clearly, the Lady Luck is taking a beating. At 11 A.M. on Tuesday, 165 visitors were on the casino floor, compared with the 1,300 that Mr. Miller said would normally be there at that time.
The casino, the largest employer in the area, has had to lay off almost half of its 1,000-person staff, many of them Arkansans. Two of its four restaurants are closed, and a third is open only on the weekends.
In the highly competitive world of Mississippi Delta gambling, rival casinos have tried to take advantage of the Lady Luck's misfortune. Two casinos in Greenville, the Las Vegas Casino and Bayou Caddy's Jubilee Casino, have teamed up with their local convention and visitors bureau to increase their advertising, directing their campaign at the Lady Luck's geographic market.
Officials with the Greenville casinos said they had attracted some new customers but were disappointed that the bridge repairs had gone faster than planned.
"Unfortunately, the downside of all this is the bridge is going to be open sooner," said Mike Howard, general manager of the Jubilee.
To fend off his competitors, both in Greenville and in Tunica to the north, Mr. Miller has offered free meals and discounted hotel rooms to regulars and provided hot-air balloon rides from the casino parking lot. When the bridge reopens, he plans to lure customers back with a fireworks display and a contest to give away four Chevrolet Blazers.
The company may also briefly continue the helicopter rides, which have been popular. About 175 people took the seven-minute trip in the four-seat Bell Jet Ranger 206 on Friday, and 200 did so on Saturday.
As a community service, and to cultivate good will, Mr. Miller also has made the helicopter available to Helena residents who need to cross the river for reasons more compelling even than the compulsion to throw dice. So far, it has transported a cancer patient who received chemotherapy in Mississippi and a physical therapist who treated patients there. It is on call for a pregnant woman who is near delivery.
But primarily, the helicopter is for gamblers. Early on Tuesday afternoon, 20 people were waiting in stifling heat at the West Helena airstrip, which is home to little more than a fleet of lemon-yellow crop dusters. Some of the people had waited more than two hours, but seemed willing to wait longer.
"I'm retired, don't have nothing to do," said James A. Moody, 63, who had driven nearly two hours from his home in Benton, Ark. "It just passes the day."
Mr. Moody said that gambling provided him with "the pleasure of a satisfied mind, just like fishing."
Seated in the cab of his maroon Ford pickup, Cheslie H. Powell, 57, was waiting to take his fourth helicopter trip in the last five days. One day after the bridge was closed, he drove 96 miles from his home in Brinkley, Ark., up through Memphis, and back down to one of the casinos in Tunica, north of Lula. But familiarity quickly brought him back to the Lady Luck, even if it meant a long wait.
"I like the Lady Luck," Mr. Powell said, adding that he knew most of the casino's dealers and managers. "I just feel at home there."

HEADLINE: Reuters Steps Up Its Talks On Times Square Building

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Reuters, the British media and information giant, is stepping up its negotiations with Prudential Insurance and New York City to build an 800,000-square-foot office tower in Times Square.
The talks, which began in the spring, have reached a decisive stage, according to city officials and Prudential executives. If a deal is struck, Reuters will consolidate operations and build a North American headquarters in a 38-story tower at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street, one of four sites designated for office buildings under the redevelopment plans for the area, according to executives and officials familiar with the talks. The existing buildings on the block would be demolished. 
 Reuters, which now has about 1,800 employees in 13 buildings in Manhattan, is also considering other locations in the metropolitan area, but city officials and some Prudential executives are optimistic that an agreement can be reached on the Times Square site. Reuters is expected to make a decision on the move within a week.
Reuters, which is known for the rapid transmission of data, photographs and text to financial capitals of the world, would sit across the street from Disney's recently renovated New Amsterdam Theater and blocks away from other, glitzier media companies: Bertelsmann, Viacom and, sometime next year, the Conde Nast publication company.
The potential deal between Reuters and Prudential, which controls the site, could still founder over financial details, design issues or the company's demand for additional tax breaks if it agrees to build a new tower in Times Square. Some Reuters executives are reportedly still debating the wisdom of the move, but the company's demand for extra multimillion-dollar tax subsidies could prove to be a volatile political issue for the Giuliani administration.
Under the Times Square redevelopment plan, the site is already laced with an unprecedented level of tax incentives for midtown Manhattan, and in the last year Times Square has become one of the most desirable business locations in the city.
Brendan Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society, an influential civic group that has closely followed redevelopment plans in Times Square, said the Society would oppose a double helping of tax breaks for the proposed tower.
"It makes no sense for taxpayers to pay more money in the form of tax breaks to get rid of prime property in Manhattan right now," Mr. Sexton, a former real estate executive, said. "As a business deal for the public, it stinks."
Glen Elliott, vice president for real estate services at Reuters America, declined to comment on any potential sites for a North American headquarters. "We're looking at alternatives throughout the tristate area," he said. "We're not at the decision stage."
The city's Economic Development Corporation customarily declines to comment on whether it is negotiating with any corporation. But Charles Millard, president of the Economic Development Corporation, did say: "Of course, we would want Reuters to stay in, and expand in, the City of New York."
City officials have been meeting with Michael Bailkin, a lawyer hired by Reuters to negotiate with the city over the additional tax incentives, said three people involved in the talks. Mr. Bailkin, who declined to comment because of confidentiality agreements, has developed a reputation in corporate circles for extracting lucrative subsidies for companies that threaten to leave the city. A year ago, Mr. Bailkin helped Conde Nast obtain $10.75 million in tax incentives from the city for a move to a 1.6 million-square-foot tower now under construction on another former Prudential site in Times Square.
That deal provoked criticism from liberal and conservative politicians as well as civic leaders, who described the subsidies as "corporate welfare" and ridiculed any suggestion that Conde Nast would make good on its threat to leave New York.
Reuters is not the only company that has shown interest in the 42d Street site. Douglas Durst, a developer who is building the office tower across Seventh Avenue that will house Conde Nast, had tried unsuccessfully to buy control of the property, for a possible deal with Reuters. And earlier this year, Marriott International talked to Prudential about building a hotel on the corner. Over the last year, Reuters has looked at various locations where it could bring its operations under one roof, including Rockefeller Center.
But Mr. Durst has not given up on the site, either. "Our primary concern, as it has been from the inception of this project, is that the rejuvenation of Times Square occur as quickly as possible," he said. "To that end, we are continuing to expend time and money developing plans for what we believe should be built in Times Square in the belief that we will be the eventual developer of those sites."
Reuters now has an informal agreement with Prudential for exclusive rights to negotiate for the corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, according to executives on both sides of the talks.
More recently, Prudential executives showed state officials some preliminary ideas for a Reuters tower that sparked a fiercely negative reaction. Prudential seemed to have revived six-year-old plans for a tall glass tower designed by the architect Philip Johnson that provided little ground-floor retail space or the kind of vibrant neon signs that have come to characterize Times Square. The plans did include a "news museum" inside the building and a green Reuters logo and video screen outside.
"We were very disappointed," said one person who had seen the plans. "There's no street level excitement."
One Prudential executive suggested that state officials had "overreacted" to what were merely some "preliminary marketing materials."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Reuters news agency is negotiating to erect a headquarters building on the northwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Illness Is Turning Into Financial Catastrophe for More of the Uninsured

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: SHERWOOD, Ark.

 BODY:
As her three boys were returning from school one Friday in March, Charlene Prowse, who works nights at a convenience store here, awakened from her day's sleep. Mrs. Prowse, 31 and robust despite a battle six years ago with ovarian cancer, stepped into the hallway of the family's home in this working-class suburb of Little Rock. Then she collapsed.
"Mom was on the floor," said Cory, her 8-year-old son, who rushed in from the porch with his brother Steven, 7. Her husband, Randal Sr., 40, said: "She was shaking, staring into space. I started giving her C.P.R." 
 Charlene Prowse eventually recovered. But the family had no health insurance, and the thousands of dollars worth of medical bills brought on by her illness swept them over the edge, putting them in a red file folder in the fast-expanding bankruptcy stacks at the Federal courthouse in Little Rock.
Their petition, filed in early July, listed nearly $8,000 in medical bills, half of which came from four days that Mrs. Prowse spent at a Little Rock hospital recovering from what doctors said was a seizure.
With the number of uninsured working poor having increased over the last 10 years, the Prowse case is not unusual. Even as managed care and the growth of private hospitals is upending the world of health care and as Washington is putting the finishing touches on a budget bill that provides health insurance for more children, the number of uninsured Americans remains at its highest point in years.
In 1987, according to the Census Bureau, the number of uninsured working people living below the Federal poverty line -- $7,890 a year for individuals and $16,029 for a family of four -- was 8.1 million, which was 45 percent of the working poor. By 1992, when President Clinton was elected and began pressing for an overhaul of the health care system to make sure all workers are covered, the numbers had grown to 9.6 million and 48 percent.
And through 1995, the latest year for which the bureau has data, little had changed. In spite of a growing economy and declining poverty, 9.4 million working poor, still 48 percent of the working poor, did not have health insurance.
Though Congress and state legislatures have been wrestling for months with the problems of the country's 10 million uninsured children, the population of 23 million uninsured working adults, 17 million of whom work full time, has been largely ignored in the debate. The working poor in this group, typically earning $6 or $7 an hour, make too little to afford health insurance but too much to qualify for Medicaid, the state and Federal insurance program for the poor.
So when medical misfortune strikes, they can only plead for the forbearance of doctors, compete for the increasingly scarce resources of charities or file for bankruptcy.
"At least 40 percent of my clients have medical problems that have caused them to file," said Danyelle J. Walker, one of Little Rock's busier bankruptcy lawyers.
The economy, perversely, bears some of the blame. Though it has lifted millions off the welfare rolls and pushed unemployment down to 30-year lows, it has created mostly low-wage service and retail jobs like Mrs. Prowse's, which are much less likely to provide insurance. And once off Government aid, most former welfare recipients cannot rely on Medicaid.
In Arkansas and many other states, the uninsured working poor outnumber the uninsured unemployed poor. In fact, the rise in the uninsured working poor accounts for most of the growth of the nation's uninsured, to more than 40 million today from 31 million a decade ago.
Many are parents weaned from the welfare rolls who keep their Medicaid until a year or two after their wages lift them above the poverty line, under provisions of the law to encourage the poor to get jobs. Most are either blue-collar self-employed workers or wage earners whose employers either do not provide insurance, are terminating it or are raising the share of the cost workers must pay to levels they cannot afford.
"They just do without," said Ray Hanley, medical services director for the Arkansas Department of Human Services. "They have to choose between buying enough medicine and buying enough food."
Dr. Karmen Hopkins, a family practitioner at the St. Vincent Health Clinic East in Little Rock, said, "You present them with a prescription for medication," and when they realize what it will cost, "they look at you like you're crazy."
"They ask you," Dr. Hopkins said, " 'What do you want me not to pay -- the rent or the utilities?' "
From 1994 through April 1997, the economy had generated just 19,000 jobs in well-paid fields like manufacturing, which tend to provide health insurance, while it created 428,000 retail store jobs like Mrs. Prowse's.
"We've had a 5 percent decrease in employer-based coverage because of the shift to the service-based economy," Mr. Hanley said.
Nationwide, the Employee Benefit Research Institute in Washington says, employers providing subsidized insurance dropped to 64 percent last year, from 69 percent a decade ago.
Here, in the President's home state, 17 percent of the population is uninsured, more than in at least 40 other states. Household incomes are just 79 percent of the national average. So in Arkansas, as in much of the South, the squeeze on the working poor is especially pronounced.
And those who study the state say it has become the nation's unhealthiest.
"For the last few years, Arkansas has been at the bottom of the pile" on health issues, said Kathleen Morgan, co-editor of Morgan Quitno Press, a Kansas reference-book publisher that studies state economies and living conditions. The company's most recent study, Ms. Morgan said, shows that people in Arkansas who get sick, stay sick longer than those in any other state.
The Prowses, with an income of $20,000 a year when both parents are fully employed, cannot begin to afford the $450 to $600 a month that Ronald Sheffield, the deputy insurance commissioner of Arkansas, estimates they would have pay on their own for family coverage. Their insurance would cost more than their monthly rent, $400.
The Prowses said that even when Mr. Prowse had a regular job a year ago, maintaining an apartment building, their share of his employer-subsidized insurance -- $241 a month -- cost too much. Like many other small businesses, Mrs. Prowse's employer, Shipley's, does not offer her insurance or most other benefits, like sick pay and vacation pay.
Employers say there is little they can do because of the costs. Foster Higgins, a national employee benefits consulting concern, says that employers who provided health insurance for their employees last year paid an average of $3,915 per worker. That amounts to 38 percent of a full-time worker's earnings at the minimum wage of $5.15 an hour, and many employers say they cannot stay in business if they pay it.
Small employers often must pay even more because they lack big employers' negotiating clout with insurance companies.
And so for the uninsured poor, bankruptcy becomes a solution to a medical crisis. The American Bankruptcy Institute says a record 1,125,006 consumers filed for bankruptcy last year, an increase of 29 percent from the year before and a 150 percent increase since 1986, when 450,000 petitions were filed.
Credit card debt is the biggest culprit, said Samuel J. Gerdano, the bankruptcy institute's executive director. No one, Mr. Gerdano said, breaks down with any precision the other causes, like medical bills, divorce, losing a job or gambling.
But judges and debtors' lawyers say medical bills seem to be surpassing the others. That is the perception in Arkansas.After three years of slight declines, bankruptcy filings in the state, nearly all by consumers, jumped 37 percent in 1995 and 41 percent last year, to 13,189.
An informal review of the latest 200 petitions in Federal court in Little Rock shows a medical bill on 1 in 2 cases. In about 1 out of 4, medical debts exceed the petitioners' other unsecured debts, which are those that have nothing material behind them, like homes and automobiles.
Credit card debt, moreover, may camouflage medical debt. With the proliferation of credit cards, James G. Mixon, one of the state's three Federal bankruptcy judges, said, "Most every doctor or hospital will take a credit card."
"For anybody who's uninsured, that's a way to deal with the problem," Judge Mixon said.
Still, bankruptcy is often a mixed blessing. Many who file, like the Prowses, choose to try to pay off a part of their debts, while others apply to have all their debts wiped out. Under the plan the Prowses worked out, Mrs. Prowse is keeping just $66 of her weekly pay of $211 while the rest goes to pay off debts, including medical bills.
Mr. Prowse, now unemployed, typically earns twice the pay that his wife does when he works. But when the couple filed for bankruptcy, the bank repossessed the 1992 Chevrolet Blazer he used to search for jobs and to get to them. They have a 15-year-old Chevy Silverado, but the transmission needs to be replaced before Mr. Prowse can use it.
Doctors are still unsure what caused Mrs. Prowse's seizure, and now a new problem threatens her health.
"The doctor found a new knot on my ovary," Mrs. Prowse said. "He told me to get over there, that he'd work with me, let me pay $10 a month."
"But I'll have to stay off work for six weeks," she said, explaining that she cannot afford to do so until the fall, when her husband expects to find work and the children are back in school.
"I won't have to pay a baby sitter then," Mrs. Prowse said.

HEADLINE: Sun Microsystems to Buy Diba, a Start-Up

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 31

 BODY:
Seeking to broaden its reach in the consumer market, Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it would acquire Diba Inc., a start-up company that is developing technology for small communications and computing devices called information appliances.
Terms of the deal were not disclosed. 
 The acquisition by Sun follows close on the heels of the Microsoft Corporation's acquisition of Web TV and the Oracle Corporation's acquisition of Navio Inc. for its Network Computer Inc. subsidiary. All three acquisitions illustrate the importance the major computer companies are placing on the convergence of the Internet and television. With Diba, which was founded to create technology for simple devices that could surf the World Wide Web or send electronic mail, Sun is staking its claim on this emerging market.
"There is going to be a realigning of the television world in the next five years," said William Bluestein, an analyst with Forrester Research. "Whether it's Web TV, HDTV or our old friend 500 channels, you're going to see a whole new assault on the television as a platform, so you see all the computer guys circling around. This is essentially a move made by Sun to give it an entree in that world."
Diba will become a new Sun business unit, the Consumer Technologies Group, within the company's microelectronics division. This group will work with major consumer electronics companies, so-called O.E.M.'s, to provide technologies for building consumer products such as Internet-enabled TV's, set top and satellite boxes, and smart phones, said Sun, which is based in Mountain View, Calif. Diba employs 79 people and is based in Menlo Park, Calif.
"Information appliances represent an enormous opportunity for manufacturers who can deliver the right products at the right time," Scott McNealy, Sun's chairman, president and chief executive, said in a statement. "By leveraging the Java software platform and Java-enabled microprocessors with Diba's experience in assembling technology components into complete solutions, Sun hopes to enable O.E.M.'s to take advantage of the market's vast potential sooner rather than later."
Whether the Diba brand name will continue after the acquisition has not been determined.
"We're figuring it out right now in real time as we speak," Farzad Dibachi, Diba's president and chief executive, said in a telephone interview. Mr. Dibachi, a former Oracle executive, and his brother Farid, Diba's chairman and co-founder, will join Sun, reporting to Chet Silvestri, president of Sun Microelectronics, he said.
Part of the appeal of the television market is that Microsoft and its Windows operating system software is not yet entrenched there, Mr. Bluestein said. "The standard is literally up for grabs," he said. "There is compelling reason for it to be based on Windows software.
"One thing to watch will be Sun and Diba versus Oracle and Navio, and whether they agree on a common standard against Microsoft."

HEADLINE: Holders Oust Management Of Sallie Mae

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Shareholders of the Student Loan Marketing Association ousted the management yesterday by electing a dissident slate of directors to run the company, ending a protracted, bitter struggle over its strategy.
Jonathan E. Gray, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, called the vote "the stock market equivalent of the Boston Tea Party; it's a revolution." The company's shares surged in response to the vote. 
 Shareholders also overwhelmingly approved a plan to turn Sallie Mae, as the company is known, into a fully private, state-chartered corporation. Since its creation in 1973, Sallie Mae has been a Government-sponsored enterprise, though it has been partly privatized since then.
While both sides favored full privatization, yesterday's votes culminated a two-year battle over how the company, which buys and services student loans, should conduct its business. On the one side was Sallie Mae's management, and on the other, a group of directors who have called themselves the Committee to Restore Value.
Currently, the company benefits from its quasi-public status by borrowing at below-market interest rates with Government guarantees to buy repackaged loans from banks, though it does not directly issue loans. Under the dissidents' plan, Sallie Mae will now compete with banks by making loans directly to students and schools.
The current management wanted to maintain the lending approach but also wanted to enter other businesses, such as servicing consumer loans, providing back-office processing and computer software services.
"Sallie Mae shareholders have made their choice regarding the future leadership and direction of Sallie Mae," said William Arceneaux, the current chairman of Sallie Mae, and he pledged to cooperate with the newly elected board to achieve a smooth transition to the new corporate structure.
The dissident group is led by Albert L. Lord, a former chief operating officer and chief executive at Sallie Mae and current board member. Mr. Lord, who left Sallie Mae in 1994, will return as chief executive. Edward A. Fox, who served as president and chief executive of Sallie Mae from 1973 until 1990, will become chairman.
The struggle over Sallie Mae's future began at a time when the company's stock price was languishing in the mid-$30's, roughly half the level it was when Mr. Lord left the company.
Following a bitter proxy fight in 1995, Mr. Lord and eight of his associates were elected to the board. Shortly thereafter, Sallie Mae began carrying out a number of recommendations made by the new board members, changes that included deep cuts in expenses and a stock buyback program.
Helped by those changes, for which both sides take credit, Sallie Mae's stock has quintupled in value since 1995.
"It is unprecendented in corporate America for shareholders to replace a management team whose stock has gone up five times in the last two years," said Steven Eisman, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company.
Final figures of the vote to oust the management were not available, and the results will need to be certified, a process that could take as long as a week. But according to preliminary results, the dissident group received nearly 58 percent of the 44 million proxies cast.
The outcome was greeted with a hearty endorsement from Wall Street. On the New York Stock Exchange, Sallie Mae's shares rose $4.8125, to $149.9375.
The company's surging stock price was reflective of its solid financial position.
Last month Sallie Mae said that second quarter net income rose 16 percent from levels a year earlier, to $119.2 million, or $2.20 a share. At the end of June, the company's portfolio of student loans stood at $41.5 billion, up 11 percent from the same period a year earlier.
Sallie Mae's current management attempted to take credit for many of the changes of the last two years, but analysts said developments at the company in recent weeks did little to instill confidence among investors that the executives had a clear idea of how to move the company forward.
Indicative of what they characterized as disarray was the announcement on June 11 that Lawrence A. Hough would step down as Sallie Mae's chief executive as soon as a successor could be found.
Although Mr. Hough said the idea to resign was his own and was done to seek an end to the stalemate between the dissidents and management, analysts said a number of large institutional shareholders had insisted that Mr. Hough step aside.
The management shake-up made a deep impression on David Drake, director of the proxy advisory service at Institutional Shareholder Services, the nation's largest proxy advisory firm.
As recently as May, Mr. Drake had issued a report supporting current management.
But last week he changed his mind, and strongly endorsed the dissident slate.
"When I sat down and re-evaluated the situation, I thought the dissident slate already has a lot of experience with this company and that they were already dictating strategy from their minority position," he said.
"When I talked to management, they never denied that. And when Mr. Hough resigned, it eroded management stability, which had been a major reason I had supported them before."
Mr. Eisman at Oppenheimer said the Institutional Shareholder Services recommendation "was a major step, and Hough's resignation was a strategic error."
"This is the culmination of what has been an incredibly long, convoluted and exciting story," he said.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Deal Could Keep the Bills In Buffalo for 15 Years

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: FREDONIA, N.Y., July 31

 BODY:
The Buffalo Bills reached an agreement today with local and state agencies that could keep the team at Rich Stadium for another 15 years.
The deal is contingent upon the Bills' selling 90 percent of 76 new luxury suites and 6,900 club seats, and also contingent on legislative approval. New York agreed to pay $63.2 million in stadium improvements and incentives for the Bills' owner, Ralph Wilson. 
 "This is a special day for the Bills, for Buffalo, for the county and the state of New York," Wilson said during a news conference at Fredonia State College, the site of the team's training camp. "The Bills will be here for a long, long time."
The key to keeping the Bills into the next century is selling the new seating. The suites would replace about 5,000 seats some 40 feet from the field.
If sold by Dec. 1, 1998, they would be in place for the following season, and the Bills would be locked in for six years before having an option to buy out of their lease.
If the luxury seats are not sold, the Bills would have an option to move out of town. The maximum agreement is for 15 years.
The deal, reached with Gov. George E. Pataki and Executive Dennis Gorski of Erie County, ends two years of haggling and, if implemented, would eliminate the possibility that the Bills would move.
 The Bills have been in Buffalo since 1960, when Wilson was one of eight original owners who founded the American Football League. The team has played at Rich Stadium under its current lease since 1973.
Wilson for years has voted against teams' moving to other cities, but he has been concerned with the Buffalo economy and season-ticket sales, which decreased from 57,132 in 1992 to a projected 34,000 this year.
New York will reimburse the Bills for an estimated $12 million the team spent to improve the stadium in 1994. Wilson was also given naming rights to the stadium, which would generate millions of dollars annually.

Israel Is Reported to Take Harsh Stance After Bomb
Israeli radio and television reported that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Government had decreed harsh measures against the Palestinian Authority after suicide bombings killed 13 people in a Jerusalem market, and did not exclude sending commandos into Palestinian areas. A1
 
President Clinton and his aides considered options to salvage the rapidly dissolving peace agenda negotiated in Oslo four years ago. A8 

Six Hanged in Burundi
Six people convicted of having taken part in ethnic massacres in Burundi were hanged in Bujumbura, the capital, officials said. The executions of three Hutu, two Tutsi and a member of the Twa ethnic group were the first since the Tutsi-controlled Government began trials last year of people accused of what it calls war crimes. A3
 
German Tax Cuts Shot Down
Germany's opposition Social Democrats shot down a Government proposal pushed by Chancellor Helmut Kohl as the tax "reform of the century," saying it favored the rich. The plan sought to reduce income taxes considerably, in hopes of encouraging investment that would tackle the country's 11 percent unemployment rate. The Government majority was expected to block the opposition's counter-proposal in the lower house of Parliament, leading to an unwieldy political paralysis. A4
 
Court Ponders Swiss Suit
A United States District Court in Brooklyn began hearings over whether a class action suit brought by 18,000 American Jews against Swiss banks, which they contend kept the assets of Holocaust victims, should proceed. A5
 
New Requirements for Mir
NASA announced that in the future American astronauts staying aboard the aging Russian Mir space station will probably have to be qualified to make space walks. The new policy means that Wendy Lawrence, who is too small to fit in a Russian spacesuit, will not stay on Mir. She will fly up to the station aboard the space shuttle, but her replacement, David Wolf, will stay on Mir. A6
 
Rockets Fired in Afghanistan
The Taliban religious army controlling most of Afghanistan sent helicopter gunships to attack opposition soldiers just nine miles north of Kabul, prompting a blistering rocket attack on the capital. Ahmed Shah Massood, the opposition leader, predicted that the Taliban would lose its grip on Kabul within a week. (AP)
 
Japanese Convicted in Lebanon
A judge in Beirut praised a Japanese man who led an attack on an Israeli airport, calling his actions "heroic," but then convicted him and four other Japanese Red Army members on a separate charge of illegally entering Lebanon and sentenced them to three years in prison. One of them served 12 years in an Israeli jail for the 1972 attack on Tel Aviv's airport that killed 24 people. (AP)

Some 'Limited' Tax Breaks Help A Small Constituency
The tax bill passed by Congress includes many narrowly focused provisions that benefit just a few individuals or businesses. But this year, for the first time, President Clinton can veto them if he wishes. Among the beneficiaries of the "limited" tax breaks are hard-cider producers in upstate New York and Vermont, who would pay lower Federal excise taxes, life insurance companies and securities firms, which would be able to defer taxes on income earned from overseas transactions, and software giants like Microsoft, which would get tax breaks intended to encourage exports. Benefit Seen in Baby Talk
Baby talk spoken to infants plays a larger role in the development of speech than previously thought, according to a new study. Mothers who engage in baby talk are producing highly exaggerated speech sounds that provide the basis for all subsequent learning of that language. A21

Psychology of Video Rentals
It can be amateur psychology at its best: Consumers rely on video rental shops to help heal the wounds accumulated during the day, to further passions or get excited about life again, and a video clerk with a reasonable knowledge of 10,000 movies and a passable ability to judge character can help in ways that may never have occurred their customers. Mass marketing has killed many local video stores, but the some of the survivors, run by owners who know their neighborhoods' needs, continue to thrive, because no demographics-chewing computer can take the place of experience. HEADLINE: Flake to Leave Congress To Devote Time to Church

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Citing the growing weight of his ministerial duties, Representative Floyd H. Flake said yesterday that he would resign from Congress by the end of this year to devote more time to the church in Queens where he has been pastor for 21 years.
Mr. Flake, a 52-year-old Democrat, indicated a week ago that he was considering leaving Congress at the end of his current term, 17 months from now. But, in an interview last night, he said he would leave before the end of the current session in December, declining to be more specific. He said he would make his formal announcement to his congregation on Sunday, at the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church. 
 The decision to resign, Mr. Flake said, was based on the fact that Allen A.M.E. had recently opened a $23 million cathedral in Jamaica, Queens, and that overseeing its progress and that of the church's swelling social-service and economic empire would require his full attention.
"I believe this is one of those situations where the congregation needs me," said Mr. Flake, who is serving his sixth term in Congress. "And I want to build the church operation in a way that allows us to have the foundation to make sure our ministry grows."
With his departure, Mr. Flake will become the second member of Congress from New York City to resign this year. Susan Molinari, a Republican from Staten Island, resigned to become an anchorwoman on a CBS television news program. Her resignation becomes effective today, leaving behind a spirited race for her seat in Congress.
Similarly, the departure from Congress of Mr. Flake, which comes far sooner than many in political circles had expected, is certain to set off a torrent of activity among the various politicians in southeastern Queens who hope to succeed him.
The name mentioned most frequently is Gregory W. Meeks, a State Assemblyman, who has a close relationship with Mr. Flake. Mr. Meeks, 43, is also chairman of the state Council of Black Elected Democrats.
Another is State Assemblywoman Barbara M. Clark, 58, who has been in office since 1987 and has already begun discussing fund-raising strategies, several political officials said. State Senator Alton R. Waldon Jr., 60, who briefly held a seat in Congress a decade ago, is also said to be interested. Archie Spigner, 68, a member of the City Council since 1974, is also mentioned as a possible contender.
If Mr. Flake's resignation becomes effective after Oct. 1, Gov. George E. Pataki can call a special election no sooner than 30 days after the seat is vacant and no later than 40 days afterward, under the state's election law. If his resignation becomes effective before Oct. 1, an election for a new representative could be held in November, at the same time the polls will be open for other municipal races.
Mr. Flake said he had not decided whom he would endorse. "At the moment I am trying to inform people of my own decision and work my way through that," he said. "Then, I will deal with other decisions like an endorsement."
Any endorsement by the Congressman, however, would be welcomed by any of the contenders because half of Allen A.M.E.'s 8,600 members live within the congressional district.
Allen A.M.E. is one of the city's largest congregations and its new, 2,500-seat cathedral, which opened a week ago, is the second-largest predominantly black church in New York City, behind the Concord Baptist Church in Brooklyn.
Under Mr. Flake's pastorship, the church's operations have been complex and diverse. Allen A.M.E. has established an elementary school for about 500 students, a 300-unit senior citizens complex, a bus chartering corporation and a community center that operates a health clinic and a Head Start program. The church's development corporation has also purchased commercial storefronts.
Mr. Flake said he felt comfortable about leaving his position now because several of the projects he has worked on in the Jamaica neighborhood -- a Federal Aviation Administration headquarters and a regional office of the Food and Drug Administration -- are nearly complete.
While Mr. Flake has often been mentioned as a possible mayoral candidate in 2001, he said yesterday that he had no political plans. "I have no political program whatsoever," he said. "I would not limit myself by saying that I would not pursue something that might make sense one day. But my only specific plans now are focused on the church."
In addition to his work at the church, Mr. Flake said he intends to lecture and write books on the need for black elected officials to revise their political strategies and to devote more attention to economic development in their areas.
"It is my belief that much of our leadership is still mired in the rhetoric of the 1960's and 1970's," Mr. Flake said. "Serving in a legislative body and doing practical economic development in a community that many had given up on represents what can be done. I expect to have a lot to say about that in the future."
