HEADLINE: THE BUDGET DEAL: THE SCORECARD;
In Budget Bill, President Wins Welfare Battle

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
When President Clinton signed the welfare bill last year, he said it was "far from perfect," and pledged to "change what is wrong."
Slim as the odds seemed then, Mr. Clinton largely got his way in the budget agreement that both chambers of Congress have just approved. He paid a price in acquiescing to tax cuts for wealthier Americans, analysts on the left and right say, but he won major concessions in blunting some of the welfare law's toughest provisions. 
 The President also lost some battles. For example, he was unable to raise food stamp allotments to families living in high-cost areas like New York City, where the rent can consume more than half their income, and he won only $1.5 billion of the $4.8 billion he sought for all food stamp spending.
Moreover, nothing changes the basic objective of the welfare law that both Mr. Clinton and Congress endorse. It turns over most of the control of the welfare system to the states, ends the old system's womb-to-tomb entitlement to cash assistance, limits welfare payments to families to a maximum of five years and requires that welfare recipients be engaged in work or work-related activity within two years.
Besides the concessions in the budget bill, Mr. Clinton has won important battles over how the regulations implementing the 1996 welfare law are applied. For example, the Labor Department recently ruled that welfare recipients who take state jobs must be paid the $5.15-an-hour minimum wage, a ruling that has Southern states bristling, and that the budget bill lets stand.
Elaine Ryan, director of government affairs for the American Public Welfare Association, said Mr. Clinton "certainly got what he wanted" for the welfare law in the budget deal.
Douglas J. Besharov, resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, said, "The President succeeded in moving the bill much closer to his own priorities."
Wendell E. Primus, who helped write Mr. Clinton's original welfare legislation and resigned in protest over the compromises worked out with Congress, said the economy must weather a recession before the impact of the welfare law can be fairly assessed. "But," Mr. Primus added, "there's no doubt that this budget bill, in terms of what it does for immigrants, welfare-to-work and food stamps, reverses some of the worst aspects of the welfare law."
Under the 1996 welfare law, noncitizens, including many who had worked in the United States and paid taxes for up to 10 years, lost Supplemental Security Income, the welfare program for the aged and disabled poor, and Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor.
Now, legal immigrants who resided in the United States last Aug. 22, when the President signed the welfare bill into law, remain eligible for the programs, whether they were covered by them then or will need them in the future. Only those arriving in this country after that date remain excluded.
The budget bill gives the President another provision that he stressed in his re-election campaign last fall: a welfare-to-work tax credit.
To encourage more employers to hire and retain welfare recipients, Congress approved paying employers a 35 percent credit on wages up to $10,000, or $3,500, in the first year that those who had been on welfare remain on the job, and even more -- 50 percent on the first $10,000 of their second year's wages. The Department of Health and Human Services said the plan would cost only $600 million over six years.
Congress also approved $3 billion over two years in job-hunting assistance for mostly single, able-bodied adults. Under the welfare law, this group is treated more harshly than most. They are allowed food stamps only for three months every three years unless they are working.
But the budget bill permits states to exempt 15 percent of the adults from this requirement, and it allocates the $3 billion for job-hunting assistance and training, which critics say violates the welfare law's overriding objective of requiring all recipients to go to work.
"The welfare bill had an operating paradigm -- work, not job training," Mr. Besharov said. "This is a $3 billion boondoggle, hush money, for big-city mayors to quiet them down on welfare reform."
Able-bodied adults have also profited from the way the Administration is enforcing the three-month, three-year provision. The law permits states to exempt communities with unemployment above 10 percent or with shortages of jobs.
But the law does not establish criteria for such job-shortage areas, so the Department of Agriculture, which enforces food stamp regulations, has been using a Labor Department criteria to define such areas. So far, said a department spokesman, Phil Shanholtzer, "hundreds and hundreds of communities in at least 41 states" have been exempted.
The Administration's biggest coup may be in the $24 billion that Congress granted over five years to extend Medicaid to half the nation's 10 million children who lack health-care coverage. Part of the cost would be paid with increases in the cigarette tax, from 24 cents a pack now to 34 cents by 2000 and 39 cents by 2002.
That and the restoration of Medicaid for legal immigrants and for some disabled children who lost it under the welfare law mark a big change in the fortunes of the working poor and of indigent families, Administration officials said.
"With Medicaid," said Melissa T. Skolfield, the spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Human Services, "we were able to achieve everything we wanted."
The Children's Defense Fund, one of the 1996 welfare law's harshest critics, remains opposed to the welfare-to-work time limits, but is pleased with the Medicaid changes. "The child health provision is a very big victory," said Deborah Weinstein, director of the fund's family income division.
Across the political spectrum, analysts say Mr. Clinton won much more than he lost. Isabel V. Sawhill, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute and for two years an associate director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, urges a wholly different overhaul of the welfare system, one that focuses much more on school systems and ailing cities.
"But from a political perspective," she added, "you have to call this a real win for the President and a partial win for the poor."
Michael Tanner, director of health and welfare studies at the conservative Cato Institute, was most critical of the Labor Department's requirement that people on workfare receive the minimum wage. "We are rapidly undoing the welfare reform law even before we've seen if it works," he said.
But he agreed with Ms. Sawhill on another point. "The President got everything he wanted," he said, "and then some." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges Against Mark On Strong U.S. Economic Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar hit an eight-year high against the mark yesterday and surged in most other currency dealings, powered by strong United States economic data that raised the prospect of higher interest rates.
The advances in jobs, incomes, spending and manufacturing suggested inflationary pressures that might persuade Federal Reserve policy makers to nudge up rates at their August meeting. Higher rates tend to strengthen a currency. 
 The dollar also briefly surpassed the 119-yen level for the first time in two months on signs of Japanese economic weakness, but it retreated to end lower on rumors of possible intervention to defend the yen by the Bank of Japan. A drop in the mark's value against the yen also indirectly helped strengthen the Japanese currency versus the dollar.
Traders said the power of the dollar's advance against the mark increased during the day, as those who had sold dollars on a bet the currency would retreat scrambled to buy them back.
"It's really kind of taken off," said Jim Powers, vice president of foreign exchange sales at Westdeutsche Landes Bank in New York. "The numbers that came out today were very strong in the U.S., leading people to think a possible pre-emptive interest-rate tightening is in the cards, and that's dollar bullish."
The dollar hit an intraday high of 1.8675 marks, the strongest since November 1989, before settling in New York at 1.8635 marks, up from 1.8384 marks on Thursday. The advance left the dollar 1.4 percent higher against the mark for the week, 6.7 percent higher for the month of July and 20.8 percent higher for the year.
Against the yen, the dollar reached an intraday high of 119.18, the strongest since May 12, before falling to settle in New York at 118.40, down from 118.59 on Thursday. The pound weakened to $1.6318 from $1.6420.
Traders were also emboldened to buy dollars for marks yesterday because of an increasing belief that Germany's central bank will not take action to arrest the dollar's advance.
There had been speculation since last week that the Bundesbank might nudge up German interest rates as a sign that it was prepared to defend the mark. But Bundesbank officials have been quiet since then in the face of the dollar's gains.

HEADLINE: Golden Years for H.M.O.'s;
Budget Deal May Push More Elderly Into Managed Care

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Older Americans escaped the costly overhaul of their Medicare benefits that some lawmakers in Congress were seeking in Washington's budget negotiations this week. But like younger people with employer-paid or individual health insurance, the elderly are finding it harder to dodge the pressures to sign up for managed care.
Attracted by coverage for prescription drugs and other expensive features that the Government does not pay for in traditional fee-for-service Medicare, five million elderly and disabled people, almost one in seven, have joined a health maintenance organization, almost all in the last 12 years. 
 Each month, 100,000 more sign up, trading the freedom to choose their doctors and hospitals for the simplicity and lower costs of managed care. And though the proportion of elderly in managed care is far less than the majority of working Americans in such plans, the budget agreement will very likely speed the narrowing of that gap.
It provides for higher payments to H.M.O.'s in rural areas, which will most likely draw more elderly patients into managed health plans, without cutting the generous payments that have allowed urban H.M.O.'s to offer broad coverage.
Patients have the legal right to return to traditional Medicare if they later become unhappy with their health maintenance organizations. But going back is not easy because fee-for-service coverage for the elderly is becoming more costly.
Under the budget agreement, the $43.80 monthly Medicare premium for doctors' care and other nonhospital charges will gradually rise to $105.40 by 2007, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
Meanwhile, after four years of shadowing the general inflation rate, premiums for the so-called Medigap policies that supplement traditional Medicare are rising sharply as well.
No one has analyzed the latest rates set by the hundreds of insurance companies that sell Medigap coverage. But last year, the average cost of a basic Medigap policy rose 31.4 percent in Arizona, 32.4 percent in Ohio and 27.2 percent in Virginia, said Lisa Alecxih, who headed a recent study of Medigap plans conducted by the Lewin Group, a research firm in Alexandria, Va., for the Commonwealth Fund.
Not least of the reasons why Medigap rates are skyrocketing is that it is the healthier elderly who are joining health maintenance organizations, leaving a smaller pool of sicker people in the market for Medigap coverage. Moreover, most private carriers and Blue Cross plans now base their Medigap charges on age, so older people pay higher premiums. And even the American Association of Retired Persons, which does not have age-based premiums, raised its prices by 45 percent in the last two years, opening the floodgates to increases by commercial carriers, health finance experts said.
The bottom line is that out-of-pocket spending on health care by the elderly averages more than $2,600 a year, or 21 percent of their income, according to another Commonwealth Fund study.
So while the Clinton Administration says it favors choice for the 38 million people served by Medicare, remaining in -- or returning to -- traditional Medicare is becoming a luxury beyond the reach of many people of modest means, just as working people are being priced out of traditional fee-for-service health care.
"An H.M.O. is the only way I can afford medical care," said Steven Brown, a taxi driver in Venice, Calif., who recently became eligible for Medicare.
Indeed, about five million elderly people enrolled in traditional Medicare are unable to afford any kind of Medigap plan, said Patricia Newman, director of a project on Medicare policy at the Kaiser Family Foundation. That leaves them without coverage for the first $736 of annual hospital charges, the first $100 each year of doctors' fees and then 20 percent of all remaining medical charges.
About 12 million people pay out of pocket for Medigap coverage; 9.6 million more retirees have employer-financed Medigap benefits, although many employers have been pushing their retirees, like their active employees, into health maintenance organizations.
Elderly H.M.O. members have told researchers that they prefer managed care because of the lower costs and extra benefits, made possible by lavish Government payments to health plans in cities where Medicare payments are already high.
A survey of 11,000 Medicare beneficiaries by the Sachs Group, a health care information firm, found, for example, that H.M.O. enrollees were more likely to be satisfied than those with traditional Medicare. Moreover, fewer than 100,000 each year have returned to traditional Medicare. The budget agreement would make the move back more difficult starting in 2000 by narrowing the time frame in which the switch could be made without the patient being denied coverage for pre-existing medical conditions.
The H.M.O. recruits are attracted by reduced or no monthly premiums, nominal out-of-pocket fees -- typically $5 or $10 for a visit to a doctor -- and free or low-priced extras such as prescription drugs or eyeglasses. Coverage is especially generous in California, Florida and cities like New York, Boston and Philadelphia, where Medicare rates are high, the elderly are numerous and the competition among H.M.O.'s is fierce.
Mimi Schreiber, 67, of Lakewood, Calif., said she had "loved every minute" of her care at Kaiser Permanente, a unit of Kaiser Foundation Health Plan and Hospitals and the biggest health maintenance organization in California. "If I was rich, I could afford a private doctor," she said. "You have to be realistic."
In part, such expressions of satisfaction reflect the ways that health maintenance organizations focus on the elderly population. "The beneficiaries who enroll in H.M.O.'s are systematically younger and healthier than those who don't," said Bruce C. Vladeck, head of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare. The American Association of Health Plans, an H.M.O. trade group, argues that this is not true.
Experts note that health maintenance organizations do not advertise to attract the chronically ill, who only add to their costs. "No health plan says, 'We are really good at arthritis,' " said Stan Jones, a health insurance policy analyst at George Washington University.
In fact, H.M.O. members in several surveys have expressed less satisfaction than other elderly patients when asked about delays in getting care and referrals to specialists.
Stories like that of George Thomas, a 72-year-old retired Navy pilot who lived near San Diego until recently moving to a Los Angeles suburb, fuel their fury.
As a member of a Medicare H.M.O., Mr. Thomas said, he was shuttled among hospitals and nursing homes last year and ultimately was sent home when he complained of fainting spells and intense neck pains. His weight dropped 47 pounds to a skeletal 118 in nine months, and he was too weak to walk.
"He was dying," his daughter, Sharon Cain, said. "His doctor in San Diego threw up his hands and said, 'I don't know what else I can do.' "
Luckily, Superman came to Mr. Thomas's rescue. His grandson, Dean Cain, the actor who played the superhero in ABC's "Lois and Clark: The New Adventures of Superman," arranged to have Mr. Thomas transferred to the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center.
Because FHP International, Mr. Thomas's health plan, refused to approve the move, Mr. Cain said he had to provide a $30,000 cashier's check before U.C.L.A. would admit his grandfather. The Los Angeles doctors diagnosed a dangerous spinal infection that had also damaged Mr. Thomas's heart.
Now, Mr. Thomas is suing FHP, contending that the health plan and its doctors failed "to provide reasonably necessary care" without regard to cost, as required by state and Federal H.M.O. regulations. The suit contends that FHP and the doctors knew that "financial considerations" would "override reasonable patient care needs."
Cheryl Brady, a spokeswoman for Pacificare Health System, which bought FHP in February, said the H.M.O. was "not aware that they had any problems, or an issue over the quality of care or the treatment being provided by the medical group." After the suit was filed, Pacificare recently paid part of the U.C.L.A. hospital bill.
Mr. Thomas, who is back on his feet and feeling stronger, said he would like to return to traditional Medicare. But like many older patients, he said he was unable to find a Medigap insurer that would cover his "existing conditions" -- not to mention the $500 he spends each month for medicine.

HEADLINE: Madeleine Albright Sings Out

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's belting parody of "Don't Cry for Me, Argentina" at this week's meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations drew critical acclaim from her fellow foreign ministers. They were not as happy with her speeches, which some dismissed as patronizing lectures on human rights. Americans, however, would consider her performance a spirited defense of their values, exactly the kind of plain speaking Ms. Albright promised when she took the job, and exactly what Asean needed to hear.
Ms. Albright offended by speaking the truth. After the Foreign Minister of Myanmar, once known as Burma, depicted his country as a human rights paradise, Ms. Albright quickly set the record straight. She also unsuccessfully tried to convince Japan, an Asean observer, to suspend aid to Cambodia. After a coup there earlier this month, Asean uncharacteristically reversed its earlier decision to admit Cambodia. But its members considered Ms. Albright's plea an unwarranted interference in Cambodia's affairs. 
 Leaders in Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore have long argued that Asians do not value or need individual political and civil rights and that governments should not try to force these concepts on others. In Asia, these leaders say, the interests of society trump those of the individual. They also point to the importance of economic rights and their own nations' notable success in reducing poverty. At the Asean meeting, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia even endorsed rewriting the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which he said did not suit developing countries. That document, adopted in 1948, does contain the right to a decent standard of living, but focuses mainly on political and civil rights.
The Asian-values argument is hollow. Numerous studies have shown that whether a country is a democracy or an autocracy has little effect on its economic growth. Asean's members need only look in the mirror. The Philippines, a democracy, grew nearly 7 percent last year. Myanmar, ruled by a repressive military junta, is nearly bankrupt, in part due to swollen military spending.
It would be easier to take these leaders' concerns about Asian values seriously if they were not so self-serving. No one knows if Indonesians want political rights, because they are not allowed to say so. But everyone knows that life would become unpleasant for Indonesia's Government if journalists could expose official corruption or citizens could vote freely. Malaysia's Dr. Mahathir did not enhance his credibility, moreover, when he accused the American financier and philanthropist George Soros of trying to bring down Asian currencies because Asean admitted Myanmar.
Ms. Albright drew criticism not only for what she said, but also because she dared to say it at all. American officials do indeed spend much of their time telling the rest of the world what to do. But Ms. Albright is speaking out for freedom. Asean is a cozy club of mainly authoritarian leaders whose human rights policies benefit themselves at the expense of their people. We hope Ms. Albright will return next year for an encore.

HEADLINE: Economic Analysis;
Measuring Productivity in the 90's: Optimists vs. Skeptics

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
To hear Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, tell it, along with various bulls on Wall Street and assorted chief executives, the United States is entering a period in which the productivity of the American worker is accelerating in ways reminiscent of the best years of the country's economy. And that is why the economy is strong, stock prices are rising and both will continue upward.
The productivity enthusiasts pushing this view argue that the new electronic technologies have finally been harnessed and exploited in the workplace. Starting in 1994 or so, they say, the nation's workers have been producing more for each hour and each day they work. Most important, this improvement will last, they say. 
 Their enthusiasm, however, relies heavily on their own narrow measures of productivity -- measures they consider more accurate -- and on circumstantial evidence. The official broad statistics flatly deny that productivity is rising. Quite the contrary, they show it weaker than ever in the 1990's. Many economists, embracing the official statistics, are skeptical of the bullish view. And even on Wall Street there are those who contend that the productivity optimists, including Mr. Greenspan, are engaging in "creative statistics" to make their case.
"Productivity is a broad national concept that does not lend itself to mining statistical data for favorable results," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "I am really critical of Mr. Greenspan for doing that."
The stakes in this debate are enormous. The performance of the stock market and the future financing of Social Security and Medicare are increasingly tied to the outcome.
Corporate profits, for example, have been growing lately at more than double the rate of growth of the economy itself. In the absence of rising prices, that can only be happening, the productivity optimists say, if workers are producing more for a given day's work, and the added revenue from their production is going into profits. The rising profits, in turn, have justified rising stock prices. And the expectation that profits will continue to rise, thanks to the growing productivity, keeps the Dow Jones average climbing.
"Improved productivity has played a key role in profit margins, profit growth and the resulting rise in stock prices," said Abby Joseph Cohen, chief equity strategist for Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Beyond Wall Street, rising productivity and rising profits in the years ahead would mean rising tax revenues, just when the Federal Government needs the money to help pay for Medicare and Social Security as baby boomers retire. That has made the Administration distinctly sympathetic to the rising productivity argument. "It makes Social Security and Medicare much less of a crisis," said Lee Price, the Commerce Department's Acting Under Secretary for Economic Affairs.
Productivity measures a worker's output in a given time period. Take as an example a long-distance telephone operator. Her company has furnished her with an array of new computers and software. As a result, she increases the hourly revenue that she brings the company from toll calls to $1,022 from $1,000 -- money that can go into profits or wages or both. This operator's 2.2 percent productivity improvement was in fact roughly the rate of productivity growth for the nation's entire work force in the postwar decades, until 1973.
The 1990's are a different matter. While many workers are indeed becoming more efficient, the official statistics say that the average rate of productivity improvement for the private sector work force as a whole during the 90's has been only nine-tenths of 1 percent annually.
The skeptics believe that discouraging statistic. They argue that as wages rise, and they are beginning to do so, the higher pay will either cut into profits, hurting the stock market, or force companies to raise prices. With inflation rising, the Federal Reserve will respond by raising interest rates to slow the economy. Mr. Greenspan says that rising productivity may be saving the day, but he makes no bones about what Fed policy will be if he is wrong.
The productivity optimists start with the accurate observation that the nation enjoys today a rare combination of healthy economic growth, rising profits, low inflation and plentiful employment. While others more pessimistically argue that this current, happy moment can be explained as a temporary phenomenon -- a result mainly of shifting corporate income into profits and away from wages -- the optimists insist that rising productivity is the only explanation that solves the puzzle.
They charge that the official productivity measure, showing very weak growth, is inaccurate, a victim of mismeasurement. To make their case, they explore a range of statistics for evidence that their thesis is correct. Or they adopt more positive, narrower measures of productivity, as Mr. Greenspan has done.
One test came this week, when the Commerce Department announced updated estimates of how much the economy, as measured by the gross domestic product, has actually grown since late 1992. The productivity optimists had expected a sharp upward revision. The G.D.P., in effect, adds together all the final sales -- retail sales and telephone tolls, for example -- to gauge the total output of the economy in a given year. The higher the output for the same number of hours worked, the higher the productivity growth rate.
But the G.D.P. revision was minor. The average annual growth from 1992's last quarter through this year's first quarter was revised upward by only one-tenth of 1 percent, to 2.8 percent, not enough to make a difference in productivity.
The revision held another disappointment for the productivity enthusiasts. While the Commerce Department and most economists consider adding together all final sales as the most accurate measure of output, the productivity enthusiasts would prefer to add together "income" -- that is, all the wages, salaries, dividends and profits earned in producing the national output.
Theoretically, the "income" measure of G.D.P. should equal the "product" measure. But in recent years, income has been running well ahead of product, suggesting a higher productivity growth rate than Government statisticians accept as accurate. The productivity enthusiasts had hoped the revision would close that gap by raising the product calculation to the level of income. That did not happen.
Still, Mr. Greenspan embraces the income approach. Basing his decision on research by two Fed economists, he has decided that the more accurate measure of national productivity is really contained in a subset of the overall statistic. The overall statistic covers all three private sectors: financial, corporate and noncorporate.
Mr. Greenspan's new favorite measure covers only the corporate sector, leaving out the two others, which he considers harder to measure. While the overall productivity statistic shows just under 1 percent annual growth in the 1990's, the corporate sector has averaged 1.5 percent, surging to more than 2.5 percent in the last 24 months. While "product" is used to calculate output for overall productivity, the higher "income" calculation determines corporate productivity.
The difference in these two measures, the Fed said in a just-released report signed by Mr. Greenspan, "raises the possibility that overall productivity is stronger than indicated by the official index for nonfarm business."
To which Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley replies: "What Mr. Greenspan is doing is taking apart the national trend and finding a piece of it that fits his story."

A few ecnomists argue that the broad productivity measure that most of their colleagues follow is less accurate than figures that cover only corporations. Graph shows average annual percentage change in output for each hour worked. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)(pg. 33)

HEADLINE: U.S. LIFTS A BAN ON WEAPON SALES TO LATIN AMERICA

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Reversing a policy enacted two decades ago because of human rights concerns, the Clinton Administration announced today that it would lift the ban on sales of the most advanced weapons, like fighter jets and tanks, to countries in Latin America.
President Carter imposed the ban in 1978, determined to deny advanced weaponry to the military dictatorships that then ruled most of Central and South America. In recent years, though, the Pentagon and the nation's military contractors have pressed the White House to allow some sales, arguing that most of the countries, except Cuba, are now moving toward democracy. 
 The Administration said it would now consider allowing arms sales "case by case," essentially putting Latin American countries through the same approval process as other countries. In announcing the change, the Administration insisted that selling the weapons would help stabilize the region and bolster the transition to democracy.
"It is in America's national security interest to promote stability and security among our neighbors in the hemisphere by engaging with them as equal partners as they modernize and restructure their defense establishments," said a statement released today by the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry.
The reversal is a victory for the big military contractors, like the Lockheed Martin Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. While the arms market in Latin America is relatively small -- ranging from $500 million to as much as $2 billion a year, most of it for aircraft -- the change could open markets in countries that have in the past bought weapons elsewhere.
"Latin American countries will now be able to consider American products as well as European and other," said Joel L. Johnson, a vice president of the Aerospace Industries Association in Washington, which represents aircraft makers. "We have had for the last two decades a policy of unilateral paternalism, in which we've told them they shouldn't have modern military equipment. And the end result is they bought it elsewhere."
The Administration's decision, which followed an internal review that dragged on for more than a year, drew immediate criticism from lawmakers and arms-control advocates. They say that Latin American democracies remain unstable and that an influx of advanced weapons could set off an arms race in the region and rekindle traditional rivalries like those between Chile and Argentina, or Peru and Ecuador.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, denounced the change and said he would redouble efforts to pass legislation restoring the restrictions on sales. Representatvie Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat from New York, has introduced similar legislation in the House.
"I continue to believe that the 20-year policy has worked and is the right policy," Mr. Dodd said. "I find it hard to believe that selling sophisticated aircraft, such as F-16's, helps to maintain regional security and stability."
Perhaps anticipating criticism, the White House made the announcement with little fanfare, issuing a statement today as Congress broke for its August recess.
The previous policy was not a blanket ban on sales of weapons including jets, helicopters, tanks and radar systems. Instead it was "a policy of restraint with the presumption of denial." In practice, though, only once did the United States allow an exemption for a major sale, permitting Venezuela to buy 24 F-16 fighter jets in 1981 because of its fears about Soviet troops stationed in Cuba.
The Pentagon, under Secretary of Defense William J. Perry, asked President Clinton to review the policy two years ago. Chile, which made its transition to democracy from military rule in 1990, also promoted the reconsideration, expressing an interest in buying 18 to 24 F-16's.
The review led to an internal debate. Warren Christopher, Secretary of State at the time, told the Senate's Committee on Foreign Relations, "I think we should show great restraint in introducing new or high levels of weapons into areas where they do not presently have them."
In January, however, Mr. Christopher joined Mr. Perry in recommending the review before both stepped down. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright also supported the change, State Department officials said, but Mr. Clinton held off on a decision until now as opponents in the Administration continued to argue against it.
Administration officials said today that even now the United States scrutinize each request closely, granting sales only to those countries with solidifying democracies and firm civilian control over the military. Also, officials said the United States would not approve sales to countries with unresolved conflicts, like Peru and Ecuador, which battled along their border just last year.
"It's a lifting of the ban, not an invitation to an arms race," Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the President's special coordinator for Latin American policy, said.
The likelihood of military conflict in Latin America has certainly declined in recent years as countries moved toward civilian governments and increasingly integrated their economies.
Thomas E. McNamara, the Assistant Secretary of State for Political-Military Affairs, said the United States had to allow countries in Latin America to modernize their militaries, as any modern democracy would. Jeffrey S. Davidow, the Assistant Secretary for Inter-American Affairs, said the change was "a sensitive decision" but was the next step in relations with the region.
"If we're going to deal with these countries as democracies," he said, "I think we have to have a little faith and confidence in them."

HEADLINE: Strong Economic Data Send Bonds Sharply Lower, Stocks Less So

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
For weeks, investors have been pushing interest rates lower and stock prices higher on the belief that the economic outlook was a combination of moderate growth and low inflation.
But with the July employment data and purchasing managers report issued yesterday, they got a hint that growth is not moderating as much as they had thought. This made them think of inflation and wonder how much longer the Federal Reserve could hold off raising interest rates. And they ran for the hills. 
 In the sharpest selloff in the bond market in more than a year, the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond jumped to 6.45 percent, from 6.29 percent on Thursday. And in stocks, the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks initially tumbled more than 1 percent.
But while bonds kept falling, the stock market rebounded, with the Dow -- which had been down 118 points, finishing off 28.57, at 8,194.04, and the Nasdaq composite up 0.52 point, at 1,594.33. Still, declining stocks led advancers by a nearly 2-to-1 margin.
The rebound in stocks late in the afternoon may be a signal that the new economic data, while surprising, do not change the optimistic outlook significantly. Or it may be a tribute to the incredible resilience of a market that has the backing of millions of investors who are pouring their money into equity mutual funds.
While analysts were cautious about interpretations of the new data, there was no rush to revise forecasts or change predictions about when the Federal Reserve might see enough signs of rising inflation to increase interest rates. They are now 5.5 percent, and the central bank is still expected to remain on hold for some time.
"You can say that things are not in the nirvana state that we have believed in," said Cheryl R. Katz, senior economist at Merrill Lynch. "Or you can look at the data and say 'hey, wait,' they are not really consistent with other economic numbers." She took the latter approach, sticking with a forecast of moderate growth, low inflation, a steady Federal Reserve and, therefore, a positive outlook for bonds and stocks.
The July jobs report showed that the unemployment rate had dropped to 4.8 percent and that 316,000 new nonfarm jobs had been created. The 316,000 was higher than the 200,000 expected and signaled that labor pressure -- which could lead to higher wages -- had not eased.
But the data that generated more selling in both the bond and stock markets were in the report of the National Association of Purchasing Management. Its factory index rose to 58.6 in July from 55.7 in June. At the same time, the closely watched index of prices paid jumped to 53.6, from 48.1 in June.
Both the jobs and purchasing managers reports indicated that the economy was going to be growing faster in the third quarter than in the second, said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. But, he added, it is still unclear how much faster. He is forecasting growth of 2.5 percent to 3 percent, compared with the 2.2 percent annual pace in the second quarter and the 4.9 percent rate in the first quarter.
The longer-term issue, he said, "is whether this stronger growth translates into inflationary pressure."
"Until you see signs of inflationary pressures, it's hard to be bearish, he added. "The question is how bullish are you going to be."
And he noted that while the headline numbers in the jobs report were higher than expected, other data, including average weekly hours, manufacturing overtime and the manufacturing workweek all declined last month.
Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation, saw a little more to worry about than some others in yesterday's data. He cited three warnings of rising inflation: the rise in the prices-paid index and a slowdown in supplier deliveries, both in the purchasing managers report, and an increase in the ratio of those employed to the number of people able to work.
"It's not alarming, but it's a cause for concern," he said, adding that he no longer considered it a "sure bet" that the Fed would not raise interest rates when its policy-making committee meets in August and September.
Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at Nationsbank, is still positive about the outlook for stocks and bonds, although he thinks that rates could rise in the near term as the economy picks up some. "The market was good news-vulnerable," he said, referring to its recent gains. "Now, with these types of numbers, the market is going to be wary of the pickup of growth and could be bad news-vulnerable."
In the bond market, the selloff was aggravated, said William Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs, by the prospect of the Treasury's quarterly auction of notes and bonds next week, an event that can add uncertainty.
In the stock market, the Standard and Poor's index did not rebound as well as the Dow, finishing down 7.15 points at 947.14.
J. P. Morgan, which fell 1 3/8, to 114 1/2, led the Dow lower. But it also contributed to the Dow's rebound as it came back from a low of 112 1/4 on the day. Only a few Dow index stocks finished higher, led by Caterpillar, which was up 215/16 , to 5815/16 . The most actively traded stock on all markets, Intel, rose 113/16 , to 93 5/8, on volume of nearly 22 million shares.
While stocks fared better than bonds yesterday, it might be hard for them to move much higher if the bond market does not follow suit by rebounding next week.

HEADLINE: Mir Shadow Falls on Russian Role in Space

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: KOROLYOV, Russia

 BODY:
Forty years after launching the world's first satellite, Russia is struggling to conquer space on a shoestring.
The establishment that sought to beat the United States in the space race has been forced to contend with plummeting budgets, shaky political support and a drain on its scientific talent. 
 Now it has the Mir, the space station that has been plagued by accidents, malfunctions and crew problems.
The Mir's Spektr module was punctured in a collision with an unmanned cargo vessel on June 25. A new crew, blasting off on Aug. 5, is to try to restore full electrical power to the space station, and future crews may try to patch the hole, a repair job that has not even been tried in space before.
With NASA and the European space program paying hundreds of millions of dollars to station astronauts on the Mir, there is a lot riding on the repair effort. But the effort is also about national pride -- no small matter for the space establishment that put the first man in space and still operates the world's only space station.
If Russia can repair the Mir, it will demonstrate that it is still a vital repository of experience and expertise on space operations. Failure will be exploited by the growing legions of critics, who say that the glory days of the Russian space program are past and that NASA is endangering its astronauts by training them on the 11-year-old space station.
Nonetheless, the best and the brightest of Russia's space program are counting on the success of the repair mission. "My feeling is that after we think more, and make additional plans, we can restore almost everything on this space station," insisted Sergei Krikalyov, 38, the deputy flight controller, who has spent 15 months in space.
The space program that the Mir has come to symbolize has become increasingly fragmented since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. A commercial program for launching foreign satellites is largely successful. The Mir may have its troubles, but it is also long lived. Still, planetary science is being squeezed out in the battle for dwindling money.
The contrast with Soviet days is stark. During the cold war, in addition to a hefty budget for military space operations, Russia spent heavily on its civilian space program. In 1989, the civilian space budget was $3.2 billion, according to the Russian Space Agency.
Since then the civilian space budget has declined precipitously, to less than a tenth of that of the United States. Spending also lags behind the budgets of the Western Europeans and Japan. It is just slightly larger than India's space budget.
The budget crunch has its humiliations. Last year, the Mir and its crew were rented out for a Pepsi television commercial. A version of the Buran, the Soviet space shuttle that in 1988 flew only one mission, is an amusement park ride at Gorky Park in Moscow.
It has also injected a powerful note of uncertainty into space planning.
Last year, President Boris N. Yeltsin's Government was forced to rip up its own budget plan after it failed to collect enough taxes. The Government began distributing funds to Government ministries and agencies and then stopped mid-stream when the money ran out.
This year, budget politics again played havoc with the Russian Space Agency's plans. Parliament approved $650 million for 1997. But Yuri Koptev, the head of the agency, said in an interview that his agency would actually receive only $535 million.
That is hardly the only budget headache. Mr. Yeltsin has repeatedly promised the West that Russia will pay for and build a critical module for the navigation and control of a new international space station. Reflecting pride in their space station, the Russians have taken to calling the module Mir II.
Russia's failure to deliver the module on schedule -- a launching is set for late 1998 -- could delay the completion of the space station and lead to pressure to ease Russia out of the space-station consortium. So to insure its completion, the Yeltsin Government approved a special appropriation of $260 million this year in addition to the regular space agency budget.
But the space agency has yet to receive all of the money.
Mr. Koptev said the agency received $140 million in the form of Government-guaranteed credits from Russian banks. But then economic reformers in the Yeltsin Government decided that the practice violated budgetary discipline and shut off the credits.
To get the remaining $120 million, Mr. Koptev has asked Mr. Yeltsin to sign a decree, tapping funds provided to Russia from international organization like the International Monetary Fund and World Bank and other international organizations. Russian space officials expect Mr. Yeltsin to sign the decree next week.
The results of the monetary squeeze are apparent even in the secretive military Russian space program. In May, the Russians successfully launched a photo-reconnaissance satellite. Until that launching, the Russians had not had one in orbit for almost eight months, the longest gap since 1962.
In the civilian realm, the Russians have stopped maneuvering their communication satellites out of geosynchronous orbits as they near the end of their useful life, a standard practice to reduce the problem of space junk. Now they push the satellites to the limit and allow them to die in orbit.
They have also cut back on resupply missions to the Mir and delayed replacing its crews when the program ran out of booster rockets.
No area of space activity is harder hit than planetary science, which has taken a back seat to work on the space station.
During the cold war, some 1,500 scientists and support staff worked at the Soviet Space Research Institute to keep the Soviet Union on the cutting edge of space science. Now the staff has been cut by a third, and many of the scientists who are supposed to be working there actually spend valuable time away from the institute at their second or third jobs.
It is easy to understand why. The monthly salaries of scientists at the institute range from $87 to $175 for someone at the highest level.
"The number of personnel has diminished, and we have lost intellectual power," said Vyacheslav N. Linkin, a laboratory director at the institute.
Last year, the planetary program suffered a devastating setback when the launching of a Mars probe failed, sending the device crashing into South America. Russian scientists have been unable to identify the cause of the failure, which resulted in the loss of $180 million in scientific instruments because the Russians had decided not to send a vessel to monitor the launching to sea in order to save money.
Mr. Linkin said the institute needed to devise a cheaper research plan based on smaller payloads and booster rockets. Under the current plan, the main program to launch an astrophysics laboratory has been delayed to 1999, five years past its original launching date.
Because of these economic woes, the Russian space program has become increasingly dependent on foreign funds. This industrial town where the control center is situated is named after the legendary space designer Sergei Korolyov, whose very name was treated as a state secret in Soviet times. And a marble bust of a pensive Lenin still watches over the reception area at the Mission Control Center. But now the control center is festooned with a banner from Hewlett-Packard, the computer company.
According to Mr. Koptev, about 40 percent of Russia's production of rocket boosters and other space components is underwritten by foreign funds. NASA is paying the Russians $473 million over five years, mostly to train its astronauts and conduct experiments on the Mir.
The Russians are receiving another $190 million for one of the two modules the Russians are building for the new international space station. The module is being built by Russia's Khrunichev factory under a contract with Boeing.
Russia is also developing a successful business in launching foreign satellites for profit.
With their eye on the bottom line, the Russians have been careful not to let the drop in the production of space boosters affect their deadlines.
"Commercial launches is a big priority," said Geoffrey Perry, the head of the Kettering Group, based in England, a worldwide association of space observers. "They have not dumped a commercial payload."
Seeking to drum up business, Mr. Koptev insists that Russian space launchings are far less costly than in the West. Even so, he concedes, foreign funds are not a panacea.
"Our task is to get better financing from the state," he said.
Still, Russia also boasts some of the world's best and most experienced space scientists. They have vast experience in lifting large payloads into orbit and pioneered the space station. Russian astronauts also have unparalleled experience in long duration space travel.
And many Western experts say it would be a mistake to count the Russians out.
"They are alive, but in trouble," said Dr. Louis D. Friedman, the director of the Planetary Society, a nongovernmental organization, based in Pasadena, Calif., dedicated to space research. "The Russians have had extraordinary achievements in space, and losing them would mean losing a major part of the capability in space science."
At mission control, Mr. Krikalyov is staking his considerable reputation on success. The veteran astronaut was on the Mir when the Soviet Union collapsed and was forced to extend his stay. He was the first Russian to ride on the American space shuttle. And he has been selected to serve on the first crew of the new international space station.
Since the June 25 collision, however, Mr. Krikalyov has spent hours in a water tank and vacuum chamber trying to fix the Mir under conditions that approximate those in space.
Fixing the hole in the Mir is the hard part, he says, because it has never been done in outer space.
"We need to find out whether it possible to do this in a spacesuit," Mr. Krikalyov said during a break in his 15-hour day. "We need to see if the materials and tools can work in a vacuum."
American astronauts have likened life in Mir to a camping trip in a dirty old car.
American lawmakers have all but dubbed it a deathtrap.
But where critics see an anachronism, Mr. Krikalyov insists there is a proven design.
"If something happens with one module, you can seal it off and work in another module," he said admiringly. "The modular design of the space station is very successful."

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Backs Down in Tiff With Belarussian Over Arrests

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Even as an international human rights organization met with the Belarussian authorities in Minsk to demand the release of three detained Russian reporters, President Boris N. Yeltsin retracted criticism of the Belarussian President today, and promised that the journalists' detention would not affect their relationship.
Human Rights Watch/Helsinki today published a searing 51-page report documenting President Aleksandr R. Lukashenko's systematic repression of civic organizations, opposition groups and the press. The report said Belarus "bears an eerie and increasing resemblance to Soviet society." 
 Long before the Belarussian President started his crackdown on Russian reporters, the West had condemned his increasingly bizarre and dictatorial behavior. In March, Belarus expelled a United States diplomat as a spy. And the United States has suspended $40 million in foreign aid to Belarus because of the country's human rights record.
But Moscow signed a reunification agreement with Mr. Lukashenko in May, and his growing campaign against the Russian press has made it increasingly difficult for Mr. Yeltsin to defend the merger.
On Wednesday, Mr. Yeltsin threatened to revoke the reunification treaty if Mr. Lukashenko did not free the reporters from the state-owned Russian network ORT who are in jail in Minsk and under investigation in connection with espionage, according to the Belarussian security services. They were arrested last week and charged with illegally crossing the Belarussian-Lithuanian border.
Mr. Lukashenko defied the Russian leader. "I will explain myself to Yeltsin," he told reporters, "after he explains the war launched against me by Russian TV channels."
His Government hauled 15 Russian and Western reporters who protested their colleagues' arrest into a Minsk courtroom today, fining 6 and releasing 8 others with a warning.
And today, his truculence paid off, at least in the Kremlin.
Mr. Lukashenko huffily canceled a visit to Kaliningrad today and lodged a complaint with the Russian Foreign Ministry after the local Governor asked him to postpone it because of concern over the fate of the Russian TV crew. Mr. Yeltsin's spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, said the Governor, Leonid Gorbenko, had acted unilaterally and "harmfully."
Mr. Yeltsin is under pressure from nationalists and Communists and many of his allies to press ahead with reunification. The President, who is vacationing in Samara, reconsidered his tough stance and tried to placate Mr. Lukashenko. Jocularly calling his counterpart, "young, quick-tempered and not as good at sweating criticism as I am," Mr. Yeltsin said today that the arrest of the Russian journalists "will not affect our cooperation or relations."
Mr. Yeltsin is particularly intent on not antagonizing Mr. Lukashenko these days because he did so more significantly in April, when he allowed his aides to dilute a charter on integration with Belarus on the eve of its signing. The first draft was hastily rewritten by economic reformers in the Russian Cabinet who feared the economic and political consequences of shackling Russia to its poor and backward neighbor.
That rebuke from the Kremlin has not chastened Mr. Lukashenko. He has resisted any attempts at reforming and decentralizing the economy and has instead turned his country of 10 million people into a kind of totalitarian biosphere. His Government routinely uses club-wielding riot policemen to break up demonstrations,and arrests and intimidates artists, dissidents and nationalist opponents.
In addition to the arrest of the reporters, Mr. Lukashenko has recently yanked the accreditations of a number of Russian TV network correspondents. In March, he expelled a correspondent from the privately owned Russian network NTV, whose alleged infractions included the fact that he had Israeli citizenship.
Mr. Lukashenko, who has spoken admiringly of Hitler and Stalin, disbanded Parliament last year when it refused to increase his powers. In April, he imposed a $3 million fine on the Belarussian branch of the Soros Foundation, on allegations of currency exchange violations. The foundation, which had invested $13 million in educational and civic projects, suspended its operations.
But, particularly in the wake of NATO expansion, reunification with Belarus remains a strong emotional issue for Russian nationalists. Some of Mr. Yeltsin's top foreign policy advisers, including Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov, have been lobbying to speed up integration as a response to the West's plans to expand NATO eastward.

HEADLINE: $1.2 Million For a Plan On the Future Of a Harbor

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Hoping to win more than $1 billion in Federal funds to expand shipping in New York Harbor, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has agreed to spend $1.2 million on a plan to revitalize wharves from Brooklyn to Bayonne.
The plan has to be completed before the Port Authority can compete for Federal aid. But it is also aimed at reassuring international shipping companies that both states are serious about keeping the harbor's channels deep enough, and cargo-handling equipment modern enough, to serve the tankers and giant container ships of the future, with drafts of 45 or 50 feet. 
 Confidence in the future of New York Harbor dimmed in recent years after channel dredging became paralyzed when New York and New Jersey could not agree on where to dump dredged silt, much of which contained traces of hazardous pollutants. The states are developing a list of repositories for the tainted mud but until now have never drawn up a thorough plan for modernizing the port, Port Authority officials said.
The plan, to be completed in six to nine months, will help determine how the states can get the most economic benefit from investments in new wharf space, cargo-handling equipment, roads and rail lines, said Chris Ward, the director of port redevelopment for the authority.
He said the flow of ships loaded with food, furniture and other goods to and from the East Coast was expected to double in 25 years. "All that traffic has to come through somewhere," he said, mentioning Philadelphia, Norfolk, Va., and Halifax, Nova Scotia, as competitors.
Mr. Ward said the analysis would favor neither the New York side of the harbor, where many piers sit idle, nor the New Jersey side, which has had the largest share of harbor commerce since the 1970's.
"It's not a New York-versus-New Jersey issue," Mr. Ward said. "We're going to need all of our assets. Whether it's Brooklyn or Staten Island, Newark or Bayonne, we're going to need it all in play to capture this growth."
Among other things, Mr. Ward said, the analysis will seek uses for the dredged mud. For example, it could be used as fill along deteriorated shorelines near existing wharves, he said, creating new space for handling cargo.
By deciding where the Port Authority should invest its resources, Mr. Ward said, the plan would also help shape a simultaneous study by the Federal Army Corps of Engineers that will assess the cost and benefits of deepening the harbor's main channels to 50 feet.
Tom Dowd, a professor of port and marine transportation management at the University of Washington in Seattle, said this kind of analysis is essential if New York Harbor is to flourish in the next century.
"Facilities, docks, channels, and equipment all have to be continually modified and modernized to stay competitive," he said. "Thirty years ago, if you wanted to move something to Chicago, you sent it through New York and put it on a truck. That's all changed."
New York Harbor's competitors are already busy with new plans of their own. In 1995, a direct rail link was opened between Halifax and the American Midwest, carrying double-decker train cars of containers. Partly as a result of that link, the amount of goods moving through the port is steadily rising, said Dennis Creamer, a vice president of the Halifax Port Corporation. "In 1997, we're up 30 percent from last year," he said.

INTERNATIONAL 3-5
 
White House Removes Ban On Latin American Arms
The Clinton Administration said it would end a ban on sales of advanced weapons to Latin American countries; the ban was imposed 19 years ago out of human rights concerns during an era of military dictatorships. 1
 
Mideast Recriminations Fly
After two suicide bombers killed 13 people in Jerusalem, Israel accused the Palestinian leadership of laxity towards terrorism, and Palestinian officials charged that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu wanted the peace talks to fail. All but 2 of the 18 members of Yasir Arafat's Cabinet tendered their resignation, saying the Palestinian leader needed freedom to act in the crisis. 1 

Russian Space Heritage at Risk
Drastic budget cuts have challenged the survival of Russia's once proud space program, now readying its mission to repair the damaged space station Mir. 1
 
Yeltsin Placates Belarus Chief
President Boris Yeltsin of Russia retracted his criticism of President Aleksandr Lukashenko of Belarus, saying that relations between the two countries would not be affected by Mr. Lukashenko's detention of three Russian reporters on charges of espionage. International human rights organizations condemned the detentions and Mr. Lukashenko's authoritarian style of governing as bearing an "eerie and increasing resemblance to Soviet society." 5
 
Cease-Fire Eludes Algeria
Hopes that the Algerian Government's release of a leader of the Islamic Salvation Front, a militant group, would lead to a cease-fire and eventual peace were dashed by a spate of renewed violence. The military was reported to have swept into an insurgent area south of the capital, and shortly afterward more than 50 villagers were killed and mutilated in what many think was a response by the hard-line Armed Islamic Group. 3
 
Salvador Scion Jailed in Scandal
A prominent figure in El Salvador's governing right-wing party has been implicated in a scandal in which $115 million are missing from two investment companies he manages. Roberto Mathies Hill, from one of the wealthiest families in the country, has been jailed with four other business leaders for fraud. 4
 
Gypsies Seek Compensation
As Hungary's gypsies began to gather in Budapest to commemorate the deaths of half a million European gypsies in the Holocaust, a demand was made in Parliament seeking collective compensation for the tens of thousands of gypsies killed by Hungarian Nazis. Florian Farkas, who represents the country's 500,000 gypsies in Parliament, sought to widen an existing law that allows individual compensation cases. (Agence France-Presse)
 
NATIONAL 6-9
 
'Senator No' Wields Fear As a Legislative Weapon
Senator Jesse Helms' ability to block single-handedly William F. Weld's nomination to be Ambassador to Mexico is only the latest example of a Washington axiom: Everyone is afraid of the Republican from North Carolina. Mr. Helms, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations, has a decades-long history of using the Senate rules as a legislative roadblock to further his crusades against Communism and to press his conservative social agenda. His efforts to delay, in some cases halt, Presidential nominations or to sabotage legislation have earned him the nickname, "Senator No." 1
 
Cancers Feared From Fallout
Fallout from nuclear blasts at the Nevada Test Site near Las Vegas may have caused from 10,000 to 75,000 thyroid cancers, 70 percent of which have not yet been diagnosed, the National Cancer Institute said. Three-quarters of those cases are expected to develop in people who were younger than 5 at the time of exposure, which occurred in 1952, 1953, 1955 and 1957, the Institute said. Medical experts say that about 10 percent of such cancers are fatal. 6

Families with children, students and investors are not the only people who will benefit from the first Federal income tax cut in 16 years. A sixth woman has come forward to accuse the Army's most senior enlisted soldier of misconduct, the Army announced. The Army has preliminarily charged Sergeant Major Gene C. McKinney with assault and battery and with maltreatment of a subordinate. 8

BUSINESS DAY 31-45
 
Unemployment Falls Again
The economy entered the summer with fresh strength, as an unexpected number of new jobs dropped the nation's unemployment rate to 4.8 percent last month, matching a 23-year low set in May, Government figures showed. While analysts had predicted that the economy would rebound from a spring slowdown, the jobs data, combined with a private report on manufacturing, fanned fears that the rebound would be too strong. Investors, who have been pushing bond and stock prices higher on the belief that growth is moderate and inflation tame, wondered whether the Federal Reserve would now need to apply the brakes with an increase in interest rates. 1
 
Total Auto Sales Increase
Auto sales rose a combined 5.6 percent last month compared with the same period a year earlier for the 11 auto makers reporting sales results. Ford, which will release July sales data next week, said it would hold overall prices steady for its 1998 models, which go on sale this autumn. 31

HEADLINE: A Flip Side to E-Z Pass: East River Tolls and Rush-Hour Prices

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Most drivers in the New York metropolitan area who have embraced the technology of electronic fare collection probably think about the E-Z Pass stickers on their cars and their little radio transponders only when they are passing through the tollbooths at places like the Tappan Zee or George Washington Bridges. That is when the system pays off for motorists, allowing them to avoid the long lines of people still using old-fashioned money.
But for the people who administer the region's highway systems, E-Z Pass represents far more than a time-saver. Collecting tolls is, in fact, only the beginning of what the system can do, and what it may hold in store in politics and economics as well as transportation. 
 Perhaps the most dramatic application, and almost certainly the most politically explosive one, concerns the question of applying electronic toll collection to places that do not now have tolls, like the East River bridge crossings into Manhattan. Although there is no move to impose new East River tolls, the idea has become, almost overnight, dramatically easier to put in place, at least in engineering terms.
Incentive pricing -- setting different toll amounts for different times of day to try to flatten out peaks in the rush hour -- has already become a reality because of E-Z Pass. The New York State Thruway Authority began a pilot project for off-peak pricing two weeks ago for trucks on the Tappan Zee and is studying whether to expand the system to include cars.
Odd new theoretical problems are emerging as well, like how to avoid "shoulders." (If you lower the fare for off-peak travel, how do you prevent having people pulling over to wait for the lower rate?) And old problems continue to haunt. (If you lower a toll at one time of day, the bond covenants that govern revenue flow at agencies like the Thruway Authority require that you raise another toll.)
"It really goes to the heart of how we're going to manage the transportation system of the future," said Emil H. Frankel, a lawyer and former Commissioner of Transportation for Connecticut.
Mr. Frankel and other transportation experts said that some of the ideas swirling around E-Z Pass technology remain largely theoretical -- but only because they have not been tried, not because they are impossible, as was the case in the past.
When William Vickrey, the Columbia University professor who is generally considered the father of incentive pricing strategies, first proposed his ideas in 1959, no way existed to make them work. A tollbooth clerk could not calculate different fares for different times of day without making everything worse.
Professor Vickrey died last October, shortly after receiving the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for his work -- too soon to see what experts say E-Z Pass can do. "It has moved pricing from academia into the offices of transportation executives," Mr. Frankel said. "It doesn't get us over the political hurdles, but it does allow us to think about it."
As with any profound change, especially one that cuts so close to political hot-buttons like taxation, the discussion of E-Z Pass is full of awkwardness and uncertainty.
Two weeks ago, for example, when the Thruway Authority eliminated the 40-cent passenger toll in Spring Valley near the Tappan Zee, it decided to make up the lost revenue by raising the fare on the bridge itself to $3, from $2.50 -- at least for regular old-fashioned toll payers. E-Z Pass holders making 17 or more trips across the bridge each month were spared -- their fare was kept the same, at $1 per trip.
The decision, transportation experts say, is the complete opposite of most of the accepted goals of traffic management, which aims at spreading out or reducing traffic: It created an economic reward for greater travel. A driver who uses the bridge a lot pays less.
The authority's chairman, Howard E. Steinberg, said the problem his agency faced in that question, as it will in the study of incentive pricing, is that it did not want to penalize people who might have no other choice but to travel when they do.
"Commuters going to and from work tend to have less flexibility, and we wouldn't want to penalize people," Mr. Steinberg said.
Some transportation agencies, notably the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, have decided not to even think about questions like that. The agency, which administers many of the bridge and tunnel crossings within New York City, requested proposals for a study of incentive pricing systems in December, but then shelved the idea in March. Critics said the agency was afraid of the E-Z Pass implications for the East River bridges.
A spokeswoman for the M.T.A., Lisa Schwartz, said the board thought the issue should be looked at "regionally" first and wanted to see what the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Thruway Authority experienced before charging ahead.
For decades, the two main obstacles to the idea of putting tolls on East River crossings like the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges centered on physical constraints and air quality. The old stand-in-line system required huge toll plazas that at various times of day could turn into parking lots of idling vehicles. That meant lots of land -- a dear commodity on either side of the river -- and lots of pollution.
Both those objections have been severely weakened, if not swept away, by automatic toll collection. Though there would still have to be tollbooths for people using cash, the waiting time -- and thus the resulting space and air quality issues -- would be reduced by widespread E-Z Pass use.
And New Yorkers are using the system. Port Authority officials said yesterday that about 22 percent of the cars crossing the George Washington Bridge were using E-Z Pass, five days after it started there.
The Thruway Authority has on its drawing board what it calls a "virtual tollbooth," which Mr. Steinberg said would probably first be tried on a stretch of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, but which would have applications for bridge travel as well. Because the E-Z Pass receivers read a car's stickers even at high speeds, drivers may no longer have to cruise slowly through a tollbooth at 5 miles per hour as they do now. E-Z Pass can dispense with booths, and plazas, and, for that matter, with toll-collecting employees.
Administrators are also learning how to avoid the "shoulders" that can be created as fares fluctuate. On the Tappan Zee, commercial truck drivers who are being discouraged from traveling during rush hour face incrementally increased fares as the morning and evening rush hours begin. The fares go back down at the end of peak periods, but the incremental changes are stretched out over 45 minutes, going up about $1 every 15 minutes depending on the size of the truck. This is so gradual, officials say, that drivers have little incentive to stop and wait for a more favorable rate to come along.

HEADLINE: Sales of Indian Crafts Rise and So Do Fakes

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: ZUNI, N.M.

 BODY:
Displayed for tourists in an "Indian jewelry" store in Albuquerque, the bracelets, pendants and rings were labeled "Made in Zuni." Precise labels would have read: Zuni, Philippines.
As demand soared for American Indian arts and crafts in the 1980's, an American jewelry manufacturer set up an assembly factory in a village in the southern Philippines. To increase sales, the manufacturer persuaded people there to rename their village after a distant and ancient people, the tribal residents of this desert corner of the American Southwest. 
 "In the Philippines, they are copying this design," Loren Panteah said as he sat at his workbench here overlooking the Zuni River and Sacred Corn Mountain. Mr. Panteah held up a $90 pair of earrings he had fashioned using tribal symbols and techniques and working with silver, turquoise, lapis lazuli and jet.
The developing nations are undercutting the United States' own underdeveloped pockets, as copies are made in the Philippines and elsewhere, and American and European shoppers snap up "Indian" arts and crafts.
Brazilians, Nigerians and Pakistanis weave copies of Apache, Navajo and Pima baskets. Mexicans weave imitation Navajo blankets. Chinese carve animal fetishes. Thai workers make imitation jewelry, sometimes using blue plastic instead of turquoise stone and a nickel-zinc alloy for silver. Filipino workers specialize in Hopi kachina dolls as well as Zuni inlaid jewelry.
Estimating that foreign fakes had cut his income by one-third in the last five years, Mr. Panteah said the impact had rippled across the impoverished Zuni Indian Reservation in remote western New Mexico.
"A lot of families are really hurting," he said. "They have had their vehicles taken, their lights cut off."
Hardest hit are the Hopis, Navajos and Zunis, three tribes with styles that account for about 90 percent of the Southwest Indian jewelry sold today. In Zuni land, a high-altitude desert expanse of about 700 square miles, cottage craft industries have long helped to ease unemployment, officially calculated at 74 percent in a tribal work force of 5,000 adults. For the Zunis' northern neighbors, the Navajo, blanket weaving and jewelry making have traditionally brought cash to a society in which the average household income is about $10,000, barely one-third of New Mexico's state average.
Even though it is illegal to pass off the fakes as real Indian crafts, the imitators are bold.
"Hopi style, Navajo style and Zuni style -- we are distributors for some of the best silversmiths Asia has to offer," reads the Internet catalogue of Buck-A-Gram, a Bangkok jewelry company run by a Connecticut man. "To those of you who think our jewelry is worth less because it was not made by an American Indian, the truth is that it is estimated that 90 percent of all Indian goods sold as genuine are actually imported."
Although estimates vary, foreign fakes are now believed to account for as much as half of the market in Indian arts and crafts, worth $1 billion a year.
In the Southwest, non-Indians have been copying Indian arts and crafts ever since the first tourist markets sprang up there a little more than a century ago. But with the modern interest in all things Indian, counterfeiting has surged, with increases in both quantity and in quality.
Low foreign wages and mass production are depressing prices, said Andy Abeita, an Isleta Pueblo Indian and sculptor who is president of the Indian Arts and Crafts Association, a nonprofit group in Albuquerque.
"Import jewelry is no longer a trinket industry," said Mr. Abeita, whose group is dedicated to protecting and promoting authentic Indian crafts. "Now it is very difficult for the artists themselves to tell if a piece is Indian handmade or not."
The Customs Service has begun a half-dozen investigations into imports of Indian-style arts and crafts, focusing on Mexico, the Philippines and Taiwan, said Connie Fenchel, the director of investigative operations at the agency.
"We are investigating people who are smuggling and disseminating this jewelry," Ms. Fenchel said.
Under the Indian Arts and Crafts Act of 1990, which was fully put into effect only in November, it is illegal to sell or display for sale any product not made by Indians in a way that falsely suggests that it was. A first-time violator faces fines up to $250,000 and jail terms up to five years. Repeat violators face penalties of up to $1 million in fines and 15 years in jail.
A Federal law also requires that Indian-style products imported into the United States be indelibly marked with the country of origin. Many importers flout this law by affixing stickers that can be peeled off. Some of these Indian-style goods are "laundered" in Gallup, a busy trading-post town where the origin of the goods is obscured. Out-of-state buyers, many of whom know that the goods are fake, stock up in Gallup and then peddle Asian-made wares as "straight from the reservation."
"It's not turquoise -- it's plastic," said Susan McGuire, executive director of the Indian Arts and Crafts Association, a group of artists, dealers, collectors and museum officials. "It's not Zuni; it's Filipino. It's not straight from the reservation; it's straight from Manila."
To combat counterfeits, the association has conducted seminars this spring for customs agents and for investigators of the New Mexico Attorney General's Office. Although 10 states have laws against marketing imports as "Indian handmade," prosecutions have been rare.
In Santa Fe in August, 100,000 people are expected to gather for the city's 76th annual Indian Market, where about 1,200 Indian artists are expected to display their wares.
Imitations are rare at that market.
"It's not common at the Indian Market because people know that if they are caught, they are out," said Paul Rainbird, a market organizer.
Fakes often penetrate markets elsewhere, especially ones far from the Southwest.
At the Red Earth powwow last month in Oklahoma City, "there was one Santo Domingo Pueblo lady selling Philippine jewelry with her name scratched on the back," said Tony Eriacho, a Zuni jewelery maker and dealer. "Outside, a couple of Navajo families were selling Philippine jewelry as Indian jewelry."
To avoid fraud, buyers should ask sellers for written certification that names the tribal artist and the stones and natural materials used in producing the product.
Under New Mexico law, "Indian handmade" means using tools and processes that allow the maker to determine individual shapes and design. In contrast, "Indian crafted" refers to assembly-line production, usually by Indians employed in factories in the Albuquerque area.
To protect tribal artisans, the Hopi, the Navajo and the Zuni are debating the formal adoption of tribal trademarks. These marks could be used only by tribal artists who would agree to abide by trademark restrictions.
On a survey form of tribal jewelers and traders on the problem of imitation jewelry, one Zuni artisan printed in bold letters, "We all suffer -- time to take on the fakes."
