HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Robust Growth Seen In July Jobs Report
An unexpectedly large number of jobs were created in July -- 316,000 -- well above expectations and above a revised 228,000 jobs in June. As a result, the nation's unemployment rate declined to 4.8 percent last month, matching a 23-year low set in May, Government figures showed. 
 A separate report, from the National Association of Purchasing Management, showed that manufacturing expanded in July. The two reports raised fears that the economy might be growing too fast to keep inflation contained and some asked if the Federal Reserve would need to apply brakes to the economy and raise interest rates. [Page 1.]
 
Airbus Wins 2 Big Orders
Virgin Atlantic Airways and Air Canada have placed orders worth $3.9 billion with Airbus Industrie for stretch versions of its largest passenger plane. The European consortium's four-engine aircraft, which can carry up to 378 passengers, is intended to compete with the Boeing 747 jumbo jet. [32.]
 
No Strike at United Parcel
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters decided not to order a strike against the United Parcel Service as negotiators for the two sides continued to meet with a Federal mediator. The company and the union were optimistic that they could resolve their differences without a strike by the 185,000 unionized drivers, loaders and sorters. [8.]
 
Agreement Reached in Steel Strike
Negotiators reached a tentative agreement yesterday to end a 10-month strike by 4,500 workers at Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel. The agreement to end the walkout by the United Steelworkers at plants in Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania came after 10 straight days of negotiations in New York. Union officials and the full membership must still ratify the deal. Workers are expected to return to their jobs in about two weeks. [7.]
 
Dollar Hits a High vs. Mark
The dollar hit an eight-year high against the German mark and surged in most other currency dealings, propelled by strong United States economic data. The dollar closed at 1.8635 marks after setting an intraday high of 1.8675 marks, the strongest since November 1989. But the dollar slipped to 118.40 Japanese yen, from 118.59 yen on Thursday. [41.]
 
Seeking On-Line Updike Wannabes
Amazon.com, the on-line bookseller, has developed a contest that is part lottery, part chain letter. Amazon.com is asking imitation John Updikes to write the middle of a short story the author has started about a Miss Tasso Polk. A winner will be chosen each day, with a grand-prize winner selected at random in the fall. The epic will be called "The Greatest Tale Ever Told." [11.]
 
Gasoline Prices Increase
Gasoline surged after Shell Netherlands unexpectedly closed part of Europe's second-largest oil refinery, the latest in a spate of problems for gasoline that pushed prices up 20 percent last month. On other markets, platinum rose and copper fell. [41.]
 
2 Ski Resorts Acquired
ASC Holdings, the parent of the American Skiing Company, has bought the Steamboat Ski Resort in Steamboat Springs, Colo., and Heavenly Ski Resort in Stateline, Nev., for $288.3 million. American Skiing acquired its first ski area in the West in April when it purchased Canyons Ski Resort, in Park City, Utah. [33]
 
Reshuffling at G.E.
General Electric named Eugene F. Murphy as a vice chairman, corporate executive officer and a director, amid a reshuffling of several executives. [45.]
 
Nomura to Spin Off a Unit
Nomura Securities Company's United States subsidiary plans to spin off its real estate lending unit, one of its most profitable businesses, into a private company, paving the way for a possible sale. The real estate group at Nomura provides the bulk of the firm's profits in the United States by making loans using Nomura's capital. Those loans are then packaged into securities and sold to investors. Last year, Nomura was the fourth-biggest underwriter of commercial mortgage-backed securities.[34]

HEADLINE: Report Shows Robust Growth With New Jobs

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
The United States economy entered the summer with fresh strength, as an unexpected number of new jobs reduced the nation's unemployment rate to 4.8 percent last month, matching a 23-year low set in May, Government figures showed today.
While analysts had predicted that the economy would rebound from a spring slowdown, today's data on jobs, combined with a private report on manufacturing, fanned fears that the rebound might be too strong. Some investors, who have been pushing bond and stock prices higher on the belief that growth is moderate and inflation tame, wondered whether the Federal Reserve would now need to apply the brakes with an increase in interest rates. 
 "We've kind of shattered the old conviction of no Fed tightening," said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation.
Bond and stock prices tumbled after the report, although stocks later recovered. The Dow Jones industrial average, which earlier fell 1 percent, ended the day down 28.57 points, or less than half a percent. Bond prices, however, continued to slide, driving the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for consumer interest rates like mortgages -- to 6.45 percent, from 6.29 percent on Thursday. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions.
While the employment report revived Wall Street's fears of higher interest rates -- which eat into corporate profits and make bonds less attractive -- it confirmed the improved position of job seekers. The unemployment rate for black teen-agers, for example, fell by more than four percentage points, to 28.6 percent, the lowest since 1969.
Over all, 316,000 jobs were added to the nation's payrolls last month, well above expectations and above a revised 228,000 jobs in June. When combined with a modest increase in the labor force, the jobless ranks contracted by 253,000 and the unemployment rate fell to 4.8 percent, from 5 percent in June -- matching the rate in May and the lowest since November 1973.
At the same time, however, the average hourly earnings of production workers were unchanged while their weekly earnings fell because of a shorter workweek.
The Clinton Administration applauded the July jobs report.
"This morning we have further evidence that the strategy of balancing the budget while investing in our people and selling more American products around the world has helped to produce sustained prosperity for Americans," President Clinton said today. "There is no doubt that the economic strategy we put in place in 1993 created the conditions for the extraordinary private-sector growth."
July's gains in jobs showed that the May report was no fluke, said Nicholas S. Perna, economist for the Fleet Financial Group in Boston. "The most important thing is that the unemployment rate is clearly below 5 percent again," he said.
Mr. Perna and other economists worry that such low unemployment will soon drive up wages and spur inflation.
Further signs of economic growth came in a survey today by the National Association of Purchasing Management. The association's report, which covers manufacturing, showed its overall index rising to 58.6 from 55.7, while the production index leaped by 8.4 points, to 64.4.
Rising for the first time in four months, the group's price index surged to 53.6 from 48.1, with 17 percent of members reporting paying higher prices compared with 13 percent in May and June. The index of supplier deliveries climbed to 55.3 from 54.6, which the association said meant that "deliveries are slowing at a faster rate."
In other reports, the Commerce Department said that orders placed with factories rose 1.2 percent in June, more than recovering a drop of five-tenths of 1 percent in May. The department also said that Americans' income grew six-tenths of 1 percent in June, while spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
While today's reports raised expectations that Federal Reserve policy makers might increase rates, few analysts expect them to do so at their next meeting on Aug. 19.
Macroeconomic Advisers, a St. Louis consulting firm, told clients today that "despite the continued benign behavior of wages, the further tightening of labor markets will be of concern to the Fed and keeps the possibility of a tightening alive, although almost certainly not before" the Fed's September meeting.
The 316,000 jump in employer payrolls last month was well above expectations, though the total was swollen by a 48,000 increase in local education that was statistically suspect because of changing seasonal patterns of the school year. Teachers are considered employed year-round, but others, like cafeteria workers and sports referees, move on and off education payrolls and may or may not take unrelated jobs.
But the report showed a 31,000 advance in health service jobs following an unusually weak June, a 65,000 surge in retail trade -- half in restaurants and bars -- and a 26,000 gain for the finance-insurance-real estate category that was more than twice the monthly average over the last year.
Factory jobs, however, were flat with 20,000 additional people producing durable goods more than offset by 25,000 fewer producing nondurables.
The workweek shortened by 18 minutes and factory overtime also fell, suggesting to some that employers were confident enough to add permanent workers, which tends to reduce the need for long hours. The index of aggregate weekly hours fell seven-tenths of a point, to 139.9.
Another reflection of July strength, analysts said, was the resumed increase in the percentage of the unemployed who voluntary left their latest job, typically because they thought they could readily find another one. This percentage was 12.6 percent in July, up from 12.2 in May and June and 11.2 in April.
By region, the West showed the most improvement, with its July unemployment rate declining three-tenths of a point, to 5.3 percent. The Northeast and Midwest posted two-tenths of a point declines, to 5.5 percent and 3.6 percent, respectively, while the South edged down to 5 percent from 5.1.

HEADLINE: In Washington, Few Trifle With Jesse Helms

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE and STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Senator Jesse Helms's ability to block William F. Weld's nomination to be Ambassador to Mexico, single-handedly, is only the latest example of a Washington axiom: Everyone is afraid of the Republican from North Carolina.
President Clinton was so intent on not crossing Mr. Helms, White House aides said, that he was careful to offer only a tepid endorsement of Mr. Weld as an aside in a speech this week. 
 Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader who is not generally timid about meddling with his committee chairmen, turned aside private pleas from some other Republicans to challenge Mr. Helms on this nomination.
Even Democratic colleagues have chosen not to go against Mr. Helms, though he is as much a beacon of unsparing conservatism as Senator Edward M. Kennedy is of unsparing liberalism.
Mr. Helms, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations, has a decades-long history of using the Senate rules as a legislative roadblock to further his crusades against Communism and to press his conservative social agenda. His often-successful efforts to delay, in some cases halt, Presidential nominations or to sabotage legislation have earned him the sobriquet Senator No.
Asked in an interview today how Mr. Helms commanded such power, Bob Dole, the former Senate Republican leader, said of the political establishment: "They're afraid of him. Jesse runs a pretty tight ship."
Though he has forged a strong relationship with Mr. Helms, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the ranking Democrat on the committee, was blunter. "He's prepared to be mean," Mr. Biden said. "He's prepared to be disliked. He's prepared to be ostracized."
But Mr. Helms's leverage is rooted in more than his image as an intractable extremist. Even as he refuses to budge on Mr. Weld, Mr. Helms is working closely with the Clinton Administration on a host of issues, most notably efforts to pay off back dues to the United Nations and to reorganize the State Department.
Mr. Helms and Madeleine K. Albright, the Secretary of State, have become so close that they greet each other with kisses. Two and a half years into Mr. Helms's tenure as chairman, his relationship with Ms. Albright is producing substantive agreements on foreign policy.
The two are so chummy that Administration officials said they did not want to jeopardize that bond for the sake of Mr. Weld, a moderate Republican who resigned as Governor of Massachusetts this week to devote himself to pressing for his confirmation. (Ms. Albright has talked to Mr. Helms about the Weld nomination, her senior aides said, but has not pressed him especially hard.)
Chatting in the lobby of a Las Vegas hotel this week after Mr. Clinton resisted delivering a more effusive endorsement of Mr. Weld, John Podesta, a deputy chief of staff who is shepherding the nomination through the Senate, said, "We don't need to add a new log on to the fire of antagonism."
 
A Willingness To Say 'Hell, No'
The sources of Mr. Helms's power are his deeply held convictions, his stubborn streak and his lack of concern about what people say about him. And unlike many of his colleagues, Mr. Helms has no hesitation to exercise his power, and to seize on every parliamentary maneuver that exists to press his causes.
Most senators, for instance, would not dare use their authority to refuse to schedule a hearing on a Presidential nomination, as Mr. Helms has done in the Weld case.
And because Mr. Helms, who is 75, has been something of an icon in the conservative movement since he was first elected in 1972, many Republicans are loath to take him on, for fear of offending that segment of their party's voting base.
"The Senate club is not a place where you have a lot of guys who got there because they were willing to say, 'Hell, no.' " said Richard S. Williamson, a former aide to President Ronald Reagan who has known Mr. Helms since they both worked together on the 1976 Republican Party platform.
Mr. Williamson added: "The nature of politics is to try to gather support and be collegial. Someone who is willing to stand alone is always going to have disproportionate influence."
Mr. Helms's iron-fisted control, and the end of the cold war, have discouraged senators from serving on the once-coveted Foreign Relations Committee. Of Mr. Helms's 10 Republican colleagues on the panel, 7 are freshmen. His control also reflects Mr. Helms's intense belief in preserving Senate traditions.
Several authorities on Congress said former Senator Howard Metzenbaum, a liberal Democrat from Ohio, was the only other senator in recent times who was willing to exert power to the maximum extent possible, even at the expense of inconveniencing or thwarting colleagues.
"They all do it," said Ross K. Baker, a political scientist at Rutgers University, "but usually they do it less offensively and with less callous disregard for the consequences.
"At the same time, Helms is respected. He is not viewed as a Joe McCarthy, someone who bring the Senate in disgrace. He has extremely firm convictions and believes in using every parliamentary device at his disposal to achieve his objectives."
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, praised Mr. Helms, saying he "virtually cleared the calendar of ambassadorial nominations." Yet Mr. Daschle said that when Mr. Helms dragged matters out like with Mr. Weld, it bogged down the institution.
"If every chairman would take that kind of action," he said, "it would be impossible for us to conduct the business of the Senate."
Trying to halt the appointment of ambassadors has been a Helms speciality. In 1987, for example, Mr. Helms fought bitterly with the then committee chairman, Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, over a nomination for Ambassador to Portugal.
Mr. Pell pressed for confirmation, arguing that it was important to "get on with the nation's business."
Mr. Helms replied, "Bull!"
Mr. Helms lost the fight, and dived into a speech as Mr. Pell tried to cut him off.
"You cannot take the floor away from me," Mr. Helms declared. "If you railroad me, Mr. Chairman, you'll regret it."
 
A Hard-Liner Finds Some Unlikely Allies
When Republicans gained control of the Senate after the 1994 elections, sweeping him into the chairmanship of the Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. Helms appeared determined to live up to his reputation, developed by years in the minority, as an extremist, an obstructionist, an isolationist.
Even before the 104th Congress convened, he declared Mr. Clinton unfit to be Commander in Chief and suggested he "better have a bodyguard" if he decided to visit a military base in North Carolina. Things did not improve.
After striking what he thought was a bargain with Warren Christopher, who was then Secretary of State, to reorganize the State Department, Mr. Helms was infuriated when the White House backed off.
So for months, Mr. Helms halted all meetings of the committee, thereby stalling ratification of a dozen treaties and freezing 400 promotions in the State Department. He also refused to hold hearings for dozens of ambassador nominations, prompting Mr. Christopher to complain that the impasse had created "management and morale problems."
Eventually, Mr. Helms yielded and the committee resumed work. Mr. Clinton, facing re-election last year, also showed a willingness to compromise, and the turning point was probably when he signed Mr. Helms's legislation to tighten the economic embargo of Cuba.
But the Administration's designated charmer is the Secretary of State. Ms. Albright, who visited Mr. Helms in North Carolina while still delegate to the United Nations last year, spent a day with Mr. Helms again this year, delivering a speech, planting a kiss on the Senator's cheek in his hometown and presenting him with a T-shirt that read, "Someone in the State Department Loves Me." She danced with him at her 60th birthday party. And her softball team challenged his (and lost, 8 to 4).
Though Ms. Albright is a creature of the Democratic Party, she and Mr. Helms seem to share a genuine affection. Aides to both say it springs from his respect for her patriotism as a refugee who found a home in the United States and from shared anti-Communist zeal.
In addition to Ms. Albright, Mr. Helms has also developed a respectful relationship with Stuart E. Eizenstat, the new Under Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs. And he has worked well with Erskine B. Bowles, Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, whose father, Hargrove Bowles, was a friend of Mr. Helms since grade school in North Carolina.
These ties have produced results. After vowing to block a vote on the chemical weapons treaty earlier this year, Mr. Helms relented and allowed it to reach the Senate floor. He still voted against it, and forced the Administration to give assurances on how the treaty would be enforced.
The relationship with Ms. Albright also led to agreement on legislation to reorganize the State Department and to pay off the dues to the United Nations, long a bete noire of conservatives.
Just this week, as the House and Senate met to hash out differences in the State Department legislation, Mr. Helms held fast in a dispute over how many under secretaries a reorganized State Department should have. Insisting on the current level of five, Mr. Helms exclaimed, "The question is, Are we going to control the bureaucracy or aren't we?"
By the next morning, the Senator from North Carolina had changed his tone. He told his colleagues that he had spoken again by telephone with Ms. Albright, who was in Asia.
"She said she wasn't dressed yet," Mr. Helms said, noting that it was morning in Asia when they had spoken. In an apparent reference to telephones that transmit people's faces, he said, "I said I'm glad we don't have television."
He then conceded the fight to Ms. Albright, agreeing to allow her to have a sixth under secretary.
"I want her to continue the good job she's doing," Mr. Helms said.
 
Policy Differences Are Just the Beginning
 Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, a Republican who is close to both Mr. Helms and Mr. Weld, offered some advice for the two men to patch things up over a bratwurst. "The two of them need to go out and have a beer," he said. "It would be a little rocky at the beginning, but I think they would get it done."
Marc Thiessen, Mr. Helms' spokesman, brushed aside the suggestion with a laugh, saying, "Helms doesn't drink beer."
Beer or no beer, Mr. Helms and Mr. Weld have never met, and that prospect seems increasingly unlikely. In his only lengthy interview on the subject of nomination for Mexico, Mr. Helms said on Fox News earlier this summer, "I don't think he is ambassador quality."
Given the problems with drug trafficking in Mexico, Mr. Helms has said he could not condone an ambassador to that country who, like Mr. Weld, supports the use of marijuana for medicinal purposes. But he said there were other reasons as well for his opposition to the nomination.
People close to Mr. Weld speculate that Edwin Meese 3d, the former Attorney General, was pressing Mr. Helms to reject Mr. Weld. Mr. Weld was denounced by conservatives when he resigned as head of the criminal division of the Justice Department in 1988 to protest Mr. Meese's policies. But in an interview, Mr. Meese denied that he had spoken to Mr. Helms.
"I'm staying completely away from anything to do with Weld," he said.
Mr. Helms's advisers noted that beyond the drug issue -- and Mr. Weld's liberal positions on social matters like abortion and homosexual marriages -- there were plenty of other reasons Mr. Weld had not endeared himself to the Senator.
In a debate last October, in Mr. Weld's bid to unseat Senator John F. Kerry, the moderator asked the Governor, "If you are elected, will you vote in the Republican caucus to reconfirm Jesse Helms as chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee?"
The Governor sidestepped the question, responding, "You know, you never know whether incumbents are going to get re-elected," adding that he would have to "wait and see when I get down exactly what all those votes I would cast would be."
Asked last week whether he regretted his response to that question, Mr. Weld said, simply, "No."
Beyond slights and ideology, some of Mr. Helms's friends said the Senator dislikes Mr. Weld for the same reason he was never close to President George Bush: he has a disdain for politicians who came out of the Ivy League Eastern establishment.
"This may seem overly cynical, but I told Jesse, 'You know what this is about? He thinks you're tacky -- the tackiest of all,' " said David Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union, referring to Mr. Weld. "This guy is a rich patrician dilettante. And I think he thinks it's beneath him to talk to Jesse Helms or the other hoi polloi."
Mr. Helms's advisers said any hope that the Senator would sit down with Mr. Weld were dashed when the latter asserted publicly that his appointment was being held up because of "ideological extortion."
"Weld does not want to be Ambassador to Mexico," said Mr. Thiessen, the Senator's spokesman. "Weld is using his appointment as a tool to start an intra-party battle for the soul of the Republican Party. And he's using Jesse Helms as his foil. That's an abuse of the confirmation process, and an abuse of the U.S. Senate."
Mr. Dole said Mr. Helms could be difficult but not completely obstinate.
"I never had a time where if I went to Jesse personally and said, 'This is very important to me or the President,' where we couldn't work it out," he said.
Echoing many others, Mr. Dole described Mr. Helms as a gentleman. "My mother-in-law had her 96th birthday in May," he said. "Who calls her up and wishes her a happy birthday? Jesse."
In late June, Mr. Dole said, he was in Boston and tried to meet with Mr. Weld so he could offer to broker talks between him and Mr. Helms. But Mr. Weld was in Hong Kong. Mr. Dole said he left a message for the Governor, but never heard from him.
"I wanted to give him a little free advice," Mr. Dole said. "I didn't reach him -- and nobody called me back."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 19; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1019 words

HEADLINE: Kill an Elephant, Save an Elephant

BYLINE: By Matthew Scully; Matthew Scully, a speechwriter in the Bush Administration, is a free-lance writer.

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
You'd think that after a century's worth of service as the noble Republican symbol, the elephant might enjoy some special conservation status in the party. But it was a Democrat, Senator Barbara Boxer of California, who rose the other day in its defense.
By voice vote, the Senate approved her motion to restrict American financing for Campfire, a program in Zimbabwe under which elephant hunting is allowed as a means of raising local revenue. 
 By the logic of Campfire, the only way to save the elephant is to turn him over to the hunter. Around the world are hunters willing to pay good money for an elephant. Surrounding the elephant preserves are poor communities that could certainly use the revenue. So, the argument runs, give those communities control over elephants, and let them sell the hunting rights at premium rates. They will thus have an incentive to guard against poachers. From now on, only paying customers get to hunt.
The idea of trophy hunters as the elephant's only deliverance from poachers may not sit well with some of us, but such is life. Best, we're told, to avert our eyes and let Market Forces work another miracle. Campfire, as one proponent put it in The Weekly Standard, has "transformed elephants from economic liabilities into community assets," thereby "empowering the peasants."
The economics do seem to add up, but one thing I notice in all these arguments is that we never meet the Market Force himself, the trophy hunter upon whose money and conservation instincts the whole plan rests. To see how Campfire is playing out on the consumer end, go on line sometime, key in "hunting" and "elephant" and you'll find dozens of safari outfitters advertising what looks to be a trophy free-for-all. "Come to Tanzania," says one company, "the very essence of Africa, unspoiled yet spectacular." The "Big Four" -- elephants, lions, leopards, buffalo -- are all there. And best of all, "You may shoot as much as you please."
Come to Zimbabwe, beckons Matupula Hunters of Texas, for "Africa's best elephant hunting." And hurry: "With the country dry and surface water limited, the elephant bulls can be tracked going to and from water, or in amongst the woodlands and forest where they feed and lay up."
Let me explain: It's hot and dry. The creatures live in a fenced game park where water is scarce. Though wary of the water hole, they have to drink sometime, and when they do you'll be positioned just right. Catching them en route makes for "an exciting and rewarding elephant hunt."
A few restrictions still apply. "No Elephants are allowed to be hunted in Mozambique," says Hunt Mozambique Inc. You can stay for that tempting "Lion and Buffalo Package" ($13,450) or head over to Zimbabwe where the action is. Daily rates there cover "accommodation in fully equipped tented safari camp, camp personnel, all meals, daily laundry service, trackers and skinners, field preparation of trophies, vehicle transport during hunt, services of PH" -- professional hunter. With Dembe Safaris you'll have a hunt "reminiscent of Hemingway," unless you prefer "luxurious 5-star lodges with swimming pools, TV, and all the amenities."
But for skinner and PH, one notices, all these are things a tourist armed only with camera would pay for, which makes you wonder why nonhunting tourism (let alone nontourism trades) could not just as well support those communities. On the other hand, then we could not don safari suits and feel like Hemingway. We would miss the rewarding experience of being fed, tidied up, tucked in, served breakfast, driven up to a trapped and thirsty animal -- on his best day, about as hard to hit as Bullwinkle floating down Fifth Avenue -- and after our kill repairing to the hotel bar to swap stories, while the empowered peasants handle the skinning and stuffing back in the bush.
Adventures Unlimited lays down what seems to be the standard rule: "Trophy fees payable when animals are killed or wounded." The fees: "Elephant -- $10,000; Giraffe -- $1,000; Lion -- $3,500; Hippo -- $2,500." At just $700 the zebras are a steal, and for $75 you can shoot yourself some "Bait" -- an impala.
 There are pictures, too. A client of Adventures Unlimited, a meager fellow bearing some serious weaponry, grins at us through the now horizontal tusks of an elephant that has just been transformed into a community asset. The great elephant, all $10,000 worth, looks asleep.
Oh, and you can also enjoy vicarious adventures through videos like "Pure Africa" ("lots of action and kill shots"), "Sudden Death" ("wounded trophy lions") or, for the gals, "Lady Africa."
There are now 500,000 or so elephants left across the continent, down from roughly 1.3 million in 1979. Your average adult is maybe 20 years old. It used to be around 60. All but a few of the trophy-ready elders have assumed their places in living rooms and lodges across the Western world. Observing the hunters, though, you get the impression they think that whole extinction business was all nonsense. As if the elephants were just getting better at hiding.
Having spent a few generations exploiting Africa, without much apparent concern for "community development," the hunters now offer themselves as a free-market solution. Actually, the arrangement more resembles a monopoly, the ivory and hunting industries buying off the locals and agreeing with each other to "leave enough for us!"
 Senator Boxer's proposal on Campfire -- an amendment to an appropriation bill for foreign operations -- is now before the House. She and Senator Wayne Allard of Colorado, the most vocal Republican on the issue, are right to oppose Campfire, but don't stop there. Redouble aid to Africa and see that every dollar goes to building nonhunting industries. Offer every tax incentive in the book for investment in Africa, including a deduction for dollars spent there by unarmed tourists. And ban the importation of any elephant trophy across American borders -- providing violators with fresh attire, trained escort and vehicle transport on their one-year prison adventure, all amenities included.

PUB-DATE: August 3, 1997

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 24; Column 1; Education Life Supplement 

LENGTH: 3666 words

HEADLINE: Community Colleges At the Crossroads: Which Way Is Up?

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME; Peter Applebome is the national education correspondent for The New York Times.

DATELINE: PHOENIX

 BODY:
There is no stiff academic reserve at the copper-colored office tower in suburban Tempe, Ariz., where Linda Thor is discussing her imperial visions for Rio Salado Community College. The school has no campus and educates 34,000 students in places like churches and shopping malls, and increasingly at home on their computers.
"We were established as a college without walls," Ms. Thor said of the school, which is part of the Maricopa County Community College District, "and today we believe we're a college without boundaries, including geographical boundaries as well as other boundaries, such as the way instruction is delivered, formats and schedules. 
 "Frankly, we see Rio Salado as a global institution, serving not only Maricopa County, but the Southwest, the nation and the world."
The world of Rio Salado and the other Maricopa County community colleges (second in size only to the Los Angeles County system) could not be further from the familiar, ivy-edged stereotypes about higher education. Here there is 110-degree midday heat and a desert landscape. There are little-known campuses, long-in-the-tooth students (averaging 30 years old) and courses that are as likely to train firefighters, police officers and undertakers as scholars, teachers or executives.
But increasingly, in ways legislators in state capitols and in Washington are struggling to make sense of, the higher education mainstream is coming to look a lot more like Rio Salado and Maricopa than like Harvard or Yale.
In fact, the increasing influence of community colleges is putting these institutions at the middle of disputes and turf battles over race, access, budgets, opportunity and educational philosophy that play out in an emerging educational world that is often very different from the one lawmakers and policy makers know best.
Maricopa, for instance, is now the largest provider of higher education in Arizona. It has an almost $600 million annual budget, enrolls more than 200,000 students each year in credit and noncredit courses, employs more than 10,000 people and operates 10 colleges and a skill center offering certificates in career-oriented programs. At about $450 a semester, tuition is just over half that of the four-year state universities.
And in a nation whose students are increasingly older adults, minorities and workers looking to upgrade their skills, community colleges have become an increasingly attractive alternative. The nation's 1,500 community colleges now enroll 10 million students, including more than half the freshmen in higher education, 44 percent of all undergraduates, 45 percent of all the black students in higher education and 52 percent of the Hispanic students.
Nationally, President Clinton perhaps did more for the visibility of community colleges than any other President when he vowed to make a 13th and 14th year of education as common as high school by offering Hope Scholarships, tax credits worth up to $1,500 a year for two years. These would pay the full cost of most community colleges but only a fraction of four-year college tuition.
This changing landscape has led to political disputes over governance, the transferability of junior college credits and more contentious issues:
* New York City's community colleges, particularly Hostos Community College in the Bronx, faced a wrenching debate this spring over language-competency standards, which ended up with hundreds of students, most of whom speak English as a second language, failing an English proficiency test required for graduation. Many feel that the dispute helped fuel efforts to force out the system's chancellor, W. Ann Reynolds, who resigned in mid-July to become president of the University of Alabama, Birmingham.
* In Kentucky, Gov. Paul Patton fought and eventually won a bruising battle to sever the administration of the state's community colleges from the University of Kentucky.
*Florida's budget was delayed because of a bitter fight over community college financing. The argument included debates over the amount of funds, whether the financing should be distributed equally among campuses and whether standards should be established that tie community college financing to performance factors, like the percentage of students who graduate.
* California was one of several states in which the legislature struggled with ways to reconcile welfare reform's mandate to cut off assistance after a designated period with the ability of recipients to finish community college study in time to get a job.
One of the more interesting battles took place in Arizona over a proposal to allow community colleges to offer four-year applied baccalaureate degrees for the first time. The degrees were to be granted in selected areas of professional development like health care, law enforcement and manufacturing technology.
The issues differed from state to state, but they all illustrated the extent to which community colleges have entered the mainstream. It is questionable, however, whether the nation's academic and political leadership are recognizing the increased influence of community colleges and planning for the growing role that they will play.
"The reality now is that we are bearing the load for higher education in the United States in a very significant way," said Paul A. Elsner, Maricopa's chancellor, and one of the leading figures in the community college world. "Look at the transfer numbers. At Arizona State, 65 percent of the upper-division students come from Maricopa Community College. In California, 65 percent of the upper division students at Cal Poly transferred from community colleges. At Rutgers, it's 58 percent. We're a major player, but no one recognizes it at the policy level. We're invariably looked at as the poor cousins or lesser relatives. We're late at the table, often forgotten and most of the time only an afterthought when it comes to policy decisions."
The stories of students at various campuses in the Maricopa district are a dramatic reminder of the changing face of American education.
In 1982, when Jerry Roberts graduated from high school in Phoenix, college seemed neither affordable nor necessary, so he went to work as a concrete finisher. He then spent 11 years at Allied Signal Corporation, where he is now a laboratory technician.
But as Mr. Roberts stared at a computer image of a machine tool he was creating at GateWay Community College here, he reflected on how outdated his former assumptions had become.Now he is back at school nine hours a week, paid for by his employer. He is working on an associate's degree in manufacturing technology and plans to get a bachelor's degree later.
"I couldn't afford college after high school," he said. "But you just need an education today. At my company, it's something they want to see on your resume. I can already see jobs being posted on the board that I can apply for next year."
Other students show how community colleges are serving varied needs. Charity Cook is a 15-year-old high school graduate, schooled at home, who is studying elementary education for the deaf at Phoenix College. Lloyd Foust, 29, who shows up for night classes at Phoenix College in his brown United Parcel Service uniform, wants to be a Southern Baptist minister, but needs to get his bachelor's degree. So he is picking up credits where he can afford them.
Alberta Joe, 18, just graduated from high school and plans to do two years at Phoenix College before transferring to the University of Arizona to study pharmacy.
Jasper Deale, 23, is studying printing at the Maricopa Skill Center under a program administered by the Navajo Department of Employment and Training. The program brought him from the Navajo reservation 700 miles away and pays his rent and tuition in Phoenix. Mr. Deale said that although there was a community college at the reservation (Navajo Community College's Shiprock Branch), it did not have the printing programs he needed. (Story on tribal colleges, Page 28.
"Basically, to get what I needed, I had to go to a big city, Albuquerque or Phoenix," he said. "I was tired of the reservation. There were no jobs or opportunities, but this program was exactly what I needed."
And then there is Dana King-Esquer, a 34-year-old mother of three who graduated from high school in 1979 and got married a year later. She has been working at a high school cafeteria, but got the urge to teach. Attending school full time was out of the question, but in January 1996, she enrolled at Rio Salado.
Rio Salado provides education to 24,000 for-credit students and 10,000 not-for-credit students at 200 sites -- increasingly through distance learning, which includes the use of video and audiotapes, computer disks and the Internet.
Ms. King-Esquer took one course via computer disk on her old Packard-Bell computer, loved it, and has so far taken 55 course credits. This year she won a spot on the All-Arizona second team for academics in a competition supported by the state's community colleges and the national community college honors society. Only 53 of Arizona's 300,000 community college students earned the honor. Ms. King-Esquer hopes to go on to teach second grade.
"I've written essays at 11 at night and at 6 in the morning," she said. "There's no way I could fit a traditional course schedule into my life. But this has worked so well, my daughter, who's a junior in high school, plans to do her first two years of college through distance learning and then transfer to a regular university."
Officials at Maricopa know they still rank well below the state's research universities -- places like the University of Arizona and Arizona State University -- in the traditional academic pecking order. But they are not shy about making the case that as time goes by, what they are offering is what the academic market is increasingly demanding.
"Just like you have just-in-time production, our responsibility is to provide just-in-time education," said Brian Johnson, a 40-year-old New Jersey native who is now dean of Student and Community Services at Mesa Community College, which sprawls across 140 acres of what used to be alfalfa fields and sheep pasture east of Phoenix. Mesa has grown since 1965 from one room in what used to be the Landmark Restaurant in downtown Mesa to the sixth-largest single-site community college in the country, enrolling 23,108 students at the main campus, plus more than a 1,000 other students at four satellite sites.
"Our students need it now," he said. "They need it better, faster and cheaper, and they look to community colleges to deliver it."
It is probably inevitable that community colleges have become bigger players as higher education has gone from a service aimed at society's elite to one that is seen as available to everyone.Indeed, from their beginnings, community colleges have reflected a distinctly American commitment to democratized education.
The first public community college, Joliet Junior College, opened in Illinois in 1901. California, in laws passed in 1907, 1917 and 1921, established the nation's first comprehensive network of community colleges. Other states followed suit with schools designed to be community-based and open to all, and which offered a broad range of academic, professional and technical programs.
But what really changed community colleges was World War II, when a flood of returning veterans looked for education under the G.I. Bill of Rights. The Truman Commission, established by President Harry S. Truman in 1947, proclaimed that the single best way to break down the barriers to higher education was to promote a broad network of publicly supported community colleges. (The term immediately caught on as a replacement for the somewhat dismissive "junior college." The terms are used at both public and private institutions, but "community college" is the much preferred designation.)
The report signaled the first time that community colleges were seen as an integral part of a comprehensive system of higher education. It made the radical claim that 49 percent of the population could benefit from two years of education beyond high school. President Clinton's recent vow to make those two years as common as a high school diploma is a reflection of how much the concept has advanced. Between 1975 and 1992, total community college enrollment grew from 55 percent of the figure for four-year college enrollment to 65 percent.
The Maricopa district illustrates this evolution dramatically.It had its beginnings in 1920, when Phoenix Junior College opened as a department of Phoenix Union High School, with 18 students taking classes in a small one-room cottage on the high school campus. Taxpayers approved a $175,000 bond campaign in 1929 for a new building with 24 classrooms.
The school grew steadily, if quietly, until 1960, when the State Legislature established a community college system. Since then enrollment has exploded, with campuses popping up all over the Phoenix area. The Maricopa district now rivals some state systems, with 10 campuses and one skill center, serving a geographic area larger than the state of Connecticut. About 40 percent of Maricopa County's high school students attend one of the community colleges within a year after graduating, and fall enrollment is expected to grow by 68 percent over the next 10 years.
Besides providing much of the first two years of college training, Maricopa is a huge part of the economic development and job training process in Phoenix. Its Glendale campus is particularly strong in computer and high-technology education. Maricopa now provides specified job training to 25 to 30 companies directly and offers classes in a broad range of skills to at least 70 others. The system is a critical player, for instance, in training high-technology workers for the burgeoning Arizona semiconductor industry.
It has been a long year, said David Baime, director of government relations for the American Association of Community Colleges in Washington.
"Everyone tells me I look like hell," he said.
Actually, it has been a long year for everyone involved in higher education in Washington, as wrangling continues over the Clinton Administration's tax proposals. But it has been especially vexing for Mr. Baime because of the fight over expanding Pell grants for the needy and the efforts to focus tuition and tax assistance on low-income students, often the core constituency of community colleges.
Because they so often deal with the economic needs of low-income and nontraditional students, community colleges sometimes have different priorities from those of the higher education establishment. This can make it difficult for them to sell their programs to legislators more attuned to the agendas of four-year institutions.
"They're only human, and I think it's a constant struggle to get legislators to understand the unique perspective of our institutions," Mr. Baime said. "People identify with what they know best. It's just a fact that the overwhelming majority of members of Congress did not attend a community college and that most of them don't think about sending their children there, though that's less true than in the past."
Such attitudes are common in the states as well.
In Arizona, for instance, most of the legislators have gone to state schools like the University of Arizona and Arizona State, whose prestige and competitive position vis-a-vis other states' flagship campuses inevitably become a source of state pride. There are all sorts of glamorous intangibles, like the University of Arizona winning the N.C.A.A. basketball championship or Arizona State going to the Rose Bowl, that build good will in ways community colleges can never match. And the universities can turn out alumni to lobby for their interests, some of whom may have begun at the community college level but who transferred their loyalty when they transferred their enrollment. Maricopa gets only 14 percent of its budget from the state, compared to the universities' 40 to 45 percent.
The political picture, however, is hardly one-sided. Because they have campuses in legislative districts across the state, community colleges have their allies as well. As the largest provider of job training in Arizona, much of it customized work force training for big employers, Maricopa can and does call on powerful business interests to plead its case.
And as the largest provider of higher education in Arizona, with two full-time lobbyists, Maricopa is not quite David with a slingshot against the Goliaths at Arizona and Arizona State. The district, for instance, had enough political savvy to pass a $386 million bond issue a few years back -- a far cry from the $175,000 issue passed in 1929 and the largest ever passed by a community college district in the United States.
"With them considered the people's colleges, especially in rural areas, they can be a much easier sell than we are," said Blake Anderson, a government relations analyst with Arizona State University. "And Maricopa, in particular, has a huge constituency. I think they're every bit as influential as we are."
Recently, the balance of power was put to the test. Maricopa, like most districts, regularly faces issues related to financing and governance. In Arizona's last legislative session, it was also heavily involved in welfare reform, bidding -- unsuccessfully, as it turned out -- to become a favored provider of education to welfare recipients as they try to get training before their benefits run out. But the biggest education issue, and one that pitted the four-year colleges against the community colleges in a way that was unusually stark, was the fight over the proposal to begin four-year applied baccalaureate programs in selected occupational areas at community colleges.
At least two states, New York and Utah, offer such degrees in limited areas. And community college advocates argue that they are merely proposing degrees in selected applied areas, like the training of fire fighters, police officers, manufacturing specialists or surgical nurses, which are not now covered by four-year institutions. For instance, they say the kind of manufacturing technology training Mr. Roberts is getting at GateWay could be delivered by the community college system more cheaply and efficiently than by four-year institutions.
"We don't aspire to be a university; we like who we are," said Ms. Thor, who began her career in higher education as a public information officer for the Pepperdine University School of Continuing Education in Malibu, Calif., and later earned a master's degree in public administration from California State University, Los Angeles, and a doctorate in community college administration from Pepperdine University. "What we aspire to is to fully meet the needs of our students in the areas in which we are expert," she said. "That's what matters, not some outmoded view that what we do always has to fit into two years. The reality is that there are many programs that take more than two years now."
Rather than a need unfilled, the universities saw a grab for turf and power and turned out a full-court press against the proposal that saw the presidents of all three public universities in Arizona -- the University of Arizona, Arizona State and Northern Arizona University -- personally lobbying legislators.
Allan Price, vice president for institutional advancement at Arizona State, said he was not convinced that there was a demonstrated need in any of the areas in which the community colleges were contemplating four-year programs, and said that the proposal represented a threat to the carefully delineated system in place now.
"This is a solution looking for a problem," he said. "Right now we have a system that's very coherent. We need to be very careful about blurring the lines that work well now."
In the end, the proposal narrowly passed and then was vetoed by Gov. Fyfe Symington. Two study groups have been convened to examine the issue further, and it is likely to reemerge next fall.
To many people both inside and outside the community college system here, the issue in Arizona is a precursor to a much broader look at what kind of role community colleges should play at a time the public is demanding cheaper, more relevant, more efficient education, and when cost pressures are making it impossible for universities to build enough buildings and hire enough professors to meet anticipated needs.
"I think the recognition is building, but it will take a long time," said David Pierce, president of the American Association of Community Colleges, in Washington. "Right now the public is very positive toward community colleges. Our job is to work hard to keep building an identity and a message."
Among issues that need to be addressed, Mr. Elsner, the Maricopa chancellor, cited a more equitable share of Federal science financing and international development grants, as well as making financial aid more responsive to the needs of nontraditional students.
Regardless of what happens with the four-year proposal, he said there will inevitably be more collisions, not just between two- and four-year institutions, but between traditional institutions and emerging for-profit ones which are now operating in states around the country, like the entrepreneurial University of Phoenix.
Experts say these confrontations are all part of the change slowly transforming higher education here and elsewhere. This change, Ms. Thor said, may blur the neat lines between two-year and four-year institutions, but that is not necessarily bad.
"If you look at other industries -- utilities, telecommunications, health care -- the lines used to be neat and well defined, and then the market changed completely," she said. "They were restructured into very different industries with a lot more competition. I think we're the next health care."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 18; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1067 words

HEADLINE: Making a Federal Case

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis; Anthony Lewis, the author of two books on Supreme Court cases, is a columnist for The New York Times.

 BODY:

NEW FEDERALIST PAPERS
 Essays in Defense of the Constitution.
 By Alan Brinkley, Nelson W. Polsby
 and Kathleen M. Sullivan.
 179 pp. New York: A 20th Century Fund Book/
 W. W. Norton & Company. $23. 
 The men who assembled at the Constitutional Convention of 1787 had a daunting goal: to create a new Federal Government that would knit together jealously independent states. They had to be optimists, but they would surely be astonished at the success of their creation.
How ungrateful we are today for the miracle of their governmental structure. We live in a time of political discontent that goes even to our basic institutions. Radicals in Congress, calling themselves conservative, press for major surgery on the Constitution. Some demand an end to the judicial independence that has assured our freedom. The very idea of the Federal Government is treated with contempt.
This contemporary assault on our system led the 20th Century Fund to commission "New Federalist Papers," essays in defense of the Constitution by Alan Brinkley, Nelson W. Polsby and Kathleen M. Sullivan, respectively professors of history at Columbia University, political science at the University of California, Berkeley, and law at Stanford. As the title of the collection indicates, the authors go back to first principles -- to the arguments made in the Federalist Papers to save the Constitution from defeat in the state ratifying conventions to which it was submitted.
We are mostly unaware now what a close thing ratification was. Americans had just carried out a revolution against the centralized power of an English king. Many feared that the proposed new Federal Government would bring tyranny again.
Defenders of the Constitution responded to that fear with what Bernard Bailyn of Harvard has called "one of the great surges of creative political thought in Western history," most of all in the articles that constitute the Federalist Papers. This collection, by James Madison, Alexander Hamilton and John Jay, was produced mainly for newspaper publication, at the astounding average rate of 1,000 words a day for over six months. Yet it is rightly compared to the work of the greatest political philosophers.
The Federalist Papers' answer to the fear of power was that safety lay, as Madison put it, in "the extent and proper structure" of the proposed Federal Government. The very size and diversity of its constituent states and populations would make it safer than smaller, more homogeneous polities because "the greater variety of parties and interests" would prevent a passing political passion from overwhelming the system. A second defense against political extremism was that the constitutional system was not a direct democracy, with all the dangers of popular emotionalism, but a republic -- in which the people's views would be filtered through elected representatives.
But it was the governmental structure, the most ingenious of the Framers' creations, on which the Federalist Papers most heavily relied as assurance against abuse of power. Authority was divided between the states and the national Government. And within the latter there was the separation of powers among the three branches -- executive, legislative, judicial -- each on guard against overreaching by the others.
The wisdom of the Framers has been proved so often over 200 years that it should not be necessary to examine their views again. But it is necessary, as "New Federalist Papers" makes plain. For those who are attacking the constitutional system now make some of the same arguments that were made against the Constitution at the beginning -- in corrupted form.
Thus we are told that the Federal Government is inherently evil, that its functions should be turned over to the states. But for the reasons that Madison and his colleagues saw, it would be exactly wrong -- unsafe -- to leave Americans to the mercies of the separate states. Moreover, the cry for "states' rights" is hypocritical, in fact masking a desire to advance particular interests. The same people who denounce Federal power have federalized ordinary criminal law to an extent that would have appalled the Framers, and demand that tort law -- always a province of the states -- be federalized to protect corporate defendants from large judgments.
Brinkley explains how we have lost what was the premise of 1787: the belief that government can work. Fewer and fewer citizens perform their essential duty -- voting. Most see politics on a television screen, and regard it as a closed world "in which nothing is real and nothing is true."
Public contempt for government, he says, produces a vicious circle that makes government worse. Suspicion of scandal immobilizes bureaucracies. Official discretion is feared, so that we surround every potential decision with conditions that prevent action.
Sullivan examines the current attempts to impose social or economic policies by amending the Constitution. We tried that once before, she notes, with the Prohibition amendment: not a happy precedent. If we had had a balanced budget amendment in force for the last 50 years, she says, "the nation's economic health would be a great deal weaker now."
POLSBY asks Americans, movingly, to think about how well we have done in governing a continental nation: "If one accepts the premise that tribalism is a human universal, then the incarceration of Japanese-Americans in World War II, the exclusion of Jews from universities and the professions in the 1920's and 1930's, the ruthless persecution of Mormons, the removal of Indian tribes and the maintenance of a brutal, racial caste system in the pre-1960's South seem less remarkable than the eventual alleviation, reversal or abandonment of all these social policies by the American political system."
It is not possible to give more than a few examples of the themes in "New Federalist Papers." Some of it examines particular issues of only passing interest. But there is much here that goes to the roots of our political system and its present illness.
The authors do not offer easy remedies, and I do not suppose there are any. But the more Americans read and understand this wise book, the healthier our political society will be. We might become less cynical about politics. We might be less susceptible to political quackery about the evil of the United States Government.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Chicago

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON; DIRK JOHNSON is a correspondent in the Chicago bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
This Midwestern behemoth is a city that seems eternally at work: building, shaping, dealing. But in summer, Chicago is at play: Sunbathers on Oak Street Beach and sailboats on Lake Michigan, baseball at Wrigley Field and iced tea at Rush Street outdoor cafes. Chicago these days seems one long celebration, a time for survivors of the famously brutal winters to cherish the loveliness, and liberation, of summertime in the city.
The mood of this traditionally blunt, no-nonsense capital of Middle America is positively giddy at the moment. Crime has fallen. The economy is booming. New town houses and shops are transforming old neighborhoods. Growing numbers of suburbanites have been returning to shop and play, and even to live. 
 Late last month, road repairs were slowing traffic on Michigan Avenue from the Chicago River to Randolph Avenue; visitors may face delays.
 
Events
 The Chicago Jazz Festival, a celebration from Aug. 28 to 31 in Grant Park alongside Lake Michigan, will feature Betty Carter, the bebop singer, as well as Clarence (Gatemouth) Brown and his Big Band and the Joe Henderson Quartet, among many others. Seats go fast, so take a chair or a blanket to spread on the grass. Performances are Aug. 28, 6 to 10 P.M.; Aug. 29, 5 to 10 P.M., and Aug. 30 and 31, noon to 10 P.M. Information: (312) 744-3370. Admission is free.
One of the top acts (literally) at the Chicago Air and Water Show, an exhibition of daring over Lake Michigan Aug. 23 and 24, will be the United States Air Force Thunderbirds, precision-formation fighter pilots commanding F-16 Fighting Falcons. The beaches at Oak Street or North Avenue are good places to watch. Information: (312) 744-3370. Exhibitions by trick water-skiers start at 9 A.M. The air show begins at 11 A.M., with the Thunderbirds performing at 3 P.M. Admission is free.
The Gold Coast Art Fair on Friday, Saturday and Sunday on the sidewalks just northwest of downtown features the works of about 300 artists, mostly paintings and sculpture. The fair is centered on the intersection of Erie and Wells, in the city's River North area. Hours are 10 A.M. to 8 P.M.; admission is free. Information: (312) 787-2677.
The Chicago Symphony Orchestra is presenting a series of open-air performances next weekend at Ravinia, (847) 266-5100, in suburban Highland Park, about 25 miles north of the city. Performances start at 8 P.M. on Friday and Saturday and 7 P.M. on Sunday. A Metra "Ravinia Park Special" train leaves Madison and Canal Streets at 5:50 and arrives at Ravinia's gate at 6:30 P.M. ($4 round trip). The orchestra will present works by Beethoven, Schubert, Brahms and Verdi and Mahler, among others. Other performers at Ravinia include the flutist James Galway with the Ravinia Festival Orchestra on Aug. 14; Willie Nelson on Aug. 22 and the Joffrey Ballet of Chicago on Aug. 27 to 30 (all at 8 P.M.). Tickets, $8 to $40.
The Steppenwolf Theater Company, with its reputation for visceral, highly charged works, and alumni that include John Malkovich, Joan Allen and Gary Sinise, will present "A Fair Country," by Jon Robin Baitz, about a family in South Africa, through Aug. 24. Performances are at the Steppenwolf Theater, 1650 North Halsted Street, (312) 335-1650. Tickets, $24.50 to $36.50.
A collection of sculpture from India, the Himalayas and Southeast Asia will be displayed at the Art Institute of Chicago, 111 South Michigan Avenue, (312) 443-3600, through Oct. 26. The sculptures are chiseled from sandstone as well as delicately crafted in bronze, copper, silver and gold. They include images of the gods Shiva and Vishnu and an elegant seated Indra (the Vedic god of the heavens who hurls thunderbolts). They are on loan from the collection of Chicagoans Marilynn Alsdorf and her late husband, James. The museum has one of the world's largest collections of Impressionist art, among other treasures. Suggested admission $7; free on Tuesday. Open Monday to Friday 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., and until 8 P.M. on Tuesday; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday, noon to 5 Sunday.
 
Sightseeing
 The best place for shopping and people-watching is along North Michigan Avenue, a stretch that includes the grand old limestone Water Tower, the only major building downtown to escape the Chicago Fire of 1871. A mile or so to the south, noisy El trains circle the famous Loop, still a bustling commercial district, a place where ordinary Chicagoans tend to do their shopping, rather than on the expensive North Michigan Avenue. Just west of the El tracks is the nation's tallest building, the 110-story Sears Tower, 233 South Wacker Drive. An observation deck on the 103d floor, (312) 875-9696, is open daily, 9 A.M. to 11 P.M. Admission is $6.75. The entrance is on Jackson Boulevard between Wacker Drive and Franklin Street.
The Chicago Architecture Foundation, (312) 922-3432, offers excellent architecture tours, by foot, bus, bike or riverboat, for $10 to $25. Sites include the Frank Lloyd Wright home at 951 Chicago Avenue in the suburb of Oak Park; the dramatic Wrigley Building at the river bridge on Michigan Avenue, and the Carson Pirie Scott Department Store at State and Madison Streets.
Anyone who wants his 15 minutes of fame recorded on videotape should head for the Museum of Broadcast Communications, in the Chicago Cultural Center at the corner of Michigan Avenue and Washington Street, (312) 629-6000. Along with displaying an authentic Charlie McCarthy used by Edgar Bergen and an example of the first swiveling television set, the museum allows visitors to slip on a jacket and a clip-on microphone, then settle into the anchor's chair and read news from a teleprompter. The tape of the show costs $14.95. Open Monday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., and Sunday noon to 5; free admission.
The Field Museum, Roosevelt Road at Lake Shore Drive, (312) 922-9410, is a stately Georgian marble building displaying 23 Egyptian mummies, among other artifacts; visitors descend into a full-size copy of a mastaba (burial chamber) to reach the mummies. Through Sept. 1, the Dinosaur Families exhibit features bones from the Titanosaurus and Majungasaurus, discovered recently in Madagascar, and a 10-foot-tall dinosaur robot that roars like the real thing. The museum is open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily, on summer Thursdays to 9. Admission is $7, free on Wednesday and Thursday eve ning. The dinosaur exhibit costs an extra $3.
 
Where to Stay
The Whitehall, 105 East Delaware Place, (312) 944-6300, fax (312) 573-6250, is a quiet hotel in the Gold Coast shopping and residential district. Its 221 rooms have understated English decor. Doubles start at $259; there are seasonal and weekend specials.
The 535-room Drake Hotel, 140 East Walton Place, (312) 787-2200, fax (312) 787-1431, an elegant old hotel in Italian Renaissance style, has played host to heads of state from virtually every region of the world. Inside the Bedford limestone building, the marble-floored lobby is warmed by Oriental rugs, and ornately carved plaster adorns the soaring celings. The gracious, traditionally decorated rooms are a bit smaller than at some of the newer hotels. There is a fitness center. Doubles are $265 weekdays, $185 weekends.
Budget: The 358-room Best Western Inn of Chicago, 162 East Ohio Street, (312) 787-3100, fax (312) 573-3140, is a half-block east of Michigan Avenue. The hotel was built in 1927, but rooms have modern furnishings. Double rooms start at $99.
Across from the lake, the 578-room Days Inn Lake Shore Drive, 644 North Lake Shore Drive, (312) 943-9200, fax (312) 255-4411, is within walking distance of Michigan Avenue and three blocks from Navy Pier. The hotel has an outdoor pool and an indoor fitness center. Double rooms start at $129.
Luxury: The 343-room Four Seasons Hotel Chicago, 120 East Delaware Place, (312) 280-8800, fax (312) 280-9184, in the 900 North Michigan Avenue building, has a marble lobby and a grand staircase, as well as a running track on the roof and an indoor pool. Double rooms, decorated with a traditional English flavor, start at $395 weekdays, $300 weekends.
 
Where to Eat
 Charlie Trotter's, 816 West Armitage Avenue, (773) 248-6228, specializes in a modern American cuisine influenced by Asian minimalism. The chef is known for the artistic presentation of his dishes. Diners generally order the tasting menu, sampling six to eight courses, for $90. There are three intimate dining rooms in the two-story, turn-of-the-century brownstone building. Among the favorites is Illinois rabbit loin and foie gras seared with golden chanterelle mushrooms, swiss chard and cumin-scented sweet corn emulsion. Dinner for two, with wine, costs about $250. Reservations necessary. Dinner only; closed Sunday and Monday.
In this meat-and-potatoes city, Gene & Georgetti's, 500 North Franklin Street, (312) 527-3718, famous for its steaks since the 1940's, is not the kind of place to worry about cholesterol. Its broiled T-bone steak, 32 ounces ($33.50 at dinner), is served with cottage-fried potatoes and salad. Patrons often split the meat portions. A three-course dinner for two with a bottle of wine runs about $90. Dark wood paneling sets a classic tone in this 175-seat spot. The restaurant plans to close on Aug. 14 to add another 100 seats; it is scheduled to reopen Sept. 3. Open Monday to Saturday for lunch and dinner.
Shaw's Crab House, 21 East Hubbard Street, (312) 527-2722, is noted for dependably fresh seafood and attentive service, in a crowded setting that feels like 1940's New England. The menu depends on what's in season; sauteed soft-shell crabs ($17.95) will be available until around mid-August. Reservations are a good idea, for lunch and dinner. There is live blues and jazz on Tuesday and Thursday evenings. A three-course dinner for two with a bottle of wine costs around $75. Open every day for dinner, lunch Monday through Saturday.
Earth, 738 North Wells Street, (312) 335-5475, serves mostly organic and environmentally-conscious fare, such as chemical-free, naturally raised chicken. The vegetable stew with baby squash and mushroom puree ($14.95 at dinner) is among several fine vegetarian offerings. A three-course dinner for two with a bottle of organic wine runs about $70. Beer is also available. Lunch Monday through Saturday, dinner Tuesday through Saturday.
Chicago is known for delicious pizza, and Pizzeria Uno, 29 East Ohio Street, (312) 321-1000, which predated the chain, specializes in the deep-dish pies. A large pizza with mushrooms and green peppers costs about $20. Open every day for lunch and dinner.
Breakfast is good at the Original Pancake House, 22 East Bellevue Avenue, (312) 642-7917, especially the oven-baked apple pancake with a cinnamon-sugar glaze, which is $6.75. Cash only. Open daily.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Deals and Discounts

BYLINE: By JANET PIORKO 

 BODY:

CAYMANS PACKAGED -- The Cayman Islands Department of Tourism has launched Chillin' 'n' Cayman, a package program available through mid-December from a variety of tour companies; consumers must buy the packages through a travel agent. For example, Gogo Worldwide Vacations has a four-day, three-night package starting at $539 a person, double occupancy, through Sept. 5; the price drops to $499 after that. The price includes round-trip air fare from New York on American Airlines to Grand Cayman; transfers; three nights at the Ambassador Inn, the Sleep Inn or Sunset House, and hotel tax. Those who buy the package also get a discount card good at restaurants and attractions. Information: (800) 327-8777. 

MANHATTAN DISCOUNTS -- Through Sept. 2, the Crowne Plaza Manhattan, (800) 243-6969, at 49th Street and Broadway, is offering a rate of $169 a night plus tax, single or double occupancy, from Thursday through Sunday. The Crowne Plaza at the United Nations, on 42d Street between Second and First Avenues, (800) 879-8836, has a rate of $149 on the same dates. The West Side hotel has 770 rooms and a 29,000-square-foot health club with a 50-foot indoor pool; the East Side hotel has 300 rooms and a fitness center.
The 561-room Millenium Hilton, 55 Church Street, across from the World Trade Center, has a rate of $119 plus tax for a double on Fridays and Saturdays this month; (212) 693-2001, ask for package PW. The hotel has a fitness center and indoor pool.
 
MAURITIUS GETAWAY -- Seven-night packages to the island of Mauritius in the Indian Ocean are offered by Air Mauritius starting at $1,899 a person, double occupancy, Sept. 1 to Oct. 30. They include round-trip flights from New York on Virgin Atlantic and Air Mauritius; accommodations; two meals daily, and transfers. The minimum-price hotels are the Colonial Coconut or Colonial Beach; the Berjaya Le Morne Beach Resort is $2,145. Activities on the 720-square-mile island include diving and fishing. Call (800) 537-1182.
 
SKY DRIVING -- Destination Europe, the tour company of Auto Europe, is offering a week's car rental at no extra charge to travelers who buy a round-trip air ticket to Europe in its Sky Drive program. With a ticket to London from New York at $654 a person, for example, travelers get an Opel Corsa or similar manual-transmission economy car with unlimited mileage. Tax is extra; insurance must be bought in Italy. The offer, based on two traveling together, is valid through Sept. 15. There are some limits on availability, but a spokeswoman said travelers who can be flexible in their dates should be able to take advantage of the offer. Tickets must be bought seven business days before departure, and there may be penalties for changes or cancellation. Information: (800) 223-5555. JANET PIORKO
