HEADLINE: COLLEGE & MONEY;
Balancing the Babies and the Books

BYLINE: By HALIMAH ABDULLAH; Halimah Abdullah is a senior at the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa.

 BODY:
Two years ago, Marie Gardner was on welfare, a single mother of two who put her children in a cart attached to a bicycle and pedaled 10 miles a day to and from her classes at South Suburban College in South Holland, a Chicago suburb. Today she has a nursing degree, a car and a job at Ingalls Memorial Hospital in nearby Harvey, Ill.
 Ms. Gardner credits the day care center at South Suburban, a community college, for providing her and her children with the financial and moral support they needed. 
 "I couldn't have made it through school and off welfare without the help," she said.
 Increasingly, today's college students are, like Ms. Gardner, single parents struggling to balance course work, financial hardships and their children's needs. For many, the ability to find adequate, affordable child care can make the difference between remaining in school or dropping out, said Denise Fogarty, program director for Child Care Aware, a nonprofit organization based in Rochester, Minn., that helps parents contact child care referral services.
 "There is a trend that more colleges and universities are becoming aware of the needs of parents with small children," she said. "They are discovering what they believe is a solution -- on-site child care."
 According to the American Council on Education, in Washington, by the year 2005, there will be roughly 6.5 million students aged 25 and older enrolled in the nation's colleges and universities. Taking a cue from big business, administrators are finding that one of the best ways to serve these students is with on-campus child care, said Todd Boressoff, advocacy chairman for the National Coalition for Campus Children's Centers, in Cascade, Wis. Nationwide, roughly 1,700 campuses are offering on-campus child care, he said.
 The schools are as varied as the services. From four-year Ivy League institutions like Cornell University and the University of Pennsylvania to state universities and two-year community colleges, schools are discovering that offering child care saves thousands of dollars in tuition and other fees that are lost when overburdened students drop out to care for children.
 Even those who stay in school sometimes bring their children to class. "That was definitely a problem for us," said Gale Stevens Haynes, provost of the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University, which now offers on-site child care. "We knew that it was not a good environment for any of the people involved. But whenever a student you recruit leaves, it costs the university."
 Students who drop out, especially those on public assistance, cost not only the college or university, but also society, said Jose Regalado, assistant dean of job training at South Suburban College. The college's five-year-old Opportunities program, which helped Ms. Gardner, is designed to provide low-income students with day care services.
 "The whole idea of work force preparation is that you can't have economic development without a trained work force," he said.
 Although schools' participation in on-site day care is new, student advocacy for obtaining these services is not.
 In 1970, a group of graduate students at Cornell University helped pioneer the on-site day care movement by forming a parent cooperative to help take care of one another's children. Now, the University Cooperative Nursery School serves the children of about 50 student, faculty and staff members, said Sally Reimer, the school's part-time director.
 Parents can choose from two-, three- and five-day enrollment options, and they pay on a sliding scale, based on income. Although not officially connected with Cornell, the nursery school is allowed free use of campus space.
 "In addition, Cornell issues the teachers' checks," Ms. Reimer said, "so that they are eligible for campus employee benefits."
 The Penn Children's Center at the University of Pennsylvania, which cares for 73 children, is also an offshoot, said Angali Chawla, the center's director. Originally managed by the university's School of Social Work, the center is now a separate entity, supported by the university and parents' tuition payments. These range from $140 to $210, based on the age of the child.
 While services like these can often rely on private and student contributions, schools with more indigent parents face greater difficulties. Currently, the Federal Government provides colleges with a child care allowance for student parents on public assistance. The amount varies, based on the number of students receiving welfare. Some institutions combine this financing with state funds. Some needy students also use money from Federal Pell grants to help pay their child care costs.
 Sometimes universities and colleges must create a veritable financial gumbo to provide the child care services that best serve their students, said Charlene Kohler-Britton, director of Brooklyn College Child Care Services Inc. Her program currently serves 35 children of students attending Brooklyn College, a branch of the City University of New York.
 "What the students get out of it is a nearby place to put their kids," she said. "What the school gets out of it is the ability to pay teachers with Federal money."
More than 20 of the students using the college's day care are on public assistance; they net almost $67,000 in Federal aid for the program. Program administrators use this amount, along with state funds, to pay for five teachers' and assistants' salaries and supplies. Students pay anywhere from $1 to $48 a week, based on their incomes, Ms. Kohler-Britton said.
 Zephie Powell, an adjunct professor of English and a graduate student at Brooklyn College, is confined to a wheelchair, the result of third-degree burns she suffered as a child. The 33-year-old mother of two daughters, she found her child care options limited when she returned to school for a master's in education.
 "I would go to school until 10 or 11 o'clock at night," she said. "A lot of times, I had to bring the baby to class."
 After a professor pointed Mrs. Powell in the direction of the program, she quickly enrolled.
 "What makes it easy for me is that everything is in one place," Mrs. Powell said, "where I go to school, where my child goes to school, where I work and where I study."
 Convenience is an increasingly important factor for the older college population, said Ms. Stevens Haynes. Long Island University's student body, which is 68 percent female, virtually demanded that the school address this issue, she said.
 The university responded last fall by contracting Corporate Child Care Services, a for-profit day care business, to serve the 100 children of students who need such care. The service costs $400,000 a year, a great deal less than the estimated $2 million it would have cost the university to build and staff its own day care center, Ms. Stevens Haynes said.
 Legislative trends toward cutting welfare rolls have also made child care a much more urgent need, said Alistair MacKinnon, coordinator of Federal education legislation for the New York State Department of Education.
 Carlow College, a four-year liberal arts institution in Pittsburgh's inner city, allocates $300,000 annually to provide child care, said Sister Mary Paul Hickey, executive director of the college's Children's Center.
 "We were seeing increasingly young parents coming back to school to get their degrees," she said.
 Nearly a fourth of the college's 22,000 students uses the school's two child care centers, one of which is located in the Bedford Dwellings housing project.
 While most students in the Opportunities program at South Suburban College receive both Federal financial aid and welfare assistance, it is not enough to cover the additional cost of child care, Mr. Regalado said. The program provides day care services and, in some cases, an additional $300 annual stipend.
 "Welfare parents find themselves taking care of kids and living off the Government," he said. "The best thing to do is to help them find child care, train them and get them in the work force."
 
Ways to Get Help With Your Children on Campus
 
Todd Boressoff, advocacy chairman for the National Coalition for Campus Children's Centers, in Cascade, Wis., suggests the following strategies for students seeking child care:
-- When considering a college or university, ask the admissions officers about campus-based child care. Some schools have on-site centers, while others contract out to corporate services.
-- If a school has on-site day care, look into it as soon as you are accepted. Most centers have a limited capacity and long waiting lists.
-- If a school does not have on-site day care, investigate the nearest child care resource and referral agency. Such services can often help find affordable providers.
-- If dealing with day care centers, check on their schedules. Not all offer early-morning and extended hours.
-- Look into financial aid. In most cases, student aid can be used to pay for child care services, but only after primary educational expenses have been met. When considering these sources, consult a financial aid counselor.

HEADLINE: Teaching on the Front Lines

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON; Karen W. Arenson covers higher education for The New York Times.

DATELINE: MANASSAS, Va.

 BODY:
Life as a community college professor sometimes turns Sheri David churlish. At a barbecue this summer, she snapped at a professor from a prestigious four-year college who was complaining about being forced to teach three classes in the coming term. She usually teaches five.
 And in a van to the airport after a history conference in Chicago last year, she turned to a professor in the seat behind her and told him "to shut up" after listening to him whine about how his college paid for only two nights of travel, rather than the typical three. Her college allots her $50; she pays the rest. 
 Like many community college professors across America, Professor David, who teaches history at Northern Virginia Community College, in Manassas, has seen her career turn out far differently from what she had envisioned.
 As a student at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, she studied under Arthur Schlesinger Jr., the noted historian, and hoped to emulate his career as a researcher and writer. During graduate school, she taught at Essex County College in Newark, Lehman College in the Bronx and Caldwell College in New Jersey. After graduate school, there were jobs at Hofstra University on Long Island, and then, after she divorced and moved south for personal reasons, at George Mason University in Virginia. Eight years ago, she came to Northern Virginia Community College because it offered her a permanent, full-time position. Here she finds little time to do research or write.
 "When I took this job at the community college, I knew I was destroying my career," said Professor David.
 But Professor David, who is 48, is not as unhappy as she sounds.
 Like many of the 200,000 full-time community college professors in America, she loves what she is doing and is convinced that it is important. She has forged a career as a college professor, even as many of her fellow graduate students failed to find jobs in academia. She is passionate about teaching and relishes even her basic courses, like American History I and II. And even though she spends most of her time teaching basic history, she does not have to spend time teaching other basics. Although many community colleges struggle with students who know little English or who are not ready to do college work, these are not big problems for Manassas and the four other Northern Virginia Community College campuses. The college draws many of its 60,000 students from the middle- and upper-middle-class communities around it. In fact, more than 500 of its students already have Ph.D.'s, and many are there for training that will help them enter new fields, like computing.
 Professor David sees community colleges as the front lines of higher education in a nation that has placed a bigger and bigger premium on getting a college degree.
 "I'm now one of these totally committed community college people," she said. "When I go to the two main history conferences, people ask me whether I am looking to leave," she added. "I say, 'No, why would I?' I really enjoy it."
 In addition, history courses are staples for many community college students, because the credits are generally transferable to four-year colleges.
 "Half of all college students taking history are getting their history from community colleges," Professor David said. "So I feel good about my role."
 She even loves speaking to community groups -- one of the forms of community service that her college expects of its faculty, although it does not pay them extra.
 But there are drawbacks to working at a community college, she concedes, conditions that sometimes make her feel as if she and her colleagues "are doing our jobs with one hand tied behind our backs."
 The biggest is pay.
 Teaching loads at community colleges are higher than those at four-year colleges, but salaries are generally lower. With state budget cuts, Northern Virginia's pay scales have slipped among community colleges. As a single mother supporting two sons in college, Professor David finds her $44,000 salary doesn't stretch very far.
 Another disadvantage is the limited support for career development.
 Although Northern Virginia has some programs to foster faculty development (like encouraging them to use their classrooms for research that they can publish in journals), the college does not offer much time for research or paid sabbaticals. When Professor David won a Fulbright-Hays fellowship to teach in Belarus four years ago, Northern Virginia had to make special arrangements to pay part of her salary so that she could take the position.
 Working conditions are also spartan, even in Professor David's building, which was constructed last year. As she ushered a visitor into her office -- a faculty cubicle separated from others by dividers -- it was hard to ignore the English professor next door quizzing a student about why he missed the first two classes in the term. And while the college hopes to give each faculty member a computer before the end of the summer, for now, groups of professors must share machines.
 All this was forgotten, however, as Professor David headed for her 6:30 class in American History on a hot Monday evening in early July. Nearly 30 students, most in their teens or early 20's, were crammed into a small classroom, waiting patiently for the professor.
 College professors often try to avoid teaching in the summer. For Professor David, however, it is an economic necessity. But she also views the summer session as "fun," because half of the students are from other colleges, and many dislike history.
 "It is a personal challenge to turn them around," she said.
 In the classroom, she quickly took attendance, and then moved briskly into a whirlwind tour of American politics in the early 1900's: Teddy Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson, the Panama Canal, muckraking -- all in a couple of hours.
 Much of the class was a straightforward lecture. Professor David, wearing comfortable shoes and a silky shirtdress, alternated between standing behind a lectern and sitting on the front edge of her desk. She knew her material and was an engaging speaker.
 She squeezed in points about how history is chronicled and information gathered. She played a brief tape of Pete Seeger singing about coal miners, for example, and asked the class what information they could glean from the song. "Sometimes we can see history or hear history," she said.
 Professor David also related her lesson to current events, suggesting, for example, that the strong modern American presidency has its roots in the early days of the century. Teddy Roosevelt, she told her students, sent the Navy halfway around the world and then dared Congress to get it back.
 Although it was the end of the day, and many students had come to class from full-time jobs, most were attentive.
 "I hate history," said Brian Paget, a 20-year-old student from James Madison University, who is trying to squeeze enough courses for a triple major into five years, "but I need general education credits and I am finding this interesting." Northern Virginia allows him to take summer courses cheaply. He added: "She really brings a lot of visual images into it. She uses techniques I've read about. My last teacher was so bad, I didn't go to class."
 After the class break, Professor David raced through a variety of social issues -- child labor, worker safety, prohibition, racism, women's suffrage, birth control. "You get the idea," she said. "There was a lot of stuff going on.
 "We've swept through the entire progressive movement," she said at the end of the class. Then she added suggestively, "You can take an entire course of this."
 She does not teach such a class herself. But she does give one on Vietnam, a course on policy issues surrounding the American experience there, which she says she would probably not be allowed to teach at a university because she has not published in the field.
 Teaching the course in Northern Virginia has been especially interesting, she said, because of the diverse mix of students: veterans, children of veterans, current military officials and lately, more and more nearby residents of Vietnamese descent.
 Sometimes the conversation gets heated, and she has to put a lid on the discussion.
 "I remind the students that where they were and when they were there very much defines their experience," she said. "It doesn't substitute for the whole picture."
 What she likes best, she added, is that "I never know what to expect."
 One student, a military officer, took Vietnamese history at three different colleges to see how it was being taught. He was particularly worried about her course, she said, because it was being taught by a woman, but he sat through the semester.
 "He said it was fine," she recalled with a satisfied smile. "That was his highest compliment."

HEADLINE: Bringing Hope and Education To the Reservation;
Tribal Colleges Grapple With Challenges of Success

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES; Steven A. Holmes covers race relations and demographics for The New York Times.

DATELINE: CROW AGENCY, Mont.

 BODY:
Two years ago, Danetta Jane Holds, a Crow Indian, tried to help her 15-year-old son with his algebra homework and discovered to her horror that she couldn't do it. This abrupt affirmation of her educational shortcomings convinced Ms. Holds, who never went beyond high school, that it was time to finally get a college degree.
 Daunted by the prospect of traveling 65 miles to the nearest four-year college in Billings and what she saw as an alien and not very friendly white world, Ms. Holds enrolled at Little Big Horn College, a two-year community college on the sprawling Crow Reservation in south central Montana. 
 "There are no strangers here," she said. "I got married when I was pretty young, so I've never actually been any place else. So it's kind of scary to go other places. I'd rather stay here. This is my sanctuary, the Crow reservation."
 Ms. Holds's reasoning is shared by thousands of Indian students and helps to explain the explosive growth in recent decades of tribal colleges, which are chartered by their tribes and based on remote reservations primarily in the West, where most Indians live.
 Many of the tribal colleges were founded because a number of Indian educators became concerned about the high dropout rates for Indian college students. Studies in the 1970's indicated that about 70 percent of Indian students quit college before graduating from traditional four-year schools, and at many institutions, the dropout rate was more than 90 percent.
 Indian leaders blame racism, a lack of sensitivity among authorities at mainstream colleges and the poor preparation of many Indian students who attend high school on reservations. But they acknowledge that cultural considerations play a part, especially for some close-knit tribes like the Crow. Many educators involved in the founding of tribal colleges believed that the answer was a system of colleges on the reservations that would grant degrees or ease the transition from reservation life to mainstream schools.
 Since 1968, when the Navajo tribe established Navajo Community College in Tsaile, Ariz., the number of colleges chartered by Indian tribes and run by Indian administrators has increased to 27. The number of full- and part-time students attending these colleges and three others run directly by the Federal Government has more than doubled since 1989, to about 25,000 from 10,000.
 Tribal colleges are now among the bright spots on Indian reservations, which, despite the emergence of casino gambling, remain some of the poorest areas in the United States, with an overall unemployment rate of 49 percent.
 In a May report, the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching said that tribal colleges had "taken on a breathtaking array of responsibilities" and that with each passing year, they "prove their worth to Indian communities and the nation."
 Yet tribal colleges are struggling financially. Unlike other community colleges in the country, they receive no funding from state and local governments, which view the colleges as Federal entities, because they are usually on Indian reservations. And because they have to keep their tuitions low, student fees cannot be counted on to finance the colleges. Legislation passed in 1978 authorizes a lump sum payment of Federal aid that translates to about $5,820 per Indian student. But Congress has never actually given the colleges that much money. Federal aid has also not kept pace with the growth in enrollment and is currently about $2,900 per student.
 "That's our number-one problem and our number-one challenge," said Gerald (Carty) Monette, president of Turtle Mountain Community College in Belcourt, N.D., which is associated with the Chippewa tribe. "Our funding is disastrous."
 Some college officials believe the financial situation is about to get worse. In addition to granting associate's degrees, the colleges offer remedial courses and general equivalency diplomas.
 In coming years, administrators fear that their campuses will be swamped by untrained and out-of-work Indians who have been forced off the welfare rolls by recent Federal legislation.
 "Many individuals are not employable," Mr. Monette said. "Most don't have skills to go out to find a job and keep it. But they have to do something, and most will go to places like the tribal colleges."
 The financial fragility -- and resourcefulness -- of many tribal colleges can be seen at Little Big Horn. A tiny school of about 200 students, Little Big Horn is tucked away on the 2.2-million-acre Crow Reservation. The campus consists of a few trailers and a former gymnasium given to the college by the tribal government.
 The buildings have been expanded and renovated by carpentry and building trades students as their academic projects. Strapped for cash, administrators are paying the salaries of 4 of the school's 18 instructors through one- or two-year grants from private foundations until the school is sure there is enough student interest in these teachers' courses to pay them directly from the college's budget.
 School officials say this practice allows them to expand the number of courses without committing large sums of money up front. But they fret about possibly losing some faculty since they cannot promise to pay them after one or two years.
 "It's a very risky strategy, and it's a strategy that most colleges would never use," said Janine Pease Pretty On Top, president of Little Big Horn. "It's a very eyes-open way to try to build up our capacity. But it is a risk."
 Little Big Horn improvises in other ways. For example, through grants it has created an impressive computer network. More than 100 computer work stations -- about one for every two students -- are scattered throughout the college. And, as faculty like to point out, the computers are not under-powered hand-me-downs discarded by local businesses, but modern work stations loaded with sophisticated software. All of the computers on campus have Internet access and each student has an E-mail address.
 "People see we're a little tribal college in the back of Crow Agency and think they're going to see DOS computers and maybe a few scattered work stations," said Randy Falls Down, head of the computer science department. "But they're real surprised."
 The tribe, whose name in its own language is Apsaalooka or "children of the long-beaked bird," which was incorrectly translated by early white settlers as "crow," is a tight-knit group for whom maintenance of culture is important. About 75 percent of the approximately 7,000 tribe members live on or near the reservations, and about 85 percent speak the Crow language, a far higher proportion of native language speakers than any other tribe in the country, except the Navajo.
 Obligations to extended family are also critically important. "My seventh cousin is the same as my first cousin," said Jennifer Flatlip, head of the Crow Studies Department at Little Big Horn.
 As a result, members of the tribe are reluctant to leave the reservation and tend not to do well when they go to school elsewhere.
 "We don't think there is much out there that is worthwhile," said Ms. Pretty on Top.
 Given the remoteness of the reservation and the reluctance of tribal members to leave, Ms. Pretty on Top, like a number of other heads of tribal colleges, is trying to structure the school's curriculum to help the reservation's economic development.
 "We don't have nine randomly picked associate of arts degrees," she said. "We've chosen specific fields so that people can be working here. We're building this community, not any other community, so we're not a generic community college in that regard."
 Little Big Horn established its computer science program after surveys of businesses in nearby towns like Hardin, Mont., and Sheridan, Wyo., revealed a need for computer-literate workers. The college is also trying to build a strong program in natural science, a field that can lead to careers in land management and animal husbandry. The goal is to help train a cadre of Crow who can manage the reservation's buffalo and elk herd, its stock of trout and its oil, gas, coal and timber reserves.
 "I want to clean up the area," said Trisha Bird Bear, 19, a first-year student who wants to major in environmental science and natural resources and become an environmental lawyer.
 Ms. Bird Bear is the third in her family to attend college, but her older brother and sister, who went to school away from the reservation, both dropped out and returned home. Yet when asked if she was going to make it all the way through Little Big Horn, as well as through a four-year college and then law school, she answered matter of factly, "Of course."
 In some smaller ways, the college is trying to accomplish more immediate economic development.
 Little Big Horn, like a number of tribal colleges, tries to help nurture small businesses on the reservation and trains members of the tribe to be guides to fishermen angling for trout on the Big Horn River.
 In recent years the college began offering courses to train tour guides for the Little Big Horn Battlefield, which is about two miles away. Through its Institute for Micro-Business and Tourism, the school helped start Apsaalooka Tours, which this year won a concession to provide guided tours of the battlefield where George Armstrong Custer and the members of the Seventh Calvary were defeated by Sioux and Cheyenne warriors.
 Beyond the economic boost, the college also serves other purposes for the Crow. It is a community center where groups can hold meetings. Members of the tribe and other Indians can all use its library, which is linked electronically to five other regional libraries. . And the school strives to help insure the tribe's cultural heritage, requiring, for example, that all students, including non-Indians, take at least one semester of the Crow language.
 To some Crow, the college is also a symbol of nationhood, a reminder that their reservation is not merely a sprawling ghetto, but a sovereign entity deserving its own institutions.
 "We're like a national university," said Ms. Pretty On Top. "Like those national universities in Latin America. We exist for the preservation and the protection and, you might even say, the defense of the country. We're not just a neighborhood literacy center."
 In early June, in a stand of tall cottonwood trees, about two miles from the historic battlefield, 18 Indian students -- 1 Navajo and 17 Crow, including Denetta Holds -- strode onto a makeshift stage and received their associate of arts degrees.
 In the audience was Ken Dawes, 32, a 1995 graduate of Little Big Horn, who in May received his bachelor's degree from Montana State University in Billings. Mr. Dawes had dropped out of high school when he was 16 and didn't get his GED until 1988. Now he is hoping to get a master's degree in museum science and to do research on the Crow tribe.
His inspiration, he said, came from a former Crow chief.
 "It's like Chief Plenty Coups said," he explained. "With an education, you're the white man's equal. Without an education, you're his victim."

HEADLINE: Behind Botanical Garden's Renovation

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHEN the New York Botanical Garden's spectacular glasshouse, the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, reopened in May after a four-year, $25 million restoration, which returned the century-old building to its former splendor, nobody was happier than Amy E. Cohn.
For Ms. Cohn, director of capital projects at the Botanical Garden in the Bronx, it was a day of mixed emotions. 
 "I felt enormous relief, followed by great pride on behalf of all those people in every department of the garden who worked on the project," Ms. Cohn said. "They did a tremendous job."
As for Ms. Cohn, 51, who became the garden's first capital projects manager in 1989, the four years spent on the conservatory project not only transformed the building but also her job.
"When I first took the job, I was the entire Capital Projects Department," she said. "Four years later, we grew into a 12-member staff, with an in-house construction management team, project managers, administrators and support staff."
Ms. Cohn, who holds a Ph.D. in Fine Arts from Boston Univesity, wrote her dissertation on the post-war architecture of convention hotels. She also has master's . degrees in art history and finance. Her work experiences, she said, can be accurately classified as eclectic.
"Basically, the position I have today evolved through explorations," she said. "While I was at school I had a job with the Cambridge Historical Commission in Cambridge, Mass. I worked on preservation, which was a relatively new concept in 1970. I administered historic district cases and issues, discovering that I was good at administrative work, which I liked."
When she was ready to enter the work force full time, Ms. Cohn sent her resume to a dozen or more hotels.
"Why hotels? In writing my dissertation, I learned a lot about them," she said. "And I figured anyone with a Ph.D. who wanted to work in that relatively low-paying industry would at least get an interview.
"The only one interested was the executive vice president of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan. He asked me to come for an interview, and the upshot was that he offered me a sales job, which I declined. He later came up with the position of rehabilitation manager, which started out more like interior decorating."
But interior decorating quickly turned into renovation, and Ms. Cohn was assigned to the building superintendent.
"I knew nothing about construction, but I knew I'd better learn quickly," she said. "I followed the building superintendent around and noticed that, invariably, when he was inspecting a job he threw his hands in the air and swore. 'You call this a wiring job?' he would scathingly say. I got the hang of it. On my first assignment -- the renovation of a suite in the Towers -- I was quaking in my shoes, but I threw my hands in the air, pointing to a wall and in an aggressive tone, I said. 'You call that an electric outlet?' "
Eventually, Ms. Cohn was named the hotel's director of rehabilitation and was put in charge of planning, budgeting, design oversight for guest rooms. tower suites, meeting and conference rooms and restaurants.
She was also responsible for bidding projects to separate trades, awarding contracts and managing renovations.
"I like paying attention to detail, bringing projects in on time and on budget," she said.
But after three years, she was back in school part time, studying in a program for a master's degree in business administration from New York University.
"I thought it would be very useful to know something about accounting and tax issues if I wanted a job in business," she said. "I became vice president of the Georgetown Company in Manhattan, and one of my responsibilities was coordinating capital projects at the New York Public Library, which stood me in good stead later at New York Botanical Garden."
In the interim, Ms. Cohn married Rabbi Gordon Tucker, had two children and when they were growing up, worked as a commercial real estate broker before going back to work full time.
"The ideal job appeared in a classified ad, and my immediate reaction was: 'Here is a perfect match. A job that combines all my interests and experience,' " she recalled. "The best part about it was that I knew the Botanical Garden as the beautiful place my husband and I loved to visit. We were living in the Bronx then, and we jogged through the Botanical Garden forest very often."
When Ms. Cohn arrived at the garden in December 1989, two major capital projects, the conservatory and the Plants Study Center, a 70,000-square-foot space for the library and botanical collections, had already been planned.
"As the first capital projects director, I was asked to draw up a master plan of other projects," she said. "Two years later, there were 19 additional projects of all sizes in the plan budgeted at $40 million. The first project, the conservatory, began in 1993, and it was of such magnitude that we knew we had to hire an outside construction management firm."
But after a few months, problems appeared.
"There was some trouble with the glazing contractors and then with the painting contract, but the real problem was that we didn't have a direct relationship with the subcontractor," Ms. Cohn said. "When anything had to be changed, we had to go through the construction management people. It was a very costly and inefficient way to operate, and as time went on it was clear we needed a hands-on approach. To do management internally was expedient and economical with big savings in fees and staff. We took direct control, and at the time the old line company George Fuller went out of business, so we were able to pick up some very seasoned construction management people from Fuller."
Ms. Cohn now manages the Botanical Garden's capital projects department and as such oversees the planning, design, bidding, construction, furnishing close-out and completion of new buildings and restoration projects making up a capital projects program of more than $80 million.
"It's an ongoing program," she said. "Currently in the works is the Everett Children's Adventure Garden, eight acres where kids can investigate firsthand how plants live and function and what scientists do. And construction for the Plant Studies Center for the library and Herbarium, to house archival collections and research materials, budgeted at $28 million, is due to start in September."
When she is not at the garden, Ms. Cohn is busy with her duties as a rabbi's wife.
"I lead a dual existence," she said. "In 1994, when my husband became the rabbi of Temple Israel Center in White Plains, we moved to White Plains. Temple Israel is a conservative synagogue with an active membership numbering 850 families. I am involved in everything from weddings to Saturday morning services. We host dinners for new members several times a month at home and also host Shabbat dinners at the synagogue. But I still find time to jog. Most mornings at 6 A.M., I'm out there."

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Condo Board's Dinner
 
Q. Our town-home condominium homeowners association board, which is elected, gives itself an "appreciation dinner" each year. They also invite the lawyer and committee members. This year's dinner, which requires an expenditure of $3,000, was recently approved by the board. I have written to all homeowners, most of whom do not approve, but the apathy and indifference in the community is so high that no one takes any action. As for electing a new board, we have problems getting people to run. Does the board have the power to do this with our money? . . . Phyllis Spiegel, Plainsboro, N.J.
A. Eric Davis, a real estate lawyer who practices in both New York and New Jersey, said that the New Jersey law regarding condominiums provides that while a condominium board generally has the power to incur expenses on behalf of the condominium association, the board also has an obligation to refrain from fraud and self-dealing and to insure that the actions it takes are not "unconscionable." 
 "In essence, the board must act reasonably and in good faith," Mr. Davis said, adding that, in fact, annual "appreciation dinners" are quite common.
"Many co-ops and condominiums will run a dinner once a year as a way of showing appreciation to board members and to companies and individuals that the board does business with," Mr. Davis said. "You have to remember that in the vast majority of cases, condominium board membership is voluntary. Some board members put in hours and hours each month in furtherance of the condominium association's business. The dinners are a way of providing a small benefit to the non-paid members."
That having been said, however, there is always the possibility that spending $3,000 on a dinner might be considered unreasonable or unconscionable.
"If the dinner is for 10 or 15 people, you're talking about a fairly extraordinary expense," Mr. Davis said, adding that generally, such disputes must ultimately be resolved in court.
 
Piggyback Loan Vs. 2d Mortgage
 
Q. What is meant by a piggyback loan? How is a piggyback loan different from a second mortgage? . . . Tom Resadove, Yonkers
A. Richard Nardi, a Manhattan lawyer who is a past president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of New York, said that the term "piggyback loan" most likely refers to what is more commonly known as a "wrap-around mortgage."
Generally, Mr. Nardi said, such a mortgage is used to provide additional financing on property that is already encumbered by a first mortgage.
Assume that a co-op building has an existing first mortgage with an outstanding principal balance of $500,000 and an annual interest rate of 8 percent. The co-op needs to borrow $100,000 for capital improvements. With an ordinary second mortgage, the co-op would be obligated to make two mortgage payments every month -- one on the first mortgage and another on the new second mortgage.
With a wrap-around mortgage, however, the face amount of the new loan is the total of the outstanding balance on the first mortgage and the amount of new money being borrowed. While the borrower's new monthly payment is based on the total of both loans, the borrower actually receives only the new money. At the same time, however, the lender agrees -- in writing -- to make monthly payments on the borrower's original first mortgage as they come due.
Mr. Nardi said that one reason such mortgages are offered is because lenders can make more money from them. For example, he said, using the above situation, if a lender provides the co-op with a $600,000 wrap-around mortgage at an annual interest rate of 10 percent, the lender makes 10 percent on the $100,000 of "new" money and 2 percent on the remaining $500,000. The 2 percent "bonus" results from the fact that the borrower's original mortgage is being repaid by the new lender at the original interest rate of 8 percent.
And while it might seem foolish for a borrower to agree to such terms, Mr. Nardi said, there are times -- particularly when a borrower has credit or cash-flow problems -- when such a loan is the only kind he can obtain.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-DATE: August 3, 1997

SECTION: Section 2; Page 11; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2507 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Working the Angles in Low-Budget Paradise

BYLINE: By PETER M. NICHOLS 

DATELINE: SHREVEPORT, La.

 BODY:
IT'S A MODERATELY TENSE moment on a set high in the Louisiana Tower. Gliding into an office on in-line skates, a tall, stunning blonde in a red vinyl jumpsuit with deep decolletage and open midriff swoops around a desk and plunks herself down at a computer terminal. Carrie Ann Westcott was the centerfold in the September 1993 issue of Playboy magazine ("the back-to-school issue," she notes), but here she is portraying Sofia, an agent of evil forces on a global grab for treasure.
Posing as a pizza deliverywoman, Sofia has skated into the usually tightly guarded offices of Lethal (Legion to Assure Total Harmony and Law) and is about to make off with some crucial information from the computer. Across the desk, the cinematographer Howard Wexler leans into a viewfinder. Over his shoulder peers Andy Sidaris, a B-movie director with never a second's doubt about exactly what he wants in front of the camera. "That's great, sweetie, now look around warily," he tells Sofia. "Look back at the computer. Now hit the enter key." 
 Mr. Sidaris and his wife, Arlene, who produces his movies, have brought their small and smoothly functioning Skyhawks Films team from Hollywood to Shreveport to shoot some of the more expensive parts of "Return to Savage Beach," a straight-to-video action epic to rival his "Day of the Warrior," a best renter this year, and earlier Sidaris thrillers like "Fit to Kill," "Hard Hunted," "Guns" and "Savage Beach," the forerunner of the production at hand.
Sofia pecks at the keyboard, prompting a spray of colorful graphics on the computer screen. If there's anything tenser than a Sidaris scenario, it's a Skyhawks budget, which hangs by a shoestring. Authoritative computer display is a must in an action film, and since it needn't cost much, even a production as thrifty as this one can afford to put a good show onto the monitor. It's the explosions, the shootouts, the boat and motorcycle chases that take some inventiveness.
The Sidarises won't say what one of their films costs, but Mr. Sidaris allows that it's in the neighborhood of $1 million, a pittance as action movies go. Several days before, "Return to Savage Beach" blew up a speedboat out on Cross Lake and staged a major gun battle in a city park. A Bruce Willis movie pays a lot for scenes like these, partly because they require, as a safety precaution, the presence of police officers and firefighters. "In Los Angeles, a cop is $45 an hour from the time he leaves the house," Mr. Sidaris says. Shreveport, a town that loves to be in the movies, provides its services free of charge.
A Sidaris production is cleverly geared to such economies, one sign of an operation that knows exactly how to get along in the tough lower precincts of American filmmaking. These days, higher standards and increased competition demand a considerable amount of acumen from a B-movie maker. The Sidarises won't divulge income, but with cast and crew working at wages described as modest but fair, they perform at peak efficiency.
Skyhawks films go straight to video, and after that, they move on to cable, where they have loyal audiences and play for years. Distributors say that Sidaris movies work because, despite the small amounts spent on them, they look relatively sleek and glamorous, which is a must these days even for films that don't play in theaters.
Mr. Sidaris, a short, effusive man in his mid-60's, is a former producer and director for ABC Sports who won seven Emmys before he got tired of that field and started making movies in the 1980's.
"They're small pictures, but they have big vistas and views," he says. Some critics credit the look to clever cinematography, Mr. Sidaris's editing skills and scenes that seem to jump around the world -- even if the filming never leaves Shreveport.
Mr. Sidaris owns homes in Beverly Hills and Hawaii (fruits of his sports producing and not his filmmaking, he says), but he was reared here and knows everybody. Situated in the northwest corner of the state, about 185 miles east of Dallas, Shreveport prides itself on being a regional center of movie and television-commercial making. In addition to providing city services as a gesture of good will, Shreveport and environs offer a variety of looks and feels. Swamps, for instance.
"A lot of people think they have better swamps down in the bayous, but we have some of the best ones right here," says Betty Jo Lebrun, executive director of the city's film commission.
Being close to Texas, the countryside also has a flat western look. In the middle of that is a city skyline. Outside town, Cross Lake is perfect for careening Jet Skis and sumptuous-looking yachting scenes. The Louisiana Downs race track has suites and backdrops good for trysts and chicanery, and along the Red River, which winds through the city, casinos with names like Harrah's lend that Las Vegas touch.
Fees, if any, are minimal. At the Pelican Inn, a sprawling motel hard by the airport, the Sidarises swung a deal to lodge cast and crew, about 15 in all, for $700 a day. That's total, including dinners for everybody. After Sofia's computer scene (shot rent-free in the offices of an oil exploration company), everybody repairs to the noisy, smoky Pelican dining room. "I don't like to give them a per diem," says Mr. Sidaris. "If I gave them per diem, they'd spread out all over town. I want them to be like family."
Around the room, actors and technicians sprawl, chatter and act down-home, or as down-home as its gets with two former Penthouse Pets and two ex-Playboy centerfolds in the cast and an assortment of very L.A. film people. Mr. Sidaris eats fried chicken and table-hops. A voluble and supportive dictator who may be grumbled about occasionally, he generally commands affection and respect from an industrious group of actors and crew who appreciate the fact that they have work. No one complains publicly about the Pelican. "You wouldn't get Sharon Stone here, but that's not what this is about," Mr. Sidaris says.
Skyhawks movies might be categorized as an extremely low-cost cross between James Bond and "Baywatch": thighs, spies, bikinis and ballistics, as one person on the set says. That's true, but the Sidaris approach is, if pure macho, quite clean and scrubbed. Certainly there is violence, but people who get shot or blown up often miraculously recover. As for sex, scenes are shot once topless, for the R-rated video version, and again with tops in place for the movie that will be shown on television. Either way, the effect is more gymnastic than erotic. "We have no heavy profanity because I don't like that," Mr. Sidaris says.
Parts of "Return to Savage Beach" were shot in Dallas, Malibu, Beverly Hills and Hawaii, and the plot is a pastiche of every cliche character, situation, gimmick and gadget from every spy movie ever made. Simply put, the gorgeous operatives of Lethal, three women and two men with names like Cobra, Tiger and Doc, are locked in combat with Martinez (portrayed by Rodrigo Obregon, a swarthy Colombian with classically villainous looks) and ninja-terrorist types in pursuit of a horde of gold stolen from the Philippines by Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos.
Dialogue proceeds apace. "They've managed to smuggle guns, rockets, high-tech detonators and plastique explosives from China and the Pacific Rim up through Mexico to the heartland of our country," exclaims Doc, a hunky Lethal agent (Paul Logan, a martial-arts expert). "I'll hit the computer satellite fax and fill everyone in," says Tiger (Shae Marks, May 1994 Playboy centerfold), Lethal's technology wizard.
Mr. Sidaris writes the scripts, sometimes between tennis games at his large Beverly Hills house. He admits the scenarios are silly. "The idea is to have fun," he says. As with everything else about a Sidaris movie, scripts don't waste time. One instruction for a love scene reads, "Cobra and Doc lovage here, details TBA."
In most movies, one page of script translates to a minute of film. For a movie that will run about 90 minutes, Mr. Sidaris has written a script of only 49 pages, so there is a lot of room for on-the-set rewrites and those things a Sidaris film does best, which is pose good-looking actors against glamorous-looking backdrops. The next day begins with some shots of beautiful people at the Shreveport Yacht Club on the lake.
FORMERLY IN CHARGE OF ABC's "Wide World of Sports" and major events like the 1968 Olympics in Mexico City, Mr. Sidaris is used to keeping tabs on up to 75 screens at once. Unlike many directors, he never uses a video tap (a scope that views a scene as it appears on screen) but lets his eyes prowl as they did in the old days in a control room.
"The guy has the most incredible instinct for what works," says Mr. Wexler, the cinematographer. An angle or juxtaposition is chosen instantly. Instructions are terse but always supportive. If a line is missed, the camera keeps rolling while it is tried again. Sidaris actors may not be Wynona Ryder or Daniel Day-Lewis, but they work hard, and he tries not to embarrass them.
The Sidaris production rolls around Shreveport in a rented truck, two vans and whatever civilian vehicles happen to be handy. A leased motor home transports the cast. Always there is the pressure of time and money. Every shot turns out great, even if it doesn't. "That was absolutely wonderful, sweetheart," Mr. Sidaris says. "That's a wrappage. We're done here, right, Howard?"
A Sidaris movie typically uses 50,000 feet of film. Many directors shoot that much just for tests. At the yacht club, Mr. Sidaris wonders if they are running short and should they send to Los Angeles for more? Mr. Wexler says they'll make it.
On the sidelines the actors apply sun block and sit in camp chairs bearing their names written on strips of masking tape. One production assistant, a recent graduate of Centenary College in Shreveport, is headed for the Yale School of Drama in the fall. Asked if she expects to see anything like this in New Haven, she says she guesses not.
One of her professors at Centenary, Jeff Hendricks, is serving as assistant director of "Return to Savage Beach." He describes a Sidaris movie as a strain of post-modernism, all parody and excess. "It gets at the absurdity of materialism," Mr. Hendricks says, "or that's how the culture critic might look at it." Other folks, he says, actually take the stuff literally.
That afternoon, two Lethal agents (Mr. Logan and Cristian Letelier, a singer and a dancer as well as an actor) get jumped by three ninjas in a shady backyard in the wooded Shreveport suburbs. The only safety official on hand today is Marshall Peacock, whose card identifies him as a certified instructor of the National Rifle Association, which, he says, regularly dispatches firearms experts to the scenes of action movies.
Mr. Peacock is the keeper of the guns, about a half-dozen of them, which he doles out to actors as needed. There's the Uzi, a couple of large automatics and two more small handguns suitable for a woman's boot, bag or bosom. Most impressive is the .44-caliber, a huge four-pound revolver made famous by Clint Eastwood in "Dirty Harry."
If his belt holds up, Mr. Logan will pack that one in the forthcoming battle of the backyard. The ninjas, two young men recruited from Tracy's Karate Den in Shreveport, work out gracefully with Marcus Young, a mild-mannered fight coordinator brought in from Los Angeles. It seems that every town in America has martial-arts studios teeming with young men who could kick the stuffing out of anybody on a movie set. The Jackie Chan phenomenon did it, Mr. Young says. Everybody's a karate star. Best of all, they're free.
These ninjas, affable young men in black-hooded karate get-ups, say movie fighting is a lot slower than what they normally do. Nevertheless they wear padded chest protectors against Mr. Logan, a swift and accomplished opponent. Throughout the afternoon the brawl goes splendidly, with bodies flying and hitting the lawn with satisfying womps.
A director of countless football games and boxing matches on television, Mr. Sidaris gets the most from a fight scene. Before the action begins, he fiddles with 17 pairs of Ray Ban sunglasses, donated by the company. With him is Julie Strain, a Penthouse Pet of the Year, who plays Commander Willow Black, the chief Lethal agent. A fixture in Sadaris films, Ms. Strain stands 6 feet 1 (6 feet 8 in stiletto heels), and today she is wearing a little leather outfit that makes her look like Xena, the warrior princess, only with a lot less on underneath.
Leather is definitely Ms. Strain's material -- "You smell like a new car," a lover tells her in the movie -- but on the set she is regarded as a sort of den mother who cheerfully looks out for the other women, even sharing her own $20,000 wardrobe she has brought from Los Angeles (forget that kind of expenditure on this production).
Sidaris women have been described as "top-heavy." As Ms. Strain describes it, the typical Sidaris audition consists of a visit with Andy and Arlene at their home in Beverly Hills. Candidates are asked to take their clothes off and are inspected for nicks and bruises. Then they run a lap or two around the tennis court. "They want to see what jiggles," Ms. Strain says.
Each Sidaris movie needs several love scenes. "It's the foreign market; distributors won't touch it otherwise," Ms. Strain explains. "If the girls had their choice, they wouldn't do it, but it's part of the package."
On the movie's next to last day in Shreveport, a sex scene is shot in a strip club called, oddly enough, the Centerfold. On tap is Julie Smith, or Little Julie, a lithe, athletic former Penthouse Pet, who dons a naughty, abbreviated policewoman's outfit, then slithers and climbs all over Mr. Logan. But the look is more dance than lust. Ms. Smith classifies Sidaris films as innocent, tongue-in-cheek fantasies. She says she doesn't feel exploited. "It doesn't pay the rent and there are no great scripts, but it's work I can believe in," she says.
Outside the club, Mr. Wexler sets up the camera for an exterior shot. In the film, the Centerfold is supposed to be an upscale establishment in Beverly Hills. In Shreveport, the actuality falls short of that. Mr. Sidaris hustles about with a hose watering the bushes and the black paving by the front door. Mr. Wexler inserts a purple filter and suddenly through the lens the watered-down entrance takes on a lustrous, tonier appearance.
Shreveport is also the home of Barksdale Air Force Base, which houses many of the country's B-52 bombers. The Centerfold is close to the runway and overhead the huge aircraft, flaps spread and belching long trails of black smoke from roaring engines, are landing one after the other. Mr. Sidaris has a sudden brainstorm. "Got enough film, Howard?" he asks. Mr. Wexler does and swings the camera to film the next B-52 on its approach.
Maybe a terrorist takeover of one of those things in the next film. And why not?

PUB-DATE: August 3, 1997

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2640 words

HEADLINE: Uneasy Freedom for the Once Fettered

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: KARLOVY VARY, Czech Republic

 BODY:
WHILE MOSCOW WAS RULING Eastern Europe, the region's movie makers knew where they stood. If they made conformist films, they were assured of Government financing. If they stepped out of line, their films would be banned. Yet, as soon as political controls were relaxed in Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary at different moments of the 1960's and 1970's, directors of the stature of Milos Forman and Roman Polanski promptly appeared. Surely, then, with the collapse of Communism, a new New Wave of Eastern European movies would not tarry.
So, where is it? 
 The last eight years have changed the region beyond recognition. Ancient lands have rediscovered their identities; new countries have been created. Most have freely elected governments, and many have come to terms with the good and the greed of market economies. Last month, the Czech Republic, Poland and Hungary were even invited to enter NATO. Yet, puzzlingly, in cinema, that most exportable of art forms, expectations have so far been disappointed. Could it be that democracy is a lesser muse than dictatorship?
Certainly, freedom's unannounced arrival stunned the region's filmmakers. They were no longer muzzled but, as Government subsidies were slashed or canceled, they struggled to find money for even low-budget productions. New television stations, cable channels and booming video sales began stealing traditional moviegoing audiences, forcing hundreds of dilapidated Government-owned movie theaters to close. Surviving theaters -- plus a handful of new cineplexes -- were soon showing Hollywood movies almost exclusively.
Then there was the predicament faced by directors who for so long had been silenced or had been forced to convey their screen message through obscure codes and symbols in a kind of unspoken conspiracy with audiences.
"When you're not allowed to talk, you know what you want to say," explained Mr. Forman, the Czech director who made his name with such films as "Loves of a Blonde" and "The Firemen's Ball" during the Prague "spring" of the mid-1960's and who opted for exile in the United States after the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. "Censorship identifies what's worth talking about. But when you're free, you have to decide what's important. And that's more difficult."
There were other unpleasant surprises. Under Communism, American and European audiences eagerly embraced Soviet bloc movies that "escaped" to the West -- those by, say, Mr. Forman, Jiri Menzel ("Closely Watched Trains") and Jan Nemec ("The Report on the Party and the Guests") from Czechoslovakia, or Mr. Polanski ("Knife in the Water") and Andrzej Wajda ("Ashes and Diamonds") from Poland, or Istvan Szabo ("Mephisto") from Hungary. Then, almost overnight, Eastern European films found themselves struggling no less than other foreign-language productions to find distributors in the United States and Western Europe. If once the magical aura of political dissidence had sufficed, now they had to measure up as entertainment.
Still, if at times they have come close to despair since 1989, filmmakers in Eastern Europe have not given up, above all in the Czech Republic, Poland and Hungary, countries with traditions worth reviving. Directors love to list the problems they face, yet films -- probably more than 100 a year -- continue to be made in the former Soviet bloc. Some Government financing is available, but for the first time, real producers exist. In the past, governments determined movie budgets; now independent producers must put together complex packages involving domestic and Western European investors, the Council of Europe's Eurimages Fund and, above all, newly affluent television companies.
The great majority of the movies made in the region since 1990 have been eminently forgettable: cheap pastiches of American action films, and soft-porn movies galore. "The number of films generating little public interest and at the same time lacking redeeming artistic qualities is on the increase," the Czech Ministry of Culture noted chastisingly in a report on the Czech industry in March.
Yet there are encouraging signs. Across the region, serious directors have begun tackling the great untouchable subjects of the last half-century, from the Nazi occupation and the Holocaust to the tedium and oppression of the Communist years. Some, among them Krzysztof Kieslowski, the Polish director who gained international acclaim for "Blue," "White" and "Red" before dying last year, have also looked at the new moral questions posed by the onslaught of primitive capitalism.
This very seriousness also poses a problem. Many moviegoers in Eastern Europe prefer the escapism of Hollywood (and even locally made) action movies to the discomfort of confronting an unpleasant past and a confusing present. In any event, the blockbusters are what is on offer because theater owners feel more secure showing American movies, which now account for more than 90 percent of the box-office take in the region. Further, the dramatic drop in the number of available screens (from 3,081 in Bulgaria in 1989 to just 209 in 1996, for instance) insures that thoughtful movies from Eastern Europe can be seen by few people, even in their countries of origin.
FAIRLY TYPICAL IS "Bolshe Vita," a film by the Hungarian newcomer Ibolya Fekete about three Russian men and two Western women who meet in Budapest as Communism crumbles. It was well received in several festivals but was seen by just 4,700 people over a 10-week period when it was released in Hungary last year. In contrast, Istvan Bujtor's "Three Guardsmen in Africa," a locally made comedy with no political content, drew 207,000 moviegoers, but even so it ranked only eighth, behind American films like "Independence Day" and "Twister," among the hits of 1996.
Unsurprisingly, Eastern European films that have won prizes in festivals struggle to find buyers in Western Europe and the United States. Emir Kusturica's "Underground," a surrealistic allegory about postwar Yugoslavia, which won the Palme d'Or in Cannes in 1995, was ignored by American distributors. Even acclaimed films that make the art-house circuit in the United States -- among them "Before the Rain," by Milcho Manchevski of Macedonia; "Burnt by the Sun," by Nikita Mikhalkov of Russia, and "A Chef in Love," by Nana Djordjadze of Georgia -- can expect to earn little. No less than, say, French movies, they run up against the infamous American resistance to subtitles.
So far, only one post-cold-war movie from Eastern Europe -- "Kolya" by Jan Sverak of the Czech Republic -- has been a big success. Still showing in the United States six months after its release, this poignant story of an abandoned Russian boy and a womanizing Czech bachelor won the Academy Award for best foreign-language film this year and has so far earned almost $13 million worldwide. Made for $1.3 million, it has become a beacon of hope for other filmmakers, but it shines as an exception.
The Karlovy Vary International Film Festival, which took place three weeks ago, hopes to change this. Throughout the Communist era, this elegant spa town formerly known as Carlsbad, in the western Czech Republic, was host for a biennial festival of Government-approved films from the Soviet bloc. It also carefully selected movies from the West "to show how bad it was over there and how good it was here," recalled Rudolf Biermann, the festival's general manager. Now, however, the festival has been revamped to be held annually and sees its role as a display window -- and above all a marketplace -- for the best movies from Eastern Europe.
"It's very important to give space to this cinema," said Eva Zaoralova, the festival's director. "In the past, the Cannes and Berlin festivals would look for films from Russia, Hungary or Poland, but now they say there is nothing interesting being done there, that there's a crisis of esthetics. I don't think this is true. But since these festivals are snubbing Eastern Europe, we can profit from this and make our own discoveries."
This year's festival included 7 films from Eastern Europe among the 18 in the official competition. None were masterpieces, but all were worth watching. Thirty-five other films from the region were shown out of competition, along with nine films made by Czech television. A two-day seminar on movie distribution brought together experts from Poland, Slovenia, Hungary, Russia, Slovakia, the Czech Republic and the United States. And as a measure of the Czech Government's interest, the festival was opened by Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus and closed by President Vaclav Havel. Actual American distributors, though, were noteworthy for their absence.
Still, the Czechs, at least, have some reason for optimism -- and not only because of "Kolya," which was a huge box-office hit at home before it began collecting prizes abroad. When the Velvet Revolution and the end of Communism came, movie production slumped from 35 in 1989 to just 6 in 1990; now 20 to 22 new movies are being made annually. The legendary Barrandov Studios have been privatized. And while the company is currently in disarray after the ouster of its director, Vaclav Marhoul, in a power struggle with the majority shareholder, the studios have the space and equipment to support growth of the local movie industry.
Some veteran directors, like Mr. Menzel, Vera Chytilova and Juraj Jakubisco, are still making films, but they have not recaptured the magic of their pre-1968 work.
"I was the only one who was able to keep working," explained Mr. Forman, whose American-made movies have included "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," "Hair," "Amadeus" and, most recently, "The People vs. Larry Flynt." "The others were banned for two to five years after 1968. That kind of unwilling interruption is like a knife in your back. You never recover. That was, more or less, the fate of my generation."
TODAY, MORE INTEREST has been stirred by several young directors in the Czech Republic and Slovakia. Mr. Sverak, 32, who had already been noticed with "The Elementary School" before "Kolya" made him a star, is preparing a movie in English about Czech pilots who fought alongside the Allies in World War II and were later sent to Communist labor camps as collaborators.
Vladimir Michalek, 39, is currently shooting "It's Necessary to Kill Sekal," also set in World War II. In contrast, his last film, "Forgotten Light," which won praise at last month's festival here, is set in Communist Czechoslovakia and parallels a young Roman Catholic priest's effort to save his church from being closed with his growing love for a dying parishioner.
Others are making more intimate films. "Blue Heaven," a first film by Eva Borusovicova, 27, who is still a student in the Slovak film school in Bratislava, portrays the conflicting dreams and stormy cohabitation of a young woman, her mother and her grandmother.
In Poland, too, the movie industry is stirring. After a sharp slump in 1992 and 1993, audiences are beginning to return to theaters, while new productions are now averaging 40 a year, thanks to continuing Government subsidies and major investment by Polish television. Older directors like Mr. Wajda are still at work, although the most important Polish director of the early 1990's was undoubtedly Kieslowski who, after a 15-year career, was finally hailed as a maestro through "The Double Life of Veronique" and the "Three Colors" trilogy. His death in March 1996, at the age of 54, was a blow to all European cinema.
New names, though, are arriving with strong stories. In "Temptation," Barbara Sass has turned the clock back to Stalinist Poland, where a young nun charged with a political crime is released from prison on condition that she return to her convent to spy on a dissident priest. With "Pigs," Wladyslaw Pasikowski borrows American police-thriller techniques to tell a gripping story about two former political policemen who are forced to answer for their activities after the demise of the Communist regime. Dorota Kedzierzawska has followed her debut film, "Devils, Devils," with "Crows," a psychological drama about the kidnapping of a 3-year-old child by a lonely prepubescent girl.
In Hungary there is also official interest in rebuilding the movie industry. And with 15 to 20 new films per year, audiences for Hungarian films, principally comedies, are slowly growing. But many directors continue to bemoan the need to go cap-in-hand in search of financing. "In the old regime, the problem was ideological censorship," said Ildiko Szabo, who has made "Child Murders" and "Bitches" since 1990. "Now it's the censorship of money."
Still, at least in festivals, several Hungarian directors have been noticed. Janos Szasz's version of Georg Buchner's play "Woyzeck" was praised by Variety as "involving, moving, intelligent." His next film, "The Witman Boys," was a dark tale of matricide. Peter Gothar, already spotted in the West in 1981 for "Time Stands Still," continues to make gripping movies, like "Vaska Easoff," which tells of an urban thief and a rural thief who join forces to steal czarist gold from Soviet bank vaults.
The Karlovy Vary festival also demonstrated that unusual films could come even from countries with rudimentary movie industries. "Late Full Moon" by the Bulgarian director Eduard Zachariev, who died last year at the age of 59, portrays the dark side of "freedom" through an elderly man who, disgusted by the manic materialism of his son's family, finds contentment living with Gypsies on a garbage dump. In "The Wolf-Tooth Necklace," a much-admired film by Algimantas Pulpa of Lithuania, 46, a painter-writer recalls his upbringing by his mother and his grandparents after his father's deportation to Siberia.
Even Russia, where the movie industry seems close to collapse, occasionally produces noteworthy films. At the festival, Russia was represented by Aleksei Balabanov's "Brother," a fast-paced story about the country's chaotic transition from Communism in which a former conscript joins his hired-gun brother in St. Petersburg and is drawn into a shadowy world. It is a measure of the distribution crisis in Russia that "Brother" cannot find a domestic distributor and will go straight to video.
So, at least for older filmmakers, nostalgia for a simpler past with handout budgets and assured theater releases is perhaps understandable. By contrast, many younger Eastern European directors seem unperturbed by the current uncertainty, even by the invasion of American movies. And it is this generation -- "free of the eccentricities and idiosyncrasies of the past," as Mr. Forman put it -- that will determine whether Eastern Europe can again become a cradle of original movies. Yet, without the unifying straitjacket of Communism, even the term "Eastern European cinema" may soon become a misnomer. Under the new rules of the game, only the ability to combine talent and business acumen will count.
"I have no wish to be close to Eastern Europe because we spent so many years together without positive results," said Mr. Sverak, the director of "Kolya." "To be frank, when I notice a Latvian film in the program, I have no desire to see it. Or a Hungarian or a Bulgarian or a Romanian film or whatever. It's better to talk to those you can learn from. What the United States can teach us is marketing."
He should know because he has seen it happen.
" 'Kolya' was picked up by Miramax at last year's Cannes festival," he said. "Within a day, we had sold the film to 20 other territories. The film's first international release was in the United States in January this year, so it was Miramax's marketing that hit the world. We've now sold it to over 40 countries. It's the marketing power of the United States that counts."

HEADLINE: Redevelopment Enriching Baltimore's Inner Harbor

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHAROFF 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
THE redevelopment of this city's waterfront into a retail and entertainment district -- one of the big downtown success stories over the last 20 years -- is continuing with several new mixed-use projects that promise to add a new dimension to what is already a thriving tourist destination.
The projects include two renovations of historic, but long empty, properties and a third that involves both renovation and substantial new construction. 
 The project with the highest profile -- if only because of its location in the heart of what's called the Inner Harbor, the hub of the redevelopment effort, is the renovation of the Power Plant complex, three massive brick buildings that have dominated the waterfront since 1895. The buildings originally housed coal-fired electrical generating equipment for the city trolley system.
In the late 1980's they were taken over by Six Flags Theme Parks for an entertainment center that lasted less than a year. Now, the Cordish Company, a national developer based here that specializes in downtown "festival marketplace" projects such as Bayou Place in Houston and Charleston Place in Charleston, S.C., has signed a 99-year lease with the city for the complex. It expects to spend about $20 million to convert it into an office and entertainment center.
"It will be a major new anchor for the Inner Harbor," said Joseph Weinberg, vice president of Cordish.
The three buildings, which range in height from 94 to 120 feet, have a total of 150,000 square feet of space. Cordish's plan calls for three levels, or about 115,000 square feet, of retail with the rest devoted to offices. Plans for the project have been drawn up by Design Collective, an architectural firm based here.
"The challenge is making the building as inviting and accessible as possible both for the public and for tenants," said Richard Burns, a principal with Design Collective.
Mr. Burns said his plans called for, among other things, replacing an exterior wall of the project with glass to show off the four 200-foot-tall smokestacks that rise through the interior of the middle building. "We want to open the building up and show what's amazing about it -- the incredible steel and bolts and trusses," he said. "It has a wonderful 1890's industrial feel to it. They don't build buildings like this anymore.'
The stacks -- or at least the plan for the stacks -- have already caused a lot of talk in town. Early in July, the first tenant -- the Hard Rock Cafe --- moved in and immediately hung a 65-foot neon guitar on one of the stacks. Mr. Burns said that the stacks would also be outfitted with laser lights and might be made to smoke again, but only for decorative purposes. "The guitar has been very controversial," said Laurie Feinberg, a planner in the city's Planning Department. "People are afraid they're going too far with it, making the whole thing too loud and tacky."
But it seems to be working. "We always look for a 'wow' factor in terms of locations and the Power Plant has that," said James Berk, chief executive of Hard Rock Cafe chain. He added that the restaurant had performed considerably above expectations since it opened and that "if it keeps up at this rate, it will equal New York in terms of volume."
The project's second anchor, a 30,000-square-foot Barnes & Noble book store, will open this fall. The rest of the project will be finished by next summer.
Both Hard Rock and Barnes & Noble represent the kind of major national force that has not been much in evidence along the reinvigorated waterfront. Indeed, when Barnes & Noble opens it will be the largest retailer in downtown Baltimore.
"For the first time in 10 years we're seeing a resurgence in downtown retail,"' said Neil Tucker, a broker with CB Commercial here.
RENTS, however, still lag behind the top suburban malls. According to Rene Daniel, president of the Daniel Group, a real estate consulting firm here, the best retail space along the harbor goes for about $20 to $24 a square foot, compared with $25 to $30 a square foot in the suburbs.
The other two projects are in Canton, a neighborhood at the eastern end of the seven-and-a-half mile public promenade that defines the downtown waterfront redevelopment district. The promenade, a brick walkway created in the late 1960's, extends along the harbor through four distinct neighborhoods -- Canton, Fell's Point, Inner Harbor and Federal Hill.
All of this land, largely industrial for most of Baltimore's history, is now being converted to residential and commercial uses.
The Canton projects are the renovation of the old American Can Company complex and the renovation and construction of Lighthouse Point, a new marina and boat storage complex that involves partially renovating an old licorice factory and adding several new buildings. Both are within a block of each other on Boston Street, which follows the shoreline.
The American Can project consists of five buildings erected over roughly 30 years beginning in 1895. The former American Can Company vacated the site in 1988 and it has been vacant and deteriorating ever since. Struever Bros. Eccles & Rouse, a local firm known for innovative renovation projects, took over the site a year ago and is beginning a $24 million overhaul.
When it is finished sometime after the first of the the year, there will be about 50,000 square feet of retail space on the first floor and 125,000 square feet of office space on the remaining three floors. "This will be the biggest office building in Canton," said William Struever, president of Struever Bros. The architecture firm handling the renovation is again Design Collective Inc.
Mr. Struever said that several anchor tenants were already in place for the project. Like the Power Plant, the main retail tenant is a book store, a branch of the local Bibelot chain. The main tenant over all, with 50,000 square feet, will be the Maryland Economic Development Corporation, a quasi-public group that plans to use the space as an incubator for fledgling high tech companies.
The final project is Lighthouse Point. In addition to a 490-slip marina and a "boatel" that will store up to 200 boats year-round, the site consists of a boat-repair facility, a pool and cabana club and 50,000 square feet of office space. Also on the drawing board is a 30-unit luxury town-house development.
The developer of the project is East Harbor Marine Center, a limited partnership of seven partners, several of whom are doctors and all of whom are active in boating. According to Dora Naor, one of the partners, the project will costing about $24 million and all but the town houses will be finished this fall.
"This will be the most comprehensive marina in Baltimore," she said, "and the only one that offers year round high and dry storage."
