HEADLINE: Roadside Cornucopia

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: LONG VALLEY

 BODY:
THE Ort family's farm stand sits on the side of a country road between Schooley's Mountain four miles away, where the first Ort bought a farm in 1866, and the old white farmhouse across the road, where the family moved around 1916.
It is a classic New Jersey farm stand, long and low, a 50-by-30-foot shed of weathered red barn siding and flaking white trim, largely open in front, just off a two-lane blacktop road. 
 The stand was built around 1975 on a potato patch where, in the late 1960's, the Orts had placed a farm wagon to display their produce, shaded by two large umbrellas. And long before that, they sold fruit and vegetables from picnic tables under the three maple trees in front of the farmhouse.
"My grandfather sold raspberries and strawberries and potatoes and stuff like that back in the 1930's," said the current patriarch, 70-year-old Harvey Ort Sr. "And then my daughters, when they were growing up, they always sold stuff on the front lawn under the maple trees. It was getting so dangerous with traffic we decided to put something on the other side of the road."
Ron Good, an agricultural marketing specialist for the State Department of Agriculture, estimates there are between 700 to 800 farm stands statewide in just about every county, ranging from a wagon or shed like the Orts' to the mega-stand -- barnlike metal buildings that function more like stores.
Some farm stands are even more elaborate, he said, mentioning DePiero's Country Farm, a huge modern structure across from Mercedes-Benz headquarters in Montvale, Bergen County, that has its own restaurant.
Mr. Good, who helps farmers market their produce more efficiently, says farm stands have proliferated over the last 30 years, especially in the last decade as an increasing number of farmers have taken to selling directly to a public that has become more health-conscious.
Mr. Ort and his wife, Edith, have 10 children, 19 grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren. Only two sons, Harvey Jr. and John, and a daughter, Janie Hoskin, are actively involved in running the farm.
But come autumn, when swarms of customers ride in hay wagons pulled by John Deere tractors to pick their own pumpkins and the children gather to pet the farm animals that are John's responsibility (including Sam, a gentle 2,000-pound black steer), the whole family turns out to sell and lend a hand.
"In the fall, I would say, on any given day, you could probably say you need 7 or 8 of the kids and probably 8 to 10 of the grandchildren." said Harvey Jr., 41, who manages the farm. "Some of the grandchildren tow wagons with pumpkins to the cars."
BUT right now is that lush time of year when people go to farm stands from as near as down the road and far away as New York City and Philadelphia, looking for the perfect tomato or ear of sweet corn, just as at Halloween they go to buy pumpkins and in December Christmas trees.
You see the tourists in greater numbers on weekends as they set out with the children in the back seat for a drive in the country. And you see the regulars on weekdays, the housewives coming for the morning's first fresh crop and the businessmen, truckers and commuters stopping in the evening on their way home for the most freshly picked produce.
And as they hand their money to the cashier, who may be the farmer's daughter or grandson or family friend, that tomato takes on a symbolism that is dearer than the tomato itself.
They are buying fresh, customers say; they are buying healthy, and they are getting the good feeling of knowing they are directly supporting a farm family rather than a supermarket chain. And there is something nostalgic in the process that touches America's pastoral myth and their own personal past.
"There is a nice feeling between the farmer and consumers because the farmer is not only providing them with the experience of eating that freshly picked tomato but also bringing back the memory of the freshness they first tasted as children, when they may have picked a tomato from their grandfather's farm or mother's garden," said Mr. Good, who grew up on a farm in Ohio. "Farm stands, with their fresh produce, can create all these pleasant images."
The farm stand, on Bartley Road near Route 24 about four miles from Chester, is open from 9 A.M. to 7 P.M. daily from Easter through Christmas, when it is shuttered for the winter. Janie Ort Hoskin, who manages it, arrives each day at 8 A.M. to set out the produce.
At 48, she is the third of Harvey Sr. and Edith's 10 children, and like her mother before her, she has been working at the stand for many years. Her daughter Sandy, 18, has been working with her since she was a child but has been spending less time since beginning her studies to be a nurse.
"Both my boys worked here," Mrs. Hoskin says. "Basically, all the nieces and nephews worked here one time or other."
A survey of New Jersey farmers released in 1994 by the Department of Agricultural Economics and Marketing at Cook College of Rutgers University revealed that most farmers who responded prefer selling their produce retail -- at farm stands or at the 48 farmers markets statewide -- rather than wholesale because the returns are higher and they can sell in limited quantities.
The Cook College survey also revealed that gross retail sales ranged from $10,000 to $5 million (for perhaps three or four large farms). The average was about $221,000. Mr. Good, the marketing specialist, said many farmers fell in the middle range.
Ramu Govindasamy, a marketing specialist at Cook College, estimates that farms that sell retail recive about 25 percent of their total gross sales from farm stands
Harvey Ort Jr. said his farm sold about 50 percent of its produce retail and estimated that 75 percent of those gross retail sales came from the farm stand. The remaining 25 percent are derived from seven farmers' markets within a 25-mile radius.
"We try to retail as much as we can," he says, noting that among the principal fresh market vegetables the Orts grow are tomatoes, sweet corn, peppers, cabbage, cucumbers, lettuce, eggplants, snap beans and asparagus. They also grow melons and strawberries.
The Orts raise 75 percent of what they sell. What they don't have, like peaches, Mrs. Hoskin orders from other farmers.
About 10 years ago, Harvey Jr. began raising flowers in greenhouses to tide the farm over in the spring, and two years ago he put in a half-acre of flowers that customers can cut themselves. The Orts also sell hay to horse farms in the area and grain to brokers and mills.
He estimated that 75 percent of the farm's gross sales came from edible products and 25 percent from the grain and hay. The Orts also have 19 cows, 35 sheep, 10 goats, 20 chickens and 4 pigs, some of which are sold to other farms or at market.
The stand also sells Amish craft work, from birdhouses to lawn furniture, that Harvey Ort Sr. buys on his regular trips to Lancaster, Pa.
Each morning before 7, Harvey Jr. is in the fields with two or three hired hands picking the corn and tomatoes he will sell retail at the stand and wholesale to seven other farmers with farm stands in the area.
The corn is stacked on two large bins on the far wall, which is covered with old framed photographs of Long Valley that Harvey Ort Sr., a local history buff, put there. Near the doorway to a small back room is a framed photo of his father, Jacob Wack Ort, standing in front of a 1930's car. It was Jacob who bought this property and the farmhouse across the road in 1916. Another photo shows Jacob's father, Harvey S. Ort, whose father, William Henry Ort, a Civil War veteran, bought the farm on Schooley's Mountain in 1866.
This was a dairy farm until 1974, but for Harvey Jr., dairy farming offered little financial reward, and he chose to concentrate on vegetables. At one point the Orts owned 166 acres, but after Jacob's death in 1972, Harvey Sr. sold much of the property to pay inheritance taxes. They still own about 75 acres but farm 500, much of it leased from other property holders. A total of 150 acres are used for vegetable growing, 200 for hay and 150 for grain.
On any given weekday, 200 to 300 people shop at the stand, and 300 to 400 on weekends, Mr. Ort said.
On Monday, many were regular customers, some of whom had been buying produce here for as long as 15 years, because, they all said, it was fresh.
"We tried all the farms and we ended up coming here," said Sefton Vergano, 22, of Bedminster, of his family's loyalty to the Ort farm stand. "The corn was great, and they also had hayrides and on Halloween you picked your own pumpkins."
Many felt a loyalty to the Ort family either because they had come to know them personally or appreciated the difficulty of making a living farming.
"We got to know everybody," said Ron Blankley, a financial services manager who lives on Schooley's Mountain. "We know the Orts; we know the people who work here; we know the folks who come and shop."
"And," said his wife, Sheryl, "we know how hard they work to keep this this kind of vocation going to produce this kind of food."
Standing in the farm stand that evening, Harvey Jr., the fifth generation in his family to farm the land, recalled how a man used to drive up to the stand in a Rolls-Royce several times a summer to buy corn for his son in Alaska.
"He was telling me it cost him, like, 30 bucks to have a dozen ears airmailed to Alaska," Mr. Ort said, "but that was the only way his son could get it fresh."
Another customer "took some to Colorado for a wedding," he said. "She actually brought 200 ears."
A S he spoke, a customer was buying 10 pounds of tomatoes that she said her father-in-law planned to take the next day to relatives in Arizona.
And Janie Hoskin recalled that several years ago their corn was the subject of a dispute between a local couple and friends "out West."
"I think it was Iowa," she said. "They said their corn was better than our corn, and this couple, as soon as we picked it, they put it on ice and sent it out to them to do a taste test. And ours was better."
The subject turned to the future of the stand, and Harvey Jr. said he had been thinking about building a bigger one a quarter-mile down Route 24, where there is more traffic, perhaps in two or three years, but it would not be one of the megastands that in his mind are too much like stores.
"If I built something," he said, "it would have to have a real farm look, not a commercial-type look."
The Orts drifted away, leaving Jody Miktus, 18, whose mother went to school with Mrs. Hoskin, to tend the stand. At closing time, Ms. Miktus, who will soon be entering the University of Scranton, put some of the perishables in coolers and then stretched a rope across the front of the open shed. The remaining tomatoes and melons could be clearly seen from the road, but this did not appear to be a problem.
The rope, she said cheerfully, is only there to show that the stand is closed. No one takes anything, she said, and if they do, they usually leave money for it.
"They'll come and get six ears," Ms. Miktus said. "And in the morning you'll find the money on the counter."
Outside, John Ort, 37, had finished feeding his animals and was heading to the farmhouse.
He seemed surprised that anyone would be surprised the stand was left open. Well, yeah, he acknowledged, someone once tampered with the register. "I think that was in the springtime," he said.
Asked why they don't put up a more secure barrier, he smiled and said, "Trustworthy, I guess."

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Hot Enough for Ya?

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
THE bank sign near Paramus Park Mall was blinking "34," and I wondered if maybe that was the annual credit-card interest rate. But of course it was just the temperature, in Celsius, a scale used chiefly by people who work in laboratories.
It was hot, was all I knew. How hot was it? Actually, bank signs that require elaborate mathematical conversions aside, that's becoming a tough question to get a straight answer to these days. 
 "Whoa, it's 107 degrees out there," huffed a delivery man hauling a big tray of packaged doughnuts and cakes into a deli in Montclair later that same afternoon. In fact, it was not anything like 107 in Montclair. According to the paper, it was 107 in Phoenix. According to a hopelessly old-fashioned thermometer from Home Depot, in Montclair it was only 92.
Talking about the weather used to be a lot simpler in the days when we all agreed on the practical value of the traditional thermometer, which displays a precise number on a rational scientific scale. But now, along with baffling new area codes and nine-digit ZIP codes, progress has presented us with the heat index, evil offspring of the pestilential winter wind chill factor, to further muddy the waters of our common rhetoric.
Inflated relentlessly by television weather-peddlers, dutifully parroted by the poor devils assigned to write summer dog-days weather features in newspapers, bandied about everywhere the weather is discussed, the heat index is a pop meteorological product so freshly minted that it wasn't even mentioned in this newspaper until two summers ago -- and then with quotation marks around it, to indicate its quaintness.
Now, it's everywhere, to the point where it's increasingly difficult to find out what the thermometer actually reads.
Television weather forecasts "really latched onto the heat index in the past few years," said Dave Robinson, the New Jersey state climatologist, based at Rutgers University. "Now, it's all you hear on a hot day, when what you really want to know is the actual air temperature, which is at least useful. It drives me nuts when they go on about the heat index and forget to give you the temperature."
The wind chill factor, annoying as it may be to anyone simply interested in how cold it is outside, at least provides an objective measure of long it will take water to turn to ice at 32 degrees Fahrenheit (or zero Celsius) at a given wind speed.
The heat index, which was boringly known as the humiture before the television marketing geniuses pounced on it as a great new way to hype the weather, is a measure of apparent heat, a wholly subjective concept derived from a formula that takes temperature and relative humidity into account. As a chronic layman who once was actually dumb enough to write that there is nothing more boring than someone else's weather, I have carefully examined this formula. As far as I can tell, it involves subtracting 21 from the air's vapor pressure in millibars while adding the ambient air temperature and, I think, tossing in a wren's egg acquired at midnight under a new moon while performing Gregorian chant. The result is a purportedly precise number that quantifies your feelings about how hot it is outside -- and entices people to watch the television news well past the sixth antacid commercial.
"The heat index really doesn't have any scientific value," Mr. Robinson said. "It doesn't even factor in the wind." However, he does profess to find some benefit from its inexorable march into the collective cultural consciousness. "When I take off my scientific hat and look strictly at the issue of public safety, I'd argue that giving the heat index does have value in alerting people to the potential dangers" of sunstroke, he said.
In other words, broadcasting alarms of a heat index of, say, 130 and above may well save lives among those who are inclined to put on extra layers of clothing and chop firewood in mid-afternoon in an August heat wave.
Mr. Robinson said relative humidity, the weak ingredient in the heat index formula, varied too wildly all day to be useful in gauging heat discomfort. Instead, forecasts should concentrate on two fundamental numbers: the temperature and the dew point, which is the point at which dew forms in a given air mass. "Those two numbers are what you really need" to predict how uncomfortable a hot day is likely to be, he said. "But evidently, the public isn't ready to handle two variables.
"People apparently want to hear that it's 105 today," Mr. Robinson said, "even when it's really just 93."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
South Windsor Getting a Piece of the Pie It Rejected

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
WHEN developers proposed a regional shopping mall for the Town of South Windsor 10 years ago, some local residents opposed the project. So it went to the next town.
The 1.18-million-square-foot Buckland Hills Mall became wildly successful: It and surrounding development now total some 6 million square feet of commercial space in neighboring Manchester. And more than 1,600 housing units are completed or planned in the area. 
 "People in the area felt that they didn't want a Buckland mall, so Manchester got the development, they got the revenues and we got the traffic," said Matthew B. Galligan, South Windsor's town manager.
But over the years the development has crept closer to South Windsor. Now I-84 Associates, which developed much of the Buckland area, has proposed Northern Hills, which would include a 14- to 16-screen movie theater, a restaurant and 30,000 square feet of retail space, the first major outgrowth into South Windsor.
"Although we still have land in Manchester, to continue the project in a large scale it seemed best to move into South Windsor," said Richard J. Ripps, a principal in the development company. Mr. Ripps said the Northern Hills project would leave 15 of its 32 acres undeveloped for now, adding that their future use had not been determined.
"It probably will be some sort of a mix -- perhaps another hotel, possibly a restaurant and maybe more retail or some spec office building," Mr. Ripps said. "I would think at least another 100,000 square feet of development of some sort would be possible. But we want to proceed at a pace where the marketplace, and the community, can comfortably digest what we develop. Things are working very well now, and we don't want to disrupt that."
In the decade since it first turned down the Buckland Hills Mall, South Windsor has adopted an ordinance to help developers pay for sewers and utilities through tax abatements, has zoned areas along Routes 5 and 84 for commercial and industrial use and it has improved the roads in those areas.
"The business climate in South Windsor has changed, there's no question about that," said Dexter S. Burnham, executive director of the South Windsor Chamber of Commerce. "Manchester is getting pretty full, so developers are going to start looking in this direction. And I think when they get here they're going to find an environment that has improved dramatically for business."
Robert E. Costa, president of Eagle Tissue, a tissue-products company at 70 Bidwell Road, said he chose to open his business in South Windsor last year because of the availability of space and the quality of life. For almost 20 years he worked in the Maspeth section of Queens in New York City.
"We had problems getting people to come to work there in the day, and we couldn't get them there at all at night because they were afraid of crime," he said. "You don't have that problem here. We're able to get a decent quality of employee here at a decent price."
Mark Pellegrini, director of planning and economic development for Manchester, said there was sufficient prospective development for both towns. "The retail created an identity for the area, an economic presence, and the area has now become a destination," Mr. Pellegrini. "We're seeing a lot more interest in entertainment businesses and restaurants. We've got some luxury apartments going up in the area, and there's an application to build a luxury hotel down there."
"It's not that commercial development bypassed South Windsor, it just hadn't gotten to them -- that's what's happening now," Mr. Pellegrini said.
Mr. Ripps noted that the Northern Hills project would require cooperation between the two towns, since it straddles the border. About 6 of the 38 acres are in Manchester.
South Windsor is slightly larger geographically than Manchester, 28.5 square miles versus 27.2 square miles, but has less than half Manchester's population of almost 53,000. Until the last several years, it has been largely an agricultural town, with extensive tobacco and dairy farms.
So when the Buckland Hills Mall went in just over the town line, there were some adjustments, particularly for traffic. The state constructed two exits off Interstate 84 to serve the shopping centers and built Interstate 291, which connects I-84 with Interstate 91.
Stephen F. Mitchell of F.A. Hesketh & Associates in Hartford, the traffic engineer for I-84 Associates, said local roads were now handling traffic well, adding that additional development would not create traffic problems.
The original mall generated about 35,000 vehicle trips a day, said Mr. Mitchell. Although the mall represented about one-fifth of the commercial space that is now in the region, the volume of traffic has just doubled, he added.
"What you see is that as development continues, particularly retail development, it's not a linear relationship," Mr. Mitchell said. "As you add more development, the number of vehicles entering the area tends to level off. People start to make more than one stop, visit more than one store. So you can continue to add development and it doesn't have as much of an impact as the first phases."
Local opposition to development has lessened over the years. Mr. Galligan said he attributed that in part to the fact that people in South Windsor work and shop just over the line, and in part to a recognition that commercial development would bring badly needed tax revenues. Moreover, South Windsor is changing as the suburban sprawl of Hartford pushes out.
"Ten years ago we were a town of 14,000 people, now we have 24,000 residents," Mr. Galligan said. "But only about 18 percent of our tax base is commercial property. We'd like to see it at 30 percent. We have an excellent school system, and if we want to maintain it we're going to need a stronger commercial tax base to support it."
Mr. Galligan said it was not just the Bucklands area where South Windsor was promoting growth. The town has zoned a 400-acre area along Route 5, about two miles away, for commercial and light industrial uses, and it has begun organizing a panel of five local business owners who would help start-up businesses negotiate leases, apply for Federal loans or maneuver through the regulatory process.
"Some people think it's all starting to happen overnight, but the town has spent the last three years making this happen, putting all the regulations in place and planning it all out," Mr. Galligan said.
MR. RIPPS said his company had obtained development permits for the Buckland Hills Mall, the Avalon Pavilions Luxury Apartments, a 932-unit rental complex, and some of the large stores in the region. He said the area was similar to Tyson's Corner in Fairfax County, Va., where mixed-use development created a place where people live, work and play. "What's happened in Bucklands, it's become so large and so prominent and so successful so quickly, it's managed to bring together that kind of critical mass," Mr. Ripps said. "There's a lot that's already happened there, and we think there's a lot more that's going to happen."
Mr. Galligan said in addition to the parcel where Northern Hills has proposed the first project, now in the final stages of the approval process, there were about 100 more acres on the east side of Buckland Hills. Across the road, he added, is a 232-acre parcel and some smaller plots.
"We still have a substantial amount of land along that corridor," Mr. Gilligan said. "We've already widened the road and put the water lines in and we're ready to go. South Windsor's at a point where it can really begin to capitalize on the development taking place in that area."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
A New Report Tells Just How Preservation Pays

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
HISTORIC PRESERVATION is not just good for the eyes and heart it is good for the pocketbook," said David Listokin, a professor at the Center for Urban Policy Research of Rutgers University in New Brunswick.
He was commenting on a recently released two-year study that he co-authored with Michael Lahur, another professor at the center. 
 The 350-page report details the economic benefits, both direct and indirect, in New Jersey and nationally from such historic preservation activities as restoring and rehabilitating historic structures, heritage tourism and the operations of historic sites and organizations.
State and national advocates say the report is the first to provide the hard numbers to substantiate what they say they knew all along -- that the dollars spent on historic preservation create jobs, promote tourism, increase property values and attract new investment.
"For too long, and largely the fault of preservationists, the arguments for historic preservation have been soft, and about its 'touchy, feely' impacts," said Dovanan D. Rypkema, a real estate and economic development consultant in Washington. "But what decision-makers want to know is how much will it cost and how much will it generate in revenue."
This study, he said, will help answer those questions and remove a weak spot in the growth of preservation.
"It is a new source of ammunition for preservationists trying to leverage more room at the bargaining table, especially at a time of budget crunching," added Janice Wilson Stridick, president of the board of Preservation New Jersey, a statewide nonprofit advocacy group.
The study showed that historic preservation activities generated $580 million annually in direct economic activity in the state. Using a multiplier effect, the report says that direct benefits on an annual basis translate into, among other things, 10,140 jobs, $263 million in payroll and business earnings and $293 million in local and state taxes.
As part of those benefits, the report also says that historic properties in New Jersey, valued at $6 billion, pay $120 million in annual property taxes and have a higher market value because of their designation as historic sites. New Jersey has about 1,100 properties individually listed on the State and National Registers of Historic Places and thousands more in 240 historic districts, according to state figures.
"There are real dollars to be made in historic preservation," said Professor Listokin, noting that its "economic pump-priming effect" was greater than some alternative investments. For example, the study reports, every $1 million spent on historic rehabilitation generates 38.3 jobs, $1.3 million in payroll and business earnings and $202,000 in state taxes, compared with 36 jobs, $1.2 million in income and $189,000 in taxes from new construction projects.
The study also points out that 9.1 million tourists visit New Jersey's historic sites each year and spend $432 million. "Heritage tourism is an area that has not been fully exploited in the state," said Professor Listokin.
The $70,000 study was financed by state and Federal grants, notably from the National Center for Preservation Technology and Training of the Federal Department of the Interior, which provided $40,000. The center is making the study available to other state historic preservation organizations and a summary of its highlights to targeted groups such as urban planners and developers, said Marc R. Gilberg, research coordinator at the center.
THE report was done for the New Jersey Historic Trust, a quasi-public agency within the state's Department of Environmental Protection that awards matching grants to projects involving historic buildings owned by government agencies or nonprofit groups.
Two projects in the state that received grants from the trust in recent years underscore the economic benefits of historic preservation.
One is the Essex Club in Newark, a former gathering place for this city's business leaders. It overlooks Military Park and is not far from the New Jersey Performing Arts Center.
The $1.25 million grant awarded by the trust was used to restore and convert the 1926 Georgian Revival structure into the headquarters of the New Jersey Historical Society. The work included creating a library, museum, office and classrooms in the building.
Using the Rutgers study's model, the trust said the economic multiplier effects per $1 million of the estimated $3.8 million total construction cost of the Essex Club generated an estimated 73.4 jobs, $2.6 million in annual income and $266,000 in annual state taxes.
"This building is part of the critical mass that is aiding the economic revitalization of downtown Newark," said Maureen Ogden, president of the Historical Society. Ms. Ogden, a former State Assemblywoman who now heads the Governor's Council on the Outdoors, added that the project "could not be totally duplicated in a new building."
In nearby Jersey City's Van Vorst historic district, the Barrow Mansion, built in 1834, is a rare survivor of the city's antebellum era. A $311,375 grant from the trust was used to to restore the facade of the Greek Revival structure, as well as interior spaces. It is now used as offices by 20 community and nonprofit organizations.
Using the Rutgers study's economic multiplier effects, each $1 million of the $2.1 million cost of the project would produce on average 40.5 jobs, $1.4 million in income and $147,000 in state taxes.
"The project, which is ongoing, has been credited with spurring other restoration efforts in the neighborhood and in attracting people to live there," said Peter L. Jensen, president of the board of the Barrow Mansion Development Corporation, the nonprofit group working to preserve the building and promote its use as a community service center.
The benefits are also evident in communities where historic preservation is linked with tourism. An example is Cape May, whose tourist industry thrives on the fact that it has more than 600 historic buildings, many of them Victorians for which the city is noted. Communities also look to historic preservation to help revive their downtowns.
The New Jersey Historic Trust is the only state agency to provide funds for "bricks and mortar" preservation projects. To be eligible for a grant a building must be owned by a government agency or a nonprofit group and be listed as a state or Federal landmark or be suitable for such a listing. The trust holds easements on land under the buildings that prohibit them from being demolished and insure public access for up to 20 years.
UNDER its grant program, capitalized by $60 million set aside under 1987, 1992 and 1995 bond issues, the trust has awarded nearly $41 million in matching grants to 152 projects. It is now reviewing its last round of grants that can be financed from the bond issues.
The agency has received 109 applications for more than three times the $11.5 million in grants it has left to spend, according to Harriet C. Hawkins, its executive director.
She noted that the trust, which has a $3 million revolving fund for low-interest loans, was authorized to spend $4.5 million in administrative costs.
Meanwhile, efforts are advancing to find other ways to finance preservation projects. Ms. Ogden, chairwoman of the Governor's Council on the Outdoors, which advises the Governor on open-space and recreational issues, is recommending $15 million in financing for historic preservation.
The request, part of the $200 million package that she expects to present to the Whitman administration by year's end, also includes funds for the conservation of farmland and open space.
When the State Legislature convenes next month, it will consider a bill to provide tax credits to homeowners and businesses that rehabilitate historic properties in 100 municipalities that are classed as "distressed."
The bill would offer a gross income, or corporate, tax credit equal to 25 percent of the cost of rehabilitating a property. Among the "distressed" municipalities are Newark, Jersey City, Paterson, Camden and Trenton.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut;
Casinos' Ripple Effect Attracts Bets on Real Estate

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
A RECENT tour of commercial property in southeastern Connecticut -- an area once known mostly for making submarines -- drew 55 real estate brokers and investors from all over the state who were looking for hotel, restaurant and golf course sites, rather than industrial properties.
The interest has been engendered by the phenomenal growth of the Foxwoods Casino in Mashantucket, the opening of the Mohegan Sun Casino last October by the Mohegan Indian tribe across the Thames River in Montville and the planned opening, pending Federal approval, of the Eastern Pequot tribe's casino in the North Stonington area. 
 Foxwoods gets more than 50,000 visitors a day; Mohegan's figures were not available.
"It's going to hit a critical mass," said Harold Kurfehs, who went on the tour. He is a Danbury realtor and president of the Commercial Investment Division of the Connecticut Realtors Association.
"That's one of the reasons there's so much interest here today," he said. "Any of the hospitality businesses are going to want to be in this area -- hotels, restaurants, bed-and-breakfasts, attractions of all sorts, are all going to add to the mix."
John C. Markowicz, executive director of the South East Area Regional Economic Development Corporation, said a strategic planning report it commissioned as the cold war ended in 1989 and 1990 had forecast a 15 percent unemployment rate and a huge loss of population in the region as Electric Boat laid off submarine builders in Groton and the Naval Undersea Warfare Center closed its offices in New London.
"That's all happened, but unemployment is below 5 percent and the population has remained stable," Mr. Markowicz said. "The only thing that's changed is that employment at the casinos has absorbed that unemployment."
Three major parcels in the region that will soon become available are generating a large number of proposals -- the 788-acre Norwich State Hospital property that straddles the Norwich, Ledyard and Preston town lines; the 28-acre former Naval Undersea Warfare Center base, which has 730,000 square feet of office space, much of it built within the last five years. and the 37-acre Seaside Regional Center on Long Island Sound, formerly run by the state's Department of Mental Retardation.
Foxwoods, which opened in 1991, has never used the locks that were initially installed on its doors because people have never stopped coming. On the three-day Memorial Day weekend this year alone more than 210,000 gamblers came, and the casino grossed $4.5 million from gaming alone, not counting its revenues from the restaurants, shops and hotels. The complex, after a $350 million expansion now under way, will comprise 3 million square feet of commercial space, including 332,000 square feet of casino space and 1,200 hotel rooms.
The Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, which operates Foxwoods, has also started a mail-order pharmacy and opened the Pequot River Shipworks, where it has built the high-speed trimaran ferry Sassacus, which starting this fall will carry gamblers from Manhattan to the casino. It is now marketing the boats to other operators and has announced an $11.5 million contract to build the next one for an Argentine company.
While its plans to bring a Six Flags amusement park into the area have been put on hold because of local opposition, in briefings with town leaders from the area, officers of the tribe have said they plan to build, on land outside the reservation's boundaries, at least two new hotels, two golf courses, a resort complex to be called Pequot Island and a large parking garage.
It has also submitted plans to the Federal Railroad Administration for a $100 million magnetic-levitation train that would operate initially on the reservation, but eventually connect to Norwich to the north, Interstate 95 to the south and T.F. Green Airport outside of Providence, R.I. to the east. It is negotiating with Norwich to help build a ferry dock as an additional stop for its high-speed ferry.
The tribe purchased the Norwich Inn & Spa, which it has upgraded to luxury accommodations for the casino's high- profile entertainers as well as paying guests, and it has promised to make an $18 million investment in that city's Mercantile Exchange, a city block that was once a thriving commercial center but has fallen into disrepair.
T RIBAL officials did not return calls for comment, but they have consistently declined to talk about their development plans publicly. Only recently did they start advance briefings for elected officials in the towns that will be affected.
"What they have is what appears to be a very reasoned plan for growth," said William D. Moore, president of the Southeastern Connecticut Chamber of Commerce, referring to the Mashantuckets. "I think they recognize that sooner or later the bubble of casino gaming has got to pop, so the sooner they diversify the better they will be prepared for the future. By creating a resort with golf courses, the museum, all of that will help them ride through the next downturn that occurs, whether it's a national recession or just a downturn in gaming."
Much of the investments by or related to the casinos have been concentrated in the local urban areas of New London and Norwich. Small towns in the region, which have suffered the heavy traffic and construction noises of the entertainment complex, have yet to see much benefit, their officials say.
"When Foxwoods first opened, several developers came into town, and five hotel projects were approved, but to date none of them have broken ground," said North Stonington First Selectman Charles Elias. "We have seen a couple of doughnut stores and convenience shops, but that's been about it. And one of the new convenience stores has gone into bankruptcy."
"What we're seeing is more residential development," said Ledyard Mayor Wesley Johnson. "Subdivisions that have sat empty for a few years, the developers are now beginning to pave the roads and market the lots. Most of the houses being built now are in the $130,000 or $140,000 price range, which we think are targeted at people who have worked at the casino two or three years, have developed a credit history and are ready to get out of their apartments and into a home of their own."
Preston First Selectman Robert Congdon said that in his town as well, he could not cite a single commercial development that spun off from Foxwoods. But he is hopeful
"We're going to start to see some spinoff soon, particularly if there is some kind of mass transit to tie the region together, so you can go to Mystic, and Foxwoods, and Mohegan," he said. "That's going to be a key to starting this kind of development."
Some groups don't want the spinoff, however. Madeline Jeffrey, a member of the North Stonington Citizens Land Alliance and other groups that oppose some of the development associated with the casino, said she was suspicious even of the tribe's noncasino plans.
"With the exception of the pharmaceutical company they've started, it seems to me that everything else is just a way to bring more people to the casino," Mrs. Jeffrey said. "It's great that they're creating shipbuilding jobs. But the purpose of those ships is to bring people to Connecticut's shores so they can gamble. And it's the same with the maglev trains."
Katherine L. Bishop, co-chairman of Not A Done Deal, a group that organized to battle the Six Flags proposal, said she hoped that in the future there could be discussions before a development proposal was put on the table.
"I hope the people in the region can be more proactive, that there can be ideas put forth and the towns can decide what they do want, so it isn't a battle every time something comes up," Mrs. Bishop said. "I think Six Flags was about the worst that can come down the pike. Now we need to work towards what the best can be."
Donald M. Peppard Jr., a Connecticut College economist who has tracked the casino's growth, said the point might be moot.
"I suspect there's not that much room left for gambling to grow," Dr. Peppard said. "Gaming may continue to grow faster than the rest of the economy for a little while, but I think the kind of growth we've seen in the past is just about over." He said, however, that the tribe seemed to recognize that.
"From the very beginning, they were thinking about other things to do," Dr. Peppard said. "That's one of the advantage of the tribes over Electric Boat -- Electric Boat was either unwilling or unable to diversify, while the tribe is making at least fledgling efforts to spin off some of that gaming money into efforts that could benefit the entire region."
Because of the tremendous changes in the economy, the regional economic development agency two years ago paid to have its then-five-year-old plan updated. The conclusion was the region should attempt to promote four "clusters of development" -- biotechnology, tourism, education, and high- technology manufacturing.
"I think the lessons we've learned from the 1970's and 80's is that a broadly based, diversified economy is what prevents sudden ups and downs in the region's fortunes," Mr. Markowicz said.
"We're in the position of trying to create jobs, and if there's a powerful entity out there trying to create jobs either in the clusters or in a new cluster, we're not going to oppose it," Mr. Markowicz said. "We'll take help from whatever force provides that kind of positive momentum to the economy."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: E. 28th St. Renovation Creating 416 Apartments for Lower-Income Tenants and the Homeless;
For the Prince George Hotel, a New Life

 BODY:
The Prince George Hotel, a hulking 13-story eyesore at 14 East 28th Street with a tattered black canopy and crime-ridden past, is being refurbished as part of a $28 million project providing both living quarters and support programs.
Common Ground Community, a nonprofit housing development and management group, is turning the hotel, abandoned since 1990, into a residence with 416 efficiency apartments for the formerly homeless and for lower-income working single adults earning between $13,000 and $30,000 a year. Construction is to begin in October. 
 The project, to be completed by the fall of 1998, is being financed by the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the New York State Office of Mental Health, the state Department of Social Services and by low-income housing and historic tax credits.
Common Ground is modeling the project after the 652-unit Times Square at 255 West 43d Street, a former hotel it renovated and runs with its on-site social services partner, the Center for Urban Community Services.
It is also proposing to put the Prince George on the National Register of Historic Places. "It shares many of the same characteristics as the Times Square," said Roseanne Haggerty, executive director of Common Ground. "It's a landmark-quality building that has been badly misused. We look forward to renewing the property and having it be a neighborhood treasure again, while assisting those in need of housing."
The Prince George, an elaborate 1905 apartment hotel designed by Howard Greenley, was most recently the largest welfare hotel in the city.
The empty building now reminds Brian Keenan, Common Ground's on-site project manager, of a "haunted house."
"Out of five elevators, one works," he said."There's tremendous water damage." But Elizabeth Newman, project architect with Beyer Blinder Belle, said that "the building is essentially sound with some cosmetic problems."
Apartments, ranging from 250 to 300 square feet, are to have kitchenettes as well as basic furniture and a bathroom. Residents may also do their own decorating. Common rooms are to include art, computer and rehearsal spaces, as well as two landscaped roof decks.
Those leasing any of the three commercial spaces, including the ballroom, must hire at least 25 percent of their employees from those living in supportive housing in the city.

HEADLINE: Downtown Is Looking Up

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
IT was the 11th hour and the decision on the largest downtown lease in years hung in the balance. Harold McGraw 3d placed a call. He talked briefly to David G. Bronner, who runs the pension fund that owns the building, about rent.
The agreement reached in that conversation has given the slowly recovering office market in the downtown financial district a shot of adrenalin -- a 20-year lease for 15 huge floors at 55 Water Street. The occupant will be the Standard & Poor's divisions of the McGraw-Hill Companies. The owner is the New Water Street Corporation, an affiliate of the Retirement Systems of Alabama, which Dr. Bronner runs. 
 On those 62,400-square-foot floors -- the 33d through the 47th -- there is a total of 936,000 square feet of space, about the same amount of space as there is in Donald Trump's 40 Wall Street wedding-cake skyscraper a few blocks away, which rises 66 stories high.
The deal completes the leasing comeback of a nationally prominent building that was relinquished by Olympia & York Properties, the Canadian development company headed by the Reichmann family of Toronto, to its creditor-bondholders in the early 90's. The vacancy rate has gone from 40 percent to under 2 percent.
The deal also calls attention to the fact that there has been an upsurge of large space commitments downtown in recent months. These, combined with the removal of mostly obsolete space through residential conversions, have considerably tightened the market this year.
"There has been a flight to quality, which happens whenever there's been a real-estate recession," said John F. Powers, an Insignia/Edward S. Gordon Company broker who led the team that advised McGraw-Hill.
The flight so far has tended to benefit principally the newest, highest-quality buildings. The question still open is how the second tier of office buildings will fare. Many of them are from the postwar era but were completed before 1980.
Moreover, many of the moves so far are internal to downtown. Standard & Poor's, for example, will be giving up downtown about half as much space as it is leasing. Most of it is in two buildings that face each other at Bowling Green -- 337,000 square feet at 25 Broadway on the west side of Broadway, and 135,000 square feet at 26 Broadway on the east side.
Moves into downtown from midtown -- by no means improbable inasmuch as the rents for large-scale tenants are effectively about 30 percent below rents for comparable space in midtown -- would increase the net effect of leasing activity on office occupancy and employment growth.
But for now, there is mainly a feeling of pleasure and relief that 55 Water Street has been spoken for. Once that happened, in fact, Goldman Sachs & Company, which had long been considered the leading candidate to take at least part of the space that ultimately went to Standard & Poor's, agreed to lease the entire building at 10 Hanover Square, brokers report.
That 1971 property has half a million square feet of space, and its future had seemed to lie in residential conversion when Steven Witkoff, principal in the Witkoff Group, bought it vacant last year.
There have been other big deals of late: In June Merrill Lynch bought 222 Broadway, the former Western Electric Building between Ann and Fulton Streets, to house support functions forced out by business growth at its headquarters location in the World Financial Center, at Battery Park City. The seller was Swiss Bank, which is moving to Stamford, Conn.
Merrill will take over the bank's 409,000 square feet, and over time will probably occupy additional space in the 750,000-square-foot 1964 building, said Peter G. Riguardi of Colliers ABR, Merrill Lynch's real estate consultant, and use it for expansion.
"It's really a 1990's interior," said Colleen Sheridan, the Insignia/ESG broker who represented Swiss Bank. The bank put $45 million into the building in 1990, she said.
And also in June, 130 John Street came off the market with a lease that will return all its empty 490,000 square feet of space to office use. The city's Human Resources Administration took the entire building for its headquarters, leaving nine other downtown buildings. It will be renamed 180 Water Street, said Robert F. R. Ballard of Cushman & Wakefield, who represented the city in the transaction.
Seven of the 10 largest recent leasing deals have been in the so-called Financial East district on or near Water Street, brokerage reports show. With the help of such deals, the overall downtown vacancy rate in the first six months of this year declined to 15.2 percent from 20.1 percent in the first six months of last year, according to Cushman & Wakefield Research Services.
Real estate firms usually break down the inventory by classes -- A for the newest and highest quality, most of them built after 1980, B for the second tier, usually earlier postwar buildings that have not undertaken the kind of renewal program that is bringing 55 Water Street to Class A status, and Class C for older, lower-cost space. Using this categorization, Cushman & Wakefield says that the vacancy rate among Class A downtown buildings fell to 12.2 percent in the first six months this year from 15.3 percent in those months last year.
THE Class A buildings account for about 50 percent of the 108 million square feet in the downtown office inventory, as Cushman & Wakefield measures it. The vacancy rate was 18.2 percent in Class B buildings, down from 25.8 percent, and 18.9 percent in the Class C category, down from 25.8 percent, the firm says.
Some of the improvement in vacancy rates in Class B and Class C properties is the result of the withdrawal of buildings from the office leasing market as they move toward residential conversion. But the figures to date indicate that all the residential conversions completed, in construction or planned, will remove only about 3.37 million square feet of office space, or roughly 3 percent of the inventory, from office use.
Residential conversions notwithstanding, therefore, downtown's fate is linked to the success of its office buildings. The 55 Water Street saga is only the latest example of a comeback, building by building, of prime properties that took heavy blows from bankruptcies, contractions, restructuring and move-outs in the early 90's. Some buildings have been able to use the period, sometimes under changed ownership, to put themselves in position to compete for major tenants when the market improved.
An earlier example is the 400,000-square-foot 55 Broad Street, now the New York Information Technology Center, where the Rudin Organization poured $40 million into a building that was empty six years after Drexel Burnham Lambert went into bankruptcy. It is now 95 percent leased to 75 tenants, said William Rudin, all in the new-media or information technology fields.
In this building small companies can get wireless broadband access or hardwired fiber optics at the desktop, traditionally services that only large companies could afford and provide. Some tenants have already expanded, Mr. Rudin said. The company has begun to use a similar approach in another property, 110 Wall Street, a 1965 building with 300,000 square feet of space.
And still earlier, Chase Bank poured $150 million into improving public spaces and upgrading building systems at the 50-story 1968 building at One New York Plaza, with 2.1 million square feet of space. Chase, a lessee in the building, exercised its option to buy it when it was largely vacant, and then signed major leases with Prudential Securities and Goldman Sachs.
Despite the recent activity by large tenants, it is smaller tenants in the middle-tier buildings that are providing most of the current dynamism. Often these buildings are in the hands of new buyers who paid prices that permit aggressive dealmaking.
Mr. Witkoff, often making purchases with financing from Credit Suisse First Boston, has over the last two years acquired 2.5 million square feet of office buildings in the financial district alone -- 156 William Street, One Broadway, 100 Wall Street, 33 Maiden Lane and 10 Hanover Square.
Credit Suisse First Boston has financed a number of other acquisitions of its own or with developers in Manhattan over the last 15 months, taking advantage of a "window of opportunity" when prices have been favorable, said Andrew D. Stone, head of the firm's principal transaction group. The firm has put about $2 billion into New York City deals, Mr. Stone said.
The prices paid for buildings have ranged drastically -- from $10 to $125 a square foot, brokers and buyers say -- depending on such factors as current profitability and the amount of additional investment required to attract tenants. In one recent purchase at $38 a square foot, for example, Mr. Witkoff paid $18 million for the 475,000-square-foot 1969 building at 100 Wall Street, between Water and Front Streets. The owner, Hexalon, a Dutch pension fund, had bought the property in the 80's and upgraded it, increasing its value. Now Mr. Witkoff will "work the building" as corporate leases come due over the next three years. "About 160,000 feet will roll over, creating an opportunity to consolidate occupancies into contiguous spaces," Mr. Witkoff said.
Among other buildings that have transferred in the downtown shake-out are 22 Cortlandt Street, 250 Broadway, 80 Maiden Lane, 222 Broadway, 50 Broadway, 111 Broadway, 71 Murray Street, 2 Rector Street, 100 Church Street and 17 Battery Place. Darcy Stacom, the Cushman & Wakefield broker in a few of the sales, noted that motivations of the purchasers vary. "Some buyers are investors betting on the future of the office market, some are planning residential conversions, and one was to a user," she said. The user was Merrill Lynch.
At 50 Broadway, a 1927 office building a few steps north of Bowling Green, Charles Bendit, president of CBC Properties, bought a 340,000-square-foot property with partners in June from Cigna Corporation for $14.4 million when it was 65 percent occupied.
Since then about 20,000 square feet has been leased out, Mr. Bendit said. There are 45 tenants in the building, most of them in about 2,000 to 4,000 square feet, and three have renewed their leases and taken more space over the last six weeks, he said.
At 22 Cortlandt Street, Credit Suisse First Boston was the buyer last December. It is a 668,000-square-foot 1972 building between Broadway and Trinity Place that has the Century Department Store in the base but was entirely vacant in the 400,000 square feet of office space above. Norman Sterner, the general partner in Murray Hill Properties, which handles management and leasing, said 350,000 square feet had already been committed to seven tenants, three of them coming from midtown. The minimum lease size is a full floor of 17,000 square feet.
As for 55 Water Street, its saga began in the late 60's when builders were taking advantage of a widening of Water Street that the City Planning Commission initiated specifically to direct office growth in the financial district to the eastern rim of lower Manhattan. The Uris brothers -- Percy and Harold -- were the builders.
With a total of 3.6 million square feet of space, it is the second largest privately owned office building in the country, behind Sears Tower in Chicago, which has 3.8 million square feet. The building has a 53-story tower attached to a 14-story wing, with an open 40,000-square-foot plaza at the third level, reached from an open stairway between the wings and intended for public functions. The design, by the firm of Emery Roth & Sons, was strongly influenced by the city's downtown planning office.
Almost from the beginning the largest occupant has been the Chemical Bank -- now merged with Chase -- in 1.2 million square feet on the first 14 floors in both wings. The lease runs to 2003.
The vacancy rate climbed as high as 40 percent -- about 1.5 million square feet in 1993 -- with move-outs by big investment firms. Olympia & York, no longer in a position to get the financing to carry out the asbestos removal and other major improvement work necessary to attract or hold major tenants, relinquished the ownership to its bondholder-creditors. The largest one, the Retirement Systems of Alabama, bought out the other bondholders.
A key goal was to win a renewal lease in 1995 from the Depository Trust Company, a longterm tenant, said Edward J. Kulik Jr., director of the investment management division of Jones Lang Wootton U.S.A., who is in charge of leasing. Depository Trust renewed to the year 2018, taking an additional 180,000 square feet for a total of 500,000 square feet, Mr. Kulik said. In May, Chubb Insurance, currently in 100 William Street, leased 155,000 square feet on three floors.
"In the 80's we were considered a B building even though we were well-occupied, because we were being used mainly for trading and back offices," Mr. Kulik said. "So the question was do we continue on that path or do we make it an A building. The retirement system decided to spend $140 million on the base building structure and become an A building."
The future of Chase's occupancy in the building and beyond is of obvious importance. The Chase-Chemical operation uses 16 million square feet in office space and branches in the metropolitan area, and seven million square feet of pure office space in Manhattan alone, of which 4.5 million is downtown, said Cesar J. Chekijian, senior vice president of Chase Properties Group.
As a result of the merger, the bank is moving as much space as it can from midtown to downtown, where Chase formerly had its headquarters and still has a major presence. But it has also vacated two floors at 160 Water Street in a move to One New York Plaza. No further large moves are anticipated in the 90's, he said.
At McGraw-Hill, the company said that both the ratings group and the financial information services group of Standard & Poor's would move to 55 Water Street, with occupancy starting next July. If the deal had not worked out, said Mr. Powers of Insignia/ Edward S. Gordon, McGraw-Hill was prepared to build a new building in the Lefrak Organization's Newport development in Jersey City. A tax relief package from the state and city of New York, announced April 24, was critical, he said.
THE 55 Water deal will probably also assist efforts to lease up 2 Broadway, an almost vacant postwar building of 1.5 million square feet on 32 floors, acquired out of bankruptcy for $21 million in cash last year by Tom Sapir, the principal in Zar Realty. Mr. Sapir is a Russian-born investor in his 40's who made a fortune in the electronics distribution and oil export businesses, operating through a Manhattan-based company called Joy Lud International, according to Frederick Contini, his associate.
Mr. Sapir acquired and later sold 99 John Street and 80 John Street, but has kept and undertaken leasing campaigns at other acquired properties, including 260 and 261 Madison Avenue, between 38th and 39th Streets, Mr. Contini said. Two-thirds of the Zar portfolio of 5 million square feet is in lower Manhattan. Besides 2 Broadway, it includes 110-120 Church Street and 53 Park Place, Mr. Contini said. Williams Real Estate was given the leasing assignment at 2 Broadway in June. Expressing optimism, Brian Given, the broker in charge, said that as soon as Standard & Poor's signed at 55 Water Street, "we became the only building in the state of New York that can offer a million-plus square feet under one roof."
Helping these leasing efforts, all brokers say, is the apparent improvement in the financial district's physical environment as the result of the activity of the business improvement district, run by the Alliance for Downtown New York. And the residential conversions promoted by the alliance, with the help of substantial city tax incentives, have helped to lower the office vacancy rate even as it prospectively brings more round-the-clock activity to the district.
"Tenants big and small are looking," said Caleb Koeppel, the 40-year-old manager of the family-owned building at 26 Broadway, which Standard & Poor's is leaving. "We'll get a 100,000-square-foot tenant from midtown."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 10; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 795 words

HEADLINE: In Vineland, a Marketplace Run by Farmers, for Farmers

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
SAM RONCHETTI is still going strong. Six days a week, 35 weeks a year, Mr. Ronchetti calls the prices in his rapid-fire, singsong voice at the Vineland Produce Auction.
"I was 5 years old when my father started this auction," said Mr. Ronchetti, who will be 82 in two weeks. "I haven't missed more than two weeks in 52 years, and I'm going to keep calling until I can't do it anymore." 
 The Vineland Produce Auction is a Sotheby's for squash and as many as 70 other varieties of vegetables and produce raised in New Jersey's 8-to-10-month growing season. So influential is this nonprofit marketplace, owned and operated by farmers, that no matter where you bought your tomatoes, cucumbers, green beans, blueberries, peppers or eggplant, Vineland Produce Auction had something to do with how much you paid.
"There is no other auction of this size anywhere in the country," said Joseph Tarpine, a State Department of Agriculture market reporter based in Bridgeton. "Vineland sets the prices on produce from Canada down to Florida, in Chicago and Detroit. The buyers of tomatoes for supermarkets in Florida will find out what tomatoes sold for in Vineland and use that as the standard."
The auction also acts as a village green. Farmers from 300 farms in Burlington, Atlantic, Gloucester, Cumberland, Salem and Cape May counties gather Mondays through Saturdays, arriving sometimes before the sun comes up. They gather outside the drab shed, warm themselves over a cup of dandelion soup from nearby Tony's Luncheonette, and trade gossip and shop talk before Mr. Ronchetti begins the auction at 10:30.
"The auction itself hasn't changed," said Charles Bylone, 74, a Cumberland County farmer who as a teen-ager sold his family's eggplant at the auction. "A farmer's livelihood comes down to finding a buyer for his crop and getting a fair price for what he has to sell, and an auction is the best way that that can happen."
Founded in an abandoned gravel pit in 1931, the Vineland Produce Auction was then one of nine rural auctions in South Jersey. Vineland's auction arose "as a way of making sure the farmers got paid," Mr. Ronchetti said. "They used to have to put their produce on train cars to New York or Baltimore and take whatever price they could get on consignment, and not really have any idea of what the prices were until several days after the sale. When we started the auction, we brought the bidding and selling up to where we could keep an eye on it."
Other auctions have either closed or changed to non-bidding, direct sales operations negotiated by telephone and fax, but Vineland persists with in-person voice bidding on produce samples that buyers can inspect, smell and taste before haggling over the price. Once the sample is sold, the auction levies a 4 percent fee to cover its operating costs. The buyer sends a truck to the farm to get the rest of the lot.
Complex factors of weather, transportation costs, supply and demand mean prices can fluctuate wildly from $2 to $12 a box or bushel. Daymon W. Thatch, a Rutgers University professor of agricultural economics and marketing who has studied the auction, said these fluctuations "can drive the major chain buyers, your supermarkets and major distributors up the walls."
"The function of the auction is to keep the buying process honest and out in the open, and diffuse the risk over the greatest possible number," Mr. Thatch said. "This wasn't so much a problem 50 years ago when the markets were smaller --individual produce stands, mom-and-pop grocery stores, packers and canning companies. But a chain market like an Acme or a Pathmark is going to want a fixed price on green beans or tomatoes for several weeks so they can determine a price and run a sale, and not be beaten somebody else buying the same produce at a lower price."
To get this fixed price, more buyers are bypassing the auction block to negotiate with individual farmers, sometimes before the crop is ready for harvest. The Vineland Produce Auction also negotiates direct sales. Last year, two-thirds of the $50 million in wholesale produce that moved through the auction were direct sales.
Although live bidding remains strong, Mr. Bylone, a former president of the auction and still a board member, fears that its days might be numbered. "From the beginning, there's been pressure on us to change our ways," he said, "to make things easier or more efficient or cheaper. We've lost some farmers over the years for a lot of reasons, most of them having to do with land costs and development. I think we'd lose a lot more if we gave up the auction."
But Mr. Ronchetti said he wasn't worried. "As long as people want to see where the money comes from and where it goes," he said, "I'll have a job."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sam Ronchetti calling the prices at the Vineland Produce Auction. (Allen Oliver for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1299 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1998 Subaru Forester;
A Car for Town and Backcountry

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
BY children constantly stump me with questions. For instance, as we assembled s'mores recently, my daughter left me cold when she asked how marshmallows were made.
My 5-year-old son socked me with another one as he climbed out of the 1998 Subaru Forester. "Is this a car or a truck?" he asked. (He obviously hadn't read Subaru's press materials -- he can't read, period -- which stressed that the Forester begs the question, "Is it a car or is it a truck?") 
 He went on to say that the Forester felt like a car when he got in and out because it sat low to the ground. But with its white body and black luggage rack, it resembled his baby-sitter's Ford Explorer, a truck that has the same color scheme. Still, he decided, the Forester was too small to be a truck. "I guess it's a car-truck," he concluded with as much satisfaction as if he had solved the riddle of the Sphinx.
Indeed, the Forester, like many of the newest utility vehicles, defies precise categorization.
With more than two million sport-utility vehicles sold last year and continued growth predicted into the next century, auto makers are scrambling to fill market niches and to create new niches in the segment. Among the companies hoping to create another winning formula is Subaru, which has thrived with the introduction of rugged-looking, all-wheel-drive Outback versions of its Legacy and Impreza cars.
The Forester is Subaru's latest small car-truck hybrid. Like its prime competitors, the Toyota RAV4 and the Honda CR-V, the Forester combines the ride, handling and comfort of a sedan with the outdoorsy appearance, practicality and off-road capability of a sport utility. And in many ways, the Forester outperforms the entries from Toyota and Honda.
The Forester is classified by the Environmental Protection Agency as a small station wagon -- that is, as a car. It is equipped with dual front air bags, side impact beams and bumpers that meet the Federal Government's more stringent requirements for cars.
Indeed, the Forester is derived from the compact Subaru Impreza. Longer and taller than the RAV4 and close in exterior size to the CR-V, the Forester has a more head-to-the-woods appearance than the oh-so-cute RAV4 or the uncluttered, box-shaped CR-V. With its macho grille, square head lamps, ground-hugging stance, mud flaps and "AWD" badges, the five-passenger Forester looks ready for serious off-roading.
Inside, however, the Forester is undoubtedly a car. Its low profile makes entry and exit easy. From behind the wheel, there is good visibility -- thanks to large expanses of glass, narrow roof pillars and a low hood line. The view out the rear window is good, too: unlike the RAV4 and CR-V, which have the spare tire mounted to the back door, the Forester stows its full-size spare beneath the floor of the cargo area.
The Forester's seating positions are car-like as well, except that the roomy cabin provides more headroom than most small cars. The front buckets proved comfortable, once I figured out how to use the two unconventional rotating controls that tilt the seat and adjust the lumbar support. The rear seat is a three-person bench, with shoulder-lap safety belts for the outer passengers and a lap belt in the center. The rear seat can be partly folded or entirely folded for maximum cargo space.
The instrument panel, which includes a large analog speedometer and tachometer, is similar to that of a traditional sedan. Only the optional and rather gimmicky gauge package for the center of the dash, which includes an elaborate compass, thermometer, altimeter and barometer, suggests that this Subaru could be used for cross-country rally racing.
Largely aimed at young buyers, the Forester emphasizes good vibes. An 80-watt stereo radio and cassette player with four door-mounted speakers is standard. A CD player can be added as an option without sacrificing the cassette. But the system's ergonomics need improvement. The teeny buttons are better suited to my children's fingers than to my own.
The cup holders could also use some attention. One pulls out from the dash directly in front of the heating and air-conditioning vent; a second is oddly placed inside the center console, while another pair is available to back-seat passengers.
Nice touches are the 12-volt outlets for lighters, cellular phones, computers or air compressors. There is one outlet in the front and another in the cargo bay.
Storage is bountiful. When not being used for the cup holder, the center console offers a storage box. Mounted in the ceiling is an overhead console with map lights, a digital clock and a built-in case for glasses. The doors have map pockets and storage bins in the armrests. Some Forester models have storage nets on the seat backs.
At 33.2 cubic feet, the cargo bay beats the CR-V and RAV4. Accessible by the rear lift gate, which opens upward, the cargo area sits low for easy loading and unloading. It easily accommodated sleeping bags, camping gear and backpacks for the three Girl Scouts I delivered to camp. Fold the rear seats down, and the cargo capacity doubles.
If that's not enough, there is always the roof rack. The short stature of the Forester makes the rack practical for carrying bicycles, canoes and skies.
The Forester is loaded with standard features, including power steering, windows, seats and locks, all-wheel drive, anti-lock brakes (on the L and S versions, but not available at all on the base model), air-conditioning, cruise control, tilt steering and rear defroster and wiper.
Living up to its billing, the Forester offers carlike ride and handling. It uses a 2.5-liter "boxer" engine, which is positioned horizontally under the hood; the same engine is used in the Legacy Outback and 2.5 GT and the Impreza 2.5 RS. The engine's design gives the Forester a lower center of gravity and shorter length for good stability.
The Forester also has best-in-class power. Rated at 165 horsepower, the four-cylinder engine rivals some sixes and compares favorably with the RAV4 and CR-V, which have less than 130 horsepower. Torque, at 162 foot-pounds, is significantly higher than its two competitors', aiding in getaways from a dead stop.
The Forester comes with a five-speed manual or a four-speed automatic transmission; the tested model had the automatic, which shifted quite smoothly.
Despite higher power, and thanks to Subaru's lightweight all-wheel-drive system, the Forester still gets good fuel economy.
The Forester also has an advantage in handling. It conquered winding roads and tight corners with plenty of grip and agility. Braking is not only carlike, but similar to that of a sports car. According to testing conducted by Car and Driver magazine, the Forester's braking approaches that of the Porsche 911.
Plus, the Forester offers added confidence in winter driving. Its all-wheel-drive system constantly varies torque between the front and rear wheels for better traction. The system, the vehicle's ground clearance and the angles at which it can climb and descend hills make it possible to take the Forester off road. My only macho experience, however, was on the winding dirt road leading to the scouts' wooded campsite.
The Forester's ride was quiet and car-like, too. While not as silent as a Lexus, the Forester is far less noisy than the raucous RAV4 and the deafening CR-V.
Despite their shortcomings, the RAV4 and CR-V have been successful in the market. The Forester, with its quiet ride, carlike handling, roomy cabin, cargo capacity and long list of standard features, will likely follow suit, especially with its competitive pricing of $19,000 to $24,000.
And Forester buyers won't care if it is a car or a truck.
 
INSIDE TRACK: The spirit of the great outdoors in a small package.

GRAPHIC: Photos: An instrument panel fit for a rally. Nothing blocks the view from the rear. Is the Forester a truck or a car? Or has Subaru created something in the middle? (Subaru of America)
