HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Widgets for Credits in a Cashless Marketplace

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
ANTHONY DeGANO, who owns a photography studio in Belmar, N.J., has photographed weddings and family portraits for clients and traded his work for, among other things, a diamond for his wife and electrical work for his business.
Robert Cook, who owns a commercial printing company in San Francisco, has printed color brochures for customers and swapped his products for items including office equipment for his company and a patch of land on Hawaii for himself. 
 In these transactions, Mr. DeGano and Mr. Cook have used barter dollars, earned from the barter exchanges of which they are members. Such groups, for membership and transaction fees, act as matchmakers of sorts, bringing together an increasing number of owners of small and midsize businesses to barter their goods and services.
Bartering is nothing new. But in the last few years, more sophisticated and computer-savvy barter exchanges have been able to add and improve links among barterers to deliver more goods and services. And while some informal barter still exists elsewhere, all the new barter companies have formal requirements on reporting to the Internal Revenue Service. This has helped dispel some of barter's shady image and has given a new tool to businesses seeking to use barter to conserve cash and find new customers beyond their usual trade areas.
When members sell their goods and services, at retail prices, through an exchange, they earn trade dollars that are credited to their account and can be used to buy from other members. Exchanges get their revenue through membership fees, generally $300 to $600, and from commissions, which tend to be 10 to 15 percent for each transaction.
Like the rest of corporate America, the world of barter is undergoing consolidations and mergers, resulting in new regional, national and international exchanges. One exchange has gone public and another plans to do so; an exchange's assets, like those of a stock brokerage firm, are the commissions it makes on trade transactions. And some exchanges have formed alliances, fostering trading among themselves.
Last year, 686 local, regional, national and international barter groups serving 408,000 clients conducted transactions valued at $9.1 billion in the United States and Canada, up from $8.4 billion in 1995 and $5.3 billion in 1990, according to the latest estimates from the International Reciprocal Trade Association in Chicago, one of two large barter trade groups. The current total is one-thousandth of 1 percent of the gross national product, said Robert Meyer, the publisher of Barter News in Mission Viejo, Calif.
Steven M. White, president-elect of the National Association of Trade Exchanges in Euclid, Ohio, the second big American barter trade group, said, "Bigger is better because consumers are demanding more choices and services." To further that goal, Mr. White said, his association set up a cooperative last month that any of its 110 members can join, for a fee of $50 a month and one-quarter of 1 percent of the value of any transaction. The cooperative is a kind of bank for barter dollars and transactions that can be traded by members across the nation through a computerized system -- effectively allowing small, local groups to increase their reach to match the scope of bigger exchanges, Mr. White said.
So far, 60 of the association's members have joined, enabling "each exchange to secure the other's trade dollars," said Mr. White, who is also president of the International Barter Corporation, a 1,000-member exchange in Seattle. He said that International Barter was going public and that his goal was to raise $1 million by the end of the year to expand his company by acquiring others.
The International Reciprocal Trade Association is also working on a "universal currency" system for its 180 members, said Steven Goldbloom, its president, and a principal of two barter exchanges, one corporate and one retail, in San Francisco.
Proponents of bartering say businesses that barter can profit by increasing purchasing power and attracting new customers. For example, a widget maker who spends 35 cents on making a widget barters it at its full price, say $1, and receives back $1 in goods or services from barter companions, minus the commission. Or a barterer in New Jersey may be able to find a new customer in Hawaii through a barter exchange, expanding her trade area.
While some exchanges have formed alliances, others have joined forces with their corporate barter counterparts. Those counterparts buy surplus from large companies to sell to secondary and overseas markets. The alliances give the corporate barter groups another distribution system and the smaller businesses get more products to trade for.
Bartering does not benefit all companies, however, particularly those that work on profit margins of 25 percent or less, Mr. Meyer said. Moreover, a trade dollar is like an i.o.u., so members must depend on their exchange's ability to fulfill it, and desired goods may not always be available.
Businesses should not use bartering unless they spend the trade dollars, Mr. Meyer said. Unspent trade dollars create cash-flow problems and tax-liability issues because credits are taxed as income when they are received, he said.
Bartering went through a shakeout in the late 1980's and early 1990's, and many of the barter groups that lacked experience and capital closed, Mr. Meyer said. Once perceived as part of the underground economy -- a way to avoid paying taxes -- bartering also gained credibility with the passage of the tax act in 1983. It required barter exchanges, for the first time, to report to the Internal Revenue Service the value of transactions, which are subject to the same tax treatment as cash transactions. (Transactions by individuals who barter outside a formal exchange are also subject to the tax treatment of cash transactions.)
But the image of barter as a sometimes questionable practice is still vivid in some minds, in part because of highly publicized cases like one last year in which the artist Peter Max was indicted on charges that he bartered paintings as partial payment for three homes and failed to declare the sale of those paintings on his income tax return. The trial is set to begin on Oct. 1 in United States District Court in Manhattan.
The Itex Corporation of Portland, Ore., the barter exchange that started publicly trading its stock in 1992, has also been making the news. Among the nation's largest exchanges, with 14,000 clients and 124 broker offices across the country as well as 20 foreign offices, Itex has been involved in a lawsuit and has been under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for more than a year.
Itex won the suit, in which it accused a rival company, BXI Inc., of breach of contract after its attempted takeover of that company went awry, but BXI is appealing the decision. The S.E.C.'s investigation about certain of Itex's accounting policies and business transactions continues.
The company's stock, which in January 1996 traded as high as $12.50 a share, has plunged to around $3.
DESPITE these troubles, barter transactions continue to grow. Bartering is a way to conserve cash, and "businesses can never have enough cash," said Chris C. Christensen, who runs C. N. Barter Inc. in Belmar, N.J., a part of Itex.
He gets no argument from Mr. DeGano, the photo studio owner, who has been a member of C. N. Barter for nine years. Bartering, he said, is a way to increase his working capital and fill slow periods. "Rather than sitting idle, I can barter my services," said Mr. DeGano, adding, "a deal is a deal."
Of course, bartering is no substitute for cash when it comes to paying bills, but barterers can still be creative.
Susan Groenwald, president of the Barter Corporation, which is based in Chicago, tells of an owner of a bicycle and silk-screening shop who bartered enough bicycles and T-shirts to to earn trade dollars that he used for an expanded plant for his business.
And Mr. Cook, the San Francisco printer, who has been bartering for the 13 years he has been in business, says he even used trade dollars to buy out two partners. "It is not a magic black box and you have to be smart about using it," he said. "But I wonder how you can run a small business without it."

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
The Cosmopolitan Touch

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
Mutual fund investors in the United States are moving more money abroad, according to a recent survey by the Gallup Organization for Scudder, Stevens & Clark, which sponsors many funds that invest internationally.
The number of American households that invest overseas through funds has risen almost 18 percent since 1994, to 6.7 million, according to the survey. The number that invest solely in funds that stick to American markets has declined 11 percent in the same period. 
 And more investors are planning to send some money overseas soon. Nearly 20 percent of investors who did not own an international fund said they intended to buy one in the next 12 months. These people were particularly interested in broadly diversified funds that could invest anywhere in the world, the survey found.
Nonetheless, some investors remained leery about leaving home, at least in their mutual-fund investments. Though some of these investors cited concerns about political volatility and currency fluctuations, still more stressed their preference for supporting American companies as well as a lack of knowledge about foreign investment. A larger proportion of domestic investors -- 16 percent versus 9 percent last year -- said they would avoid foreign investing.
The survey, conducted annually in late March and early April, is based on 1,000 telephone interviews with heads of households that own mutual funds.
Scudder has recently been on the receiving end of some international investing; last month, Zurich Group, Switzerland's largest insurance company, agreed to buy the American fund company for $1.7 billion.
 
Retirement Planning
T. Rowe Price Associates has a new version of its financial-planning software for people thinking about retirement (as well as for those who have already retired). It allows couples to calculate their needs using a different retirement date for each spouse, and has a new -- and, the company says, more accurate -- calculation of the income tax rates that retirees are likely to pay, which can have a big effect on how much money they need to live comfortably.
The software requires an I.B.M.-compatible PC with Windows 3.1 or higher. It is available on compact disk or 3.5-inch diskette for $19.95, and can be ordered by calling (800) 541-5760.
 
Exchange Privileges
Investors in Van Kampen American Capital funds will be able to exchange their shares for shares in Morgan Stanley funds starting tomorrow. Morgan Stanley bought Van Kampen last year. The firm has ended a separate program under which investors in the funds of other companies could move their money into Van Kampen's offerings without paying a sales charge.
 
New Managers
Eric Miller, a research analyst and money manager with Heartland Advisors, has joined William Nasgovitz as co-manager of Heartland Value.
David Rosenberg, lead manager of Oppenheimer Limited-Term Government Bond and Oppenheimer U.S. Government Trust, resigned because of ill health. Jerry Webman, director of Oppenheimer's tax-exempt fixed-income investments group, will run the funds until the company picks a new manager.
Douglas D. Ramos, formerly lead manager of New England Balanced, has joined the Dreyfus Corporation. He takes over Dreyfus Balanced from Timothy Ghriskey, and Dreyfus Growth and Income, Dreyfus Premier Growth and Income and the Dreyfus Variable Investment Growth and Income Portfolio from Richard Hoey.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Judith Vale;
Neuberger & Berman Genesis Fund

BYLINE: By ANNE TERGESEN 

 BODY:
JUDITH VALE began her career at Radio Free Europe in the 1970's, critiquing Russian-language news reports that were beamed into the Soviet Union. Then she moved to the Greek isle of Hydra, ostensibly painting portraits but mostly swimming, she said. Today, she is a self-taught money manager who specializes in the stocks of small companies, which she describes with unusual verve.
But if Ms. Vale is colorful -- at least for the navy blue world of portfolio managers -- the mutual fund she manages, Neuberger & Berman Genesis, is not. And its dullness, she said, is part of the secret of its success. 
 In the three years she has run the fund, Ms. Vale has eschewed glamorous but risky high-fliers for sensible, humdrum, even boring companies, as she is fond of saying. Her aim is to compile a portfolio that avoids the sharp peaks and valleys characteristic of small stocks -- those that the market values at $1 billion or less.
The portfolio's companies "will put you to sleep -- but we think this is great," Ms. Vale said from her office overlooking lower Manhattan. "We don't want managers that glitter too much and have too much pizazz."
Pizazz is certainly not a problem for the 125 stocks in the $855 million fund; many are companies that basically make parts for other companies' products. The fund's biggest investments are in aerospace and energy, and it owns a smattering of smallish banks.
The strategy seems to be working. In the three years since Ms. Vale took command of the fund, the returns of Genesis have averaged 20.3 percent, exceeding the average of all domestic equity funds by 4 percentage points and the average small-capitalization fund by 6.5 percentage points, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund trackers.
Ms. Vale calls her staid investment approach "common sense," though at first glance it may seem at odds with her nontraditional path to Wall Street. A Russian literature major at Yale who never took an economics course, Ms. Vale said she settled on investing in part because everything else she explored "sounded pretty dreadful."
She got her first chance at a tiny investment partnership, where she typed and answered phones for three months before publishing her first research report -- and snaring a client. She later worked at several money management firms, including Atalanta Sosnoff Capital, Merrill Lynch Asset Management and Quest Advisory, which is run by the small-company investor Charles M. Royce.
In championing unexciting but predictable performers and looking for relatively inexpensive stocks, Ms. Vale, 44, is bucking the prevailing wisdom among many small-cap managers, who tend to prefer fast-growing concerns and typically own large blocks of technology and other stocks prone to earnings surprises, both positive and negative. The average domestic small-cap fund invested about 18 percent of its assets in technology stocks as of June 30, according to Morningstar, but the figure for Genesis is now about 10 percent, Ms. Vale said.
"Some people think it's sort of an inside-out way of managing money, but we look at the risk in a holding before we look at a return," she said. "I think a significant portion of our outperformance over the last couple of years has come from simply having far fewer blow-ups than other small-cap managers."
To minimize risk, Genesis follows a few guidelines. First, it looks for companies that have usually posted annual earnings increases of 15 to 18 percent for several years. Such steady returns are "a lot more sustainable," Ms. Vale said, than the high-octane performances that receive much attention.
The fund also looks for companies whose stocks are cheap simply because they have been overlooked, not because they are financially frail. Ms. Vale seeks companies that generate excess cash they can use to finance expansion either internally or by acquisitions or to repurchase stock to increase earnings per share. She also focuses on a company's return on assets, which helps weed out companies with a lot of debt. And she likes to meet with the company's executives to get an idea of their management skills.
Right now, Ms. Vale is keen on stocks in two areas, energy and commercial aerospace, which are experiencing rising demand for their products. In the case of energy, a protracted period of underinvestment has left drilling capacity tight while technological advances have lowered exploration and drilling costs, she said. In aviation, the companies that remain after the recent spate of consolidation should see sustained demand, she said, because Federal regulations are prompting airlines to replace their aging fleets.
Though these industries are generally sensitive to the economic environment, companies in both sectors enjoy the ability to raise prices -- a rarity that should help insure profit growth and protect Genesis shareholders from any economic slowdown, she said.
Ms. Vale is a patient investor. Accordingly, the percentage of the portfolio that changed last year -- its turnover -- was 21 percent, versus 93 percent for the average small-cap fund, according to Morningstar.
This placid style seems a world away from the adventures of her earlier life, but Ms. Vale does not see it that way. "Quite frankly, I view this job probably as a middle-aged version of the same thing," she said. "I am never bored."
 
A Choice in Energy
In energy, one of Ms. Vale's favorites is National-Oilwell Inc. of Houston, which recently bought another of the fund's top holdings, Dreco Energy Services of Edmonton, Alberta. A large maker of equipment for oil rigs, National-Oilwell is poised to benefit from rising energy demand that has recently encouraged oil service and drilling companies to build new rigs, Ms. Vale said.
"Clearly, there is going to be dramatic earnings growth ahead," she said, which justifies the recent doubling this year of National-Oilwell's stock price. (It now trades for more than $61 a share.)
 
Parts for Aircraft
The fund's largest holding is Thiokol, the Ogden, Utah-based maker of parts for commercial aircraft. Ms. Vale said she would not be surprised if rising revenues and profit margins helped push the company's stock from today's price of just under $74 to $100 a share within 18 months. That would be $58 more than the average price that Genesis paid for the stock.
Most analysts expect Thiokol's earnings for the year ending next June to be about $4.50 a share. But Ms. Vale says that estimate is too low. Given the company's solid management and the industry's strong fundamentals, she said, $5 or above is more likely.
 
A Distributor's Potential
Another favorite is Aviall Inc. of Dallas, a big independent distributor of new airplane parts. As the industry consolidates, Aviall is poised to remain a leader, Ms. Vale asserted, in part because it can generate much cash to buy back shares or to make acquisitions. She predicts that, with sales rising and management containing costs, earnings should rise 20 percent next year.
A stock price of $20 is "an easy shot" within 18 months, she added. Aviall now trades for $15 -- about 12 times next year's projected earnings a share -- making it "very inexpensive," she said.

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
The Never-Ending March of Lawyers

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
TIGHT-LIPPED and anxious, they marched en masse to the Javits Center last week, pens and pencils clutched in nervous hands. After three years of law school, two months of cram courses and countless sleepless nights, this, at last, was it: the New York State Bar Examination. For 5,000 aspiring New York lawyers, it was time to do or die.
The test-takers in Manhattan were among nearly 9,000 statewide, the biggest group ever, according to Nancy Carpenter, executive secretary of the State Board of Law Examiners. 
 The number of hopefuls taking the two-day summer exam and its February counterpart has been rising for some time, she said, with each year bringing another record number of applicants seeking entry into the legal profession.
Yet it is a profession that has seen better days, to be sure.
As lawyers themselves love to say, the evidence is overwhelming. Scorned by the citizenry (a Consumer Reports survey last year found that only diet clinics were held in lower esteem by their patrons), lawyers are nearly four times as likely to be depressed than average Americans, according to The Legal Intelligencer, a trade publication.
Partnership opportunities at big firms are down, and working hours are up, The National Law Journal says, and polls taken by various bar groups show that record numbers of lawyers would do something else if given the choice.
The situation is so bleak that legal experts participating in an on-line forum held this year by Counsel Connect, a service for lawyers, echoed the sentiments of Kathleen Munden, a Texas lawyer, who said that once students graduated from law school, the majority "will be left with an enormous student loan, no job and no practical knowledge about how to practice law."
But such pessimism seems not to dim the ardor of most graduates, 75 percent of whom usually pass the July exam. Cognizant of the pessimism surrounding their future profession, many are anxious nonetheless to go out and give it a try. Whether it is the prospect of the money they think they will earn that motivates them, or the bravado of those who have not yet known failure in their young lives, they believe they can transcend the problems.
Erica Fine, editorial director of the New York office of BAR/BRI, the nation's foremost cram course, is not so sure. She voices worry that some of the 6,300, mostly 20-something students taking her company's New York summer course are overly coddled by their families and are unrealistic.
Like the other members of BAR/BRI's New York management staff, she is a lawyer who does not practice ("I hated it," she says of her four-year stint in a small firm), and believes she was poorly prepared for the rigors of the profession when she graduated from law school in the early 1980's.
Today, she said, the problem is worse; her students "are needier now than ever before."
"They live with mom and dad longer, and expect that things are going to be done for them," said Ms. Fine.
Her job includes handling the phone calls of students who have problems or need additional tutoring. She says that more parents call her every year with questions that their adult children should be asking directly, but don't, as if they were too busy to pick up a phone.
Still, she said, the majority of cram course participants are neither deluded about their prospects, nor too lazy to care about the problems they face.
Basheva Genut, for example, a 24-year-old Fordham graduate from Manhattan, has already chosen not to seek legal employment. She'll be working at a nonprofit policy research institute. While she is taking the bar exam to complete her legal education, she says she views her legal credentials simply as "something good to have."
Sharon Dutch, 25, of Brooklyn, agrees. She concedes readily that she went to law school not out of some burning need to pursue justice but because she "wasn't ready not to be a student."
But after graduating from college, she managed to find interesting part-time work with a small law firm while attending Brooklyn Law School, and already has a job awaiting her at summer's end.
"I feel that law school provided me with a trade," she said.
Optimistic about her own future, she is nevertheless aware that plenty of lawyers for whom the law is "just a paycheck" are stuck in terrible jobs.
That's just what Richard Davies, 24, is determined to avoid. Having turned down a job in Los Angeles, where he attended school, he returned home to New York City confident of landing a position with a good firm.
He dismisses the widely held cynicism about lawyers as "jealousy and economic envy."
"I went to law school because most people I admired had law degrees," he said. "That hasn't changed."

"For This You Cram"
This question is excerpted from the February 1997 bar exam:
 
Hal and Win, after five years of marriage, agreed to separate. As long-time friends of yours, they have asked you to prepare a separation agreement. They have not consulted or retained other counsel. Hal and Win have agreed on most of the terms to be embodied in the separation agreement, including maintenance payable to Win. They have agreed that Win is to have custody of their only child, Peg, age 4, but they have not been able to agree on the amount of child support
 
(A) Can you represent both of them in preparing the separation agreement without jeopardizing the validity of the agreement?
 
(B) How should the appropriate amount of child support for Peg be determined?
 
ANSWERS:
(A) You could represent both if you divulge the possible conflict of interest.
 
(B) Child support should be calculated based on the Uniform Child Support Act.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1004 words

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Free-Market Fallout. For This We Won the Cold War?

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
WRITING about a new CD-ROM from Microsoft, a software reviewer recently noted, in a by-the-way tone, that the games on the disk were mostly developed in Russia under Alexey Pajitnov, the creator of the popular game Tetris. (He now works for Microsoft.)
In these post-cold war days, such arrangements are common enough to warrant only a ho-hum. But in the view of William Wolman and Anne Colamosca, authors of "The Judas Economy: The Triumph of Capital and the Betrayal of Work" (Addison-Wesley, $25), they add up to a kind of free-market fallout. It is a current, they say, that increasingly controls the direction of developed economies, especially our own. 
 "Understanding the impact of the cold-war victory on the United States is the key to understanding every major economic trend now in operation in the United States," the authors say.
It's an intriguing premise. And even if that key doesn't always fit, "The Judas Economy" is nonetheless persuasive as it argues that an unfettered free market has its tyrannies, too.
Since capitalism prevailed over Communism in the late 1980's, the authors contend, globalization has stepped up. Increasingly, corporations have been hiring the best and brightest in freshly pro-market countries like China, the former Soviet bloc and India, which abandoned its Soviet-model economy in 1991. The ranks of such workers are huge. Eager and prepared, thanks in part to socialist-style free education, these employees can be snapped up for a fraction of the cost of their American counterparts, the authors say.
The effects are "barely being felt now" by mid-level American workers, the authors say, but "it will get worse" as companies start to farm out engineering, architecture, banking and medical projects via E-mail.
In other ways, too, they argue, the post-cold war economy is a chilling place for Americans who rely on work, not capital, to support themselves. As capital roams the globe, putting more of its resources at the disposal of the newly available "knowledge"' workers, health and retirement benefits for domestic employees are dwindling. And with laissez-faire ideology riding high and even mild state intervention out of favor, Government isn't picking up much of the slack. "The market is now God; economic planning is the Devil incarnate," the authors lament.
"The Judas Economy" delivers a caveat about succumbing to such free-market triumphalism. Among the perils, the authors warn, is the specter of recession, along with a wider gap between rich and poor.
Mr. Wolman, chief economist at Business Week (where this writer was once a distant colleague of his), and Ms. Colamosca, a free-lance business journalist, know they are swimming against a tide -- a gush, really -- of optimism and pride. The economy's numbers are terrific these days: unemployment is low, inflation mellow, corporate profits healthy, the stock market snorting and pawing.
But with some lapses, "The Judas Economy" uses its post-cold war premise and those same statistics to challenge this bullishness.
The Fed's anti-inflation "hysteria," the authors say, only keeps growth dangerously slow. Anyway, its real purpose is to protect the value of loans for creditors (the owners of capital), not debtors (workers with high consumer debt and mortgages). And while more people may be working, inflation-adjusted wages are stagnating. Corporate profits are sturdy as Wall Street rewards downsizing and other cutbacks, but people are cheering for the stock market "at their own expense."
"The Judas Economy" doesn't always succeed in linking these traditionally liberal arguments to its premise about the new post-Communist global labor market. And in any case, it may be overstating that premise.
The authors never demonstrate, for example, that on-site employees have been replacing the Western engineers and executives usually sent abroad on projects. Although a chapter on Bangalore, India -- where legions work for American computer companies -- gives us a fascinating glimpse of the brainpower at Western capital's disposal, the book largely ignores the problems that keep many investors out of some newly pro-market regions: tangled bureaucracies, ingrained corruption, outdated infrastructures. For a slightly more pessimistic view of India's chances of attracting investment, for example, read Shashi Tharoor's "India: From Midnight to the Millennium" (Arcade Publishing, $27.95).
Over all, however, the book offers some compelling arguments, including a view that more Federal aid to university researchers will help American workers keep their creative edge. At times, its warnings are even entertaining. Calling re-engineering "a sick joke" for employees, the authors somewhat outrageously compare it to Mao's Cultural Revolution. And a discussion of the Fed's failures includes a terrific footnote on the hidden economic messages in "The Wizard of Oz."
 
BUTTON UP YOUR OVERCOAT Remember "Dress for Success"? Pick up a copy at a summer tag sale, as I did, and you'll get a quick glimpse of corporate culture 20 years ago. The book, by John T. Molloy, instructed a generation of white-collar workers that "conservative, class-conscious conformity" in clothes is "absolutely essential to success." That meant blue, gray and beige suits -- and beige (only!) raincoats. Black raincoats, then favored by the "lower middle class," were seen as a ticket back to the mail room.
Has this changed? Yes, according to the latest primer, "Work Clothes: Casual Dress for Serious Work," by J. Scott Omelianuk, the latest in the Chic Simple life-style series (Knopf, $23).
And no.
It's unquestionably hipper, and this guide to prevailing during the "casualization of America" is more about deconstruction than directives. It also applies the language of re-engineering -- "audit," "dejunk," "reinvest" -- to work wardrobes. Still, it primly advises that "a quality timepiece sends a signal of authority." And among the photos is that reliable trench coat -- in beige.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
With Rates Down, Will Investors Sell?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Where is Bob Dole when we need him?
Just a year ago Mr. Dole was promising legislation to let you file your tax return on a postcard. But he lost, and President Clinton and the Congressional Republicans have given us a law that only an accountant working by the hour could love. 
 The bill was so complicated that it was not until details were announced that someone realized it would actually raise capital gains taxes on many transactions. After some scrambling, that was fixed by making the law even more complex. Now there will be three capital gains holding periods, with different rates. No one knows how much it will cost mutual fund companies to change their computer programs and forms to keep track of all of that.
If Congress thought the Government was taking in too much money, it could have just cut tax rates a bit. But that is not how the politicians like it. So now you can look at your own family circumstances and see whether or not Washington approves of you.
The most despised people in America are smokers who fly a lot, have high incomes and little in the way of investments -- or at least little in the way of successful investments other than their homes. They don't get the benefit of lower capital gains taxes, since they don't have capital gains. Neither do they get any benefits from new individual retirement accounts or child credits or higher education credits. All of them have income limits. Taxes on cigarettes and plane flights are going up. And some people with expensive homes who formerly did not have to pay taxes when they moved now will owe money.
For investors, the most important part of the bill is, of course, the capital gains cut. Now, if you have owned a stock for 18 months and a day, you can sell and pay a tax of just 20 percent on your profits. The old rate of 28 percent applies on investments of one year and a day to 18 months. And you still pay rates of up to 39.6 percent, if you sell a year or less after buying.
An important question for market seers is to what extent the new rules will stimulate selling. (Washington assumes they will; this tax break is supposed to bring in revenue.)
Certainly, there are plenty of profits available for investors to take. The Dow Jones industrial average is now three times as high as it was at its 1987 peak. And a lot of that came in the last 18 months. Over that period, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 50 percent through the end of July. That was, as it happens, the best such performance since the 18 months that ended on July 31, 1987.
This column has, in the past, warned of the impact of pent-up selling demand once it became clear that the seller could qualify for a lower capital gains rate. Some sales will be made. But an offsetting factor is the widespread belief that this is a new era, one in which stocks are guaranteed to be the best long-term investment, in which neither inflation nor recession is a threat and in which baby boomers worried about retirement will put money into retirement plans -- invested in stocks -- every month. The enhanced I.R.A.'s in the tax bill could very well increase that investing.
This bull market will not last forever. But it is so strong that a mere tax incentive to sell may not have much impact. It will take something that challenges the new-era philosophy to do that. Valuations are stretched now, but they may go higher, with the party ending only when it becomes clear that the business cycle has not been repealed.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Younger Investors to the Muni Rescue?

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
AT 38, Mark Hyman, a doctor in Los Angeles, does not fit the image of the typical municipal bond investor: someone in his 50's or 60's, golf club in hand, in search of a steady stream of tax-free income for retirement.
But Dr. Hyman is a buyer of municipal bond mutual funds and some individual muni bonds, and is stashing cash in a tax-exempt money market fund while he ponders new equity and fixed-income investments. "I wanted a place that was less volatile" than the stock market, he said, and that "saves me on some taxes." 
 Dr. Hyman -- and millions of baby boomers like him -- are the great hope of the municipal bond market, which has been losing investors for years. Some analysts expect that these younger people will turn to municipal bonds as a low-tax, less-risky place to park some of the money they have made from other investments.
"Many investors are capable of taking substantial capital gains, and they're saying, 'Let's translate some of the gains into income,' " said Paul Williams, a vice president of John Nuveen & Company. "That's typically munis."
So far, though, the very success of those other investments, particularly stocks, has lured investors away from municipal bonds, a trend that could be magnified by the cut in the capital gains tax that Congress passed last week, analysts say.
Investors who hold securities for more than 18 months will now have to pay a tax of just 20 percent on their gains from appreciation, down from 28 percent. While this applies to all securities, it will have far more effect on those that are bought for price appreciation, like stocks, than on those bought for their income, like municipal bonds.
But the new tax treatment will not have much effect on the municipal market, or its efforts to attract new investors, said Jim Lynch, editor of the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory, an investment newsletter. "The newer people, they're not being dissuaded by capital gains, they're being dissuaded by the stock market," he said.
Ownership of bonds by individuals has been declining since 1991, according to Federal Reserve data. In 1996, investors held $419 billion of individual bonds, down 32 percent from 1991.
For the most part, municipal bond mutual funds have seen investor cash flowing in one direction -- out -- since 1994, according to the Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund industry trade group. This year alone, through June, $4.1 billion has left long-term municipal bond funds; last year these funds saw net outflows of $6.3 billion.
In response, fund companies are consolidating funds that are no longer big enough to run economically. For example, Fidelity Investments recently announced plans to merge three municipal bond funds -- Spartan New York Municipal Income, Spartan New York Intermediate Municipal Income and Fidelity New York Insured Municipal Income -- into the Fidelity New York Municipal Income fund. A shareholder vote on the merger is scheduled for December.
The competition from stock funds has been tough in the recent bull market, analysts say. But the exodus from muni funds has also resulted from the funds' low yields, which, when coupled with management fees, eat away at investor returns.
In part as a result of the declining demand for muni investments, the bonds' prices have yet to rebound to the levels they reached in 1993, according to data collected by the Delphis Hanover Corporation, a bond research company in Southbury, Conn.
But individual purchases of bonds are beginning to pick up, as more sophisticated investors balk at the low returns on muni mutual funds and their management fees. "Investors are thinking, 'I can do this on my own,' " said Tom Doe, president of Municipal Market Advisors, a research and risk management firm in Concord, Mass.
The changing tide even prompted Nuveen, the municipal bond fund powerhouse, to start Nuveen Asset Management almost two years ago to handle the the municipal bond portfolios of high-net worth individuals.
DESPITE the lower capital gains tax, many of these investors are unlikely to be lured away by equities. "The income-oriented investor is still going to need the income," said George D. Friedlander, a managing director and fixed-income strategist at Smith Barney. "If you need after-tax income there aren't a lot of places to go,"
And new buyers are starting to appear. At Paine Webber, these buyers include young professionals, athletes and entrepreneurs seeking tax shelters and future income, said William J. Jester Jr., a managing director and head of the municipal bond department.
They, like Dr. Hyman, see value in tax-exempt bonds.
"As my income grows, and I fill up on I.R.A.'s and pensions," Dr. Hyman said, "the rainy-day money falls into munis."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
The Search for the Perfect Corporate Board

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
ARE stockholders asking for too much?
One might think so from the sweeping set of proposals covering the structure of corporate boards that was issued recently by one of the biggest shareholders of them all, the California Public Employees' Retirement System. 
 The list was remarkable both for the self-proclaimed importance of its mission -- "to provide a benchmark of what is 'good' corporate governance" -- and for its specificity, addressing everything from who should sit on certain committees to compensation for directors and term limits.
There's only one problem: hardly any companies in the country even come close to filling the bill.
An analysis by The New York Times of data compiled by Directorship, a consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn., shows that of the 861 public companies on the Fortune 1000 list, only one, Texas Instruments Inc., meets a wide range of basic Calpers tests, including having a majority of independent directors, a separate chief executive and independent chairman and independent committees for ethics, compensation, auditing, governance and board nominations.
Texas Instruments also meets other criteria suggested by Calpers, whose $115 billion in assets makes it the largest public pension fund in the country. The big semiconductor maker has an age limit for directors, pays a significant part of the directors' compensation in company stock and does not provide retirement benefits to board members. In addition, its directors meet regularly without the chief executive.
The New York Times analysis also yielded no clear pattern that would link "good" governance to good performance, an outcome that is consistent with many other studies.
After all, while Texas Instruments has outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index since 1990, so has the company that fails the greatest number of basic Calpers tests: the Walt Disney Company. Its board lacks a majority of outside directors, its chairman and chief executive are the same person and a number of key committees are not made up entirely of independent directors.
When told how the company's board fared against the Calpers guidelines, executives at Disney responded with a letter discussing the company's performance, including the fact that an investment made in Disney 12 years ago has grown at an average annual rate of 28.1 percent.
The company said its strong performance was the direct result "of the excellent stewardship of the Disney board of directors, one of the strongest groups of its kind in U.S. business."
CALPERS, which has long been active in governance issues, says it isn't thrown by the results of the analysis. Good governance, it said, should be viewed as a kind of insurance policy to help all companies weather the inevitable difficult times.
"Should Calpers wait until companies are in the dumper before asking them to have decent corporate governance?" said Patricia K. Macht, a spokeswoman.
Its suggested principles, the most far-reaching of several such efforts in recent years, should be viewed as a worthy goal, Calpers executives say.
Although Calpers stopped short of adopting the principles because it wanted to study two of the proposals further, even the draft version released in June has heightened the scrutiny of companies and their boards. The draft immediately raised Calpers's profile in an arena where it had grown relatively quiet, but it also invited quick criticism that the guidelines were too restrictive and that Calpers was perhaps growing too meddlesome.
"The pendulum has swung too far, and Calpers is starting to overreach," said John M. Nash, president of the National Association of Corporate Directors, which sponsored a commission last fall that issued a more modest set of recommendations on governance.
The growing debate over the Calpers proposals underscores the lack of consensus about what constitutes a "perfect" board in the first place.
While many of Calpers's principles are universally accepted, some are viewed as counterproductive. One guideline facing further study -- a limit on the number of directors who can be older than 70 -- has drawn the most fire.
"Age limits would cut off too many good people with too much savvy," said Ralph D. Ward, editor of The Corporate Board magazine and author of "21st Century Corporate Board" (Wiley, 1997). "I don't really believe Calpers wants to put in anything that firm."
For Calpers, though, the debate over the proposals is almost as important as getting the companies in which it invests to fall in line, said William D. Crist, president of Calpers, based in Sacramento, Calif.
"For a very long time, the makeup of corporate boards is a subject that has been ignored, and we do believe that the issue is very important going forward into a new global economy," Mr. Crist said. "The dialogue that is going on is very healthy."
The dialogue promises to become even more lively should Calpers formally adopt the principles, which it is expected to do later this year. At that point, Calpers will most likely send them to perhaps 500 of the largest public companies in which it owns stock and ask for explanations about how they meet the criteria. In areas where companies come up short, Calpers will expect to hear how they plan to measure up, including offering alternative ways to meet the spirit, if not the letter, of the guidelines.
Calpers then plans to grade the companies and publicize the results. Uncooperative companies, Calpers executives say, will be prodded with proxy votes and shareholder proposals.
Such a strategy strikes some experts in the field as unnecessarily heavy-handed. Ira M. Millstein, a partner at Weil, Gotshal & Manges who led the commission last year that drew up governance principles for the National Association of Corporate Directors, said he had no objection to Calpers's sharing goals to which it thinks corporate America should aspire. But to then grade companies on how they measure up is not constructive, he said.
"I don't think it's useful to put people in a bad light if they don't happen to follow what you think," Mr. Millstein said.
IF nothing else, Calpers certainly has set an ambitious target for companies to meet.
The analysis of the data compiled by Directorship showed that large numbers of companies fail some of the tests. For example, boards have for the most part purged their compensation committees of insiders because of the outcry some years back that too many executives were setting their own pay or that of their chums. Still, 77 of the 845 largest public companies that disclosed information about their compensation committee have at least one insider on the panel, which decides how well executives are paid.
The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, has two insiders on its compensation committee: Gerald Greenwald, the company's chairman, and Michael H. Glawe, chairman of United's pilot union. But John D. Kiker, a spokesman, said the company felt a need to put insiders on the committee because UAL is owned, in the main, by its employees. In addition, Mr. Greenwald routinely removes himself from committee discussions about his own compensation, Mr. Kiker said.
Of the 140 companies that disclose information about their ethics committees, 21 have at least one insider on the panels. Disney has two insiders on its ethics committee: E. Cardon Walker and Raymond L. Watson, both former chairmen.
With so many specific requirements -- there are 37 principles over all -- it is inevitable that many companies that have generally served their shareholders well will fail a number of the tests.
The Calpers principles also include the recommendation that independent directors meet alone at least once a year; that the board designate a lead director when the chairman is also the chief executive and that a retiring chief executive not be allowed to continue serving on the board.
Calpers categorizes 23 principles as "fundamental" and 14 as "ideal." Calpers considers the age-limit proposal an ideal, which it would merely like companies to consider, as opposed to one of its fundamental criteria -- points on which it is less open to debate.
The philosophical underpinnings of many of the guidelines are widely held notions about the wisdom of aligning the interests of board members more closely with shareholders and otherwise making sure that boards are not too beholden to management. If there was a central message in a McKinsey & Company report from last fall that said major investors were willing to pay a premium price for companies that had good governance practices, for example, it was that directors should have a personal financial stake in running an effective board.
Like Calpers, the commission formed last year by the National Association of Corporate Directors applauded the idea of paying directors in stock.
One commission member, Charles Elson, a professor at the Stetson Law School in St. Petersburg, Fla., said stock ownership was the key to effective governance. Before Mr. Elson joined the board of the Sunbeam Corporation, the company required him to buy 5,000 shares with his own money. He now owns 9,000 shares and was traveling around Mississippi last week visiting Sunbeam plants.
"Calpers didn't tell me to do that -- my ownership led me to do that," he said. "Most of this stuff makes sense."
In the same vein, Russell S. Reynolds Jr., chairman of Directorship, attributes good corporate performance over the long term to "oversight by a board of strong, independent people truly representing the long-term interests of all the shareholders."
The kind of governance that is needed, however, is "not necessarily that dictated in the recent flurry of governance guidelines," added Mr. Reynolds, whose firm evaluates board practices and helps recruit directors.
Indeed, some of Calpers's principles and what it plans to do with them have governance experts at odds over whether they would make things better or worse.
In criticizing the proposal on age limits, Mr. Ward, editor of The Corporate Board, said that it would restrict corporate America's access to the many veteran business people who help guide fledgling companies through the difficult early years after an initial public offering.
BUT Harvey J. Goldschmid, a professor at the Columbia University Law School, said that while many directors remained effective after 70, age limits and term limits would be useful for companies that wanted some new and younger faces around the board-room table.
"It solves the etiquette problem in a relatively blunt way, but for some companies, it may be the best way," Mr. Goldschmid said. "It's difficult to tell directors they are no longer right for the job."
The Digital Equipment Corporation, for example, has come under criticism from many investors for having five directors, more than half its board, who are at least 70, and who therefore came of age professionally well before the rise of the Internet and other milestones in the computer field. Digital has called the criticism misplaced. "To criticize the effectiveness of anyone based on age is simply naive," Dan Kaferle, a Digital spokesman, said in June about the subject.
The push to put limits on the age of board members is certainly at odds with the philosophy in countries like Britain and Japan, where gray hairs are regarded as assets for directors. The Calpers plan is more in tune with foreign practices when it comes to separating the jobs of chairman and chief executive, which companies in many other countries generally do.
Ann Yerger, director of research for the Council of Institutional Investors, whose members include corporate, union and public pension funds like Calpers, predicted that some members would probably endorse all the Calpers principles. But, she added, a "fair number" of members would probably oppose at least some.
Mr. Nash, the president of the corporate directors' association, said Calpers had done a lot through the years to improve board performance, starting in the 1980's with its objections to, among other things, anti-takeover measures that protected incumbent managers and rewarded corporate raiders.
But the growing scrutiny of boards may ultimately shrink the pool of capable directors, he contended.
"Directors don't manage companies; managers manage companies," Mr. Nash said. "Good directors are tired of having their reputations maligned in the public spotlight, and good people are going to say, 'I don't need this grief.'
"I'm afraid overreaching is going to defeat the purpose," he added. "And what are the next demands? I have no idea what they may be."
For his part, Mr. Crist, the president of Calpers, defended the age-limit proposal as a way to guard against directors' growing too comfortable with one another.
"Any age is arbitrary," Mr. Crist said. "The point, if you do some historical research, is that a lot of corporate boards didn't replace members, and their members got older. It wasn't their age that was the problem, but that they had been talking to themselves for a very long time."
MR. CRIST said Calpers would be flexible when it asks companies for report cards on how they measure up to the principles. After all, Calpers itself has reasons why it does not meet all of its criteria, including the fact that some directors have served for more than 10 years. The people who make up the membership of the California Public Employees' Retirement System do not elect all its directors -- the board also includes political appointees and officers of state agencies.
"Moses didn't send these things down from the mountain, and we certainly don't expect all boards to toe the line precisely," Mr. Crist said. "There is no simple, perfect formula. We're not in a chemistry lab here making a compound."

GRAPHIC: Charts: "Uneven Practices"

"One in a Thousand"
To find out if the perfect board exists, Directorship examined large industrial and service companies to see which lived up to several of Calpers's key tests of good governance. Few did. The companies would have fared even worse had the analysis included hard-to-quantify criteria, including recommendations that independent directors meet without the the chief executive present at least once a year or have some expertise in fields like finance and international markets.
 
Out of the Fortune 1000 companies, 139 are not publicly traded, leaving 861.
 
PASSING THE TESTS
 
Of those 861, 778 pass the first test, with boards comprising a majority of outside directors.
 
Of those 778, 40 companies meet the next standard, with independent chairmen.
 
Of those 40, only one company, Texas Instruments, has five key committees -- compensation, governance, ethics, nominating and audit -- made up completely of outside directors.
 
FAILING THE TESTS
 
Of those 861, 83 have insiders who make up at least half the board.
 
And all 83 either have the same people serving as chairmen and chief executives or lack independent chairmen.
 
Of those 83, only Walt Disney has insiders on as many as four key committees -- compensation, ethics, nominating and audit.
 
(Source: Directorship)(pg. 7)

HEADLINE: Medicare Crisis Is Nearly On Hold

BYLINE: By Warren Rudman and Sam Nunn; Warren Rudman, a former Republican Senator from New Hampshire, and Sam Nunn, a former Democratic Senator from Georgia, are co-chairmen of the Concord Coalition.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For the last few days Washington has been indulging in a well-deserved round of self-congratulation over passage of the first balanced budget in three decades. After 10 years of failed deficit reduction efforts, the bill passed last week stands out as a significant bipartisan accomplishment. So why are we applauding with only one hand?
While the new balanced budget is a short-run fiscal encouragement, it fails to address the much tougher challenge waiting for us in only a decade, when the oldest members of the baby-boom generation begin signing up for Social Security, in 2008, and Medicare, in 2011. Unless we tackle this huge problem, all of the hard work to balance the budget in 2002 will be washed away in a sea of red ink. 
 The numbers are relentless. Today, the United States has about 24 million retirees. When the boomer generation is fully retired, the figure will be 48 million. But the number of working age citizens, whose payroll taxes finance most of the seniors' Social Security and Medicare benefits, will increase only 20 percent in that period. And Medicare spending per beneficiary will have continued to rise.
Well, if the balanced budget neglects the country's long-term generational challenge, how does it do in the short term?
The economy and the private sector are performing so well that revenue is pouring into the Treasury faster than politicians can claim credit for reducing the deficit. But the assumptions in the balanced budget plan mean the economy must continue performing at a strong pace. Congress, of course, can't repeal the business cycle, and the plan leaves no reserve for error.
To reach balance also requires that future Congresses and the next President live up to tough limits on discretionary spending. These ceilings have provided spending discipline for a decade. The new plan conveniently allows a $7 billion boost in the current round of appropriations bills, but the limits tighten dramatically after that. By 2002, discretionary spending will have to be reduced by 10 percent, something that sounds easier in the abstract than it will be politically, since these cuts remain unidentified.
Finally, the budget agreement will reduce Medicare reimbursements to doctors, hospitals and other health care providers by $115 billion over the next five years, which will help patch up the program's balance sheet temporarily. So will program changes that encourage beneficiaries to choose from various plans that will be offered in addition to the traditional, and expensive, fee-for-service system. But these steps, while helpful in the short term, are nowhere near enough.
The failure to respond to the long-term challenge does not mean that elected leaders are unaware of it. The Senate voted 70 to 30 in June to phase out the subsidies received by the upper-income elderly enrolled in the Part B Medicare program, which covers doctors' bills. The same day, 62 Senators voted to phase in over 30 years an increase in the Medicare eligibility age to 67 from 65, in tandem with the increase scheduled for Social Security. Both of these structural changes would help meet the long-term challenge, but, sadly, both were dropped in the final negotiations.
A bipartisan commission will be charged with reporting recommendations by March 1, 1999, on how to meet Medicare's long-term crisis. It is critical that this commission not serve as yet another excuse for delay, diversion and denial but instead call for fundamental restructuring, including means-testing, higher eligibility ages and adjustments of cost-of-living allowances. It is also important that policy makers not focus on Medicare without also considering Social Security's financing and benefit problems. The generational challenge extends well beyond Medicare and requires all of us to consider what benefits we are prepared to provide and pay for when the baby boom becomes the senior boom.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

SHAREHOLDER REVOLUTION
Sallie Mae's Management Ousted in Favor of Dissidents
In what one analyst called "the stock market equivalent of the Boston Tea Party," shareholders of the Student Loan Marketing Association ousted the management by electing a dissident slate of directors to run the company. "It's a revolution," said the analyst, Jonathan E. Gray, of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. Shareholders also overwhelmingly approved a plan to turn Sallie Mae, a Government-sponsored enterprise, into a fully private, state-chartered corporation. On the New York Stock Exchange, Sallie Mae's shares immediately surged almost $5.
 
BALANCING THE BUDGET
Is Everyone Happy?
In Washington, euphoria reigned as politicians of both parties congratulated themselves on agreeing to balance the Federal budget and to provide the first Federal tax cut in 16 years. "We have put America's fiscal house in order again," President Clinton proclaimed. Republicans, like Representative Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, hailed the agreement as the culmination of their quest to slim down Government. But economists, ever the dismal scientists, were skeptical that all would go as planned. Taxes on long-term capital gains are to be cut to a top rate of 20 percent, and eventually to 18 percent. And new rules increased the tax advantages of individual retirement accounts for millions of Americans. The package also provides child care credits, tax benefits for college students, health insurance options for the elderly, higher airline ticket taxes, lower estate taxes and higher cigarette taxes. 

THE ECONOMY
Looking Up, Looking Down
Adding to Washington's cheer was news that the economy slowed during the spring as consumers cut back on spending. The gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 2.2 percent in the April-June period, less than half that of the preceding quarter, showing no danger of inflation, even though employee compensation costs rose slightly in the spring. Sales of new single-family homes rose 6.1 percent in June, showing the housing sector entered the third quarter on a solid footing. "It's about as good as it can get for a fully employed economy," said Robert G. Dederick, economic consultant to Chicago's Northern Trust Company. But on Friday two reports revived fears of inflation. The unemployment rate dropped to a 24-year low of 4.8 percent in July, and the National Association of Purchasing Management index rose to its highest level in two and a half years, 58.6, showing expansion in manufacturing.
 
THE MARKETS
A Whiff of Inflation
After a record-setting first part of the week, inspired by the favorable economic data and the budget agreement, markets stumbled on Friday as the unemployment and purchasing managers' numbers reignited fears of inflation and higher interest rates. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond, whose lower yields have recently propelled stocks higher, sank 1 26/32, pushing its yield to 6.45 percent from Thursday's close of 6.29 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average was still up 80.60 points for the week, at 8,194.04. The Nasdaq composite rose 24.75 points, to 1,594.33.
 
CAREER MOVES
New Chief for Donna Karan; Jobs Tries Recruiting for Apple
Deciding to concentrate on her role as chief designer, Donna Karan stepped down as chief executive of her namesake company and named John Idol, right, an executive from Polo Ralph Lauren and an expert in licensing, to the post. Wall Street analysts hailed the move. Stephen L. Ruzow resigned as president of the company but will remain a consultant for six months. Attempting to restore Apple Computer to health, Steven P. Jobs, its co-founder and now an adviser to the company, has been trying to persuade Eastman Kodak's chief executive, George M. C. Fisher, to come to Apple, according to an executive who knows both men. So far, Mr. Fisher is not biting.
 
THE MERGER FRONT
Chips on the Table
Consolidation in the chip industry accelerated, as National Semiconductor agreed to acquire Cyrix in a stock swap the companies valued at $550 million, and Intel said it would acquire Chips and Technologies, a producer of graphics processing chips for personal computers, for $384 million. Fujitsu of Japan said it would pay $850 million for the 58 percent of Amdahl that it did not already own. Also, Sun Microsystems agreed to acquire Diba Inc., a start-up company that is developing technology for small communications and computing devices called information appliances. Terms were not disclosed.
 
THE DEAL FLIES
KLM to Sell Northwest Stake
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines agreed to sell its 19 percent stake in Northwest Airlines back to Northwest for more than $1 billion -- a tidy profit on an initial investment of $400 million. The two have maintained a successful operating alliance, but a two-year legal squabble over KLM's investment threatened to undermine it. Now the lawsuits are to be withdrawn, and the carriers are to expand their relationship into potentially lucrative new areas like cargo transportation and linking their computer systems.
 
SCANDAL IN JAPAN
Penalties for Nomura And a Leading Bank
Japan's Finance Ministry, in the strongest punitive action it has ever taken against major financial institutions, ordered Nomura Securities and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank to suspend part of their operations for the rest of this year as punishment for making payments and loans to a racketeer. Still, analysts said, the penalties were more lenient than expected and should not result in red ink. Illegal dealings that could undermine the market's credibility are believed to be widespread in Japan. Tokyo prosecutors raided the headquarters of Yamaichi Securities on suspicion that it, too, had made payments to the same racketeer.
 
THE SPORTS BUSINESS
G.M. Goes for Gold
Is the business of America still business, or is it sport? General Motors committed some $900 million to sponsor the Olympics through 2008 -- a wager that the next six Winter and Summer Games will continue to galvanize public interest. The deal with NBC and the United States Olympics Committee is expected to be the first of many. AT&T, Coca-Cola and Anheuser-Busch, all longtime Olympic sponsors, may well follow suit. Nor is America's obsession unique. Alan Shearer, captain of Britain's national soccer team and center forward for Newcastle United, badly tore his ankle ligament in a preseason tournament last weekend. When the London stock exchange opened for trading on Monday, $20 million disappeared from Newcastle's share valuation.

HEADLINE: The World;
The Overfed Tiger Economies

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
BY the time they make it from the airport to the hotel, first-time visitors to the "tiger economies" of Southeast Asia almost all blurt out the same question: Where did all the money come from?
In Kuala Lumpur, the Malaysians are putting the finishing touches on the world's tallest twin towers, and the national car, the Proton, competes for space with Mercedes on the streets below. Bangkok, once known as the Venice of Asia for its tree-lined canals, has filled every watery inch with concrete to support office towers that stretch into the polluted mist. Even the Philippines, once Asia's basket case, finally has its act together. 
 So the financial crisis that has shaken the region in recent weeks -- huge currency devaluations, the International Monetary Fund sweeping in to prop up the Philippines and virtually take over the central bank of Thailand -- naturally raises the question of how much of this phenomenal growth is a chimera. Are the tigers just large house cats? Have they caught Japan disease, letting their banks get ahead of their brains, lending money with abandon for multibillion-dollar projects no one needed?
 
Conspiracy, No
 And what about the weird conspiracy theories of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, who charges that speculators like George Soros used their market prowess to undermine Southeast Asia's currencies? Mr. Mahathir's complaint that Malaysia's decades of hard work were unraveled by mysterious foreign forces in "a period of weeks" prompted Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, in Kuala Lumpur last week for an annual meeting of the region's leaders, to publicly ridicule the whole notion.
"There is a search on for scapegoats," said Clyde Prestowitz, a trade expert who served on a Presidential commission appointed last year to come up with a new strategy for dealing with the region. "They were used to being the world's economic hothouse, and it's a bit of a shock when an Arctic breeze flows through the door."
Mr. Prestowitz is right: When you are accustomed to watching your economy grow at 8 percent or 10 percent a year, the prospect of mere 6 percent growth can seem like a national crisis. For all of Mr. Mahathir's squawking, his country is likely to post better than 8 percent growth this year and next -- while the quite healthy American economy, by comparison, has managed a little more than 3 percent this year.
But there are some real cracks in Southeast Asia's economic infrastructure -- cracks that investors often overlooked as they raced to grab a piece of what mutual fund hawkers enthusiastically call "the world's fastest-growing economies."
Thailand is a good place to start. The country launched its own satellites, published five-year plans, built car plants faster than it built highways and became the darling of mutual fund managers around the world. In fact, most of its mega-projects were financed with foreign money (much of it Japanese), a river of cash so wide and so deep that it covered up economic strains.
What was missing was discipline on the part of the country's politicians and financial managers. Prestige or under-the-table money governed decisions to invest in major projects, many of which added little to the nation's competitive power. After all, how many car factories does the world need?
Banks lent money on the assumption that land would only grow scarcer -- offering rationales about why they were not headed down the path of the Japanese, who made the same flawed assumption in the late 1980's and early 90's, when the land under the Imperial Palace in Tokyo was said to be worth more than the state of Florida. When investors don't blink at such comparisons, something's wrong.
In Thailand, they blinked. Speculators realized that Thailand's policy of linking its currency to the dollar and the yen -- the two forms of money with the greatest aura of stability -- was unsustainable unless the country could improve productivity, lower wages and rein in the banks and the corruption. To make their point, they started selling Thai baht, and the Government spent billions in the markets trying to fend off the attacks. Eventually the dam broke. The Thais dismissed their central bankers and, in desperation, turned to the International Monetary Fund, which has been given new authority -- and a special fund -- to solve such problems since Mexico's similar crisis in late 1994.
And like the Mexicans, they are being made an offer they can't refuse: They must cut their deficits, stop borrowing, clean up the drunken banks and reveal to the world what the country's finances really look like.
So did the speculators cause this problem, or just exacerbate it? "In almost every case," said Lawrence Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary and the man who designed the Mexican bailout, "major financial disturbances almost always have deeper causes than a few speculators. And it's important to remember that you can't attack 'speculation' without also undermining the flow of capital that can finance productive investment."
 
So Forward-Looking
 In fact, neither the Thais nor Mr. Mahathir were complaining about the cruelties of global capital markets when investors were pouring $60 billion to $70 billion a year into East Asia, roughly two-thirds of all the money invested in the developing world in the mid-90's. Then the speculators were wise investors who understood the economies of the future.
With the immediate crisis blowing over, the big question now is how the tigers claw their way past the meanest animal in the forest: China. One reason exports have slowed -- particularly of electronics, the boom industry of the region -- is that the Chinese are getting better at producing the same products at far lower costs.
"It's the same phenomenon we saw in Korea," the former South Korean foreign minister, Han Sung Joo, said in Washington last week. South Korea benefited greatly from a flood of investment in the 1980's, and the money stayed around long enough for the wealth to spread throughout the country. But the run-up in wages eventually sent investors fleeing to Southeast Asia.
Now the process is speeding up. Before the Thais had a chance to fully exploit the benefits of being a tiger, the investment money is beginning to hit the road. "The problem in Southeast Asia," said Mr. Han, "is that there is still a big gulf between the rich in the cities and the poor. The money went into the fancy hotels before it went into the factories."

HEADLINE: July 27-August 2;
Politicians Dine on the Crime Dip

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Politicians from President Clinton to Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani of New York have patted themselves on the back as Federal crime reports show that the rates of most violent crimes, like murder, are falling to their lowest levels since the early 1960's.
Now Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington, whose city has the reputation as a murder capital, says Washington is "as safe or safer" than Topeka, Kan. Last week Washington police officials reported that 149 people were slain in the first half of 1997, a 25 percent decline from 1996's midyear toll. Washington still has a higher murder rate than many other cities (like Topeka, which had 17 murders in 1996), but its drop is comparable to the decrease in homicides in New York, where murders fell by 30 percent in the first half of this year. 
 Political leaders have been quick to take credit for the falling crime rate, saying it is the result of community-based policing, tougher prison sentences and stricter gun laws. But many criminologists find the crime drop a bit mysterious, involving not only local policies but a booming economy, a decline in warfare between drug-trafficking gangs and the aging of baby boomers who are growing out of their crime-prone years. And some predict the drop may be short-lived. Why? The number of people in their teenage years will grow by one percent each year over the next decade. DAVID JOHNSTON

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Bringing Diversity to the Politics of Distrust

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
DAVID N. DINKINS lost the New York mayoralty four years ago in part because of what some people called his timorous response to a black-led boycott of a Korean-owned grocery store. So it was more than a little noteworthy when the Rev. Al Sharpton -- another black man seeking to be Mayor of New York -- showed up at a dinner of Korean-Americans the other evening to deliver a cordial if awkward talk about race and politics.
"Tonight, I'm doing a lot of reaching out," Mr. Sharpton said, leaving an untouched plate of Korean food as he took his spot at the lectern. "We must protect each other's rights and existence. The minorities of this city are together the majority of this city." 
 Mr. Sharpton's appearance at a midtown Korean restaurant suggested an unlikely development in race and politics in 1997. So did the questions posed to this familiar symbol of black activism (almost none had to do with race), and his reception afterwards (the audience clamored around him, seeking autographs and photographs). Indeed, the evening pointed up that the highest-profile urban political campaign of the year has been notable not for what it is about, but for what it is not about: Race.
It seems that racial politics, even racist politics, are not quite as simple as they once were. What had been a clear-cut matter of, well, black and white, has become staggeringly complicated since the days when Archie Bunker knew precisely where to direct his venom from his armchair in a Queens living room. It has become harder to figure out who to hate. And so it is that political candidates are finding it trickier to incorporate race into appeals for votes.
In part, this is because the edges of racial antagonisms have been blunted a bit by good economic times. But more than that, the growing diversity of the nation's cities appears to be forcing a redefinition of racism. A campaign swing with a candidate in Boston, Miami or Los Angeles these days can seem like a trip around the world.
Take New York, the city that most scholars view as the best example of Archie Bunker's changing universe. In 1970, whites made up 63 percent of New York's population and blacks 20 percent, and the city's unpleasant racial dynamics reflected that. The remaining 17 percent were mostly Hispanic (Asians were barely 1 percent).
But by the year 2000, the city's Planning Department projects, non-Hispanic whites will be just 35 percent of New Yorkers and blacks 26 percent. The remaining 39 percent -- though many are not citizens, and thus not voters -- are Chinese, Dominicans, Ecuadorans, Cubans, Mexicans, Indians, Salvadorans and Peruvians (to mention a few). Mr. Sharpton's recent electoral target, Koreans, tripled as a proportion of the city's population from 1980 to 1990, and now make up a full 1 percent.
 
Pandering Gets Tough
 What that means is that racial appeals -- benign ones encouraging ethnic identity and malignant ones tapping into racism -- are not so easy anymore. First, it's hard to figure which group to pander to in cities where there is no such thing as an ethnic majority.
Most intriguing is what this means for the coarser form of racial appeal. There have always been coded ways in which candidates have exploited prejudices, but these tactics have become trickier in more complicated electoral landscapes.
What, after all, is the difference between appealing to racial animosities, which is often effective, and to anti-immigrant feelings, which might be politically ruinous in many cities? It's a critical difference, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has demonstrated by portraying himself as an advocate for immigrants.
Of course, none of this is meant to suggest that America has reached the mountaintop; it would be quite a stretch to suggest that big cities are on the threshold of racial peace. Tom Hayden did call Mayor Richard J. Riordan of Los Angeles a racist in the final heated days of his very losing campaign, and he went on to win the city's black votes by a three-to-one margin. A New York Times poll in the spring found that black and white New Yorkers held opposite views on nearly every major issue. The two groups couldn't even agree about the quality of the city's water.
Indeed, the animosities between ethnic groups are arguably not so much gone as more diffuse. Blacks marched on Koreatown during the 1992 riots in Los Angeles. And in New York, Mr. Sharpton is extraordinarily unpopular among Hispanic people.
"I was in Bay Ridge and I heard an Italian woman cursing the influx of Arabs in a once-Italian neighborhood," said Mitchell Moss, the director of New York University's Urban Research Center. "Southern Brooklyn is becoming Asian and Arab. The old Italian neighborhoods are vanishing. That's discombobulating people."
There are some circumstances in this year's elections that contribute to a sense of racial equanimity. Mr. Sharpton is a long-shot candidate, and the final lineup in New York's race is expected to be, as in Los Angeles, white versus white. "There are no minority folks running for citywide office," Mr. Dinkins says by way of an explanation.
Mr. Dinkins also says race is being ignored because the news media have failed to give racial injustices the attention they warrant. But Ruth W. Messinger, the leading candidate for the Democratic mayoral nomination, has also avoided such subjects.
And it's not a surprise. After all, when Mr. Hayden accused Mr. Riordan of racism, he triggered a furor so intense he was forced to apologize. Mr. Riordan then trounced his Democratic opponent, in no small part because of the emergence of a new center of power in that city's politics. For the first time, Hispanic voters outnumbered blacks. They took a liking to Mr. Riordan.
