HEADLINE: The Nation;
Clinton Sees History in the Budget-Making . . .

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN the wake of the final budget deal, Washington talk was as thick last week with the word "historic" as with such staples as "bipartisanship" and "campaign reform."
President Clinton plainly hopes that a deal to balance the budget will get him into the history books. Dick Morris, his former adviser, tells us that just a year ago, this very item was number two on a list of four major items he told the President he needed to insure a high ranking in posterity. Mr. Clinton's brief remarks announcing the agreement on Tuesday, with three "historics," four "futures" and three "generations" in a few minutes, shows the lesson took. 
 Some professional President-judgers think the plan will work. Richard Norton Smith, a biographer of one President, Herbert W. Hoover, one losing candidate, Thomas E. Dewey, and Col. Robert R. McCormick, the publisher of The Chicago Tribune "who thought he was more important than any President," offered encouragement.
Mr. Smith said Mr. Clinton might succeed where Jimmy Carter failed, in being "remembered as the first Democratic President who realized that the New Deal was over" and moved the party with him. "If he can equate the Democratic Party with economic prosperity," he said, "then he will have completed the work that Jimmy Carter began a generation ago."
 
Captives of Their Times
 But more historians had their doubts. Robert V. Remini, biographer of Presidents Martin van Buren and Andrew Jackson (and the disappointed candidates Henry Clay and Daniel Webster), said that most Presidents worry about their place in history, but that "sometimes there is really nothing they can do because the times are not conducive to great actions and great decisions and great results."
Jackson, Mr. Remini noted, "was the only President who ever eliminated the national debt, and he got very little credit for it." And while balancing the budget was certainly important, he said, it did not really count as a great issue.
"There is one, and that is the race question," he said, which Mr. Clinton has talked about earnestly but does not seem to be solving.
The same thought, more bluntly, came from Robert A. Caro, Lyndon B. Johnson's biographer, who recalled Johnson's great speech in the House chamber proposing the 1965 Voting Rights Act. " 'Balance the budget' doesn't have the same ring as 'We shall overcome,' " he said.
Another critical voice was offered by John Kenneth Galbraith, an ally of President John F. Kennedy and a liberal economist and economic historian. He said balanced budgets were not necessarily a good idea because supporting a balanced budget was usually a device of "people who are seeking to reduce the social role of the state." He said, "You never hear a balanced budget advanced when defense is at stake."
Nathan Miller, a biographer of both Roosevelts, was skeptical both of the significance of balancing the budget and of it being a lasting achievement. "His accomplishment may not outlast his term," he said. "These things are usually done with smoke and mirrors." But he said he had not included Mr. Clinton among the subjects of his next book, "Star-Spangled Men: America's Ten Worst Presidents."
 
Balancing Act
 That uncertainty was also conveyed by Robert Dallek, a Johnson biographer, who said that balancing the budget was not only not "terribly sexy," but that its impact was uncertain. "If we get through the next 10 or 15 years with terrific growth," he said, prosperity might make Mr. Clinton's reputation. But, he observed, "That's pretty dicey."
Even if few Presidents have been remembered for prosperity (as Mr. Morris said he warned Mr. Clinton), Douglas Brinkley, who is finishing a Carter biography, said, "I can't imagine people bemoaning the Clinton years.
"He redirected the Democratic Party," Mr. Brinkley said, and also redesigned himself from a first-term "policy wonk" into someone who judged well where America wanted to be. His biggest problem, he said, was that "more than anything else, Clinton is trying to not be Warren Harding, where scandals overtake a legacy."
If the President is fortunate, Mr. Brinkley said, his legacy would amount to "good government, political shrewdness, warding off the Republican right and overseeing economic prosperity."
But the historians all observed that Presidential reputations are exercises in constant renovation. Mr. Dallek quoted the Dutch historian Pieter Geyl as saying, "History is indeed an argument without end."
Mr. Clinton, who will be 53 as he leaves office, may get a better sense of that than most Presidents. Mr. Smith said, "He's going to live long enough to see his reputation on a roller coaster."

HEADLINE: Fake Licenses Tied to Bribes In California

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 2

 BODY:
Investigators say the quest for a counterfeit-proof driver's license has spurred a black market in which state workers issue fraudulent licenses in return for bribes of $200 to $1,000 each.
The California Department of Motor Vehicles fears that at least 25,000 fraudulently issued licenses are on the street. Seventy-nine employees have been dismissed in the last 19 months, and investigators estimate that 250 of the department's 8,000 employees may be involved in the scam. 
 The California driver's license, held by 20.2 million motorists, is a basic identification document and gives people access to other forms of identification. Licenses are used as proof of identity for everything from welfare applications to bank accounts.
The California card incorporates numerous anti-counterfeit safeguards, including holographic images, coding and layering, to make it all but impossible to duplicate.
But the increased difficulty of counterfeiting licenses means that people unable to obtain them legitimately, including undocumented immigrants and people with revoked licenses, try to buy them by bribing clerks.
"Ironically, as our documents become more tamper-proof, it's become more of a problem," said the Director of the Department of Motor Vehicles, Sally Reed.
The California department's investigation has led to the dismissal of 24 clerks since May, most of them for driver's license or registration fraud. Six others have been disciplined.
An additional 55 clerks were dismissed after investigations dating to January 1996 into similar activities. At least two prison terms have been meted out -- a three-year sentence in one case and a one-year term in another, said a department spokesman, Bill Gengler.
California officials say they do not know whether other states are seeing a similar increase in internal fraud. But many other states are introducing anti-counterfeit measures on the licenses they issue, and California investigators say that is the driving force behind the increased fraud here.

HEADLINE: Survey Ranks Nigeria as Most Corrupt Nation

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
For the second year running, a survey of executives and public opinion worldwide has found that Nigeria tops the list of the most corrupt countries to do business, an independent monitoring organization said in a report last week.
The third Corruption Perception Index issued by the organization, Transparency International, listed Denmark as the least corrupt place to do business. The United States was ranked the 16th-cleanest country among the 52 nations surveyed for the 1997 report. 
 Introducing this year's survey, Dr. Peter Eigen, a former World Bank official who is chairman of Transparency International, said his five-year-old organization "is not saying in this index that one country is more corrupt than another."
"We are reporting how business people around the globe perceive levels of corruption," he said.
The compilers of the survey acknowledge that some of their information comes from companies involved in corrupt practices. Some are large international corporations frequently criticized by developing nations for indulging or acquiescing in practices that the companies and their governments then condemn.
Over the last few years, corruption has become a much more public issue as international aid organizations, like the United Nations Development Program and the World Bank, have warned developing nations that bad reputations are costing them needed investment.
In a period of shrinking foreign aid, governments are also under pressure to withhold or reduce assistance because of the perception that a considerable part of the money spent is wasted on bribes and kickbacks.
In May, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, representing the world's industrial nations, asked its members to agree this year to pass laws against corrupt practices and to put an end to tax deductibility for bribes paid in business transactions.
Frank Vogl, vice chairman of Transparency International, said in an interview on Thursday that the founders of the organization have been surprised by the chord that their message has struck in many capitals, including in the third world.
Transparency International has chapters in more than 70 countries and its headquarters in Berlin. It compiles its annual list using information gathered from its own Internet network and from studies made by major polling or risk-analysis organizations -- including Gallup International, the Political and Economic Risk Consultancy of Hong Kong and the DRI/McGraw-Hill Global Risk Service.
The list, which is drawn up under the direction of Dr. Johann Graf Lambsdorff, an economist at Gottingen University in Germany, sets 10 as the cleanest score and 0 as the most corrupt. Nations are arrayed on the scale after information from four or more sources is averaged.
Nigeria scored a 1.76 this year, substantially lower than the next country most frequently cited for corruption, Bolivia, at 2.05. Other countries scoring under 3 were Colombia, Russia, Pakistan, Mexico, Indonesia, India, Venezuela and Vietnam.
At the top of the scale after Denmark, with a 9.94 score, business leaders consider Finland, Sweden, New Zealand, Canada and the Netherlands -- all with scores over 9 -- the least corrupt countries. Among other countries that scored higher than the United States, with a 7.61 rating, were Singapore, Ireland and Israel.
The Transparency International list is limited to 52 countries because the compilers do not have enough sources of information to make a fair judgment on other nations, Dr. Lambsdorff said in a statement accompanying the report.
At the Nigerian Embassy in Washington, Patrick Ayendi, the information attache, said that the perception of Nigeria as corrupt was no longer based on fact.
"I can tell you very categorically that the present regime in Nigeria has fought corruption down to its barest minimum," he said. "At Government level, if any official is found to be corrupt in Nigeria, you are not only relieved of your duties, you are also prosecuted."
He said the Government welcomed cooperation from other nations where accusations of corruption against Nigerians arise.

HEADLINE: 35 Communities Are Eligible for Loans Under Nafta Program

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, accused of not doing enough to deal with job losses caused by increased competition from Canada and Mexico under the North American Free Trade Agreement, has released a list of 35 communities in 19 states that will be eligible for economic development loans.
A group of Hispanic members of Congress said last month that the Administration was dragging its feet in carrying out the loan program. No loans have been approved even though the trade agreement took effect more than three years ago. 
 Businesses in the designated areas, which include Syracuse and Fulton, N.Y.; Elizabeth, N.J., and Dayville, Conn., will be able to apply for loans and loan guarantees administered through the North American Development Bank. Treasury officials said more communities would be added in coming months.
The $3 billion bank was set up by Congress in 1993 as part of the legislation that created Nafta. It is supposed to provide loans for environmental cleanup projects along the United States' border with Mexico and support economic development in cities hit hard by job losses caused by increased competition from Mexico and Canada.
In a letter sent last month to President Clinton, a group of Hispanic lawmakers threatened to withhold support for the Administration's efforts to expand Nafta to other Latin American countries unless more was done to help displaced American workers.
Representative Esteban Torres, Democrat of California, one of the main sponsors of the development bank in 1993, said on Friday that he was disappointed that more areas were not included on the initial list, given that the Labor Department had certified job losses from Nafta in virtually every state.
"This is an answer to some of the criticism we raised, but much remains to be done," Mr. Torres said in an interview. "There is still a long way to go."
The trade agreement over all has bolstered the United States economy through increased exports to Mexico and Canada, but care must be taken to deal with workers who have lost jobs, Administration officials said.
"While Nafta has benefited the U.S. economy as a whole, we are committed to insuring that capital is available to create new job opportunities where they are most needed," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said in a statement.
The loans and loan guarantees will go to businesses to support jobs in the designated areas.
The economic development office of the North American Development Bank is in Los Angeles, but officials said businesses could also apply through their local Small Business Administration or the Agriculture Department.
Following are the 31 other communities declared eligible by the Treasury Department for business loans under the program:
Ketchikan, Alaska; Blytheville, Des Arc and Pocahontas, Ark.; Pacoima, Santa Ana and Watsonville, Calif.; Dawson and Vidalia, Ga.; Hayden Lake, Idaho; Monon, Ind.; Coushatta, La., and White Pine, Mich.
Also, St. Joseph, Mo.; Chocowinity, Laurinburg, Lumberton, Rocky Mount, Tarboro and Washington, N.C.; Greenfield, Ohio; Erie and Lewistown, Pa.; Celina, Tenn.; Brownsville, El Paso and Robstown, Tex.; Centralia and Richland, Wash., and Hawkins and Racine, Wis.

HEADLINE: In America;
Brick By Brick

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT; William Safire is on vacation.

 BODY:
There was a time, not long ago, when the Bronx would set itself on fire every night. Darkness would fall and entire sections of the borough seemed to go up in flames. A national audience once watched this phenomenon on television, when the Yankees were in the World Series. Off in the distance, beyond the lights of the stadium, the flames from several fires could be seen licking at the sky. Howard Cosell provided the commentary.
The fires combined with a hideous array of less-spectacular problems to reduce vast acres of the Bronx to ruins. In 1990, even as jokesters were quipping that there was nothing left to burn, a fire at the Happy Land Social Club in the East Tremont section killed an astonishing 87 people. 
 To most observers, the Bronx was a twisted and ghastly place, the quintessential example of all that was wrong with America's cities. Novelists, movie makers, journalists and national politicians in search of urban desolation all headed for the Bronx.
That was then. If you care to hop a northbound subway now you will find in the Bronx a great deal of evidence that devastated inner-city neighborhoods can be reborn. It is a slow and complicated process that doesn't readily lend itself to a novel or a screenplay, but it is happening.
A few days ago I spoke with a longtime resident named Sharon Jacobs. We were standing in the air-conditioned hallway of a renovated apartment building two blocks from the site of the Happy Land fire. The hallway was well lit and smelled of fresh paint.
"This building was always dark and the drug dealers lived right there," Ms. Jacobs said, pointing down the hall. "It was like people from the street just came in and took over, like it was their building. Squatters, drug dealers. It was very dangerous. You can see how it's changed."
The building, on Southern Boulevard, is one of several blighted residential and commercial structures that have been transformed by the Aquinas Housing Corporation, a nonprofit group that has been one of the many participants in the heroic fight to reverse the decline of neighborhoods across the Bronx.
Similar efforts are under way in cities around the country and many are very successful. But they don't get a lot of attention. Newspaper editors and television producers develop nervous tics and extended fits of yawning when reporters try to explain the importance of C.D.C.'s (community development corporations, of which Aquinas is one), supportive housing, creative mortgage financing and low-income tax credits. Careers have been derailed at the mere mention of the word "urban."
So you won't hear much about a group like Aquinas reclaiming a neighborhood with fresh housing, services for the homeless and the elderly, recreation programs for children and employment training for able-bodied adults. And yet its work, and that of thousands of similarly unheralded groups, is one of the key reasons for the improving health of cities.
Aquinas is one of about 700 nonprofit neighborhood groups supported by the Enterprise Foundation, which was established in 1982 to help local organizations create affordable housing. The sustaining idea of the foundation is that the availability of decent housing is essential if low-income people are to become self-sufficient. It is very hard to do great things if your mailing address is a broken-down park bench.
What has been happening around the country is that C.D.C.'s, some affiliated with Enterprise and some not, are using the cornerstone of affordable housing as a way of reclaiming one blighted neighborhood after another. These are for the most part well-planned and financially rigorous ventures that use the expertise of both public and private organizations. The Enterprise Foundation alone has raised more than $2 billion in low-interest loans, grants and equity investments for such projects.
"It is important to show that these successes can occur and that they can be replicated," said William Frey, director of Enterprise's New York office. He noted that attitudes toward big-city neighborhoods change as the housing improves, homeownership expands, crime and other problems diminish, and new stores and churches begin to be built.
That is what is happening now. Eventually, even television will notice.

HEADLINE: Lonely Song of a Chinese Minstrel Bares a Migrant's Lament

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: HAIKOU, China, July 28

 BODY:
Over the clatter of Chinese meal-making in the outdoor food stalls that overflow with diners on a hot summer evening, Shen Ping sings with a lonely voice.
A long-faced young woman with wide eyes, Ms. Shen wanders with a friend from one stall to the next through a back alley in this southern city, offering to strum her guitar for any customer willing to throw a dollar her way. 
 Stopping beside a low-lying table piled high with dishes and surrounded by six men on small wooden stools, Ms. Shen and her partner sing a duet earnestly, if a little off-key. It is a sentimental love song, something about being far from home, which is apt enough for the two young women, since they are migrants.
Hundreds of thousands of outsiders looking for easy money have flocked to this part of Hainan Island, touted as China's Hawaii by development-hungry local officials. Most of them, like Ms. Shen and her friend, Lan Feng, have to settle for something less.
A leader in free-wheeling economic reforms, Hainan, off China's southern coast, rode a real-estate boom in 1990-1992, only to suffer badly from a crash in 1993. Thousands of half-built hotels lie vacant, like ghosts of another era.
But young people like Ms. Shen still pour into Hainan because, even with a downturn, China's coastal areas offer more opportunity than most of the slower-growing interior.
"Mainlanders do the kind of jobs that locals would never want," said Hong Yansheng, a food stall manager, referring to the migrants. "A local resident would never sing for money. You lose too much face."
In many nations, immigrants often do the kind of work that native-born residents look down on. In China, migrants from other parts of the country play that role, on an enormous scale.
More than 100 million of China's 1.2 billion people are estimated to be on the move, leaving their homes to look for work elsewhere. This floating population is causing an enormous but largely unmeasured social upheaval across the country.
When Ms. Shen, 23, left her village in Anhui province four months ago, she came to Hainan because a friend told her she could easily find a job in a hotel. But Ms. Shen found that one hotel after another would only offer work in a massage parlor, which she declined to do.
Instead, she bought a guitar and teamed up with Ms. Lan.
"I get tired of the men who pinch my rear end, but I can always walk away," said Ms. Shen.
Ms. Shen said she made about $25 to $35 a night, more than 10 times what she made working as a store clerk in her hometown. She sends $50 home to her parents each month, but will not tell them the truth about how she earns her living.
"They think it's bad for a girl to work on the street," she said. "I tell them I am an attendant in a hotel."
At another food stall, a diner who was red-faced from beer-drinking called Ms. Shen and her partner over to play.
"Where are you from, little sister?" he asked.
Ms. Shen eyed him warily, and did not answer. Instead she asked if he had any requests.
"As you like," said the man. "Sing a beautiful one."
Ms. Shen had hardly begun her song when the man waved her off.
"That's terrible!" he said loudly. "Sing another!"
Letting her finish this time, the man reluctantly gave Ms. Shen the equivalent of $1.25. She and Ms. Lan headed for the next stall.

HEADLINE: Some in Latin America Fear End of U.S. Ban Will Stir Arms Race

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The armed forces of Latin America celebrated the Clinton Administration's decision on Friday to permit the sale of advanced weapons that were restricted for decades. But many other government officials and military analysts expressed concern today that the move could set off a regional arms race in which countries feel under pressure to buy sophisticated weapons they neither need nor can afford.
"It's a matter of keeping up with the Joneses," said a senior Argentine military official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "If these new weapons become available and your neighbor acquires them, no one in your house is going to sleep well at night unless you get the same level of security." 
 Argentina initially opposed a relaxation in the United States ban, saying sharp budget cutbacks had reduced its ability to pay for advanced weapons. But Argentine military officials said today that the lifting of the ban would only strengthen their argument that after years of reductions they need a major increase in weapons spending to remain competitive.
In Chile, Argentina's cash-rich neighbor to the west, military officials were said to be elated over the removal of the weapons ban, especially since the decision comes at a time when the air force plans to spend $400 million this year to buy about two dozen new jet fighters.
Chile had considered buying Swedish JAS-39 Grippen and French Mirage 2000-5 fighters, but military officials there have said they would prefer American-made F-16's.
Indeed, the Lockheed Martin Corporation, an American contractor that makes the F-16, had lobbied heavily for the Administration to lift the ban, particularly because Chile was about to close the bidding process to supply its new fighter planes.
"This is certainly great news for the purchaser, and the Chilean Air Force must be on top of the moon with this news," Raul Sohr, an independent military analyst, said in a telephone interview from Santiago, Chile. "But personally, I find it a bit distressing that the States is putting an end to a policy that has served this region so well for decades. This is the beginning of an arms race. There's no denying that."
Mr. Sohr said that although both Argentina and Brazil have reduced military spending in recent years, he expected them to come up with the money for the advanced planes, radars, tanks and other weapons that the United States is now making available.
"The reasons for lifting this ban are purely commercial and political," Mr. Sohr added. "The United States wants the economic benefit of selling these weapons and also the political influence that goes along with servicing and supplying them."
Some experts cited Peru's recent purchase of a squadron of Russian MIG-29's at an estimated cost of $350 million as a factor in persuading the Administration to lift the ban, which was imposed by President Carter in 1978, when many Latin American nations were under military dictatorships.
In Argentina, Horacio Jaunarena, an opposition congressman and a former Defense Minister, said he believed that selling such advanced weapons to Latin America would result in an arms buildup.
"To avoid an arms race, the effort has to come from the countries that are selling the weapons," he said. "But I understand that United States citizens are asking themselves, why don't we sell arms when other countries like Russia, Belgium or Germany are doing it."

HEADLINE: A Tax Cut Your Lawyer Will Love

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Investors, students and families with children are not the only people who will benefit from the first major Federal income tax cut in 16 years. Accountants, lawyers, tax preparers and publishers of tax books and software also expect to put a lot of money into their pockets, from people paying them to learn how to take advantage of the tax breaks.
The tax bill newly passed by Congress adds "a nightmare of complexity" to existing law, said Verenda Smith, a spokeswoman for the Federation of Tax Administrators, the association of state tax agencies. 
 Patrick Fleenor, an economist at the Tax Foundation, a research organization in Washington, said, "This tax bill is a gift to the middle class, but it's also a gift to the lawyers and accountants who will do a lot of business helping take advantage of it."
And Doug Ammerman, partner in charge of financial planning at the accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick, said that "the complexity in this tax bill is across the board, not just in one area."
For those who prepare their own tax returns and want to take advantage of the breaks, doing so will mean more hours of work.
The 51 pages of instructions that the Internal Revenue Service wrapped around Form 1040 this year will grow a little for 1997 returns, and probably increase to more than 60 pages by the time the 1998 forms are mailed in January 1999, said Clint Stretch, director of tax legislative affairs for the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche.
Some instructions will have to be revised annually, Mr. Stretch added, because a number of changes are being phased in over a period of years.
The Form 1040 itself, already tightly packed with detail, will have to be revised to take account of the $500-a-child credit and the college tuition credit, and to track money flowing through the new, nondeductible Super I.R.A.'s, from which all earnings can be withdrawn tax free at the age of 59 1/2.
Mr. Stretch and others said that there was not enough room to fit all the information onto the existing Form 1040 and that the I.R.S. would therefore probably create new schedules, which must be attached to the basic form, and additional work sheets so that only one or two new lines would be squeezed onto the 1040.
Schedule D, which is used to report capital gains, will have to be revised -- in keeping with a variety of tax rates that will apply, depending on how long the asset was held before sale -- and then revised again in coming years.
Mr. Ammerman, of KPMG Peat Marwick, said that by lowering capital gains rates while maintaining existing tax rates for other income, the new law would encourage schemes to turn ordinary income into capital gains.
"And that will spawn tax controversies," he said, "and the litigation will mean more regulations."
Intuit Inc., which publishes the Turbotax and Macintax software programs popular with individual taxpayers, sees opportunity in the need for pages of new instructions, new forms and complex calculations.
"Any time there is tax legislation our sales spike, because people fear changes in the tax law," said Bob Meighan, vice president of Intuit's personal tax group.
Intuit will seek new customers, Mr. Meighan said, by emphasizing how its software will simplify the complex calculations that the new law will require.
CCH, the nation's largest publisher of tax information, said no vacations would be allowed this month for 60 of its tax lawyers, who have been told that they will have to work through the weekends to update its books and manuals within 30 days of the bill's becoming law.
CCH expects to mail 8,500 new pages for clients to insert into its Federal Tax Service, an 18-volume loose-leaf guide for accountants that already runs 35,000 pages. Simply inserting the new pages will mean labor costs for its clients totaling about $59 million, figures from CCH show.
"Every time there is this kind of major tax change the tax professionals benefit more than anyone else, and we as publishers get a trickle-down benefit," said Arthur Rosano, director of marketing for CCH's tax compliance software, which is widely used by accountants.
Mr. Stretch, of Deloitte & Touche, said exceptionally complicated calculations would be required of the working poor who have more than two children and want to qualify for the earned-income tax credit.
"This is so difficult," Mr. Stretch said. "And people who are affected are not sophisticated about taxes. So maybe we will end up with court-appointed tax preparers to help the poor."
Michael Graetz, a professor of tax law at Yale who was a tax policy official in the Bush Administration, said he had slogged through the eligibility calculations for the earned-income tax credit and was "still not sure I understand them."
Professor Graetz said one outcome of this complexity might be that fewer of the working poor would take advantage of the credit.
The changes in the estate tax can save heirs several hundred thousand dollars, but they too come at a price, although a relatively small one.
"Everyone who owns a small business will need to rewrite their wills to make sure that their asset division between spouses" takes advantage of the new law, Professor Graetz said.
Tax simplicity, long promised by Republicans and championed by Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, has nothing to do with this bill, observed Chris Burgin, the editor of the weekly magazine Tax Notes, which, to track the bill, has added between 25 and 50 pages to its usual 120 for the last six months.
"Ever since Bill Archer said he was going to tear the income tax out by its roots," Mr. Burgin said, "he has been fertilizing the tax code."
Mr. Burgin said the tax breaks for college educations would prove especially vexing for taxpayers.
"President Clinton said that the era of big government is over," he recalled. "But because we are financing breaks for college students through the tax code instead of the spending side, this bill will mean more regulations and more complexity. And that means more big government."
J. D. Foster, executive director of the Tax Foundation, said:
"The 1986 Tax Reform Act was designed to make things simple for individuals, but it was hell for corporations. The 1997 tax act makes things a lot simpler for corporations after a one-time transition, but for individuals it is hell -- although a voluntary hell, if they want to take advantage of its goodies -- because they will have to do a lot of work or pay financial planners and accountants and lawyers.
"The goodies are so good, though, that people will complain all the way to the bank."

HEADLINE: Target of Twin Broadsides on Corruption and Bombing, Arafat Goes to See Mubarak

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Under fire from other Palestinians as well as from the Israeli Government, Yasir Arafat traveled to Egypt today to seek Arab backing against what he called "the dangerous measures" taken by Israel since a devastating suicide bombing Wednesday.
Israel has not yet carried out the most drastic steps threatened in response to the attack. But it has suspended plans for peace talks with the Palestinian Authority, arrested scores of people and demanded that Mr. Arafat, the Palestinian leader, crack down on militants -- even that he arrest his police chief in connection with a separate incident. 
 At a time when Mr. Arafat is also facing troubles over accusations of government corruption, his visit today to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt was a quest for both support and redemption. Mr. Arafat has accused Israel of using the suicide bombing "to declare war on the Palestinian people, their national authority and their leadership, instead of declaring it against terrorism."
On Friday night, all but two of Mr. Arafat's 18 ministers offered to resign, saying they hoped that step would help him address the widening Palestinian resentment toward a government accused of mismanagement and financial improprieties. Most said, though, that they expected to remain at work in the weeks ahead as Mr. Arafat and his team struggle to cope with the crisis caused by the bombing, which has been attributed to Islamic militants.
Mr. Arafat has also called for the personal intervention of President Clinton to rescue the quest for a broader peace. The President's help has become "necessary in the current circumstances more than any other time before," he said.
Even before Mr. Arafat departed, Israel's Foreign Minister, David Levy, had dispatched official notes to his counterparts in Egypt, the European Community and the United States, urging that they press Mr. Arafat to crack down on militants.
The Israeli radio reported that Mr. Levy had complained to Foreign Minister Amr Moussa of Egypt about the lack of security cooperation between Israeli and Palestinian forces, calling it one of the factors that led to the bombing last week. Thirteen Israelis were killed, as well as the two bomb-laden men who committed suicide in the attack on a crowded Jerusalem produce market.
Videotape of some of the 79 arrests made by Israel in the two days after the attack has shown officers blindfolding Palestinian suspects and tying their hands behind their backs, then shepherding them into vans.
But to the evident frustration of Israeli officials, the attackers have not yet been identified. A spokesman for the Israeli Defense Force said this afternoon that no arrests had been made in connection with the bombing in the last 24 hours.
A pair of leaflets issued in the name of the militant Islamic group Hamas praised suicide attacks as the best tactic with which to confront Israel. One, issued Wednesday, warned of unspecified further action if Israel did not release Palestinian prisoners by 9 P.M. Sunday.
Israeli officials say that Hamas was responsible for the attack but that they are not yet certain that either leaflet was authentic. Nevertheless, Israel announced today that it was stepping up security all over the country.
An Israeli police spokeswoman said the warning in the leaflets of further action after 9 P.M. Sunday had been among the factors that had persuaded the authorities to bolster their security presence.
Mr. Netanyahu accused Mr. Arafat of doing precious little to halt such attacks, and Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai declared in a television interview Friday night that the Palestinians "need to meet their basic commitment to fight terror." Mr. Mordechai said Palestinian forces had begun to crack down to a certain extent but not yet with "full intensity."
In response, Saeb Erekat, a top Palestinian peace negotiator, said Friday night of Mr. Netanyahu, "Instead of declaring war on the enemies of peace, he has declared a war against the Palestinian people and the Palestinian Authority."
The Mubarak-Arafat meeting took place at the Egyptian leader's private residence near the Mediterranean coastal city of Alexandria. Mr. Mubarak, whose Government has played an important mediating role between the Israelis and the Palestinians, did not speak to reporters either beforehand or afterward. But an announcment on Egypt's state television, which almost always reflects Government policy, seemed to echo Mr. Arafat's critical language.
According to the announcement, the two Arab leaders "discussed the latest developments and the crisis that the peace process is going through, particularly after the dangerous decisions issued by the Israeli Cabinet in the wake of the explosions that took place in West Jerusalem."
In addition to making the arrests and halting plans for peace talks, Israel has sealed off the West Bank and Gaza Strip, threatening to send Israeli commandos into Palestinian-controlled areas to seize suspects.
On Thursday night, it also issued an arrest warrant for Gen. Ghazi Jabali, the Palestinian police chief for Gaza and the West Bank. General Jabali was not accused of involvement in the suicide bombings, the Government said in a statement, but of encouraging attacks on Jewish settlements. Israeli officials have said the general will be arrested if he enters Israeli territory, as he must if he is to travel from his headquarters in Gaza to perform his duties in the West Bank.
For several years, Israeli forces have generally respected Palestinian authority, and either the arrest of General Jabali or an incursion into Palestinian territory could bring about an utter collapse in relations between the two sides.
A planned trip to the Middle East by Dennis Ross, the American special mediator, was postponed after the bombing Wednesday, but Mr. Clinton said Friday that Mr. Ross would visit soon after Israel's weeklong period of mourning was over. He also held out the prospect that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright would make her first trip to the Middle East since taking office.
But so far he has proposed nothing on the order of the summit meeting that the United States organized in the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheik in March 1996. A series of suicide bomb attacks in Israel brought leaders of some two dozen countries together there.
Today, the only clash between Israelis and Palestinians took place outside the site known as Rachel's Tomb in Bethlehem, where a Palestinian woman was arrested after reportedly trying to stab an Israeli soldier. The Israeli Defense Forces spokesman who reported the attack said the soldier had not been wounded.
Late Friday night, some of the Palestinian ministers who had offered their resignations suggested that they had been motivated by a desire to allow Mr. Arafat greater freedom in responding to the security crisis.
But ministers interviewed at greater length today made plain that they had been responding instead to criticism of governmental misconduct. This included a nonbinding but overwhelming 56-to-1 vote Thursday in the elected Palestinian Legislative Council giving Mr. Arafat one month to replace his cabinet.
"We really felt that the change was demanded and requested by the representatives of the people," Riad Zanoon, the minister of health, said in a telephone interview. Mr. Arafat has given no public hint of whether he will accept the resignations. Mr. Zanoon and others said Mr. Arafat had indicated that he would almost certainly postpone any decisions.
Mr. Arafat appeared to confirm that as he returned to Gaza today.
"There is still a long period," he said.
Among the cabinet members, only the planning minister, Nabil Shaath, and the information minister, Yasir Abed Rabbo, did not offer to resign. Mr. Rabbo dismissed the actions as "theatrical."
But those who did extend the offer included such well-known figures as Hanan Ashrawi, the minister for higher education, who said of Mr. Arafat in an interview that it was important "to free his hand so he can take the necessary decisions."
The most damning of the recent charges against the Palestinian Authority were contained in a report by a panel of the Palestinian Legislative Council. It included allegations of corruption and misuse of funds.
The evidence of apparent official corruption and mismanagement has added to resentment felt by Palestinians, many of whom suffer economic hardship. It has also embarrassed Mr. Arafat among donors, including the European Union and the United States, which have disbursed some $1.5 billion since the Palestinians reached a first accord with Israel in 1993.
Among Palestinians living in the West Bank and Gaza, there was praise for the ministers' offer to resign, mixed with skepticism. A Reuters dispatch quoted a Ramallah man, Yakub Jaarah, 60, as saying, "They are like thieves, and changing them would be very useful, but I do not believe that Arafat will replace them."

HEADLINE: YACHT RACING;
A Permanent Bond To the America's Cup

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

DATELINE: NEWPORT, R.I.

 BODY:
It was an indelible introduction to the America's Cup for Don Smith, the chief benefactor in the New York Yacht Club's current effort to win back its revered old mug.
He is 52 now, a wealthy entrepreneur in alternative energy from Oklahoma City. But Smith was an impressionable senior at a private high school in Providence, R.I., when he had his first brush with the cup. 
 "I was wearing Bermudas and knee socks," he recalled of the memorable moment in 1962, "dressed in a way that would seem pretentious in those days. And I walked out on the dock at Bannister's Wharf here in Newport. A man with a badge and white shirt stopped me, and said, 'What are you doing here?'
"And I said, 'Why are you here, sir?' And he said, 'Because President Kennedy is coming over to view the yachts.' And I said, 'Well, that's good, let me through.' "
It was a defining moment, similar in its scope to President Clinton's chance encounter as a youth with President Kennedy. But instead of the politics that drew young Clinton, Smith bonded to the America's Cup.
But it wasn't until the summer of 1996 that Smith became a member of the New York Yacht Club. For one whose membership is still green, Smith has become a major player by way of funding -- as much as $4 million worth of cash and gear so far. New York's vehicle for trying to win the 146-year-old trophy from New Zealand in the year 2000 is the syndicate Young America, which has so far raised about one-third of its $40 million budget. Of the $20 million it hopes to find from private sources, about half has been pledged, including Smith's donation.
"It's an outrageous amount of money," he said of the costs of a cup campaign. "There's no way one can justify it from a social point of view that spending this much money is right for society. The only way we can justify it is through the pursuit of excellence, and magnificence, as a symbol of success. The America's Cup has always, always been won on the basis of technical innovation, every single time."
Smith's own contributions to the Young America campaign could top the $10 million mark. "Don't tell my wife," he quipped.
But, it was clear that Smith's wife, Vicky, already knew about his obsession. The yachting blood runs deep in Smith; after all, his grandfather was a prominent yachtsman from Rhode Island. And although Don, Vicky and their three children live on a ranch 40 miles outside of Oklahoma City, the family is used to his yachting forays.
He was here last week for the first day of boat testing between the club's two former America's Cup contenders: Young America, the 74-foot cup defender in 1995, and TAG Heuer, a New Zealand trial-race challenger that year. Both boats are outdated, but the syndicate is using them to try out new design ideas.
Smith's cup donations so far have gone largely to pay for the construction and upkeep of the new maxi-yacht, Falcon. The 80-foot sailboat is being used by the Young America syndicate as a competitive crew-training vessel. But the yacht is still mostly Smith's to use as he wants.
By donating Falcon to the syndicate, which is a nonprofit organization, Smith is eligible for a tax break. But if that were his purpose, he said, a corporate tax haven might have realized a far greater benefit.
The syndicate asked him to build a maxi rather than two 46-foot International Level Class yachts, as he had intended. The value of a maxi-yacht, he was convinced, would be in "experience, science, crew and a statement of their economic power."
As it turns out, Smith said, the decision was right. The 46-foot sailboat I.L.C. design he had expected to race competitively has waned in popularity in international yachting circles, whereas Falcon's size and power is similar to the 75-foot International America's Cup Class sailboats. Until Young America builds its own 1999-2000 cup yachts, Falcon has served its purpose, Smith said.
There is no mistaking Smith's purpose, or his commitment to it. "I want to win that cup," he said, his square jaw tightening and his eyes burning like lasers, "and I'm going to find a way to do it."

MAKING WAVES
 The American team took the lead yesterday in the Mumm Admiral's Cup after three days of racing off the Isle of Wight. JOHN KOLIUS, helmsman on MK Cafe in the I.L.C. 40 class, was first in the 30-hour Channel Race. Two other American boats finished second. The Americans lead with 33.75 points to 45.00 points for Britain and 51.50 for Germany. New Zealand is fourth with 54.38.

HEADLINE: A Reverse Discrimination Suit Upends Two Teachers' Lives

SERIES: A TEST OF FAIRNESS -- First of two articles.

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY, N.J.

 BODY:
The two women were brought together by a common desire to teach children. But they have been driven apart by race, politics and, paradoxically, a social policy that was supposed to help end such divisiveness.
For Sharon Taxman, it all began eight years ago, when the Piscataway Board of Education decided to eliminate one job in the high school business department. The one job was hers -- not because she was a poor teacher, the board reassured her. The sole reason, the board said, was that she was white. 
 Debra Williams, a business teacher as well, was hired the same day as Ms. Taxman. She kept her job, she learned, because she was black.
In early June 1989, about two weeks after the school board made its decision, Ms. Taxman filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, and what started as a mundane school board budget and personnel matter quickly evolved into a subject of national debate.
Was this a case of an employer going too far in complying with laws intended to remedy past discrimination in the workplace? Or was this just an instance of a school board trying to make sure that its teaching staff reflected the racial diversity of the students?
The Bush Administration, which had been searching for cases that could help eliminate race-based preferences, seized on the Piscataway case in 1991 and sued the school district for discrimination. Earlier this summer, the Supreme Court announced that it would take up the case in its next term, and the Court may well use it to set new limits on the extent to which an employer can use race as a factor in making personnel decisions.
But regardless of the final Court ruling, the case has irrevocably changed the lives of Ms. Taxman and Ms. Williams. "You keep thinking, 'This might be a dream or something,' " Ms. Williams said. "But you wake up and it doesn't go away."
In the beginning, in the days after the board's decision, Ms. Taxman was primarily concerned that she had lost her job just as her oldest child, Michael, was about to go to the University of Wisconsin.
"The timing, for her purposes, was horrible," Ms. Taxman's lawyer, Stephen E. Klausner, said recently. "She wanted her job. She needed her job."
Ms. Taxman got her job back in 1993, after another teacher at the high school took an early retirement. But she has continued to sue for back pay for the two years when she was unemployed, even as she has reluctantly become a symbol of what has become known as reverse discrimination.
She has rejected legal assistance from conservative groups, which have rallied around her case, and she refuses to discuss her case with reporters, referring all questions to Mr. Klausner.
Even though she kept her job, Ms. Williams has found little comfort in it. The fact that her race was the only factor that mattered to the school board was unsettling.
"It hurt her self esteem," Ms. Williams's husband, Alvin, recalled. "With all that she had put into education, and then to be told that the only reason she has her job is because she's black."
Ms. Williams and Ms. Taxman have taught in adjoining classrooms and shared an office ever since Ms. Taxman was rehired in 1993. They share a telephone, and twice a month they sit alongside each other at departmental meetings. But, other teachers say, the two women rarely acknowledge each other's presence. They spoke to each other only once during the last school year, when Ms. Williams went into Ms. Taxman's classroom to help break up a fight between two students. "She thanked me," Ms. Williams recalled. "Other than that, she does not say a word. Not even 'Good morning.' "
Throughout the high school, some teachers have informally broken into cliques -- mostly along racial lines -- in support of either Ms. Williams or Ms. Taxman, some teachers say. And around town "there are some mixed emotions," said Jerry Mahoney, the current school board president.
"People feel strong about this," said Mr. Mahoney, a local police officer who was not on the board in 1989. But, he said, "There haven't been any negative things like people trying to force their opinions on others."
 
Integrated Town
Record of Diversity Intriguing to Court
Piscataway seems like an unlikely place to find racial turmoil. Situated in central New Jersey, about an hour's drive southwest of New York City, this racially diverse town of 47,000 people has long been sensitive enough about race that it holds a multicultural Fourth of July parade, and each school has an annual Diversity Day.
Before the 1960's, Piscataway was a farming community with no real identity of its own. But when Route 287 opened, housing and industry followed, and bit by bit suburban houses and industrial parks overtook most of the town's 20 square miles. Like many suburban towns in New Jersey that grew up in the last three decades, Piscataway has no central town or village. Of some 6,200 students in Piscataway's schools, about 50 percent are white, 30 percent are African-American, 10 percent are Asian and 5 percent are Hispanic. The racial and ethnic composition of the teaching staff in the district has long reflected the population.
Mr. Mahoney noted that even though the overall teaching staff was racially and ethnically diverse when Ms. Taxman was dismissed, the business staff at the high school was not. It was important to retain Ms. Williams, he said, because the board wanted to make the business department "more reflective of the student population."
Mr. Mahoney, who is black and grew up in Piscataway, said the town is fortunate not to have any racial problems. "I think that comes from having a lot of diversity," he said. "Every neighborhood in Piscataway is integrated."
But it is because Piscataway High School had no history of discrimination and because its overall teaching staff was already diverse that the Piscataway case has found its way to the Supreme Court.
The arguments before the Court will center on Title VII of the landmark Civil Rights Act of 1964, which was intended to end discrimination in the workplace on the basis of race, religion, sex or national origin. Last August, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, which sits in Philadelphia, upheld a Federal District Court ruling that an employer may consider race in voluntary affirmative action only if it is used to remedy past discrimination or to correct distinctly low representation by minority workers in a traditionally segregated job category. The appeals court ruled that the Piscataway board did not meet either criterion, and that even if it had correctly identified a problem, terminating an employee would have been an extreme way to deal with it.
Some legal experts question whether the Piscataway case is the best test of affirmative action. They argue that although the district invoked its affirmative action policy, it was not intended to remedy any past discrimination.
 
Arrested Identity
Teacher Struggles For Recognition
Through the years, Ms. Williams has been on a crusade to prove her worth as an educator, constantly struggling to show that her qualifications, not her race, sustained her professionally. She keeps a file of papers, including diplomas, certificates and citations she has received, in her car. She even keeps handy a copy of the commencement program from her high school class in 1970, which shows that she graduated with honors.
During lunch at a local diner in July, the former Superintendent of the district, Philip Geiger, went over to Ms. Williams's table. "How's the Supreme Court?" he asked with a smile. "I got two A's on my courses at Rutgers last semester," she responded.
And although she is not an official party to the case, she has fought to keep the lawyers from ignoring her.
Mr. Klausner recalled an occasion, during oral arguments in Philadelphia, when Ms. Williams walked into the crowded courtroom and the marshal told her she would have to leave because there were too many people already inside. "She started yelling: 'This is my case. This is my case. I belong in this courtroom,' " Mr. Klausner said. "But this is not her case. She is nowhere to be found in this case as a litigant."
Ms. Williams says the board used her as a scapegoat to avoid making a tough personnel decision, and she insists that the board was wrong to determine that the only criterion distinguishing the teachers was race. "It really bothers me every time I pick up the paper and read that we had identical qualifications," Ms. Williams said. "We're not Siamese twins."
Indeed, while the courts may have deemed them equally qualified, the two women have distinctly different qualifications and backgrounds.
Ms. Taxman, a native of Buffalo, received a bachelor's degree in business education from the State University of New York at Buffalo. When she arrived at Piscataway in 1980, she was a 33-year-old mother of two children, whose first marriage had ended in divorce. She had taught high school courses for three years in upstate New York and had a comprehensive teaching endorsement that certified that she could teach a range of courses, including bookkeeping and accounting, business math and business English.
Ms. Williams, who was 28 years old when she started working in Piscataway, grew up in Winona, Miss. Her mother was a teacher and her father and grandfather funeral home operators. When the civil rights workers came through her hometown, her father opened his chapel to them, providing food and a place to stay.
She received her bachelor's degree in business education from Mississippi Valley State University in nearby Itta Bena. And it was there that she met her husband, who was president of his class and had led local civil rights marches himself. When the couple moved to New Jersey in the late 1970's, they had one son. They had another later.
Before teaching at Piscataway, Ms. Williams taught middle school for half a school year in Plainfield. Before that, she worked in administrative jobs at colleges in Mississippi. She was authorized to teach only secretarial studies and typewriting. But a year after joining the Piscataway staff, she received her master's in business education from Mississippi State University. And in 1985, she received her comprehensive certification, which allowed her to teach all the courses Ms. Taxman was certified to teach.
Ms. Williams was the first black teacher in the school's business education department, which in 1980 had 15 teachers. By 1989, because of declining enrollment, the department had just 10 teachers, and Ms. Williams was still the department's only black teacher. She is still the department's only black teacher.
From the start, the relationship between the two teachers was never more than cordial, and some teachers at the school recall that Ms. Taxman seemed withdrawn from many of her colleagues. But "it really wasn't unusual," said Priscilla Tucker, a former math teacher whose classroom was across the hall from Ms. Taxman's. "She was no different than a lot of other teachers who stay to themselves."
 
Icy Polarization
Serious Rift Comes With Long Debate
On April 24, 1989, a courier delivered letters to both Ms. Taxman and Ms. Williams in their classrooms. "The Board of Education will be discussing a reduction in the number of business teachers," said the letters from Gordon Moore, the school district's director of personnel. "This board discussion could possibly result in a recommendation to abolish a teaching staff position and terminate your employment."
On May 22, Ms. Taxman was told that she was out of a job.
The State of New Jersey requires that a reduction in force be done on the basis of seniority, and schools are allowed to use their own discretion only when there is a tie. In this instance, the school board followed a recommendation from the Superintendent and chose to invoke the district's affirmative action policy to break the tie.
As David B. Rubin, the lawyer representing the school board, explained, both teachers had received excellent evaluations and both had strong records of participation in related professional activities. "One may have had a master's and the other one didn't, and one may have had certifications the other one didn't," Mr. Rubin said. "But in all ways that mattered" the board deemed them to be equal.
On June 8, 1989, 16 days after the board told her she was terminated, Ms. Taxman filed a charge of discrimination with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Over the coming months, while her complaint was under review, she looked for work and collected unemployment benefits, Mr. Klausner said.
When one teacher in the department went out on maternity leave in 1991, Ms. Taxman returned to her old job for a brief period. She was permanently rehired in 1993.
In the meantime, the two women had already gone before the State Commissioner of Education for a hearing, where Ms. Taxman argued that Ms. Williams had less seniority because she had used a large amount of leave when she gave birth to her second son and later suffered injuries in a car accident, all in the same school year. In 1990, the Commissioner ruled in Ms. Williams's favor, maintaining that they were equal in seniority.
But that same year, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission determined that there was "probable cause" to believe that the district had discriminated against Ms. Taxman. After the commission's determination reached the civil rights division of the Department of Justice, the case became a political matter.
In 1991, the Federal Government filed suit against the board. The Government was the principal plaintiff in the suit, joined by Ms. Taxman. In September 1993, a Federal District Court in Newark found in Ms. Taxman's favor and awarded her $144,000 in back pay. The school board appealed, and the White House, which by now was under the control of the Clinton Administration, tried to switch sides and support the school board's appeal.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied the Administration's request, but allowed the Government to withdraw from the case. In August 1996, the appeals court upheld the lower court's ruling, which led to the Supreme Court appeal.
As the debate has continued, the rift between the two teachers has widened. Ms. Tucker, who retired this year, said she was friendly with both teachers, but found it difficult to be around them at the same time. "I noticed that when I'm with Debbie, Sharon doesn't speak," Ms. Tucker said. "But when I'm not with Debbie, she's very friendly."
On one occasion, the department supervisor tried to clear the air by calling the two into his office to shake hands. Even though they agreed, the gesture apparently held no lasting meaning. Ms. Tucker said that she noticed "a kind of polarization that occurred as a result of the case" and that Ms. Taxman "has become very friendly with a group of teachers, and they shun other groups of teachers." A district official denied that there was any added tension in the school as a result of the case.
But, teachers at the schools say, Ms. Williams is criticized by some of her colleagues who imply that she should just be happy to have her job. "My close friends, eating buddies, say things about her," Ms. Tucker admitted. "People are aware of the case and they talk about the nature of why Debbie was kept as a teacher and Sharon was not. But that was not Debbie's doing. She's not responsible for being born black, and she's not responsible for the board's decision. She's trying to defend herself when she shouldn't have to defend herself."
To be sure, the case has made life more complicated and stressful for both teachers.
Ms. Taxman, her lawyer said, "is not clinically depressed, but she is depressed."
Ms. Williams is careful about what classes she allows her youngest son, a 10th-grade student at Piscataway, to take. "I select his teachers, because I know that some might be prejudiced because of the case," she said.
It has also affected her health. She doesn't sleep well and her blood pressure is high. "Every day, she comes home all twisted up," Alvin Williams said of his wife. "Why do you have to pay such a price for a job?"
Mr. Williams said he has told his wife: "You have both been judged by the color of your skin. This situation violates the principle that civil rights stand on. The board did both of you wrong. You both have been used. You should be teamed up, together."
NEXT: In the coming Supreme Court debate, one Justice will be on the spot.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Next Up in Reinsdorf's Great Chicago Fire Sale: Ventura to Yanks?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Jerry Reinsdorf, a general manager was saying the other day, has done two things that have not been good for baseball. Other people in baseball, union officials, for example, would suggest that Reinsdorf, the Chicago White Sox owner, has done many more things that have not been good for baseball, but the general manager was speaking of two specific things.
"Signing Albert Belle was one," he said. "Doing this is not good for baseball either." 
 "This" was the startling trade the White Sox made with the San Francisco Giants last Thursday, the one by which the White Sox announced to the rest of the baseball world and their fans that with a third of the season still to be played they were putting their bats and balls in mothballs for the winter.
"It's the Major League Baseball version of 'no mas,' " an owner of another team remarked.
By giving the Giants their No. 1 starting pitcher (Wilson Alvarez), their closer (Roberto Hernandez) and another veteran pitcher (Danny Darwin) for six minor leaguers, only one of whom is considered a top prospect, the White Sox signaled surrender when they were only three and a half games behind Cleveland in the American League Central.
If there is something beyond unconditional surrender, though, the White Sox may do that, too, by trading Robin Ventura, their recuperated third baseman, to the Yankees. After talking with the St. Louis Cardinals about Ventura last week -- "at length," an official of another club said -- the White Sox have continued speaking with the Yankees, another official said.
"There might be a deal with the Yankees in the next week or two if they can get Ventura through waivers," the official said.
Because the July 31 deadline has passed, anyone who is traded now must clear waivers first. Ventura, 30 years old, missed the first 99 games this season with a broken right leg and a severely dislocated ankle, but since returning July 24 he has batted .379 in eight games.
If the Yankees were to get the four-time Gold Glove winner, they could use Charlie Hayes as a right-handed-hitting designated hitter, now considered a problem area because of the injury to Cecil Fielder. Ventura has a $6 million salary this season, and his contract includes a club option at $6.1 million for next year. Trading Ventura would no longer come as a surprise, considering what the White Sox have already done with some of their higher-priced players.
The Chicago fire sale was not what Reinsdorf had in mind when he threw $55 million, $11 million a year, at Albert Belle, last November and single-handedly escalated the salary scale by the largest dollar leap ever. Concerned about lagging attendance and decreasing revenue, Reinsdorf believed that the addition of Belle would make the team a contender that would attract hundreds of thousands of additional fans.
The fans' anger with the White Sox, though, evidently runs deeper than the game's richest contract can dissolve. After drawing an average crowd of 21,220 last season, the White Sox have averaged 24,050 this season, an increase far below what Reinsdorf had in mind.
The Belle signing, then, has failed on one narrow economic front, in that it didn't achieve Reinsdorf's goal. But it has been devastating in a broader economic way. It forced other clubs to give their star players much more money than they otherwise would have had to pay them: the Giants gave Barry Bonds $11.45 million a year for two years; Sammy Sosa got $10.62 million a year for four years from the Cubs; Gary Sheffield received $10.17 million a year for six years from the Marlins and the Rangers signed Ivan Rodriguez for $8.4 million a year for five years.
"It had a tremendous impact; there's no question," Dave Dombrowski, the Florida Marlins' general manager, said, discussing Sheffield's contract. "They didn't want to talk at all until Belle signed. Once the Belle numbers came in, they were very open to talk. I said this might be an aberration. Then the Bonds numbers came in and the market was defined. So it had a tremendous impact."
Until Belle signed, the highest annual average value was $8.5 million for Ken Griffey Jr.
"That was a very easy number to justify," Dombrowski said, "because Griffey was a complete-package player. In our initial discussions, we weren't prepared to go above that."
Andy MacPhail, the Cubs' president, said that the Belle contract affected their negotiations with Sosa, too. "We weren't interested in any five- or six-year contract," MacPhail said. "We were willing to make a concession on the average annual value to keep it four."
Doug Melvin said that the Rangers' difficulty in signing Rodriguez, which they finally succeeded in doing last week, stemmed from Belle's double digits and those that followed.
"The whole negotiation was 'if Belle, Sheffield and Sosa can get $10 million,' " the Texas general manager said. "That's what we were faced with."
Reinsdorf was not available at the end of the week to comment on the ramifications of the Belle contract or the club's shredding of its roster.
"Jerry will not be able to return a call today," his assistant, Anita Fasano, said, adding that he would then be away for a week.
Reinsdorf, who has been very discouraged and has constantly complained about the attendance at Comiskey Park, had been quoted earlier in the week as saying, "Anyone who thinks this White Sox team will catch Cleveland is crazy." Is the newly constituted White Sox team capable of catching the Indians? Not in this millennium.
Defending the team's trades -- Harold Baines was also traded last week, to Baltimore -- General Manager Ron Schueler said: "I gave them 102 games to compete and we weren't even at .500. If we got lucky, we might contend for the division. There wouldn't be anything after that. I don't see where we threw in the towel."
Some baseball people, upon hearing about the White Sox-Giants trade, immediately thought of the deals Bowie Kuhn, then the commissioner, wouldn't let Charlie Finley of Oakland make in the middle 1970's. Finley, however, wanted to shred his roster mostly for cash.
Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, was asked about Chicago's roster-shredding trades.
"In this particular situation," he said, choosing his words carefully, "every club has to make their own individual decisions. Obviously, the White Sox, I'm sure, thought this out very well and decided this was the direction they wanted to go."
A high-ranking executive of another club questioned how well thought out that direction was.
"If you have a strategy and stick with it, ultimately you will be rewarded," the veteran executive said. "They were three games out and didn't let the strategy follow through. When you switch strategies in midstream, it's going to create problems."
 
Intriguing Moves in Seattle
 If the White Sox trade was the most shocking made on deadline day for trades without waivers, the Mark McGwire trade from Oakland to St. Louis was the most predictable and the Seattle Mariners' trades the most curious.
"The Jose Cruz thing knocked everyone's socks off; he's such a good- looking player," one general manager said, referring to the trade of Cruz Jr., a rookie outfielder, to Toronto for two relief pitchers, Mike Timlin and Paul Spoljaric. "The only guy I think they could have given up Cruz for was Ricky Bottalico. Everybody I talked to said the same thing."
Lee Thomas, the Philadelphia general manager, said that the Mariners talked to him about Bottalico but did not offer Cruz.
"It never got that far," Thomas said. "There was a lot of sparring around about him, but it was never, 'I'll do it, will you do it?' "
The Mariners, desperate for a closer, apparently wanted one from the American League so he would be familiar with A.L. hitters. But they got Timlin, who had lost his closing job with the Blue Jays to a rookie, Kelvim Escobar, and in a second trade, Heathcliff Slocumb, who minutes before the trade squandered yet another save and cost Boston a victory.
The Mariners also talked to the White Sox about Roberto Hernandez but didn't offer Cruz. "I don't know if that would have got it done," said Ron Schueler, who included the team's solid closer in the San Francisco package.
 
Garner's Magic Act
 Taking nothing away from Terry Collins of the surprising Anaheim Angels, Phil Garner of the Milwaukee Brewers should be named the American League manager of the year right now.
Despite injuries to some of his key players and far less talent than many teams, Garner has the Brewers playing like a division contender. They entered last night's game with a nine-game winning streak, sitting only two and a half games behind Cleveland in the A.L. Central.
During the winning streak, Garner's guys pulled off perhaps the most remarkable team feat of the season. They won doubleheaders from Toronto on consecutive days, sweeping a four-game series in 48 hours.
 
Realignment Gains Momentum
 Despite some reluctance, teams seem to be moving toward major realignment of the leagues. At a realignment committee meeting last week, a vote on the most radical plan, one that would shift just about half of the teams, was 12-2 in favor.
Atlanta and San Diego voted no, but an owner of another team said the Braves and the Padres support "significant" realignment but questioned parts of the proposed plan.
The committee doesn't have to make a recommendation unanimously. However, any team that would be asked to change leagues can veto the move. The Players Association is also expected to oppose radical realignment.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Olympic Wrestler's Silver Medal Has Brought Little in Value

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
ALMOST everywhere he has gone for a full year now, no one has cared or even remembered that Matt Ghaffari came in second. An embarrassingly dumb corporate slogan from last summer's Atlanta Olympics claimed that you "don't win silver, you lose gold," but Ghaffari's tears as the silver medal for Greco-Roman wrestling was placed around his ample neck represented how far he had come, not where he had failed to go.
An escape from the upheaval in late-1970's Iran. Nine knee operations. Years of financial sacrifice by him and his wife. He had a story to tell, and suddenly, amazingly, he had a platform from which to tell it. 
 Ghaffari told Jay Leno he thought only "gold medalists get to sit on your couch," but Leno didn't care that he came in second. The Republican National Convention, which he addressed last August, didn't mind that he finished in exactly the same position that Bob Dole was going to. The daughter of the woman killed in the Centennial Park bombing knew Ghaffari from his visits to her hospital bedside as her Olympic angel, with a heart of gold.
Everywhere he has gone for a full year now, 36-year-old Matt Ghaffari, out of Paramus High School in New Jersey, has worn his silver medal with pride, with hope. Everywhere, it seems, but the bank.
"I went to try to get financing for my house, which I rent with an agreement to buy," he said recently from his home outside Cleveland. "They asked for tax statements for the last 10 years and say, 'What have you been doing for the last few years?' I tell them, 'I was training for the Olympics.' Then they say, 'That means you were unemployed.' "
The bankers have not wanted to know how he rejected the chance to wrestle at the 1988 Olympics for Iran after failing to make the United States team. How he closed a car park-and-lease business in Phoenix, and his wife quit her job with an insurance firm to accompany him to Colorado Springs, so he could train for 1996. In tax-code speak, he is nothing more than a runner-up to a Russian, Aleksandr Karelin. Sorry, the bankers have said, we can't help you.
It became frustrating for Ghaffari to hear through the wrestling grapevine what became of Karelin, who finished the Atlanta Games unbeaten for almost a decade. "I was told he was a colonel in the army and they made him a three-star general," Ghaffari said. "They had a parade for him in Red Square. He's a millionaire now. He walks with two bodyguards."
This could be apocryphal. Karelin didn't seem the type who needed protection. At 6 feet 4 inches and 300 pounds, he walked with a menacing strut and brooding, deep-set eyes under blond, peach-fuzz hair. In wrestling circles, he was sometimes referred to as the World's Meanest Man.
Ghaffari also knew Karelin as something of a humanitarian, a statesman, so respected that a campaigning Boris Yeltsin was said to have visited the wrestler at his Siberian home, 1,750 miles from Moscow, to seek his endorsement.
Upon winning his medal, Ghaffari patterned himself after Karelin, becoming the Leonard Zelig of the United States team. No photo opportunity could go off without him. No little old lady could cross the street without him on her arm. Instead of a party week on the United States Olympic Committee, he gave his time to the Paralympics. He made the acquaintance of other bombing victims. In the months ahead, his reward would be a job as a sort of lounge act sports celebrity. He would crisscross America, weaving a tangled web of fund-raising dinners and golf.
"Never played in my life, but I just had to go out and actually buy a set of clubs," he said.
People like him, he said. They listen to his story, even if they think Greco-Roman might be a sport played with shields and clubs. But in the year since the Olympics, he has earned between $30,000 and $40,000, not enough to support three young daughters, not even enough to borrow from a bank. He thinks he could have been a star, but knows now that corporate America is too busy throwing millions at bratty teenagers and Dennis Rodman to use imagination and bankroll some likable athletes who actually deserve it.
From last summer, it is his understanding that the swimmer Amy Van Dyken made out great. The gymnast Kerri Strug thought she could be a solo act, but how much limping by a nutritionally challenged young woman can an audience stand? At least she had her teammates to vault back to, to go on tour with. At least the women's basketball players now have not one, but two, professional leagues of their own.
As for Ghaffari's career, the 2000 Sydney Games are too far away. He injured his knee helping one of the wrestlers he works with part time at Cleveland State University, his alma mater. And this life on the road is getting old.
He just got home from appearances in Idaho and Minneapolis. This week, he's in Baltimore, home for two days, off to Denver. His wife calls him an "absentee father," which upsets him. He worries about health insurance for his girls. He knows his one-year ride, Matt Ghaffari's silver surfing, is coming to an end.
"It's back to changing diapers and taking the garbage out," he said, with a sigh. "I need to get a real job."

HEADLINE: Surging Economy Vindicates Supply-Side Claims

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In your Week in Review piece "The Supply Side's Irrepressible Charm" (July 27), you avoid the tiresome arsenal of myth, caricature and falsehood that critics usually roll out in an effort to discredit President Reagan's economic policies. Instead, you opt for the slightly bemused, dismissive approach of one commenting affectionately on the foibles and crankiness of a dotty old aunt. Cute, but intellectually vacuous. 
 You dismiss as hysterical the warnings that President Clinton's 1993 tax increase would damage the economy and observe that today, "the economy is robust." The fact is, the supply-side criticism of the Clinton tax increase, as well as of the increase under President Bush, was right on the mark. It took the economy seven years to completely digest the impact of these tax increases. If not for the increases, the gross domestic product would now be at least 11 percent bigger than it is and the large deficits of the early 1990's would never have occurred.
You give credence to the flawed philosophy that tax increases improve the economy by lowering the deficit, thus lowering interest rates. This mixes up cause and effect. As the past year has made clear, the rapidly vanishing deficit is the result of the robust economy, not vice versa.
You say my suggestion that Africa could foster entrepreneurship by reducing taxes ignores the fact that few of Africa's poor, or its wealthy, pay their taxes. Let me make a simple point. Most Africans will never pay taxes as long as rates are prohibitively high. Since people don't pay taxes under high tax rates anyway, why are you so afraid to lower the rate?
I assure you, if rates were lowered (in conjunction with a free-trade zone, stable monetary policies and foreign-investment programs with a focus on privatization) revenues would grow, as they did in America under John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan.
 
JACK KEMP
Washington, July 31, 1997
