HEADLINE: Surging Economy Vindicates Supply-Side Claims;
A Fiscal Theory Only Orwell Could Love

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your July 27 Week in Review article on the remarkable durability of supply-side economics describes supply-siders as "offering the somewhat tortured argument that the economy would be even stronger if not for the 1993 tax increase." Actually, they're more imaginative than that: the same people who predicted disaster four years ago are now insisting, with straight faces, that the nation's prosperity is -- guess what? -- a confirmation of their doctrine. 
 Consider, for example, the columnist Paul Craig Roberts, who once warned that a Clinton tax increase would produce "a bigger deficit, higher unemployment, rising inflation and a currency crisis to boot" -- but who recently wrote a column titled "What's So Mysterious About the Rip-Roaring Economy?" proclaiming that plunging deficits, low unemployment, stable prices and a surging dollar are exactly what supply-side economics predicted.
Or check out the editorial in Investor's Business Daily titled "The Supply-Sider's Revenge" declaring the decline in the deficit a vindication of Ronald Reagan's 1981 tax cut. (Applying the same time lag, we might surmise that credit for the economic turnaround of 1982 belongs not to Mr. Reagan but to Lyndon B. Johnson.)
So while some supply-siders are claiming credit for a healthy economy, others are using the standard tricks of statistical distortion to claim that it isn't that healthy after all. But as George Orwell could have told you, absolute commitment to a doctrine always requires not just the willingness to rewrite history but a talent for double-think: the ability to believe two contradictory things at the same time.
 
PAUL KRUGMAN
Cambridge, Mass., July 30, 1997
 
The writer is a professor of economics at M.I.T.

HEADLINE: The Irish and Their Montauk Connection

BYLINE: By RICK MURPHY 

 BODY:
THE brogue is heard in delis, video stores and fish markets, spoken by house cleaners, landscapers and bartenders.
It's not Dublin. But with the throngs of Irish men and women who have flocked to the East End, it might seems that way. 
 Many are linked to one family in East Hampton, Brian and Prudence Carabine. The Carabines say they have "networked" 1,500 young Irish people in 15 years, taking them into their home or finding work and lodging for them.
"There were so many people coming here at one point that if the cops found kids with Irish accents sleeping on the beach they would automatically bring them to our house," Ms. Carabine said.
The Carabines began housing Irish students in 1983, charging a small amount for food and a bed.
"I grew up with parents that did what they could for other people," Ms. Carabine said. "That's just the way it was."
Her family settled in East Hampton in the 17th century. She ran a work agency in the 80's and sought out Irish students to fill jobs.
Mr. Carabine's parents hailed from Ireland. "They always stressed hospitality," he said. That's what we do here."
As visitors returned and told others about their summers, they passed along the Carabines' telephone number. Each summer, more called.
"It got out of hand," Ms. Carabine recalled. "One night Brian came home for supper, and there were 42 of us at the table."
Naomi Corbett-Kelsall has been spending part of each year in the Hamptons since her first visit 11 years ago. She attributed the large numbers of her countrymen who have migrated here to liberal immigration between the two countries.
The Hamptons are particularly appealing, Ms. Corbett-Kelsall said, because the area has many decent-paying summer jobs. In her case, a help-wanted sign at the Irish consulate in Manhattan that she saw shortly after her arrival was the impetus.
"Chamber maids wanted in Montauk," it read. "We all looked at each other and asked, 'Where's Montauk?' " she recalled.
That job did not pan out, and before long Ms. Corbett-Kelsall found her way to the Carabines.
"Most every one of us who have been out here have done a stint on a mattress on Prudie's floor," she said.
Ms. Corbett-Kelsall met her husband in East Hampton, and for five years has returned to work at Jeff's Fancy Produce, a greengrocer. She returns to Ireland with her husband each winter.
Another Carabine alumna, Pat Lillis, took a break from teaching in Ireland eight years ago to vacation in East Hampton. And she has stayed.
"The people are so civilized when it comes to animals here," Ms. Lillis said. "There are a lot of animal lovers. I found it difficult to live in Ireland because it's not the case there. Here if you find an injured critter you can find some help for it."
She works cleaning houses and watching pets.
"I like to say I'm in A & E, anything and everything," she added.
Anne-Louise Kieran, an art student in a college in Glasgow who was born in Northern Ireland, is spending her first summer in the Hamptons along with her boyfriend, Julian Kildear.
"I'm the third member of my family to come here," Ms. Kieran said. "We just said, 'Let's drop everything and have a life experience in the Hamptons.' "
She said she had mixed feelings about her summer.
"I have a love-hate relationship with America. I don't think I could live here permanently. It's too big. It's too fast. There is an incredible work ethic. But the big thing is being here by the ocean. It's just incredible."
Both students had heard that the Hamptons were a hot spot for celebrities. Sure enough, Ms. Kieran was in line at a store when she encountered Jamie Lee Curtis. "She seemed very nice," Ms. Kieran said.
"The cost of living here is quite a bit higher than at home," Mr. Kildear said. "We still haven't figured out this whole tipping thing. We get paranoid when we're in a restaurant trying to figure out how much."
The Carbines have made several trips to Ireland after having heard so much about the country.
"It's amazing," Mr. Carabine said. "We've been walking across a bridge and met people we've had in our house."
"It's almost impossible for us to go into a pub in Dublin without seeing someone we know," Ms. Carabine said. "In our little way we've made the world smaller."
Because of an abundance of hotel and restaurant jobs in Montauk, it remains a hot spot for visiting students. Many gather at the Old Shebeen tavern. Occasionally the police said, the rowdy crowds cause vandalism and commit petty crimes, but for the most part the students are well behaved.
"The Irish people like to work hard and they like to play hard," Ms. Corbett-Kelsall said.
"We're friendly. We talk to everyone and accept everyone," Ms. Lillis said. "People hear an Irish accent and they know they aren't going to get killed. They trust Irish people."
Many Irish visitors have stayed in the United States and found high-paying jobs, because, Ms. Corbett-Kelsall said, they are highly educated, and Ireland is one of the most computer-literate countries.
Ms. Kieran's brother is a computer programmer in Pittsburgh.
But Mr. Carabine said now that the Irish economy had improved, more and more former borders are heading home.
Although Ms. Lillis calls East Hampton her "home away from home," Mr. Carabine said that for many borders "there is only one real home."
"You can spend a lifetimelooking for those kinds of roots and never find them," Mrs. Carabine said.
Visitors from Ireland are hardly a new phenomena in America, but Ms. Corbett-Kelsall traces the latest influx from visa agreements that the two countries forged in 1968.
"A lot of students use these visas as a steppingstone," especially in the summer, she said, to travel freely on school vacations.
Groups of students, who arrive in New York, are accompanied by coordinators to help them through the first few days.
The arrangers frequently provide temporary lodging, and the students are told "to pound the streets and find work," Ms. Corbett-Kelsall said.
But even if New York City is the destination of choice for many, "you quickly realize accommodations are out of the question," she said.
After the first wave settled on the East End, the gates opened.
"The Hamptons are well known in Ireland," Ms. Corbett-Kelsall said. "We have contacts here. We are a very close-knit community, and we bond. I would do things for Irish people in East Hampton I wouldn't do for them at home. It's become a summer phenomena."
Though certainly a popular settling point, The Hamptons is not the only place to welcome visitors from across the sea. Ms. Kieran spent her first summer abroad in San Francisco. Martha's Vineyard is another popular locale. This year, a large group of students went to tiny Block Island.
More than a few visitors, like Ms. Lillis, have permanently settled in the Hamptons. Several own businesses, including a seafood store, an upholstery shop and a deli.
"Obviously, they are predisposed to hiring Irish," Ms. Corbett-Kelsall pointed out.
For 10 years the sluggish European economy has fueled a major move to find work abroad. But with the European economy regaining now, Mr. Carabine said, he sees signs that the flow of Irish visitors may have peaked.
The family receives fewer calls and takes in fewer boarders, offering beds only to those with family connections. The Carabines' children, like their parents, have all visited Ireland and stayed at the Kierans' home.
Mr. Kildear said that more and more Irish students were choosing to stay in Europe. There are more jobs, he said, and, "It's fashionable to be Irish all over Europe these days, even in Britain."

(Michael Shavel for The New York Times)(pg. 1); Patrons, many of them Irish immigrants, taking an opportunity to meet over drinks at a bar. (Michael Shavel for The New York Times)(pg. 12)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 32; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Civic Pride Aside, Some Economists Say, Costly Sports Stadiums May Not Be Worth It

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Have New York and Los Angeles been wounded by the loss of their National Football League teams? Have Indianapolis and Jacksonville, Fla., been reinvigorated by gaining such teams? Is civic pride reason enough to invest tens -- or hundreds -- of millions of dollars to keep a profit-making sports team from fleeing?
New York State lawmakers have rekindled interest in such questions by agreeing to invest $75 million from the state budget in the improvement of Rich Stadium to keep the Buffalo Bills from leaving the state. In an era when sports teams have perfected the dance to get hold of tax dollars, threatening to jump cities unless they are given lavish new homes at public expense, many cities have debated the merits of giving in to such demands. 
 It is an immediate concern in New York City, where George M. Steinbrenner 3d, principal owner of the Yankees, has threatened to leave town when the team's lease at Yankee Stadium expires in 2002 and the Mets, too, are eager to build a new home. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has supported the idea of building the Yankees a new home, for $1 billion, above a rail yard west of Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan.
But many economists who have studied the issue have concluded that cities and states almost never gain by giving in to teams' demands for new stadiums.
"Any politician who says this is sound economic development is either misinformed or lying," said Andrew Zimbalist, a professor of economics at Smith College who is writing a book on the subject with Roger Noll of the Brookings Institution.
Sports teams produce little or no net increase in economic activity in a city, critics contend: rather, they take away money from other forms of entertainment, like eating out or going to the movies.
And, the critics argue, an investment of hundreds of millions of dollars in a new stadium is far out of proportion to the meager commerce the stadium would, by itself, produce.
Robert Baade, an economist at Lake Forest College in Illinois, said it is not worth the effort. "And," he said, "when you take into account that the money spent on a stadium could be invested in roads or bridges or industrial parks or schools, all of which have much greater return, it may well be that stadium-building actually has a negative economic impact."
Despite such arguments, elected officials routinely refer to spending to keep sports teams as an important form of economic development.
Trumpeting the Bills' deal in Buffalo on Thursday, Gov. George E. Pataki, said, "We will do what Los Angeles, Cleveland and Houston could not: hold onto our N.F.L. team in this era of franchise free agency."
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has introduced legislation that could make city-hopping harder for teams by barring local and state governments from using tax-exempt bonds to build sports arenas.
Analysts say that a project like Buffalo's, which merely upgrades an existing stadium with luxury boxes and other amenities, is less of a boondoggle than building an entirely new stadium. But the Buffalo deal obligates the Bills to stay for only one to six years, depending on a number of factors, though there would be financial penalties for leaving before 14 years.
In general, analysts say, a baseball team is a better investment for a city than a football team because a baseball team plays 81 home games a year in the regular season, as compared with the 8 home games played in football.
Economists note that a major sports team has only about 100 full-time, year-round employees, and while several hundred more may work at the stadium during the season, most are in low-paying jobs and work only on game days or during special events like concerts.
Politicians have been known to fear being tarred as the one who lost a team, but history provides little evidence that elected officials pay a political price for standing up to team owners and watching them leave.
In New York, Mayors Edward I. Koch and Robert F. Wagner were handily re-elected after sports teams departed for newer arenas, and the same holds true in Los Angeles for Mayors Tom Bradley and Richard Riordan.
"When cities go to great lengths to keep these teams, I think it's all about a municipal macho," said State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat. "And that's just not a good enough reason."

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 18; Column 1; Education Life Supplement 

LENGTH: 1653 words

HEADLINE: SOFTWARE;
Professor Higgins Would Be Pleased

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD; Matthew L. Wald is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

DATELINE: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio

 BODY:
From the computer's speakers came a well-modulated American male voice with perfect diction, delivering "model utterances" to a Chinese student. The phrases were nothing like those in a Berlitz course for tourists or in a high school language textbook; these were designed for college professors, doctors, executives and other professionals.
 "Your college transcripts are absolutely confidential," the voice said. It continued with other sentences: "She has office hours in the morning. Specifically, do you know which algorithms are causing problems? We have no doubts that the software is pirated." And, "Sign these checks." 
 The program, developed by Arthur H. Schwartz, a speech pathologist, is an advanced example of a growing effort on campuses and in businesses nationwide to teach not English, but English pronunciation.
 Learning to speak any language exactly like a native becomes impossible for most people after the age of 12, and thus nearly everyone who learns English as an adult lacks the ability to pronounce some of its consonants. But according to Dr. Schwartz and others, Asians generally find English harder than Europeans do, because most Asian languages lack the patterns of stress and intonation that impart much of the meaning in spoken English.
 Another reason for the Asian emphasis is that what used to be called the "brain drain" is still operating, drawing a torrent of professionals to the United States -- more and more of them from Taiwan, Korea, Japan and China. Programs that work on pronunciation have sprung up in places ranging from Honolulu to Stillwater, Okla., as well as Cincinnati, Boston, Syracuse and traditional centers of immigration like the New York City area. According to the United States Census Bureau, more than 200,000 people arrive in the United States from Asia and the Pacific Islands every year.
 An example is Oliver Wong, the student seated at Dr. Schwartz's computer. A physician at the Cleveland Clinic, Dr. Wong, 35, arrived from Hong Kong six years ago with both an M.D. and a Ph.D. in nuclear medicine. Staring intently at the computer's screen, he tried saying, "Sign these checks." What he saw on the monitor was a voiceprint of the "model," showing the pitch and volume of each sound. Below it was a print of his own effort.
 Dr. Wong did well with the "n" in "sign," which is often a problem for Chinese students, who tend to drop final consonants. He also pronounced the "th" in "these" correctly, another tricky area, because Chinese students sometimes produce the sound without using their vocal cords, so it resembles the whispery "th" in "think."
 But Dr. Wong, who is one of Dr. Schwartz's most advanced students, found the real value of the computer-based system in the last word, "checks." For Dr. Wong, it had come out "chess."
 Dr. Schwartz pointed at the voiceprint of the sample utterance and the print of Dr. Wong's effort. "Did you have a match for the word ending?" he asked, indicating the thin squiggle, which represented the "s" sound, at the end of the print.
 Yes," said Dr. Wong, but he frowned at the screen. Something else was wrong, he knew, but like many students, he was having trouble identifying his error.
 "Was it the 'ch' sound?" he asked. But no, that was fine. Then he looked near the end of the voiceprint. In the model there was a tiny gap, representing silence, between the main body of the word and the ending "s," but in the print of his voice, there was no such gap.
 "There's a 'k' sound; I missed the 'k' sound," he said.
 Then Dr. Wong moved on to the sentence about college transcripts. Dr. Schwartz congratulated him on correctly producing the last vowel sound in "confidential," and the "ts" in transcripts. Getting those correct made his whole sentence easy to understand, even though he missed the "p" in "transcripts."
 Dr. Wong, who was born in Fujian Province and thus speaks two Chinese dialects in addition to English, said: "In Chinese, when you're done with one vowel, you're done with that particular word. We don't depend on consonants that much." But in English, he said, "you need to master several vowels and consonants in one word."
 Dr. Schwartz is a professor of speech and hearing at Cleveland State University, where several faculty members had referred graduate students to him for remedial work. That prompted him to found a small company, Accent Services, USA, and begin teaching students on the side, like Dr. Wong. His goal, he said, is not to produce students who sound just like Americans, but to help people make enough of the sounds that the listener expects so that their speech will be clear, or at least intelligible. As an example, he gave the word "parallel."
 An Asian-born speaker trying to produce the word "parallel" might miss one sound, and say something like "pawallel," but that would still be intelligible, Dr. Schwartz said. Missing a second sound might still work, he said. "The listener is willing to work to fill in one, or to struggle for two," he said. But if the speaker missed a third sound, a native-born American would say, "the hell with it," Dr. Schwartz said.
 SOME academic institutions have found that out the hard way. Syracuse University, for example, now runs a course in English pronunciation for foreign-born teaching assistants. Jeanette D. Macero, who teaches the course, said the genesis was complaints from parents that they were paying tuition for instructors whom their children could not understand.
 Now, she said, "We have rankings, one to four." One is near-native speaking; two is very good; three is someone who needs help, and four is "needs a great deal of help," she said.
 "In order to teach, everybody needs to be a two," she said. "Eighty-five percent of all students become a two by the end of the second semester, and most of the remainder are a two by third semester."
 In addition to English pronunciation, the course also teaches instructors that if they do not understand a question raised by an undergraduate, they should ask to have the question repeated. Female teachers from countries in which women do not raise their voices are taught to speak more firmly, and teachers of both sexes are taught a mixture of rhythm, intonation and melody (called prosody) that is characteristic of English. In Chinese, for example, tones give meanings to individual words but not to whole sentences. In English, tone differentiates a question from a declarative statement and also shows emphasis.
 Foreign students at Syracuse and other colleges are given carefully graded tests of spoken English. The Educational Testing Service, in Princeton, N.J., developed a Test of Spoken English in 1981, and last year, nearly 20,000 people registered to take it; the number is still growing, according to Anthony P. Ostrander, associate director of the service. Tens of thousands more take a SPEAK test, or Speaking Proficiency English Assessment Kit, which is sold by the service to colleges and universities to administer to their foreign graduate students.
 On many campuses the pronunciation programs originated in a speech pathology center, even though there is nothing wrong with these students; they simply grew up speaking another language.
 At the Queens, N.Y., campus of St. John's University, Dr. Donna Geffner, director of the Speech and Hearing Center, also teaches graduate students and faculty members whose native tongue is not English. She encourages them to bring in their textbooks for help with certain words.
 "If it's a teacher in the College of Pharmacy and Allied Health Professions," she said, "if he doesn't put the stress on the right syllable in the name of the chemical, the students don't have a clue about what he's talking about."
 That is a problem not only for the listeners, but for the speakers, too. Adelina Samuels, who came to New York from Tashkent, Russia, six years ago, said: "You have no idea how frustrating it is. I didn't speak to people for a year and a half after I came to this country, even though in a year I knew some English already. Understanding what harm I do to language when I speak, I was afraid to communicate."
 Ms. Samuels, who was a speech pathologist in Russia and now works with mentally handicapped Russian children in Queens, helping them speak, has developed her own multimedia computer program to help with pronunciation. Unlike Dr. Schwartz's, hers combines sounds with pictures of a mouth making the sounds.
 Ms. Samuels herself speaks with less than perfect grammar, but her pronunciation is clear and, with her linguist's ear, she can produce on request a credible imitation of a native saying "Lawn Gyland," where she now lives.
 Dr. Schwartz's program and Ms. Samuels's, which is not yet commercial, are two of several that use a personal computer. Computers with microphones and speakers are now almost universally available. Virginia Brogan, a speech pathologist who is a partner with Dr. Schwartz at Accent Services, contrasted this equipment with earlier tools.
 "Tape recorders were a major step forward for grammar and vocabulary, and for someone who has a good ear," she said. "For a visual learner, it's a problem." The computer, on the other hand, can give visual input to someone working on an aural task.
 But the computer is only a tool, and Dr. Schwartz has found that the software, which was developed in part with a grant from the United States Department of Education, is most useful with an instructor to run it. And a speech professional's time tends to cost more than a piano teacher's or even a plumber's: Accent Services charges about $125 an hour, and students usually take an hour or two a week. Most are professional people, like doctors or engineers.
 It also takes repeated sessions for the lessons to sink in, instructors say. But, said Ms. Brogan, "At 18 to 25 hours, it all gels."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 10, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article in the special Education Life section last Sunday about computer-based programs to help Asians with English pronunciation misstated the profession of Virginia Brogan, a partner in Accent Services of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. She is a multimedia specialist with a degree in anthropology, not a speech pathologist.
The article also referred erroneously to Tashkent, the native city of one program developer. It is the capital of Uzbekistan, not part of Russia.

HEADLINE: Execution Set for Tuesday Stirs Debate in California;
Appeal Says Defense Missed Flaws in Case

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Nearly two decades after California reinstated capital punishment and more than five years after it resumed putting convicted criminals to death, the state's especially long and anguished fight over the issue finally seemed settled.
 
 In recent weeks, however, plans to execute a 42-year-old former boat repairman for the rape and murder of a young woman in Laguna Beach in 1981 have stirred new polemics in the state that has the most death row inmates in the country.
 The fate that awaits the convict, Thomas M. Thompson, has become almost familiar here. Barring a last-minute stay, Mr. Thompson will be strapped to a gurney at San Quentin State Prison and killed by a lethal injection of potassium chloride at 12:01 A.M. on Tuesday.
 Yet unlike the four men who have been executed in California since 1992 and most of the other 443 people who sit on its death row, Mr. Thompson had no prior criminal record. His supporters say he was given in inadequate courtroom defense. And almost 15 years after his conviction, there is still debate over his guilt.
 "This case leaves me with a very unsettling feeling in the pit of my stomach," said Donald H. Heller, a Sacramento lawyer who wrote the death-penalty initiative that was approved in 1978 with the support of 82 percent of the state's voters. "I've not had that feeling before with any other case in California."
 Others see the case in a very different light. Among them is the Governor, Pete Wilson, who flatly rejected Mr. Thompson's plea for clemency, saying "his claims of innocence are built on sand."
 At a hearing on Friday before the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, Mr. Thompson's lawyers did not argue his innocence. Rather, they asked the court to stay his execution on the ground that he had been ineffectually represented in trial and that prosecutors had committed misconduct by using contradictory arguments to convict Mr. Thompson and his accomplice, David Leitch, in separate proceedings.
 In an earlier motion, Mr. Thompson's lawyers also petitioned the State Supreme Court for a new trial on the basis of evidence that they say was suppressed for 15 years: Mr. Leitch's statements to his lawyers that he walked in on Mr. Thompson and the victim, Ginger Fleischli, as they engaged a consensual sex.
 Mr. Thompson had always denied raping Miss Fleischli, 20, and it was his conviction for rape that added "special circumstances" to the murder and landed him on death row. Lawyers for Mr. Thompson said that the authorities had known of Mr. Leitch's account but that they never made it available to Mr. Thompson's defense.
 "The question is, 'Did a rape occur?' " one of the Ninth Circuit judges, Stephen Reinhardt, said on Friday. "It not, he cannot be executed."
 In what will most likely be a record year for capital punishment in the United States, the pace with which death-penalty cases are being processed in California is just beginning to quicken.
 Before 1986, the State Supreme Court under Chief Justice Rose E. Bird reversed 64 of 68 death sentences that came before it. But Chief Justice Bird was swept from office that fall, and since executions resumed in 1992, opinion polls have shown its public support in the state ebbing only slightly from a high of more than 80 percent. Until Mr. Thompson began to exhaust his appeals, there was little new hint of unease with the penalty.
 At the time of Ginger Fleischli's murder, Mr. Thompson and Mr. Leitch had been sharing a modest apartment in Laguna Beach; they had met only three weeks earlier. Mr. Thompson, an Army veteran who once worked as a fire-department photographer, was scraping by doing carpentry and repairing boats. Mr. Leitch was unemployed and recently divorced.
 Miss Fleischli had dated Mr. Leitch briefly before his marriage and she moved in with him briefly after it broke up. A few weeks before her death, however, she called a Laguna Beach police officer to help her move out, telling him that Mr. Leitch had threatened to kill her.
 Miss Fleischli then moved in with Mr. Leitch's ex-wife, Tracy. The relationships remained vague enough that after the two women bumped into the two men at a restaurant on Sept. 11, 1981, the four went out together for drinks.
 David Leitch left with Tracy Leitch, and Miss Fleischli drove to Mr. Thompson's aparmtent with him and another man. But Ms. Leitch would later testify that before the group split up, Miss Fleischli had asked her, "Do you think David would have Tom kill me?"
 Miss Fleischli was found three days later in a shallow grave at a nursery in Irvine. She had bled to death after being stabbed five times in the head.
 Mr. Thompson claimed that he had had sex with Miss Fleischli and then fallen asleep soundly enough that he was not awakened by her violent murder five feet away.
 At Mr. Thompson's trial, the proscecutors said he had raped her and then killed her to cover up the rape. But in winning Mr. Leitch's conviction for second-degree murder in 1985, the prosecutors argued that rape was not the motive; they said Mr. Thompson killed the young woman on orders from Mr. Leitch, who thought she would interfere with his efforts to reconcile with his wife. (Mr. Leitch remains in prison, serving a sentence of 15 years to life.)
 In their appeal, Mr. Thompson's lawyers argued that his trial lawyer had failed to challenge obvious flaws in the state's case: uncertain physical evidence of a rape, and a pair of dubious jail-house informers who testified that Mr. Thompson had confessed to them.
 In March, a Federal District judge in Los Angeles, Richard A. Gadbois Jr., agreed with Mr. Thompson's lawyers, reversed his conviction for rape and overturned his death sentence.
 Weeks later, though, a three-judge panel of the Ninth Circuit reversed Judge Gadbois's decision, saying the trial lawyer's incompetence had made no difference in the outcome.
 For the Ninth Circuit to change its mind now, said a Deputy State Attorney General, Holly Wilkens, it "must be convinced that an innocent man is about to be executed."
 The 11-judge panel has until Monday to decide the case.

Pete Wilson of California, left, rejected a plea for clemency from Mr. Thompson, who is scheduled to be executed on Tuesday. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Not Drinking: A Love Story

BYLINE: By Valerie Sayers; Valerie Sayers is a professor of English at the University of Notre Dame. Her latest novel is "Brain Fever."

 BODY:

ROUND ROCK
 By Michelle Huneven.
 296 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $24. 
 MICHELLE HUNEVEN has found an apt form for her immensely likable first novel: to tell the story of two recovering alcoholics, she uses an omniscient narrator with a clear, authoritative voice. Clarity and higher authority, the reader comes to see, are important concepts in this book. While it is not exactly a 12-step tale, "Round Rock" borrows from Alcoholics Anonymous an insistence on facing sad truths in the past and then getting on, one day at a time, with the rest of life.
The two men in question are Red Ray, a lawyer and founder of the Round Rock Farm for Recovering Alcoholics in California's Santa Bernita Valley, and Lewis Fletcher, a graduate student who, before arriving at Round Rock, has been collecting incompletes and sleeping in his professor's garage. In turn, they become involved with Libby Daw, a violinist living in a trailer near Round Rock.
Huneven gives her readers a strong sense of the Santa Bernita Valley, which is defined by the Rito River and the citrus groves that cover the countryside. In the valley, the irrigation ditches sometimes flow uphill and so, the novel's prologue hints, does life. Yet some aspects of the landscape are said to have therapeutic powers, particularly rocks from the river that are "perfectly, naturally, remarkably round!" The phrase, and its exclamation point, give a good sense of Huneven's straightforward prose, as well as her suggestion that coming to terms with the physical world is a crucial element of spiritual healing.
In such a climate, healing often seems elusive. Red has been sober for years, but his life as director of Round Rock is sometimes lonely, filled with self-doubt. Lewis cannot admit, at first, that he is an alcoholic. And once he does leave his drinking life, he finds it hard to attach himself to any life at all. (He has studied "inscape and individuation" in Gerard Manley Hopkins, but has difficulty locating his own interior.) In this age of the sympathetic character, it's delightful to see how unlikable Lewis can be. He is needy, selfish, immature -- in other words, real -- and his bad-boy stunts provide the early stretches of the novel with dramatic tension and the hope of forgiveness.
Libby, the object of the two men's affections, has recently been abandoned by her husband. Her open, honest face, which suggests the possibility of strong attachment, both attracts and terrifies them. Deftly shifting the narrative's focus from one character to another, Huneven lays bare these three searching souls. One of the novel's happy strengths is its depiction of their sex lives: Huneven's forthright language comes in especially handy here.
Forthright language is also used to describe the characters' spiritual lives, and gradually it becomes clear that spirituality will provide the underpinning of their stories. Lewis, an unapologetic atheist as the book opens, prays recklessly and profanely by its end. The reader also learns that Red has gone through a funny (and very Californian) series of spiritual quests. Huneven is matter-of-fact about her characters' grabs for God and about A.A.'s belief in a higher power. The search for a purposeful life, she reminds us, does not happen in a spiritual vacuum, and it does not necessarily happen within the confines of organized religion.
Nor does healing happen in a cultural vacuum. (It is no coincidence that Lewis is pursuing a doctorate in cultural history.) The valley's class structure is shaped by the wealth of the growers (one refers to the farm workers as "my Mexicans") and the economic struggles of the workers. One of the novel's most tantalizing characters is David Ibanez, a target of wealthy white prejudice and a practitioner of Mexican healing arts. Indeed, the book would be stronger if his presence -- accompanied as it is by an emphasis on tradition and ritual, as well as politics -- were more fully established earlier. And Huneven's introduction of many new characters, especially Lewis's friends and lovers, two-thirds of the way through the book produces a small patch of mundane, literal storytelling in an otherwise rich and tightly constructed narrative.
"Round Rock" uses metaphor gracefully and simply. Happy Yolanda's, a local bar, is described as a place with "no gimmicks," which makes it akin to Huneven's writing. Like that other West Coast chronicler of struggling Americans, Raymond Carver, she's determined to tell the story straight. She is not interested in literary pretension or post-modern razzle-dazzle, but in achieving a measure of truth -- and her generous, engaging novel does just that.

HEADLINE: The Iranians Confirm A Moderate As President

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Mohammed Khatami, a moderate Islamic cleric overwhelmingly elected after promising Iranians social and political change, was confirmed today as the country's President.
During a religious ceremony before his swearing-in before Iran's Parliament on Monday, Mr. Khatami said that Iran "wanted peaceful coexistence with the world." 
 "The message of our revolution is the message of spirituality, peace and security," he said, referring to the 1979 Islamic revolution in a brief speech before hundreds of ministers and senior officials sitting cross-legged on a carpeted floor.
But he added that in pursuing those goals Iran would "oppose the high-handedness of certain big countries," a thinly veiled reference to the United States.
Since sweeping to power with 69 percent of the vote in May, Mr. Khatami has been watched closely in the West for signs that he might moderate the hard-line policies of Iran's ruling clerics.
American officials have said that any warming of ties would depend first on changes in Teheran. Specifically, they have warned Iran against supporting terrorism, scuttling peace efforts in the Middle East and pursuing nuclear weapons.
While some foreign ambassadors came to the ceremony today, representatives from European Union countries did not attend. Nearly all European Union countries recalled their ambassadors after a German court ruling in April that implicated top Iranian leaders in political assassinations in Berlin.
Most of the 20 million voters who supported Mr. Khatami, a former culture minister, were younger Iranians dissatisified with Iran's strict social code and ailing economy. But the new President will nonetheless face a formidable challenge from the ultra-conservatives who still dominate Iran's Parliament.
The hard-liners are already preparing a challenge to Mr. Khatami's choice of Cabinet ministers, who for the first time are expected to include women. The ceremony today was a reminder that much real power in Iran resides with the ruling clerics. The outgoing President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, read the confirmation of Mr. Khatami on behalf of Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khamenei. All the men wore the turbans and flowing robes of clerics.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 637 words

HEADLINE: Bennett A. Brown, 68, Southern Banking Executive

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Bennett A. Brown, a captain of Southern banking who navigated through the financial shoals of bad real estate loans and interstate mergers, died on Saturday morning at Emory University Hospital in Atlanta. He was 68.
Lung cancer was diagnosed in Mr. Brown a year ago. 
 He served as chief executive of the Citizens and Southern National Bank of Atlanta from 1978 to 1991, when the bank acceded to a takeover offer from the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C. Mr. Brown served as chairman of the combined company, renamed Nationsbank, through 1992.
Through the 1960's and 70's, Citizens and Southern had been the largest and most flamboyant bank in the South. But its loose real estate lending practices sent the bank to the brink of failure in the recession of the mid-1970's. The problems lingered and the bank was under close regulatory scrutiny in 1978, when Mr. Brown was named acting chairman. The appointment was meant to be temporary, and a search was under way for an outsider to take the helm.
"The troubles were of such magnitude you could hardly describe it," said Larry Gellerstedt, a longtime member of the Citizens and Southern board. The board ultimately decided to give Mr. Brown the job permanently.
"It was so impressive to see how the management team and the people in the bank rallied behind Bennett; there was an air of euphoria," Mr. Gellerstedt recalled.
Mr. Brown clamped down on lending standards and nursed the bank back to health. In the 1980's, he led an acquisition spree, first buying smaller Georgia banks and later, when the law allowed, banks in Florida and South Carolina, as well. But Citizens and Southern's earlier troubles fostered a caution that caused it to fall behind other Southern banks, especially NCNB, which by then had become the biggest in the South.
In 1989, Citizens and Southern rebuffed an unsolicited takeover offer from NCNB. Mr. Brown was put off by Hugh L. McColl Jr., NCNB's brash and ambitious chairman, who announced the bid without ever speaking to him.
A few months later, Citizens and Southern agreed to merge with the Sovran Financial Corporation of Norfolk, Va., in what was then the largest bank merger in the United States. Mr. Brown remained chairman.
That merger hurt Citizens and Southern more than it helped it. The two partners never worked together well, and Sovran turned out to be full of bad real estate loans, this time in and around Washington.
Detecting weakness, Mr. McColl tried again to buy Citizens and Southern in 1991. This time, he tried to reach out to Mr. Brown in a private and friendly manner. Eventually, Mr. Brown agreed to the $4.3 billion takeover.
That deal created what would be renamed Nationsbank and was, at the time, the second-largest bank in the country. It has now fallen back to the fourth largest, but has continued to be one of the most aggressive banks in the country. After the merger took effect, Mr. Brown served as chairman of Nationsbank for a year although Mr. McColl remained chief executive.
Mr. Brown was born in Kinstree, S.C. After graduating from Presbyterian College in South Carolina, he served in the Army and then worked briefly at Chemical Bank in New York. He joined Citizens and Southern as a trainee in 1955, moving up through a series of jobs with increasing responsibilities.
Since retiring in 1992, he lived in Atlanta and on Pawleys Island, S.C.
Mr. Brown served as president of the Bankers Roundtable, a leading industry group, and of the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce.
He is survived by his wife, the former Mary Alice Rustin of Columbia, S.C.; three daughters, Charlotte Brown Dixon of Atlanta, Leila Brown Armknecht of Salt Lake City, and Katherine Brown Ohlhausen of Atlanta; a son, Bennett Alexander Brown 3d of Temple, Ga., and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Watch 800 Companies Stuff Themselves Into One Phone Booth;
In the Long-Distance Market, Lean And Mean Just Gets the Door Open

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Kenny Troutt got into the long-distance telephone business after the oil market went bust. In late 1988 he abandoned the petroleum fields for the discount grocery stores that dotted suburban Dallas almost as densely as dormant oil wells.
There, on sidewalks outside sliding glass doors he persuaded bargain-stalkers to pare their phone bills by signing up with a long-distance company few of them had ever heard of. 
 Mr. Troutt isn't haunting strip malls and church socials anymore. His company, Excel Communications Inc., sold about $1.1 billion worth of telephone time in 1996 and this year is poised to become the sixth-largest long-distance company in the nation.
Excel is only one of the biggest of the more than 800 companies that have pried into the $82 billion long-distance business since deregulation in 1984, following the breakup of the AT&T Corporation.
Few of the new carriers have done as well as Excel, which has grown on the back of a commissioned, part-time sales force dedicated to winning over friends and family. But most of these new competitors have turned a healthy profit while whittling AT&T's market share to less than 50 percent.
"I was looking for something that was sort of recession-proof," Mr. Troutt said in a recent telephone interview. "I was in oil when oil was $8 a barrel and in construction when interest rates were 20 percent. I was looking for something everyone used, and where you could build a customer base -- and if it was succesful you could take it nationwide and even worldwide. And my brother said, 'Hey, the communications business would be a great opportunity.' "
But the fat years seem near their end; squeezing into the crowded long-distance market is becoming possible only for the slimmest of players and for those with bulging muscles of capital strong enough to push aside competitors far more tenacious than AT&T.
The demand for advanced data communications services continues to soar, fueled by the popularity of the Internet, and most of the top long-distance companies are profiting from it. But the lifeblood of the long-distance giants remains standard interstate phone service.
Even as Americans spend more time on the telephone, declining rates are making profit margins thinner than the dimes many customers pay for a minute of conversation. And in a twist on customary economies of scale, niche long-distance companies that resell network time they buy from others are continuing to surge even as their suppliers, the bigger carriers, begin to stumble.
"I don't think there's any question the overall industry has slowed a bit, starting maybe at the back half of last year," said Gary Forsee, president of the long-distance division at the Sprint Corporation, the No. 3 long-distance carrier.
Long-distance companies rarely lose money, but the last two quarterly earnings reports for five of the six largest carriers (including Excel, which plans to complete an acquisition of Telco Communications Group Inc. this year) showed a drop in earnings per share, relative to corresponding periods a year earlier.
The exception was Worldcom Inc., the No. 4 long-distance carrier, which posted modest profits in the first half of this year after a large loss over the beginning of 1996. But Wall Street analysts are predicting lower earnings during the current quarter for all six of them.
Last week's earnings report from the MCI Communications Corporation, the No. 2 long-distance operator, was typical of the larger carriers. Earnings for the second quarter fell 6.7 percent from the corresponding 1996 period. Some of the loss stemmed from large new investments in the company's network.
But while the traffic carried on that network rose by 5.5 percent, down from an 8.2 percent increase in the first quarter, long-distance revenues increased by only 4.7 percent.
Excel's per-share earnings over the last two quarters declined by about 6.1 percent from the 1996 period.
"The transmission and the provisioning of long-distance service is pretty much a commodity operation, like grown wheat," said Frank Governali, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. "What's not a commodity is the way in which you distribute and sell the product, the wheat. Are you making Wonder Bread? Are you selling cake mix?"
Commodity is just about the last term that Gail McGovern, who runs AT&T's residential long-distance business, wants to hear applied to telephone service. Excluding toll calls carried by local phone companies, AT&T's share of the long-distance market fell to 47.9 percent from 90.1 percent between 1984 and last year, according to the Federal Communications Commission. One reason for the loss could be that AT&T's rates are routinely the highest in the industry.
The way to stanch the bleeding, Ms. McGovern said, is to reduce the emphasis on finding new customers and instead focus on retaining those who have not fled already. Slashing prices, she said, would not help.
"People are differentiating paper towels, toothpaste, water," she said. "You probably pay $2 for a bottle of Evian water."
So, the logic goes, there is no reason AT&T should not be able to persuade customers to pay a few more cents a minute to use AT&T, confident in the knowledge that they are getting a superior product -- and a vital one.
"People probably touch AT&T's products and services more often than they touch water," Ms. McGovern said. "Probably the only thing that people consume more than communications is air. We can command a price premium because we invest in innovation and have an R & D program that helps customers enrich their lives."
By way of example Ms. McGovern pointed to new AT&T long-distance enhancements that are meant to enhance sound quality; to allow a customer's bill to be organized by sub-accounts and to allow automatic redialing of a busy number.
One reason AT&T does not want to play the pricing game may be that the company cannot afford it. The company's cost structure is one of the most weighty in the industry.
Despite reducing its overall selling, general and administrative costs by 11.5 percent since 1992, AT&T still spent $113,390 per employee on such costs in 1996, according to a recent report from Arthur Andersen, the consulting firm. That compared with $90,947 at MCI, $79,143 at Excel, $65,792 at Sprint and $63,769 at Worldcom. AT&T has said it intends to reduce costs by an additional $2.6 billion this year.
If any set of companies is responsible for AT&T's position in the market, it is not big-name competitors -- MCI, Sprint, and in the business market Worldcom; rather, it is the gaggle of relatively obscure companies that buy or lease network time in bulk from major carriers and resell it at a markup.
Companies other than the four largest -- AT&T, MCI, Sprint and Worldcom -- have increased their share of the market to 17 percent last year from 2.6 percent in 1984.
In the market serving small and medium-sized businesses, fast-growing companies like LCI International Inc. and the American subsidiary of Cable and Wireless of Britain have used such a resale strategy to complement their own networks. The Frontier Corporation, a large carrier that is more balanced between business and residential customers, has done so as well, though it has struggled recently.
The most prolific resellers in the residential market, besides Excel, have been what are known as the dial-around companies, which have blanketed the country with direct mail advertisements urging customers to dial a five-digit code to receive low rates, often 10 cents a minute.
Unlike companies like Excel, which usually require users to switch their default long-distance carrier, the dial-around companies allow users to keep their provider.
"There is a great deal of hesitation on the part of the typical consumer to give up their subscriber service because it's what they're used to," said Al Beach, director of consumer marketing for Vartec Telecom Inc., which will become the No. 1 dial-around provider once Excel completes its acquisition of Telco.
Vartec's long-distance revenue increased to $470 million last year from $107 million in 1994, according to the F.C.C.. The company is projecting $1 billion in sales this year.
To beat back the resellers, AT&T, MCI and Sprint are counting on their entry into the $100 billion local telephone market. Of the three, only MCI has registered market-share growth recently, creeping to 20 percent from 19.7 percent last year. Sprint is at the same position in the market, 9.7 percent, that it was in 1990.
That is the kind of competitive urge that the architects of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 hoped to see when they provided ways for long-distance companies to begin offering local service.
But they also provided ways for the local phone companies to move into the overstuffed long-distance market. The six regional Bell local telephone companies, with a combined market value of about $212 billion, are themselves set to wade into the long-distance market, with capital resources that outweigh those of the six largest long-distance companies, which are valued at a combined $134 billion.
And, since most technology and financial analysts consider local telephone markets a far more complex technical and business environment than its long-distance counterpart, many predict that the regional Bells will win as much as 20 percent of the country's long-distance business within five years -- but far fewer believe that the long-distance companies will win a comparable share of the local market.
The long-distance companies' bid to offer local service is "definitely a defensive strategy," said Steve Korba, an analyst at Northern Business Information. "Let's face it, you're dealing with a highly subsidized segment called residence, which is mostly under cost. They have to bite the bullet to hold onto their core business."
But the bullet might not taste so bad. If the free-for-all contemplated by the Telecommunications Act begins in earnest over the next few years, almost every telecommunications company is going to lose share in its core market in exchange for opportunities elsewhere, analysts said.
"AT&T's share slippage has only just begun," said Bryan Van Dussen, a telecommunications analyst at the Yankee Group, a consulting firm in Boston. "When the regional Bell telephone companies get into in-region long-distance, the long-distance companies' market share is going to drop precipitously, no matter what value or service propositions they argue."

HEADLINE: Even Titles Are Flexible as U.S. Magazines Adapt to Foreign Ways

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
When Conde Nast Traveler starts its British edition in October, alert readers may notice one difference right away: "Traveler" is to be spelled with two l's, the way the British prefer.
Inside, there will be differences, too, with the types of articles that are deemed important to Britons. "There really is a hole in that market and Conde Nast Traveller will step right into it," said Lisa Henriques, the publisher of the original. Hawaii might not receive the same coverage as the American magazine provides, she said, but other destinations more popular with British travelers -- Provence, perhaps, or the Himalayas -- will fill the space. 
 Conde Nast Traveller is but one of a proliferation of exported American magazines that are altered in language and content, sometimes only slightly and in other cases radically, to appeal to readers as wide ranging as the South African residential elite (House and Garden, a Conde Nast title), the fashion-conscious, upwardly mobile European woman (Glamour, also a Conde Nast magazine) and the emerging-markets consumer (Buenhogar, as Good Housekeeping, a Hearst title, is known in Latin America). Then there are the post-Iron Curtain woman who wants to have it all (Polish Cosmopolitan) and the Teutonic self-improvement seeker (the German edition of Men's Health, a Rodale Press publication).
"If you're just thinking Manhattan, you're dead," said Judy Price, the president of Avenue Magazine Inc., which publishes Avenue, a glossy life-style magazine with local editions in China, France, Japan and Spain that are published in the languages of those countries. "You have to think globally."
That thinking, said to be hugely profitable though few companies will release figures, has required normally identity-conscious American publishers to bow to the tastes of each area, relying on either joint-venture partners or licensing their titles to companies that retain most of the control over content.
The activity has built at a fevered pace, with the Hearst Corporation starting five overseas editions of Cosmopolitan alone this year, for a total of 33 Cosmos worldwide and nearly 100 editions over all, counting all nine Hearst titles. Reader's Digest has another huge effort overseas, with 48 editions in 19 languages that are sold to 27 million readers, nearly twice the magazine's 15 million American readers. Conde Nast, whose magazines are owned by Advance Publications, is starting 7 titles this year to bring its total to 39.
"The rest of the world has started to catch up to the West in economic development and in its thirst for information and advertised products," said Jonathan Newhouse, the chairman of Conde Nast International.
A request by an advertiser prompted the creation of at least one foreign edition of a Conde Nast magazine. "The president of Estee Lauder International came to us and said, 'Why don't you launch Vogue in Korea? We need Vogue in Korea to market our products,' " Mr. Newhouse recalled. Last year, Korean Vogue appeared.
These days, the market appears to be entering a secondary phase, in which American publishers are talking seriously about buying foreign-owned magazines -- something international media companies did in the United States years ago.
"Traditionally, U.S. publishers have been very reluctant to partner with companies in foreign markets," says Marco Sodi, a managing director at Veronis Suhler & Associates, the media mergers and acquisition firm. "But through licenses and start-ups they have learned they can be quite successful in those markets. For the most part, they are able to buy 100 percent of these foreign companies. It's about time they do."
Out in front of this trend is Hearst and its Hearst Magazines International.
"We're embarking on a program of investment and acquisition," said George J. Green, president of Hearst Magazines International. "We do think we could invest in some of our partners and at the same time in other publishers with other kinds of titles. And we've been given whatever resources we need."
Hearst is so bullish overseas that Mr. Green and others in the company anticipate that international profits will account for 50 percent of the magazine unit's earnings within a few years, double the current 25 percent.
Investing heavily in international publications represents a sharp switch in Hearst's strategy, which has been to start up magazines as cheaply as possible, using mostly local labor in the foreign editions and overseeing them from New York.
Total ownership of overseas publications appears to make the most sense for many American publishers, since they would have both total control and all the profits. Reader's Digest is looking at several potential acquisitions in Europe, said the worldwide editor in chief, Christopher Willcox, though he refused to be more specific. "We're looking for opportunities," he said.
One media giant that has not aggressively pursued the international publishing scene is the Time Warner unit Time Inc., which has made only a handful of acquisitions and minor forays into new markets.
"It's harder to do with news magazines," said Henry Muller, Time Inc.'s editorial director. "There are certain topics, like fashion, in which the interest doesn't shift all that much around the world. There are other topics -- and news is a good example -- that are very sensitive to the culture for which they're written."
Mr. Muller insisted that Time Inc. was interested in overseas publishing. It has licensed an Australian edition of People, called Who. A Chinese edition of Fortune is published through CCI Asia Pacific Ltd., an independent Hong Kong company. Time Inc. also owns Asia Week, an English-language news magazine based in Hong Kong. The company is printing supplements from Fortune, translated into Spanish, that are distributed in Latin American newspapers, and it may do the same with Time magazine. "We are open to trying different things in different places," Mr. Muller said. Last month, it acquired Wallpaper, a British interior-design magazine.
With all the growth, entire swaths of the globe remain untouched, usually markets, like most of Africa, that are widely held to be too small. And few publishers have succeeded in China.
"The Far East, for whatever reason, just scares a lot of people," said Mrs. Price, the president of Avenue, which got its Chinese edition going in 1994 through an alliance with an arm of the Chinese tourism ministry. It is not profitable, she added. But it needs time. "The reason we're all there, hunkered down in this community," she said, "is because we feel there's a future."

HEADLINE: Flake Tells Parishioners He'll Be All Theirs

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
By the time they arrived for the 8:30 service yesterday morning, the congregants had known for days that their minister would leave Congress. Nonetheless, when the Rev. Floyd H. Flake took to the pulpit yesterday to formally announce that he was resigning from the House of Representatives after 11 years, there was no shortage of drama and poignancy.
With his wife, Elaine, by his side wiping away tears, Mr. Flake -- the pastor of the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Jamaica, Queens, and a Democratic member of New York's Congressional delegation -- explained to the standing-room assembly of worshipers that he had grown weary of a routine of catching shuttle flights day after day to get home from Capitol Hill for the evening service at the church. With his congregation burgeoning and the church's enterprises expanding, he said, he wanted to devote more time to the work of being a pastor. 
 And so, with some members beaming, others weeping, and clearly overcome by emotion himself, Mr. Flake said he would leave the House, effective Oct. 15.
"So many of the nights that you saw me, I had already been to Washington all day long," he told the hushed, standing congregation. "After 11 years of going and coming and going and coming," he said, it had grown strenuous "to do what I've done in Congress and still be able to lead you in the building of this tremendous cathedral."
In the cavernous, $23 million cathedral that opened just a week ago, Mr. Flake's announcement brought together not just members of Allen A.M.E., community residents and friends from across the city, but also a wide array of politicians who rarely converge.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was in a front pew, clapping to the beat of the gospel music. Directly across the aisle was the Rev. Al Sharpton, a candidate in the Democratic primary for Mayor who does not share much political philosophy with the incumbent.
In the pew with Mr. Sharpton -- who received the loudest ovation among the guests who were introduced -- were another Democratic mayoral aspirant, Ruth W. Messinger; Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, and some of Mr. Flake's Congressional colleagues: Thomas J. Manton, Charles B. Rangel and Edolphus Towns. A few pews back was City Councilman Sal F. Albanese, another candidate in the Democratic primary for Mayor.
The wide array of politicians at the service was in large measure a testament to Mr. Flake's philosophy -- which he summarized often yesterday -- of leveraging his political power with both parties to gain economic clout for his church.
At a time when Mr. Flake's political influence is viewed widely as being at its zenith, his decision to resign is seen as a curiosity in political circles. Some have suggested that he is gearing up for a mayoral run in 2001, speculation he has vigorously denied.
Mr. Flake sought to take on the issue yesterday. "Most people believe that once you get there and you get the power, that you're there forever," he said. "But my love is that which I've been called to do," he said, referring to his work in the ministry.
Mr. Flake's decision has been greeted with divergent opinions by the members of his congregation. Several said they were torn between their desire to have Mr. Flake spend more time at Allen A.M.E., and the political influence he wields as a Congressman.
In a sermon filled with fiery oratory, Mr. Flake indicated that he would write books and that he planned to be a crusader, urging black politicians and others to rely less on government for solutions to social problems and more on developing economic programs for their communities.
"America has shifted, and we're still holding on to the rhetoric of the 1960's," Mr. Flake said to thunderous applause. "Yes, fight for welfare. But understand that, even before there was a welfare program, we were a people determined to make something out of our lives and to do something for ourselves."
The political scramble to succeed Mr. Flake in Congress was a prominent undercurrent yesterday.
Assemblyman Gregory W. Meeks attended the service at Allen A.M.E. -- as well as the earlier one at 6:30 -- before joining his colleagues in Albany who were deliberating on the state budget. "I will, in fact, be a candidate," he told reporters after the service. "We're beginning to put a campaign committee together."
Also in attendance was City Councilman Archie Spigner, who has said he is thinking of running.
In Albany, State Senator Alton Waldon Jr., who briefly held the 6th Congressional District seat in Congress a decade ago, said he had decided to run.
"I'm doing all that one has to do to run for Congress," Mr. Waldon said in a telephone interview. "I will be seeking the county's designation," he said, referring to the Queens Democratic Party organization. "But I will run no matter what. I don't have to have a learning curve. I know what to do."
Assemblywoman Barbara M. Clark sounded a lot like a candidate in a telephone interview from Albany, though she said she had not decided whether to run. "I'm very interested in it," she said. "There has been no black female in Congress from New York since Shirley Chisholm, and she's been out of office for 15 years. I feel a responsibility to try to change that."
Under the state's election law, the Governor will call a special election no sooner than 30 days after Mr. Flake leaves office. Several politicians have speculated that the election will likely be in January or February.
Mr. Flake said he had not decided whom to endorse, but left little doubt of his regard for Mr. Meeks, whose marriage ceremony he performed two weeks ago.
Speaking to reporters after the service, he mentioned all four candidates, saying he had worked closely with them over the years. But with Mr. Meeks at his side, Mr. Flake said the Assemblyman's candidacy "would probably make some sense for the continuity of what I've been doing."

HEADLINE: After Condemnations, Arafat Is Still a Target

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
In the welter of outrage and agony that has followed Wednesday's suicide bombings in a crowded Jerusalem market, the most piercing Israeli allegation has been that Yasir Arafat bears primary responsibility. The Israeli Government says the Palestinian leader has made angry or incendiary comments, failed to condemn such statements by others and refused to cooperate fully on security matters.
Israel's delegate to the United Nations, Dore Gold, told the PBS program "Newshour" on Wednesday night that "preliminary evidence" on the source of the bombing pointed to Hamas, the militant Palestinian group that opposes peace with Israel. "However, we're pointing the finger of blame to the Palestinian Authority," Mr. Gold said, referring to the governing body Mr. Arafat heads. 
 No one is suggesting that Mr. Arafat authorized or even gave a "green light" to the bombers. Mr. Arafat was quick to respond to the bombing, saying, "I condemn it completely, these terrorist activities, because it's against the peace process."
But Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has accused Mr. Arafat of doing little to stop violence, creating an atmosphere in which Islamic militants feel free to stage attacks.
Senior American officials say Mr. Arafat was "shocked" by the attack and understood that it was also aimed at him, even though they criticized his "inconsistent efforts" to crack down on terrorists.
"One can't expect 100 percent results when fighting terrorism," Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, said today on the CBS News program "Face the Nation." "But there can be a total, 100 percent unrelenting effort. I think the effort's been uneven. It has to intensify."
Mr. Gold asserted that after an American-brokered agreement in January on the withdrawal of Israeli troops from much of the West Bank city of Hebron, the Palestinian Authority "failed to fulfill any of its commitments," especially in security. "Had they fulfilled those commitments -- in our judgment -- this type of incident wouldn't have occurred," he said.
The Palestinians, in return, say Israel violates its commitments under the Oslo accords on greater Palestinian self-rule, creating political and economic despair in which terrorism thrives.
To bolster the Israeli case, Mr. Netanyahu's office and pro-Israel groups keep a running list of Palestinian statements that are considered incendiary, called "golden nuggets" by the Government Press Office, and make them available on the Internet.
But even Israeli officials and diplomats, speaking on promise of anonymity, say Mr. Arafat has been careful about his own public statements, especially this year, since the Hebron accords. Sometimes he has been angry or frustrated, but rarely incendiary. More problematic, they say, is his refusal to condemn inflammatory statements or actions by others, including his own cabinet ministers or the Voice of Palestine radio.
"While there is a level of Palestinian frustration that he, as their leader, must acknowledge," an Israeli diplomat said, "there are tacit messages. If he chooses not to say something, that carries messages, too."
Under the Hebron accords, the Palestinians promised to prevent incitement and hostile propaganda. More important than the words, Israelis say, is Mr. Arafat's open strategy of providing and withholding security cooperation as a form of leverage on Israel.
The Israelis have documented a decline in security cooperation from the Palestinians since the uproar over an Israeli housing project in Jerusalem in March, followed by a Hamas suicide bombing in Tel Aviv on March 21. The Palestinian Authority has released "dozens" of Hamas and other extremists from detention in what Israel calls "a revolving door policy," while failing to extradite terror suspects or confiscate illegal weapons.
They say Mr. Arafat has done nothing about allegations that the Palestinian police in the West Bank city of Nablus ordered attacks on Jews and that the Palestinian police commander for Gaza and the West Bank, Gen. Ghazi Jabali, is involved. On Thursday, Israel issued an arrest warrant for him.
"The police issue is very serious," said Robert Satloff, director of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. "Jabali is appointed by Arafat. For many months there is a pattern of Arafat letting a lot of things happen that he shouldn't, letting people out of jail, letting Hamas re-emerge as a legitimate political actor and letting violence go on in Hebron."
Senior State Department officials reject any simple connection between Mr. Arafat's statements, or even his efforts to keep up tension, and the bombings.
"You have to distinguish between violence, rioting and the Palestinian police not stopping rock throwers and the suicide bombers themselves," a senior official said. "There's a lot of the former Arafat could have fixed, but if the argument is that the former causes the latter, it's not necessarily true -- there were four suicide bombers before." He referred to the former Labor Government of Prime Minister Shimon Peres, who had a more cooperative relationship with Mr. Arafat.
"It's true Arafat uses security cooperation as leverage, but it's not true that he causes suicide bombers," the official said. "In fact, his ability to put international pressure on Israel is destroyed by these events."
The official conceded that Mr. Arafat's ambivalent attitude toward Hamas is damaging. "It's a problem when he can't -- or won't -- decide whether to co-opt them or destroy them," the official said of Hamas.
Even those sympathetic to Mr. Arafat, like Philip Mattar, director of the Institute for Palestine Studies here, acknowledge that he is riding a tiger, and sometimes maladroitly.
"He's in a tough position," Mr. Mattar said. "He's trying to find cells and future plans. But on the other hand, he can't be unhappy about some tension between the United States and Israel, since the political process so far has gotten him so little -- a few cities and some 2.8 percent of the occupied territories."
Israeli border closures, preventing Palestinians from working in Israel, are oppressive, Mr. Mattar said, and even American officials recognize that per capita income among Palestinians has dropped by a third. "So the economy is bad, and politically it looks bleak with Netanyahu, so they ask, 'What good is Oslo?' " he said. "Arafat has a hard time answering, and his negatives in the polls have increased tremendously."
Abroad, Mr. Arafat has lost some credibility through his indecision, his refusal to quickly condemn hostile or incendiary statements by others and reports of pervasive corruption in his cabinet. "The Palestinian diaspora is quite upset with the behavior of Arafat and Company," Mr. Mattar said. "We have dreams of a nation, yet this looks like another corrupt, inept regime."

HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY CHINA IS NOT READY FOR TRADE GROUP

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
After several months of slogging negotiations, Clinton Administration officials say they now doubt that they will reach broad agreement this year to admit China to the World Trade Organization, an accord they once hoped would be the centerpiece of President Jiang Zemin's state visit to Washington in October.
American officials had hoped that during talks in Beijing and Geneva that concluded on Friday, China would make a comprehensive offer to open its markets and allow foreign competitors to take on state-owned Chinese industries, which employ a majority of China's urban population. 
 But instead, officials from the United States and Europe said, China's negotiators offered piecemeal concessions. Now American officials are questioning whether Mr. Jiang, who is assembling a leadership team that will be formally endorsed at a major party congress just before his visit here, is ready to take the politically difficult steps required for his country to join the club of trading nations. Now, 131 countries and regions are members of the World Trade Organization -- with the notable exceptions of g China and Russia -- and Beijing has sharply criticized the West for setting conditions that it believes bar it from entry.
American officials say that China is unwilling to make large-scale concessions that would allow, for example, foreign companies to sell stock, deliver packages commercially and sell telecommunications services across the breadth of China. Currently, a number of companies are permitted to do these things, but only on an experimental basis in some cities.
"China's offers were tepid," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative who has supervised the delicate negotiations. "This was a view shared by a number of our trading partners," she said, even Japan and Europe, which have pressed for quicker admission for China under relaxed rules. "If China wishes its hopes to enter the W.T.O. to be a key element of the meeting with President Clinton, it must move quite rapidly now," she said. "But there is no indication at this juncture that China intends to move meaningfully forward."
Some of the comments made by Ms. Barshefsky's negotiating team and their Chinese counterparts in recent days were clearly part of the posturing that accompanies the complex economic negotiations that have become the 1990's successors to arms control talks. But the negotiations over market openings in China are particularly fraught with high-level politics in both capitals.
Chinese leaders have to weigh whether it is worth surrendering further control over the nation's economy to market forces in order to meet the entrance requirements for the World Trade Organization. And they have to consider the potential political costs if open competition -- and a phasing out of subsidies to state-run industries -- results in waves of unemployment.
In Washington, the current investigations into China's possible role in the 1996 Presidential and congressional campaigns have also lurked in the background. Several months ago, Chinese officials warned that they would not make a comprehensive trade offer if they believed that President Clinton could not enter serious negotiations that would also require concessions on the American side.
"They are worried that any American concession to China would result in someone charging that the Chinese were getting a favor for their contributions, even if they didn't make any contributions," one senior American official said recently. "And they may be right -- this is not a time when Clinton can make many horse trades."
China's intentions may also become clearer in a series of high-level visits by American officials to Beijing over the next several months. Administration officials say President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, is considering a trip there later this month, if the latest Middle East crisis recedes. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is planning his first trip there in late September, and that may turn out to be the last chance to settle on agreements that could be finalized during Mr. Jiang's state visit, the first by a top Chinese leader since the 1989 military crackdown on pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square.
But Ms. Barshefsky said she had no immediate plans to travel to China, despite an announcement by China's chief negotiator, Long Yongtu, that she was coming to Beijing soon. Her direct participation in the talks would be the surest sign that a deal was nearing.
Negotiators who have sat at the table with the Chinese for several weeks report that there has been modest progress. For example, the Chinese promised not to provide export subsidies for agricultural products. Although China offers no such subsidies now, American officials are concerned that as China's market opens, farmers will press the Government to help them send their products abroad.
China also agreed to eliminate import quotas for cars and minibuses -- which have kept American and Japanese makers from making vehicles in their existing factories and shipping them to China -- over 8 years instead of the 15 years they first offered. Currently, American auto manufacturers seeking to sell cars in China must enter joint ventures to build cars there, and agree to transfer significant manufacturing technology to their Chinese partners. While several carmakers have entered such arrangements, others have balked, saying China's demands are too high.
Chinese negotiators have also agreed to abolish quotas on the importation of other items as soon as the country is admitted to the World Trade Organization, and reduce tariffs on a range of goods, although American officials say the cuts are still insufficient.
At a meeting last month, President Clinton's economic advisers generally agreed that the most that could now be hoped for from Mr. Clinton's summit meeting with Mr. Jiang is a commitment to keep talking -- rather than a real accord.

The sorters, loaders and drivers of the United Parcel Service began walking off the job early this morning after the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced a strike for 185,000 union members at U.P.S. Negotiations had faltered over pensions and the use of part-time workers. 
 The action against U.P.S., the nation's largest shipping company, will create potential havoc for businesses across the United States in shipping millions of their packages. [Page A1.]
 
Big Change in Taxes on Home Sales
Under the tax bill approved by Congress, one of America's most cherished tax breaks -- the right to roll over the profits on your old home when you sell it and buy a new one -- is about to vanish. Replacing it will be a tax exemption that will benefit most homeowners, although some people will have to pay some unexpected taxes. [D5.]
