HEADLINE: U.P.S. Struck By Teamsters As Talks Fail

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The drivers, loaders and sorters of the United Parcel Service began walking off the job early this morning after the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced a strike by 185,000 union members at U.P.S. Negotiations had faltered over pensions and the use of part-time workers.
The action against U.P.S., the nation's largest shipping company, could create havoc for businesses across the United States in seeking to ship millions of packages. 
 The union's president, Ronald Carey, announced the strike about two hours before the deadline of 12:01 A.M. Eastern time and after emerging from almost three hours of intense but unsuccessful talks with a Federal mediator and officials from U.P.S.
"We have exhausted every possible approach to try to resolve the problem," Mr. Carey told reporters shortly after the talks broke off at the mediator's office in Washington. "At this point, it's just a waste of time."
The principal obstacles to an agreement have been the union's demand that U.P.S. hire more full-time workers and fewer part-timers and the company's demand to set up a new pension plan and pull out of the current multiemployer plan.
"It's about good jobs in America," Mr. Carey said. "It's about jobs that have some hope for the great American dream."
Shortly after midnight, teamsters appeared with picket signs at U.P.S. sites in New York City, Atlanta, Louisville and other cities, and company officials said they expected most of their 2,400 sites in 50 states to be affected.
Ken Sternad, a U.P.S. spokesman, said, "We are extremely disappointed the teamsters' leadership has discarded the interest of U.P.S. employees and customers by taking this unnecessary and irresponsible action."
With truck horns honking loudly and some 300 picketers walking alongside him, Pat Beam, a driver at the main U.P.S facility in Louisville, sounded committed to the strike, but not thrilled that it was happening.
"We got to do what we have to do," he said. "The company needs part-timers, but they really must do more to give them full-time jobs. When I came here 28 years ago, it was 85 percent full-timers and 15 percent part-timers. Now it's 60 percent part-timers."
Teamsters at worksites across the nation decided to walk out after letting pass a previous strike deadline, on Friday, because they believed then that they were making important progress in talks. But Mr. Carey indicated that he would not let today's strike deadline pass without action, unless there was major progress or a settlement.
After the strike was declared, the company's chief negotiator, David Murray, urged teamster leaders to let the rank-and-file vote on the U.P.S. offer. Company officials argued that that was the right thing to do if the union had its members' interests at heart.
Mr. Murray said U.P.S. would use its limited work force to deliver priority packages, including perishables and hospital shipments. He also said the company's overseas operations would not be affected.
"The economy is going to have 5 percent of its gross national product not moving," Mr. Murray said.
Shortly before the talks resumed last night, Mr. Carey said that if U.P.S. did not address the issues, "I assure you at 12:01, we'll be on strike."
John Calhoun Wells, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Services, had asked the two sides to resume talks last night -- the first time they had met since talks broke off late Friday. On Saturday, the union gave Mr. Wells what it called a comprehensive new offer that it asked him to present to U.P.S., which is based in Atlanta.
"We had some good discussions," Mr. Wells told reporters after the talks failed. "We just didn't make it."
Mr. Wells added, "We're motivated very strongly to try to reach a settlement and to try to prevent a strike because we understand that there are tens of thousands of people who would be directly impacted by a strike."
Of all the labor contracts up for negotiation this year, the U.P.S. agreement involves more workers. Although the teamsters have represented workers at U.P.S. since 1916, this is the first time the union is carrying out a nationwide strike against the company, although U.P.S. has been the target of several localized teamster walkouts.
Companies around the country have braced for a strike in recent days as they searched for alternative ways to ship their packages. Teamster officials predict that the strike will largely shut down U.P.S..
Many corporate executives have voiced fears that the strike will create chaos in the nation's package-shipping business because U.P.S., with daily volume of 12 million packages, handles four-fifths of the packages shipped by ground nationwide. Transportation experts say competitors like the United States Postal System and Federal Express will be hard put to handle the surge in business caused by the strike.
The Independent Pilots Association, which represents the 2,000 pilots at U.P.S. has vowed to honor the picket line, although the company says it will seek to use 138 managers who are trained as pilots to handle the company's overnight air deliveries. All told, U.P.S. has 302,000 employees nationwide, with more than 100,000 workers -- managers, administrators, sales officials and clerks -- not belonging to the teamsters.
At 12:30 this morning, a few picketers were outside the company's processing center at 43d Street and 11th Avenue in Manhattan. "I would never have thought U.P.S. would go this far," said Jimmy Walker, a union business agent. "No one can deal with a long strike."
A long strike could take a significant toll on union and management. The company's volume was already down 8 percent before the strike as many traditional customers handed their packages to U.P.S.'s competitors.
As for the workers, many will have to cope without the salaries of almost $800 a week for full-time drivers. The strikers will be eligible for strike benefits of $55 a week from their union.
Greg Sweatman, a 44-year-old driver at the U.P.S. sorting facility on Manhattan's West Side, said, "Things will be a little tight, but I can make ends meet."
Mr. Carey, a former U.P.S. driver in New York City, called the strike at a time when he is doing battle on other issues. Last December, he narrowly defeated James P. Hoffa in his race for a new five-year term, but Mr. Hoffa has asked the Federal official who oversaw the election to overturn it on the ground that the Carey campaign received more than $100,000 in contributions that prosecutors say were diverted from the union's funds.
Ever since negotiations began four months ago, teamster officials have said their main goal was to push U.P.S. to stop hiring so many part-time workers -- three-fifths of its employees work part-time and four-fifths of the employees hired during the four-year contract that just expired were part-timers.
Teamster officials repeatedly argued that U.P.S. did not pay part-time workers nearly enough to support a family. U.P.S. pays $9 an hour to part-time workers with two years' experience, while paying $19.95 an hour to full-time workers with the same experience.
The part-time issue was on workers' minds as they picketed last night at a depot in Atlanta. "I never would have thought I'd have been here 19 years and still working part-time," said Victor Fountain, who moves tractor-trailers around the site. "I don't understand why we can't have full-time jobs."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rusty Kramer, a United Parcel Service worker, hands out picket signs at a company building in Louisville, Ky., today, after a strike began at 12:01 A.M. The strike is expected to affect most of U.P.S.'s 2,400 sites. (Associated Press)(pg. A13)

HEADLINE: Drug Companies' Sales Pitch: 'Ask Your Doctor'

BYLINE: By ABIGAIL ZUGER 

 BODY:
DO you have signs of persistent anxiety? Are you irritable, restless, tense or easily fatigued?
It is not your doctor who wants to know; it is the folks at the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company. They spent almost $2 million in the first four months of 1997 asking these questions in a nationwide ad campaign to inform Americans that the prescription anti-anxiety drug Buspar could be just right for them. 
 Buspar is one of dozens of prescription drugs that are now being marketed directly to consumers in an escalating blitz of magazine, newspaper and television advertisements. The campaigns have intrigued patients, startled doctors and left policy makers and regulatory agencies scrambling to catch up.
Promoted drugs hail from all areas of medicine, from general practice with its runny noses, sinus congestion and heartburn, to far more specialized fields. Treatments for severe diabetes, AIDS, breast cancer and other conditions have all been touted in million-dollar advertising campaigns.
Inspired by evidence that patients are fertile ground for cultivating brand awareness in an ever more competitive market, pharmaceutical companies spent almost $600 million last year advertising prescription drugs over the heads of doctors directly to their patients. That is twice as much as they spent in 1995 and almost 10 times more than was spent in 1991, said Competitive Media Reporting, a company that tracks ad spending. Figures for the first months of 1997 suggest that the total will double again this year, making consumer ads an ever more significant fraction of the estimated $12 billion spent by the drug industry on advertising and promotion.
The companies are betting that if they encourage patients to ask their doctors to prescribe a particular drug, the doctors will comply. And there is good evidence that the companies are correct. In one widely quoted 1995 survey performed by the Scott-Levin consulting firm in Pennsylvania, 99 percent of doctors said they would prescribe or consider prescribing a specific drug requested by a patient. In another survey by the market research NPD Group, more than 40,000 consumers confirmed that prescription drug advertising had changed the way they took care of medical problems.
Some experts say that consumer advertising is accelerating because of changes in the climate of medical practice. Relationships between doctor and patient, they say, may no longer provide the necessary context and guidance for drug prescribing decisions.
In testimony at a 1995 hearing by the Food and Drug Administration, representatives of pharmaceutical companies urged the agency to relax its regulations governing advertising of prescription drugs. They said the advertisements made patients better advocates for their own health care in dealings with managed care organizations, doctors and hospitals.
"The simple fact is that the amount of direct-to-consumer advertising has mushroomed because people crave information about their health-care options," said Matthew Seymour of Common Health USA, an alliance of health care, marketing and communication companies. "Direct-to-consumer advertising plays a critical role in building bridges between consumers, health care providers, and the health care system."
"Advertising is information," said Nancy Buc, a spokeswoman for Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories. "Empowering the patient as well as the physician with information increases the likelihood that someone -- patient, friend or relative of the patent, or physician -- will get the dialogue started."
Other experts counter, however, that the advertisements do not empower patients so much as entangle them in misinformation. "I would be as adamant as anyone that a patient has to be well informed," said Dr. Sidney Wolfe of Public Citizen's Health Research Group in Washington. "But the information has to be accurate, and accurate information is not to be confused with direct-to-consumer advertising."
Most individual doctors are still cautiously feeling their way around the ads, new intruders into examining-room decisions.
"It's a complicated question, a paradox," said Dr. Mack Lipkin, a professor of medicine at New York University. While educating patients and getting them to ask questions has been proven to promote good health, he said, aggressive marketing campaigns may lead consumers to greatly misplaced enthusiasms.
"Promoted drugs might be outstanding ones, but they might not be," he said. "Usually my patients bring in the ad and ask what I think. I launch into an explanation of the evidence, and they're satisfied."
Dr. Thomas Lee, an internist and cardiologist in Boston, said: "The patients come in asking if they shouldn't be on something. And they are mildly suspicious that the physician has blown it by not treating them."
Dr. Lee once informed a patient requesting a specific treatment, "I am not a waiter in a restaurant." After a lengthy discussion -- "She actually smacked her hand on the table!" Dr. Lee recalls -- the patient got what she asked for. But another patient's specific requests he found himself rebutting "like a hockey goalie kicking away every shot on goal."
"Many of my colleagues feel that consumerism has gone too far, and is a significant danger to the doctor-patient relationship," Dr. Lee said. "We hate it when we see these full-page newspaper ads for drugs. It's not that we don't think patients have a right to know about these things, it's just that we feel that the drug manufacturers are creating demand where often there isn't a real need.
"Consumerism has a lot of pluses, but it has a dark side too. Patients have been put on edge by magazine articles and horror stories about managed care, and often don't see physicians for what they remain, the patient's best advocate."
Other physicians, particularly those caring for low-income patients, have yet to confront the issue.
"I have not been asked by any patient about the medications on TV," said Dr. David Schiedermayer, a Milwaukee internist who sees mostly indigent patients. "Most of my patients are more worried about trying to get the pills they are already supposed to be taking than asking for new ones."
Anticipating irritation in the medical community, some drug companies now actively seek to deflect it by warning doctors before an ad surfaces in their community.
Novartis Pharmaceuticals sent a mass mailing to doctors in the New York City area shortly before the appearance of ads for Lamisil, a drug for treating toenail fungus, (and before Novartis sponsored the inflation of a giant helium-filled foot in Central Park). Doctors were invited to review and comment on an advance copy of the ad. "We didn't want the doctors to have any surprises," said Judy Glova, a Novartis spokeswoman.
"Our M.D.'s really let us know if we don't warn them," agreed Diane Parks of Hoechst Marion Roussel, whose ad campaign for the antihistamine Allegra also occasioned premonitory "Dear Doctor" letters. "They let the drug reps have it in the middle of the waiting room."
Consumer watchdogs have begun to worry that the fledgling trends in consumer advertising may soon come to mimic disturbing patterns that have been noted in ads geared to physicians.
"I have little doubt that there are patients now in droves going to the doctor saying, "I saw an ad; let's try it," Dr. Wolfe said. "But if you go to your doctor with misleading information, and that doctor is already being misled by advertising, it's a recipe for a prescription being written."
Drug advertisements directed at physicians have sustained a variety of recent assaults on their integrity. A 1992 study published in Annals of Internal Medicine concluded that more than half the ads surveyed lacked key information on drug safety and side effects, and 44 percent might lead to prescribing mistakes.
A similar study late last year in The Journal of General Internal Medicine found that among the drugs publicized, only 10 percent were substantial improvements over other therapeutic choices.
In the 1995-1996 fiscal year, according to Dr. Wolfe, the Food and Drug Administration made more than 150 requests that drug companies pull physician-directed ads for false or misleading information.
Advertising directed at consumers has not yet faced similar criticism, although a small study sponsored by Consumers' Union last year concluded that fewer than half of 28 ads surveyed were honest about drug efficacy, and risk and benefit information.
The Food and Drug Administration encourages but does not require drug companies to submit consumer ads for clearance before the ads run. The agency does require that any advertising mentioning both a drug name and the condition it treats must also provide a "brief summary" that describes the benefits and risks of the drug, including side effects, interactions with other drugs, and contraindications.
This information often runs to thousands of words, difficult to include in some media presentations. Hence the surreal pharmaceutical-sponsored interludes on television or in the subways, in which clouds drift through a balmy blue sky or a man climbs a mountain to the accompaniment of nothing but a toll-free telephone number. Only consumers who call the number learn about the antihistamine behind the scenery.
A new television ad for the contraceptive injection Depo-Provera that was broadcast in four cities on July 9 is the first to provide an F.D.A.-approved brief summary on television, devoting a full minute to a scrolled list of indications, warnings and side effects.
Although some print ads rephrase the required technical information for consumers, most simply reprint the same information provided to doctors. Critics have pointed out that consumers are not trained to interpret this information and most probably ignore it.
When Katherine Riggs, a Harvard-educated lawyer in San Francisco, saw ads for a toenail fungus medication, she read them "with great interest," adding, "Then I went to my doctor and discovered this drug could really do a number on your liver, which I would never ever have figured out from the ads."
The other missing piece of information for consumers in the advertising is information on the drug's competitors. Dr. Wolfe pointed out that while doctors usually know about the alternatives to an advertised drug, consumers usually do not. And information on the comparative benefit of competing drugs is often hard to come by, Dr. Wolfe said. "Increasingly, head-to-head comparisons of drugs don't happen because of the messy possibility that the drug of interest won't be better," he said.
Many of the most widely marketed prescription drugs are so highly competitive because they are medically quite similar. But whether extensive advertising will drive the prices of these drugs up or down is still unclear.
For some doctors and patients, the ads have proven to be a great deal of talk about nothing. "People wind up a little disappointed," said Dr. David Rosenstreich, a Bronx allergist and immunologist. The tools of Dr. Rosenstreich's trade, the antihistamines and decongestants, accounted for three of the five most intensively marketed drugs in 1996. "They think they've found a great new drug, but it turns out it's the same as what they're on," he said.
For other doctors the ads serve a purpose. "Doctors are creatures of habit," said Dr. Jeffrey Gumprecht, a Manhattan internist. "We tend to treat things we suffer from ourselves and things we are used to treating. No one has time to ask every question about every symptom. So when people come in with a shopping list, maybe it's a good idea. They've gotten the message that some symptoms can be treated, that you don't have to live with them, and it can open up a reasonable discussion. It's quite useful. Doctors can use all the help they can get."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prescription drugs are now marketed directly to patients. "Get flexibility in your H.I.V. medication schedule," reads an ad. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)(pg. C1)

HEADLINE: Protecting Elephants By Hunting Them

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Matthew Scully ("Kill an Elephant, Save an Elephant," Op-Ed, Aug. 2) not only makes hunters sound like bon vivants with weapons who manage to bag an elephant just in time for cocktails, but also makes us believe that they are solely responsible for the elephant's diminished numbers in southern Africa. 
 The idea of shooting elephants for the economic development of rural villagers may sound reprehensible to Americans, but Campfire, a program in Zimbabwe under which elephant hunting is allowed as a means of raising local revenue, actually benefits elephant numbers. Drought, competition for land and poaching in Africa reduced the elephant population in Africa from 1.3 million in 1979 to less than 700,000 in 1987. Since the Campfire program was instituted in 1989, Zimbabwe's elephant population increased almost 42 percent, to more than 68,000 in 1995.
Mr. Scully implies that the Campfire program sanctions a Wild West shootout of elephants, but Campfire has strict quota controls on the number of elephants that can be hunted per year. In 1993, only 171 were killed.
 
ALLAN RICHARDS
Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Aug. 2, 1997

HEADLINE: China's Resistance to Fair Trade

 BODY:
American officials are disappointed that months of negotiations over whether to admit China to the World Trade Organization have failed to produce an agreement to open that country's booming economy to foreign imports and investment. But the Clinton Administration has wisely decided that it would rather let an artificial deadline -- President Jiang Zemin's visit to Washington in October -- slip than hastily invite China into the W.T.O. on the wrong terms.
China's economy relies heavily on companies owned and subsidized by the state. For admission to the W.T.O., a country must agree to sell its exports free of government subsidies and to permit imports to compete against its domestic products on commercially viable terms. They must also allow trading partners to monitor whether these fair-trade rules are obeyed. China resists these changes in part because they would prove wrenching. The Chinese would need to make government subsidies explicit and then agree to phase them out at a steady pace. That could throw huge numbers of Chinese out of work before a well-functioning labor market could steer them into new jobs. 
 It is uncertain how many market-based rules that govern tariffs, quotas, subsidies and other trade barriers China is willing to swallow. So far the Chinese have made only timid offers to the United States, which has assumed the lead in negotiating terms of China's entrance into the W.T.O.
Beijing's hesitation is unsurprising. It already reaps, without making concessions, the benefit of "most-favored-nation" status, in the United States and most other countries, which guarantees that exports from China are taxed no more than exports from any other country. Membership would therefore give the Chinese little economic advantage.
To Beijing, the lure of membership is political. President Jiang appears to covet the political glow of leading China, which will soon be the world's largest exporter, into its rightful place in the club of international traders. Membership is also important to those Chinese officials who want to embrace markets as the driving force of the economy. Once China is a member, these officials can use the threat of W.T.O. sanctions as a hammer to hasten reform. China may also anticipate the day when its exports bump against protectionist forces abroad and it will wish to invoke international sanctions from inside the W.T.O.
For the West's part, membership offers an effective way to side with Chinese reformers in converting China to an economy governed by rules subject to international judicial proceedings. The United States would no longer have to play the role of a bully threatening sanctions for Chinese trade violations and could instead let an international body resolve disputes. That would deflate trade and political tensions between the two countries.
Despite nearly a decade of negotiations, the fractured Chinese leadership appears unready to embrace a specific schedule of steeply lower tariffs and elimination of other trade barriers like restrictions on the right of foreign companies to sell products in China or of foreign investors to export products from China. The West will not demand that China turn itself into a clone of the West by privatizing state-owned companies. But it will demand that China, like other members of the World Trade Organization, end subsidies for state-owned companies that are used to promote exports and block imports. China has not made up its mind to accept the Trade Organization on its terms. The West can wait until it does.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: INDUSTRIES REVISIT GLOBAL WARMING

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: BONN, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Early in this decade, as the nations of the world negotiated a treaty to head off man-made global warming, industry lobbyists spoke with virtually one voice on the issue of climate change. They just said no -- no to any binding agreement obligating countries to control emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, and no to the very idea that there was serious cause for concern.
But times have changed, and the industry stance has changed as well. Though hard-liners still see no need to force anyone to limit emissions of greenhouse gases, a whole new spectrum of industry voices has joined the policy debate as businesses have examined more closely how they might win or lose. 
 At least one big crack has developed in the once-monolithic front presented by the producers of fossil fuels, like coal and oil, the very people who might be expected to hold out most strongly against any change.
At meetings here, where delegates from around the globe have gatheredunder the five-year-old treaty, these changes have surfaced as a more widespread willingness to accept the view of mainstream scientists that the problem is real and to take at least some action to solve it.
The heads of several large corporations met with President Clinton in Washington today to discuss the problem. The President has promised a strong American proposal for specific levels of greenhouse gas reductions that is still being drawn up.
In what may be the most telling change, British Petroleum, the world's third-largest oil company, broke ranks with other fossil fuel producers recently and announced that it believes that there is now enough scientific evidence to warrant concern about whether human activity -- primarily the burning of fossil fuels like coal, oil and natural gas -- is changing Earth's climate.
The time to contemplate action "is not when the link between greenhouse gases and climate change is conclusively proven, but when the possibility cannot be discounted and is taken seriously," John Browne, the company's chairman, said in a recent speech. British Petroleum, he said, "has reached that point."
Delegates to the meeting here are negotiating reductions in emissions of greenhouse gases. The most important of these is carbon dioxide, which is produced by burning fossil fuels. The negotiations will conclude in Kyoto, Japan, in December.
In the conference rooms, corridors and coffee bars of the Bonn Maritim Hotel, where the talks are taking place, the spectrum of industry opinion runs from hard-liners in the coal and oil industries who want no agreement in Kyoto to companies that produce alternatives to fossil fuels and want strong action immediately. In the middle is a broad group with a range of positions.
The dominant scientific view is that greenhouse gas emissions are probably responsible for at least part of a rise of 1 degree Fahrenheit in the average global temperature over the last century. Mainstream scientists predict that if emissions are not reduced, there will be a further rise of perhaps 3.5 degrees in the next century and more after that, with accompanying disruptions in climate. These include, for instance, more frequent and severe floods and droughts and a rise in the sea level. By comparison, the world has warmed by 5 to 9 degrees since the last ice age.
There is considerable uncertainty in these estimates. Nevertheless, Mr. Browne said in a telephone interview, "it seems to us it's time we should do something" about greenhouse gas emissions. "Just because there are uncertainties," he said, "it doesn't mean you just stand still and do nothing."
In that spirit, the company is formally collaborating with the Environmental Defense Fund, a private group, to test practical, market-based approaches to emission reduction. It is taking steps to control its own emissions and to develop alternative fuels and energy technologies. It is undertaking cooperative efforts to reduce emissions in developing countries. And it has assumed the rotating leadership of a broad Washington-based coalition of industry moderates on climate, many of them multinational companies.
The Clinton Administration is looking to the moderates for support as part of a campaign to win public acceptance of Mr. Clinton's pledge at the United Nations in June to seek strong action in Kyoto. Mr. Browne was one of the chief executives who discussed the subject with the President today.
Mr. Clinton's United Nations speech appears to have infused the climate debate with new zest -- and to have increased the lobbying from all points on the industry spectrum.
"The status of industry has dramatically changed," said Dan Esty, who directs the Yale University Center for Environmental Law and Policy, alluding to the period since the climate treaty was negotiated in 1992, when he was a member of the American negotiating team. "There was only one position in '92; today there is a flowering of industry positions." And back then, he said, "you didn't have a major industrial powerhouse like B.P. coming in and saying the time for action is now."
As views have proliferated, so have industry lobbyists. Connie Holmes, a lobbyist for the National Mining Association who opposes any but voluntary action to reduce greenhouse gases, said that when she began lobbying in 1988, there were "maybe three or four people" from industry doing the same. Here in Bonn, there are scores. Mrs. Holmes acknowledges that they consist of "a much broader range of people, a wide spectrum of opinion."
The shift in outlook should not be overstated, though. Mr. Browne, for instance, does not see climate change as a crisis and argues that there is time to head off the problem in a deliberate, step-by-step fashion that balances economic growth and environmental protection. Any targets and timetables for emission reduction, he says, should be realistic and achievable.
Further, industry is virtually unanimous in insisting that developing countries share in emission reductions. Otherwise, it fears, companies in industrialized countries will be at a competitive disadvantage. As of now, the richer countries are obligated under the treaty and subsequent international policy decisions to take the first steps.
Developing countries say those first steps have not been taken, since most of the richer countries have not even been able to fulfill a voluntary pledge under the treaty to stabilize emissions at 1990 levels.
Most companies and industry groups do not go as far in the direction of strong action as does an American organization called the Business Council for Sustainable Energy. Its members include several utilities -- whose leaders have found it in their interest to promote energy conservation, which reduces fossil-fuel burning and greenhouse gas emissions -- as well producers of solar power, wind power and natural gas. The last, while it is a fossil fuel, is viewed as a preferred alternative in the near term because it produces less carbon dioxide than coal or oil.
This group as a whole stands to benefit from controls on greenhouse emissions since its members put a premium on the more efficient use of energy. Michael Marvin, the group's executive director. said "we've got the technology right now" to produce energy more efficiently. Not surprisingly, his organization favors an early stabilization of greenhouse gas emissions, by 2005, followed by progressive reductions beginning in 2010.
A larger group, the Washington-based International Climate Change Partnership, now under the chairmanship of British Petroleum and including a wide range of industries, accepts the existence of a scientific consensus that some measure of man-made global warming is likely. "We think that appears to be relatively strong," said Kevin J. Fay, the group's executive director.
But, he said, climate change is a highly complex, long-term problem that need not necessarily be attacked with immediate targets and timetables for emission reductions. The Kyoto deadline is an artificial one, he said, adding that it is more important to achieve a lasting solution that allows both environmental protection and economic growth rather than a quick "feel good" result. There are probably many pathways by which the objective of heading off dangerous climatic change can be achieved, he said.
Still another group, consisting of electric utilities and represented by the Edison Electric Institute, is collaborating with the Administration to reduce greenhouse emissions by promoting more efficient use of electricity. This program, the institute says, has already brought significant reductions. All of this is voluntary, and the group favors that approach in any Kyoto agreement. It also is determined to get credit for reductions already achieved as part of such an agreement.
The hard-liners have not changed their position. Several of them are to be found in the Global Climate Coalition, a Washington-based lobbying group representing core energy and manufacturing industries. Gail McDonald, the new president of the coalition, formed zeros with her fingers when asked what her group would like to see happen in Kyoto.
The coalition continues to question the science of global warming. It argues that the impact of climate change is too uncertain and that the risk of economic damage is still too high to justify stronger, mandatory action.
The Administration's present course toward mandatory targets and timetables is "an unjustified rush to judgment," the coalition's chairman, William F. O'Keefe, told Congress recently. He likened it to driving too fast in a thick fog. This, he said, "risks a fatal crash."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.P.S. Strike Is Disruptive, But Vital Goods Arrive
A strike by 185,000 members of the teamsters' union idled most of the trucks of the United Parcel Service, slowing the movement of millions of packages and inconveniencing businesses and their customers.
The most essential goods -- food for grocery stores, medicine and medical supplies for hospitals -- appeared to be getting to their destinations. But the walkout came at a bad time for the book publishing industry, because this is the week that most trade publishers start shipping major titles for fall. [Page A14.] 

G.M. to Continue Stock Buyback
General Motors, moving to return more cash to shareholders, said that it would buy back another $2.5 billion of its stock -- following an initial repurchase of the same amount -- though it kept its dividend unchanged. [D5.]
 
Columbia/HCA Names President
Columbia/HCA Healthcare named a former top executive with the Hospital Corporation of America, Jack O. Bovender Jr., as its president and chief operating officer. [D2.]
 
Stocks Show Modest Gains
Despite rising interest rates, stocks rose. Retailers like Sears and Wal-Mart and technology companies like Intel and I.B.M. led the modest gains. The Dow industrials rose 4.41 points, to 8,198.45, and other indexes showed bigger gains. [D8.]
 
But bonds continued the slide that started on Friday, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury rising another two-hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.47 percent. [D15.]
 
Construction Spending Drops
Construction spending unexpectedly fell 1.1 percent in June to the lowest level since January, an annual rate of $591.5 billion, the Commerce Department said. Analysts had expected an increase of 1.6 percent. [D2.]
 
The I.M.F., in its assessment of the United States economy, recommended that the Federal Reserve raise short-term interest rates to stave off inflation. [D2.]
 
Yeltsin Adjusts the Ruble
In Russia, President Boris N. Yeltsin took what might seem to be an easier approach to countering inflation, in effect lopping three zeroes off the ruble in a redenomination of the currency. The exchange rate for new bills, above, will be approximately 6 rubles to the dollar, instead of 6,000; the underlying value of the currency, after adjusting for the redenomination, will not change. And the Government also ordered a delay in issuing the results of a privatization auction involving Norilsk Nickel, a metals company. [A3.]
 
The Internet Imitates TV
MCI and Progressive Networks, an Internet software company, are expected to announce a service that will permit thousands of computer users to simultaneously receive video broadcasts. [D20.]
 
Progress on Thai Rescue Deal
Thailand moved closer to the completion of a multibillion-dollar international rescue package as economic ministers approved details of an agreement with the I.M.F. [D4.]
 
Kia Gets Breathing Space
Creditors of the Kia Group of South Korea agreed to give the company two more months to settle its debts in an effort to avoid a bankruptcy. [D4.]
 
Health Care Changes in Tax Bill
The budget bill awaiting President Clinton's signature includes two new health insurance options that give Medicare beneficiaries greater freedom to choose their doctors and hospitals, but also exposes elderly patients to much higher costs. [A1.]

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Wants Federal Reserve To Increase Short-Term Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund has recommended that Federal Reserve policy makers raise short-term interest rates to stave off inflation, according to a statement released by the fund today.
The fund said that many on its 24-member executive board "cautioned that undue delay in tightening monetary policy could undermine the current expansion by increasing the risk that aggregate demand pressures would build." 
 These board members "took the view that a further, moderate and pre-emptive tightening was necessary to guard against the emergence of inflationary pressures."
Still, The I.M.F. statement praised the United States over all for its "skillful management of economic policies, which has yielded remarkable results." The "continued adept handling of monetary policy and further progress in reducing the budget deficit would establish a firm basis for sustaining the current economic expansion," the statement added.
The I.M.F. plays just an advisory role with the United States, because it and other leading industrial countries provide the bulk of the money used by the fund to assist nations with hard currency shortages and other economic difficulties.
The statement follows the fund's annual consultation with the United States Treasury Department. I.M.F. staff members met with Government economists and officials including the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, and the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan.
In a statement on the consultations released last month, the Treasury said the fund's assessment "highlights the strength of the Clinton Administration's economic record," though "we do not agree with every point" expressed by the organization.

HEADLINE: Stocks End Higher, With Dow Rising 4.41

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Despite rising interest rates, the stock market's major indexes ended higher yesterday, as investors apparently continued to believe in moderate inflation and temperate economic growth.
Retailers such as Sears, Roebuck & Company and Wal-Mart Stores and technology companies like Intel and I.B.M. led the modest gains. 
 After plodding through negative territory for most of the morning, the Dow Jones industrial average wound up with the smallest gain of the major market gauges, rising 4.41 points, to 8,198.45. Despite its lackluster performance yesterday, the Dow is still up more than 27 percent this year.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index led the market's advance, crossing the 1,600-point mark for the first time and ending with a rise of 11.12 points, to 1,605.45. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 3.16 points, to 950.30.
On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing issues barely outpaced decliners, 1,496 to 1,379. Volume was strong, with 456.4 million shares traded.
Yesterday's modest rally came although long-term interest rates, as measured by the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, have jumped nearly two-tenths of a percentage point since Friday.
That surge was prompted by economic reports Friday that showed stronger-than-expected job growth in July and by a sharp jump in the prices manufacturers paid to their suppliers.
Yesterday, the yield on the 30-year bond finished at 6.47 percent, up from 6.45 percent Friday.
For the most part equity investors remain bullish about corporate profits and the ability of the Federal Reserve to keep inflation in check while the economy continues to grow moderately. And, said Daniel Morgan, a research analyst at Noble Capital Management in Boca Raton, Fla., that means investors are still channeling cash into equity mutual funds.
As a result, portfolio managers remain reluctant to sit on the sidelines with cash in their coffers. And stock selloffs are seen as buying opportunities.
"They're afraid of being left behind, so when the index dips, they buy," Mr. Morgan said.
Following his own logic, Mr. Morgan bought I.B.M. last week at slightly more than 103 a share. It closed yesterday at 106 1/4 a share, up 1 1/2.
"Fundamentally, I can't see any reason the market should be derailed," said Jack Baker, head of equity trading at Furman Selz.
"The big picture is no or little inflation. The economy is performing well," Mr. Baker said. He added that once investors had digested the employment report, they continued buying. On Friday, the Dow was down as much as 118 points but then rallied to close off just 28 points.
Yesterday, Sears, Roebuck finished up 2 1/8 at 64 3/8. Todd Slater, an analyst with Lazard Freres, said that Sears, the nation's second-largest retailer, was reaping the benefits of improved business operations. The company should also benefit from the Montgomery Ward Holding Company's bankruptcy and the expected closing of about 100 Montgomery Ward stores. The chain had been a major rival of Sears in home appliance sales.
Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, was up 1 3/16, to 37 7/8.
Intel, the day's most active issue with more than 17.4 million shares traded, led the gains among technology issues, rising 3 1/8, to 96 3/4.
After matching its 52-week high of 64 1/2, General Motors dipped 1 13/16, to 62 5/8, as investors expressed disappointment that the auto maker did not increase its dividend. An announced share buyback by the company did little to appease investors' unhappiness, said Richard Hilgert, an equity analyst at Stifel Nicolaus & Company in St. Louis.
Yesterday's drop in the stock price was the first for G.M. in six trading sessions. On Friday, General Motors shares reached a high of 64 1/2.

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Fell 1.1% in June

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Construction spending unexpectedly fell 1.1 percent in June to the lowest level since January, the Commerce Department said today.
Spending decreased to an annual rate of $591.5 billion in June. That matched the average rate for the year's first half and was the lowest level since $577.1 billion in January. 
 Analysts had expected the report to show a rise of 1.6 percent.
The department, however, revised its statistics for May and April to show more strength than originally reported. May's spending was revised to show a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent, instead of the 1.8 percent decline reported previously, and the April figure was revised to show an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent, up from three-tenths of 1 percent.
The June report "indicates that construction spending ended the second quarter on a weak note, indicating little forward momentum going into the third quarter of the year," said Marilyn Schaja, money market economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York.
Cheryl Katz, senior economist at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, said before the report was released that "we do not look for residential investment to add much to overall economic growth, but rather that home sales remain near recent levels."
Today's report showed that spending on residential construction, which makes up almost half of the total figure, fell 1.2 percent in June, to an annual rate of $256.4 billion.
Still, the housing market over all made a positive contribution to growth in June. The Government reported last month that housing starts rose 4.8 percent during June, the first monthly increase since April, and analysts said starts were likely to rise further as declining mortgage rates attracted buyers.
Sales of new homes climbed 6.1 percent in June.
Today's report also showed that spending on commercial projects, like factories and warehouses, fell 2.8 percent in June, to a rate of $158.9 billion. Spending on public projects, including schools, prisons and sewer systems, increased seven-tenths of 1 percent, to a rate of $136.7 billion.
Last week, in its report on gross domestic product in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said fixed investment in nonresidential buildings rose 15.1 percent -- nearly four times the 4.1 percent gain in the first three months. Investment in residential buildings rose 5.6 percent, from 3.3 percent in the previous quarter, as mortgage rates fell.
Over all, the Government said that growth in the gross domestic product slowed to a 2.2 percent pace in the second quarter from a 4.9 percent rate in the first three months of the year.

HEADLINE: Japan Considers Opening the Veiled Corporate Ledger

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The word for an auditor in Japanese is "kansa-yaku." But people here jokingly call them "kansan-yaku," meaning a do-nothing job.
Pity the corporate auditor in Japan. The lack of respect for them in this country, and their lack of aggressiveness, shows. One-fifth of publicly traded Japanese companies have been involved in some sort of scandal in the last 10 years, according to the Japan Corporate Auditors Association. The scandal unfolding over the last few months involving payoffs by two big financial institutions, the Nomura Securities Company and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, to a racketeer are just the latest example of corporate corruption. 
 But the unprecedented punishments meted out last week -- which included the suspension of parts of their business for the rest of the year -- show that corporate Japan is under new pressure to clean up its act, especially as deregulation of the financial-services industry is getting closer.
Japan, of course, has promised changes before, and little has happened. But now, this country has promised to open its financial markets to more competition, akin to that in the United States and Britain. Japan's so-called Big Bang, scheduled to be completed by 2001, is aimed at revitalizing the uncompetitive financial-services industry and improving the meager returns earned on savings.
For the Big Bang not to turn into a big bust, analysts say, Japan must end widespread corruption and require companies to provide more accurate and abundant information to investors and regulators. People do not want to bet in a rigged casino.
The fact that deregulation will mean more Government oversight, not less, might be considered counterintuitive. But with markets less regulated, there will be presumably more complicated financial transactions and more chance for recklessness or crookedness.
The United States found this out the hard way when it deregulated the savings and loan business at the same time as Federal budget pressures led to a reduced number of banking examiners. The result was that many of the newly liberated savings and loan institutions went on a binge of reckless and sometimes illegal lending, precipitating a bad-debt crisis that required billions of dollars in taxpayer money to clean up.
Britain, too, having left regulation largely to the financial industry, is now strengthening Government oversight of markets in the wake of scandals, including the huge losses attributed to a rogue trader that brought down Barings.
"One of the most important preconditions is transparency," said Koyo Ozeki, director of the Tokyo office of IBCA Ltd., a British credit-rating agency. "Without that, whatever deregulation occurs, it will not create an efficient market."
That means that the Japanese Government will have to vastly strengthen its oversight of companies and its punishments for wrongdoing. It also means that companies will have to police themselves better.
Both steps are being started. The watchword in companies here these days is "kohporeto gabanansu," the Japanese pronunciation of corporate governance. Many companies are discussing how to modernize outdated accounting systems, install stronger internal controls and better serve shareholders, who until now have been considered almost a nuisance by corporate managers.
Indeed, the type of racketeer that Nomura Securities and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank paid off exists because Japanese companies do not really want to talk to their shareholders. These racketeers, known as sokaiya, extort money from companies by threatening to disrupt annual meetings and by taking up time airing corporate dirty laundry.
But if Japanese executives were not afraid of talking to shareholders and letting an annual meeting last more than 30 minutes, the sokaiya would have a harder time extracting payoffs.
Sokaiya are sometimes hired to intimidate shareholders into keeping silent. R. Taggart Murphy, a former investment banker in Tokyo and the author of books on Japanese finance, said that one reason the Finance Ministry made such a show of its punishment of Nomura and Dai-Ichi was to assure foreign investors, who as shareholders tend to be more vigilant than those here, that the Tokyo market is safe to play in.
Stil, change will be slow, and there is a chance that it will be overtaken by deregulation, which will let banks and brokers enter each other's business and offer new types of products.
"Since we were formerly in a system where a lot of things were de facto prohibited, we didn't have to set up rules," a Finance Ministry official said. Now, clear rules will be needed.
Japanese politicians are discussing raising penalties for financial crimes. In the United States, when Daiwa Bank was found to have tried to conceal a bond-trading scandal in its New York office from Federal regulators, it was fined $340 million. When Dai-Ichi Kangyo was recently found to have tried to conceal its loans to the racketeer, it was fined the equivalent of $4,300, the maximum allowable.
The insignificant size of such fines forced the Finance Ministry to punish Dai-Ichi by suspending some of its operations. Such suspensions must be used with caution because they also hurt blameless customers.
As for oversight, the Finance Ministry has only about 500 bank examiners, compared with about 7,800 in the American Federal system. A ministry official said there needed to be three or four times as many to allow annual inspections. There is likely to be a moderate increase next year, despite an austere national budget.
Japan next year will spin out its examiners from the Finance Ministry into a new agency, to separate those who police the industry from those who promote it. Now, there are often cozy relationships between inspectors and those they inspect.
Masao Miyamoto, a social critic who once worked for the Health and Welfare Ministry, recalled that when he inspected a hospital he would be picked up in the hospital's car, and given a tour of the city and free meals.
"I said I just wanted to do the inspection, go back to the hotel and read my book," he recalled. But hospital officials insisted he go out for a night of entertainment.
Traditionally, Japanese companies have been managed on behalf of their employees, not shareholders. The majority of a company's shares are likely to be held by banks and other companies for the purpose of maintaining a relationship, so there was little concern about shareholder returns and little fear of hostile takeovers.
The return on equity of Japanese companies averages roughly 4 percent, about one-fifth the level in the United States. Indeed, said Kathy Matsui, chief strategist for Goldman, Sachs in Tokyo, Japanese companies as a whole have not been earning back their total cost of capital, meaning that they have been reducing shareholder value.
Some companies have begun paying attention to return on equity. A few dozen companies, including the Toyota Motor Corporation, have begun to grant executives stock options, giving them an incentive to work to raise the stock price, a practice they once looked down upon as resulting in outrageous salaries for American managers.
Others are adopting Western-style management practices. Sony, for instance, has cut back the size of its board to 10 people from 38, and has included three outside directors. Most boards in Japan are made up of the top 30 to 50 managers, with no outsiders.
Paying more attention to shareholders will not by itself mean fewer scandals. But the changes in corporate governance being put into effect should have some influence.
For instance, accounting rules now under consideration would compel greater disclosure, making it harder for companies to sweep problems under the rug by burying losses in a subsidiary whose results are not consolidated with those of the parent company. In the longer term, companies that bought stocks at low prices years ago, and continued to value them on their books at those low levels, would have to declare the shares at market value. At times of corporate crisis, they would no longer be able to sell the shares and reap a huge one-time gain.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Slip Ahead Of New Issue

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices for Treasury securities sagged yesterday, pressured by weakness in the dollar against the Japanese yen, a large coming supply of new Government debt and the possibility that the economy is running on more cylinders than previously thought.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 13/32, to 101 31/32; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, rose to 6.47 percent, from 6.45 percent on Friday, when it leaped 16-hundredths of a percentage point because of a stronger-than-expected monthly report on the labor market. 
 The market continued to be concerned yesterday that the tightening job market might help to spur inflation -- and thus erode the value of bonds. Some analysts pointed to the strike at the United Parcel Service as evidence that wage pressures were increasing.
But Thomas E. Donne, vice president and senior portfolio manager at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, disagreed with that view. "The market looks at any strike as possibly raising wage pressures," he said. "But I don't see the U.P.S. strike over benefits and recent General Motors strikes over job security necessarily translating into large wage increases."
He attributed the bond market's drop in its last two sessions to other factors, including profit taking after a perception that the market had risen too quickly. The employment report last Friday was strong only in the term of payroll growth, Mr. Donne said, and did not indicate that labor costs were growing quickly.
Though the dollar rose against the German mark yesterday, it fell against the yen. The Japanese are still big investors in the Treasury market, and a weaker dollar makes United States debt less attractive to foreign investors.
Also weighing on the market was new supply, with the Government's quarterly refunding of debt this week. Prices often fall before Treasury auctions as dealers try to lower the prices on new securities, making it possible for quicker sales.
But, Mr. Donne said, "we are approaching a point where the reduction in the deficit could lead to lower issuance of government debt securities, which of course could have rates falling because there would not be a lot of supply to clear."
Traders will also closely watch reports on producer prices and retail sales next week, though both are expected to be market-friendly.
Still, Dave Shabelman, Treasury market analyst at Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, said that because the market would have all this news to digest, its upside potential would be restrained in the near term. "Even if the market comes through the auctions relatively unscathed, it still must contend with both inflation and retail sales data the following week, which will limit a recovery before then," he said.
Interest rates at yesterday's regular weekly bill auction increased modestly, but the results were as expected. The average rate for the three-month issue was 5.15 percent, up from 5.12 percent last week, while the six-month issue was 5.20 percent, up from 5.15 percent.
In when-issued trading ahead of today's $16 billion auction of a new three-year note, securities firms were offering them at a price to yield 6.01 percent. The $12 billion 10-year note to be auctioned tomorrow was offered at a price to yield 6.19 percent and the $10 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday, at a price to yield 6.44 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Expectations Germany Will Not Lift Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar touched another eight-year high against the mark yesterday and rose in most other currency dealings, buoyed by forecasts of further gains and diminished chances of higher German interest rates.
Weaker-than-expected industrial output data from Germany and expectations that German July unemployment data due tomorrow would show more jobless people persuaded currency traders that recent speculation of a rate increase by the Bundesbank was overdone. 
 Traders seeking to lock in profits from the dollar's nearly 7 percent gain against the mark last month pushed the United States currency back slightly in New York trading, and the dollar ended lower against the yen. But the underlying forces propelling the dollar higher remained intact.
Some traders also sold dollars after Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco and a member of the Fed's policy-making committee, said low American inflation was partly the result of a strong dollar, and "we can't expect the dollar to keep appreciating forever." But the impact of Mr. Parry's remarks at a speech in San Francisco was slight.
"It seems to be everyone's idea that the dollar's rise is going to continue, but you have to be reluctant to hold dollars at the highs," said John Hazelton, chief currency trader at Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company in New York. "Obviously there's some profit taking going on."
The dollar reached an intraday high of 1.8730 marks, the strongest since October 1989 and the second consecutive eight-year high, before retreating to settle at 1.8664 marks in New York, up from 1.8635 marks Friday. The dollar fell to 118.35 yen from 118.40 yen. The pound slipped to $1.6303 from $1.6318.
The dollar initially weakened in Asian dealings, partly in reaction to tough new currency restraints imposed by Malaysia's central bank meant to discourage speculation in the ringgit.
The move by Bank Negara Malaysia, which limited the amount of ringgit that banks could lend to overseas borrowers, helped increase the ringgit and other Asian currencies that have lost value against the dollar in recent weeks.

Panel Proposes Abolishing U.S. Immigration Agency
A Federal advisory panel has decided to recommend abolishing the embattled Immigration and Naturalization Service and assign its duties to other Government agencies in an effort to improve the nation's immigration system. The United States Commission on Immigration Reform is proposing that the Justice Department, the immigration service's parent agency, retain responsibility for controlling the border and removing illegal immigrants. The State Department, which now deals with visas at American embassies overseas, would handle immigration services and benefits, like citizenship requests. And the Labor Department, which now monitors wage and hour laws, would also enforce rules covering the hiring of foreign workers. A1

The budget bill awaiting President Clinton's signature includes two new health insurance options that give Medicare beneficiaries greater freedom to choose their doctors and hospitals, but it also exposes elderly patients to much higher costs. The options, which represent a radical departure from current Medicare policy, are likely to appeal to rugged individualists who resent Government interference with their medical care and can afford to pay more for it. HEADLINE: Honk if You Love-Hate the Wall;
Designed to Save Eardrums, Barriers On Expressway Get Less Hard on Eyes

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: JERICHO, N.Y., Aug. 4

 BODY:
Some people call the concrete slabs being built along the Long Island Expressway here the walls of Jericho, and there are many who would like to see them come tumbling down.
"I hate the wall. I hate it with a passion. I abhor it," said Gloria Zvinglis as she stood at her screen door in neighboring Syosset and shook her head at the new monolith towering over her front yard. "I feel like I'm being boxed in. I miss the sunsets." 
 But the walls, part of a 4.5-mile expansion of expressway noise barriers in eastern Nassau County and western Suffolk County, also have their fans.
"Now it's much better; I like this," said Gwang Oh, who lives across the road from a new wall in Jericho.
A neighbor, Syndee Perlman, said the wall has helped: "Before, it was so noisy I couldn't hear myself."
And Chisty Kamrul said, "It looks more private now."
One thing is certain about these latest walls, however. They look distinctively different from older models, reflecting a concerted effort by transportation officials to make them more appealing.
More than 1,300 miles of walls have sprouted along the nation's highways since a 1972 Federal environmental law fostered the building of noise barriers. But as the walls have risen, so has the debate over their cost and usefulness -- and complaints about their spreading a drab blight on the landscape.
The walls, most of them gray concrete masonry blocks or weathered planks, offer motorists all the visual charm of a drive past a penitentiary. But highway planners are trying to change that.
After consulting with local officials and community groups here, the state is installing precast concrete that looks like a wall of tan stone blocks. It has a raised rough surface and mortarlike grooves, topped by a dark red border. The other side, facing the adjacent properties, is a pinkish tan with a pattern like vertical wood slats.
"When they started putting up wooden barriers in Suffolk in 1991, we got a lot of calls that they were really ugly," said Mark Kulewicz, a traffic engineer for the Automobile Club of New York. "The response we're hearing to the two-toned walls is much more positive, maybe because people are more used to walls, and maybe because they really are more attractive."
Experimental barriers along Route 18 in East Brunswick, N.J., feature a "living wall," an earth mound with vines and shrubs. Another segment is made of recycled plastic and still another is wooden with clear plastic windows.
And in Phoenix, officials invited artists to create geometric and American Indian designs for the walls.
"More and more walls are being built, and more attention is being paid to esthetics," said El W. Angove, publisher of The Wall Journal. (He noted that his newsletter about sound barriers, with 1,800 subscribers, "is not to be confused with The Wall Street Journal.")
In the arcane field of noise walls, appearance now rivals sound, said Ilene Busch-Vishniac, an engineering professor at the University of Texas at Austin. "In the last decade, at least half the papers on noise barriers have been on the esthetic appeal, or rather the lack of esthetic appeal," she said. "It's hard to come up with an esthetically appealing noise barrier."
Although the latest walls may be less ugly, the debate over their effectiveness continues.
"The noise seems to me like it's worse" since the wall went up, said Milton Marcus of Jericho. Standing on his curb on the expressway access road, he talked at the top of his lungs to be heard above the din of tractor-trailers rumbling by. Although some noise walls enclose both the expressway and its access road, here the wall was installed between them.
"It doesn't make sense -- our problem was not the expressway but the noise from the access road right here," said Mr. Marcus, a computer mechanic. "The wall doesn't do anything about that except maybe reflect it back on me. Visually, it's not bad. But remember, we had hundreds of trees back there that they knocked down for this."
Acoustical scientists argue the pros and cons.
"The thing about noise walls is they really do have a good effect for the first row of houses, but after that the cost effectiveness raises real questions," said Dr. Joseph Pope, past chairman of the noise committee of the American Acoustical Society -- whose headquarters is just off the expressway near here.
Some government officials question whether the high cost -- ranging from $1 million to $2 million a mile for each side of the road -- is worth it.
More than $1.5 billion, in 1995 dollar values, has been spent on noise walls in this country. The Federal Government picks up the cost on new highways or major expansions, but walls for other highways hinge on state or local aid.
"There is considerable activity in Japan and some in Europe, but the overwhelming majority is right here in the good old U.S.A., because it is a very profitable business," said Dr. William W. Lang, president of the International Institute of Noise Control Engineering. "Contractors are making a lot of money.
"The acoustical efficiency is, let's say, modest, but the psychological efficacy is great in the sense that the barriers block the view of the highway," Dr. Lang said. "As a consumer and taxpayer, I'm not sure these noise walls are all that good, but certainly in affluent neighborhoods the political pressure is there to spend the public's money to build them, and contractors love them."
The new walls here, adding to about 10 miles built along other stretches of the expressway, are part of a major reconstruction that includes new car-pool lanes. Tri-Venture, a consortium of the Posillico, Hendrickson and Scalamandre construction companies, bid $245 million to get the job, including the noise walls, beating five competitors. The State Department of Transportation supervised the bidding.
But some legislators in the New York metropolitan region argue that with government trying to economize, the walls are a luxury. A Connecticut transportation planner, Carmine P. Trotta, said, "Since 1991, we've basically stopped funding sound barriers because of budget constraints."
Advocates of the walls say the best test of their effectiveness is the backlog of neighborhoods clamoring for them.
"We don't ram noise barriers down people's throats," said William McColl, an environmental analyst for New York State's Transportation Department. Neighborhood opposition will veto a proposed wall, he said. "This has happened only three or four times across the state, and in every case, they had second thoughts and subsequently wanted the walls."
Jericho's section of the expressway carries 150,000 vehicles a day -- averaging 6,250 an hour. Although some residents moved here fully aware of the traffic, older neighbors arrived when the volume was much lower and some settled here before the expressway was built.
Walls are erected to block sound waves from pounding on nearby eardrums. The walls here range from 16 to 24 feet high. Although some surfaces are specially designed to help absorb sound, many experts say the results are modest. The choice of materials like wood and concrete is based on cost, appearance or maintenance considerations rather than sound absorption.
"We strive to get a reduction of about 10 decibels, which a person in the community would perceive as a halving of the noise level," Mr. McColl said.
Properly designed walls "work very well" for adjacent residents, contends Mr. Angove, the newsletter editor. "Four blocks away they think it's a waste of money, but I've been at a lot of community meetings and in the backyards of a lot of people next to the highway after the walls go up, and you walk around with them and they say, 'Oh, my God, this is wonderful!"'
But for Alisa Chafitz, who lives across the street from the end of a new wall here, the change in sound and sight seems negligible. "It's actually pretty much the same," she said, "because there were a lot of trees they knocked down for the wall. Either way, the view's not great."

Zvinglis, whose Syosset home is near one. (Photographs by Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)(pg. B1)

HEADLINE: THE U.P.S. WALKOUT: NEWS ANALYSIS;
High Stakes for 2 Titans

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The walkout against United Parcel Service stems from the inevitable clash of two powerful forces in the nation's economy: the revitalized labor movement's opposition to the use of part-time workers and corporate America's insistence that it needs such workers to remain competitive.
That collision pushed the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to begin a strike yesterday morning against 2,400 United Parcel depots -- a high-stakes high-visibility move that involves more workers than any other strike this decade. 
 Even before the 185,000 drivers, loaders and sorters walked out, the teamsters' union drew a line in the sand over the issue of part-time workers.
At a time when the economy and United Parcel profits are booming, the teamsters are angry that of the 46,000 unionized jobs that the company has created since 1993, only 8,000 have been full-time. The part-time jobs pay $9 an hour, on average after two years, while full-time jobs pay $19.95 an hour.
In an era in which flexibility and speed are corporate watchwords, United Parcel sees the lower-paid part-timers as an economic lifeline. In a quick-turnaround business, corporate officials say, United Parcel needs thousands of people to sort packages and load trucks part-time from 4 A.M. to 8 A.M., not from 4 A.M. to noon.
"Over the last five years, part-time work has shifted from being an occasional strategy to being a way of life at U.P.S.," said Harley Shaiken, a professor of industrial relations at the University of California at Berkeley. "That's why there is the anger right now. For U.P.S. workers it represents, in effect, a hidden downsizing."
There are high stakes, indeed, in this clash, and not just because the strike has created chaos for some retailers and catalogue companies. The showdown pits one of the most powerful unions against the nation's largest shipping company.
The dispute is also one of the rare instances when a union has walked out over a two-tier wage system, a system that many unions regret having accepted in the 1980's.
If management retains the right to create as many lower-paid part-time jobs as it wants, employers everywhere are most likely to feel emboldened to rely on part-timers and other cost-cutting techniques that unions detest.
If the teamsters limit the use of part-timers at United Parcel, that could not only encourage other unions to confront managements over part-timers, but also enable the labor movement to trumpet a little louder that it is alive and kicking.
"This is a very important strike," said John T. Schmitt, an economist with the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research group. "You have a company that is a textbook example of the new economy, a service sector industry that's highly computerized, that's based on information, organization and smarts. If this kind of company cannot offer workers middle-class wages, if it pays $8.50 an hour instead of $20, that's a bad omen for the future."
The teamsters desperately need to win the dispute. For the 1.4 million-member union, which has struggled for five years to shed its corrupt autocratic image, fighting the use of part-timers has become nothing short of a crusade. When the union polled United Parcel workers about the issues to focus on, the workers -- three-fifths part-timers -- not surprisingly told their bargainers to concentrate on turning more part-time jobs into full-time ones.
The union president, Ronald Carey, who is mired in a fund-raising scandal, has not hesitated to embrace the issue as a way of rallying his troops. For Mr. Carey, a longtime United Parcel driver in New York City, the dispute is also an opportunity to show the world that this is a new teamsters' union, one willing to go toe to toe with employers, rather than make backroom deals with them.
"U.P.S. wants throwaway jobs that no one can live on," a spokesman for the union, Rand Wilson, said. "It's time that somebody stood up to them and said: 'This is not the right direction for America. This is not the right direction for our communities and for working families.' "
The company sees the strike as a chance to stand up and say there is nothing wrong with hiring part-timers, who nationally represent 18 percent the nation's work force. Indeed, United Parcel says using part-timers has been pivotal to its huge growth over the last four years, when it added the 46,000 workers.
The company, whose headquarters are in Atlanta, has relied heavily on part-time sorters for its fast-growing overnight air-delivery business. And executives say United Parcel has also needed an army of part-timers to enter information into computers so the company can offer customers the ability to track deliveries every step of the way.
The company's chief negotiator, David Murray, said: "It's significant to note that a whole lot of our part-time employees want part-time work. We have a lot of college students working as part-timers, paying their way through college."
In a news conference yesterday, United Parcel executives said with considerable pride that over the last four years they had moved 13,000 part-time workers to full-time jobs. Their contract proposal calls for turning an additional 11,000 part-timers into full-timers over the next five years, a number that the union says is far too small.
Some U.P.S. executives assert that the part-time issue is a smokescreen, suggesting that the union's real complaint is with a company proposal to set up a new pension plan and pull out of the existing multi-employer plan, in which United Parcel is by far the biggest contributor.
Union officials call that assertion ridiculous. The union, they note, has made clear for a year that the talks would focus on part-time work.
The teamsters have methodically planned the strike, and as a result an overwhelming majority of members honored the picket line.
That is far cry from a one-day strike in 1994 that Mr. Carey called on a moment's notice when United Parcel demanded that drivers lift heavier loads. Four-fifths of the workers ignored that strike call because of poor planning and because Mr. Carey's many opponents did little to publicize the strike.
Speaking privately, some company executives said Mr. Carey had an improper behind-the-scenes agenda in this dispute. They suggested that by calling a strike, he is trying to divert attention from a scandal in which Federal prosecutors say a fund-raiser for Mr. Carey engineered an illegal scheme in which more than $100,000 in union money was diverted to Mr. Carey's re-election campaign.
In December, Mr. Carey eked out a victory against James P. Hoffa, son of the teamsters' famous leader. But Mr. Hoffa is now demanding that the election be thrown out, because of all the questionable contributions that Mr. Carey received. Teamster officials say Mr. Carey knew nothing about the donations.
"This strike is really due to unstable internal union politics," said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, a professor of business administration at Emory University.
But Mr. Wilson, the union spokesman, said the strike was over the quality of the jobs of tomorrow.
"Our workers tell us their No. 1 priority is full-time jobs," he said. "People are cobbling together part-time jobs to make a living. They're working at U.P.S. and McDonald's. That what they have to do to earn enough to support a family."
