HEADLINE: Clinton Expected to Defer Action on Tobacco

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
President Clinton is likely to delay acting on the proposed $368.5 billion tobacco settlement until after he returns next month from a two-week summer vacation, a White House official said yesterday.
Mr. Clinton had originally been expected by aides to indicate his position on the proposal before leaving on vacation at the end of next week, but that apparently will not happen. 
 However, the President is expected to take one big, albeit partly symbolic, step against tobacco before he leaves on vacation. Mr. Clinton is said to be ready to sign a long-awaited executive order imposing the strongest anti-tobacco ban ever on Federal property.
Discussing the settlement proposal, the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said yesterday that even if Mr. Clinton received the recommendations of an Administration task force that is reviewing the plan, the President was unlikely to announce his position on it until September.
Mr. Clinton is expected to support the plan. A White House task force led by Bruce Reed, Mr. Clinton's top economic adviser, and the Health and Human Services Secretary, Donna E. Shalala, is reviewing the settlement proposal, which was reached in June between tobacco producers and state attorneys general.
Both Mr. Reed and Dr. Shalala have indicated that to win approval from the White House, the settlement proposal would probably have to be strengthened so that it did not undermine the Food and Drug Administration's existing authority to regulate cigarettes and nicotine.
Also, task force members have indicated that they believed that the proposed settlement would impose inadequate fines on cigarette companies if youth smoking was not reduced.
Under the plan, the companies agreed to pay tens of billions of dollars to settle lawsuits by states and smokers, restrict marketing and pay fines if youth smoking did not decline.
The proposal, which must be approved by Congress, would give the companies protections against lawsuits and punitive damages.
The order against smoking on Federal property is expected to be announced as soon as Saturday. A ban is already in effect in many Federal office buildings, but Mr. Clinton's order would broaden the prohibition. His decree reportedly will forbid such once-familiar activities as lighting up outside entrances to office buildings or in courtyards.
Mr. Clinton's order would directly affect only buildings in the executive branch of the Government, not buildings of the Federal judiciary or Congressional buildings, where some smoking is allowed.
But a Presidential order would increase the pressure on other branches of Government, and it would broaden restrictions that now exist for the executive branch.
For example, smoking would be barred in military officers' clubs, a change that would make a Defense Department policy against smoking all but total. The Department began phasing out smoking in most of its buildings in 1994.
Reports that Mr. Clinton is ready to sign the order came today from representatives of anti-tobacco organizations, who have been told to stand by for a signing ceremony before the end of this week.
The President has already banned smoking in the White House.

HEADLINE: Taiwan and Beijing Duel for Recognition in Central America

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
No sooner had China regained Hong Kong last month than Taiwan's Foreign Minister embarked on a three-week, 11-nation tour to shore up ties with his country's closest allies. His first stop was Honduras, where he and his Central American counterparts issued a joint declaration condemning China's designs on Taiwan.
Though half a world away from East Asia, Central America has in recent years emerged as one of the main battlegrounds in the decades-old diplomatic struggle between China and Taiwan. Now, with Hong Kong under Chinese control, the scope and intensity of the contest between Communist Party leaders in Beijing and the prosperous island they regard as a renegade province have rapidly risen to new levels in this region. 
 Of the 30 countries that recognize the Republic of China on Taiwan, rather than the People's Republic of China in Beijing, as the legitimate government of China, 14 are in Central America and the Caribbean. Taiwan's influence and generosity throughout the region are traditional and widespread and have led to increasingly conspicuous efforts by Beijing to neutralize that advantage.
For Taiwan, relations with Central America and the Caribbean provide both political legitimacy and a promising market for trade and investment. This region's trade with China and Hong Kong is also booming, but China has been less successful, until recently, in efforts to persuade countries to recognize Beijing.
"There have been rumors that after the first of July, perhaps the relations between my country and the nations of Central American and the Caribbean would be affected," Chang Hsiao-yen, Taiwan's Foreign Minister, said during a two-day visit here, referring to the date on which Hong Kong reverted to Chinese sovereignty. "But those relations are solid and quite cordial, and I have come precisely to seek a better and more effective way to deepen them and increase our mutual support in the international arena."
The maneuvering is especially intense here, and focuses on the Panama Canal, which the United States is scheduled to hand over to Panama on Dec. 31, 1999. China is the fifth largest user of the waterway, while Taiwan has cultivated a particularly close relationship with the Panamanian Government and has made large investments here, including a container port at a former American submarine base.
"The Chinese, both China and Taiwan, have spotted an opening and are trying to exploit it," an American military official said. "The United States is leaving Panama, there's a void, and each wants to fill it."
To increase its limited leverage in the region, China has not hesitated to brandish Hong Kong. Even before assuming control of the former British colony, Beijing had warned nations recognizing Taiwan that they would have to close their consulates and negotiate new arrangements if they wished to maintain a diplomatic presence in Hong Kong.
That alarmed many governments in this region that have made millions of dollars selling visas or passports to Chinese from Hong Kong and the mainland. Typically, a relative or close friend of a president is appointed consul general in Hong Kong, and a healthy cut of the sales flows back into the pockets of top government officials.
In Panama's case, there is also an implicit threat to the lucrative business of ship registrations. Panama is the flag of convenience flown by thousands of ships around the world, including many owned by Hong Kong or Chinese fleets. In the past, those fleets have often registered their vessels and crew members through the Panamanian consulate in Hong Kong; but now they may turn to the Bahamas, a competitor that broke relations with Taiwan in July.
But Taiwan is not standing pat. In his meeting with Central American foreign ministers, Mr. Chang indicated that Taiwan might be willing to hire Central Americans to replace its estimated 240,000 "guest workers" who are currently imported from the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and other countries that recognize Beijing.
During the meeting in Honduras, the countries of Central America described Taiwan as "a sovereign country" and said that only "peaceful means should be used to reach national unification." They also agreed to a summit meeting with President Lee Teng-hui in September in El Salvador.
At a time when the United States is reducing its own aid to the region, the indications of Taiwan's largess are becoming an ever more visible part of the landscape. Police cars and garbage trucks in Haiti, for instance, proclaim in French that they have been "donated by the Republic of China on Taiwan," as do the trash cans in Castries, the capital of the Caribbean island of St. Lucia.
Missions from Taiwan have helped increase rice yields and organized fishing and agricultural diversification projects. Taiwan also helps pay the operating costs of several foreign ministries and police forces in the region and regularly sponsors trips by government officials, military officers and journalists to Taiwan for training courses or "familiarization visits."
China's approach to the region, in contrast, seems to emphasize the stick much more than the carrot. The result of those hardball tactics, it would appear, has generally been resentment.
"You gringos have pushed us around for 150 years, and we never liked it," said the Foreign Minister of one Central American country. "So what makes the Chinese think that kind of Great Power arrogance would be any more palatable coming from them? For them to tell us not to recognize Taiwan is no different than Washington saying we shouldn't have relations with Cuba."
[After Central American countries said in late July that they favored a plan to readmit Taiwan to the United Nations, China issued a letter publicly warning that "they would ultimately pay the price" for that position. President Arnoldo Aleman of Nicaragua responded by denouncing the Beijing Government as one that has oppressed and slaughtered its own people, and on Aug. 3 he left Managua for a five-day official visit to Taiwan.]
Early this year, after a peace agreement brokered by the United Nations brought an end to 36 years of civil war in Guatemala, China delayed deployment of a United Nations military mission for nearly a month to punish Guatemala for its support of Taiwan's readmission to the international body.
In Panama, Chinese pressures have been aimed primarily at the economy. More than a quarter of the $5.5 billion worth of goods sold in the Colon Free Zone each year are imported from Hong Kong, and Panamanian executives are accustomed to flying there on short notice to conduct business. Now, however, they are being told that the Panamanian Government's friendship with Taiwan means they need visas to enter Hong Kong, which is causing costly delays.
"The dispute between China and Taiwan is a political one that ought to be resolved in East Asia and should not spill over into Latin America," Nessim S. Bassan, president of the Colon Free Zone Traders' Association, said.
There are also some indications that China now feels it can play the game through Hong Kong intermediaries. In July the Bahamas switched recognition from Taiwan to Beijing after Hutchison Whampoa, a Hong Kong conglomerate, agreed to invest more than $175 million in construction of a container port in Freeport and the purchase and refurbishing of three hotel complexes.
In Panama, Hutchison Whampoa recently outbid American companies and secured the contracts to modernize and administer ports at either end of the Panama Canal. American officials have complained publicly that the bidding was marred by irregularities.
"It is very hard to distinguish Hutchison Whampoa capital from mainland China capital," Mr. Chang, the Taiwanese Foreign Minister, said. "Some people say we are using money to buy the region. That is not the case. It is mainland China who is doing this kind of thing, not us. But I think if they persist in this campaign against us, it is going to backfire against them."

HEADLINE: Unlearned, Unhealthy and Mostly Uninsured

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
It was 7:45 A.M. when Eddie Breedlove, speechless and grasping a swollen jaw, signed the log at the St. Vincent Health Clinic East here. He had roused his wife and their three small children at 5 to make the 50-mile drive from their home in a rattling 16-year-old Mercury, after weeks in which he had been tormented by a relentless toothache.
"He said that last night he drank as much as he could," an aide recounted, having interviewed him, "and then used a pocketknife to try to get it out." 
 Mr. Breedlove, tall, slender, with a week's growth of beard, was greeted leaving the dentist's office by his wife, Blenda, who told a visitor, "He needs a full mouth extraction."
Mrs. Breedlove, pregnant and unemployed after three bouts of back surgery, said her husband earned $100 a week as a self-employed mechanic, barely $5,000 a year. She and the children are covered by Medicaid, the Federal-state health insurance program for the poor, but he is not. Buying private insurance for himself could consume all he earns, and so he is his own physician. Only as a last resort does he settle into his old car for the long drive to the clinic, which caters largely to the uninsured and where he will pay little or nothing for treatment.
Who are the nation's uninsured, and how do they cope?
For the most part, they are working people who cling to the bottom rung of the ladder, people whose only real asset may be a clunker of a car but who -- given Medicaid income and asset eligibility standards, which vary from state to state -- frequently do not qualify for the health care assistance available to the unemployed poor.
Nationally, the Census Bureau reports, 41 million people, 15.4 percent of all Americans, lacked health care insurance throughout 1995. Among the poor -- those with incomes below the Federal poverty line, $12,156 for a family of three -- the proportion was double that: 30.2 percent.
Not surprisingly, young workers and people with little education, low wages and temporary or part-time jobs are less likely to be covered than others -- often voluntarily, unwilling to pay the worker's share of premiums in an employer's plan.Among older workers, more men, and in particular more poor men, are uninsured than women. Among the races, a third of people of Hispanic origin lack insurance, compared with 21 percent of blacks and 14.2 percent of whites.
The uninsured also include 10 million children. For many of them, the budget legislation that President Clinton is about to sign promises relief by making more eligible for Medicaid.
But most of the uninsured -- 31 million, including 23 million employed -- are adults, and the Government has nothing in the works for them.
Dr. William Mason, who gave up a group practice in pulmonology to work as a family practitioner treating the poor at the St. Vincent Health Clinic East, says the general condition of the uninsured poor is often quite different from that of the well-covered patients he used to see.
"I see a tremendous amount of undiagnosed and untreated mental disorder," Dr. Mason said. "You see very poor oral hygiene. We see a lot of diabetes. We see a lot of hypertension and obesity. People can't get good health habits when they're struggling to make ends meet."
Alma Hawkins, who has been a licensed practical nurse at the clinic for 17 years, said: "We are seeing quite a few people that are depressed that we didn't used to see. We're seeing more sick young and middle-aged people."
Some patients, like Mr. Breedlove, still rely on home remedies: putting molasses in an ear to relieve an ache, putting liniment on arthritic knees, wrapping salt pork onto a wound.
"When I was a child, if you punctured your foot on a nail, you soaked it in turpentine," said Dr. Mason, 54. "Those things are still around."
The clinic, operated by the City of Little Rock and the St. Vincent Infirmary Medical Center, a hospital complex here, charges its poorest patients nothing and others low fees on a sliding scale tied to income, with payment plans of $5 or $10 a week. It sees 30 to 40 patients a day. That is all it can handle, and so it does not advertise.
The traffic through the clinic runs the gamut of the uninsured and the underinsured.
Most of the patients are among the nation's 23 million uninsured working adults, whose numbers are likely to grow as the overhaul of the welfare system drives more off the Medicaid rolls.
Others are the underinsured, who have lost out to the quirks of regulation and the limitations of Medicare, Medicaid and private plans. The Arkansas Medicaid program, for example, will pay for the pulling of teeth of eligible adults, but not for dentures.
And although Medicare covers everyone over 65, it is not free. Unless exempt or helped by Medicaid, a Medicare beneficiary must pay for most prescriptions as well as a monthly premium of $43.80 to visit doctors, 20 percent of doctors' fees and a deductible of $760 for the start of a hospital stay.
"We have patients who are working full time but don't have insurance," said Jo Ann Shaw, the clinic's director. "We have patients who have insurance on their children but not on themselves."
The patients, Ms. Shaw says, have been brought to the clinic by poverty and aging, by bad diets, bad breaks and bad habits, or by bad genes and bad choices.
"We have patients who are -- I don't want to say illiterate -- unlearned," she said. "They don't understand why they should see a doctor. Or they don't go to the doctor until they have a severe attack of something. You have to be nonjudgmental in this type of setting."
It is because of their ignorance, or simply because of poverty, that patients rely on their own devices to try to cope with turns in their health. "They'll take half as much medication as required, to stretch it," Ms. Shaw said. "Or when they're prescribed two linked medicines, they'll take one."
A young uninsured man, about 20, stopped by the clinic the other day on friends' advice. He had been bitten on a finger and on his neck in a fight the night before. A nurse gave him a tetanus shot, and he was charged $3.50. She advised him to come back when a doctor was in, because she had found that he also had strep throat.
Another patient was Elizabeth Oliver, who has diabetes. She is 31, the unemployed wife of a $5-an-hour van driver who has no insurance for himself or for her.
By previous marriages, they have two children: Christina, 6, and Christine, 12. The children have Medicaid, which paid for Christina's silver metal replacements for seven baby teeth.
"She doesn't like brushing," Ms. Oliver said.
Christina's head was wrapped in gauze that covered three stitches she had received at a hospital emergency room the day before. Her mother's car had struck the back of a pickup waiting at a stop sign.
"They gave me two tickets," Ms. Oliver said. "They said I was driving too close and I didn't have a license. I've never had a license."
Not all the clinic's patients are in need of urgent care. Some are uninsured young adults in robust health who pay the low fees for a flu shot or for dental work. Anita Lewallen, 22, who was having a tooth filled, works 30 hours a week at a blood plasma bank for $5.74 an hour and is a student at the University of Central Arkansas.
"I used to have some insurance," Ms. Lewallen said, "but I couldn't afford it. It went from $64 a month to $103 a month in three years. I never used it anyway."
Vallery Nix, 20, works at a dry cleaner for $5.75 an hour. Her two children have Medicaid, but she is uncovered. Under her employer's plan, she would have to pay $36 a week.
"I'm not a sick person," said Ms. Nix, who was having her teeth cleaned. "I go to the dentist once a year."
But then there are young adults like Jamillah Junior, 20, a single mother. She has Medicaid for her 2-year-old son but not for herself, in part because she was recently working and, now receiving an unemployment check of $97 a week, cannot qualify. She earned $6 an hour as a temporary office worker but was dismissed in December.
"I was lifting boxes and hurt my back real bad," Ms. Junior said. "I have sclerosis in my back." Her right arm hurts, from the shoulder to her hand. Without warning, her knees buckle, and she falls. "I lose a job just getting up and walking around."
When she was a toddler, her knees would go out, said her mother, Allene Junior, 44, a guard at a women's prison who has complete coverage for herself and the two of her five children who are still minors. "Her back goes out," the elder Ms. Junior said. "And she doesn't scheme. She got fired because of a medical problem."
The mother was angry. "It seems money goes here and money goes there," she said, "but what about the people? You got people here that really need help and don't scheme."
Dwight Smith, 33, sat in the waiting room, hugging his ribs and rocking in pain from a toothache. The single father of two children who have Medicaid, he earns $6.50 an hour, or about $13,000 a year, as a full-time forklift driver at an animal feed warehouse. His employer does not offer insurance, and he is ineligible for Medicaid himself.
"You know it when you need a tooth pulled," Mr. Smith said. Since the winter, he said, "I tried to just let it go and take its course." Now it was July.
Like Mr. Breedlove, he had tried his own remedies. He had tried swilling baking powder and salt. He had tried stuffing the hole in the tooth with tobacco.
"I'd take some Tylenol," he said, "and crunch it up and put it in there and let it sit."
The dentist, Dr. Rosetta Shelby-Calvin, said: "We have preventive care. But the preponderance of care I do is because of hurt. That's what gets them in the door."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. William Mason, who gave up a group practice to work as a family practitioner treating many of the uninsured poor, says their general condition tends to be decidedly inferior to that of patients he used to see. (Spencer Tirey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Relief Teams Say North Korea Faces Vast Drought Emergency

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Relief officials allowed to visit North Korea over the last several weeks say that a drought may be pushing millions of people in the reclusive country to the brink of starvation and that they have not seen such severe malnutrition since the famines in Ethiopia and Somalia.
The drought -- more than 60 days with no rain and temperatures in the 90's -- arrived after food stocks were already severely depleted by two years of floods and decades of economic ruin wrought by the most bizarre of Communist systems, which is now struggling to feed itself without allies. 
 The relief officials acknowledged that they could not move freely in North Korea and that their visits were tightly controlled by Communist authorities, making the extent of what some experts have called an "invisible" catastrophe hard to gauge. North Korean officials themselves, who have long tutored their population in a philosophy of self-reliance, often appear ambivalent about how dire a picture they want to paint for the outside world.
Foreign reporters are barred from visiting the country.
There have been mounting reports in recent months of widespread food shortages. But the drought of the last two months, American Government and relief officials said, has significantly worsened the situation.
"It appears the North Koreans are going from bad to worse," a senior American official in Washington said today. "They were dead on their feet economically for years. Then came the floods. Then a drought."
The official acknowledged that the United States does not yet have a full grasp of the extent of the food shortages, but he said, "What we do know is that there is serious malnutrition across the country. I have no doubt that there are people on the verge of starvation, no doubt at all."
The reports of the aid specialists who visited Korea were uniformly bleak. In interviews since their return, officials from international groups and private agencies described skeletal people living each day on "a fistful" of rice and children too weak to stand.
"We saw children in institutions who are at the level of malnutrition comparable to the mid-80's drought in Ethiopia," said Dr. Milton Amayun, a physician who had just returned from conducting the first systematic measurements of children to determine their level of malnutrition.
Trevor Rowe, spokesman for the United Nations World Food Program, came to a similarly grim conclusion. "The difference is that in Ethiopia and Somalia you had pockets that were affected because of drought or war, but it wasn't a generalized phenomenon," he said. "In North Korea it is far more generalized. As the food goes down, everyone is suffering."
Most relief specialists permitted to enter were limited to seeing institutions where their own aid money was spent, and spontaneous visits to private homes were rare. But most aid officials now returning from a third or fourth trip say they have seen the health of North Koreans deteriorate on each visit.
"During winter, malnutrition is sometimes camouflaged" by many layers of clothing, said Dr. Amayun, who toured the country for World Vision, a private group. "But now in summer, we could really tell how stunted they were and how thin were their arms and legs."
Today four United Nations agencies and two independent groups said in a joint statement that the drought had already cost North Korea 70 percent of this year's corn crop, withering virtually all plants not irrigated. Falling water levels will soon threaten rice crops as well, they said.
The country of 24 million people, most of whom are already subjected to strict food rationing, had hoped to harvest four million tons of food this year. Projections now show that at least 1.5 million tons will be lost.
The United States has given North Korea $60.4 million in food aid since September 1995 and is prepared to contribute more if necessary, a State Department official said. But the United States, which has no diplomatic representation in North Korea, is also pressing Pyongyang to allow Americans to monitor future shipments and to assess the situation in the country. Officials in the United States, South Korea and other Asian nations have expressed concern that a potentially huge number of people could try to flee North Korea in desperation.
The relief officials who recently returned from North Korea said that in July the sights in the countryside were startling.
"Flying over the northeast in a chopper from Pyongyang to Hamhung and Chongjin provides stark visual data on the extent and severity of the drought," an official from the World Food Program wrote to the group's headquarters in Rome. "Vast expanses of parched, arid land; fields with barely a hint of green crops; fields that were planted in the past lying barren and deserted; much of the hillside and mountainside stripped of trees, exposing sandy soil, rocky outcrops and scrub vegetation.
"The sense I got was one of exhaustion -- parched, dried, exhausted land," he added.
In an telephone interview today from Pyongyang, Bergitta Kalgren, the World Food Program's representative in North Korea, said that reservoirs were drying up everywhere, and that residents of the capital were experiencing breaks in the urban water supply.
A Food and Agriculture Organization specialist said today that the situation is "absolutely disastrous."
Today, North Korea will for the first time be taking part in preliminary talks with South Korea, China and the United States that could lay the ground for a peace conference to reduce tensions in the Korean Peninsula. Relief officials familiar with North Korea, suggest that the talks, to be held at Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs, are more important to the North Koreans than they have admitted publicly.
Although the United States and other governments say that their aid is not politically conditioned, many officials say they believe that only if North Korea appears more cooperative in dealing with South Korea, Japan and other nations, will Pyongyang have a hope of getting major international aid.
The World Food Program, which has raised more than $120 million in emergency aid to North Korea from governments and private donors, has developed a monitoring system to insure that the food reaches the right people.
North Korea's two million government officials and army soldiers have their own system of acquiring and distributing food for themselves -- siphoning off much of what is produced within the country -- and they never go without.
The relief group has thus so far focused on supplying mostly children up to six years old, hospitals and some geographic areas where crops were lost to floods in 1995 and 1996. Another $75 million in aid or commodities has been provided directly by governments and private groups.
Relief officials say that famine and starvation occur only after a confluence of failures -- economic, environmental and political -- but that no single event, like drought alone, would be enough to cause such widespread calamity.
Continuing economic mismanagement and decades of outdated agricultural policies, including a lack of crop rotation and the inadequate use of fertilizers, have made North Korea vulnerable to such a disaster.
This summer's monsoon rains arrived in South Korea in June, but then veered away from the peninsula and into the Sea of Japan just as they neared the border with the North. Even still, though there is no crisis in South Korea, its economic and agricultural policies would allow farmers there far greater flexibility in responding to such a drought.
No one can estimate what will be needed if famine and starvation appear on a mass scale and among all age groups. Some relief officials believe that older people, no longer seen on the streets, may be too weak to leave home -- or may be dying.
Relief officials also said they fear that if starvation occurs on a mass scale it will be difficult to arouse public sympathy around the world, as the crises in the Horn of Africa did, or that an effective response would come too late.
At the World Food Program in Rome, Mr. Rowe, the spokesman, said that the crisis is very visible to aid workers and organizations, who have made videos and taken many photographs of the steadily deteriorating condition of the population. Mr. Rowe said that his program had seen a "record response" to appeals from governments.
But North Korea, whose government has been hostile to the outside world and has a record of supporting terrorism, is not an easy country to win sympathy for among the general public, said Ted Yamamori, a doctor and president of Food for the Hungry, who has just returned from Pyongyang. He estimated that at least five million people were already being afflicted by famine.
"What we are seeing is not enough pictures on the screen," Dr. Yamamori said in a telephone interview from Scottsdale, Ariz., where the group is based. "People are not really able to understand what is going on."
"They are mobilizing soldiers to carry water to the cornfields," he continued. "You see women lining up to carry water on their heads to irrigate the crops. Fields are scorched. The plants are wilting." He said that people have begun making porridge of wheat gruel and grass.
Dr. Amayun, the specialist who toured for World Vision, said in an interview that increasing numbers of children are being given up to government orphanages by their relatives, who can no longer feed them.
"Children of primary school age are now showing stunting, which means they are chronically malnourished," Dr. Amayun said. "We see a lot of children given up by their parents, who cannot guarantee normal feeding. Most of the children in the Government centers I saw were abandoned.
"But we know there are children born in hospitals who are not being taken home by their families. There are a lot of newborns being brought to orphanages directly from the district hospitals.
"We saw diarrhea, kwashiorkor and pneumonia. We were told there are cases of measles, and that they have stopped immunizing children in a systematic way."
"The children we saw were apathetic, lethargic," he continued. "Many had no strength to stand. They had no energy. The severely malnourished had the faces of old men, with nothing but skin and bones in their arms and legs."
World Vision plans to airlift high-protein food to North Korea this week. For many, said Dr. Amayun, it will be too late.

HEADLINE: THE U.P.S. WALKOUT: THE OVERVIEW;
Shippers Scramble as Strike Hits U.P.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
A strike by 185,000 members of the teamsters' union idled most of the familiar brown trucks of the United Parcel Service today, slowing the movement of millions of packages and inconveniencing businesses and their customers across the country.
The walkout against U.P.S., the nation's largest shipping company, began the moment Sunday turned into Monday as the shipper and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters failed to reach an agreement over pension funds and the use of part-time workers. 
 The strike is the first nationwide job action in U.P.S.'s 90 years, and it forced corporate giants and mom-and-pop stores alike to find other ways to move their goods, if they could. Most businesses were able to adjust, but there were exceptions.
The most essential goods -- food for groceries, medicine and medical supplies for hospitals -- appeared to be getting to their destinations. United Parcel itself was able to move a trickle of its usual stream of 12 million parcels a day as managers drove trucks and flew a fraction of the company's 200 planes, giving high priority to medical and pharmaceutical supplies.
For many businesses and customers, the strike comes at a relatively good time: August instead of autumn. Lands' End, a giant catalog company that ships clothing from its headquarters in Dodgeville, Wis., said it was shipping by priority mail, and that its customers were willing to be patient with the Christmas season months away. "One person said that as long as their winter jacket got there by October it was O.K.," a spokesman said.
No new talks have been scheduled, and President Clinton said today that he did not plan to intervene at this time. The Federal Taft-Hartley Act and the National Labor Relations Act allow a President to halt a strike, but only when the national health or safety is imperiled, a standard that so far would be difficult to meet here.
"U.P.S. is a very important company to our country, and there are a lot of employees there, and I hope they'll go back to the table," the President said, hoping persuasion might work in the absence of White House intervention. A Federal mediator had tried to bring the parties together before the talks broke down.
Some of America's biggest businesses, especially those that do a heavy mail-order trade, had seen the strike coming and made contingency plans, arranging for their products to be shipped by Federal Express and other air express companies or through the United States Postal Service. But the extra load on those services was a burden as well as a boon. U.P.S. normally handles 80 percent of packages shipped by ground nationwide, and transportation experts say FedEx and the postal system cannot take up all the slack.
For some businesses, the strike was a crisis.
The walkout comes at a particularly bad time for the book-publishing industry, which is largely centered in New York City. This is the week that most trade publishers start shipping major titles for the fall season. Publishers of educational textbooks are eager to ship books to schools.
New York publishers generally rely heavily on U.P.S., and it seemed doubtful today that other shippers could fill the gap. "We're hoping for a quick resolution to this strike," said Andrew Giangola, a spokesman for Simon & Schuster. "We're certainly rooting for quick Federal intervention."
So were smaller businesses, which seemed most vulnerable. LeBlanc's Harbor Chocolates in Salem, Mass., tried to ship 60 boxes of chocolates by FedEx today. FedEx said it would accept exactly one.
"If this were Dec. 15, we'd be screaming," said Phyllis LeBlanc, whose company sells about $2.5 million worth of candy a year, much of it at Christmas. LeBlanc's relies overwhelmingly on U.P.S.
So do lobster dealers in Maine. Many held back on their perishable shipments, fearing that other carriers would not be able to deliver on time.
The plight of the candy company and the lobster dealers was no surprise to Todd McCracken, president of National Small Business United, a lobbying group based in Washington. "Companies like FedEx are going to serve their biggest customers first, which puts small businesses in a tough spot," he said today.
In the strike's early hours, a quick resolution seemed unlikely, given the depth of feeling on both sides and that no talks have been scheduled.
"We're ready to meet," Rand Wilson, a teamsters' spokesman in Washington said today. But not, he said, unless U.P.S. changes its stand on part-time workers. "U.P.S. wants throwaway jobs that no one can live on," Mr. Wilson said. "This is not the right direction for America."
When a U.P.S. spokeswoman, Susan Rosenberg, was asked about the likelihood of new talks, she said: "Ask dear Mr. Carey. He walked away. When's he coming back?"
Ronald Carey, the teamsters' president, had announced the strike late Sunday in Washington, calling the talks "just a waste of time."
The teamsters' union, like others, has been increasingly bitter over part-time employees -- thousands of them in the case of U.P.S., paying an average rate of $9 an hour, versus about $20 an hour for a full-time job. When the country's economy is booming and U.P.S.'s profits are soaring, it is unconscionable for managements to lean so heavily on part-timers, the union argues.
United Parcel executives have argued just as adamantly that, in an era when a stodgy company can soon be a dead one, it needs the speed and flexibility of part-time help, especially in sorting packages and loading trucks by the dawn's early light.
There was scattered unrest on the picket lines -- six strikers arrested for disorderly conduct near Boston, four in Chicago -- and union members voiced determination.
"I would rather be working, but I'm going to stick with the teamsters," Jim Hoover, a 28-year-old driver, said outside a U.P.S. warehouse in Gaithersburg, Md.
A fellow Maryland union member, Ronald Warren, spoke over jeers and catcalls that picketers hurled at managers who entered the warehouse. "Most people understand that this is a fight for the future," Mr. Warren said.
At United Parcel's air hub at Louisville, Ky., dozens of strikers waved signs and shouted at the occasional driver who crossed through the gates, but there was no violence. "We don't appreciate it, but we're not there to do any damage," said Keith Johnson, whose job includes directing U.P.S. planes to loading docks. "Of course, I can't say what will happen in the future."
Ms. Rosenberg, the U.P.S. spokeswoman, said this evening that the company hoped to fly about 40 of its own planes with management pilots in the cockpit, plus 8 or 9 chartered planes out of Louisville early Tuesday to deliver U.P.S. parcels.
She acknowledged that that would be a fraction of the company's normal nighttime activity: some 200 U.P.S. aircraft plus an additional 300 or so chartered planes serving 400 airports in the United States and 200 in other countries.
The Independent Pilots Association said its 2,000 pilots who fly for U.P.S. would refuse to work.
Anticipating a strike, many businesses had made contingency plans, some involving their own trucks.
The Allegiance Corporation, a branch of Baxter International, the country's biggest supplier of medical, surgical and laboratory products, said it was deploying its own fleet of 400 trucks and was confident of providing uninterrupted service.
But some hospitals reported delays in their package deliveries. North General Hospital in Harlem, which depends heavily on U.P.S., said its incoming packages were down drastically (it was not clear how many delayed packages, if any, were crucial to patient care), and Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan said it had received a half-dozen U.P.S. packages today, not the usual 80 to 100.
Gateway 2000, a $5 billion company that sold more than two million computers last year, said it began setting up its strike plans last week, switching to FedEx, other carriers and its own trucks. "It will have a minor impact," Jim Taylor, the head of marketing, said today. "We are pretty comfortable."
Some titans of American commerce -- General Electric, Kodak, Xerox -- said they too had been planning for the strike, but that some inconvenience was inevitable.
"We are trying to divert as much as possible to other carriers," said Paul Allen, a Kodak spokesman. "But options are limited, so we expect our customers will experience delays."
Harry A. Ikenson, a retail-industry analyst in New York, said he understood that Neiman Marcus, which usually ships only 4 percent of its packages through the postal service, had been sending 20 percent of them by Friday.
Mr. Ikenson gave especially high grades to J.C. Penney, which started planning for a U.P.S. strike as far back as February, shifting to other carriers and the mail. Investors rewarded the company today: its stock closed at $59.375 on the New York Stock Exchange, up $1.75.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 8, 1997, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about effects of the United Parcel Service strike misstated the ownership of the Allegiance Corporation, which is deploying a fleet of 400 trucks to keep supplying customers with medical, surgical and laboratory products. It is an independent company, not a branch of Baxter International.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
MY old friend Alexis Lichine would have been dancing through his wine cellar in Bordeaux. "Look," he would have said, waving a newspaper, "$32.50 a bottle for my 1996. Incredible!"
Incredible is the word for it. Prices for the 1996 vintage in Bordeaux have been set, and it's no exaggeration to say that they are out of control. Two hundred dollars a bottle is about average for the seven or eight most famous names among the Bordeaux chateaus, and $100 or more is common among the second tier. 
 Mr. Lichine, who died in 1988, spent years improving the wine of his chateau, Prieure-Lichine, in Margaux; he was quite happy to see it reach $15 and eventually $20 in his lifetime. The idea that it would one day reach $32.50 would have astonished him. But then, what would he have said about the 1996 Chateau Latour and Chateau Margaux, both first growths, at $215 and $247 a bottle, respectively?
These are the prices of futures, contracts to buy the wine now with delivery in two years. Most of the prices given in this column are from Zachy's Wine and Liquor of Scarsdale, N.Y., one of the best-known wine retailers in the New York metropolitan area.
Here are some prices per bottle: Chateaux Ausone, $295; Leoville-las-Cases, $215; Lafite-Rothschild, $186; Mouton-Rothschild, $186; Haut-Brion, $175, and Cheval-Blanc, $165.
Since Chateau Petrus, the billionaire's favorite, made only 800 cases of wine in 1996, Zachy's is not offering it as a future. When the store's small consignment arrives in 1998, it will be sold in one- and two-bottle units. But Zachy's is offering the 1996 Petrus as part of two interesting packages. Order a case each of Ausone, Cheval-Blanc, Haut-Brion, Latour, Lafite-Rothschild, Mouton-Rothschild and Margaux, and Zachy's will toss in a single bottle of Petrus. The cost for this little collection: $16,000.
For the really big spender, the Scarsdale store will put together a collection of a case each of all 131 chateaus being offered as futures in 1996, plus a sampler of 12 of the best-known wines in its advertisement. The cost: $102,761. For an extra dollar, Zachy's will include a case of 1996 Petrus.
Certainly, the wines that command these prices must be exceptional. It is difficult to make judgments about very young Bordeaux wines, but the general conclusion among the many specialists who have tasted them is that many of them are very good, indeed, but probably not as good as the 1995's and certainly not as good as the 1990's.
But quality, where big-name Bordeaux wines are concerned, is a secondary consideration. Demand is what drives these prices up -- demand from buyers, few of whom would ever drink the wines or would appreciate them if they did. At these prices, wine ceases to be a drink and becomes an investment.
The most insistent demand these days appears to be from the Far East. Buyers in Hong Kong and Singapore are apparently ready to pay any price for Bordeaux first growths and other Bordeaux wines of similar stature. These newcomers to expensive wine are driving up demand in a finite market. Most of the famous chateaus in Bordeaux produce between 10,000 and 25,000 cases of wine a year.
Just how good an investment is fine wine? The obvious parallel is with the stock market. Bordeaux prices have been increasing steadily through the 90's, despite relatively mediocre vintages from 1991 through 1994. With 1995, they really took off, and in many instances the 1996 prices are 30 percent higher than what they were a year ago. Futures buyers are betting they will go even higher.
But wine, like any agricultural product, is subject to booms and busts. In the early 70's, the Bordeaux market was thought to be on the verge of a huge expansion. Investors bought in, despite several mediocre vintages. In 1973, the market collapsed. Famous old Bordeaux firms disappeared, and fortunes were lost on both sides of the Atlantic.
Should the average wine drinker buy futures? Probably not now. Prices of the top wines are ridiculously high. An investor might want to gamble that the wine's value will continue to go up and that he or she can sell the wine in 10 years at a big profit. A collector might be willing to pay just to round out a collection of a certain chateau. But for a wine drinker, there really are not many bottles of wine -- if any -- worth $250 or more.
Even the Bordeaux trade is being cautious about buying futures now. "It makes sense if you follow certain chateaus and want to be certain of having their 1996's in your cellar," said Fiona Morrison, a spokeswoman for the Bordeaux Wine Council. "If not, you may be better off buying wines from earlier vintages that will be ready to drink sooner."
Buying lesser-known chateaus doesn't make sense, Ms. Morrison said. "You tie up your money too long, and the economics just do not stack up."
In fact, there are plenty of good wines offered on futures contracts at much more reasonable prices. Chateau Phelan-Segur, at $285 a case, and Chateau Meyney, at $279 a case, are relatively reasonable in price; so is Chateau du Tertre, a respectable Margaux, at $199 a case. Again, the wines will not be delivered for another year or more, and the money could be used now to buy other wines, like Italian or Californian wines, or even lesser-known but good Bordeaux from recent vintages at much more attractive prices.
Prieure-Lichine is a sentimental favorite with me, but at $32.50, I'll hold my emotions in check.
 
TASTINGS
Caliterra Cabernet Sauvignon 1995, Maipo and Curico valleys, Chile. About $8.
 
If ever a wine-growing region suffered from too much hype too early in the game, it is Chile. The stories from Santiago a decade ago were simply too good to be true. But everyone wanted to believe. The adjustment to reality has been painful but valuable. This 1995 Caliterra cabernet, for example, is clearly better than most of the Chilean wines so highly praised a few years back. The wine blends fruit from the Curico and Maipo valleys with just a touch from the Aconcagua valley, which is Caliterra's home turf. The result is a wine with good body, a long finish, not too much oak and little of the rustic quality that has characterized many Chilean red wines. At around $8, it offers good value, too. The Robert Mondavi Winery is an investor in Caliterra, which augurs well for it.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prices are high for 1996 Bordeaux, like Chateau Haut-Brion ($175 a bottle), where Jean-Bernard Delmas is an executive. (Robert Tixador/Agence)

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Lawyers wrangle over the move by Ritz-Carlton to strip its imprimatur from four U.S. hotels.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH the Ritz-Carlton name was stripped last weekend from hotels in New York, Washington, Houston and Aspen, Colo., as of yesterday afternoon only the Aspen property appeared resigned to its fate. Its operator answered the telephone: "Good afternoon, this is Kathy. How may I assist you?" and when asked if this was the number for the Ritz-Carlton, replied, "Formerly." But operators at the other three properties all answered, "Thank you for calling the Ritz-Carlton," followed by the name of the city.
A Ritz-Carlton spokeswoman said that while the hotels no longer had the right to the luxury chain's name, lawyers were still wrangling over it. The issue erupted in the early hours of Saturday when Ritz-Carlton, which is controlled by Marriott International, sent teams of managers into the four hotels to terminate its management agreements with them. The four properties are owned by separate holding companies controlled by an investment firm owned by Sheik Abdul Aziz bin Ibrahim al-Ibrahim, a Saudi businessman. The Ritz-Carlton said it had acted because of breaches of contract, including their owners' representatives' refusal to pay more than $4 million in management fees and cost reimbursements. 
 Yesterday, the owners of the four hotels filed a $250 million lawsuit in New York State Supreme Court against Marriott International and Ritz-Carlton, charging fraudulent conveyance in connection with Marriott's 49 percent acquisition of the hotel chain's assets in 1995. The suit charges that the acquisition was intentionally structured to shift assets from Ritz-Carlton so it could avoid paying more than $200 million in restitution and damages stemming from a lawsuit the four filed in 1995, charging Ritz-Carlton with mismanagement and breach of contract. Ritz-Carlton countersued and both previous cases are pending.
Meanwhile, employees at the Houston and Washington properties, who would not speak for attribution, said their hotels were functioning fully, honoring existing reservations and taking new ones. One of those employees said the hotel was still using the Ritz-Carlton name "because we don't know who the new management company is." Most hotels take the name of their management company.
Ritz-Carlton withdrew its 200 management employees from the hotels, and its toll-free number no long accepts reservations or cancellations for the four hotels. But it acknowledged that guests in those hotels were unlikely anytime soon to experience a reduction in quality. "The hourly employees were trained by Ritz-Carlton," said Karon Cullen, a company spokeswoman, "so for a while at least guests will still have a Ritz-Carlton experience."
 
A Low-Key Reaction
Business travelers are not exactly ecstatic about the taxes and fees imposed on air fares by the new budget bill, but neither are they outraged, judging from the reaction of the National Business Travel Association.
"This may well prompt companies to explore alternatives in order to stay within their budgets, including sending fewer people on fewer trips," said Mark Johnson, the president of the 2,000-member association, who is also the travel manager of the Cessna Aircraft Corporation in Wichita, Kan. "Nonetheless, so long as the nation's economy is strong and there is business to be conducted in the country and globally, corporations will continue to use travel as a strategic instrument."
Still, other travel industry officials questioned the timing of the tax increase on round-trip international flights to $24 from $6. "It's not out of line with what many foreign nations charge for the departure tax alone," said Dexter C. Koehl, the spokesman for the nonprofit Travel Industry of America, "but it's bound to turn away some foreign visitors, who last year spent more than $90 billion in the United States.
 
Fares on the Rise
Air fares for business travelers have already risen substantially this year, according to American Express. The typical business air fare for more 215 point-to-point routes from 40 major United States cities rose 24 percent from January to June, compared with the corresponding six months of 1996.
 
Niche Marketing
Most airlines are offering fares over the Labor Day holiday as low as $158 round trip between Newark and Los Angeles. But seats and travel times are limited.
Such sales are examples of the niche marketing at which the airlines, hoping to fill every seat instead of just most of them, have become ever more proficient. "We've gotten so good at finding what we call 'troughs of availability,' " said Tim Smith, a spokesman for AMR's American Airlines, which is credited with offering mini-fares for flights of two or three days, "that we offer them in selected markets even on holidays and in summer."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Germans' Inaction on Rates And Data in Japan Lift Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar touched its third straight eight-year high against the mark and a nearly three-month high against the yen yesterday after Germany's central bank left an interest rate unchanged and new Japanese economic data showed surprising weakness.
There had been speculation that the Bundesbank might raise a securities-repurchase rate from its current 3 percent level as a sign of concern over the mark's steady erosion against the dollar, particularly in the last month. Higher rates tend to strengthen a currency by increasing returns on investments denominated in that currency. 
 But the central bank said in a routine announcement yesterday that it was keeping the repurchase rate steady.
Traders were further emboldened to buy dollars on a report from the Ifo economic-research institute of Germany suggesting that the Bundesbank was unlikely to take decisive action now to defend the mark. The conspicuous absence of any central-bank warning about the dollar's ascent also contributed to the rally.
"Now that the Bundesbank thing is behind us, the dollar continues to roar," said Jan Alvarez, senior foreign-exchange trader at Corestates Bank in Philadelphia. "Nobody's coming in putting their foot down, saying enough is enough."
The dollar reached an intraday high of 1.8832 marks, the strongest since October 1989, before settling in New York late yesterday at 1.8792 marks, up from 1.8664 late Monday.
Against the yen, the dollar reached an intraday high of 119.32, the strongest since May 13, before settling at 119.25 yen, up from 118.35 yen Monday. The British pound weakened to $1.6242 from $1.6303.
The dollar gained against the yen on a report by Japan's Economic Planning Agency saying that consumer spending was taking longer than expected to recover from tax increases in April. The report also said that housing construction, an important barometer of the economy's direction, had sharply weakened after showing signs of strength.
It further suggested that Japanese interest rates, which have remained at record lows since September 1995, were unlikely to rise any time soon. Low rates have reduced the demand for yen.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sales at Ford Rose 5.1% In July, Outpacing Estimates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that its United States sales rose more than expected in July, led by continued gains by its pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles.
The company's overall sales rose 5.1 percent from a year earlier; analysts had expected sales to rise about 1 to 2 percent. Ford said domestic car sales fell 5.3 percent, to 153,407, while sales of pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans rose 14.9 percent, to 200,342. 
 Ford said that the decline in sales of cars alone was caused, in part, by insufficient ordering by dealers, masking strong demand.
"Obviously, we're delighted by our continuing success in trucks," Bob Rewey, Ford's group vice president for marketing, sales, and service, said. "Not so obvious is that our car sales are picking up -- more than we expected. For the first time in a long time, dealers are telling us they should have ordered more cars."
As a result of July's increase in overall sales and a favorable economic outlook, Ford said it would increase its third-quarter production schedule by 15,000 cars and 15,000 trucks.
Last week, the General Motors Corporation said its United States sales in July rose 6.7 percent, which was also better than expected, though the Chrysler Corporation said that its July sales fell 9.3 percent.
Japanese auto makers reported mixed results. The Honda Motor Company said its American sales during July rose by 31.8 percent, while the Toyota Motor Corporation said its sales rose 14.6 percent. The Nissan Motor Company, however, said its sales fell 6.9 percent.
Taken together, the reports indicated an industry selling rate for July of 15.1 million vehicles annually, the strongest performance since March and well above the projected 14.8 million, according to Diane Swonk, an economist at First Chicago NBD. The numbers might be exaggerating underlying demand, though, she said.
"Discounting fleet sales and catch-up from earlier strikes played a big role, so this is still a very distorted picture," Ms. Swonk said. "You have to take it in context. The world didn't collapse in the second quarter, and it's not booming today."
Auto makers are using higher rebates and lower loan financing rates and other incentives to draw customers to showrooms. Incentives in July rose to $1,200 a vehicle on average from $800 a year ago, analysts said.
Still, Nicholas Lobaccaro, a Merrill Lynch & Company analyst, who was optimistic about the third quarter, said, "The market has been picking up steam, with the last couple of months probably being abnormally low."
Ford shares fell 37.50 cents, to $40.875.

HEADLINE: Labor Backs McGreevey, Pledging Strong Support

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 5

 BODY:
James E. McGreevey, the Mayor of Woodbridge and a Democratic State Senator, who is attempting to unseat Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, won major campaign support today when the New Jersey State A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced it would endorse his candidacy.
With the endorsement, Mr. McGreevey gained more than just votes from the labor coalition and the million workers across the state that it represents. He is also assured the support of the national A.F.L.-C.I.O., which is expected to dedicate much of its efforts and financial resources to the gubernatorial race here this fall. New Jersey and Virginia have the only two gubernatorial races in the country this year, and both states are expected to get widespread attention. 
 "There is going to be a keen amount of focus by not only the national A.F.L.-C.I.O., but also the national political parties," said Charles Wowkanech, president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. "We expect to have a full-blown labor campaign here."
Mr. Wowkanech said he did not know how much money the group's national office expected to spend in New Jersey, but he said that during a recent meeting with union leaders in Washington, "a strong commitment was made, financially and in terms of staff."
Nearly 500 delegates from locals around the state cheered enthusiastically after voting unanimously to support Mr. McGreevey. A motion was made to endorse Mrs. Whitman, but no delegate was willing to second the motion.
Moments after the vote, Mr. McGreevey appeared on stage with leaders of the group. "We are going to rebuild this state," he said, shouting above the cheers.
Just before the vote, both candidates spoke to the delegates, who were meeting inside a hotel ballroom here. In his speech, Mr. McGreevey struck familiar themes sure to resonate with labor leaders, attacking Mrs. Whitman's privatizing of state services and the awarding of state contracts to companies that use nonunion workers.
But Mrs. Whitman, who has maintained a strong lead over Mr. McGreevey in the polls, made it clear that she is not easily conceding the labor vote. Last week, even though she knew that the group was expected to endorse Mr. McGreevey, the Governor requested that she be allowed to address the delegates.
"Knowing what the results were going to be in advance, the Governor at least wanted an opportunity to put her position out there," said Tom Wilson, Mrs. Whitman's campaign manager. Both candidates were invited as a result of Mrs. Whitman's request.
In her speech to the delegates, Mrs. Whitman discussed major construction projects she has supported, her job retention initiatives and the increase in the number of jobs in the state during her administration. "I am proud of my record," she said. "That's why I'm here today."
Afterward, Mrs. Whitman said she was confident that many union members would support her candidacy, despite the leadership's endorsement of Mr. McGreevey. Mrs. Whitman has received the endorsement of the South Jersey Building Trades Council, which represents 5,000 workers, many of them in the Atlantic City area, where Mrs. Whitman has overseen significant growth and economic development.
Earlier this week, Mr. McGreevey received the endorsement of the Communication Workers of America, which represents 30,000 state employees, in addition to 30,000 other workers in the state.
Labor is taking a stronger role in this year's governor's race than it did in 1993, when Mrs. Whitman defeated Gov. Jim Florio. Usually, the group waits until the fall to announce its endorsement, but its leaders said they want to have ample time this year to register their members and educate them on the issues. That, in itself, is a small victory for the McGreevey campaign, which has identified the labor movement as one of the traditionally Democratic groups that must coalesce this year if Mr. McGreevey is to have a chance of upsetting the Governor.
In an interview earlier this summer, Steve De Micco, Mr. McGreevey's chief consultant, said the campaign would focus on labor organizations, environmental groups and urban voters. A first priority of the campaign, he said, would be to "activate them, and re-energize them as aggrieved constituencies."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Thais Agree to Raise Taxes And Shake Up Finance

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The Thai Cabinet agreed today to increase taxes and reorganize the nation's financial industry in return for a rescue package led by the International Monetary Fund that would pump as much as $15 billion into the battered economy.
To qualify for the loans, which would also come from foreign governments and banks, Thailand must meet six stringent conditions set by the I.M.F. In addition to raising taxes and acting to clean up the finance industry, it must balance the budget, end subsidies to state companies and utilities, maintain a tight monetary policy, and preserve currency stability by retaining the current foreign-exchange system. 
 The package is meant to assure international investors that the Thai economy is being repaired and to help stabilize the currency, the baht, which tumbled more than 20 percent against the dollar in July after the Government effectively devalued it.
"The most important priority is to rebuild confidence in the foreign investment community," Finance Minister Thanong Bidaya said.
The baht's value soared after the rescue package was approved. [In New York late Tuesday, the baht traded at 27.825 to the dollar, a gain in value of more than 15 percent from a rate of 32.15 to the dollar late Monday.]
The contents of the I.M.F.'s package resemble measures that it imposed on Mexico early in 1995 after the collapse of the peso. Since then, Mexico's financial system has largely stabilized, and the economy, though still depressed in places, has rebounded some, growing 5.1 percent in 1996. It is expected to grow 5 percent this year.
The I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus, said he would soon forward the Thai economic program to his executive board for its endorsement. The fund is expected to provide a credit line as high as $10 billion as part of the overall rescue plan.
Mr. Camdessus said he was in close touch with Asian governments and international institutions "to put together a supplementary financing package in support of the policy efforts of the Thai authorities." That was an indication that the I.M.F. would look for financial help from regional nations and banks, rather than calling on the United States or other Western governments to take part in the Thai rescue plan. Japanese help in particular is expected.
The package is less than the $25 billion some economists estimate Bangkok will need to help revive the economy -- growing at its slowest pace since 1985. Some investors suggested that the I.M.F. could increase the amount if Thai foreign-exchange reserves continued to decline.
Ashok Shah, senior portfolio manager at the British offices of Old Mutual International Asset Managers, commented: "The most important thing is that once they have the I.M.F. come in, it is going to give comfort to a lot of international money managers that there is going to be discipline. Effectively, the I.M.F. is writing a blank check, even though Thailand says it only needs X amount right now."
Under the package, the Thai Cabinet is raising the value-added tax to 10 percent from 7 percent, an increase that was opposed by some ministers. The I.M.F. wanted the levy -- a kind of sales tax at each stage of production and distribution -- raised to bolster Government revenue and curb consumer spending.
"Not approving the V.A.T. increase would bring disaster," said Virabongsa Ramangkura, a former finance minister, who worked with the I.M.F. in the early 1980's, when Thailand also received a bailout.
As part of the package, the Thai central bank's governor said 42 debt-ridden financial companies had been ordered to find new owners. The order followed a similar one to 16 financial companies on June 27.
Thai shares tumbled today as the stock exchange suspended trading in banks and finance companies, creating confusion among investors. Trading resumed after about an hour, and the benchmark index partly recovered, closing 15.35 points lower, at 648.47, down 2.3 percent from Monday.

HEADLINE: Chocolate Less Sweet As a Symbol For Swiss

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: VERSOIX, Switzerland

 BODY:
A rich smell works its way through the small factory where Swiss chocolate is being made, the same way it has been for 122 years here.
Christophe Favarger, a sixth-generation chocolate-maker, points to an ancient wooden blending machine, its stone wheels rotating slowly to transform a mass of brown goo into a velvety smooth confection. 
 "It's very old but we still use it because it is better than any new machine," said Mr. Favarger, a member of one of the pioneering families who, more than 100 years ago, created a chocolate empire in this landlocked country, far from where cocoa beans are grown.
Swiss innovators transformed chocolate-making -- wresting dominance of the industry from nearby countries -- in 1875 by adding milk to chocolate and, shortly after that, using cocoa butter to create silky chocolate that melted in the mouth. For the Swiss, tales of Henri Nestle, Rodolphe Lindt and Jean Tobler, among others, make chocolate part of the country's lore.
Recently, however, ripples have disturbed the smooth surface of the venerable Swiss chocolate business. The nation's 36 chocolate manufacturers have trimmed down to 16, with Favarger remaining as one of the few family-owned companies. Like fellow chocolatiers, Favarger is facing a new era of economic change in Europe that is already cutting into chocolate sales and, ultimately, may mean one of Switzerland's cherished national symbols will have to stop being purely Swiss.
Last year chocolate exports dropped slightly -- a victim of the surging Swiss franc, according to the Swiss chocolate-makers' association, Chocosuisse.
Another threat to Swiss chocolate emerged this spring when Kraft Jacobs Suchard had to recall 500 tons of Toblerone, Switzerland's best-known chocolate bars, because they contained genetically altered soybeans, used as a combining ingredient.
Although using genetically modified products, once banned, is now permitted, Swiss consumers have vigorously opposed it, making sales here rather difficult. But finding reliable sources of conventionally grown beans is getting harder, industry officials say, because growers are increasingly mixing conventional and altered beans.
Chocolate-makers agree that the survival of the craft as a Swiss speciality depends on finding markets outside the country, since domestic consumption is not what it was. Switzerland still leads the world, with 24 pounds sold per capita last year, compared with 10 pounds for Americans. This is down, however, from a peak of nearly 25 pounds in 1990.
Because Switzerland is not a member of the European Union, it has also seen its products slapped with higher tariffs in other European nations, driving up prices and making Swiss goods less competitive.
Today, cocoa bean prices are steady, but milk subsidies in European Union countries undercut Swiss manufacturers. These problems have intensified what, until now, had been a gradual shift in where chocolate is being made. Switzerland's biggest chocolate makers already manufacture largely outside the country.

HEADLINE: Idea of Apologizing for Slavery Loses Steam, at Least for Now

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The idea of a national apology to blacks for slavery seemed to fade today as its originator acknowledged that it was unlikely to happen soon, and President Clinton backed away from it -- at least for now.
A White House spokesman said today that Mr. Clinton had not rejected the idea of issuing an apology to African-Americans. But they said the President did not consider an apology at the top of his agenda, or the agenda of his advisory commission on race relations. 
 "The President has really, in a way, put that issue aside and said that's not going to be the focus of his race initiative; nor is it the place he believes we should really start the kind of discussion he is looking for, one that's aimed at bringing Americans together," Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said today.
Earlier this year, Mr. Clinton embarked on an effort to put the nation's racial problems in the forefront of the national agenda. He has named an advisory commission to work with him and is planning monthly public appearances devoted to discussion of the racial divide in America.
The idea for an apology to African-Americans originated with Representative Tony Hall, Democrat of Ohio, and Mr. Clinton had indicated it might have merit.
In an interview on Monday night on Black Entertainment Television, Mr. Clinton stopped short of dismissing the idea of an apology. But he said that his commission on race, headed by the historian John Hope Franklin, would be weighing the idea, and he wanted to hear panel members' views before making a decision.
"What I think I should do now is let this advisory board do its work and see what they have to say about the apology issue and all the related issues," Mr. Clinton said.
When Mr. Hall first suggested the idea, he said he thought it could start a process of healing between whites and blacks. He and a dozen other lawmakers, all of whom are white, sponsored a House resolution calling for the apology. They said they hoped that once the House approved the measure, the Senate and the President would follow suit.
But in an interview today, Mr. Hall acknowledged that his proposal had not got much support and said he doubted it would be approved soon.
"It's something that I believe in personally," he said by telephone from Maine, where he is on vacation with his family. "It's a moral issue for me. I think it's right. It's raised an issue which hasn't been raised ever and it's raised a dialogue that's very, very important. I think it will happen one day. But I'm not sure it will happen while I'm in the Congress or maybe in my lifetime."
Mr. Hall's idea has generated an intense debate on talk shows and among people involved in civil rights issues. The idea gathered some momentum when Mr. Clinton suggested in an interview in June that he was open to it.
"An apology, under the right circumstances, those things can be quite important," the President said on CNN at the time. "Surely every American knows that slavery was wrong, and that we paid a terrible price for it and that we had to keep repairing that."
Mr. Clinton added: "Just to say that it's wrong and that we're sorry about it is not a bad thing. It doesn't weaken us."
Despite the support from some people, leaders of most groups that are involved in the civil rights debate dismissed an apology as an empty gesture unless accompanied by direct action, though the groups often differ on what that action should be.
"My own view, and our own view, is that an apology for slavery might be of useful symbolic value," said Hugh Price, president of the National Urban League. "But it does not address the bottom line issues of inequality, which are rooted in the gaps in education and economic opportunity."
Gerald Reynolds, president of the Center for New Black Leadership, a conservative civil rights organization, said: "An apology is nothing more than an empty gesture. I don't think it reduces crime or reduces teen pregnancy or improves the public school system."

HEADLINE: Rowland Defends His Cottage Purchase, Saying the Criticism Is Political

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Gov. John G. Rowland today defended his purchase of a lakeside cottage from a foundation run by one of his political appointees, saying criticism of the deal was politically motivated.
Edward Marcus, chairman of the state Democratic Party, has questioned the ethics of the purchase. 
 "There's only one person that's driving the story," Mr. Rowland said, "and that's, of course, the Democratic state chairman, so obviously the campaign has begun, the political season is upon us."
Mr. Rowland, a Republican, bought the four-room cottage on Bantam Lake from the White Memorial Foundation, the president of which is Arthur Diedrick, who heads several agencies in the Rowland administration.
The price was $110,000, with a down payment of $5,000 and a 25-year, 7.25 percent mortgage held by the foundation. The Rowlands are also paying the foundation $3,000 a year for 25 years to lease the land on which the cottage sits. The foundation owns most of the land on the Bantam Lake shoreline.
Mr. Marcus said in a news release earlier this summer, "Diedrick expects us to believe he had nothing to do with the exceptional bargain the Governor struck on his purchase of a highly desirable property."
Mr. Diedrick has said the foundation takes most mortgages of homes on land that it still holds because it is difficult to obtain mortgages from banks when the land is leased.
Dean Pagani, a spokesman for Mr. Rowland, said today that the deal was approved by lawyers, one of whom was a senior lawyer at the State Ethics Commission.
Mr. Rowland said the arrangement was "very similar" to those had by 35 other people who have bought homes from the foundation. He said that he had called the foundation to ask whether any properties were vacant, and that after learning that several were, he had decided on his purchase.
"I think the average person out there understands that even governors have an opportunity and a chance to buy a piece of property," Mr. Rowland said. "As I've said before, there was no sweetheart deal, everything's above board."
Mr. Pagani also said there was no reason to think the Governor got a special deal on the mortgage rate.
"In every real estate transaction there is a buyer and a seller and usually a lender and if all those parties agree to the terms of the deal then the deal is made," he said.
