HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
A Restaurant May Once Again Fill Delmonico's

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
It is a New York City landmark -- the home of Delmonico's, the restaurant credited with introducing haute cuisine to the United States in the mid-19th century. It was a gathering place for New York society, where visiting dignitaries like Charles Dickens dined on fare like the stuffed lamb dish agneau farci a la Walter Scott. One of its chefs, Charles Ranhofer, was the creator of baked Alaska and lobster Newburg.
But the restaurant at 56 Beaver Street, two blocks south of Wall Street at South William Street, has sat vacant since the early 90's, a victim of the real estate recession that turned much of downtown into a ghost town. 
 Now, however, with the upturn in the financial district's office market, and the conversion of several vacant office buildings to residences, the 12,500-square-foot-space, with its mahogany panels, etched glass windows and portrait of Mark Twain signed by the author, has suddenly become attractive to restaurateurs.
"Almost every major restaurateur has looked at the site and has expressed interest," said Francis Greenburger, chairman and chief executive of Time Equities, who with a group of investors bought the eight-story 1891 building that houses the restaurant for $3 million in 1995. "We've had offers from two or three, and we expect offers from several more. We'll take all the offers and try to choose what we feel is the best operator for the location."
He declined to disclose the names of the restaurateurs, but real estate brokers familiar with the neighborhood said they included the owners of the Harley-Davidson Cafe and the Match restaurants.
Mr. Greenburger is not alone in his optimism about the site. "Downtown is finally going to happen," said Faith H. Consolo of the Garrick-Aug Associates retail brokerage firm. "I see three or four famous restaurateurs going downtown -- they're all looking downtown -- and Delmonico's is a good location."
Mr. Greenburger actually had a potential tenant earlier this year. Joe Quattrocchi, the owner of the Commonwealth Brewery restaurants in Boston and at Rockefeller Center, planned to open a brewery in the Delmonico's space. Mr. Greenburger said there were problems obtaining a liquor license, and he let Mr. Quattrocchi out of the lease in May.
"The State Liquor Authority decided that a brewery serving food is not a restaurant, but is closer to a liquor store," Mr. Greenburger said. "And in New York State, a single proprietor can only own one liquor store. So he was denied a license."
Mr. Greenburger said he was seeking a rent of $425,000 a year, escalating to $500,000 a year over a five-year period, "which is less than $40 a square foot annually, for an equipped restaurant in a historic building in a historic location."
The building above the restaurant was one of the first downtown office buildings converted to residential use under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Downtown Revitalization Plan, which provides tax abatements for such conversions. Time Equities spent $2.5 million renovating the building into 37 loft apartments -- ranging from 750-square-foot studios to 1,500-square-foot two-bedrooms, with monthly rents from $1,200 to $3,300. The apartments are fully leased.
Previous owners had spent $6 million in the early 1980's turning the building into 30 luxury condominiums, but the residential condominium market turned soft and the apartments were rented as office space. At the same time, Delmonico's was recreated from turn-of-the-century photographs; that Delmonico's restaurant closed in the early 90's.
Delmonico's was founded in 1827 on William Street in lower Manhattan by Swiss-born brothers, Peter and John Delmonico. After their original restaurant was destroyed in the Great Fire of 1835, which devastated much of the Wall Street area, they put up a four-story building at Beaver and South William. At its entrance were four columns reputed to have been excavated from Pompeii and brought to New York by John Delmonico.
An 1838 menu had 11 pages, with 47 kinds of veal, 12 kinds of boiled beef and 50 fish dishes. In the succeeding decades, the Delmonico family opened branches elsewhere in the financial district, as well as at 14th Street and in midtown.
In 1891, the Beaver Street building was replaced, at a cost of $360,000, by the current eight-story cast-iron and steel-framed one, designed by James Brown Lord. The Renaissance Revival building, in orange brick, brownstone and terra cotta, had dining rooms on the first and second floors and a kitchen on the eighth, connected to the restaurant by pneumatic tubes and hydraulic elevators. Two columns from the 1835 building were incorporated in the new entrance. The Delmonico family closed the restaurant in 1917, but an uptown branch at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue remained in operation until 1925.
The Beaver Street restaurant was re-established in 1934 by the restaurateur Oscar Tucci as Oscar's Oldelmonico. The Tucci establishment closed in the 1970's.
The Landmarks Preservation Commission, in designating the building last year, called it "one of the finest surviving late-19th-century buildings in Manhattan's financial district."
Mr. Greenburger, who has purchased five downtown office buildings for residential conversion -- the others are at 15 Dutch Street, 41-43 John Street, 47 West Street and 80-84 Nassau Street -- said he was confident the growing downtown population would provide customers for a restaurant -- and incentive for a tenant.
"There are a lot of people coming down here," he said. "This summer, in two apartment buildings within a block of us -- at 45 Wall Street and 25 Broad Street -- 2,000 people are moving in. State employees -- 1,800 of them -- from various agencies just moved in to 60 Broad Street, a block away. And then there's 55 Water Street, which just leased 936,000 square feet to Standard & Poor's and 155,000 square feet to Chubb Insurance. That's a lot of potential customers."

HEADLINE: THE U.P.S. WALKOUT: THE IMPASSE;
No Talks, and Very Few Deliveries, in United Parcel Strike

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The strike by drivers, loaders and sorters at the United Parcel Service slowed the company's business to a near standstill yesterday, and for the second straight day there were no negotiations between management and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
Officials at U.P.S., the nation's biggest shipping company, said they had few packages to deliver, because the company had not accepted parcels for ground shipment since the strike, by 185,000 teamsters, began on Monday. 
 U.P.S. officials said that they were concentrating on continuing their overnight air shipments and international deliveries but that doing so was a struggle, because most of the company's pilots -- members of another union, the Independent Pilots Association -- had refused to cross the teamsters' picket lines.
In a rally at a U.P.S. depot in the Washington suburb of Burtonsville, Md., Ronald Carey, the teamsters' president, said it was time for the company to return to the bargaining table, which the union itself quit late Sunday night in favor of a strike.
Mr. Carey said the union's main concerns were persuading the company to create more full-time jobs and preserving the current pension arrangement.
"There is nothing more for them to wait for," said Mr. Carey, who was joined at the rally by the Rev. Jesse Jackson. "The strike has shut them down. Now it's time for them to get serious about a settlement."
Responding to Mr. Carey's call for renewed bargaining, a U.P.S. spokeswoman, Kristen Petrella, said, "We are willing to continue to discuss the matter with the teamsters, but we must emphasize that our last, best and final offer remains unchanged."
Once again, businesses around the country scrambled to find alternative ways of getting their goods shipped. A common complaint was that the United States Postal Service, concerned that it might be overwhelmed, was frequently refusing to take more than four packages from small companies.
Concerned about the strike's economic effects, Labor Secretary Alexis Herman and John Calhoun Wells, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, urged both sides to resume talks.
The White House again took a hands-off approach. Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said President Clinton did not have the authority to intervene in this case under the Taft-Hartley Act, which empowers the Government to seek an injunction against any strike that imperils the nation's safety or economic health.
"We do not find that that standard has been met in this case," Mr. McCurry said, "and it seems unlikely, given the structure of the industry, that it will be met."
Sixteen strikers around the country were arrested on Monday in incidents related to the walkout, and nine more yesterday. These included five pickets who, the police said, tried to block the way of United Parcel delivery trucks in Somerville, Mass.
Labor experts declined to predict how long the strike would last. But Michael Belzer, a former truck-driving teamster who is now a labor researcher at Cornell University, suggested that the eventual settlement would obligate the company to create more full-time jobs than the number to which it would be committed in what it calls its "last, best and final" offer.
The teamsters are angered that 38,000 of the 46,000 union jobs that U.P.S. has created since 1993 have been part-time. The part-time jobs, which account for three-fifths of all the company's unionized workers, pay about $9 an hour on average after two years, while full-time jobs pay $19.95.
In its offer, the company pledged to turn 10,000 part-timers into full-time workers as positions open because of retirement or expansion. It also offered to create 200 new full-time positions a year in each of the next five years.
But union officials are demanding that U.P.S. create several thousand new full-time positions a year. Rand Wilson, a union spokesman, said the company could easily create thousands more full-time jobs, noting that business volume was so great that in an average week, it had 10,000 part-time employees working more than 35 hours.
The company is reluctant to commit itself to thousands of new full-time jobs, however, because it wants to retain flexibility, particularly as protection against an end of the economic expansion.
Teamster negotiators are also pushing the company to raise the part-timers' starting wage, which has remained unchanged since 1982 at $8 an hour for loaders and $9 an hour for sorters. (The drivers are all full-time employees.) Company officials say their offer, which they describe as generous, would push a part-timer who begins at $8 to a wage of $10.50 after five years.
While the teamsters contend that the main issue is part-time work, U.P.S. executives maintain that the real sticking point is the company's demand to create a single pension plan for its workers and withdraw from the 31 multi-employer teamster pension plans to which the company now contributes.
Susan Rosenberg, a spokeswoman at the company's headquarters in Atlanta, said U.P.S. was tired of subsidizing the pensions of thousands of retirees whose employers have gone bankrupt. She also said the company would make sure that the new plan's investments were managed more prudently than the teamsters' multi-employer plans.
"We know that our people will get higher pensions as part of a single-company plan," Ms. Rosenberg said. "In the multi-employer plan, we have to pick up the slack of people who worked for other companies that went belly up."
Teamster officials are fighting to keep U.P.S. in the multi-employer plans. These plans, the union asserts, are preferable because if a company belonging to a plan goes bankrupt, contributions from other employers will help insure adequate pensions for workers at the failed company.
"Multi-employer plans," said Mr. Wilson, the union spokesman, "protect workers from the vagaries of the economy and any particular company's ups and downs."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Five strikers were arrested yesterday outside a United Parcel depot in Somerville, Mass., where pickets tried to block the company's trucks. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE U.P.S. WALKOUT: THE WORKERS;
Angry Voices of Pickets Reflect Sense of Concern

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: WILLOW SPRINGS, Ill., Aug. 5

 BODY:
The pickets signs bobbed like kites in the wind. Clenched-fisted truckers along 79th Street blared horns of solidarity. The striking workers chanted, vowing never to surrender.
But there was more worry than bravado in the voice of Linda Borucki, who has been a part-time worker at United Parcel Service for 13 years. 
 "You look around and it's hard to find real full-time work anymore," said Ms. Borucki, 31, who brought children's books to the picket line to occupy her 8-year-old son, Cyril. "How do people expect you to make it?"
On the outskirts of the huge U.P.S. center in this Chicago suburb, where about 70 percent of the 5,500 employees are part-timers, the striking workers sounded at times as if they were not simply taking on one company, but corporate America.
"These companies all have the formula," said Laura Pisciotti, 30, who rides two buses for more than an hour to work for $8 an hour, 20 to 25 hours a week. "They don't take you on full time. They don't pay benefits. Then their profits go through the roof."
The use of part-time workers and the pension fund are the two crucial issues in the stalemate in contract talks between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and U.P.S. The union says in a booming economy, the company should be creating more full-time, higher-paying jobs.
But in a quick-turnaround business, U.P.S. sees the part-timers as an economic lifeline.
Those workers were walking the picket line today, a sunny day with just a hint of autumn chill.
Ms. Borucki, drives an older-model car and shares a one-bedroom apartment with her son in Burbank, Ill., a working-class suburb. Her son takes the bedroom; she sleeps in the living room.
"Where would we cut back?" she asked.
A woman at her side, Leatha Hendricks, 36, spoke up in anger.
"People don't even look at workers as human beings anymore," Mrs. Hendricks said. "My name is Leatha, but to them, I'm just a machine. All they care is that you've got some strength in your back. And when your back goes out of whack, it's over. You're gone."
Most of the strikers said they had very little financial reserve to endure a long strike.
George Sanchez, who came to the United States from Mexico as a child in 1979, said he could last two weeks, at most, before looking for another job.
"I'll have to take something," Mr. Sanchez said. "But most jobs are not union. And they're worse than this."
Mr. Sanchez said that as a part-timer he earned $8 an hour, for 20 to 25 hours a week, but had little prospect for advancement. He also fixes cars in his Cicero neighborhood.
"I don't have insurance for my kids," he said, as two of his three children, Jasmine, 8, and Kiara, 3, stood nearby.
Mr. Sanchez's father came to Chicago looking for work, taking a job at a Zenith factory. But he lost his job when Zenith moved its production to a plant to Mexico.
Mr. Sanchez said U.P.S. was unwilling to pay more, or to give workers more hours. And the job atmosphere was tense, he said.
"They push and push," Mr. Sanchez said, "always on top of you."
Ms. Pisciotti, the single mother of a 3-year-old daughter, said she fell recently and hurt her arm, and a supervisor pushed her to keep working.
"He just yelled, 'Come on -- get going, get going,' " she said.
While most of the newer workers make about $8 an hour, some longer-term ones make $14 an hour. A small minority make nearly $20 an hour.
The disparity stems from a two-tiered wage scale that the union accepted in the 1980's, and now regrets. The differences in wages for people doing the same jobs has sometimes caused dissension within the ranks.
Mike McCartan, 38, a part-time worker for 10 years, said he could survive financially only because his wife had a job in a grocery store.
The father of 5-year-old twins, Mr. McCartan is a tall, square-shouldered man who wore a sticker on a T-shirt that pledged, "We'll fight for more full-time jobs."
He said the company had been dangling the prospect of a full-time job for him for many years.
"You can't feed your family on promises," Mr. McCartan said. "You can't make the house payment on promises."
The striking workers carefully watched a car cross the picket lines about every 10 minutes. When the face inside the car was familiar -- a neighbor or a friend -- a gasp would go up, and then jeers.
"No. Don't do it," said Erma Young, a 45-year-old striking worker, as she spotted an acquaintance crossing the line.
Ms. Young shook her head, then cast a look of affection toward some fellow strikers.
"Don't matter if we're white, black or purple," she said, "just matters that we stick together."
A teamsters official stopped at the picket site to rally the strikers.
"We've had reports that some people are going inside, working their shift," said Mike Marasovich, the teamster official, "then coming out and signing, as if they'd been on the picket lines."
As boos rang out, Mr. Marasovich told the strikers: "We need you to look out for each other. Somebody pulls that, you isolate them. You deserve better than that."
Kathy Gedeon, a shop steward who has been a part-time U.P.S. worker for 23 years, said teamster members had taken a more active role in the last few years, as the union has become more democratic.
"People are just now learning what a union can do for them," said Ms. Gedeon, who has a master's degree in psychology, and works a second job as a counselor at a homeless shelter. "We now feel like we have a say-so."
Strikers called today for keeping the heat on upper management.
Marilyn Lange, a 43-year-old part-timer worker, raised aloft a sign that said, "The men in suits are making all the loot."

Mike McCartan, right, vowed to fight for more full-time jobs. (Lloyd DeGrane for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Electric Cars Get a Big Push In New York

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 5

 BODY:
In a decision that environmentalists contend will provide a major boost to the nation's tiny market in electric cars, a Federal judge ruled today that New York State can order automobile manufacturers to sell thousands of electrically powered vehicles in the state beginning this fall.
The ruling by Judge Lawrence E. Kahn of Federal District Court in Albany upholds a six-year-old state rule requiring that 2 percent of all vehicles sold during the 1998 model year, which begins on Oct. 1, be powered by electricity. The quota gradually increases to 10 percent by 2003. 
 The case, which was brought by the automotive industry, was being closely watched around the country because New York is now the only state that is mandating the sale of electric cars in 1998. Under pressure from automobile makers, both California and Massachusetts backed away from similar mandates last year and now will not require the sale of electric cars until 2003.
New York State officials estimate that the mandate will require the sale of 7,800 electric cars in 1998, which would be a huge increase over the several dozen battery-powered vehicles traveling the state's roads now. No one is currently marketing electric cars anywhere in the state, officials said, though some companies are offering the vehicles for employees' use as part of test programs.
"This is tremendously important," said Val Washington, executive director of Environmental Advocates, a nonprofit group. "The car manufacturers were not bringing electric cars to New York, and they wouldn't have without this mandate. Now they have to."
But automotive industry officials said the mandate was forcing them to sell a product that is ill-suited to New York's cold climate and that consumers were not yet interested in buying. If anything, they said, the mandate would turn car buyers off of electric vehicles, thereby hurting the market in the long run. They said they planned to appeal the decision.
"Technology and the free market should determine when electric vehicles are ready for the market, not the mandate," said Jay Hyde, communications manager for the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, which represents Chrysler, Ford and General Motors. "If you force them onto the market when the technology is not ready, you run the risk of souring consumers on the technology, which is very promising. We wouldn't want to see that happen."
State officials said the ruling would help New York meet tougher pollution standards set by the 1990 Federal Clean Air Act without creating new burdens on manufacturers. "This is a victory for clean air," Gov. George E. Pataki said in a statement.
The state's regulation was enacted in 1991 under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who sought to take advantage of amendments to the Clean Air Act allowing states to impose automobile emissions rules as tough as California's. At that time, California had an ambitious timetable requiring car manufacturers to sell increasingly clean-burning cars, culminating with the mandate for the sale of zero-emission, or electric, cars in 1998.
Car makers twice challenged that rule in court and lost. Then, earlier this year, after California had abandoned its plan to mandate the sale of electric cars between 1998 and 2002, the automotive companies again sued, arguing that the Clean Air Act required New York's standards to be identical to California's. They also contended that current electric-car technology would not work in New York's cold climate.
Judge Kahn rejected those arguments today.
While the state's law may impose economic hardships on car manufacturers, he said, such problems "are overborne by Congress's intent that the quality of the air we breathe should continue to improve and benefit from all available technological advances."
Under the state rule, automobile manufacturers that do not meet their 2 percent quotas by the end of the 1998 model year can be fined several thousand dollars a day, state officials said. The state could also ask a judge to order the companies to reduce their sales of nonelectric cars in the state until the 2 percent standard was met.
It was not clear tonight whether the automobile makers would try to enter into negotiations with the Pataki administration to try to reduce the first-year quota. Aides to Mr. Pataki said they had not heard of any such overtures, and they questioned whether the Governor would entertain them if they were made.
Despite their vigorous attempts to block electric-car mandates on both coasts, some automobile makers have begun marketing, on a very limited basis, battery-powered cars in the West. General Motors, for instance, has been selling a $34,000 two-seater called the EV1 that can travel as many as 90 miles between charges. It takes about two hours to recharge the car. Only about 200 people have bought the car, which is being sold mainly in Southern California and Arizona.
Industry officials contend that the batteries being mass-produced for electric cars will get less mileage in New York's cold climate. But environmentalists say that there is new battery technology that will allow cars to travel farther between charges -- 130 miles or more -- and that are not affected by the cold weather.
The New York mandate will spur mass production of those batteries and bring down the cost of electric cars, the environmentalists said. "The technology has been advancing almost daily," said Sheila Lynch, executive director of the Northeast Alternative Vehicle Consortium, a Boston-based group that promotes electric cars. "I hope the manufacturers get the message that New York wants clean-fuel vehicles."

HEADLINE: Leading Index Slowed Pace In 2d Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
A popular index intended to forecast the economy slowed markedly in the latest quarter, perhaps signaling that any rebound in growth in this year's second half would be modest at best.
The index of leading indicators registered no increase in June despite the continued surge in stock prices, a key component of the index, the Conference Board reported today. Except for a tiny April decline, June's performance was the weakest since October. 
 "It's probably saying that you're not going to get a massive snapback" from the economy's 2.2 percent growth rate of the April-June period, said Maureen F. Allyn, chief economist at Scudder, Stevens & Clark. "If that's the case, we don't have any problems. Let's just hope it's right."
Resumption of rapid growth -- anything approaching, 3 percent, for example -- would increase the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates as an anti-inflation measure, analysts say. On the other hand, continued subdued expansion, as seemingly hinted at by the forecasting index, "could lead the Fed not to tighten," said John E. Silvia, chief economist at Zurich Kemper Investments in Chicago.
But as a predictor, the index has a spotty record. It is structured more to forecast turns in the business cycle rather than fluctuations in an existing trend.
"It hardly looks like the economy will pick up in the second half of the year," said David Orr, chief capital markets economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C. On the other hand, he added, the index rose tepidly last autumn only to have the economy soar at an unsustainable 4.9 percent pace in the first three months of this year.
Today's report showed that the index in the second quarter rose four-tenths of 1 percent, compared with a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the January-March period.
The unchanged June reading of 103.8 reflected a standoff between five components of the index that advanced and five that held it back. The main upward forces were higher stock prices and an expanded money supply. Lesser contributions came from higher factory orders for capital goods, a rise in consumer expectations and more factory orders for consumer goods.
The negatives, ranked by impact, were a rise in first-time claims for jobless benefits, a shorter average workweek, a narrower spread between overnight and 10-year Treasury interest rates, faster deliveries by corporate suppliers -- a possible sign of decreased demand -- and a further decline in permits for new buildings.
Two companion gauges of the economy were also part of today's report. The index of coincident indicators, whose components historically have reversed direction at about the same time as aggregate economic activity, rose three-tenths of 1 percent for June and increased at a 3.4 percent annual rate for the second quarter.
Assuming modest increases in the coincident indicators over the net three months, the economy should grow at a 2.5 percent pace in the July-September quarter, Macroeconomic Advisers, a St. Louis consulting firm, told its clients. It based this on an equation that predicts growth from the four coincident components.
The index of lagging indicators, which tends to move only after the economy as a whole, rose two-tenths of 1 percent, the Conference Board also calculated.
The ratio of the coincident index to the lagging one, a combination regarded as predictive, edged up slightly in June, continuing a recent pattern that has been fairly level.
The index of leading indicators, which had risen three-tenths of 1 percent in May, has itself held in a narrow range for more than a year, Cheryl R. Katz of Merrill Lynch noted. "We continue to look for United States economic growth to remain at a healthy 2.5-3 percent rate for the second half," she said.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1802 words

HEADLINE: Even Nature Can Be Turned Into a Security;
High Yield and Big Risk With Catastrophe Bonds

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Steven Goldstein has $3 million riding on whether a killer hurricane thrashes the Atlantic Seaboard this year.
If the gods of weather are kind, and damage is not widespread, Mr. Goldstein's investment venture will pocket a little more than $350,000. But if a storm hits with great force, his New Jersey firm has a whopping downside: It could lose the entire $3 million. 
 Mr. Goldstein just took the plunge into one of the most nerve-jangling securities ever designed, with a name to match: catastrophe bonds. They pay three or four percentage points more than comparably rated corporate bonds in a world where deals often hinge on a fraction of a percentage point. But unlike the situation with most other bonds, their entire principal can be forfeited to pay insurance claims if a big hurricane or earthquake hits.
When Wall Street investment bankers dreamed up these beauties, even the most daring high rollers ran for cover. But the bankers found a way to quantify the risk in terms that bond buyers could understand. And now, as they say in Monte Carlo, the tables are open. The first deal clicked last December. Late last month, the Swiss Reinsurance Company, one of the world's largest companies in the business of selling insurance to other insurers, completed a $137 million bond sale linked to the potential for a California earthquake. And a few weeks earlier, the United Services Automobile Association, one of the leading home and auto insurers, sold $477 million of the bonds that Mr. Goldstein bought.
Here is the gamble that he and his fellow bondholders -- all big-time professional investors -- are taking: If a single East Coast hurricane wreaks enough havoc within one year of the issue date to cost the insurer at least $1.5 billion in damage claims, the investors say goodbye to their entire principal. If the loss is between $1 billion and $1.5 billion, they lose a portion of their principal. Clear skies, or any combination of smaller storms, and the investors walk away with their principal plus about 11.8 percent, depending on fluctuations in London bank lending rates.
(One saving grace of the bonds is that if the worst happens, investors are at least assured of collecting the promised interest. But that, of course, amounts to only a fraction of the principal. And both U.S.A.A. and Swiss Re also offered bonds that paid less interest but guaranteed investors they eventually would get back some or all of their principal, no matter what disasters struck.)
Wall Street is humming over the new securities. Nearly every big house has a team arranging deals. Goldman, Sachs alone has a dozen people working on them full time.
"This is a hot new market, and there's a good chance of it developing into a very substantial market," said Jeff Mulholland, a vice president at Goldman.
To some extent, the new bonds are structured like those backed by mortgages, auto loans and credit card debt, in which tens of millions of dollars worth of loans are put together, then chopped up and sold to investors. The market for such bonds has soared into the trillions of dollars. And while bankers do not expect the catastrophe bonds to reach that level, they do envision a market in the tens of billions.
But unlike mortgage-backed bonds and the like, catastrophe bonds have no assets behind them; that is one reason many traditional money managers are keeping their distance. Nor do these bonds spread the risk of an individual failure in the same way as mortgage-backed bonds, since each catastrophe bond rests on a particular gamble.
But other investors like the fact that the bonds are unaffected by the ups and downs of the economy and thus help balance a portfolio, while beefing up performance numbers. Indeed, while catastrophe bonds are only for sophisticated investors with lots of money in various financial instruments, Mr. Goldstein, who has been handicapping insurance risk for years as the executive of a reinsurance company, says they are a far cry from casino gambling.
Deciding to play or not, Mr. Goldstein said, is a matter of working out the mathematical probability of disaster -- which for these bonds is tantamount to default. The bankers selling these bonds say that you do not need to be a meteorologist to quantify the risk. They have hired Ph.D.'s to churn through decades of data on storms, quakes, geographic concentrations of insurance coverage, housing stock and building codes. In the U.S.A.A. deal, the answer from the computers was that the likelihood that U.S.A.A. would be hit with a hurricane costing the company more than $1 billion was less than once in 100 years.
Once the computers did their work, the rating agencies -- Fitch Investors Service, Standard & Poor's, Moody's Investors Service and Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company -- reviewed the catastrophe bonds as they would any others.
Instead of focusing on whether a disaster might strike, the agencies took the "once in 100 years" calculation and converted that into their way of talking about the likelihood of default. By their reckoning, the riskiest bets in U.S.A.A.'s deal were equivalent to those offered by junk bonds, albeit highly rated ones. The bonds that provided some protection of principal were rated as safer investment grade. Still, because of the nature of the bonds and because they are new, the issuers had to pay several percentage points more than for comparably rated bonds.
The rating agencies, said Jon Barry, a director at Salomon Brothers, have helped make the whole enterprise look rational. "They've given everybody ground cover," he said.
Of course, the past is not necessarily prologue. Investors have only to review the disasters of recent years -- like Hurricane Andrew, which inflicted $15.5 billion in damages in southern Florida in 1992, or the earthquake in Los Angeles two years later that cost insurers $12.5 billion -- to realize that "once every 100 years" events can strike more frequently. Besides, the programs that calculate statistical probability are not perfect. "Computer modeling is an imprecise science," Mr. Goldstein said. "Therein lies the uncertainty."
Indeed, the new investments take some getting used to. "When you talk to investors they imagine going to the boss to tell her they've just invested in a hurricane hitting North Carolina," one investment banker said. "And, it's kind of binary. Either the hurricane doesn't hit and they look like a hero. Or it does hit and they get fired."
Investors in these deals, Mr. Mulholland said, have to think in terms of the long run. "You don't want to play this game just once," he said. "You want to do more transactions so you can spread your risk. If you get hit in the first year, you give yourself the chance to recoup in the following years."
Mr. Goldstein and his colleagues at the PXRE Reinsurance Company in Edison, N.J., feel catastrophe bonds may be the wave of the future for the reinsurance business. And with that in mind, they formed a joint venture, Cat Bond Investors, allying PXRE with the Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company in Hartford. The hurricane bonds were the venture's first investment.
All the deals so far have been private placements limited to professionals with portfolios in the hundreds of millions or billions of dollars. These players are big enough to absorb a $5 million or $10 million loss on catastrophe bonds and go in for another round. The bonds are not available to small individual investors, though bankers say some mutual funds -- which they would not identify -- have bought the bonds in small quantities. Investors for years have been able to take direct risk on insurance through Lloyd's of London. But the Lloyd's investors put their entire net worth at risk, while catastrophe bondholders have a finite liability.
Anthony Chiarenza, the chief executive of Hedge Financial Products, a subsidiary of the CNA Financial Corporation, one of the largest commercial insurers, said the appeal of catastrophe bonds had been heightened by a decline in junk bond yields and by increasing concerns that the stock market was overheated.
For insurers, the bonds are a response to the terrible pain they suffered in the early 1990's from Hurricane Andrew and the Northridge, Calif., quake. Not only did the one-two punch double the cost of reinsurance, it also made insurance companies realize that the reinsurers' pockets might not be deep enough to cover a truly cataclysmic event. For all the wreckage Hurricane Andrew wrought, with losses several times that of any previous storm, it only brushed Miami. A direct hit on the city could easily put the insurance industry in hock for $50 billion, the experts say. Reinsurers would be able to cover only $17 billion of that, estimates Sean Mooney, an economist at the Insurance Information Institute, a trade group in New York.
By turning to the capital markets, the insurance companies are not only tapping into an almost bottomless source of financing, but are also creating a counterweight to future price increases by the reinsurers.
Most investors in both the hurricane and earthquake deals are betting against damage levels that are set at several billion dollars greater than anything seen so far. For example, bankers estimate that it would take a storm with total damages in the neighborhood of $20 billion to cost U.S.A.A. $1.5 billion. "We felt the odds of the event happening, the hurricane, were significantly less than the amount they were paying," Mr. Goldstein said.
Demand was greater than expected for both deals. The $477 million U.S.A.A. issue was oversubscribed by more than $500 million, while Swiss Re decided to increase its offering by $22 million more than the $115 million initially planned.
As more offerings become available, bankers say, more investors will come in, and the investors in early deals can diversify their risk within the new class of investment.
"If you're investing in emerging-country debt, you want to invest in 8 or 10 countries," Mr. Barry of Salomon Brothers said. "If one defaults, your portfolio still does well. Some people are saying they don't want to invest in catastrophe bonds until there are a lot more out there."
To be sure, many seasoned professionals continue to look askance at the bonds. Albert Gutierrez, a senior vice president at Conseco Capital Management, the money management unit of the big Conseco Inc. insurance company, says his company is staying on the sidelines for now because not enough offerings exist to spread out the risk. Plus, he says, the company wants to see how the bonds actually do before it jumps in.
"The capital markets are littered," Mr. Gutierrez said, "with high-yielding securities that history has proved were not yielding enough to compensate for the risk."

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: President and Allies Hail 'Milestone'

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
With Speaker Newt Gingrich by his side, President Clinton today signed two bills he called a "true milestone for our nation" that put into place a plan to balance the Federal budget and to cut taxes for the first time since the Reagan era.
The signing ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House marked a truce between the Republicans and Democrats after two and a half years of partisan struggle on fiscal issues that led to the acrimonious Government shutdowns and veto fights of 1995. American flags dotted the lawn. A Marine band on the White House balcony played "God Bless America." 
 No better symbol of the mood of bipartisanship existed than the sight of the onetime bitter adversaries -- Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gingrich -- walking out of the White House together to the ceremony, along with Vice President Al Gore and Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey.
Despite the day's festival of cooperation, Republicans and Democrats were already starting to chart new agendas that promise battles to come over issues they failed to address in this deal, like how to reshape Medicare and Social Security to accommodate the retirement of the baby boom generation. Democrats are looking toward spending more on programs like education while Republicans want to push further with deeper tax cuts.
But for a moment they celebrated the signing of the long-sought legislation to balance the Federal budget by 2002. Surrounded by Democrats and Republicans alike, Mr. Clinton hailed the end "of years in which the deficit drained our economy and dampened our spirit."
"I believe that together we have fulfilled the responsibility of our generation to take America into a new century," Mr. Clinton said, "where there is opportunity for all who are responsible to work for it, where we have a chance to come together across all of our differences as a great American community."
Positively Reaganesque in his imagery, Mr. Clinton added, "We can say with pride and certainty that those who saw the sun setting on America were wrong. The sun is rising on America again."
Mr. Gingrich, the once-triumphant leader of the self-proclaimed Republican revolution who recently had to face down a Republican rebellion against him, thanked not just the President but the First Lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Vice President and Tipper Gore for "their willingness this year coming off their victory to reach out a hand and say, 'Let's work together.' "
Mr. Gingrich called the pair of bills being signed proof "that the American constitutional system works, that slowly over time we listened to the will of the American people, that we reached beyond parties."
In a flight of rhetoric reminiscent of his headiness of old, he pledged to work with Democrats so that "we can make bipartisan progress at home and we can provide bipartisan leadership across the planet."
While Mr. Gore took his turn hailing the agreement, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, who is expected to challenge the Vice President for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000, was notably absent. Mr. Gephardt opposed the balanced budget agreement as skewed to the nation's wealthy.
If the economy continues to perform as expected, the bills will eliminate the Federal deficit by 2002, and the Federal Government will have its first balanced budget since 1969.
The measures put in place more than $95 billion in net tax cuts over five years, including new tax credits for families with children, tax credits for higher education and reductions in the taxes on capital gains and estates.
More than $121 billion in savings are achieved over five years, mostly through limiting Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals. The measures also require that an additional $55 billion in savings be made through annual spending bills.
The bills include new spending as well, creating a $24 billion program to provide health care coverage for up to five million uninsured children. They would restore disability benefits for legal immigrants and some money for welfare programs that were eliminated last year in the new welfare law.
In some ways, the balanced budget agreement was as much a political milestone as a fiscal one, eliminating deficit reduction as the overarching issue preoccupying Washington and muting the sharp differences between the two parties that have existed on fiscal issues. It allows the great majority of Democrats who voted for it to say that they, too, support tax cuts, and gives Republicans the ability to say that they are in favor of education and health programs.
But already as they looked toward a 1998 election in which control of the House could be at stake, the two parties were looking for new agendas that they could play to partisan advantage.
Representative Vic Fazio, a California Democrat, said, for example, that he wanted to see Democrats make another try next year to win money for building new schools and to embrace a range of new issues on education, including the classroom performance of teachers.
"This just puts us in a new era where we have some new issues," Mr. Fazio said, "and the larger question of the balanced budget is no longer the centerpiece."
On the Republican side of the aisle, both Mr. Gingrich and Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, have spoken of seeking further tax reductions and an overhaul of the tax code. Republicans are also assembling their own education agenda.
One looming issue for lawmakers is the impending retirement of the baby boom generation and the threat that the benefits those retirees would draw could renew large deficits and push the Medicare and Social Security programs into insolvency.
Fiscal experts noted that Congress -- because of partisan distrust between House Democrats and Republicans -- failed to enact several measures that had been supported by the Senate that might have made a dent in the problem by raising the retirement age, tying Medicare premium payments to income and introducing a $5 co-payment for home health care visits.
"We are looking at a Medicare problem and a Social Security problem which will get very serious after 2010, and we chose not to take some modest steps toward addressing those problems," said Robert D. Reischauer, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
Instead, the budget law establishes a 17-member bipartisan commission charged with reporting back on ways to keep the health insurance program for the elderly solvent. The report is due in 1999 -- a year after the midterm Congressional elections and a year before the Presidential race.
In the high spirits of the day, Mr. Gingrich pledged to work with Mr. Clinton not just to name a commission "but to enact in 1999 the right savings and the right steps to reform the system for the baby boomers and their children."
Even as Mr. Clinton was celebrating the bipartisan budget agreement today, his aides were debating whether the President should use newly acquired authority to sign a spending or tax measure and then strike out specific provisions within five days.
For the second straight day, the President's senior advisers huddled at the White House examining specific narrowly focused tax breaks that he could cut and debating the politics of doing so.
Officials said they were weighing how this line-item veto would affect the bipartisan mood and examining what kind of veto might make the best legal case, because the power is expected to be challenged in court.
Earlier this year the Supreme Court held that the Congressional opponents who challenged the line-item veto authority as unconstitutional had no standing to sue. But once the President uses the power, it is assumed that another case will be brought.
Mr. Gephardt, in a letter to the President, urged him to take a stand against a tax break given to the tobacco industry, which would allow it to write off a new cigarette tax increase included in the budget legislation against the companies' liability under the proposed national tobacco settlement.
"The American taxpayer deserves better than this special interest giveaway that sidesteps public accountability through back-room deals and under-the-table favors," Mr. Gephardt wrote.
Mr. Clinton's aides said the tobacco provision was not one he was able to veto under the provisions of the line-item veto law.

Ford Sales Increase More Than Expected
Ford Motor said that its United States sales rose more than expected in July, led by continued gains in its pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles.
The company's overall sales rose 5.1 percent; analysts had expected sales to rise 1 to 2 percent. HEADLINE: North Korea Joins Talks With South

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Facing economic collapse, hunger and now drought, North Korea sat down for the first time yesterday with South Korea, the United States and China to discuss arranging peace talks to end the Korean War formally and to ease tensions on the peninsula.
The meeting was a preparatory session for four-party talks proposed by President Clinton and President Kim Young Sam of South Korea more than a year ago. It ended yesterday afternoon with no immediate agreements, although none had been expected.
North Korea's willingness to move ahead with the talks was seen by Administration officials in part as a sign of its desperation over its increasingly severe food shortages, which relief officials are now comparing to the famines in Ethiopia and Somalia. 
 On the eve of the talks, held in New York City in Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs, a senior Administration official said that North Korea's leaders had apparently decided the talks are "necessary to keep the international community engaged" in providing emergency food aid.
The session yesterday was the first of what are expected to be several days of meetings at Columbia involving delegations for each of the four countries. The point is to set a time, place and agenda for the quadripartite talks, which are expected to last for months.
The delegates had little to say after adjourning for the evening to attend a reception. But during a lunch recess, China's representative, Chen Jian, an Assistant Foreign Minister, offered a curt but positive assessment. "So far so good," said Mr. Chen, who was joining the talks for the first time.
Ji Won Suh, a spokesman for South Korea's delegation, said the four parties agreed to settle the least contentious issues first, including the time and place of the talks, while leaving the most contentious -- the agenda -- for the end.
North Korea has indicated that the presence of 37,000 American troops in South Korea should be included in any talks; the United States has argued that the agenda should deal with broader issues of cementing peace first.
Mr. Ji added that during the closed negotiations, North Korea's delegate, Kim Gye Gwan, the deputy minister for foreign affairs, had expressed hopes that the talks would "result in a fruitful conclusion."
Leading up to the meeting, the United States sought to play down expectations, even as American officials expressed hope that North Korea was serious in wanting to reduce tensions and to replace the armistice that ended the fighting in Korea with a more stable permanent treaty.
In what appeared to be a gesture of good will, North Korea on Monday handed over remains believed to belong to four American soldiers killed in 1950.
But with little hard information about North Korea's internal situation, the Clinton Administration remains wary. Officials said the severity of food shortages rather than a genuine interest in improved relations may be what has forced the North Koreans to the table.
Nevertheless, they hoped to use the talks as an occasion to propose modest gestures to improve relations, like establishing a hot line between the forces on either side of the demilitarized zone separating North and South Korea and providing advance notice of military maneuvers.
"I think that with respect to tension on the Korean peninsula, we are better off being engaged in this process and in this structure than we would be otherwise," a senior State Department official said. "So simply having commenced has some intangible benefit."
China's participation in the talks is likely to change the dynamic of the discussions, which until now had included only the United States and the two Koreas. China was North Korea's main ally during the war, but relations have soured in the three years since the death of the former North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung.
"I think the Chinese may be interested in rebuilding that relationship or improving on the present state of the relationship," the official said.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1233 words

HEADLINE: Budget Offers Cornucopia of Tax Breaks For Everyone

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Alongside large tax cuts with mass appeal, like reductions in property taxes and the sales tax on clothing, New York's new state budget is sprinkled with smaller cuts tailored for particular industries, some reflecting the lobbying of particular companies like International Business Machines and the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus.
Ringling and its lobbyists, the influential firm of Davidoff & Malito, won the elimination of the state sales tax on circus tickets, a cut that will cost the state a mere $100,000 a year. Because other major circuses, like the Big Apple Circus, are already exempt as "teaching circuses," only Ringling and perhaps one or two others that pass through the state each year were paying the tax, and only they will benefit from its elimination. 
 Another tax gives businesses up to 15 years to use tax credits they earn from making capital investments in the state, instead of 10 years. State officials said the company behind the measure -- and perhaps the only one that stands to benefit right away -- is I.B.M., which has not yet used all of the credits it earned for investments made in the 1980's, and stood to lose them under the 10-year rule. The extension is projected to cost the state about $5 million a year.
There are several smaller examples: wineries in New York State won elimination of the sales tax on wine tastings, at a cost to the state of $100,000 a year. Several industries that offer coin-operated amenities -- vending machines, photocopiers, car washes and airport luggage cart dispensers -- also won exemption from sales taxes, worth about $8 million a year.
"A lot of these were just nuisance taxes," said John McArdle, a spokesman for the Republican majority in the Senate. "The amounts for the state were small, but for the companies it was a lot of paperwork and a lot of hassle."
The budget also includes tax savings of $14 million a year for the insurance industry, $5 million a year for troubled banks, 1 cent on the sale of each canned or bottled drink, for a total of $26 million a year, $25 million a year for retailers, $3 million a year for unincorporated businesses that hire new workers, $9 million a year for family farmers and $1 million a year for people who put solar power units on their homes.
The Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki agreed to cut 29 taxes in all, from those that dip into the bank accounts of millions of state residents and businesses to those that affect the fortunes of just one company or industry. The list reflects the state's fiscal bounty nearly three years into a Wall Street boom, and perhaps a dose of wishful thinking about the future, as well. The reductions are to be phased in over five years, costing the state just $117 million this fiscal year and ballooning to $4.8 billion, or about $260 per person, in 2001-02.
The Governor and Senate Republicans began the year by proposing ambitious tax cuts and declaring them the top priority. The conventional wisdom was that, as in years past, they would get less than they asked for, demanding the stars and settling for the moon; instead, they got the stars. Nearly every tax cut on the wish lists released last winter appears in the budget.
Not everyone is pleased. Independent fiscal monitors and a handful of legislators have worried aloud that the state is creating huge deficits for itself in future years because the growth of revenue from the personal income tax and other economically sensitive taxes could slow or drop dramatically. Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat, called the budget "fiscal suicide for the state."
When state lawmakers set about cutting taxes two years ago, they aimed at the state's largest source of revenue, the personal income tax, which also happens to be one of the broadest-based levies, paid by everyone from the working class to the wealthy. Most elements of this year's package are for more limited groups of beneficiaries, and many are for businesses rather than individuals.
The largest cut, by far, is a state program to reduce the property taxes localities charge to support local school systems, a program that benefits only homeowners, and that delivers the greatest savings to people in the wealthiest communities. The reduction, to be phased in over five years, will ultimately cost the state $2.24 billion a year.
The impact of the change will vary enormously from place to place, in part because property taxes differ widely. And the cut also gives a larger tax exemption on homes in counties where real estate is expensive, a feature that will almost exclusively benefit residents of the suburban counties around New York City.
In the city, the average savings for a homeowner will be $390 a year. In Westchester, it will be over $1,000.
To make up for the fact that most New York City residents, as renters, pay no direct property taxes, the state will pay to lower the city income tax by 10 percent by 2001, at a cost of $464 million a year.
The state will eliminate the gross receipts tax on hospitals, nursing homes and home care companies, which amounts to a sales tax on health care, at a cost of $530 million a year. It will also reduce by 30 percent the gross receipts tax on utilities, for another $440 million a year.
"The utility tax is probably the best tax cut in terms of fairness, because it's a heavier burden on low-income people and small businesses," said Frank J. Mauro, director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a research group that studies state policies and is funded primarily by unions and foundations. "I would say the health care tax is the second-most-defensible tax cut, because it supports other important public policy goals, like keeping the hospitals viable and keeping down the cost of health care."
The state sales tax on clothing, up to $100 per article, will be eliminated in December 1999, at a cost of $445 million a year.
The budget will also greatly reduce the state's taxes on estates, at a cost of $400 million a year, in a way that will have little effect on low- and middle-income people, who rarely pay any estate taxes. Mr. Pataki has argued that the reduction was needed because elderly people were leaving New York to escape its high estate taxes.
Under the current system, when a person dies, there is no state tax on the first $115,000 of taxable assets left to heirs, on the first $250,000 in value of the person's primary residence, or on the first 5 percent of the value of a business the person owned. Above those limits, assets are taxed at a graduated scale, beginning at 2 percent and rising to 21 percent.
But effectively, the top marginal rate is actually 5 percent. That is because any state estate taxes paid, up to 16 percent of the value of the estate, can be counted as a credit against Federal estate taxes.
Starting next year, the new state law will raise the basic exemption from $115,000 to $300,000 and will lower the top rate from 21 percent to 16 percent, meaning that nearly the entire state tax bill can be credited against the Federal levy.
In 2000, the new state law will replace all three exemptions -- basic, home and small business -- with a single exemption set at the same level as the Federal exemption, or $700,000 in 2000. The Federal exemption is set to rise in steps to $1.3 million in 2006, but the state exemption will be capped at $1 million.

Hearing on Casino Donations

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
State Senator William L. Gormley, a Democrat from Margate, faced a tough battle in the June primary against an opponent whose campaign contributors included lobbyists and others who do business with Donald J. Trump.
After winning the election, Mr. Gormley asked state regulators whether those donors broke a rule banning contributions to state and local candidates on behalf of casino owners or employees. 
 In response, the State Casino Control Commission proposed to clarify the rule and will hold a hearing on it today. Under the clarification, the term "on behalf of" would apply to anyone with "any economic, business, personal, familial or other relationship" to people with casino interests.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
New Tax Law Takes Aim at Estee Lauder

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
In 1995, Wall Street was impressed by the successful initial public offering of the Estee Lauder Companies, a stock that leaped 25 percent in price when it began trading.
But many in Washington were more fascinated by the methods used by Estee Lauder and her son, Ronald, to avoid paying as much as $95 million in capital gains taxes on the profits they made when they sold stock in the company. 
 Now, in the new tax law signed by President Clinton yesterday, Washington has struck back at the Lauders. Unless one of them dies within the next few months -- or unless the law is amended or struck down by a court -- either the Lauders or their estates will end up facing a big tax bill.
That provision of the tax law could catch other families as well. The law has created a situation in which some families would face huge estate tax bills if a family member dies after a certain date, but not if he or she dies earlier. Other families may face the opposite: hefty taxes if a family member dies soon, but not if that person lives for a longer period of time.
In other words, taxes will be certain only if death comes at an inopportune time.
The relevant section of the tax bill concerns what are called "constructive sales" -- that is, transactions that have the same economic effect as selling stock but that previously escaped taxation.
Some such tactics are barred under the new bill. One is the long-term avoidance of taxes through a tactic called shorting against the box. That involves a person who owns a stock borrowing an equal number of shares of the same stock and selling them short. The seller no longer has any economic interest in the shares, since the profit or loss on the shares that are owned will be canceled out by the profit or loss on the short position. But the tax law until now has treated the two positions as separate. The new law deems the short sale to be a "constructive sale" of the stock.
One of the events that precipitated the new law was the Nov. 17, 1995, initial public offering of stock in the Estee Lauder Companies. Estee, the founder of the cosmetics company, and Ronald, a former ambassador to Austria and a one-time candidate for mayor of New York City, sold 13.8 million shares of the company to the public at $26 a share.
But rather than sell their own shares, the Lauders borrowed shares from other family members and sold them. They thus avoided paying as much as $95 million in capital gains taxes that might otherwise have been due. The Lauder case was extensively discussed when the Clinton Administration proposed legislation to prevent people from doing the same thing.
Under the law that then existed, those short positions could remain in effect until the death of each borrowing family member. Then the estate would automatically see the value of the shares raised to the then-current market value, and the share loan could be repaid. The effect would be to permanently avoid the capital gains tax.
The new law, aiming to catch the Lauders and anyone else who has done something similar, provides as follows: Anyone who opened such a position before June 8 of this year, held it open for at least two years, and had it open at any time within three years of their death, would lose the benefit of the increased value of the stock at death. The effect would be to force the estate to pay the capital gains tax.
There is one exception to that. If the short position is closed out within 30 days after the bill is signed -- that was yesterday -- the problem would be eliminated.
That exception would be of minimal use to the Lauders. The stock, having been issued at $26, closed yesterday at $47.31. Estee Lauder or Ronald Lauder could buy some stock at the current price, taking a sizeable tax loss, and repay that stock to reduce the short position. But that tax loss would be a real one as well, and seems to have little appeal to them.
A call seeking comment on the situation yesterday was not returned by a spokeswoman for the Estee Lauder Companies.
Because the stock was sold short less than two years ago, however, the new law would not apply to the estate of either Lauder if that person died within two years of the short sale -- by Nov. 17. The same would be true of the estate of any other person who did a similar transaction. Such transactions were common, although on a much smaller scale. Anyone who did such a transaction, and left it open, would be vulnerable unless they died within two years of doing the short sale.
At least, however, the tax would be smaller than it might have been. The tax would be based on paying capital gains taxes at the new 20 percent rate, rather than at the 28 percent rate that used to prevail.
The others who could be caught -- this time if they die too soon -- are those who had such a position open for at least two years and later closed it by covering the short sale. The law, rather bizarrely, exempts anyone who closes the short position in the 30 days beginning yesterday, but not anyone who closed it before or after that period. If a person who closed the position outside of the magic window were to die within three years of closing the position, his or her estate would face a hefty tax bill, noted Robert Willens, a tax expert at Salomon Brothers. But if that person died after the three years had passed, the tax bill would be much smaller.
Under the new law, constructive sales are now barred, because they will lead to taxation just as if the original position had been sold. But in doing that, Congress was relatively nice to Wall Street, and has left open a number of ways to come close to escaping risk without setting off taxes. The Congress accepted Wall Street arguments that a person should be able to temporarily hedge against losses without generating a tax.
The result is that if you do sell short against the box this year, you will not trigger the tax if the short position is closed by Jan. 30, 1998, and you then remain at risk of loss for at least 60 days. After that, you can put the short position back on, only to remove it again by the following Jan. 30.
In addition, the law seems to encourage the use of options, particularly an option technique known as a collar. In such a collar, a person who owns a stock sells a call option -- giving him the obligation to sell a stock at a certain price on or before a certain date -- and buys a put option, giving him the right but not the obligation to sell the stock at a certain price on or before a certain date. Depending on the relative strike prices of the two options, the result can be effectively the same as shorting against the box, or can leave the holder with some risk of loss or possibility of gain.
The new law says that while the Internal Revenue Service can issue regulations regarding collars, they will be effective only after they are issued, not retroactively. So any collar would now seem to be safe, at least until regulations are issued, particularly if some risk of loss or possibility of gain is preserved.
Robert Gordon, the president of Twenty-First Securities, a New York brokerage firm that often arranges tax-advantaged transactions, said the new law was likely to stimulate the use of options by investors who want to reduce risk while not having to pay taxes. He noted that in some cases, in which a collar effectively eliminated most possible losses, an investor could borrow from the brokerage house a large part of the value of the underlying stock.

HEADLINE: Evolution of an Oil Rush

BYLINE: By Daniel Yergin and Thane Gustafson; Daniel Yergin is president and Thane Gustafson is director of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, an oil research and consulting firm. They are co-authors of "Russia 2010 and What It Means for the World."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
The hottest spot in the oil industry? The Caspian Sea region, where Europe, Central Asia and the Middle East meet. The region's energy reserves are worth trillions of dollars; developing them will cost an estimated $50 billion or more over the next decade.
The stakes are huge. The Caspian Derby is a feverish amalgam of competition, collaboration and political and economic wrangling. The outcome will be critical to global economic growth in the next century -- and to the political consolidation of the independent states of the former Soviet Union, relations between Russia and the West and the role of Iran in the region's economy. 
 The Caspian may hold oil and gas reserves second only to those of the Middle East. Conservative estimates run as high as 100 billion barrels or more -- almost 10 times the reserves of Alaska. That amount could increase as exploration moves into deeper waters.
By as early as 2010 the Caspian could produce as much oil as the North Sea today, making it one of the world's main production centers. This will take pressure off the global market; by that time, the world could be consuming 30 percent more oil than it is today, with much of the increase in demand coming from Asia. The Caspian region also holds the potential of becoming a crucial supplier of the natural gas that Asia badly needs to meet its growing electric power requirements.
Azerbaijan, Kazakstan and Turkmenistan look like the big winners -- Azerbaijan and Kazakstan with the lion's share of oil, Kazakstan and Turkmenistan with well over half the gas. Russia and Iran appear to have only minor reserves in their corners of the Caspian.
Chevron is already shipping oil by rail from Kazakstan through Russia toward markets in Europe, and oil from Azerbaijan's new offshore fields is expected to reach the shores of the Black Sea, via a pipeline through Chechnya, for shipment to Europe later this year.
This treasure of the Caspian is a treasure rediscovered. In 1873, Robert Nobel, brother of Alfred Nobel, the inventor of dynamite and endower of the Nobel Prize, headed south from St. Petersburg to what is today Azerbaijan. He was looking for walnut trees, whose wood was used to make rifle stocks for the Czar's army. Instead, in Baku, on the shores of the Caspian, he found that local people had already established a primitive oil industry.
The Nobels built up the region's leading oil company; Robert Nobel's brother Ludwig became known as the Oil King of Baku. At the end of the 19th century, Baku was the world's number one source of oil. Until the middle of the 20th century it remained the largest European oil supplier, and capturing Baku was Hitler's top strategic objective when he invaded the Soviet Union in 1941. (The Nazis got close to it but ran out of fuel before they could capture it.) After World War II, output declined, and Soviet oil men turned their attention to the Urals and then to West Siberia for the resources that made the Soviet Union the world's largest oil producer, ahead of Saudi Arabia, by the 1980's.
As recently as the early 90's, many Western companies feared that investment in the Caspian region was too risky. The new independent countries of the former Soviet Union were shaky at best, and were ruled by ex-Communists. Russia might be back any day; there were numerous ethnic conflicts in the region, particularly between Azerbaijan and neighboring Armenia.
The region is hardly stable now, but the situation has improved enough to encourage investment. Russia is coming back but in a different way, as Russian companies promote their interests in the Caspian area. There are cease-fires in Chechnya and between Armenia and Azerbaijan. And though former Communists are still in power around the region, a number of them are, to one degree or another, embracing the free market and trying to attract Western investment.
Azerbaijan's President, Heydar Aliyev, got a warm welcome in Washington last week. Mr. Aliyev, the longtime Secretary of Azerbaijan's Communist Party who was a hard-line opponent of Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the Soviet Politburo, talked to American business leaders about his conversion to free markets.
Mr. Aliyev has played a skillful hand, using oil to strengthen his country's bargaining position against Russia by inviting two dozen foreign companies and governments -- Russian, American, British, French and Turkish, among others -- to develop the oil wealth off his country's shores. President Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakstan, meanwhile, has welcomed Chinese as well as Western investment in Kazakstan's oil development.
Yet the risks to Caspian oil development remain considerable. The key is transportation -- that is, pipelines. At least half a dozen projects are under way or well along in the planning stages. Every single pipeline in the works must cross more than one country's border, and every one involves a delicate geopolitical balance.
For example, there is intense rivalry between Russia and Turkey over the route of the main pipeline that will carry Azerbaijani oil to world markets. If it cuts through Russia, to a Black Sea port for shipment by tankers through the Bosporus Strait, the Russians will increase their leverage in the Caspian region and Russian companies will profit. If the pipeline crosses Georgia and then cuts south across Turkey to the Mediterranean, it would be an economic boon to Turkey.
Yet the sources of instability that scared off oil companies in the early 1990's are still threats. The conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan, for example, remains unresolved; renewed fighting could jeopardize the Azerbaijani pipeline projects.
And if fighting breaks out again in Chechnya, just north of Azerbaijan, an important transportation route from the Caspian could be threatened. There is also inherent tension between Azerbaijan and Iran. About as many Azeris live in Iran as in Azerbaijan. Most Azerbaijanis are Shiite Muslims, but Mr. Aliyev has reaffirmed the country's commitment to secularism. That puts it directly at odds with Iran's Shiite fundamentalists.
Russia casts a large shadow on the region. Some fear it may try to reclaim control over the region. The legal status of the Caspian Sea is still unsettled, and some Russian politicians see the Caspian area as part of Russia's sphere. But the current Government in Moscow is showing more interest in getting the best business deals than in geopolitical hegemony.
In all this, the United States has sought to cast itself in what Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott recently called the role of the "honest broker," helping to solve regional conflicts and building institutions of a market economy, like tax codes.
The Caspian development is off to a much more promising start than might have been expected even two or three years ago. Multinational involvement in projects, including Russian and Turkish companies, will be critical to stability, especially on the main pipeline that will transport Azerbaijani oil. Already, Lukoil, the leading new Russian oil giant with close ties to the Russian political leadership, is an important player in the Caspian region, along with other Russian companies. Other Russian companies are expected to follow.
Indeed, if there is any lesson so far from the Caspian Derby, it is that the more players and the more oil and gas pipelines, the better. This makes it less likely that political interests will overplay their hands.
