HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
3-Day Slide In Treasury Prices Ended

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Treasury market ended a three-day slide yesterday as the Government's quarterly debt refunding proceeded without stumbling and the latest business survey by the Federal Reserve showed the economy growing but with few traces of inflation.
The 30-year bond rose 6/32, to a price of 101 31/32, pushing the yield down to 6.47 percent, from 6.49 percent on Tuesday. Prices and yields of Treasury securities move in opposite directions. 
 At yesterday's auction of $12 billion in 10-year notes, the average yield came in 6.205 percent, down from 6.740 percent in May and the lowest since 5.649 percent on Feb. 7, 1996.
The Treasury's refunding continues today with a sale of 30-year bonds.
In when-issued trading ahead of the auction of 10-year notes, dealers had been offering the securities at a price to yield 6.20 percent, slightly lower than the previous day, suggesting that investors were starting to see value at these levels, given the current economic conditions.
The anticipation of demand even at these relatively low yields, borne out by the auction results, raised expectations that the recent bond market rally, which had been cut short last Friday, might resume after this week's auctions of debt.
Still, Hugh Whelan, vice president and portfolio manager at Aeltus Investment Management in Hartford, , said he thought the results were only mediocre: while the number of bids was solid, the yield was a bit higher than he had expected. "It feels as though we're getting through the auctions, but with little momentum," he said. "I'd expect a similar behavior with tomorrow's 30-year bond, with a lot of pre-auction jockying around. The auction will go well if we're trading at around 6.50 percent on the long bond; however, if it's closer to 6.45 percent, the auction may not go as well."
In fact, early losses in trading of the 30-year bond yesterday were erased as support emerged at a yield of 6.50 percent, prompting some speculators, who had expected yields to continue to rise, to cover short positions. In when-issued trading ahead of today's auction of $10 billion in new 30-year bonds, dealers were offering the securities at a price to yield 6.44 percent.
While traders were preparing for the auction, there was talk that the Fed might enter the market as a buyer of 10-year notes helped lift prices over all.
The market was also helped by the release of the Fed's beige book report on regional economic conditions, which the central bank uses to help it set interest-rate policy. The report showed continuing moderate growth, but without inflation.
"It will take more than strong growth to prompt the Fed to hike rates in August," said Larry J. Wipf, an economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "Despite a tight labor market, wage inflation remains remarkably subdued.
Mr. Wipf added that while the quarterly debt refunding this week might be expected to put pressure on the Treasury market, robust Government revenue growth and restrainted Federal outlays had slashed Government borrowing needs, while foreign buyers have been snapping up the remaining supply. "If the auctions are well received, the bull market is likely to resume," he said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The new tax law encourages savings, but there's a catch.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
AMONG other virtues, the new Federal tax package is supposed to stimulate savings by encouraging families to set aside more for retirement, college and first-time house purchases. And according to some experts, the incentives could make a real difference. "The data are pretty persuasive," argued Martin Feldstein, president of the National Bureau of Economic Research.
But there's a catch: the savings incentives in the new law are offset by new spending incentives -- notably the tax credits for children and for college tuition. 
 Make that catches: the revenue losses could be very large compared with the gain in private savings. So unless Government spending is cut to make up for the erosion in taxes, the impact on national savings (private and government combined) could actually be perverse. "It's entirely possible that the package will reduce savings over all," concluded Bill Gale, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
The two biggest savings initiatives in the tax package consist of an increase on the income limit for eligibility for tax-deductible contributions to individual retirement accounts and the creation of a brand-new form of I.R.A. The latter, dubbed the "Roth I.R.A." in honor of its champion, Senator William Roth of Delaware, allows all but the highest earners to contribute $2,000 annually to special retirement accounts. These contributions are not deductible, but the accumulated income will never be taxed if it is used for college, first-time house purchases or retirement.
The new law also tosses smaller bouquets to potential savers. Education saving accounts will permit parents to set aside $500 a year per child and (Roth I.R.A.-style) withdraw the income, tax-free, for college expenses. It ends the "success tax" -- the surcharge on withdrawals from large pension accumulations that John Shoven, an economist at Stanford University, calculated could raise the effective tax rate on retirement income above 90 percent.
But the package meant to be all things to all people also pares taxes by $400 (later $500) a child for families with incomes below $110,000. "The kiddy tax cut is obviously anti-savings," Mr. Gale argued. "Most people will spend it."
And it provides credits to offset part of parents' college tuition bills. "A lot of this money will be going toward vacations and lawn furniture," predicted Tom Kane, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
Indeed, the broadest objection to tax-based savings incentives is that they are "inefficient" in the sense that they disproportionately erode revenue. Along with Mr. Gale, Eric Engen of the Federal Reserve Board and John Scholz of the University of Wisconsin estimate that from 1980 through 1992 contributions to tax-advantaged retirement plans rose by 1.1 percent of gross domestic product, but personal savings as a percentage of G.D.P. fell.
Without the incentives, personal savings might have fallen even more. But it does seem likely that a chunk of the new retirement money was funneled from ordinary savings. "When you can save the easy way by shifting it, or the hard way by cutting consumption," Mr. Gale said, "most people take the easy way."
Few tax experts seem to object to the elimination of the tax on "excess" withdrawals from very large pension nest eggs. There is also a case to be made for allowing pre-retirement withdrawals for education and home buying. "You need to give 30-year-olds a more pressing reason to save than retirement 40 years later," Mr. Feldstein said.
But in light of the questions over the impact of I.R.A.'s in the past, there is serious doubt about the efficiency of liberalizing eligibility. "Higher-income folks have more discretion to switch savings," pointed out Joel Slemrod, an economist at the University of Michigan Business School.
And there is a lot of head-shaking about the economic logic of "backward looking" tax breaks, such as penalty-free withdrawals of money already in I.R.A,'s or preferences on capital gains earned long ago. After all, cutting the tax liability of investors smart or lucky enough to have purchased, say, General Electric stock in 1990 will not change current savings or investment incentives.
Not surprisingly, then, there is widespread skepticism about the overall impact of the tax bill on savings when the impact on the budget is taken into account. Congress is projecting a loss of $250 billion in tax revenue over the next decade. While it is also projecting a balanced budget in 2002, the revenue crunch will certainly make it harder to keep it in the black thereafter.
Besides, a nation trying to amass capital to keep the retiring baby boomers living in the style to which they have grown accustomed might want to do better than balance. "The surest way to raise savings," Mr. Slemrod noted, "is for the Government to run a surplus."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Microsoft to Join Apple In Surprise Partnership
Apple Computer is teaming up with Microsoft in a stunning alliance that could alter the map of the computer industry and help insure the survival of Apple.
Microsoft, whose operating system has long been the dominant alternative to Apple's Macintosh software, will invest $150 million in Apple, and the companies plan to cooperate on sales and technology issues. [Page A1.] 

Apple also plans to reunite with an old ally. It is expected to announce that it will return responsibilities for its American advertising to TBWA Chiat/Day, the successor to the agency that created the famous "1984" ad for Apple. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]
 
Columbia/HCA to Amend Policies
Columbia/HCA Healthcare plans to dramatically alter or abandon many of its controversial business practices in response to a wide-ranging criminal investigation. [A1.]
 
Cable Executive Quits Over Move
Amos B. Hostetter, one of the cable industry's most respected executives, resigned after U S West said it would move the headquarters of his company, Continental Cablevision, to Denver from Boston. U S West acquired Mr. Hostetter's company for $10.9 billion in 1996, a deal in which he personally earned $1.2 billion. [D6.]
 
Economic Pattern Continues
The economy is continuing to expand moderately with subdued wage pressures and stable prices, the Federal Reserve said in its latest regional economic survey. [D4.]
 
New Chief at Cabletron
Robert Levine, the chief executive of Cabletron Systems, a computer networking company, will resign, to be replaced with a top Nynex executive, Donald B. Reed. [D2.]
 
Trading Halted in Reinsurer
Equisure, a reinsurance company whose shares have surged on the American Stock Exchange, has had trading halted amid an investigation by the exchange into both its accounting and the trading in its stock. [D4.]
 
Stocks Again Set Records
Stocks rose strongly, sending the major indexes to records. The Nasdaq, helped by Apple, which soared on word of its alliance with Microsoft, gained 8.91 points, to 1,630.44. The Dow industrials were up 71.77, to 8,259.31. [D8.]
 
Drug Is Found to Aid Angioplasty
A medicine abandoned two years ago by its maker, Hoechst Marion Roussel, appears to be the first drug to reduce substantially the high failure rate of angioplasty. [A19.]
 
Teamsters and U.P.S. to Talk
The teamsters' union and the United Parcel Service have agreed to resume talks in an effort to end a three-day-old strike. [B8.]
 
Tobacco Documents Released
A judge released secret tobacco industry documents that reflect discussions among cigarette company lawyers to suppress scientific research, potentially destroy documents and mislead the public. [A18.]
 
Gannett to Buy New Jersey Papers
Gannett, the nation's largest newspaper company, agreed to buy two New Jersey papers, The Asbury Park Press and The Home News & Tribune of East Brunswick. [B1.]
 
Good for Investors, but . . .
Though investors have been seen as big winners under the new tax law, there are provisions that could hurt some of them, including pension funds that invest in foreign companies, some short-sellers and companies that invest in the stocks of other companies. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8.]

INTERNATIONAL A3-15
 
Albright Sketches Policy For the Middle East
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright outlined a shift in the Clinton Administration's strategy toward the Middle East, hoping to focus Israelis and Palestinians on the goal of peace rather than their myriad grievances. The change reflected Washington's acceptance Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's desire to reach an overall accord directly. A1 

Crown Prince Hassan of Jordan went to Jerusalem but was unable to soften the position taken toward the Palestinian Authority by Mr. Netanyahu after the suicide bombing last week. Mr. Netanyahu said Israel would ease its blockade of the West Bank and Gaza only if Yasir Arafat took action against Islamic militants. Mr. Arafat, for his part, urged his followers to stand firm, reportedly telling them, "the future will be worse than the past." A14
 
Holbrooke Returns to Bosnia
Richard Holbrooke, the American envoy who orchestrated the 1995 Dayton peace accord that brought peace to the Balkans, returned to Bosnia to try to break stalemates in the pact's implementation. One of Mr. Holbrooke's urgent challenges is patching up relations between Bosnian Croats and Muslims, who are joined in a federation that controls 51 percent of Bosnia. He met with the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, and the Bosnian Muslim leader, Alija Izetbegovic. The two men "reaffirmed the right of all refugees to return to their homes," a vital part of the peace accord. A3
 
29 Survivors at Guam
Rescuers managed to pull 32 of 254 passengers alive from the wreckage of Korean Air Flight 801, but three have died. The jet's flight data recorder and cockpit voice recorder arrived in Washington for analysis. A8
 
In Seoul, Korean Air officials struggled to cope with frustrated and angry relatives of the passengers on Flight 801. A9
 
Cambodia Adds Prime Minister
An obedient Parliament ignored a series of constitutional and procedural roadblocks and elected a new Co-Prime Minister, giving Cambodia, by various counts, either one, two or three Prime Ministers. Last month, one of the country's Co-Prime Ministers, Hun Sen, ousted the other one, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, in two days of street fighting that took scores of lives. The legislature elected Foreign Minister Ung Huot to replace Prince Ranariddh, but did not remove Prince Ranariddh from his post. A11
 
Australia Mortified by Report
A confidential Australian report containing blunt and unflattering assessments of regional leaders has caused new strains in Australia's already difficult relations with its Pacific neighbors and has embarrassed the Government. A reporter found the report in a hotel lobby in Cairns while covering a meeting of the South Pacific Forum. A6
 
NATIONAL A18-29, B8
 
Clinton Says U.S. Deficit Will Fall to a 23-Year Low
President Clinton announced that the Federal deficit is expected to drop to $37 billion this year, its lowest level in 23 years. Mr. Clinton, holding a news conference at the White House, used the new deficit projections from the Office of Management and Budget to rebut critics who had questioned whether the robust economy itself would balance the budget without the five-year plan that Mr. Clinton and the Congress put in place. A1
 
Tobacco Documents Opened
A state judge in Florida released decades of secret tobacco industry documents that reflect discussions among cigarette company lawyers to suppress scientific research, potentially destroy documents and mislead the public about the health effects of smoking. A18
 
Decoding a Bacterium
Scientists, in a tour de force of computer-aided biology, have decoded the full genetic instructions of the bacterium that causes ulcers and other stomach diseases and have figured out many of its cunning strategies. The advance is likely to lend new impetus to research on the bacterium, Helicobacter pylori. B8
 
Drug Aids Heart Procedure
A medicine abandoned by its maker two years ago appears to be the first drug to reduce substantially the high failure rate of angioplasty, one of the most expensive and vexing problems in heart care. A19
 
U.P.S. and Union Resume Talks
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the United Parcel Service have agreed to resume talks today in an effort to end the three-day-old walkout by 185,000 drivers, loaders and sorters, Federal mediators announced. B8
 
Study Challenges 'Issue' Ads
Labor unions overestimated the effect of millions of dollars of "issue advocacy" advertisements in last year's elections, according to a study by a business lobbying group. A24
 
Drug Use Shows No Change
Marijuana use by younger teen-agers declined slightly last year for the first time in five years, but the overall use of illegal drugs showed no change, according to an annual Government survey. A18
 
Chief Appointed in L.A.
Mayor Richard J. Riordan selected Deputy Chief Bernard C. Parks from a group of three finalists to lead the Los Angeles Police Department, the second-largest city force in the nation. The City Council is expected to confirm the appointment in the coming weeks. A26
 
Automatic Highway Gets Test
The National Automated Highway Consortium gave its biggest public test of vehicles that -- using radar, a video camera and sensors in the road -- were able to proceed in the controlled-access carpool lanes of a 7.6-mile stretch of highway in San Diego without the human "driver" touching the steering wheel or floor pedals. A18

Judge Rejects Plea Bargain Under Death-Penalty Law
The defendant in what would have been New York City's first trial under the state's new death-penalty law has agreed to plead guilty to murder and serve at least 50 years in prison. But the judge has rejected the deal because he has found the law's plea provisions to be unconstitutional, and the prosecution has rejected his suggestion for getting around the problem he found. A1
 
Brooklyn Building Collapses
The corner of a five-story apartment building in Brooklyn collapsed, raining tons of debris into the street and sending firefighters and police officers racing through the halls to warn sleeping residents to get out. B3
 
Radio listeners who woke up to a news report about Mayor Giuliani at the early-morning building collapse heard something extraordinary a few seconds later: a political advertisement by the Mayor's campaign boasting that he is always there at a building collapse. "It's eerie," Mr. Giuliani said. "Of course, we didn't have the slightest knowledge when we prepared the ad that this would happen." B3
 
Threat to Governors Island
The fate of Governors Island has become more unsettled because of little-known provisions, which are part of the Federal budget, that eliminate funds to maintain the island. The provisions, quietly inserted into separate appropriation bills by the Senate and the House of Representatives, cut $8.3 million that had previously been committed to the United States Coast Guard to care for historic buildings. SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1185 words

HEADLINE: For the Teamsters' Leader, U.P.S. Is an Ancient Enemy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
In many ways, the strike against the United Parcel Service is the fight that Ronald Carey, the teamsters' president who began as a U.P.S. deliveryman in Queens, has been preparing for in his three decades as a union leader.
A quarter-century ago, when he headed a New York teamsters local representing thousands of U.P.S. workers, Mr. Carey served as the field marshal in several successful strikes to win a better pension and to limit the use of part-time workers. 
 Today, he is using the expertise and experience gleaned from those battles to fight again, although this time on a much bigger playing field. Back then, the strikes disrupted deliveries in just five boroughs; the walkout that began on Monday has halted deliveries in all 50 states and involves more workers than any other strike in the 1990's.
But the current walkout comes at an awkward time for Mr. Carey because it trains a spotlight on him when Federal prosecutors have charged some of his campaign aides with illegally diverting union funds to his re-election war chest.
Mr. Carey's aides acknowledge that he and the entire 1.4-million-member union have planned for this showdown ever since he was elected president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in 1991. Not only are U.P.S. workers Mr. Carey's base and his most loyal supporters, but he also knows this particular adversary better than any other. And he has long been concerned about the overarching issue in the strike: the company's growing use of part-time workers.
"This is an issue that has been troubling me since 1968, when I was first elected president of a local," Mr. Carey said in a telephone interview last night. "I think this is a really important issue that the country has to do something about."
Tony Magrene, who worked as a U.P.S. driver and shop steward with Mr. Carey in the 1960's, recalled in an interview that Mr. Carey, as president of teamsters' Local 804, led it through a painful 14-week strike in 1974 over part-time workers.
"Ron Carey would not keep people recklessly on the street," Mr. Magrene said. "He knows it's the last card you play. He knows that strikes are very hard."
Mr. Magrene said Mr. Carey had worked feverishly to help strikers make ends meet in the 1974 walkout. In that strike, Mr. Carey pressured U.P.S. not to reduce the number of full-time sorters and replace them with part-time workers.
Mr. Carey insists that he ordered the strike and risked disrupting the nation's economy for the noblest of reasons: to help 185,000 unionized U.P.S. workers, especially the more than 100,000 part-timers, whose starting pay is $8 to $9 an hour. He contends that sorters and loaders earning $200 a week for 20 hours' work cannot support their families.
"It's unfortunate the company has failed to recognize the needs of our members, the needs for the future: good, decent jobs," Mr. Carey said. "Half a job is not enough."
But Mr. Carey's many detractors inside and outside the union suggest that his motives are less than pure. They say that Mr. Carey, who was elected to the presidency on a platform of cleaning up what was the nation's most corrupt union, is desperate to distract attention from the fund-raising scandal.
Prosecutors have charged a Carey campaign fund-raiser with managing a scheme in which the union awarded a contract to a telemarketing firm that then funneled tens of thousands of dollars to the campaign. His aides say he knew nothing about such contributions.
These detractors also suggest that Mr. Carey has orchestrated the strike as a convenient way to rally members of his highly fractured union behind him.
The man he narrowly defeated in the union election last December, James P. Hoffa, son of the former teamsters' leader, has asked the Federal election overseer to order a new election because of the charges of financial improprieties. And some detractors say Mr. Carey asserted that having the national spotlight trained on him this week would make it harder for the overseer to overturn the election, especially if he emerges victorious from the strike.
"His position in the union was weak, and that partly motivated his decision to go on strike," said Leo Troy, a professor of labor relations at Rutgers University.
U.P.S. officials have also questioned Mr. Carey's motives, suggesting that he is trying to divert attention from internal union problems.
"He is highly irresponsible," Gina Ellrich, a U.P.S. spokeswoman, said of the 61-year-old union leader. "There is more to this strike than the welfare of U.P.S. people because we made a superb offer which Ron Carey has refused. We think it's inappropriate to speculate to what else is motivating Ron Carey to lead this strike, but obviously there are a number of other issues he's facing."
Mr. Carey said his detractors were wrong to suggest that he could lead 185,000 workers into a strike like lambs, just to take people's minds off a union campaign scandal.
"That's all bull being spun out by the company and by my opponents," Mr. Carey said. He added that he did not want a strike but that the company had forced him into it by making a patently unacceptable offer.
Gregory Tarpinian, president of the Labor Research Association, said, "I don't think anybody who calls a strike like this is driven by ulterior political motives."
Mr. Tarpinian said that since the rank and file had high expectations in the U.P.S. dispute, Mr. Carey would be badly weakened if he accepted the company's latest offer, which calls for a 1.5 percent yearly raise for full-time workers and no raise in the part-timers' starting wage, unchanged since 1982.
He said another proposal that Mr. Carey could not swallow was the company's intent to pull out of the teamsters' multiemployer pension plans, a move that could anger hundreds of thousands of teamsters who belong to the plans but work for other employers.
"He needs a win here," Mr. Tarpinian said. "He needs a win because part-timers at U.P.S. need something. This is Carey's political base, and there are internal problems in the union, so he has to show that he's in charge, that he can deliver."
Mr. Carey was propelled to the union's presidency on the strength of his reputation as a reformer and as a leader beyond reproach. Entering this strike, however, both perceptions were under fire.
In his first five years as the teamsters' president, he won rave reviews for cleaning up the union. He sold off the union's two jets, ended the free lunches at headquarters and stopped holding union conferences in Hawaii. He placed more than 70 of the teamsters' 651 locals into trusteeship, dismissing suspect leaders.
Although Hoffa supporters have rallied behind Mr. Carey in the strike, some still criticize him for negotiating an agreement with long-haul trucking companies that allowed the companies to ship more goods by rail.
But a successful end to the strike would muffle many critics. "If he comes out getting a good contract and playing his cards right, he will come out strong," said Michael Belzer, a professor of labor relations at Cornell University.

HEADLINE: CLINTON ON THE ISSUES: THE OVERVIEW;
Deficit to Drop To $37 Billion, President Says

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
A day after signing laws to balance the Federal budget and cut taxes, President Clinton announced today that the Federal deficit was expected to drop to $37 billion this year, its lowest level in 23 years.
Mr. Clinton used the new deficit projection from the Office of Management and Budget, which was $30 billion lower than projections made in May, to rebut critics who had questioned whether the robust economy alone would balance the budget without the five-year plan that Mr. Clinton and the Congress put in place. 
 "Without the bipartisan balanced budget we just passed, our budget officials estimate the deficit would rise next year to $50 to $100 billion, and stay at that level for years to come," he said. "With our bipartisan balanced-budget plan, we now expect it not only to reach balance by 2002, but to have a surplus in excess of $20 billion." [Excerpts, page A28.]
In a nearly hourlong news conference, the President ranged across many domestic and foreign policy issues, urging a fair hearing for former Gov. William F. Weld, his nominee as ambassador to Mexico, and saying he did not want a debate over whether to apologize for slavery to dominate his yearlong initiative on race.
The President also said that he expected to use his newly acquired line-item-veto power to strike out either a narrowly focused tax break or a spending measure from the budget and tax laws.
And in one striking moment, Mr. Clinton went on the offensive to justify his continued fund-raising for his party. Reminded that he continued to raise for Democrats the kind of unregulated, soft-money donations that he has said should be banned, he cut off the questioner and said, "I certainly do, and I'm proud of it.
"We live in a competitive world," he added. "The Republicans raise more money, raise more big money, and raise more money from noncitizens than the Democrats do. But we have to raise enough to be competitive."
But Mr. Clinton also said that he would give "strong support" to legislation to overhaul the system and to ban soft money, changes that sponsors hope to bring up for a vote in the Senate this fall. "It is very important that every American know where every single elected Federal official in Washington stands on this issue," he said.
Asked if he would push for two fund-raisers with past ties to him -- John Huang and Yah Lin Trie -- to cooperate with the Senate committee investigating campaign finance practices, Mr. Clinton repeated a general appeal for everyone to cooperate with the committee. He said the State Department had worked with the committee to track witnesses overseas.
"So I don't know what else we can do on that," he said. Mr. Trie is in China, and Mr. Huang has refused to testify without at least partial immunity from prosecution.
Fresh from signing the balanced-budget legislation that ended years of partisan combat in Washington, Mr. Clinton was alternately high-spirited, joking and combative.
He used the news conference to highlight his economic policies and set out a future agenda. His call to action included winning Congressional backing for new authority to negotiate trade agreements, for changing the Social Security and Medicare systems to prepare for the retirement of the baby-boom generation and for an overhaul of campaign finance laws.
"All these challenges will require bipartisan cooperation," he said. "Many of them will require difficult decisions. But this balanced budget and the prosperity we are now enjoying gives us a rare opportunity to take these steps for the long-term well-being of our country."
When Mr. Clinton took office in 1993, he faced a deficit that had reached a high of $290 billion. By last year, it had dropped to $107 billion. And today Mr. Clinton announced that because of the thriving economy, the deficit was now projected to be smaller than had been expected, down to $37 billion by the time the fiscal year ends Sept. 30.
The new deficit projection by the Office of Management and Budget would be the lowest Federal deficit since 1974, when the Government's shortfall was $6.1 billion.
Mr. Clinton attributed the declining deficits to his economic policies since 1993, when he succeeded in getting a Democratic Congress to pass a deficit-reduction package that included a tax increase mostly on the wealthy. Today he described 1993 as the year "we abandoned supply-side, trickle-down economics." He praised the most recent balanced-budget deal for finishing that work by leading to an expected surplus in 2002.
Pressed on whether a balanced budget would have been reached sooner if $95 billion in tax cuts had not been included in the budget plan, Mr. Clinton skirted the question and defended the tax reduction package as a "good and balanced one" that was a "small fraction of the size" of the Reagan tax cut of 1981, which he said added to the growing deficit.
On the line-item veto, Mr. Clinton said his aides were examining a list of narrowly focused tax breaks and spending items in the balanced-budget laws to see if any were "sufficiently objectionable" to prompt his veto. "I'm assuming that there will be something in there that was not agreed to by all of us in the budget agreement, that seems to me to be a good candidate for it," he said.
Mr. Clinton was asked what he would do to win confirmation for Mr. Weld as ambassador to Mexico, despite opposition from Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. Mr. Clinton at first joked, "I thought maybe I'd go down to Mexico and jump off those cliffs at Acapulco."
But quickly becoming serious, he defended Mr. Weld against criticism by Mr. Helms, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, that he was not tough enough on drugs. "At least the man ought to get a hearing," he said, "and ought to get his day in court, if you will, his day before the committee."
On complaints that a new Federal aid package for the District of Columbia shifted power away from the elected Mayor and City Council to a financial control board, Mr. Clinton said that the power shift was required by the Republican Congress as a "condition of getting financial relief" for the strapped city.
When Mr. Clinton was asked his position on a Federal apology for slavery, he said that he had referred the question to an advisory group he has set up to examine questions of race relations. "What I hope will happen," he said, "is that the issue will not dominate all the other things that need to be discussed about the past, the present and the future."

SECTION: Section C; Page 27; Column 1; Weekend Desk

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
The Bauhaus: Utopian Ideas and Constant Uproar

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:

BAUHAUS
Crucible of Modernism
By Elaine S. Hochman
Illustrated. 371 pages. Fromm International. $29.95.
 Elaine S. Hochman's great theme is the fragility of the liberal imagination. In two fine books, Ms. Hochman has examined this subject through the lens of modern German architecture. Her "Architects of Fortune," published in 1989, cast a glaring light on Ludwig Mies van der Rohe's attempts to cut deals with the culture czars of the Third Reich. In her new book, "Bauhaus: Crucible of Modernism," Ms. Hochman chronicles the fluctuating political fortunes of the century's most influential art school.
Founded in 1919 by the architect Walter Gropius, the Bauhaus was originally based in Weimar, and later in Dessau. The school operated for only 14 years, its life span corresponding precisely to that of the Weimar Republic. Like the theater of Brecht or the drawings of George Grosz, the Bauhaus came to stand for the Weimar period's heady creative ferment. 
 Bauhaus roll call! Count off now! Paul Klee! Lyonel Feininger! Oskar Schlemmer! Wassily Kandinsky! Ludwig Mies van der Rohe! Marcel Breuer! Theo van Doesburg! Josef Albers! Laszlo Moholy-Nagy! These are just a few of the eminent artists who taught, not always happily or for long, at the school.
Painters like Kandinsky and Klee were second-rate citizens here. Though the school's predecessor institution, the Weimar Art Academy, was known for training in the fine arts, under Gropius the school shifted its focus to architecture, the applied arts, and crafts. In the workshops and studios of Gropius, Mies, Breuer, Mart Stam and Marianne Brandt, the school developed the refined, machine-age esthetic with which it became synonymous.
Ms. Hochman is not primarily concerned, however, with the art the Bauhaus produced. Rather, she focuses on the political turbulence unleashed by Gropius's utopian ideas. Her emphasis is apt. Unlike the International Style derived from its formative ideas, the Bauhaus was committed as firmly to social as to esthetic reform. Or, more accurately, Gropius regarded the two as indivisible. He had other things on his mind than well-designed chairs and teapots, handsome as many of those objects turned out to be. His goal was to transform modern life.
Gropius's contemporaries were no more comfortable with the idea of political art than many Americans are today. A popular "come to the cabaret" myth holds that Weimar Germany was a golden age of creative freedom that ended only when the Nazis stormed into power. The truth is that the era's artistic flowering took place amid opposition that makes our culture wars look like the Pepsi Challenge.
Based on the precedent of the British Arts and Crafts movement, the Bauhaus promoted itself as a model vehicle for educational reform. To us, this objective may seem unexceptionably benign. In Weimar Germany, it was a red flag, literally. Educational reform was as recognizably a part of the Marxist objective as economic redistribution.
So, too, the school's machine esthetic was unmistakably a symbolic expression of solidarity with industrial workers. The very notion of transforming an academy of fine arts into a crafts school was an act of social leveling. It was recognized and resented as such.
Ms. Hochman gives a precise account of Gropius's reforms and of the inevitable outrage they provoked. The Bauhaus was a state school, dependent on Government funds and subject to official review. The school also needed the good will of the trade associations that presided over the professional fields that Bauhaus students were being trained, at least in theory, to enter. Clashes with these authorities were unavoidable and frequent.
Ms. Hochman's account is factual, not essayistic. She is better than Joseph McCarthy at pinning down the exact number of Bauhaus students who belonged to the school's Communist cell (15, about 10 percent of the student body); she examined the banners they designed for street demonstrations, and records Gropius's ambivalent feelings toward their political activities. She documents the efforts of Government officials to intervene in the school's policies and describes the intricate ruses Gropius devised to forestall and placate them.
She also details the constant uproars within the school itself. Kandinsky and other artists opposed Gropius's plans to market the products of the school's workshops. Students and faculty members fought over the profits from these sales. Campaigns were waged against designers like van Doesburg, who preferred abstraction to technology. Student newsletters ridiculed Gropius's denials that he was creating a Bauhaus style.
It's chilling, of course, to follow this account of idealistic artists, knowing the fate that awaits them: in April 1933, three months after Hitler became Chancellor, the Gestapo moved in and shut the school down.
What is the legacy of the Bauhaus today? Ms. Hochman's only major stumble occurs at the end of the book, when she tries to answer this question. Somewhat lamely, she praises Richard Meier and Frank Gehry for "continuing to refine, re-examine and reinterpret the modernism the Bauhaus came to exemplify." It's disappointing, after reading a book that goes so far toward liberating the Bauhaus from formalist preoccupations, to find its author limiting the school's contribution to matters of form.
If Gropius left one enduring idea, it is that artists should not distance themselves from their times. They should leap into the fray and see what good they can accomplish there. Instead of keeping a safe distance from the smelly swamp of worldly values, they should dive right in and stir things up.
This ideal is more pervasive now than it was when the modern movement was in bloom. To paraphrase Gropius, modern Apollos want to make it in the marketplace; an artist's integrity stands to be strengthened, not compromised, by reckoning with the social reality. This belief may be every bit as utopian as the socialist dream of remaking the world through art. And why not?

HEADLINE: With Hong Kong, China Doesn't Need W.T.O.

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The Clinton Administration wisely insists on viable commercial terms for China's entry to the World Trade Organization, not the political convenience occasioned by the visit of President Jiang Zemin to Washington in October (front page, Aug. 4). But an Aug. 5 editorial overlooks one important aspect. 
 While China indeed "already reaps, without making concessions, the benefit of 'most-favored-nation' status in the United States and most other countries," Beijing has another way now to reap those low-tariff benefits that would be granted under the organization -- through Hong Kong.
Since its reversion to China last month, Hong Kong has retained its seat in the organization. Because exports from Hong Kong receive low-tariff treatment under the W.T.O., and trade between the mainland and Hong Kong is now internal trade, China can direct its exports through Hong Kong to the world.
China has not made up its mind to accept the trade organization's terms, because the entry can have a potential impact on its state-owned enterprises, which still employ the majority of workers.
However, once it gains admission, Beijing will get permanent most-favored-nation status, making United States Congressional debate over China's trade status obsolete. Since Chinese membership is not forthcoming, the trade organization should de-link Taiwan's application from China's and proceed on Taiwan's.
 
VINCENT WEI-CHENG WANG
Richmond, Aug. 5, 1997
 
The writer is an assistant professor of political science, U. of Richmond.

HEADLINE: Shylock on Wall Street

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Even Nature Can Be Turned Into a Security" (Business Day, Aug. 6) describes catastrophe bonds as a new instrument dreamed up by Wall Street. However, as all Shakespeare scholars know, catastrophe bonds, known then as contracts of bottomry, were the standard method of insuring ships from Roman times through the Middle Ages. 
 Shipowners usually borrowed to finance a voyage, and if the ship went down, the loan was forgiven. This contract fell out of use when the Roman Catholic Church ruled that the high rates of interest amounted to usury. When Shylock says "I'll have my bond," he of course means his catastrophe bond.
 
THOMAS RUSSELL
Santa Clara, Calif., Aug. 6, 1997

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Pound Drops as Central Bank Acts and Takes Dollar With It

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The British pound tumbled yesterday after the Bank of England signaled that British interest rates had risen enough for now, and the dollar fell in sympathy against most leading currencies.
The pound fell to a 10-month low against the dollar and a one-month low against the German mark while the dollar posted its first loss against the mark after surging to a string of eight-year highs. 
 The British central bank raised its official interest rate to 7 percent from 6.75 percent, its fourth consecutive monthly increase, but released a statement saying it had no immediate plans for future rate rises, prompting heavy selling of pounds, traders said.
Higher interest rates tend to raise the value of a currency by increasing the price of assets denominated in that currency.
"When they raised interest rates in the morning, they said basically this was the last one, and that was the reason sterling went down," said Hans Boman, chief spot currency dealer at Swedbank in New York.
The Bank of England also said that the sharp rally in the pound, which before the selloff had risen 16 percent against the German mark so far in 1997, was pressuring British businesses by making their goods more expensive in global markets.
The pound touched an intraday low at $1.5780, its weakest since October, before settling in New York trading at $1.5893, down from $1.6021 late Wednesday.
The pound's broad decline indirectly helped other currencies strengthen against the dollar. The dollar slipped to 1.8683 marks in New York from 1.8815 marks.
Traders said the pound's decline also gave investors a chance to book profits from the dollar's sharp rally.
"We saw sterling lead the way up for the dollar for a long time and now that sterling is coming back down, that undermined the dollar against the mark and yen a bit," said Earl Johnson, foreign exchange economist at Bank of Montreal in Chicago.
Against the Japanese yen, the dollar fell in part on expectations that a report today will show Japan's current account surplus -- the broadest measure of trade -- widened sharply in June. The dollar settled at 118.45 yen, down from 118.68 yen on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Buenos Aires Journal;
A Saint Besieged: Heaven Knows, Many Need Help

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Unable to feed his family after losing his job as a welder last year, Roberto Fuentes went to church on Wednesday afternoon to petition St. Cayetano, the patron saint of bread and work.
But Mr. Fuentes had to wait in line, a rather long line stretching 15 city blocks, as Argentines flocked to pay homage to St. Cayetano, a priest who used his family fortune to help the poor of Naples and who died on Aug. 7, 1547. 
 After waiting 18 hours through a freezing winter night, Mr. Fuentes, 32, burst into tears and walked on his knees when he entered St. Cayetano Sanctuary on the outskirts of Buenos Aires.
"As it was in your day, St. Cayetano, the Government ignores those in need," Mr. Fuentes said, kneeling before a statue of the saint. "We are hungry, we are cold, we are suffering. All we have is you, Saint."
It was a scene repeated over and over again today as more than a million people passed through the church -- a record turnout, according to police estimates.
On seeing the small statue of St. Cayetano, which cradles a baby Jesus in its arms, many people gasped, crossed themselves or prayed loudly as they held rosaries. Some kissed or placed their hands on the glass encasing the statue. An elderly woman fainted at the foot of the statue but was revived by Red Cross workers, who said she had forgotten to eat during the nine hours she waited.
Church officials said the vast pilgrimage was an extraordinary outpouring of faith and proof that Roman Catholicism was still relevant in Argentina despite the recent growth of Protestantism and sects.
But critics of President Carlos Saul Menem's Government said the large turnout reflected just how desperate Argentines have become after years of record unemployment and declining salaries in a country that was accustomed to lifelong employment.
The jobless rate has more than doubled since Mr. Menem came to power in 1989, making it the top issue for midterm congressional elections in October. Mr. Menem's policies have brought stability to an economy once plagued by runaway inflation, but his reforms, including opening markets to imports and selling state-owned businesses, have put millions out of work.
While the latest unemployment figures, for the first three months of the year, declined to 16.1 percent compared with 17.3 percent for last year, tens of thousands of Argentines are continuing to block roads and stage demonstrations up and down the country to protest the Government's economic program. By contrast, the unemployment rate in the United States is 5 percent, a 25-year low.
"Putting an end to Menemism is the only way we can move forward," said Carlos Santillanhe, widely known as Mad Dog, the head of the Government workers' union. "Menem has brought Argentina only more hunger, more unemployment and more desperation."
Mr. Menem has dismissed the protests as "subversion." He maintains that the country's robust economic growth combined with new laws to reduce the cost of labor will create more jobs. "They can stage a thousand marches but nothing will change," he has frequently said in response to protests.
Church officials said the Government's inflexibility perhaps explained why the number of Argentines who came to honor St. Cayetano was so large this year.
"Argentines are an intelligent people and they know where to go when they need help, especially material things," said the Rev. Fernando Maletti, who oversees St. Cayetano Sanctuary. "They know when it's appropriate to block roads, or to knock on the door of a Government agency, or to go to church and ask God or the saints for what they need."
But the Rev. Guillermo Marco, a member of the media commission for the Roman Catholic Church of Buenos Aires, said that while the lines to see St. Cayetano get longer when unemployment is higher, the anniversary of the saint's death 450 years ago today should not only be used as a barometer of joblessness.
Indeed, many people stood in line for hours today to thank the saint for jobs and blessings that they received years ago. To express their gratitude, many brought canned goods, used clothing and medicines to be given to the poor. At the end of the day, church officials said they had received more than 110,000 pounds of food.
But of all those who came to worship, no one seemed to match the devotion of Noris de Navalla, who camped out in front of the church for two months just to be the first person in line when the doors opened at midnight.
"For 16 years, I've always been the first one in line," Mrs. de Navalla, 64, said, as she warmed her hands over a small burner in her tent.
Leonor Castillo, 62, who shivered under heavy blankets in a tent next to Mrs. de Navalla, whom she has known for 16 years, disagreed. "In reality, this year I arrived first, but I don't want to have problems with my neighbors, so I left the space to her."

GRAPHIC: Photo: An estimated million-plus Argentines flocked to the church of St. Cayetano, the patron saint of bread and work, in Buenos Aires on his anniversary. High unemployment may have been a factor in the record turnout. (Horacio Paone for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Venezuela and Trinidad Square Off Over Oil Treasure

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad and Tobago, Aug. 7

 BODY:
A long-simmering boundary dispute over the petroleum-rich straits and gulf that separate Trinidad and Venezuela is flaring up again, with American oil companies caught squarely in the middle.
For decades, each country has accused fishermen from the other of illegally entering its waters, but generally tolerated such abuses because its own vessels were doing the same. But with both countries eager to expand their reserves and exports of oil and gas, they have been taking a much harder line since a fishing agreement expired two years ago. 
 Altercations in the Gulf of Paria have become more and more common, with Venezuelan patrol boats routinely running off or even boarding Trinidadian oil rigs and fishing vessels. At the gulf's narrowest point, at its northern end, the distance between the countries is only seven miles.
American oil companies like Amoco, Texaco, Enron and Conoco have large investments in both countries, and some have been doing exploratory drilling in or near the disputed area.
"You've got Americans on both sides," a diplomat here said. "Everyone who is here has interests over there too."
The United States imports more oil from Venezuela, which President Clinton is scheduled to visit this fall, than from any other country -- 1.65 million barrels a day. But American companies also have a large stake in five big petrochemical plants here, including a $1 billion liquid natural gas project that will send much of its production to the Northeast United States when completed in 1999.
Oil and its derivatives are the backbone of Trinidad's economy, accounting for a third of Government revenues and just under half of all exports. But proven reserves total less than 12 more years of production, and this Caribbean island country of 1.25 million people has been looking to expand its own production and to encourage its much larger neighbor to send some oil and gas to be refined here.
In mid-April, Venezuela said that a joint venture between Trinidad's state oil company and Texaco was conducting illegal exploratory drilling in its waters and sent troops on an armed vessel to board a drilling platform and a tugboat. The company had a Trinidadian license to operate in the gulf area, where Trinidad gets one-fourth of its daily production of 130,000 barrels of crude oil, but Venezuela said the drilling was in its territory.
Trinidad's Foreign Minister, Ralph Maraj, then warned that the situation was "heading into very deep waters." To avoid further problems, he said, "we should allow a third country to look at it to insure that things do not get out of hand."
The incident followed several instances in which Venezuelan vessels fired at, arrested, jailed or fined Trinidadian fishing boats and captains for what it said were violations of the maritime boundary between the two nations established by a treaty in 1990. After a Trinidadian fisherman was shot in one such confrontation, there were calls in the local press for the Government to take a stronger stance against Venezuela.
In an interview here, Prime Minister Basdeo Panday said he believes "the whole thing has been really blown out of proportion," and sounded a conciliatory tone. "I believe the matter can be solved by mutual agreement, peacefully, by diplomatic means."
"There is no way we can have tense relations between our countries," added Mr. Panday, who has twice traveled to Venezuela to meet with President Rafael Caldera in recent months. "Both countries have to cooperate and work together, and I am sure that can happen, this hiccup notwithstanding."
"We were hoping to cooperate with the Venezuelans in the exploration of Venezuelan oil resources and gas," Mr. Panday said. He attributed the dispute to the fact that "the systems both countries have of determining locations might be different," which leads to doubt "where the incidents are actually taking place." He said that "a technological solution" could be reached if the countries agreed to "a common method of calculating where things are."
Two months after being summoned home for "consultations," Venezuela's Ambassador to Trinidad, Efrain Silva Mendez, returned here on Aug. 1 and met with Mr. Maraj this week. But he has declined all requests for interviews. The Venezuelan Foreign Ministry, though, has repeatedly warned in statements that its authorities "will continue to fulfill their constitutional duties pursuing the preservation of the integrity and sovereignty" of their territorial waters.
The United States and other countries that have interests in the region say they fear the dispute is distracting Trinidadian and Venezuelan coastal forces, to the advantage of drug traffickers. The Orinoco River delta, just south of Trinidad, has become an increasingly important route for drugs from Colombia, with an estimated 24 tons of cocaine having moved through last year on its way to Europe and the United States.
"If this doesn't get resolved, the only assets they do get are going to be devoted to defending national sovereignty and the fishermen," a diplomat said, referring to planes and ships the United States has recently supplied to Trinidad. "We would all love to see them cooperating and jointly patrolling the waters."

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall From Records, With Dow Retreating 71.31

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks retreated from records yesterday, hurt by a slump in the Treasury market.
The Dow Jones industrial average, in a topsy-turvy session, fell 71.31 points, to 8,188.00. The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 9.13 points, to 951.19, and the Nasdaq composite index declined 6.26 points, to 1,624.18, ending seven consecutive sessions of gains. All began the day at record levels. 
 Stocks tumbled in the afternoon as bond prices fell. While the yield on the new 30-year Treasury bond, which was auctioned yesterday, fell to 6.44 percent from 6.47 percent, the yield on the old 30-year bond rose to 6.52 percent.
Higher rates raise the cost of borrowing for consumers and companies, slowing the economy. Higher rates can also undermine bank profits, and shares of the nation's biggest banks fell. Citicorp declined 3 3/8, to 136 1/2; the BankAmerica Corporation lost 2 1/4, to 70 1/2, and the Chase Manhattan Corporation fell 2 7/8, to 109.
Falling interest rates and rising profits have been the bedrock of the bull market. The Dow industrials, including dividends, have almost tripled in the last five years.
Lately, though, some investors question whether these conditiions can continue. Joe Stocke, chief of equities at Meridian Investment Company of Valley Forge, Pa., with $2 billion under management, said concern had heightened since Labor Department figures on Friday showing robust job growth, touching off fears that inflation may accelerate and prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. "Investors are concerned the economy may be doing too well," he said. "After a number of years of expansion, salaries may be going up and it will get tougher to keep profit margins growing."
The Dow rose as much as 41 points yesterday before paring gains and falling. Traders said with few fresh economic statistics and many investors on vacation, the market lacked direction.
Apple Computer Inc. was the most active stock, rising 2 7/8, to 29 3/16, in trading of 33 million shares. On Wednesday, Apple's co-founder, Steven P. Jobs, announced a $150 million investment by the Microsoft Corporation and a shake-up of Apple's board. Apple is up about 47 percent in two days. Microsoft rose 1/2, to 143 15/16.
Fisher Scientific International fell 1 3/8, to 49 1/2, after an investor group led by Thomas H. Lee Companies. agreed to buy the company for $1.4 billion. Fisher shareholders will receive $51 a share, and will also get approximately 10.3 percent common stock ownership in the recapitalized company.
The Compaq Computer Corporation rose 3 1/2, to 62 1/8. The computer maker was raised to "recommended list" from "buy" by an analyst, Kevin A. McCarthy at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. Compaq's share price has doubled in 1997, and nearly tripled in the last 12 months.
Caterpillar Inc. rose 2 3/16, to 60 11/16, after a Merrill Lynch analyst, James McCann, raised his estimate on the company to "accumulate."
The National Semiconductor Corporation rose 1 13/16, to 34 3/4, after it was raised to "buy" from "outperform" by James Barlage, an analyst at Smith Barney. The 12-month price target is $40 a share.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Two Luxury Projects May Cast Shadows on the West Village

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
Plans for two luxury condominium buildings are reflecting the increased interest of developers in the western fringe of Greenwich Village, raising community concerns that an area known for its quaint brownstones, loft warehouses and river views will soon be crowded with high-rise buildings that could change the character of the neighborhood.
Developers said that the two projects would be the first condominiums to be built in the neighborhood in five years and that similar projects may be on the way. One of the condominium buildings, 15 stories at 296-298 West 10th Street, a half-block from the West Side Highway, will be completed by the end of the year. The 23-unit project is being built by Christopher Street Associates, using air rights from an adjacent building. 
 The other building, to start construction next month, is being planned by the Rockrose Development Corporation, a Manhattan company long active in the West Village, where it has developed more than 1,300 rental apartments. The company's new project at 99 Jane Street calls for 84 condominium units in an 11-story building.
Among the factors fueling interest in the neighborhood between Hudson Street and the Hudson River are the city's strong housing market, the shortage of building sites elsewhere in the neighborhood, the reconstruction of the West Side Highway and the building of the Hudson River Park from Battery Park City to 59th Street, brokers said.
Estimates from Community Board 2, which guides growth in the West Village, are that in addition to those projects there are about six others planned for the area west of Washington Street to West Street. They could produce a total of another 150 units, mostly condominiums and co-ops, said Arthur W. Strickler, the board's district manager.
But such projects raise concerns within the neighborhood that more development will also bring more tall buildings. The Greenwich Village Historic District does not extend west of Washington Street, to the area in which the recent activity is taking place, so that area lacks the barriers to development, like restrictions on height, that accompany historic-district designation.
To protect the neighborhood, the community board is stepping up its effort to create a Waterfront Historic District, said Ben Green, chairman of the community board.
The board would also like to restrict the use of air rights to put up other tall buildings, which "are damaging the very context and character of the area and the reason workers and residents are attracted to it," he said.
Officials of Christopher Street L.L.C. said they understood the neighborhood's concerns, but said their building needed to be more than 10 stories to be economically feasible.
"We want to blend with the community," said Frank A. Raccuglia Jr. of Christopher Street. "We didn't want to build a contemporary building, so we used a traditional finish of subtle red brick."
Rockrose and Christopher Street are betting that their projects will draw families who will want to live in an area with more of a sense of neighborhood than is offered by high-rise canyons elsewhere in the city.
Andrew S. Heiberger, president of Citi Habitats, a Manhattan brokerage, said the area's rental market is tight, with monthly rents typically $3,500 for a two-bedroom rental and $4,500 for a three-bedroom.
"As rents go up there is more of an incentive for renters to look for a sales option," Mr. Heiberger added.
Thomas Elghanayan, president of Rockrose, said his company had switched from a rental project, as originally planned, to condominiums, because "a lot of families are coming into the area and they are more interested in owning than renting."
The building will contain mostly three-bedroom apartments, though there will also be some with two, four and five bedrooms. The sizes and prices of the apartments have not been set, but Mr. Elghanayan said they will plenty of open space and high ceilings.
At Christopher Street's building, the apartments will have two bedrooms, two bedrooms plus a den or three bedrooms, with 950 to 1,550 square feet and ceiling heights of 8 to 10 feet. Some of the larger units will occupy full floors, and there will also be a three-story penthouse.
"There has been no new condominium construction in the area in the last five years and we feel the project will fill a niche in the area where there hasn't been enough emphasis on large apartments," Mr. Raccuglia said.
But making the $10 million project economically feasible required the use of air rights, said Steven Haskell of Christopher Street. That permitted the building, which under zoning would have been limited to 10 stories, to be five stories taller.
The added height will also provide the building with light and clear river views, which "will more than compensate for its proximity to the highway," added Robert G. Eychner, president of Eychner Associates, the project's sales agent. Most of the apartments will have balconies or terraces.
The price for the apartments, excluding the penthouse, is expected to range from $400 to $600 a square foot, which is on par for the area. Citi Habitats puts the average sales price at $450 a square foot for two-bedroom condominiums and $525 for those with three bedrooms.
For example, a 1,500-square-foot three-bedroom apartment on the 11th floor would cost $900,000. Monthly maintenance fees, including real estate taxes, are expected to be just under $1,000 to $1,400, Mr. Eychner said. Sales are expected to start within the next 45 days.

HEADLINE: Diplomat to Make Trip to Urge Reduction of U.S. Dues to U.N.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Bill Richardson, the United States representative at the United Nations, said today that he would make a round-the-world trip beginning on Monday to persuade key countries to support reduced American payments to the organization.
He will also promote a Clinton Administration proposal to make Japan, Germany and three third world nations permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, thereby increasing the number of permanent members from 5 to 10 and the overall membership in the Council from 15 to 20. Developing nations would compete for the three permanent third world seats. 
 The reduction of American payments to the United Nations, a Congressional prerequisite for releasing money to pay any of the more than $1 billion that Washington owes, is a contentious issue among diplomats here. A new payment scale, requiring action by the 185-member General Assembly, would mean that several other countries would have to pick up the shortfall and agree to higher assessments. China, which pays less than one percent of the budget, will be one of Mr. Richardson's candidates for higher assessments. Many nations believe that the Chinese economy has grown enough to make a higher payment reasonable.
The United States now pays 25 percent of the general organization's budget, a rate based on the country's share of the world economy. An agreement between Congress and the Clinton Administration calls for a reduction to 20 percent over three years.
Mr. Richardson told reporters today that his trip would focus primarily on Asia, with additional stops in Russia, Georgia, the Ukraine and France. In Asia, he plans to visit South Korea, Japan, China, Tajikistan, Kazakstan and Uzbekistan.
The visit to Central Asia is being made at the request of Vice President Gore, Mr. Richardson said. Diplomats here are speculating that Mr. Richardson, a former Democratic Congressman for New Mexico, may be positioning himself to become Mr. Gore's running mate in the next Presidential election.
"Vice President Gore requested that I journey to Central Asia to enhance our bilateral ties as well as demonstrate support for these nations," Mr. Richardson said, uncharacteristically reading from a prepared statement.
He said topics he would discuss with Central Asian leaders include regional trade and security, the environment and the continuing war in Afghanistan, where the United Nations is attempting to start talks between the Islamic Taliban movement, which controls most of the country, and the forces of the government it ousted, which are now pressing toward Kabul, the capital, from the north. Secretary General Kofi Annan is sending a new troubleshooter, Lakhdar Brahimi, a former foreign minister of Algeria, to the region this week to assess the situation.
Mr. Richardson said today that the compromise plan the Clinton Administration negotiated with Congress that would allow the United States to begin paying its United Nations dues was still open to some adjustment. The plan is stalled because of efforts in the House of Representatives to link it to a cutoff of all aid to countries or organizations that support abortion as a form of birth control.
But even before this hurdle appeared, the agreement was creating problems for American diplomats here because Congress had been demanding closer American oversight of the United Nations, its budget and its operations.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Growth Stalls As Demand for Car Loans Drops

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Borrowing by American consumers unexpectedly stalled in June, as demand for auto financing and other personal loans declined. It was the first month without an increase in consumer borrowing in more than four years.
The level of outstanding consumer credit was unchanged at $1.217 trillion after rising by a revised $2.5 billion in May, the Federal Reserve said today. Previously, the Fed had said that it rose by $3.0 billion in May. Analysts had expected an increase of $5.0 billion during June. 
 "Consumers and the suppliers of credit have grown a little more wary" of borrowing and lending money, Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass., said. Delinquent loans sent personal bankruptcies above the one million mark in 1996, a yearly record. In some cases, banks are no longer providing credit to tardy borrowers, Ms. Latta said.
Analysts watch the Fed's consumer credit report because it helps them gauge consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of overall economic activity. June's reading was the weakest since a decline of $700 million in May 1993, according to the Fed's statistics.
By category in June, revolving loans, which include credit cards, increased by $2.5 billion, auto loans fell by $100 million, and other types of installment loans fell by $2.4 billion. The Fed's report does not track loans secured by real estate, such as home equity loans and mortgages.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said yesterday that initial claims for unemployment benefits had risen last week, though they were rebounding from the lowest level in more than 23 years. Claims increased by 25,000, to a seasonally adjusted 300,000. In the previous week, claims fell by a revised 24,000, to 275,000, initially reported as a 22,000 drop, to 277,000.
The four-week average for new claims fell to 303,750, from 325,250 the previous week. That was the lowest level for the four-week average since a reading of 302,500 in the last week of February 1989.

HEADLINE: Brest, French Home Port, Sees Future of Mothballs

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: BREST, France

 BODY:
Cardinal Richelieu selected this city at the tip of Brittany to give France a first-class navy. He succeeded so well that over 360 years later, one out of every two jobs here now depends on the military.
Brest, which was heavily bombed during World War II in an Allied effort to destroy the huge submarine base built by the Germans, has been rebuilt since the war. Nowadays, it worries about its 13 percent unemployment rate, one that threatens to get even worse because of military spending cutbacks planned over the next five years. 
 With budget cuts and spending freezes part of the order of the day for the new Socialist Government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, just as they were for the conservatives who began a top-to-bottom post-cold war restructuring of the French military last year, the director of the giant French naval shipyard that dominates the port here warns that the future will not be easy.
"We're headed towards a difficult period, so we're trying to diversify into offshore drilling rigs," the director, Louis Petitbois, said. The yard's biggest military construction project, the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle, is now nearing completion at the main pier beside its two biggest drydocks.
"We know it won't be easy, but we're doing our best to adapt," he said.
Construction or repair of giant floating oil-drilling rigs for the civilian oil industry would be a step in a new direction for the Brest Navy Yard, which now employs 5,500 local civilians compared with 6,800 five years ago.
"We're accelerating staff reductions in anticipation of a slowdown because of cutbacks in the military budget that Parliament decided on last year," Mr. Petitbois said.
He and most of the rest of the 220,000 people who live here are still waiting to hear the details of what the new Government has in mind for Brest.
But Bertrand Laot, a technician who headed the Democratic French Labor Confederation office here until this summer, thinks he knows which way the wind is blowing, since one of Mr. Jospin's first actions after taking office on June 1 was a preliminary freeze of $333 million in spending on military projects.
"Cutbacks have been continuous for the past five years no matter what the Prime Minister's name was," he said.
France's conservative President, Jacques Chirac, ordered a restructuring of the French military that will do away with conscription by 2002 and reduce the size of the military to 350,000 from 500,000 a year ago.
Brest, whose shopping streets tend toward chain department stores and American fast food outlets rather than to boutiques and expense-account restaurants, threw most of its conservative legislators out and replaced them with Socialists in the elections in the spring. But the tide continued to run against the military industry the town has always depended on.
The French Navy not only designs its own ships and submarines, as the United States Navy does, but also builds them itself instead of contracting with private builders. The Brest shipyard is wholly owned by the French military procurement agency, itself a vast establishment now in the throes of restructuring.
"They've reduced the size of the labor force by delegating a lot of jobs they used to do out to subcontractors, but it's clear that there's going to be a major reduction in shipbuilding orders and probably 3,000 jobs will be lost by the year 2000," Mr. Laot said. "We've been telling them since the 1980's that they should have gotten started earlier on diversification."
His and other unions here led a demonstration of 30,000 people last year and got another 15,000 to 20,000 people into the streets at the beginning of this year to protest the cutbacks. But with unemployment in Brest already running above the 12.6 percent national average, Mr. Laot conceded that there was little prospect of a turnabout.
"So far this year, the shipyard has hired only 19 apprentices," he said, shaking his head. "In the 1980's, they always took on 90 to 100 a year. The future looks pretty dark."
Mothballing rather than making ships threatens to become Brest's major industry. The Durance, an 18,000-ton resupply ship that visited New York City at the beginning of July, was decommissioned when it got back here at the end of the month. It will be cannibalized for spare parts for other ships of its class, a shipyard official said.
Most of the work on the $2.8 billion Charles de Gaulle, an 858-foot-long, 44,000-ton nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, is to be completed by the end of this year, nearly 10 years after the keel was laid. Jacques Bizcen, the shipyard official in charge of the project, said construction could have been completed faster but for previous Government budget cuts.
"There have been three and a half years of postponements to save money," said Capt. Richard Wilmot-Roussel, the carrier's military commander, acknowledging that the delays were false economies that had been imposed on the shipyard by budget snarls in Paris.
Captain Wilmot-Roussel is already on board, like about two-thirds of his crew of 1,250, who expect to bring the ship into full active duty in mid-1999.
Right now the carrier is cluttered with scaffolding, power cables and carpentry and painting equipment, but the forward flight deck was clear the other day for tests of one of its two American-designed steam-powered airplane catapults.
With a big thud and a trail of steam shooting across the deck like smoke from a powder fuse, the catapult launched a dead weight as massive as the supersonic Rafale fighter-bombers it will have to handle off the ship's bow at more than 150 miles an hour, making a splash as big as a bomb in the harbor.
"France's means are too modest to permit it to build a large carrier like the U.S.S. Nimitz class," the captain said. "But with the Charles de Gaulle we will have the same unlimited range and force-projection capabilities as an American nuclear-powered carrier with F-18's. We'll just carry half as many of them."
A smaller force packing a larger punch, and capable of moving troops and weapons systems far from home, is what Mr. Chirac hopes will emerge from the restructuring. But in the short run it's not good news for Brest. With no sister ship for the De Gaulle currently planned, the main source of work for Brest's shipbuilders for the rest of the decade is an amphibious assault ship called the Siroco.
"I often get calls from people asking if I think their kids should go to work at the yard," said Jean Tanguy Leost, another union official. "I tell them, if their children are doing well in school, they should keep on with their studies."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
For Stock Mutual Funds in '97, A Great Year in Just 7 Months

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT

 BODY:
Seven months into the year, mutual fund investors have already made this the second-best year ever for stock funds. Nor have they forgotten about bonds in their rush to buy stocks; bond funds have already recorded their best year since 1993.
The Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group, said yesterday that equity funds took in an estimated $23 billion in new cash in July. If the estimate is confirmed in the institute's final figures at the end of this month, it would be the fifth-largest monthly total and the biggest since January, when stock funds received a monthly record of $29 billion in new money. 
 So far this year, investors have deposited a net $133 billion in stock mutual funds, more than in any whole year except 1996, when these funds took in $221 billion in net new cash.
Bond funds in July received an estimated $4 billion in net cash flows, the best monthly total since January 1996. Including last month's deposits, bond funds have taken in $13.2 billion in the first seven months of the year, exceeding the $12.8 billion received by bond funds in all of 1996.
Bond funds suffered substantial outflows beginning in 1994, when the Federal Reserve pushed up interest rates, leading to a rout in the bond market. Investors withdrew a net $43.3 billion from bond funds in 1994 and took out $4.7 billion more in 1995.
The best year ever for bond funds was 1993, when they took in $113 billion.
In nine of the last 12 months, however, investors have added to their bond fund investments. Those additions took a sharp jump last month, as the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond dipped to its lowest level since February 1996. (Bond yields and prices move in opposite directions)
That mutual fund investors have responded with such enthusiasm to a steady increase in stock and bond prices over the last four months gives some professionals pause, however.
"As long as prices are going up, people tend to feel good," said Robert W. Bissell, a senior vice president at Wells Fargo Investment Management, the mutual fund unit of the California-based banking company. "My reaction is to be a little more careful when everything seems bright and rosy."
With both stock and bond prices significantly higher than at the beginning of the year, Mr. Bissell said, "you've got to assume that any serious bad news is going to scare people."
Not that he sees any real clouds on the horizon. Mr. Bissell said that earlier this week, he tried to list all the reasons that stocks have performed so well this year. "I think I got to about 25" items on the list, he said.
That gave him confidence that cash flows are far from the only factor propelling the stock market. In fact, Mr. Bissell said, he believes the monthly data are a lagging indicator of market sentiment, rather than a leading one.
For most of the mutual fund companies, however, the recent cash-flow figures confirm that business has rarely been better.
The Vanguard Group, the country's second-largest mutual fund company after Fidelity Investments and the biggest seller of index funds, one of the most popular types of stock funds lately, recorded its second-best month of the year for stock fund sales in July, behind only January.
Ditto at Fidelity, a unit of the FMR Corporation, where stock fund inflows also trailed only January.
July's estimated net inflows to stock funds were up 39 percent, from $16.5 billion in June, and were four times the $5.7 billion recorded a year earlier, in July 1996. That month, stock prices fell sharply, causing stock fund inflows to all but cease.
Flows into bond funds, which totaled $2.1 billion in June, nearly doubled last month. In July 1996, bond funds suffered a net outflow of $1 billion.

Chart shows net cash flow into equity mutual funds (in billions) for the years 1991 through 1997. (Source: Investment Company Institute)(pg. D6)
