HEADLINE: Welfare Bill Denies Benefits To Immigrants in First Year

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 7

 BODY:
The welfare bill awaiting Gov. George E. Pataki's signature contains a provision that would deny state-financed benefits to legal immigrants in their first year in this country. Immigrants are allowed to enter the country only if sponsors promise financial support, but New York State now provides benefits to immigrants when sponsors are unable or unwilling to support them.
The welfare bill, which the Governor is expected to approve in the next few days, would end that practice for immigrants in their first year in America. Pataki administration officials, defending the provision, noted that the sponsorship requirement in Federal immigration law made newcomers the responsibility of their sponsors and the Federal Government, not state taxpayers. 
 Beyond that, administration officials said, it is necessary to adopt the 12-month restriction on benefits for newcomers so that the state avoids becoming a magnet for poor people from beyond its borders.
"When people are granted the right to be a legal noncitizen resident, they're expected to be self-sufficient," said Daniel D. Hogan, a spokesman for the state's Department of Social Services. "But if you come to be a ward of the state, no, that's not a reason to come in. That's not a reason to be a resident."
The provision has begun to draw fire from groups that advocate benefits for the poor and immigrants. They said they were surprised and dismayed to find the new restriction buried in the 200-page state welfare bill, particularly since Mr. Pataki had expressed a desire to establish more generous state-financed benefits for immigrants denied Federal assistance under a law enacted last year. That law denies federally financed benefits to immigrants arriving in this country after August 1996.
The advocates also contend that the one-year ban on state-financed benefits might violate the New York State Constitution declaration that state and local governments have an obligation to care for the needy.
"We were shocked by this," said Marjorie McHugh, executive director of the New York Immigration Coalition, whose 175 groups represent immigrants and refugees. "This is a tremendous change in both the Governor's position, as well as state policy. It is an ill-conceived 11th-hour provision that was inserted into the law without any consideration of its necessity or impact on people."
The advocates also questioned what the state would gain by excluding this group, given that it is relatively small.
Between 100,000 and 125,000 legal immigrants come to New York State every year, according to the coalition. Welfare experts say that 5 percent require public assistance. The advocates say that people who might need public aid, particularly mothers and their children, could be left with no means of financial support if their sponsor, often a male head of household, abandons them, becomes unemployed or fails to live up to his commitment for another reason.
"The concern is that there won't be a safety net if these people lose their sponsor," said Shelly Nortz, director of state policy for New York State Coalition for the Homeless. "The policy has heretofore been to provide assistance if no sponsor is available."
Throughout the debate over reforming the state's welfare laws, Mr. Pataki has cast himself as a defender of immigrants, saying that those here legally should not be deprived of public assistance.
As recently as last week, after Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders reached a deal on changing the state's welfare laws, his office issued a news release that said simply, "Legal immigrants will receive non-cash safety-net benefits with a personal-needs allowance in year one."
Zenia Mucha, the Governor's director of communications, said today that the administration only intended to give benefits to needy immigrants already in the country.
"We're talking about legal immigrants who are here," she said. "They have a right to be protected."
The welfare bill passed by the Legislature this week would continue providing state-financed benefits for immigrants already in this country.
The immigrants would be able to get cash benefits for up to two years and then a combination of vouchers and some cash for as long as they stay on welfare. Lawmakers have said that this program is crucial for immigrants who do not qualify for Federal assistance. But newly arriving immigrants, the Pataki administration said, come under the promise that they will not depend on state aid and thus must live up to that commitment.

HEADLINE: In Balanced-Budget Deal, Bush Is Off the Seesaw

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
While President Clinton and Speaker Newt Gingrich are grandly congratulating themselves and each other over the balanced-budget deal they wrought, George Bush, the man who risked the most and paid the biggest price for cutting the deficit, is off in Maine, feeling unappreciated.
"I'm a great believer in letting history decide what you did right and what you did wrong," the former President said in a telephone interview today. 
 "I do think history will show that we laid the groundwork for some of this," Mr. Bush said. "It would please me if that was recognized, because I was derided as being out of touch and having no feel for the economy."
Mr. Bush did not say so, but among those who derided him that way were Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gingrich. The former President agreed to be interviewed on the condition that he not appear to be tooting his own horn.
The budget agreement that Mr. Bush struck in 1990 with a Congress controlled by Democrats may well have cost him his Presidency. Many of his fellow Republican politicians turned against him because as part of the budget agreement, he abandoned the promise he made in his 1988 campaign: "Read my lips, no new taxes."
In the 1992 race, Mr. Clinton advocated a tax cut and portrayed Mr. Bush as inept on economic matters. But the prevailing view of economists is that the 1990 deal was the single most important political step leading to a balanced budget.
"The major heavy lifting was done by George Bush and the 101st Congress," said Robert D. Reischauer, who was then the director of the Congressional Budget Office and is now an economist at the Brookings Institution.
"This package is not primarily about deficit reduction," Mr. Reischauer said, speaking of this year's budget legislation. "It's more about delivering on the promises of the Republicans to cut taxes and of the President to expand spending on certain programs."
At his news conference on Wednesday, Mr. Clinton allotted no credit to Mr. Bush's heavy lifting. "The first step" toward eliminating annual budget deficits, the President said, "was taken back in 1993 when we opened a new chapter in fiscal responsibility."
If that galled Mr. Bush, he did not let on in the interview.
"He's very content with himself, and he's much too much of a gentleman to pat himself on the back," said Nicholas F. Brady, who was Mr. Bush's Treasury Secretary and is still a close friend.
But Mr. Clinton's claim of originality "is just plain wrong," Mr. Brady continued. "It started with George Bush. He's the guy who lay down on the railroad tracks."
In these times of peace and prosperity, it is easy to forget the tensions that dominated politics in the fall of 1990. Iraq had just invaded Kuwait. The economy was in a recession. The budget deficit was approaching $300 billion and rising.
To break a deadlock with the Democratic Congress, the White House issued a statement saying that "tax revenue increases" would be a part of the budget negotiations. Standing before television cameras in the White House driveway, Mr. Gingrich, then the No. 2 Republican in the House, denounced the President.
After weeks of negotiations, Mr. Bush and Democratic Congressional leaders reached an agreement on the budget.With little support from the Democratic rank and file and with Mr. Gingrich organizing the Republican opposition, the agreement was voted down by the House. A new accord was annealed. Much more favorable to Democrats, it was approved in Congress even though a large majority of Republicans voted "no."
The tax increases are what is most remembered about the measure. The tax rate on the income of the wealthiest Americans was raised to 31 percent from 28 percent, and they were forced to pay more in Medicare premiums. The value of deductions and personal exemptions was phased out for upper-income taxpayers. Taxes on gasoline and cigarettes were raised.
But in retrospect, economists say, the most important element of the accord was the discipline it placed on Government spending.
Annual outlays for what is known as discretionary spending -- everything from aircraft carriers to computer paper -- were essentially frozen. No new spending on benefit programs like Medicare was allowed unless it was offset by a tax increase, and no tax cut was permitted unless it was offset by a cut in benefit programs. And an accounting loophole was closed that had allowed the Government to borrow money and not count it as spending.
Those rules were extended by Mr. Clinton's budget in 1993, and they basically remain in place today.
Mr. Reischauer has calculated that the five-year savings from the 1990 deal was $580 billion in 1997 dollars. The comparable figure in the 1993 budget was $474 billion. And the projected saving from this year's measure is $125 billion.
One reason Mr. Bush may not get credit for what he accomplished in deficit reduction is that he began apologizing even before he signed the legislation. On the day Congress voted its final approval, he said he was "absolutely going to hold the line on taxes" from then on. And in his 1992 campaign, he seemed to suggest that the deal might have been a mistake.
Today, his tune is changed somewhat. "I'm not particularly proud of the tax increase," he said at his summer home in Kennebunkport as his house guest, Brian Mulroney, the former Prime Minister of Canada, listened in to the interview. "But we had to have some compromise, and I paid one hell of a price for it."

HEADLINE: A Makeover May Change More Than Columbia

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Adopting drastic changes in the way it does business, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation has begun transforming itself into a company far different from the one that upended the once-sleepy hospital world over the last nine years.
Gone -- apparently -- is the obsession with 15 percent profit growth each year that at times may have led managers to actions that prompted a sweeping criminal investigation. Gone is the seemingly insatiable appetite for acquiring competing hospitals that has made Columbia one of the most feared participants in the health care industry. And gone is the once unshakable faith that to succeed in the modern health care system, a company must own businesses that provide every phase of treatment, from hospital care to home care. 
 Columbia's plan to alter or abandon many of its controversial business practices was announced yesterday. Elements of the plan, first disclosed yesterday in The New York Times, include selling the company's home health care division, eliminating its cash bonus program for executives who met financial targets, adopting new rules to insure employees comply with the law and abandoning the practice of selling interests in Columbia hospitals to doctors, as well as other changes.
The effects of Columbia's changes could well reach beyond just this one company to other parts of the health care industry. Indeed, analysts who just a short time ago believed that the future of American health care rested with a small number of large health care systems have found their faith shaken by the makeover at Columbia.
"Six months ago I thought I had a handle on where we would be in health care several years down the road," said Leo Murphy, vice president of investments at Pioneer Management, a Columbia investor. But with Columbia taking a step back, he said: "I think now we are going to be surprised where we are going to come out. It's not going to be what we thought."
Executives working with Columbia said that while many elements of the plan had been in place for several days the final version remained in flux until shortly before yesterday's announcement. Late Wednesday night, at meetings in the company's headquarters in Nashville, senior executives hammered out last-minute additions in the action plan, an effort to respond to wide-ranging criminal investigations of the company.
Under the additional points, the company would adopt stronger guidelines on any future transactions with doctors, to insure that they avoid the appearance of conflicts of interest. It will adopt stricter guidelines and controls in billing for laboratory services, which is one element of the multifaceted fraud investigation of Columbia.
The company will also begin reviews of what is known as Medicare coding. Under Federal rules, Medicare pays a set amount for each of thousands of specified diagnoses. Through what is known as upcoding, hospitals can increase their revenue by reporting that the diagnosis was more severe than what was actually treated. To insure against that and to avoid mistakes, Columbia will create a two-step review process, including analysis by independent auditors, for specific codes that are particularly susceptible to coding errors.
After examining information developed by The Times in the course of a yearlong investigation into Columbia's business practices, the Federal agency that runs Medicare began a review to determine if certain Columbia hospitals engaged in upcoding.
A computer analysis of more than 30 million billing records by The Times, first reported in March, found that Columbia hospitals billed Medicare for high-paying respiratory treatments far more often than did competing hospitals serving similar populations. Federal authorities called such findings an indication of possible overbilling of the program.
Columbia's plan was announced less than two weeks after the appointment of Dr. Thomas F. Frist Jr. as chairman and chief executive of the embattled company. He replaced Richard L. Scott, the hard-driving co-founder who pushed the company and its employees to meet a series of aggressive financial targets.
In a conference call with reporters yesterday morning, Dr. Frist, the co-founder and former chairman of the Hospital Corporation of America, made clear that the initiatives marked a drastic shift in Columbia's strategy, which had propelled the company to the top of the health care world while raising questions about the legality of some of its actions.
"This is a definite change in emphasis from rapid growth to operational mode for the next 18 to 24 months," he said. Saying that the "meteoric pace" of growth at the company was no longer appropriate, Dr. Frist said it was time for Columbia to "take a pause, a deep breath."
Dr. Frist also made clear that by deciding to sell its home health care division, the company was moving away from Mr. Scott's faith that the future of health care was in full-service health care systems that owned every outlet for the delivery of care. Such integration could be accomplished instead through ventures with other companies.
"This isn't abandoning the fully integrated health care system," Dr. Frist said. "The difference is, it doesn't all have to be owned."
Dr. Frist also said that Columbia would drop its adversarial approach to not-for-profit hospitals, and instead reach out to them, both for advice and for cooperative ventures.
But by disposing of its home health care division while removing pressures for executives to meet financial targets, Columbia will not achieve the earnings performance it has in the past, analysts said.
"This is all going to moderate their growth rate," Mr. Murphy of Pioneer said. "The management has accepted that, and I think Wall Street is starting to get there."
As the plan was coming into focus, in recent weeks some analysts began trimming their estimates for profit growth, from around 15 percent to about 10 percent. But, given the increasing pressure of the Federal investigations, securities analysts supported the company's moves.
Falling earnings "is not the critical issue facing the company," Kenneth Abramowitz, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said. "The critical issue is to resolve these disputes and investigations."
The same could hold true for Columbia's rivals. Many emulated the company's practices and now fear that they too could be caught up in scandal. In the end, that could save money for Federal payment systems like Medicare, as efforts to clean up billing errors and improprieties sweep across the industry.
"There is considerable concern that the investigative probes that have penetrated so deeply into Columbia will next focus on not-for-profit targets," said John Leifer, an independent health care consultant who resigned as a senior vice president at Columbia over concern about its business practices. Because of that, "the vast majority of hospitals and health systems will re-evaluate the manner in which they do business to insure that their activities can withstand scrutiny."
But the changes in the industry could reach further. In particular, with Columbia declaring its intent to sharply slow the pace of acquisitions and become more cooperative with competitors, the number of large -- and sometimes ill-planned -- health care deals could drop, some health care experts said.
"The threat of Columbia was like the Vikings coming on the coast of France, and people made very rash decisions in response," said Uwe Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University. "So a lot of the irrational integration and dealmaking that wasn't well thought out might diminish."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

F.C.C. Moves to Cut Costs Of Phone Calls Overseas
The F.C.C. issued tough new rules to reduce the payments that American telephone companies make to foreign carriers to complete their calls.
 
 The move could sharply reduce the cost of calling from the United States to many places overseas. But it represents the Government's first aggressive entry into the back-room haggling among the world's telephone companies, which questioned the F.C.C.'s jurisdiction. [Page A1.]
 
Strong Month for Retailers
American retailers in July enjoyed one of the strongest months of sales in two years. The Goldman, Sachs retail composite index rose 5.7 percent. [D6.]
 
In the previous month, however, growth in consumer credit slowed, as demand for auto financing and other loans declined. [D4.]
 
Gains in Operations At America Online
America Online, the computer on-line service, posted a quarterly loss, though Stephen M. Case, the company's chairman, noted that operating results were above analysts' expectations. The company also restated its results for previous quarters after the S.E.C. refused to approve its accounting procedures. [D3.]
 
Mixing New York and Hollywood
CBS elevated Leslie Moonves, the network's top programming executive, to president of CBS Television, giving him considerable oversight over the business side, too. [D4.]
 
Bonds Slump, Hurting Stocks
Treasury securities stumbled as an auction of 30-year bonds was a bit disappointing and as a surge of corporate debt came to market. In trading, the 30-year bond's yield rose to 6.52 percent from 6.47, through the newly auctioned issue was awarded at 6.44 percent. [D16.]
 
The weakness in the Treasury market hurt stocks, too, with the Dow industrials falling 71.31 points, to 8,188.00, in a topsy-turvy session. [D6.]
 
Agriculture Investment by DuPont
DuPont said that it would invest $1.7 billion in Pioneer Hi-Bred International, a seed producer, as part of a plan to create a powerful rival to Monsanto and others in the fast-growing business of genetically engineered agriculture. [D3.]
 
Fisher Scientific Finds Buyer
An investor group led by the Thomas H. Lee Companies agreed to buy Fisher Scientific for $1.4 billion, in an effort to thwart an unsolicited offer of $1 billion by the Bass Group. [D3.]
 
Kodak Digital Unit's Head Is Out
The president of Kodak's troubled digital imaging business resigned after struggling for a year and a half to get it on track. [D3.]
 
Tougher Times for E.D.S.
Electronic Data Systems, buffeted by tougher competition and shrinking profit margins in the computer services industry, reported declining earnings and said the poor results would continue for the rest of the year. [D6.]
 
Crackdown on Fleet-Footed Brokers
The N.A.S.D. adopted a rule that will make it much harder for brokers from firms that violate securities laws to move on to other firms after theirs have been shut down. [D3.]
 
G.E. Cuts Stake in Paine Webber
General Electric's Capital Services agreed to sell six million Paine Webber shares back to the brokerage firm for $219 million. [D4.]
 
Little Progress Seen in U.P.S. Talks
Leaders of the teamsters' union and the United Parcel Service resumed negotiations in an effort to end the four-day-old strike, but their public statements indicated little flexibility from either side. [A22.]
 
In 1982, recently hired part-timers at U.P.S. earned $9 an hour, $4 less than a full-timer. Today, the part-timers still earn $9 an hour while full-timers earn nearly $20 -- indicative of how the country has increasingly moved to two tiers of jobs and wages. [A22.]

HEADLINE: CALLING OVERSEAS MAY GET CHEAPER

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

 BODY:
In a move that could sharply reduce the cost of calling from the United States to many places overseas, the Federal Communications Commission issued tough new rules yesterday to cut the $5.4 billion that American telephone companies pay to foreign carriers to complete their calls.
The rules represent the Government's first aggressive entry into the back-room haggling among the world's telephone companies. They are intended to jump-start competition in global telecommunications and stanch the flow of dollars from American to foreign carriers. But they may have their biggest impact on the average customer's phone bill. 
 Reed E. Hundt, the chairman of the F.C.C., said yesterday that the rules would help reduce the average cost of an overseas call to 20 cents a minute from 88 cents a minute over six years.
"We are a nation of immigrants, and we ought to be able to phone home without being E.T.," Mr. Hundt said, referring to Steven Spielberg's extraterrestrial, who did not need to make expensive calls to reach the folks back home.
The F.C.C.'s unilateral move drew harsh criticism from representatives of foreign carriers, who said the United States could not impose rates on foreign carriers and predicted that some carriers might refuse to accept the commission's rates. They also questioned the F.C.C.'s jurisdiction, saying that the plan violated a recent global communications deal negotiated at the World Trade Organization.
"This is going to antagonize foreign carriers," said Albert Halprin, a former F.C.C. official and now a communications lawyer who has lobbied on behalf of New Zealand's national carrier, Telecom New Zealand. "Instead of trying to lead a global effort to reform the system, the F.C.C. has chosen to make itself the champion for U.S. carriers."
Mr. Hundt said the commission took its action after five years of failed efforts to marshal support among other countries to revamp the Byzantine system of payments between phone companies. He predicted that the foreign carriers would have little ground to retaliate.
"There has been a consensus for a decade that a cartel of companies has jacked up prices to a hideous level," he said.
At the heart of the F.C.C.'s campaign are fees called settlement rates. These are the payments that phone companies make to each other to complete calls. Settlement rates have historically been set well above the cost of completing a call, particularly in countries with less developed economies or powerful state-owned telephone monopolies.
Settlement rates can account for much more than half the total cost of an overseas call -- which is why it is so much more expensive to call Sao Paulo than San Francisco from New York. According to the F.C.C., the average cost of a domestic long-distance call is 13 cents a minute, compared with 88 cents a minute for an overseas call.
Because AT&T and other American carriers send more calls overseas than they receive, the settlement system results in a net outflow of money from the United States to foreign carriers. Reducing the settlement rates would not wipe out the imbalance. But F.C.C. officials said it could trim the $5.4 billion deficit to less than $2 billion.
The United States Government has not historically played a large role in establishing settlement rates; they were usually hammered out in private negotiations between the carriers. But because most foreign phone companies are state-owned or controlled, the American carriers were, in effect, negotiating with the governments of these countries.
Under the new rules, however, the F.C.C. would direct AT&T and other American carriers to negotiate deals with foreign carriers, based on benchmark rates tailored to the income level of their home countries. The rates range from 15 cents a minute for wealthy countries like Britain to 23 cents a minute for poor countries like Bangladesh. Countries in between, like Mexico and the Philippines, would have rates set at 19 cents.
The plan will have little effect on highly competitive overseas routes, like New York-London. The rates charged by British Telecommunications, for example, are already below the F.C.C. benchmark. But it will have a huge effect on a market like the Philippines, which currently has a settlement rate of 50 cents a minute and under the commission's new rules would have to cut it to 19 cents a minute.
The overall plan would take effect on Jan. 1, 1998, and is timed to coincide with the World Trade Organization agreement, which will open 95 percent of the world's telephone markets to competition. But the actual rates will be phased in over five years, with the wealthy countries having to comply by 1999 while the poorest countries have until 2003.
Because two-thirds of the world's overseas telephone traffic travels between Europe and North America, Mr. Hundt said the majority of consumers would see a measurable decline in rates within two years. But it is uncertain precisely how much of a decline in customer rates will come in the first years of the plan.
Mr. Hundt has already signaled his get-tough approach. He recently informed MCI Communications that the commission would reject a deal between it and the national carrier of India because the rates were too high. And he expressed displeasure with a pending deal between AT&T and Japan.
If the foreign carriers balk at lower rates, Mr. Hundt said the United States had several cudgels. The F.C.C. could order every American carrier to demand the same rate, which would ratchet up the pressure on a country to come to terms.
Last year, AT&T won the support of the commission for such a strategy when it tried to reduce the rates it was paying to the dominant Argentine carrier, Telefonica de Argentina.
When Telefonica de Argentina would not accede to AT&T's proposed rates and began refusing to complete its calls, the commission ordered other American carriers to begin paying the same rate as AT&T. That pressure brought Telefonica de Argentina to terms with AT&T.
If a country were to cut off its circuits to the United States altogether, F.C.C. officials said there was still another option. American carriers could route calls through a third country, and that country's national carrier could pass them on to the hostile country.
The prospect of a go-between siphoning off the settlement fees from calls intended for a country would be enough of an incentive for that country to come to an agreement, F.C.C. officials said.
Still, some industry experts were uncertain that the F.C.C.'s tactics would work, particularly in less-developed countries, which have come to rely on settlement fees to finance public works projects.
"Why would they give that up without a fight?" said Brian Moir, a lobbyist for the International Communications Association, which represents more than 500 multinational corporate telephone customers.
And Mr. Halprin pointed out that the immediate beneficiaries of the lower settlement rates would be the carriers -- not their customers. He said the F.C.C. had not mandated that AT&T, MCI and other carriers pass along their savings to customers on a dollar-for-dollar basis.
"They make a phenomenally high rate of return on their international service," Mr. Halprin said. "This is primarily in the interest of AT&T and other American carriers."
But Peter Cowhey, the chief of the F.C.C.'s international bureau, said the coming competition in long distance would make it untenable for carriers not to pass along the savings to customers.

HEADLINE: Landmark Settlement Ends Hispanic Housing Bias Suit

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 7

 BODY:
When a job in the press room of a printing company lured Francisco Hernandez to Addison, Ill., a dozen years ago, he was one of only a few Mexican-Americans in town.
The Chicago suburb, where boxy factories as flat as the land churn out gaskets and garage doors, conveyor belts and plastic bubble wrap, had long been a destination of the city's middle-class whites, many from an earlier kind of American immigrant stock: Greek, Italian, Polish or German. 
 But Mr. Hernandez was soon joined by other working-class Mexican-Americans, who abandoned Chicago's grit and strain for Addison's safe streets, humming economy and solid schools. By 1990, they made up more than an eighth of Addison's 32,000 residents.
Then, three years ago, the local government bulldozed the small apartment building where Mr. Hernandez lived. It also razed seven other buildings and condemned three more in Mr. Hernandez's neighborhood, saying those and dozens of other buildings containing several hundred apartments were blighted.
The Hispanic residents said Addison was trying to force them out of town, or at least discourage more from coming. The Justice Department agreed and sued, accusing Addison of intentional discrimination.
Today, Addison officials settled the Federal case and a private class-action lawsuit with an ambitious plan that Justice Department officials and housing experts said was a watershed resolution to a housing discrimination claim: While denying that it intentionally discriminated, the village will agree to build affordable housing to replace what it tears down, pay moving costs or compensation to dozens of families, deposit $30,000 in a fair housing fund and put up a community center and parks in the two Hispanic neighborhoods.
The plan is expected to cost $20 million to $25 million, most of it in development costs, Addison officials said. The cost of damages to families and fair-housing groups alone, up to $1.4 million, makes the settlement one of the largest by a municipality in a fair-housing suit, said Paul Hancock, acting deputy United States Attorney General for civil rights.
The case, Justice and housing officials say, is also the latest example of a recent and troubling trend in which Hispanic residents have become the target of a kind of bias that blacks once faced, with several municipalities in New Mexico, New Jersey and elsewhere in the country using government programs or zoning laws as discriminatory tools.
Hispanic Americans, now 10 percent of the United States population and expected to become the country's largest minority by 2010, are beginning to leave overcrowded urban neighborhoods for better jobs in the suburbs, many of which have long been dominated by whites.
"A lot of these jurisdictions for the first time are experiencing an increase in Hispanic population," Mr. Hancock said. "In previous decades we dealt with opposition to racial minorities moving to the suburbs. This seems to be similar."
In Addison, Mr. Hancock said, "our concern was not just that they were tearing down housing, but that their intent seemed to be to rid the village of Hispanics. Now with this plan they are improving the sections of the village where Hispanics live and everyone will be able to stay in the village. That's what makes this such an important settlement."
Municipal officials said they were not biased, but were trying to address concerns about overcrowded housing and dilapidated apartments. Some said that if the Hispanic residents were affected by the ordinances, it was because their families tended to be larger, sometimes including several relatives beyond the immediate family, or because they lived in neighborhoods where the houses were more run-down.
Addison officials denied any discriminatory intent in their decision to use a state tax incentive program to demolish some buildings and make way for new development. John Berley, the assistant village manager, said officials settled the case to avoid the cost of continuing legal proceedings and the risk of losing at trial.
Mr. Berley suggested that the village, a Republican stronghold, might have been the focus of a political agenda by a Democratic Administration in Washington. And he said that much of the settlement, including the new parks and community center, was "a plan we probably would have done anyway."
Hispanic residents and advocates say there is more to it. They say that Hispanic Americans encounter friction after their neighborhoods swell and their culture and language begin to be noticed.
"People hear Spanish being spoken in the street and at school," said Jonathan Rothstein, a lawyer who represented the plaintiffs in the class-action suit against Addison. "They see Latinos using their front yards instead of their back yards. It reaches what some people consider an unacceptable critical mass."
Charles Kamasaki, a vice president of the National Council of La Raza, said that Hispanic residents long unwilling or insufficiently savvy to file civil rights complaints were becoming better organized and more aggressive.
Mr. Hancock said the Addison settlement, which still must be approved by the Federal district judge handling the case, went far beyond what could have been achieved at trial and "the city deserves credit for sitting down and working out a solution."
In the last three years, three other towns have reached settlements with the Justice Department in housing discrimination cases against Hispanic residents.
In New Jersey, the beach town of Wildwood, near Atlantic City, agreed to pay $75,000 in damages after the Justice Department accused the city of discrimination against Hispanic families by selectively enforcing an ordinance that allowed only one person to a bedroom.
The City of Hatch, N.M., settled a lawsuit brought by the Justice Department in December by agreeing to pay $260,000. The suit said town officials used a ban on mobile homes to force Mexican farm workers to move out of Hatch and live in "colonias," squalid shacks without sewage systems or potable water.
Another Chicago suburb, Waukegan, agreed in May to pay up to $200,000 in damages, hire a bilingual fair-housing counselor and stop enforcing a housing ordinance that limited the number of people who could live under one roof to the immediate family and two additional relatives.
And Cicero, Ill., a historically white town west of Chicago, is also being sued for what the Justice Department said was a similar restriction on occupancy that not only seemed to target the town's rapidly growing Hispanic population but also angered real estate agents who said the ordinance kept them from selling houses to the many Hispanic families moving in.
A spokesman for Cicero, David Donahue, denied the allegations and said the town had no intention of settling the lawsuit. "If you have two families living in a single-family home," Mr. Donahue said, "they are only paying one set of property taxes. It's a safety reason and a school overcrowding issue."
Fair-housing advocates and Hispanic organizations said that the Justice Department was selective about the cases it chose and that they had seen similar examples of housing discrimination in Minnesota, Texas and other states.
In the Chicago area, where housing advocates have a long tradition and Hispanic immigration has risen sharply, several suburbs have been confronted about their housing plans or zoning laws and subsequently agreed to change them.
In Addison, a middle-class suburb on the loops of Interstate highways that rope Chicago to the rest of the Midwest and beyond, many of the residents work on assembly lines or in packing plants, and live in modest ranch houses or split-level homes. In the 1950's and 60's, Addison was a prime destination for white ethnic Chicago families. The village has seen its economy energized in recent years as a convenient place for companies to base their Midwest operations.
Addison officials said they did not intend to drive Hispanic residents out of town. "If it looks that way, we're sorry," Mr. Berley said. "We were doing our duty as public officials. Sometimes you have to do things in the public interest and sometimes a small number of people are going to get hurt in the course of it."
Mr. Berley said the buildings in Addison, 30-year-old yellow or tan brick low-rise apartments, had been built too close together and lacked adequate parking and playgrounds. He said the buildings had fallen victim to maintenance problems ranging from broken steps to cockroaches. Mr. Berley said newer residents were renters without the same stake as earlier owners in keeping up the property. "Hispanic families generally do live several families together in the same unit," he said. "That wears property down."
Mr. Berley also said the neighborhoods had been attracting gangs.
"O.K., they're not Cabrini-Green or Robert Taylor Homes," Mr. Berley said, referring to two of the most notorious Chicago housing projects. "Well, are we supposed to wait till it gets to be a Cabrini-Green?"
Hispanic residents say that Addison officials exaggerate the crime and maintenance problems, and that residents have been working to solve them. In a recent visit, the neighborhoods seemed generally neat, if weathered, with iron or concrete balconies, cut grass and children riding bikes or playing soccer outside.
Rita Gonzalez, 32, left one of Chicago's Mexican neighborhoods 10 years ago for a job in a plastic bag factory in Addison and the goal of better schools for her three sons, one of whom began using Chicago gang signals at age 5. A soft-spoken woman, Ms. Gonzalez said she found herself the reluctant leader of the mushrooming Hispanic community.
Ms. Gonzalez, who lives in one of the two Addison neighborhoods designated for redevelopment and was a plaintiff in the class-action suit, said there had been few serious clashes with the "Anglos" in Addison, but she believed that officials were "surprised at how rapidly the community grew."
Mr. Hernandez who used a disability payment to buy a house in Addison after his apartment building was demolished, said the Hispanic community contributed to the village economy, shopping in local stores and starting their own businesses, like the Tejano and Salsa music store, Mi Pueblo, that his family opened recently. "I feel betrayed by the village," he said. "But this is what I call my home."
The Mayor of Addison, Larry Hartwig, who is principal of a local junior high school, said officials were happy to have Hispanic people living in Addison. "I don't think it's a racial thing," Mr. Hartwig said. "I think it's a cultural thing. I see two types of Hispanics in Addison. There are those that have been here for a long time and are very acculturated. If you didn't know their last name, you wouldn't know they were Hispanic. Like Joe Fernandez, who owns the Pink Pony. He's like everybody else here in town. The newer ones, I don't blame them. We need to educate them. As they come and migrate to our country, they need to adapt and adopt our ways."

The suits were settled yesterday in favor of Hispanic residents who said the village tried to force them out of town. Rita Gonzalez has become a leader of Addison's Hispanic residents. HEADLINE: Little Flexibility Seen in Talks Between Teamsters and U.P.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Leaders of the teamsters' union and the United Parcel Service resumed negotiations yesterday in an effort to end the four-day-old strike, but their public statements indicated little flexibility from either side.
Officials from U.P.S. and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters said wide gaps remained between them, adding that it would be difficult to bridge those differences in just a day or two. 
 Before joining the talks in a Federal mediator's office in Washington, James P. Kelly, the company's chairman, said: "We hope to get this resolved. However, we do have an excellent last, best and final offer."
Ronald Carey, the teamsters' president, voiced concern that the company was returning to the bargaining table for public relations purposes and would not budge from its last offer.
"If it's just a smoke screen," Mr. Carey said, "we're out of here."
Despite the resumption of talks, over a dozen pickets around the country were arrested as they tried to block U.P.S. trucks that were driven by managers. In New York City, the police arrested Abel Whitehead, a striker, and charged him with reckless endangerment for throwing eggs at a truck at the U.P.S. center at 43d Street and 11th Avenue.
The negotiators are deadlocked over the company's demand to set up a new pension plan and the union's demands for a larger raise and for U.P.S. to convert more part-time jobs into full-time ones.
Concerned about economic damage from the strike, business leaders from around the country stepped up their calls for President Clinton to pressure the two sides to reach a settlement so that the 185,000 striking drivers, sorters and loaders could return to work.
Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said in an interview: "It's not an emergency yet, but the fact of the matter is if this thing drags on for more than a week or two, it becomes a major problem for the economy. Thus it is essential for the White House and Labor Department to use their good offices to insist that both sides stay at the bargaining table until they resolve their differences."
On Wednesday, the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Retail Federation sent letters to Mr. Clinton, urging him to push harder to end the strike.
White House officials say the President has encouraged the two sides to talk. But Mr. Clinton said at his news conference on Wednesday that he would not seek an injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act to stop the strike. U.P.S. has called on the President to seek such an injunction from the courts and has urged its customers to make similar appeals.
The strike is already taking its toll on both sides. Some business analysts estimate that U.P.S. is losing at least $50 million a day from the strike, based on an acknowledgment by the company that a one-day teamsters walkout in 1994 cost it $50 million. In addition, U.P.S. executives say they are worried that if the strike drags on, they may lose a permanent market share to the United States Postal Service or Federal Express because regular customers might decide to stay with them.
While many union members treat the first few days of a strike as a festive occasion, they quickly start to feel the financial bite of not receiving a paycheck. Making matters worse for the teamsters, its strike fund is nearly depleted, and that is expected to hamper the union's ability to pay $55 in weekly strike benefits to 185,000 strikers. That would come to more than $10 million a week.
But Steven Trossman, a union spokesman, said: "This strike is not going to be decided by the finances of the teamsters. It will be decided on the issues."

HEADLINE: Art in Review

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:

Sculpture
James Graham & Sons
1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street
Manhattan
Through Aug. 29
This group show of 19 small sculptures captures, for better or worse, a mood in contemporary art, which involves a certain goofball, what-the-heck attitude that might be called slacker surrealism. Materials are cheap and offhand, but they are often put together with an obsessive attention to detail. The subjects are obsessive, too: they involve odd scenarios or themes that the artist has latched onto, and whether the audience cares about the subject seems not to be the artist's prime concern.
In other words, the works tend to be contentedly obscure and not ingratiating, in the sense that they don't aim for traditional beauty. But they can somehow be visually catchy anyway, and the tenor is mostly wry and unpretentious. 
 In this show, one should just ignore the installations of rows of paper cups, bottled water and toilet paper, which are as ridiculous as they sound. Instead, take a look at Jill Levine's octopus-like abstraction gaudily painted with scenes from Indian movies and art, which makes the work evoke a multilimbed Hindu goddess. Helga Natz has constructed a squarish sculpture out of copper and wax. Elegant, it is the size of a slender cake, bowed in the middle. The effect is an illusion of recession and elongation, as if the square were a rectangle. From Michael Ashkin comes a miniature tableau, a fraction of the size of the one he had in the recent Whitney Biennial and better: it shows a truck, no bigger than the eraser on the end of a pencil, mired in a pool of greenish muck beside a rocky promontory, which has an oil tank on it.
Mr. Ashkin's bleak, featureless landscape captures roughly what Terrence Malick's "Badlands" evoked on the big screen. And Michael Gonzalez has constructed a modernist homage out of interlocking aluminum shaft collars, like a necklace of thick metal rings knotted into a mound.
It's different from Bill Byers's pseudo-modernist sculpture, a striped volute made of fake fur and Astroturf whose title is the work's punch line: "Deep in the Heart of Suburbia." MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Sleepless And Worried For a Family

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
NOON games come up fast after night games. Bobby Valentine had no sleep at all, and it had little to do with runs or hits or errors.
"I was doing stuff with Carl and his family," was all Valentine would say about his sleeplessness. 
 The Mets not only had Wednesday night's loss on their minds, they also knew that Carl Everett, one of their teammates, was not available yesterday because of trouble within his family. On Wednesday night, at Shea Stadium, one of Everett's two daughters and his son were taken into protective custody after somebody thought there were bruises on the girl. The action cast a pall over the family and, in consequence, over the team.
Last evening, after investigating, the police said they would not place charges and a police official said the explanation by Everett and his wife would be accepted. By that time, there had been a tense 24-hour period for all concerned.
Because this seems to be very much a team -- in an industry and a free-agency economy that does not encourage togetherness - the Mets, in their silence, showed concern for Everett and his family.
"There is not a bad guy on this team," Butch Huskey said, talking about the chemistry that has helped make the Mets a team on the rise.
Everett may be back in uniform tonight when the Mets begin a four-game series with Houston, but he was not around yesterday when the Mets blasted Colorado, 12-4.
Like most teams these days, the Mets provide a family room where children of the players can romp before and during and after a game. The Mets' room is off a dark corridor on the ground floor, midway between the bullpen, with its tiny vegetable patch, and the Met clubhouse.
"Please Open Door Carefully - Children at Play," says a sign on the family-room door. Inside there are brightly-colored plastic chairs and stools and toys. After yesterday's game, dozens of adults and children milled around happily and noisily, waiting for the players to shower and dress. A security guard at the door said, rather forcefully, that he was in charge of the room.
On Wednesday evening, somebody in that room had reported the possibility of bruises to a club official, who felt enough concern to contact the city child welfare organization, and police officers were called. The two children were temporarily placed in a foster home.
The Mets were making no detailed comment yesterday as Everett and his wife spoke with authorities, but Valentine had cared enough to be available overnight. This came after Tuesday night, when Pete Harnisch made an emotional return after discovering he was suffering from depression in April.
"It's part of the experience," Valentine said yesterday, making a little joke that when he was young and impetuous at Texas, the crises were of his own making.
These are things they don't teach in managing school. Actually, there is no such thing as managing school, no 24-credit degree, no license to hang on the wall. Suddenly, a manager is expected to know something about depression, or child-welfare regulations.
"It's challenging," Valentine said.
The noon game after a night game was an attempt to give that old-fashioned baseball experience to children arriving on yellow day-camp buses. When they made out the schedule, how did the geniuses at Baseball Central know that yesterday would turn up sunny and dry and cool, with gorgeous fluffy clouds floating across?
The Mets were only slightly shook from making only four hits off "what was that guy's name?" as Edgardo Alfonzo benignly referred to John Thomson of Colorado, the Wednesday night winner.
Valentine was not using five regulars yesterday. Bernard Gilkey was not in uniform because of a fever. John Olerud and Todd Hundley and Rey Ordonez were being rested. And Carl Everett was coping with his family crisis. Yet the Mets pounded 16 hits and showed that they will probably not fade any too easily in this pleasant little season they are having.
"It would take somebody smarter than me to explain them," Valentine said. "I'm with 'em. I was with one of their teammates last night."
Plodding along on "a coffee-adrenaline rush," the manager seemed mildly proud of the turnaround victory. His weary eyes displayed concern and respect for the Everett family. Last night all could sleep a bit easier.

Mishaps Continue Aboard The Russian Space Station
The epic woes of the Mir deepened when the system guiding the spaceship carrying a relief crew sent to repair the damaged space station failed to operate properly. The spacecraft docked successfully, but only after the crew was forced to bring it in manually. A1 

Israel and Palestine Greet Plan
Both the Israelis and the Palestinians said they welcomed a new American initiative, unveiled by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright on Wednesday, aimed at pushing the two sides more swiftly toward peace. But they also presented rival views of priorities under the plan. The Israelis said the top aim should be persuading the Palestinians to crack down on Islamic militants, while the Palestinians want the United States to persuade Israel to ease up on pressure tactics. A7

An official from the National Transportation Safety Board said preliminary analyses of the cockpit voice recorder of the Korean Air jetliner that crashed in Guam indicated that the pilots were unaware of any mechanical problems or on-board emergencies. The new Congo Government asked the Swiss to expand their search for money and other assets that may have been embezzled out of the country by former dictator Mobutu Sese Seko and his top aides and hidden in Switzerland. (The New York Times)
 
Argentines Honor Saint
More than a million Argentines passed through the St. Cateyano Sanctuary in the outskirts of Buenos Aires on the anniversary of the saint's death. Church officials said the homage to the patron saint of bread and work showcases the relevancy of Roman Catholicism in Argentina. But critics of President Carlos Saul Menem's Government said the large turnout instead shows how desperate Argentines have become after suffering years of record unemployment. A4
 
Boundary Dispute Is Renewed
A long-simmering boundary dispute over the petroleum-rich straits and gulf that separate Trinidad and Venezuela is flaring again. For decades, each country has accused fishermen from the other of illegally entering its waters, but generally tolerated such abuses. But with both countries eager to expand their reserves and exports of oil and gas, they have been taking a much harder line. A4
 
Cambodian King Backs Leader
King Norodom Sihanouk sent a message from Beijing allowing the acting head of state to replace his son, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, as co-prime minister, effectively endorsing last month's coup by rival co-prime minister Hun Sen. Army units loyal to Hun Sen, meanwhile, were deployed near the Thai border for a new offensive against opposition troops controlling the zone. (AP)

As Northeastern states suffer through one of the worst smog seasons of the decade, most state governments in the region are about to petition the Environmental Protection Agency to crack down on Midwestern utilities, where much of the pollution originates. A1

Senator Richard G. Lugar upped the stakes in the battle over William F. Weld's nomination as Ambassador to Mexico, threatening to make trouble for Senator Jesse Helms's tobacco interests if Mr. Helms did not call a committee hearing on the nomination. A1

Scientists, in a major medical advance, have discovered what causes brain cells to die in people with Huntington's disease and six related disorders. In each case, they said, an insoluble ball of protein forms in the cell nucleus and kills it. A1

A small cattle-breeding company in Wisconsin has developed a highly efficient cloning method and has used it to make genetic replicas of more than 10 adult Holstein cows, its research director said. A10

The space shuttle Discovery and a crew of six astronauts blasted off on a mission to deploy a scientific satellite that tracks atmospheric pollution and to test a new kind of robotic arm that one day might aid experiments on the international space station. A25

An internal investigation by the C.I.A. has found that the release of hundreds of intelligence reports on the Pentagon's Internet site for veterans of the Persian Gulf War did "serious damage to intelligence sources and methods," a Congressional report says. A15

A cargo plane crashed during takeoff near Miami International Airport, killing at least three people but narrowly averting a potentially higher death toll in the busy commercial area of small warehouses and businesses where it fell. Foreign Phone Subsidies Cut
The Federal Communications Commission issued tough new rules to cut the $5.4 billion that American telephone companies pay to foreign carriers to complete their calls. The move could sharply reduce the cost of calling from the United States to many places overseas. The rules, which will be phased in gradually, are intended to jump-start competition in global telecommunications and staunch the flow of dollars from American to foreign carriers. But they may have their biggest impact on the average customer's phone bill.

HEADLINE: Strike Points to Inequality in 2-Tier Job Market

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
In 1982, when the International Brotherhood of Teamsters first agreed to a lower pay scale for part-time workers at United Parcel Service, recently hired part-timers earned $9 an hour, or just $4 less than a full-timer with the same tenure. Today, the part-timers, mostly people who sort packages, still earn $9 an hour while full-timers, mainly the men and women in brown who drive U.P.S. delivery trucks, earn nearly $20.
That sort of eye-catching shift helps to explain why the strike of 185,000 U.P.S. workers, which began on Monday, is a billboard reminder of how far the country has moved toward two tiers of jobs, one with much higher pay and more benefits than the other. Part-timers, temporary workers and contract workers populate much of the lower tier. 
 "This strike is a consciousness-raising event," said Daniel Yankelovich, chairman of DYG Inc., a public opinion polling firm. "What so often happens is that an event like this suddenly and unexpectedly focuses attention on something that is on people's minds and makes their concerns more of a political issue."
The U.P.S. contract negotiations focus naturally on issues like how much to grant in raises, whether to narrow the pay gap between part-timers and full-timers and whether to convert some of the part-time jobs into higher-paying full-time jobs.
But from the struggle over these issues, a broader theme is emerging: whether it is possible, not only at U.P.S. but nationally, to narrow the spread in wages, benefits and job status that has developed since the 1960's. Should part-timers, even if they choose that status to meet their own needs, be paid closer to the full-time wage rate?
The dividing line between the two tiers of wage-earners first showed itself in the early 1970's. For the decade leading up to 1973, nearly everyone's income, whether a worker was earning $200 a week or $1,000, grew by about 25 percent after adjustment for inflation.
Over the next 22 years, until 1995, however, the weekly wages at the low end fell by 22 percent, and for workers in the middle, earning about $500, wages decreased by 10 percent. Meanwhile, skilled white- and blue-collar workers earning about $1,000 a week saw their wages grow by 10 percent to about $1,100 in 1995.
The inequality has widened over the past two years, but at a slower pace, said Peter Gottschalk, a Boston University labor economist who calculates this data from Labor Department statistics. Still, Mr. Gottschalk added, "The strong economy of the past two years has not yet reversed the trend."
The U.P.S. work force roughly mirrors what has happened to workers everywhere. At many companies, an upper tier of full-time "core" workers enjoys the best combination of pay, benefits, hours and job security that a company can offer. Below them is a second tier of less valued part-time, temporary and contract workers who, in addition to being less expensive, can be discharged more easily, giving corporate managers the flexibility that they say is essential to compete in an increasingly global economy.
At U.P.S. the second tier is mostly part-timers, who sort packages and load trucks and planes.
"If we weren't operating with part-timers and paying them the wages that we are paying today, we would be out of business," said Kenneth Sternad, a U.P.S. spokesman.
Mr. Sternad and other U.P.S. executives note that competitors -- Federal Express, for example -- also use part-timers, mainly to sort and load packages on trucks and planes. As nonunion workers, they earn less than workers at U.P.S., and they lack a company-paid health policy, which U.P.S. provides to its part-timers.
U.P.S. executives argue that full-time delivery truck drivers, earning $19.95 an hour, are more valuable to the company than the part-timers. The drivers are the company's direct contact with its customers, and they have to be skilled in the use of hand-held computers.
But the teamsters say that U.P.S. -- and by extension, the nation -- has gone too far in creating lower-tier work. Most of the new U.P.S. jobs since 1993, when the last contract was signed, have been part-time, and that category now represents 60 percent of the teamster jobs at U.P.S., up from 54 percent in 1993 and 42 percent in 1986.
"We recognize that most part-timers can't and won't ever become full-timers," said Paul Boldin, director of research for the teamsters. "So we need to raise the part-time wage."
Apart from pushing to convert 10,000 part-time jobs into higher-paying full-time positions, the teamsters want part-time wages, now $8 to $11, raised by $3.67 an hour over four years. The company is offering $2.50 over five years.
While the gulf at U.P.S. is between full-timers and part-timers, with their unequal pay, elsewhere the inequality shows up in the conditions that separate full-time regular employees from the temporary and contract workers that companies are now employing more often. The latter employees might work a full week rather than part-time hours. Some get even the same hourly wages as regular employees. But they almost always lack health insurance, vacation pay and sick pay.
But the profusion of arrangements is often hard to quantify, and that clouds the debate, even with the stimulus of the U.P.S. strike.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics at the Labor Department, for example, notes that the median wage of full-time workers is $9.36 an hour, compared with $6.01 for part-time workers, a gap that has persisted for years. But Marvin Kosters, director of economic policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute, concluded in a study that when allowances are made for skills and education, the gap essentially disappears.
Similarly, the bureau notes that the number of part-time workers rose to 19.5 percent of the work force in 1994 from 14 percent in 1968. The percentage has since dropped slightly, but Susan Houseman, a labor economist at the Upjohn Institute, argues that such data fail to account for the growing number of Americans who hold two part-time jobs, or a full-time and a part-time job. They appear instead in the official count as full-timers, working a total of more than 35 hours a week.
Ms. Houseman's survey of 550 companies last summer showed a growing use of part-time workers who cost less than full-timers.
"U.P.S. is by no means an isolated example," she said, "and that makes the strike a platform to debate the broader issues."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 12, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about the United Parcel Service strike misstated the benefits policy of Federal Express. Part-time workers there become eligible for company-paid health insurance after 90 days on the job.

HEADLINE: As Slopes Warm Up, the Sound of Festivals

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: ASPEN, Colo.

 BODY:
From a musical kernel planted here half a century ago, summer arts festivals have taken root in the Rockies, spreading this year like alpine wildflowers to 13 Colorado ski towns.
In Telluride, once a backwater silver-mining town, there is a jazz festival, a blues festival, a bluegrass festival, a theater festival, a dance festival and two film festivals. Choking on culture, townspeople recently rebelled and created a guaranteed festival-free weekend in late July: The Nothing Festival. 
 "There are now more summer music festivals in Colorado than in any other state in America," said Robert Harth, president of the Aspen Music Festival, the festival that pioneered music in the Rocky Mountains in 1949.
This summer Vail is host to two orchestras, the Rochester Philharmonic and the Detroit Symphony. Telluride is the summer home of the Joffrey Ballet. Breckenridge is host for the National Repertory Orchestra. In tiny Crested Butte, the demand for music is so strong that the town is supporting two chamber festivals this summer.
The marriage of music and mountains is so successful that the ski towns are witnessing the emergence of increasingly stable, year-round economies.
The impact is most visible in Aspen, where the Music Festival offers 150 events during a 63-day season. Beyond this marathon, the Aspen/ Snowmass Council for the Arts offers events by 23 other member groups. Art show openings are almost a nightly affair this summer as the number of galleries around Aspen has grown to 48.
With 57 percent of arts attendees coming from out of state, arts spending pumps $60 million into the Aspen economy every summer, according to a 1995 study by the University of Colorado's Business Research Division.
In a shift, August has been Aspen's most popular tourist month for the last two years, recording average hotel occupancy rates of 85 percent. Before 1995, March was the busiest month.
"I wouldn't come here without the stimulation," Barbara Rentschler, a retired New Jersey developer who now lives in Florida, said recently before the start of an Aspen Festival Orchestra concert. "I can't run up and down the mountains every day."
Attitudes like this have prompted the arts explosion. In Vail, Bravo! the Colorado Vail Valley Music Festival added the Rochester Orchestra this summer to its traditional schedule of concerts by the Detroit Orchestra. This month principal dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet, the Stuttgart Ballet and American Ballet Theater are performing as part of a new annual summer series, the Vail International Dance Festival.
"The demand for performances and the growth of the whole music phenomenon was strong enough to justify having the two orchestras here this summer," said Ross Boyle, chairman of the Vail Valley Marketing Board, a promotional group.
A decade ago, the gap between winter and summer sales tax revenues in Vail was 50 percent. By last year, Mr. Boyle said, it had narrowed to 19 percent. "With the galleries, the music and the dance," he added, "I would guess that the arts contribute at least one quarter of the draw we have in the summer."
The trend is evident across the Rockies. Jackson Hole, Wyo., has a summerlong series, the Grand Teton Music Festival. Big Sky, Mont., has an arts festival that runs the gamut from cowboy poetry to chamber music. Park City, Utah, has an almost daily summer calendar of arts events including "Music in the Mountains" concerts by the Utah Symphony and dance and chamber music by the Institute at Deer Valley.
"The most successful festivals come from the local community and not from a bunch of promoters going out and grafting something totally unrelated onto the community," said Myles Rademan, spokesman for Park City. Aspen and Park City started with strong artistic communities, added Mr. Rademan, who often works as a consultant with mountain resort towns on growth issues.
In Colorado summer festivals are backed by a strong winter arts reservoir in metropolitan Denver, home to half of the state's four million residents. Contradicting Denver's national image as a sports town, more tickets were sold in 1995 for cultural events -- seven million -- than to major league sports events -- five million. Last winter ticket sales topped a million at the Denver Center for the Performing Arts, a first in the 25-year history of that multistage complex.
In Aspen, where the music festival followed a formula set by Tanglewood in the late 1930's, residents now grumble that other ski towns are merely trying to emulate their success.
"The ski towns are copying what Aspen began almost 50 years ago," W. Harold Laster, dean of the Aspen Music School, said during an intermission at the 1,700-seat tent here. "But they are not doing it because of Aspen's humanistic ideals, of body, mind and spirit. They are doing it to make money in the summer."
Walter Paepcke, a Chicago industrialist, developed skiing here as a way to achieve an idealized community, one where residents and visitors would become well-rounded in art, music, philosophy and athletics. As a living legacy of this vision, the Music Festival is home every summer to about 1,000 music students and teachers. Aspen is believed to have the largest summer music school in the nation.
Because of strong community support, about half of the students live with local families, and three-quarters receive financial aid. Six hundred volunteers give thousands of hours. Drawing on a worldwide alumni network, the Aspen Music School this summer has attracted students from 47 states and 43 countries.
"Aspen is bigger, and there are more opportunies to play," said Marcos Max Valls Martin, a trombonist from Brazil who studied last summer at the music school at Tanglewood, in Lenox, Mass.
In a town where about one out of every seven summer residents is a classical musician, there are concerts in churches, in the newly restored Wheeler Opera House, on the top of Ajax Mountain and on the town's pedestrian mall.
Not satisfied with almost three musical events a day, students put on 50 additional informal performances during the summer. Reflecting this musical energy, a student orchestra played all of Beethoven's nine symphonies in a marathon sitting last summer.
In Aspen, where 17 different arts events are scheduled for the first week of August, cultural offerings now spill into the winter season. Four years ago the Music Festival inaugurated a year-round hall, the 500-seat Joan and Irving Harris Concert Hall.
Aspen's new concert hall did not pass unnoticed by its archrivals in the Vail valley. Next February, Beaver Creek, part of Vail Resorts, is to inaugurate its own 525-seat, year-round theater.
"The number of skiers is flat," Mr. Harth, the Aspen Music Festival president, said, referring to the industry's stagnation. Noting that Harris Hall now presents 30 concerts in the winter, he added: "The arts events are one of the advantages that Aspen has in selling itself as grandmother-friendly. Not everybody surfs, but a lot of families go to Hawaii."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Students performing in the Aspen Music Festival, which is now the nation's biggest summer music school. (Bob Krueger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Casting Call for Candidates

 BODY:
State Comptroller Carl McCall's announcement that he will not run against Gov. George Pataki in 1998 is troubling. Mr. McCall had been regarded as Mr. Pataki's toughest potential challenger ever since Representative Charles Schumer, the previous toughest potential challenger, backed out of the race. Someone has to run against Mr. Pataki. Mr. McCall has one of the strongest political resumes in the state. His analyses of the precarious economics of Mr. Pataki's budgets are compelling, and a McCall-Pataki campaign might have provided a useful education for the voters.
Mr. McCall says he has decided he can best serve the people of New York as the Comptroller, but this is of course politics-speak. There is no politician walking who truly believes that while running the state is all well and good as far as it goes, he can be a bigger help by overseeing the auditors. Mr. McCall has been very vocal in his predictions that Mr. Pataki's new budget is a short-term crowd-pleaser that will turn into a long-term economic disaster. His statement of non-candidacy this week is an acknowledgment that the long term will not be here before November 1998. 
 There are still plenty of major-league or at least triple-A Democrats who might take on Mr. Pataki next year. But Mr. McCall's retreat does not bode well. A year and a half is a very long time in advance of the election to implicitly declare an incumbent unbeatable, especially in a state that has trouble getting a budget finished four months after the deadline. If the great retreat from the governor's race continues, voters know what they can expect. We have seen the future, and it is Pierre Rinfret. If the Democrats wind up scrambling through old Rolodexes for any candidate who can afford to pay his own expenses, they may wind up learning the same sad truth the Republicans did when they nominated Mr. Rinfret in 1990. The Governor at the time, Mario Cuomo, turned out to be weaker than anyone had imagined, and only the embarrassing haplessness of the Rinfret campaign assured him victory.
There is a problem here that goes far beyond Mr. McCall's very reasonable desire for a safe political berth. The modern political process offers no rewards to the man or woman who agrees to make a difficult race for the good of the party. The promising campaigner who makes a game effort against a tough incumbent is not regarded as "seasoned" but simply as a loser. The party may owe him or her a lot. But just try to collect it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Grain and Soybean Prices Up On Mixed Outlook for Rain

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly higher yesterday amid conflicting weather forecasts for parched Midwestern growing areas.
Weather has been driving the soybean and corn markets this week at the Chicago Board of Trade. 
 "Beans need rain, and there is some rain in the forecast, but there are a lot of variations," said Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst for Prudential Securities Inc. in New York. "If we don't have rain, prices will be sharply higher Monday. If we do, they'll be sharply lower."
Jerry Gidel, grains analyst in Chicago for Dean Witter, said, "Wheat was strengthened on news that Canada reduced its crop size, and Egypt is in for between 300,000 and 500,000 metric tons of our red winter wheat."
New-crop soybeans for November delivery rose 6.5 cents while the old crop, for August delivery, fell 8 cents.
Ms. Frick said, "The old crop was under pressure from farmers moving old-crop beans to take advantage of higher prices, almost a dollar better than the new crop."
November soybeans rose 9 cents, to $6.375 a bushel; December corn was up 4 cents, to $2.57 a bushel; December oats were unchanged at $1.6275 a bushel; September wheat rose 4 cents, to $3.6725 a bushel.
On other commodity markets, precious metals rose while livestock prices were sharply lower, except for live cattle.
In precious metals trading, gold took advantage of the decline in the stock market, and platinum was strengthened by short supplies.
"Supply tightness is the reason for a rally today after a flat day yesterday and a down day the previous day," Aaron Murphy, senior economist for Platinum Guild International, said yesterday.
October platinum was $443.70 an ounce, up $11.10; December gold was at $330.40 an ounce, up $4.60, and September silver was unchanged at $4.37 an ounce.
Live cattle futures prices were higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, while feeder cattle, pork bellies and lean hogs all declined.
October live cattle rose 0.72 cent, to 70.20 cents a pound; August feeder cattle fell 0.20 cent, to 80.17 cents a pound; October lean hogs dropped 0.47 cent, to 72.50 cents a pound, and August pork bellies fell 2.37 cents, to 82.52 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: 80,000 Children Dying in North Korea, U.N. Says

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 8

 BODY:
The executive director of Unicef said today that about 80,000 children in North Korea were in immediate danger of dying from hunger and disease and at least 800,000 more were suffering malnutrition to a serious but lesser degree.
"It's a crisis where people are dying and are going to die," the director, Carol Bellamy, said at a news conference. Ms. Bellamy returned on Thursday from a visit to North Korea. There, she and other international aid officials pooled information from many parts of the isolated country. 
 Ms. Bellamy said the North Korean Government had changed its attitude in the last three to six months and was allowing agencies to work in more areas.
Only the northeast corner of the country is still off-limits to foreigners, she said. Everywhere aid officials go, they see demonstrations of North Korea's ramshackle state economy failing to cope with multiple crises.
"The pantries are bare," said Ms. Bellamy, a former director of the Peace Corps. "Hospital medicine cabinets are empty. And the results could be catastrophic if these shortages are not eased by winter.
"We are seeing children up to the age of 15 who are severely malnourished and in danger of dying. Starvation hits babies first; older children have more resistance. These children have been chronically short of food all year."
Ms. Bellamy said fewer children had been coming to schools where relief officials worked. In Government nurseries or orphanages, many children are "very, very sick," she said.
While relief agencies are not able to estimate the number of North Koreans who may have already died, officials are forming a broader picture of the disaster facing the country of 24 million people after two years of floods and two months of severe drought. But aid workers are beginning to accumulate anecdotal evidence of deaths as they distribute food and medicine.
Ms. Bellamy said today that at a state nursery, she had met children whose parents had recently died, at least in one case of diarrhea, which malnourished people have no strength to resist. Another child, who had lost both parents, was turned over to the state by a grandmother who could no longer feed her.
Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, has appealed for $14.3 million to buy emergency supplies for North Korea, particularly medicines and milk fortified with vitamins and minerals. Since April the organization has flown 70 tons of fortified milk, medicine and feeding equipment to North Korea for use in 92 hospitals and orphanages.
Most of the contributions have come from European countries. Ms. Bellamy said today that she was asking the United States to contribute as well, so that more milk can be airlifted.
On Monday the World Food Program, Unicef and Save the Children will begin a study intended to determine North Korea's needs and the condition of its people.
