HEADLINE: First Battle for the New Congress in Mexico: Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Mexico's new Congress will not be formally seated in the labyrinthine Palace of St. Lazarus until Sept. 1, but the first order of business is already clear. It is a familiar fight for any democracy: what to do about campaign promises to lower taxes.
In the election last month, the governing party lost its majority in Congress for the first time in 68 years. Now, Mexicans are learning that promising to cut taxes, as opposition parties did in the campaign, was easier than actually doing so, just as proclaiming a democracy may turn out to be far less difficult than making it work. 
 The tug-of-war between the Government and Congress has already started.
At stake in the debate over taxes is Mexico's economic recovery, a strict Government regimen of taxes and limited spending that helped bring the country back from the brink of economic disaster in 1995.
Mexican and United States officials insist that the recovery plan, backed by Washington, would be gored by the kind of tax cuts and economic tinkering -- including an overhaul of the North American Free Trade Agreement -- promised by candidates from four opposition parties.
In the past, opposition legislators routinely voted against tax increases, even though Mexicans are not heavily taxed and increases are seen as necessary to support education, health and other services that the opposition supports. Now many of them, facing new tests as they assume a share of real power, will be caught between their advocacy of greater social spending and the siren call of campaign promises to cut taxes.
Though they offered little in the way of economic justification for a tax cut, the opposition candidates connected with voters. Now the four parties together outnumber the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, in the 500-seat lower house of Congress.
If they overcome their wide differences, will form a unified opposition majority. But of the two largest opposition parties, one is to the left of the PRI and one is to its right.
The opening days of the new Congress will also test the degree to which the election on July 6 really was the historic breakthrough that has been claimed.
After so many years of one-party rule, can power really be shared by a dominant President and a legislature that until now has been little more than a sounding board controlled by the President's party?
It will probably not be easy. Last week, President Ernesto Zedillo addressed Mexican business leaders who had grown skittish over continued soundings about tax cuts. He unequivocally declared that there would be no change in Mexico's economic course.
The next day, a Congressman-elect who is leader of an opposition party's legislative caucus told Mr. Zedillo to reread the Constitution.
"I told him that he should read the Constitution again so that he will know what he's facing," said Porfirio Munoz Ledo, who will be the leader for the Party of the Democratic Revolution, or P.R.D., in the new Congress. "The economic policy of Mexico is not decided by him alone. It is a responsibility that is shared with the Congress."
The governing party's dominance of Congress until now has been so complete that there is no legal provision for selecting the equivalent of the Speaker of the House in circumstances when no party has an absolute majority.
Already there is intense jockeying for leadership positions and posturing for the moral high ground in the new legislature. Because of Mexico's prohibition against consecutive terms in any political office, there is no seniority system and every legislator is considered a freshman, although some have had experience in local legislatures.
In going after the long-governing PRI, opposition candidates vowed to cut the immensely unpopular value added tax on most goods, which was raised to 15 percent from 10 percent in early 1995. At that time, even though not one opposition member of the lower house voted for the tax increase, the PRI had enough votes on its own to pass it.
In the new Congress, the PRI will still have more seats than any other party, but it will not have a majority. While the directly elected members are already selected, the electoral authorities must still determine the final allocation of seats based on the proportion of the overall vote captured by each party. The results are not expected to change significantly.
As it now stands, the PRI has 239 of the 500 seats, the P.R.D., 125, the National Action Party, or PAN, 122, and two smaller parties a total of 14 that now become enormously important because of their ability to swing a vote. Legislation is passed by a majority vote of those members who are present.
Opposition leaders say the new Congress will not limit itself to reducing taxes. They want to revise Nafta and rework Mexico's entire economic course.
The approval of both houses of Congress is needed to pass the Government's revenue package, and the PRI still holds a majority in the Senate. But the lower house alone approves the budget.
Since Mexico devalued its currency in 1994, the country has endured successive austerity budgets. While such measures are perceived in Government and financial circles as having helped the economy recover, the Mexican people feel choked by them.
For the United States, which backed President Zedillo's recovery plan and put up $20 billion in loans to support Mexico, a politically motivated rush to rewrite Mexico's economic plans would be a disaster.
Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, who was instrumental in the Mexico rescue plan, met with opposition leaders in Mexico City this week. He said the leaders of all parties had expressed "a willingness to work things out."
"Clearly, the next few months will be an important test for Mexico's democratic institutions," Mr. Summers said at a briefing with reporters. But "it would be a serious error," he said, "to suppose that somehow multi-partisanship is inherently more risky or inherently more divisive" than one-party rule.
While he admitted that "gridlock is possible," along the lines of the budget impasse that nearly shut down the United States Government last year, he said policies with multiparty support tended to be healthier for a society than those rammed through by just one party.
During the recent campaign, the opposition parties of the left, center and right all formally vowed to undo the value added tax.
Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz Martinez has said that reducing the value added tax rate to 10 percent from the current 15 percent would cost Mexico $3.2 billion a year that the opposition parties have not explained how they would make up.
"They are accusing us of voodoo economics, but it is not so," Mr. Munoz Ledo said. He said the Mexican people had suffered enough from Governments run by economists, like Mr. Zedillo, who had never before held public office. Now, he said, they demand an economic policy that meets their needs.
"The commitment of the opposition parties to lower the value added tax is a formal promise," Mr. Munoz Ledo said. "It would be an enormous affront to the people if we didn't do it."
There is no way to tell whether the opposition parties will vote in unison against the PRI. Alfonso Zarate, a Mexican political analyst, says even a weakened PRI still has the resources to defend its interests. Rather than reform, the new congressional alignment could bring a return to corrupt past practices, he said.
"The PRI is going to achieve its majorities by buying votes, delivering privileges, giving concessions, paying for trips," Mr. Zarate said. "The new alignment of forces will force the PRI to do so."
The lower house will have about a month to debate the President's budget proposal before voting. Since Mexico's Congress cannot pass continuing resolutions the way the one in Washington did in last year's impasse, it cannot prevent a shutdown should negotiations become deadlocked.
"If there is no budget by Dec. 31," Finance Minister Ortiz said, "we can just turn off the lights and go home."
In the past, party discipline was absolute and members strayed from the party line at their political peril. But to avoid impasse in the new Congress, alliances will be common, although it is not at all clear who the natural allies are.
The head of the PRI caucus in the new Congress, Arturo Nunez Jimenez, says the ideological distance between the PRI and the nationalist P.R.D. on many issues is less than between the conservative PAN and the P.R.D. He expects alliances between the PRI and other parties to alternate depending on the vote.
"It is possible that for some issues there might be a certain combination of votes and for others a different one," Mr. Nunez said. "But we're not talking about just one majority and one opposition. We're talking about many alliances, and forming them is part of the legislative work we face."
An influential congressman from the PAN, Santiago Creel, said the first few months of the new Congress would show how successfully power was being shared in Mexico.
"Something that can give you a signal that things have changed is that we are able to reopen the Conasupo investigation," he said, referring to a congressional investigation into corruption at a Government commodities distribution agency that was shut down by the PRI last year when too many questions were being asked.
Mr. Creel said there would be other congressional investigations as well: into suspect privatizations of banks, railroads and highways; of a 1995 massacre of peasants by the police in Guerrero State that exonerated the PRI Governor despite indications that he might have been involved; into the manner in which members of Mr. Zedillo's Government carry out their duties as servants of the Mexican people.
"This does not mean it it be a Congress of confrontation, or that we want to start a holy war against the executive branch," Mr. Creel said. "It simply will be a moment in which the basic mechanisms of a democratic system begin to function."

HEADLINE: Helicopter Company Loses Bankruptcy Plea, Clearing Way for City Eviction Move

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
A Federal bankruptcy judge in Brooklyn dismissed a bankruptcy filing from Island Helicopters yesterday, giving the city the right to move to evict the company from the East 34th Street Heliport, which the city owns.
The company, which also operates as National Helicopter, has been battling the city for years. As the heliport's major tenant since 1973, the company takes tourists on sightseeing flights over the Statue of Liberty, Central Park and Yankee Stadium, and is responsible for nearly 40 percent of the 400 takeoffs and landings at the city's four heliports every day. 
 It has continued operating despite the expiration of its lease and a continuing battle with the city over back rent and what the city maintained was Island Helicopters' failure to prepare required environmental reports.
Yesterday's decision, by Judge Jerome Feller, said that the city had served an eviction notice on Island Helicopters on April 29. The company went to Federal court on May 1, seeking an injunction to prevent the eviction, but the request was turned down. On May 2, Island Helicopters made a second attempt to avoid being thrown out of the heliport, this time in State Supreme Court, but withdrew the action later that day and sought Federal bankruptcy protection instead, which automatically stopped the eviction process.
A bankruptcy declaration would have allowed Island Helicopters to continue operating while it came to new terms with creditors, including the city. Yesterday, Judge Feller dismissed the bankruptcy plea, saying it had been "filed in bad faith."
Judge Feller called the bankruptcy petition "little more than a desperate legal stratagem" intended mainly to "delay and obstruct the city" in its efforts to take control of the heliport. He said that in the dispute over payment of rent, the company had fallen $336,000 behind by 1989 but that it promised, in April 1993, to pay $226,000. By July 1993, the judge said, the city had questioned whether the company would make good on the agreement.
"The debtor has little else sustaining it" other than the heliport, Judge Feller wrote. He added that it was otherwise an "assetless corporation" that could not pay its bankruptcy lawyer's retainer.
After the ruling, Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, which is the heliport's landlord, said, "We're very pleased with the court's decision."
A lawyer for Island Helicopters, J. Stanley Shaw, did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
Several aircraft in the Island Helicopters fleet have been involved in accidents in recent years. One of the company's helicopters lost power and had to make an emergency landing in the East River in October 1993. Several months earlier, another Island Helicopters craft made an emergency landing in Central Park under similar circumstances.

HEADLINE: In Quitting, Scientists Say Beach Repair Is Foolhardy

 BODY:
Accusing the Army Corps of Engineers of ignoring Federal environmental law in a rush to begin a $60 million dune- and beach-rebuilding project on Fire Island, two biologists resigned their Government jobs yesterday in protest.
The biologists, staff members of the Fish and Wildlife Department's regional office on Long Island, said the Corps was withholding information about the project, which they said would damage natural systems, provide no proven protection against storms and cost more than $100 million over its 30-year life when maintenance costs were included. 
 "They are not informing the public about the magnitude of this project," said Robert G. Murray, who said he resigned in frustration over "Federal agencies' not following Federal law and breaking the public trust."
"To approve this project would irreparably harm Long Island's coastal environment," Mr. Murray, 30, of Center Moriches, N.Y., said.
The second biologist, David M. Edelstein, 39, of Islip, N.Y., said the Corps was downplaying the size of the project to avoid public scrutiny.
"This is an enormous project," he said. "It will rearrange the ecosystem of the entire South Shore of Long Island. The Army Corps should not be given this ecosystem to manage without first showing they understand it."
The New York district office of the Corps denied the biologists' charges and said a complete environmental study would be performed before the project begins. "I hate to giggle, but it is a little presumptuous to assume we are going ahead with anything," said Joseph R. Vietri, the deputy chief of planning for the New York district office. He said the project could not begin before 2000.
The project would dump nine million cubic yards of sand pumped from offshore along a 15-mile area of Fire Island to rebuild beaches and restore dunes damaged during severe storms in 1992 and 1993. Most of the work would be performed in summer communities from Kismet to Point O' Woods, the Corps said.
Mr. Vietri said the project would bolster the Fire Island barrier island as a first line of defense for the mainland against storms and storm surges.
Mr. Murray and Mr. Edelstein said there was no convincing proof that the project would protect the mainland. They said it would block natural events like wash-overs and breaches during storms that supplied ocean water to inland bays and increased biological diversity.
"There would be no damage you would see today or tomorrow," Mr. Edelstein said. "But it is a project designed to impede the natural flow of energy in and out of the ecosystem. If you impede it, there is a high risk of a major rupture later."
The biologists said the Army Corps was favoring the interests of property owners and an influential property owners' group, the Fire island Association.
The association's president, Gerard Stoddard, said that repairing beaches on Fire Island has enormous economic benefits for the public and inland areas, and he said his group was prepared to contribute as much as $4 million toward the work.
Mr. Murray said that neither he nor Mr. Edelstein was a member of any environmental group and that they had arranged a news conference yesterday in Mineola on their own. Mr. Murray said he was reluctant to voice his concerns publicly while still employed by the Fish and Wildlife Service. "I felt it would be risky," he said.
Mr. Murray had worked in the Fish and Wildlife Service Long Island office for five years, and Mr. Edelstein for two.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL 3-7
 
Rockets From Lebanon Strike Northern Israel
Tensions grew in Israel after rockets fired from Lebanon slammed into Qiryat Shemona, a town near the country's northern border. The attack came after a week of escalating attacks between Israeli forces and Hezbollah guerrillas. One Israeli woman was wounded and a synagogue was damaged by the rockets. 6 

Disbanding Bosnian Police
In a decision that diplomats said could be both helpful and dangerous, the American general in charge of NATO forces in Bosnia disclosed a plan to force paramilitary police forces to disband or to face being disbanded by NATO soldiers. Diplomats and human rights monitors said that paramilitary police were the most responsible for enforcing the will of nationalist hard-liners. 3
 
Strike Turns Violent in Kenya
A strike in Kenya called by advocates of constitutional reform turned violent as mobs beat a policeman to death, looted shops and broke windows in Nairobi. A rally in support of the strike turned bloody when a crowd of people recognized a plainclothes policeman and beat him to death. Western Governments and human rights groups have accused police of brutality in previous demonstrations. 3
 
South African Talks Stop
South Africa's second-largest black party said it would break off talks with the African National Congress on ending political violence in the province of Kwazulu-Natal. Testimony before a commission investigating apartheid-era atrocities linked the Inkatha Freedom Party to hit squads; angry leaders of the party demanded an investigation of the impartiality of the panel, which they called a creation of the African National Congress. 3
 
Pilot Error Cited in Guam Crash
United States officials in Guam said that newly gathered evidence points to pilot error, not mechanical failure, as the cause of the Korean Air jetliner crash. The National Transportation Safety Board said the pilots were in control of the plane and did not know they were flying too low. Officials said 225 people died in the crash and hundreds of their relatives have flown to Guam from Korea and are waiting anxiously, and sometimes angrily, for remains to be identified and returned to them. 4
 
Famine Worsens in North Korea
About 80,000 children in North Korea are in immediate danger of dying from hunger and disease and at least 800,000 more are suffering malnutrition, Carol Bellamy, executive director of Unicef, said. The famine is a result of two years of floods and two months of severe drought. 5
 
China Military Chief Visits U.S.
China's military chief visited Washington and received a 19-gun salute at the Pentagon from his counterpart, Gen. John Shalikashvili, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The Chinese official, Gen. Fu Quanyou, chief of staff of the People's Liberation Army, also met with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Defense Secretary William Cohen. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL 8-10
U.P.S. Strike Affecting Many Small Businesses
The strike by the United Parcel Service has hurt many smaller businesses around the country, especially those on tight schedules or margins. If problems for small businesses grow, they could mean serious problems for the nation's economy since they account for more than 50 percent of all jobs. 1
 
U.P.S. and the teamsters' union held their second straight day of intense talks aimed at ending the five-day-old walkout. But after a lack of major progress, union officials warned teamster locals nationwide to be prepared for a long strike. 9
 
Monsignor Ignites Controversy
Two weeks after a Dallas jury awarded a record $120 million in finding that the local Catholic diocese failed to stop a priest from sexually abusing parish boys, a former top church official who supervised the priest set off an uproar by suggesting the boys' parents were at least as much to blame as the church. 8
 
Mars Trip '100% Success'
NASA declared the month-old mission of the Mars Pathfinder "a 100 percent success" since the project's minimum goal was 30 days of full operation on Mars. The spacecraft has transmitted almost 10,000 pictures. Its roving companion Sojourner has traversed some 165 feet of Martian surface, closing in on a circumnavigation of the landing site. And both are still going strong after more than a month exploring the rocky flood plain of Ares Vallis. 10
 
Shuttle Projects Proceed
The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery tested a new five-foot robot arm intended for precision work on the future space station. A satellite released by the crew, meanwhile, began gathering data on Earth's ozone layer. 10
 
Party Denies Withholding Data
Roy Romer, the Democratic Party's national chairman, said there was "no intention to withhold or delay" the production of Democratic documents sought by the Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses and that a recent failure to do so was "an innocent mistake." 10
 
Diabetes Initiative Announced
President Clinton announced an effort to combat diabetes, a metabolic disease that afflicts millions of Americans. In a ceremony at the Georgetown University Medical Center, Mr. Clinton called attention to $2.1 billion in Federal spending over the next five years for diabetes treatment and research that is included in the newly signed balanced budget legislation. 10
 
Psoriasis Patients Warned
The Food and Drug Administration warned psoriasis patients to contact a doctor immediately if they are using a treatment called "Skin-Cap" because it secretly contains powerful steroids that can produce serious side effects. 9
 
NEW YORK/REGION 25-29
 
Local Phone Choices Grow As MCI Enters the Market
MCI began offering local residential telephone service in New York City and its nearby suburbs, becoming the first major competitor for Nynex's four million customers in the region. The move by MCI, the country's No. 2 long distance company, opens a new round in the fight for the metropolitan telephone market, a battle that consumer advocates hope will ultimately lead to lower phone bills, advanced communications services and more attention to customers. 1
 
Juvenile Facility for Shabazz
Malcolm Shabazz, the 12-year-old grandson of Malcolm X who set a fire that killed his grandmother, was sentenced to one of the few juvenile detention facilities in the nation that accepts arsonists, the Hillcrest Center in Lenox, Mass. 25
 
Protest Over Bus Access
More than a dozen handicapped demonstrators rolled their wheelchairs in front of a Greyhound bus and disrupted ticket sales for four hours at the Port Authority bus terminal in Manhattan to protest what they said was a lack of access to vehicles belonging to the largest interstate bus company in the country. The protesters sang "If we can't ride, nobody rides." 26
 
SPORTS 30-34
 
ARTS 11-19, 24
 
The Festivals of Colorado
Summer arts festivals have taken root in the Rockies, spreading this year like alpine wildflowers to 13 Colorado ski towns. In Telluride, for example, once a backwater silver-mining town, there is a jazz festival, a blues festival, a bluegrass festival, a theater festival, a dance festival and two film festivals. Choking on culture, townspeople recently rebelled and created a guaranteed festival-free weekend in late July: The Nothing Festival. 1
 
BUSINESS DAY 35-48
 
F.D.A. Loosens Ad Rules
The Food and Drug Administration issued new guidelines for prescription drug advertising on radio and television that it said would make the advertisements more useful to consumers. The guidelines, which have been under consideration for months, will allow drug manufacturers to describe the benefits of the drugs without providing long, detailed notices of the side effects. Instead, the F.D.A. said, the drug companies would only be required to include in the advertisements a "brief summary" of the major risks. The ads could include a toll-free number or an Internet address where consumers could get more details. 35
 
3 Markets Suffer Setbacks
Rallies in stock, bond and currency markets all came to an abrupt halt. The price of the 30-year bond plunged, pushing the yield up to 6.63 percent. Most of the stock market's major indexes fell 1.5 percent or more. And the dollar dropped as well: 3 percent against the Japanese yen and 1.1 percent against the German mark. Analysts had a hard time accounting for the size of the declines. The outlook for the stock market, interest rates and the dollar are all still generally positive. 35

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

United Parcel Strike Could Be Long, Union Says
Company and teamsters' union officials met for a second day of intense talks aimed at ending the five-day-old United Parcel Service walkout. But with no significant progress reported on a new contract, union officials warned locals nationwide to be prepared for a long strike. [Page 9.]
 
A mechanic in Iowa cannot get parts for car repairs. Pet fish are stranded at a Florida distributor. The United Parcel strike has straitjacketed many smaller businesses around the country. If problems for small businesses grow, they could mean serious problems for the nation's economy. [1.] 

MCI vs. Nynex in New York City
MCI began offering local residential telephone service in New York City and its nearby suburbs, becoming the first major rival for Nynex's four million customers in the region. Consumer advocates hope that the battle will lead to smaller phone bills, advanced communications services and more attention to customers. [1.]
 
Currency Trading Scheme
Schemes involving currency trading are on the rise, law enforcement officials say, and are replacing precious metals as the commodity of choice among investment frauds. Federal prosecutors and the Manhattan District Attorney's office are now investigating a Manhattan currency trading company, AEL Fund, which has closed with no sign of what happened to millions of investor dollars. [1.]
 
Bankruptcy Panel Faces Inquiry
The commission charged with recommending ways to revamp the nation's bankruptcy laws is examining whether a conference call among five of its members, led by a Federal appeals court judge, amounted to a secret meeting that may have violated Federal rules, according to commission documents. [36.]

Equisure Denies All
Equisure Inc., whose shares have been suspended from trading amid an investigation by the American Stock Exchange, outlined what it said were the exchange's suspicions and then said it "rejects these allegations and insinuations as patently absurd." [36.]
 
Stock Deal at Times Mirror
The Chandler family, which founded and controls Times Mirror, reached a deal with the company that will give the family more current income and diversify its investments, at the cost of cutting its stake in the company. The deal is expected to lead to an increase in per-share earnings. [36.]
 
Columbia/HCA Executive Resigns
The chief financial officer of Columbia/HCA Healthcare has resigned after just three weeks on the job. The departure of the executive, Robert Stearns, follows that of its founder and chief executive, Richard L. Scott. [36.]
 
Soybean Prices Await Weather
Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly higher amid conflicting weekend rain forecasts for parched growing areas in the Midwest. "If we don't have rain, prices will be sharply higher Monday," one analyst predicted. "If we do, they'll be sharply lower." [45.]
 
Air Crash Halts I.P.O.
After the crash of one of its cargo planes, Fine Air Services scrapped its two-day-old offering of stock to the public. Investors who bought shares will be reimbursed. [36.]
 
Injunction in Nursing Home Deal
Grancare Inc. said it would appeal a preliminary court injunction issued on Thursday against its proposed $1.7 billion merger with Living Centers of America. [36.]
 
Suitor for Ritz-Carlton Orphans?
ITT Sheraton is said to be looking into making a bid to manage the four hotels with which Ritz-Carlton terminated its management agreements a week ago. [37.]

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
Lawyer Is Accused of Fraud

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
While collecting unemployment after leaving his job at a Parsippany law firm in 1992, a lawyer from Pound Ridge, N.Y., illegally earned at least $58,000, prosecutors said.
The lawyer, Robert Barry Green, 42, was charged with fraud in Federal court yesterday. He was accused of earning more than $8,000 in consulting fees from the law firm of Weiner Lesniak and more than $50,000 in real estate commissions from a corporation he owned with the law firm's partners in 1992 and 1993, said Noel L. Hillman, an assistant United States attorney. 
 One of those partners is State Senator Raymond J. Lesniak of Elizabeth, a longtime adviser to State Senator James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor.

HEADLINE: Affirmative Action Isn't Issue in Piscataway Case;
O'Connor's Record

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Despite Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's seemingly moderate opinions that appear to allow some racial preferences, her voting record shows not the slightest inclination to do so (front page, Aug. 4). 
 Justice O'Connor has consistently voted against claims of racial minorities. In affirmative action cases, she has ignored her own prior decisions and opinions on access to the courts, federalism and Federal power that would have supported the minority position. Civil rights lawyers expect her to vote against the black teacher in the Piscataway affirmative action case, for they must look to what a judge does, not just what a judge says.
 
HERMAN SCHWARTZ
Washington, Aug. 6, 1997
 
The writer is a law professor at American University.

LENGTH: 1660 words

HEADLINE: SMALL BUSINESSES SUFFER THE MOST FROM U.P.S. STRIKE

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 8

 BODY:
A mechanic in Iowa cannot get parts for car repairs. Pet fish are stranded at a Florida distributor. Cases of wine are stacking up at a mail-order vineyard in California.
The strike against United Parcel Service, which began on Monday, has strained small businesses around the country, especially those on tight schedules or tight profit margins. 
 "It has caused a tremendous crimp in our business," said Christopher Britton, chief financial officer for the Liberty Malt Supply Company, a distributor of home-brew ingredients in Seattle. "It basically cuts our mail-order business, and it will be hard to rejuvenate it if it's a longer strike."
Judging from interviews with people at scores of businesses throughout the United States, from the computer giant Microsoft to the Elbert car lot and repair shop in Whittemore, Iowa, the smaller the business, the bigger the headaches.
Most big businesses, on the other hand, appeared to be weathering the strike more effectively, or at least are conveying that image. Many big businesses, including leading retailers, however, say a prolonged walkout would eventually overwhelm contingency plans and eat up profits.
For now, nothing has slowed the smokestacks at LTV Steel, Inland Steel, U.S. Steel and Amoco. At the Microsoft Corporation, which sends out about 2,500 packages a day, shipping has simply been shifted to other carriers, said Mark Murray, a company spokesman.
"You don't exactly send aircraft engines by U.P.S.," said Mark Greenberg, a spokesman for Allied Signal.
A spokesman for General Electric, Bruce Bunch, said the strike had not registered even a blip on the business screen of the huge company.
"We have other vendors handling our package shipment needs," Mr. Bunch said, "and have seen no significant business impact."
But life without the familiar brown-suited U.P.S. delivery workers has not been so easy for New Meadows Lobsters, a distributor in Portland, Me., with 10 employees.
"This is the high time of the season," said Pete McAleney, the exasperated owner of the wholesale concern. "Tourists come in and want to ship lobsters to friends at home. And now they can't."
After the first full business week without U.P.S., it seemed clear that the biggest companies were being hurt the least by the strike, while many mom-and-pop concerns said they were being stymied.
"We can afford to do this for a few days, but not for a month," said Larry Levi, the general manager of Pacific Coast Products, a 10-employee company in San Francisco that has been hiring more expensive freight trucks to ship its nuts, dried fruit and snacks. "We'll lose our shirts shipping only with trucks."
When it comes to life-and-death concerns, like the delivery of medicine, the strike appears to be posing no serious threat. Pharmaceutical and medical distribution companies typically deliver goods themselves.
"These guys have their own transportation networks, mainly their own trucks," said Larry Marsh, an analyst of drug and medical companies at Salomon Brothers. "I'm not aware of any critical needs being unmet."
Although U.P.S. handles blood products for some companies, most had time to stock up before the strike.
"There was enough lead time," said Lynn Gentry, a spokesman for VHA Inc., a national buyer for 1,500 health care organizations. "The real impact will show up next week" when those supplies run low."
Much of the slack of moving packages was being picked up by the Federal Express Corporation and the United States Postal Service. Express Mail and Priority Mail were running 75 percent above normal levels for this time of year, the Postal Service reported.
"It's beginning to look a lot like Christmas," said Sandra Harding, a spokeswoman at the Postal Service.
Customers at Federal Express were being told that nothing could be promised. Shirlee Clark, a spokeswoman for Federal Express, said the crushing demands had "approached the peak holiday season" of 4 million packages a day. The usual volume is 2.8 million a day, Ms. Clark said.
Federal Express has said it will limit pickup service on Saturday to catch up on deliveries. The Postal Service said parcels in some places would be delivered at no extra charge on Sunday if the strike continued.
Donald Ratajczak, the head of economic forecasting at Georgia State University, said, "About half the packages in the United States are not moving right now."
Coming in August rather than autumn, the strike is occurring at a relatively good time, economists say.
"August is a good time for a strike, because there is not a lot of stuff being done," said David Wyss, research director at DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic consulting company.
David J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, suggested that the strike could ultimately affect wage rates.
"This is the first major strike we have had in some time," Mr. Fine said, "and it could have an impact on wage settlements going down the road."
He added, "You could make a case that it could be a bellwether for union wage demands and pressures over the upcoming period."
For retailers, it seems clear that the strike has started to nibble on profits, even if only marginally, and that costs could rise for the quarter if the strike goes unresolved for weeks.
A spokeswoman at the Kmart Corporation, Shawn M. Kahle, said increases of 10 percent to 15 percent in alternative shipping for some items represents "a small dot on the expense line for now."
Retailers have characterized the effect of the strike in seemingly irreconcilable ways. On one hand, many retail executives were quick to tell customers to expect business as usual -- at worst, the strike would delay packages by a few days. But over 30 retail executives signed a letter to President Clinton warning that "the ramifications of the strike are alarming," and urging him to intervene.
The consequences seem much more dire for companies like Hatco, a maker of cowboy hats in Garland, Tex. With boxes of cowboy hats piling up, the company has cut back its manufacturing operation to a four-day week. And it could be forced to start laying off workers.
"If the strike continues, it's going to shut us down," said Al Luiz, vice president of Hatco, which relies on U.P.S. to move 90 percent of its daily shipment of 300 to 400 packages.
If the strike drags on and shipping difficulties worsen, the small businesses that depend on U.P.S. could face serious problems. Altogether, small businesses account for more than 50 percent of all jobs.
Many smaller companies, unable to ship inventory, are beginning to run out of storage space.
The shelves of Jam Plastics, a family-run plastics maker in Anaheim, Calif., are filled with a backlog of about 80 boxes that should have been delivered days ago.
"Usually, there is nothing on the shelves," said Bruce Buettell, a company vice president.
Before long, Mr. Buettell added, workers will need to lay pallets on the floor to store more unshipped products, like security badge holders and neck chains.
The company has tried to send out orders through the Postal Service. But that means taking a worker off the production line and having him drive to the post office, rather than simply waiting for pickup service.
"You know, the President stopped the American Airlines strike," said Cirilio Vazquez, the company's production supervisor. "Why can't he stop the U.P.S. strike?"
Even at some larger companies, a long strike could pose problems.
"So far we've been O.K.," said a spokesman for the Xerox Corporation. "But the consensus is that if this strike goes on much longer, things will really get difficult."
Difficulties are mounting at some companies. Textron Inc., for example, switched early this week to Federal Express, Airborne, and other carriers to ship electrical tools, watch bands and the handful of other products that it sells through retail outlets like Home Depot or Wal-Mart.
But a company spokeswoman, Susan Gillette, said those carriers were starting to get backlogged.
"It started taking two days to deliver a package marked, 'Urgent, Same Day Delivery!" Ms. Gillette said, adding that Federal Express and Airborne were now telling customers to expect three-day delays soon.
"Our customers understand that it is not our fault," she said, "but they are frustrated."
The strike stranded nearly 10,000 fish, bound for pet shops around the nation, at the L Segrest fish distributor near Tampa, Fla., "Swedish Erota XXX" tapes had yet to arrive at the Varsity Adult Video store in Lakeland. And the Kathleen High School band was concerned that its marching shoes would not arrive in time for the school's first football game in September.
The strike was even holding up sporting gear for professional baseball teams. When the Baltimore Orioles flew from Montreal to Seattle this week, their bats were supposed to be shipped along. They were not.
Brady Anderson, star centerfielder for the Orioles, went to Oliver Roy, shipping manager for the Seattle Mariners, and asked for a bat.
"I don't have it," Mr. Roy had to tell him.
The center-fielder did not stop looking for a bat.
"Brady beat us with an 11th-inning homer," Mr. Roy said, "so obviously they have bats."
The M. Putterman Recreational Company, which makes recreation equipment, including tennis and volleyball nets, has school systems as clients that cannot afford to wait.
The strike has taught a lesson to Janis and Jon Moran, the owners of Moran Design in Hammond, Ind.
"Use more than one delivery company," Mrs. Moran said.
At Big Sky Balloons and Searchlights in the Chicago suburb of Plainfield, a 15-foot inflatable rubber rat has been trapped. It was supposed to be shipped to New York earlier this week, said Kathryn Bertram, who works at Big Sky. The giant rodent was to be used to mock strike-breakers and nonunion companies.
"But we couldn't ship the rat to the union," Ms. Bertram said, "because of the strike."

LENGTH: 4250 words

HEADLINE: The Fall and Rise Of Kilmer McCully

BYLINE: By Michelle Stacey; Michelle Stacey is the author of "Consumed: Why Americans Love, Hate, and Fear Food."

 BODY:
In 1981, when kilmer mccully started commuting from his home in a boston suburb to a new job in Providence, R.I., he would drive past the domed Rhode Island Capitol. High atop the dome stands a statue called "The Independent Man" -- a representation of Roger Williams, the Puritan founder of Providence. "Because of Williams's religious beliefs, he was thrown out of Boston," McCully says now. "It sounded familiar." McCully, too, felt like an outcast when he went to Providence from Boston, though he was a scientific rather than a religious infidel. He had left appointments at Harvard Medical School and Massachusetts General Hospital under a cloud, told that his research had dead-ended. He had been denounced by some fellow scientists and ignored by others. His research grants had withered away. He took refuge in a pathology job far from the fast track at the Providence Veterans Administration Medical Center.
These are distinctly better days for McCully, who is now 63. His lifetime's study of a little-understood trigger for heart disease is suddenly at the forefront of cardiac research. His theory -- the same one that came close to scuttling his career -- holds that homocysteine, an amino acid in the blood, damages artery walls and causes heart attacks, and that in most cases homocysteine can easily be lowered to safe levels by taking certain common vitamins. If he's right, homocysteine could join cholesterol, smoking and high blood pressure as a major culprit of heart disease, accounting for (and perhaps someday preventing) upward of 10 to 15 percent of all cases. For an illness that kills nearly 1,500 Americans a day, these are serious numbers. 
 Homocysteine is the theory of the moment in a notoriously competitive field, and McCully's name is inextricably tied to its ascent. He has been called "the father of homocysteine" at meetings of leading international figures in cardiology and epidemiology. His book, "The Homocysteine Revolution: Medicine for the New Millennium," was published in May. Where once McCully's was almost a lone voice in homocysteine research, now dozens of articles have appeared in scientific journals, including one a few weeks ago in The New England Journal of Medicine. Where once the theory was shunned by the grant-giving powers that be, the National Institutes of Health recently put out a request for applications for further research, and at least one large-scale study of homocysteine in humans is already under way.
While McCully says he is "grateful" and "thrilled" that his work is being appreciated, there is a bittersweet quality to his current success and to his anointment as an innovator. A personality more prone to might-have-beens would find it easy to dwell on the contrast between his present situation and that of more than 20 years ago -- another moment when accolades and recognition seemed almost within reach. But beyond the issue of McCully's halted career, those concerned about heart disease -- the nation's No. 1 cause of death -- might wonder, what took so long?
 The son of two schoolteachers, McCully grew up in Colorado as a self-described "boy scientist." After graduating from Harvard College and Harvard Medical School, he embarked on a series of research fellowships. In the mid-60's, as a young pathology instructor at Harvard, McCully made the scientific observation that would define his career. He became intrigued by two different cases of children with homocystinuria, a rare genetic disease in which the levels of homocysteine in the blood are unnaturally high. In both cases, the cause of death was severe arteriosclerosis, a narrowing and loss of elasticity in arteries that is normally seen only in the elderly. By re-examining the autopsy tissues of both children and drawing on previous animal research, McCully emerged with two linked and provocative suggestions: perhaps homocysteine directly damages the cells and tissues of the arteries, in much the way that cholesterol is thought to do, and perhaps that damage occurs not just in these rare genetic cases but in the population at large, in any people with elevated homocysteine levels.
He soon expanded his theory to include a probable cause of elevated levels of homocysteine: a deficiency of vitamins B6, B12 and folic acid. When these vitamins were administered to animals with high homocysteine levels, those levels plummeted, often within hours. Once McCully started extrapolating from his cellular-tissue and animal studies to the human situation, he says, "it all began to fit together."
Homocysteine in the body derives from methionine, an essential amino acid present in large amounts in protein from animal sources like meat, eggs and milk. If there are adequate levels of vitamins B6, B12 and folic acid in the body, the homocysteine is broken down into harmless waste products or protein building blocks. But if there's a deficiency of those vitamins, the homocysteine begins its ravages on the blood vessels.
What, then, is the diet most likely to lead to heart disease, according to the homocysteine theory? One high in animal protein and low in B-vitamins, which occur in many foods but are very easily destroyed by processing -- a diet of meat, cheese, milk, white flour and foods that are canned, boxed, refined, processed or preserved. The American diet, in other words.
Here was a strong connection between diet and heart disease, but one that took a different path from cholesterol. The homocysteine theory considers arteriosclerosis a disease of what McCully calls "protein intoxication." The cholesterol theory (sometimes called the lipid theory) instead demonizes fats. Since proteins and fats often occur in the same foods, the potential dietary treatments for high homocysteine and high cholesterol are similar, with this distinction: the anti-homocysteine diet focuses on what should be eaten, as a preventive, while the anti-cholesterol diet focuses on what should be avoided, as a precipitator. Thus, a diet of lower homocysteine would include many natural sources of B-vitamins like fresh fruits and vegetables and would limit animal protein. The cholesterol-reducing diet would limit foods high in saturated fats and cholesterol, like eggs, meat and butter.
But dietary intervention often fails to lower cholesterol levels, and the next step is drug therapy. A new class of drugs called statins has been more effective than previous drugs at lowering cholesterol with few side effects, but questions have been raised about the safety of long-term use. No clinical consensus on how to treat high homocysteine has yet emerged, but most researchers say that the logical course is simply to take a multivitamin. Studies suggest an optimal daily intake of 3 to 3.5 milligrams of B6, 350 to 400 micrograms of folic acid and 5 to 15 micrograms of B12; many multivitamins contain these amounts.
"For the first few years, everywhere I turned I got evidence that the basic idea was correct," McCully recalls. He injected rabbits with homocysteine and within weeks found arteriosclerotic plaques in their coronary arteries. If the animals were also given a diet deficient in vitamin B6, the plaques were more widespread. While others conducted similar experiments with baboons, McCully examined and manipulated cell cultures from children with homocystinuria. Two Australian researchers, Bridget and David Wilcken, published the first human study in 1976, showing a possible connection between coronary heart disease and high elevations of blood homocysteine.
Then, in the mid-70's, the homocysteine theory began to lose momentum. McCully believes that his support at Harvard and Mass. General began to flag after his department chief and mentor, Benjamin Castleman, retired in 1974. Castleman, who died in 1982, had helped review McCully's findings, sponsored him for lectures and showcased his work before a prestigious panel of experts.
Under the new chief, Robert T. McCluskey, this backing eroded. He was moved to an inferior laboratory in the basement, he lost staffers and his N.I.H. funding was running out. "With the changes in my lab and the loss of some key collaborators, it was difficult to come up with new ideas," he says. "I felt very cut off from everybody, and there was no encouragement. Then they told me that if I didn't renew my grant, I would definitely be out. Their view, I suppose, was that I was no longer productive. My view was that I was being discouraged at every turn."
McCluskey, who is no longer the department head, now says that the key issue was money. "It's certainly true that, perhaps because his idea at that time wasn't generally accepted, he wasn't able to get funding for research after his grants ran out," he says. "There was some uncertainty at the time about how important his work was. Anyone doing research at Mass. General has to apply for and eventually succeed in getting outside funding, and McCully was unable -- in fact, unwilling -- to do that. He wanted the department to support him, which wasn't possible on a long-term basis. So he was asked to either attempt to get further support or to leave."
McCully acknowledges that he eventually did give up on obtaining another N.I.H. grant. "My enthusiasm had been drained," he says. "In that atmosphere, and because I hadn't generated a lot of new information, I felt it was hopeless to apply for a new grant -- that I wouldn't get it." But he denies that he asked the pathology department to support his research. "I'd already been told by the director of the hospital that it was felt at Harvard that I had not proven my theory," he says. "In fact, when I left he told me never to come back."
The current chief of pathology at Mass. General, Robert Colvin, agrees with his predecessor that "the main issue was that nobody could fund McCully's research," but he emphasizes the funders' short-sightedness. "McCully was so far advanced in his thinking about the biochemistry," Colvin says. "And N.I.H. is not very good at funding very innovative, creative research. They're better at funding natural extensions of existing theories."
Since Mass. General and Harvard appointments go hand in hand and McCully had not been recommended for tenure at Harvard, both jobs formally ended in January 1979. At about the same time, a former classmate at Harvard who went on to become the director of the Arteriosclerosis Center at M.I.T. attacked his ideas as "errant nonsense" and a "hoax that is being perpetrated on the public." McCully says that when he was interviewed on Canadian television after he left Harvard, he received a call from the public-affairs director of Mass. General. "He told me to shut up," McCully recalls. "He said he didn't want the names of Harvard and Mass. General associated with my theories."
In retrospect, it seems clear that McCully was a man ahead of his time when the times were all about cholesterol. "Kilmer McCully's hypothesis seemed to challenge the cholesterol-heart hypothesis, which was riding high," says Irwin Rosenberg, director of the U.S.D.A. Human Nutrition Research Center on Aging at Tufts University. Rosenberg was a medical-school classmate of McCully's and, briefly, a physician in Mass. General's department of medicine when McCully was in the department of pathology. "Because his work was not in vogue," Rosenberg says, "his insistence on what he was doing contributed to costing him his job."
Thomas N. James, a cardiologist and president of the University of Texas Medical Branch who was also the president of the American Heart Association in 1979 and '80, is even harsher. "It was worse than that you couldn't get ideas funded that went in other directions than cholesterol," he says. "You were intentionally discouraged from pursuing alternative questions. I've never dealt with a subject in my life that elicited such an immediate hostile response."
It took two years for McCully to find a new research job. His children were reaching college age; he and his wife refinanced their house and borrowed from her parents. McCully says that his job search developed a pattern: he would hear of an opening, go for interviews and then the process would grind to a stop. Finally, he heard rumors of what he calls "poison phone calls" from Harvard. "It smelled to high heaven," he says. "Eventually I went to an attorney friend of mine, someone quite prominent in Boston. He made a few phone calls and it was all over. Then this job came through."
The story of those two scary, free-fall years -- McCully can still recite the exact dates, Jan. 1, 1979, to March 15, 1981 -- emerges in small details, teased out by questioning. This is not a man who eagerly lays his grievances on the table. "My daughter told me recently that she still gets nightmares about that time," he says. Later, describing his son's and daughter's careers as, respectively, Wall Street banker and magazine editor, he remarks: "They both had been interested in chemistry when they were younger. Then they saw what happened to me" -- he barks a laugh -- "and that was the last I ever heard about that."
McCully also laughs with seeming good grace about the contrast between his present position and that of medical-school classmates like Irwin Rosenberg, "the director of the nutrition institute at Tufts, with a multimillion-dollar budget and all these projects." But from his much more modest perch at the Providence V.A. lab, he says, "I've been able to develop my own approach, which might not have been possible at a high-powered place."
 When McCully landed in Providence, he continued testing his theories, inducing arteriosclerosis in rabbits, observing homocysteine's effect on cancer cells and publishing his first monograph, an overview of the homocysteine theory. At the same time, a study at Cornell and several others in Europe -- in Sweden, Norway, the Netherlands and Ireland -- explored the workings of homocysteine in humans. By 1990, some of those results were beginning to pique fresh interest in the United States, and Meir Stampfer, a professor of epidemiology and nutrition at the Harvard School of Public Health, decided to take a look at homocysteine in members of the Physicians Health Study, an ongoing survey of almost 15,000 doctors. Stampfer's findings helped start the current surge in homocysteine research.
Using blood samples taken years before any of the physicians in the study developed heart disease, Stampfer and his colleagues found that homocysteine levels were directly correlated to heart-disease risk. "The study represented something of a turning point in the field," Stampfer says, "because it was the first time we had prospective data -- the men were healthy at the time the blood was drawn and some later became ill -- and also because the homocysteine levels were all basically in the normal range. Even within that range, being at the top was strongly predictive of heart disease."
Other powerful evidence soon followed. Jacob Selhub, a senior scientist and colleague of Irwin Rosenberg's at Tufts, looked at another large ongoing human sample, the Framingham Study, which has documented the population of Framingham, Mass., for nearly 50 years. Selhub found a strong association between homocysteine in the blood and insufficient levels of vitamins B6, B12 and folic acid. "We showed that 30 percent of the American population is not taking in enough folic acid," Selhub says. "And, at least in Framingham, close to 30 percent of the population has high homocysteine." Next, Selhub observed the relationship between homocysteine levels and narrowing, or stenosis, of the carotid artery. He found another correlation.
"The higher the homocysteine in the blood, the higher the prevalence of stenosis," Selhub says. "We also showed that people with low intake of folic acid and vitamin B6 have a higher chance of having stenosis in the carotid artery. That was very important and exciting -- that practically tells you that we might be able to prevent this if our folic acid intake was sufficient." Both of Selhub's articles on these landmark studies, which appeared in The Journal of the American Medical Association and The New England Journal of Medicine in 1993 and 1995 respectively, cited McCully's original 1969 article on homocysteine and arteriosclerosis in the very first sentence.
The homocysteine theory was back in business, and McCully with it. Even old-line supporters of the cholesterol theory now acknowledge that homocysteine is, if not entirely proven, an extremely promising area of research. "There's no question that homocysteine is a very important issue," says Claude Lenfant, director of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, which some scientists consider a kind of ground zero for the cholesterol camp.
"Even if only 10 percent of the risk of heart disease is explained by homocysteine," Rosenberg says, "you're talking about a huge element of the process of the disease -- and a lot of people. Forty-plus studies have so far observed a relationship between higher homocysteine levels and the risk of different kinds of vascular disease."
McCully appears to be enjoying the flowering of homocysteine with a minimum of bitterness. "Any scientist wants to have his work confirmed, wants to make a place for himself in the scientific literature," he says. "I thought it was great that these big shots were paying attention to it." Lenfant suggests that perhaps they would have paid more attention earlier if the cholesterol theory had been less divisive. "Twenty-five years ago, not everybody was accepting the cholesterol business," he says. "So who wanted to hear about something that perhaps would weaken the argument for cholesterol?"
 The cholesterol theory of heart disease, Thomas James says, "has been a favorite theory for 50 years." It holds, essentially, that high levels of cholesterol in the blood cause arteriosclerosis and heart disease and that lowering those levels will lower the risk of heart disease. But while it was easy to show that very high cholesterol was associated with a high risk of heart disease, it was harder to show how it caused heart disease, or whether reducing it would reduce heart disease. Recent studies have firmed up those relationships, according to Lenfant, who says, "Now the cholesterol story is as solid as the Rock of Gibraltar."
But there continue to be indications that the cholesterol story is extremely complex and sometimes contradictory. For instance, Stampfer says, "the majority of heart attacks occur in individuals with 'normal' cholesterol. That does not mean that cholesterol is not important, but it tells us that there are other mechanisms."
It has not always been easy to propose other mechanisms, perhaps because the cholesterol proponents themselves felt somewhat embattled. Throughout the 70's and early 80's, agencies like the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute and the American Heart Association were gearing up for major public health initiatives that culminated in the National Cholesterol Education Program begun in 1985, and the advocates for those agencies felt that a united front was essential.
Even as recently as last year, Alan Garber, an associate professor of medicine at Stanford University, was stunned after he and a colleague, Warren Browner, proposed that healthy young men and women need not be screened for cholesterol, since treatment at young ages has not been shown to be useful or cost effective. "The American Heart Association and the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute issued press releases and had a big campaign to discredit our work," Garber says.
McCully stresses that his ideas do not dismiss cholesterol as a risk factor, but they do question its hegemony. "Cholesterol is important, certainly," McCully says. "But the cholesterol theory isn't really a theory -- it's a collection of observations." He says his own theory suggests that "homocysteine might be the underlying cause of arteriosclerosis, that homocysteine damage sets the stage for cholesterol buildup in the arteries. I think altered homocysteine metabolism and biochemistry is at the heart of vascular disease.
"But," he adds with a laugh and a flash of self-knowledge, "working in this field all these years, naturally I feel that way."
As McCully knows well, history is crowded with examples of ostrich-like behavior among medical researchers. There was strong resistance for years to the idea that many ulcers are caused by a bacteria rather than stress -- a theory that was ridiculed until the evidence finally became too strong to dismiss.
The American scientific establishment's answer to such human foibles as stubbornness, arrogance and the unwillingness to let go of favored theories has been peer review. The peer-review system in research tries to be equitable by having panels of experts judge grant proposals and articles submitted to the medical journals. But even a process that has objectivity as its goal is vulnerable to the pitfalls of committee-think.
"For instance," Rosenberg says, "if most of the people on the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute's advisory council come out of the lipid-fat-cholesterol camp and there's no one from, say, a nutritional orientation, it's not as likely that an expensive study will get the same hearing if it's looking at a homocysteine-lowering intervention versus a cholesterol-lowering intervention."
James believes that as long as the management of the Heart, Lung and Blood Institute espouses the cholesterol line, "then the review committees, the other evaluating bodies, are going to be influenced -- not by written memoranda but by the environment and by word of mouth."
But James sees an even bigger reason for cholesterol's dominance of the heart-disease debate: "It's the money that's the problem. Look at the colorful advertisements in general-interest publications, explaining to grandfather that his grandchildren want him to stay alive using these drugs. The anti-cholesterol medications are multibillion-dollar industries now, and they have a huge stake in fanning the flames of the cholesterol mission."
Charles Hennekens, a professor at Harvard Medical School and chief of preventive medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital, cites the example of aspirin. "For years now, we've known about these large benefits of aspirin in treating acute heart attacks and survivors of heart attacks, and yet we have underutilization of it," he says. "At an F.D.A. advisory committee meeting recently, I joked that if aspirin were half as effective, 10 times as expensive and on prescription, maybe people would take it more seriously."
Like aspirin, the vitamins that control homocysteine levels are readily available, inexpensive and nonexclusive. "It's inescapable that there's just not the commercial interest for supporting research in homocysteine," Stampfer says, "because nobody's going to make money on it."
McCully takes this follow-the-money approach to its logical conclusion: who stands to gain? "The most dramatic improvements in longevity over the last couple of hundred years have been through public health, not through medicine," he says. "But public health is notoriously unprofitable. People don't make a profit preventing disease. They make a profit through medicine -- treating critical, advanced stages of disease."
 Although there's not much money to be made from doctors prescribing vitamins and offering dietary guidelines to heart-disease patients, corporate wheels are already turning to make homocysteine levels the latest, hottest measure of optimal health. A new TV commericial for Centrum multivitamins singles out folic acid because it "may help reduce homocysteine levels in the blood, an emerging risk factor for heart disease." McCully says that Abbott Laboratories has developed a test for homocysteine, though he feels it is inadequate. "Once we develop a better test," he says, "I would like to think that the vast majority of heart patients, far greater than the current estimates of 10 to 15 percent, will show this striking elevation in homocysteine."
Such confirmation may come years from now, and McCully realizes that he may not play a role in it. "Generally speaking, a scientist makes one contribution and then everybody else takes over and it becomes extremely competitive," he says. It is only when pressed about the past that McCully reveals, briefly, the shadow of disappointment that must have loomed larger two decades ago. "Last October," he says, "the pathology department at Mass. General had a reunion and invited me, and I saw one of the people involved in my leaving the department. 'Well,' he said to me, 'it looks like you were right after all.' It's 20 years later. My career is almost over. There's really not much that can be done about 20 lost years, is there?"
Worse, the political and economic forces that undid McCully back then may be more intense today. Last April, The New England Journal of Medicine published an article titled "The Messenger Under Attack -- Intimidation of Researchers by Special-Interest Groups," which detailed three cases of harassment by advocacy groups, physicians' associations or academic consultants who often failed to disclose their ties to drug companies. With more and more pressure groups weighing in on what research gets financed and promoted, the article said, "such attacks may become more frequent and acrimonious."

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Man With a Van

BYLINE: By John Tierney 

 BODY:
Vincent Cummins looks out from his van with the wary eyes of a hardened criminal. It is quiet this evening in downtown Brooklyn . . . too quiet.
"Watch my back for me!" he barks into the microphone of his C.B. radio, addressing a fellow outlaw in a van who just drove by him on Livingston Street. He looks left and right. No police cars in sight. None of the usual unmarked cars, either. Cummins pauses for a second -- he has heard on the C.B. that cops have just busted two other drivers -- but he can't stop himself. "Watch my back!" he repeats into the radio as he ruthlessly pulls over to the curb. 
 Five seconds later, evil triumphs. A middle-aged woman with a shopping bag climbs into the van . . . and Cummins drives off with impunity! His new victim and the other passengers laugh when asked why they're riding this illegal jitney. What fool would pay $1.50 to stand on the bus or subway when you're guaranteed a seat here for $1? Unlike bus drivers, the van drivers make change and accept bills, and the vans run more frequently at every hour of the day. "It takes me an hour to get home if I use the bus," explains Cynthia Peters, a nurse born in Trinidad. "When I'm working late, it's very scary waiting in the dark for the bus and then walking the three blocks home. With Vincent's van, I get home in less than half an hour. He takes me right to the door and waits until I get inside."
Cummins would prefer not to be an outlaw. A native of Barbados, he has been driving his van full time ever since an injury forced him to give up his job as a machinist. "I could be collecting disability," he says, "but it's better to work." He met Federal requirements to run an interstate van service, then spent years trying to get approval to operate in the city. His application, which included more than 900 supporting statements from riders, business groups and church leaders, was approved by the City Taxi and Limousine Commission as well as by the Department of Transportation. Mayor Giuliani supported him. But this summer the City Council rejected his application for a license, as it has rejected most applications over the past four years, which is why thousands of illegal drivers in Brooklyn and Queens are dodging the police.
Council members claim they're trying to prevent vans from causing accidents and traffic problems, although no one who rides the vans takes these protestations seriously. Vans with accredited and insured drivers like Cummins are no more dangerous or disruptive than taxis. The only danger they pose is to the public transit monopoly, whose union leaders have successfully led the campaign against them.
The van drivers have refuted two modern urban myths: that mass transit must lose money and that it must be a public enterprise. Entrepreneurs like Cummins are thriving today in other cities -- Seoul and Buenos Aires rely entirely on private, profitable bus companies -- and they once made New York the world leader in mass transit. The first horsecars and elevated trains were developed here by private companies. The first subway was partly financed with a loan from the city, but it was otherwise a private operation, built and run quite profitably with the fare set at a nickel -- the equivalent of less than a dollar today.
Eventually, though, New York's politicians drove most private transit companies out of business by refusing to adjust the fare for inflation. When the enterprises lost money in the 1920's, Mayor John Hylan offered to teach them efficient management. If the city ran the subway, he promised, it would make money while preserving the nickel fare and freeing New Yorkers from "serfdom" and the "dictatorship" of the "grasping transportation monopolies." But expenses soared as soon as government merged the private systems into a true monopoly. The fare, which remained a nickel through seven decades of private transit, has risen 2,900 percent under public management -- and today the Metropolitan Transportation Authority still manages to lose about $2 per ride. Meanwhile, a jitney driver can provide better service at lower prices and still make a profit.
"Transit could be profitable again if entrepreneurs are given a chance," says Daniel B. Klein, an economist at Santa Clara University in California and the co-author of "Curb Rights," a new book from the Brookings Institution on mass transit. "Government has demonstrated that it has no more business producing transit than producing cornflakes. It should concentrate instead on establishing new rules to foster competition." To encourage private operators to make a long-term investment in regular service along a route, the Brookings researchers recommend selling them exclusive "curb rights" to pick up passengers waiting at certain stops along the route. That way part-time opportunists couldn't swoop in to steal regular customers from a long-term operator. But to encourage competition, at other corners along the route there should also be common stops where passengers could be picked up by any licensed jitney or bus.
Elements of this system already exist where jitneys have informally established their own stops separate from the regular buses, but the City Council is trying to eliminate these competitors. Besides denying licenses to new drivers like Cummins, the Council has forbidden veteran drivers with licenses to operate on bus routes. Unless these restrictions are overturned in court -- a suit on the drivers' behalf has been filed by the Institute for Justice, a public-interest law firm in Washington -- the vans can compete only by breaking the law. At this very moment, despite the best efforts of the police and the Transport Workers Union, somewhere in New York a serial predator like Cummins is luring another unsuspecting victim. He may even be making change for a $5 bill.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: August 10, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Big City column on page 22 of The Times Magazine today describes the operation of Vincent Cummins, a van driver in Brooklyn. It reports that the City Council denied him a license to operate a commuter service in Brooklyn.
Mayor Giuliani vetoed the Council's action, and last week, after the Magazine had gone to press, the Council compromised by authorizing Mr. Cummins to pick up passengers by prearrangement. Mr. Cummins and other drivers are still suing for the right to compete with the M.T.A. along bus routes.
