HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
In the Suburbs, Steel Rises Again

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
AFTER being on the endangered-species list in recent years, construction cranes are being spotted on suburban horizons again. Office buildings custom built for corporate customers are rising in Westchester and Fairfield Counties, and in New Jersey speculative development is under way for the first time in a decade.
"The oversupply of office space lasted from 1989 to 1995, but now it is time to build again," said Steven J. Pozycki, whose SJP Properties is completing an eight-story, 240,000-square-foot office building in Bridgewater, N.J., and preparing to start another in a planned six-building office park at the Somerset County location. The development, across Route 202-206 from the 1.1 million-square-foot Bridgewater Commons shopping mall, is 3.5 miles south of the intersection of Interstates 78 and 287. 
 "When you see rents at $30 a foot and break-even is $24 a foot, you have to be crazy not to build," said Cary Heller, who is planning to break ground in September for a 110,000-square-foot office building in East Hanover, N.J., in a joint venture with his uncle, Gene Heller.
The building, called Eagle Rock III after a nearby road, is another example of the way New Jersey is defined by the interchange. A big selling point for the location is that nearby Edwards Road, which has limited access to Interstate 280, has been approved by highway authorities for a full four-way interchange with the highway.
"New Jersey is the most dynamic market in the region because its communities are less restrictive than places like Long Island," said Donald Eisen, a senior managing director with Cushman & Wakefield. "We are seeing buildings coming out of the ground and markets that were left for dead that couldn't be hotter."
Not all the building is in New Jersey. In Stamford, Conn., where there are still vacant lots downtown from the end of the last wave of building, a trading pavilion and office tower that are the major parts of what is eventually to be a 1.2 million square-foot complex are being completed for Swiss Bank Corporation. The bank is preparing to leave its current location at 222 Broadway in lower Manhattan early next year.
In Westchester County, I.B.M. is finishing a new headquarters building on its existing property in Armonk. The three-story, 280,000-square-foot building, near the current headquarters, is designed to house about 600 people compared to the 900 that could be accommodated by the existing 400,000-square-foot structure. An I.B.M. spokesman said it had not yet been decided what will be done with the older building.
Across Route 120 from I.B.M., land is being cleared for a 313,000-square-foot headquarters building for Swiss Re America, a leading reinsurance company. Real estate executives said this was the first new corporate headquarters building to go up in Westchester County since Texaco moved there over 20 years ago.
Other projects in Westchester have been approved, even though the developers are not ready to put a spade in the ground. Louis Dreyfus Property Group, a subsidiary of a French commodities trading company, has approval for a 313,980-square-foot office complex near Interstate 684 in Goldens Bridge.
But brokers say corporate relocations and skittish lenders are holding back development in the suburbs to the north and northeast of New York. "There's lots of talk, but not a whole lot of action," said Gerard Hallock, a broker with ESG/Rostenberg-Doern, who specializes in Fairfield County. "To get financing, you have to have a building at least 50 percent preleased."
He said the office market in the area was not helped by the decision of a major employer, the GTE Corporation, to transfer its headquarters to Dallas. Others noted that Pepsico's decision to sell its 500,000-square-foot building in Somers to consolidate at its headquarters in Purchase added further uncertainly to the market.
A survey by ESG/Rostenberg-Doern found that because of corporate transfers and downsizings, the vacancy rate in Westchester actually rose during the year, from 16.5 percent at the end of the first quarter to 17 percent at the end of the second.
On Long Island, rents have not risen to a level that would justify new construction, said Scott Rechler, chief operating officer of Reckson Associates Realty Group, a real estate investment trust based in Melville. "We have been busy doing redevelopment while we wait for rents to make new development possible," he said.
Most developers on Long Island have been through several up and down cycles and are wary of plunging in too soon with new construction, said Theodore P. Sasso, a senior managing director with Insignia/ ESG. "There is a unique situation on Long Island compared to the rest of the state," he said. "All the building here is done by local developers, rather than regional or national companies, and local developers tend to be conservative."
HE said the fundamentals of the office market, shrinking concessions packages and rising effective rents, were moving in the right direction and "there has been a fair amount of activity in land sales, so there is a good base of approved sites."
"All we are waiting for is for someone to pull the trigger," Mr. Sasso said.
William E. Greiner, president of Greiner-Maltz Company, a brokerage concern that specializes in Long Island, noted that development of office buildings on the island had been inhibited by the need to absorb 1 million square feet of office space abandoned by Grumman as the company was reduced in size. He said activity on the industrial side of the business has been picking up as companies expanded their warehouse-distribution facilities or built new ones.
"I can think of half a dozen new projects off the top of my head and I'm sure I could find more if I went through files," he said. "The point is that for the first time since 1985-1986, we have seen the return of an industrial construction market."
If Reckson has been reticent in its home market, it has been active in New Jersey, where the REIT purchased a trophy property, the undeveloped portion of Giralda Farms, 188 acres of land in Madison Borough and Chatham Township near I-287. The site is currently zoned to permit the building of 1.1 million square feet of office space. Sections of the site that were developed previously are the home of headquarters for the American Home Products, Schering-Plough and Atlantic Mutual companies.
Mark Schaevitz, the managing director of Reckson's operations in New Jersey, said the company would take its time deciding how to develop the site, which he described as "the prettiest piece of ground I've ever seen." He said the company was not prepared to build on the site on a purely speculative basis.
"We are beginning the process of design and securing an anchor tenant, before we start to build," he said. Other real estate executives said that getting permission to build may be a difficult one in affluent Chatham Township, where many residents value the meadows and trees on the site more than any tax revenues new building might bring.
About 10 miles north of Madison, Reckson is doing a completely speculative redevelopment with an existing building once occupied by BASF Corporation at the intersection of Route 3 and the Garden State Parkway. "We are taking that 180,000-square-foot building in Clifton and stripping it down to the structural steel," Mr. Schaevitz said. "We are going to convert it from a commercial use to Class A office and it has not been preleased."
He said he expected that the improvements to the building and its location near important highways would make it attractive to office customers.
The fundamentals of the New Jersey office market appear to support new building ventures. According to a survey by Julien J. Studley Inc., vacancy rates in the northern and central parts of the state have dropped sharply in the last year, from 15.1 percent in the second quarter of 1996 to 9.6 percent in the same period this year.
Because of the sharp drop in real estate values in the early 1990's, when developers lost control of projects and banks lost large parts of their loans, lenders have been reluctant to finance new construction, leading to increased bidding for existing space. The Studley survey found that "free rent is virtually nonexistent" and that allowances for building interiors for tenants are half or less of what was offered two years ago.
Mr. Pozycki said the building SJP is completing in Bridgewater is 98 percent leased, and the company is prepared to start on another 240,000-square-foot structure in October. In all, he said, he has approvals to build 1.5 million square feet of space at the site, where the buildings will be set in an array around a five-acre park complete with a pond and fountain. He said his Somerset Corporate Center and other office projects that are under way represent relatively modest additions to the state's large base of office space. "New Jersey is the fourth largest commercial office building market in the nation when you are looking at properties of 75,000 square feet or more," he said. "It's an enormous market with over 190 million square feet of space."
He said one reason the state was proving more attractive to corporations than Westchester or Fairfield was that it has more diversified housing, which means workers at all income levels are available. "In Westchester and Fairfield, low- and middle-income housing does not exist," he said.
Another important reason is that job growth in New Jersey has outpaced that of New York and Connecticut, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "The economy in New Jersey has revived faster than the rest of the region," he said. "New Jersey has recovered just about all the jobs lost during the recession, while New York and Connecticut recovered about 50 percent."
The privately held SJP kept its head down during the long recession, doing custom buildings for companies like Englehard Corporation in Iselin and holding on to the land it had acquired in more optimistic times. "We have land to develop 10 million square feet of space," Mr. Pozycki said. "It took some heavy lifting to hold on to it during the depression."
Keeping the land and going through the lengthy approval process when it was clear that nothing was going to be built anytime soon was important, Mr. Pozycki said, because it allowed him to react quickly as the market improved.
Indeed, most of the projects now getting under way are completions of undertakings that stopped when corporations downsized in the late 1980's, knocking out the underpinnings of the office market, Mr. Heller observed. His project, which he said was purely speculative, is the unbuilt fourth building of a planned four-building office park whose developer was unable to complete it in the late 1980's.
ONE permanent effect of the recession, he said, is that companies are packing people in more tightly than ever, which is altering the design of buildings and nearby areas. More people means more need for parking spaces in an area where the only commuting option is a motor vehicle.
Mr. Heller said he shrunk the size of the planned building from 120,000 to 110,000 square feet so he could fit in 4.8 parking spaces per 1,000 square feet, up from the planned 4.5. Groundbreaking is now set for Sept. 24. "It's going to be more than ceremonial," he said. "We are going to really move some dirt."
He said the project was being developed as a joint venture between his company, Sym Heller Associates, and G. Heller Enterprises. The senior Mr. Heller was associated for many years with Hartz Mountain development and more recently has been an independent developer.
Speculation in the late 1990's is not quite what it was a decade ago. Cary Heller said the venture was committed only to building the shell of the building. The interiors, he said, will not be constructed until at least one-third of the space has been leased.
Cary Heller said he and other developers were helped by the state's passage of a permit-extension act, which allowed developers to keep their building permits valid without going back to municipalities for extensions. "When you get an approval it is usually good for two years," he said. "When it expires you can go back for a one-year extension and you can only get one of those."
Having land with permits in place helps a developer by letting him bring new product to market before competitors can get under way. "Timing is key," he said. "You have to get into the ground as quickly as possible before contractors start to be less available." He said the building would be ready for interior finishing by June and ready for occupancy in early September 1998.
"Developers are looking for sites that have approvals because you can provide space in nine months to a year compared to as much as three years starting from scratch," said Joseph Romano, a broker with Grubb & Ellis in New Jersey. "We seem to have finally caught up with the glut left over from the 1980's."
Gale & Wentworth is another builder betting on the recovery of the New Jersey office market. It is constructing a four-building office park in Florham Park, near Morristown, and recently acquired 90 acres of land near the intersection of Interstates 80 and 287 in Parsippany to do a six-building, 1.1 million-square-foot development.
Stanley C. Gale, a principal of the firm, said the Florham Park project, scheduled to have 1,148,000 square feet of office space on 138 acres, was only semi-speculative. "We have anchor tenants for three of the four buildings and are negotiating with a potential tenant to lease the entire fourth building," he said. But he said there was space available in the first three buildings.
Mr. Gale said work would start early next year at the site along I-80 in Parsippany and that the company was expecting to put up a 260,000-square-foot office structure in Bedminster, N.J., starting later this year.
Like Mr. Pozycki, Mr. Gale stressed the extent of the office market in New Jersey. In the northern part of the state alone, he said, there is 160 million square feet of occupied space. "All it takes is a 10 percent demand growth, and you are talking about 16 million square feet," he said. He said telecommunications companies like Lucent, AT&T and MCI and pharmaceutical companies like Merck, Johnson & Johnson and American Home Products have been attracted to the state because of its highway and communication networks. The state's highway system is better developed than in the northern suburbs of the city and there is more land available for building, he said.
It is not surprising, therefore, to find that Mr. Gale's projects have strong highway connections. The northern Morris County site in Parsippany has a half mile of frontage on Interstate 80, while the Florham Park tract is flanked by the new, multilane Route 24. The Bedminster building will be near the intersection of Route 206 and I-287.
Industrial markets in the state are stirring as well. Matrix Development Group has acquired an old Phelps Dodge plant next to the New Jersey Turnpike near exit 8A and will enlarge the existing 637,000-square-foot building to a 1.2 million-square-foot warehouse-distribution center, one of the largest in the state, on a speculative basis.
"Industrial markets in New Jersey are among the strongest in the country," said Paul R, Rubincam 3d, a vice president of Matrix. He said vacancy rates for warehouse properties in the central part of the state are less than 8 percent, "and much of the product is functionally obsolete" because of low ceiling heights.
He said that new product-handling equipment allowed warehouse operators to use taller storage racks. "The owners are finding that the cheapest space is cube space," he said. By building taller structures, warehouse owners can handle more product without having to develop more land.
BUT taller warehouses bring stricter technical requirements. "Floors have to be flat to super-flat and capable of bearing heavier loads," he said. When a storage rack is 30 to 35 feet high, he noted, a one-eighth-inch deviation from level at the floor means a major distortion at the top.
Industrial property developers, he said, are starting projects with an eye to the real estate investment trusts that are becoming such important players in the industry. "We are taking the risk of building for markets that may be 18 months to two years out," he said. REITs and other investors prefer to buy existing properties, rather then become developers themselves, he said.
There are other projects in the planning stage that will evidently have to wait for further evidence of the market's strength. Mr. Pozycki speaks enthusiastically about a waterfront office/retail/hotel/residential development in Hoboken, which he calls the "sixth borough" of New York because of its extensive transportation links to the city.
There are other waterfront projects pending as well, including a 12-story, 435,000-square-foot office tower at 90 Hudson Street in Jersey City's Colgate Center and a 758,525-square-foot building by the Lefrak Organization in the city's Newport development. Farther inland, the Rockefeller Group is in discussions to put up a building for Bell Labs in Florham Park.
Mr. Pozycki said the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has spent $80 million to renovate two piers that are part of the Hoboken site, including one that was the site of the film "On the Waterfront." The site, which is just north of the city's railroad terminal, would include 1.1 million square feet of office space, 50,000 square feet of ground floor retail space, a 300-room hotel and 350 to 400 units of luxury apartments.
Mr. Pozycki said he was eager to get started on the development, but his enthusiasm is tempered by reality. "We won't start on a 100 percent speculative basis," he said. "We need to have the office space 30 to 40 percent leased before we go forward."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Miss Neimann and Mr. Porteous

 BODY:
Elizabeth Diane Neimann, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Neimann of Minneapolis, was married on Friday to William Dockery Porteous, the son of Douglas D. Thomas of Salisbury, Conn., and William A. Porteous 3d of New Orleans. The Rev. Anna Carter Florence performed the ceremony at the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Minneapolis.
The bride, 24, and the bridegroom, 25, graduated with honors from Stanford University. 
 She received a master's degree in social policy from Oxford University and is an editorial assistant in the Boston office of the higher-education division of McGraw-Hill. Her father is a partner in Moss & Barnett, a Minneapolis law firm. Her mother, Diane B. Neimann, is the executive vice president of Family Financial Strategies, an investment company in Minneapolis.
The bride's parents are founders of "Westminster Town Hall Forum," a monthly National Public Radio program on ethics.
Mr. Porteous received a master's degree from the London School of Economics and is an associate at Supplyworks, an Internet commerce consultancy in Lexington, Mass. His mother is the chairwoman of Awards Recognizing Individual Artistry, an opera foundation of which she and her husband, Wilmer J. Thomas Jr., are founders. The bridegroom's father is a senior partner in Porteous, Hainkel, Johnson & Sarpy, a New Orleans law firm. The bridegroom is also the stepson of Sylvia Todd Porteous.
